I purchased a MacBook Pro a few months ago and love the laptop computer. I've been an Apple customer since the inception of Macintosh, owning only one PC in my lifetime. I have never purchased an iPad. The [[ASIN:B00HRO3IBA Toshiba Chromebook CB35-A3120 PLM01U-002005 13.3-Inch Cloud Computer]] is Toshiba's first entry into the Chromebook market, my first Chromebook and it did not disappoint this consumer.

It is about the same dimensions as my MacBook Pro, but thinner and substantially lighter in weight. With a solid state, no hard drive or DVD in this one, it is the one I'll take when traveling. Out of the box, I plugged in the Chromebook, then opened the lid. Immediately, the registration process began and since I'm already a Google customer, it was quick and simple. Setup was faster than fast and within a couple of minutes I was on the web, with access to all my Google contents, even those from my Android. Another few minutes and I was set up to print from my Epson printer which is in another room. Whereas I need to use an Epson app to print from the Android, this prints from the Google Cloud. The Google store offers a lot of apps, many of which are free, and a few which I found desirable and downloaded. With two USB ports, I'm able to carry a USB with me instead of relying on the cloud for everything. With the HDMI, I can hook up to a larger screen if I want. Chromebooks are designed for streaming and internet based operations, and there is no software to install. It's all out there for you to use without taking up space or requiring moving parts in your computer. Microsoft Office doesn't work, but documents can be put into Google Docs, then be converted to an Office document.

The appearance of this Chromebook is very sleek, with an attractive texture to the cover that feels good in the hand. For me, it's an easier, less slippery grip than others I've held onto. Start up is nearly instantaneous with the Chromebook as soon as the lid is lifted up -- I turn it off each time I'm done with it. The battery time is longer than I'd expected, fortunately because although the charge time is fast, the power supply I have gets uncomfortably hot. Because of this, I do not keep it plugged in while charging. My second criticism of this unit is that it makes a disturbing noise on the left side closest to me periodically while operating. At first, I thought the sound was coming from the power supply, but determined it is from the Chromebook after disconnecting the power supply. It's not constant, just annoying when it occurs because it takes over my focus. The keypad is very comfortable for me and I've not stumbled moving between my MacBook Pro and Toshiba Chromebook. The trackpad is a little jumpy, but not as bad as it could be, even after making adjustments through the Settings. The screen presents a terrific image and the speakers also are better than I'd expected at this price. All in all, I can't believe they are selling this Chromebook for 279. I can see why Chromebooks are all that in schools now. It's nice to have an option to lock your Chromebook if you're taking it to a place where it might "walk away" and requiring a sign-in to access the operating system is another plus. I like it and could love the Toshiba Chromebook in time.

UPDATE a few days later: Amazonian Consumer, another customer, provided comments on my review which I think are important. He/she noted things that are posted on the Toshiba website, so I'll address the components. I have used the Bluetooth with no problem at all. The RAM is limited to what's installed and the battery is not user-replaceable. There is a Skype limitation because Chrome OS uses Hangouts instead, and the camera does work fine. The SD card reader works, too, without a problem. I also didn't mention that I like the Velcro cable wrap attached to the power cord, so I don't have to add one. Mine power supply still gets hot, but when the charge is complete, it cools down. Ironically, my Chromebook has stopped making the noises it was initially making. Another observation I've made is that the trackpad seems to occasionally have a mind of its own and it sends things before I'm ready. It's more than being overly sensitive and I'm going to need to work on correcting this.

UPDATE 2/6/14: The audio now continuously goes in and out and the machine sound which I mentioned in my initial review is occurring again, usually when the audio goes out. I have a call in to Toshiba but they aren't trained yet to deal with the Chromebook, so someone will be calling me back "in a day or two." I'm also still experiencing the cursor arbitrarily moving up on the page when I have stopped typing, so I have to be especially careful to assure that what I'm typing is being entered where intended.

UPDATE 2/18/14: The audio problem is even worse and Toshiba never called me or net an email other than a survey on their customer service. It took several of my initiated attempts in phone calls and I'm finally awaiting a box and label which will take another two days to arrive for this Chromebook to be returned to Toshiba for repair. They offered me no option of simply sending a label and letting me return it in the original boxes. Dealing with them has been terrible and one rep had the gall to ask if I'd rate him a 10 on a scale of 1-10 for assistance in a survey.

I'm tempted to reduce my rating of four stars but will hold off until I receive my repaired lemon of a Chromebook which I still love despite its clicking sound, faulty speakers, sticky trackpad and terrible Toshiba telephone customer service.

UPDATE 3/11/14: Received my repaired Chromebook last night (FedEx signature required delivery was only option) and the speakers had been replaced. What a difference! No clicking sound, humming, anything other than the sound of lovely audio through the speakers. The trackpad still isn't the smoothest, but more importantly, it still selects things that I have no intention of selecting. For example, when selecting an email, one above or below opens instead of the one I select. I've also had pages close or disappear for no apparent reason.
Remote has a rather short range, but that is my only gripe. The switch does what you need it to do and splits the audio to the surround sound system.

I knew, due to my disability, that I was going to need to find a professional installer to install this Boss Audio Systems B9351WRC head unit and wireless reverse camera along with two replacement door speakers I decided needed replacement (and wow, they really needed replacing). The installation took approximately three hours or so. The only problem which may not be a problem but I'm a worrier. The bracket for the wireless reverse camera somewhat, but not entirely, covers the plate expiration stickers somewhat. Other than that the head unit fit as good if not better than the stock radio fit. in the dashboard.
This radio plays AM/FM stations though there's very few decent radio stations around here. The unit also plays from USB thumb drives which plugs into a port under a panel under the volume/pause/power button. I put 600+ songs on a USB 2.0 16 GB driver and it played everything as far as I could tell. There might be a couple VBR or odd format MP3 files it may not play but I haven't gotten to them yes. Nothing's refused to play and even a couple that had imbedded album artwork actually showed up but so small it was almost impossible to see and I had no idea how to make it better. The instructions in the manual were basically "Play with things and see what happens!" more than specific directions how different functions work.
What I went with, is a 32 gig micro-SD card that had the same 600+ songs the thumb drive has. But with the micro-SD card you can close the hatch under the volume and control knob which you couldn't with the thumb drive. There's also an AUX input jack for old style MP3 players and phones.
The six inch screen is sharp and crisp. The backup camera, even with a streetlight thirty feet away had more than enough light to back out of my garage. I even backed down the street a ways in almost complete darkness and could see just fine with just the reverse lights on the car. Now as long as no cops have a problem with it I'm golden.
I tried home burned CDs and while it took a few seconds longer to recognize it played them fine. I tried store bought CDs and they played right off the bat. OH! and it plays DVD discs jut fine in case my passenger wants to watch a movie as we drive. I promise I'm no dumb enough to watch a movie while I drive.
According to the installer I can leave the micro SD card in the unit all the time. So, 600+ songs anytime I want which I can shuffle or randomly pick and play songs anytime I want. I couldn't be happier. With the stock deck I'd sometimes get to my destination just as the deck decided to recognize the CD so this deck is a godsend when I really needed a new one. Now with as many songs as I can cram into a 32 gig drive. Right now I've got 687 songs and tons of free space. I may have to start buying more music and ripping some more albums from my collection to add to my micro-SD card.
So I can play hundreds, thousands of MP3 songs on a micro-SD card. I can play CDs both homemade and store bought. I can watch DVDs on a pretty sharp (all settings can be changed in the system) the dimmer is a bit bright until it goes off completely but it's not too bad or too bright. There's a user setting EQ option as well as several other preset settings to choose from. There are options to add sound effects such as large hall, church, cavern, etc. I avoided them entirely and set my own EQ settings with the loudness off. The new speakers sound great for high end and midrange. The stock back speakers add some needed bass.
All in all? This is an affordable head unit with all the features and functions one could ask for. It comes with a remote that I'm not sure I'm even going to keep anywhere in the car. Anything you need to do can be done on the deck and no one's sitting in the back seat of a '07 Hyundai Accent, seriously. So the remote is useless but amusing.
I love this unit, the backup cam is awesome, The many ways to play music. The fit and finish, it's close to perfect.
This a little long and meandering review but I really like this radio and I'm glad I replaced the door speakers and went with a professional installer who's basically given me a lifetime warranty on his labor. I couldn't be happier.

Update 04-04-2017: It's been nearly six months since I had this head unit and backup camera installed. Radio reception is still bad, I still despise listening to radio so that's no big deal. Have kept a micro SD card loaded with hundreds of songs installed. Turn the unit on it automatically defaults to that. Everything is still working fine. Professional installation was worth the money.

If you're looking to buy this radio probably the radio you want is the Eton Field. Yes it's 50% more in price but more than 50% in value. The build quality is superior, it's heavier, the knobs are more substantial, the sound is better, and the reception is better.

This does have great sound, and the reception is decent, with some distortion on voice, nothing to write home about. It's lighter and the plastic is thinner than the Eton, and the knobs are cheaper.

The reception and sound quality of the Eton Field is why I'm sending this back. It sounds better on easy stations, and it gets a hard to get FM station at the very edge of the dial locally that the CCrane EP Pro can't hear at all. It's a rave station I like. Plus my usual oldies stations which can be hard to get are received better on the Eton. The Eton sound with high fidelity home stereo system Sennsheiser headphones is superb, free of interference artifacts and the Eton on battery easily powers them.

Because I already had the Eton Field I had something else to compare the C Crane EP Pro to. And there is no comparison.

I can barely turn my head to be able to see what they are because I can't pull it far away from my face to be able to read the buttons. However, that is my only real complaint. Neewer is my go-to budget video shooting brand. I own quite some products from neewer like camera slider, microphone, lighting, and this time, the green/blue screen. Granted it‚Äôs a budget friendly buy, but for the quality, it‚Äôs worth the money, particularly for a new YouTuber like me. It just gets me going. The screen is fairly thick and comes with all necessary accessories to hang up. For the packaging purpose, there was some folding creases, but after hanging on the wall overnight, they are all negligible. And my Final Cut Pro x is forgivable enough when I use the keyer effect, the tiny wrinkles doesn‚Äôt bother at all.

These are great inexpensive speakers.  I needed some speakers for my desktop at work and these are great for that.  I haven't turned them up a lot since I can't be jamming out at work.  But for the price, they are well worth it.

I was skeptical about these because I haven‚Äôt had any luck with wireless headphones but these are AMAZING! I‚Äôve used apple AirPods for as long as I can remember and these are so much better! Easy to setup, put on, stays on and sounds great! Love!

This vertical power strip is amazing. No only does it have lots of places to plug in, but it also has usb ports. I love the fact that this is vertical, takes up so much less space and keeps all my cords super organized. I already have ordered a second one to use in my bedroom (between my Alexa, my white noise machine, lamp, alarm clock and phone plug (traditional) I really need a way to organize the wires behind my side table. Highly recommend this to everyone. Would also make a great gift for a student or person for office use.

First the screw into the body did not snug up the plate, second the strew is half plastic and metal...not working for me so far, and last the clasp did not look very sturdy and I can not tie my baby Nikon to that flimsy little clamp...but what can I expect for 10.00
hard to program and it only works with wired headphones and the blue tooth don't work
I love earbuds but they always fall out and this overhead spring load solves the problem at a good price.
Great set of headphones

The built-in screen is not made for the device it's advertised for.  The tablet has ONE lens for the front camera, but this cover has TWO holes which do not align with the camera lens and cover it up. If you try to set up face recognition, for example, you get the message that it doesn't detect a face even though your face is exactly within the frame.  Not a biggie for those who don't do selfies, but if you do, this will not work for you.  Other than that, the case is great - - we have SEVERAL Poetic cases in our home on both our phones and our tablets.  I definitely recommend Poetic, but for the reason mentioned above, I have given them a lower rating on this case.

While I finally got it to work, doing so was not remotely intuitive. But if you just bought one and wondering what you need to do, here is how this one works:

You have to use the little plastic or small flat screw driver to put each wire in the lid, not the metal prongs. And when I say put them in the lid, I mean ALL the way down, they each pass a certain point when you get a feed back as your are pushing down that they are now firmly in. When done, double make sure they are all as far flat against the lid as possible (otherwise they'll align with the wrong metal prong).

Now close the lid and use pliers or something to REALLY clamp it down. After I removed the cable's built in jack and added this, my speed dropped from 1gb to 100, but after I grabbed a small rubber band TIGHTLY wrapped it around the lid/body, the speed is back up to 1gb.

So definitely not the best product, but I have nothing to compare it to since this was the first time I had done this.

I bought this for my son who loves his cartoons,  but hates car rides.  He has special needs so some things really upset him that most people wouldn't care about.  The last DVD player we tried skipped when we hit a bump and it made a mechanical noise that drove him mad.  This one works great without any skipping and it's very quiet.  The picture quality is great and the sound is surprisingly loud if needed.  Usually you need a pair of earbuds to be able to hear other players, but this one can be heard clearly anywhere in the van.

Great microphone!  Good quality sound, the wireless signal was clean, and the levels were really great!!  I really like this mic.  I can connect any microphone (with the right connectors/no phantom power) and use the wireless!  I have the RODE NTG2 (which runs on phantom OR Battery) wich now can be run wirelessly!  Fab !!

For some purchasing this pair of BOSE SoundTrue headphones would be quite the investment. The question then becomes "are these headphones worth the money?" Over the last two years or so, I have purchased several headphones as gifts. My sons (both teens) had been begging for headphones, specifically the Beats by Dre, for some time. So began my research on headphones on the market. I wanted a quality product for a reasonable price. So when Amazon offered a special on the V-Moda headsets, during the holidays two years ago, I couldn't pass up the deal. I purchased two pair and was pleased. Both of my sons loved them, especially when they compared them to their friends "Beats". The V-Modas were sturdy and not as bass heavy as the Beats. The bass of the V-Moda wasn't amplified and overwhelming. They didn't feel that they were sacrificing sound quality or style. During this same time period, my husband purchased two sets of Sennheiser (PX 100 and 250 series), one for himself and another as a Christmas gift. One set was around the ear and the other, over the ear. So, over a two year time span, I have had the opportunity to listen to music with all of these headphones and can offer an opinion. And while I am not an expert, I am an average wife and mother who intends to use these headphones for recreational purposes (i.e., when cleaning the house, walking in the neighborhood, etc) only.

These headphones are:

1. Extremely light weight. Light enough to put in a purse, book-bag or briefcase, etc. without weighing you down.
2. Comfortable. The ear-covers and headband are padded and extremely comfortable when worn. They block out most if not all of the outside noise. Your ears are completely covered and the sound is crystal clear. **While the ears of the set remain secure or in place, I did notice that the headphone would fall down occasionally. To correct this, I would suggest that you adjust the headphones tighter than you normally would, especially if you have thick hair and this seems to correct the problem.
3. Functional. There is a long cord that attaches from your device to the headset. The long cord gives you some flexibility and mobility. But caution, you may want to secure some of the cord if you are using an armband type holder for your device. Otherwise the cord might get stuck on stuff while you are using it. You can operate various functions (volume, etc) from the back of the microphone. It is located on the cord near your mouth. However, I do wish that the microphone with the function button was lower on the cord, or could be adjusted because while it is comfortable when using the microphone, it isn't when you adjust the sound. If it was further down, you could adjust the sound easier and see the buttons clearly.
4. Can be used with multiple devices. I use mine with my IPOD, IPAD, computer and Android phone (Nexus 4, Google Phone).
5. Enclosed in a convenient carrying case. It fits well in most bags or luggage. They are easy to pack up and travel with.
6. Sound quality. While not bass heavy at all, I think these are perfect for all kinds of music. My playlist includes music from artists like Mree, Daley, Jhene Aiko, The Weekend, Diana Krall, Young Summer and Cary Brothers...and the sound is great. These headphones have a nice, kind of surround sound quality. These definitely complement all music types. But if you want deep bass, I wouldn't recommend these. But if you want clear sound, these are the headphones for you.
7. Kind of Expensive. These headphones cost about $180. And while that price is comparable to others (i.e., The V-Modas are around $200 and the Beats can range from $200 to $300.) on the market, are you getting the same features for the price? Probably. However, if you are a DJ or money is no object, you may not blink at the price, hence viewing it as an investment. But for the average consumer, you have to consider the features and decide if they are worth the money. So if you aren't looking for bass heavy or exaggerated sound, and you like the fact that these completely cover the entire ear, these are the perfect headphones for you. I give them 4 stars.

My wife is very pleased with these wireless headphones! They come with a convenient storage case, extra pieces, and a charger. I can‚Äôt believe how comfortable these are! So easy to use too! Just connect to Bluetooth, turn on, and you‚Äôre ready to go! They also have volume control. The only downfall is there is not a lot of bass, but they still sound great. For the price you can‚Äôt go wrong!

Using this over rabbit ears on my LG OLED and it does pick up some channels but almost all of them have weak reception. Even with the amplifier on high it doesn't do a great job. Could be the location, I'm gonna try to put it in the attic and see if it helps.
Does work for picking up NXTGEN boradcasts so that's pretty cool. Only get 2 if the 12 channels available though.

This little 3lb laptop does lightweight computing very well. With a good keyboard, excellent touchscreen, fine screen quality, decent processor speed, and sleek look ... for $400 you get the best combo of a full-sized tablet with a keyboard, lots of memory, excellent screen and decent speed.  There are some knocks like that it runs a little warm and it doesn't have a lighted keyboard (got a USS LED lamp for $15), but for $400 it can't be beat!!

So, I own several of these types of small speakers and this one, for the most part, does not disappoint.  The setup was incredibly easy.  Of all of the Bluetooth connected speakers I have, this was by far the easiest setup out of all of them.  Now, I had to subtract a star because although this speaker jams, the bass wasn't quite there enough for me.  I like a little more bass in my speakers and adjustments from my iPod didn't seem to help too much. Would I recommend it to a friend... absolutely!  It seems like a great little speaker.  The size is perfect too.  We actually took it on vacation so the kids could have a better speaker once we got to the hotel room so they could all watch a video off of the iPad.  So, it's very portable.

Normally when I receive a review sample I can do a thorough evaluation and write a review within two days. This one took longer. The reason is that it took me a while to hear the differences in this model versus the [[ASIN:B00G4UQ6U8 Brainwavz S1 In Ear Headphones]], which also impressed me (and I also own).

After going through a pile of albums to try to understand what the product description meant by smoother bass I finally found an album that allowed me to hear it: [[ASIN:B00492ANTS Portrait In Jazz]]. When Scott LaFaro's bass came in on Autumn Leaves I started switching back and forth between this and the S1, and also hauled out some studio reference monitors. These phones are capable of going down in the 18Hz range for the low end, which is lower than most in ear monitors and phones that are usually in the 20Hz range at the low end. I am not sure my ears can discretely detect the differences between 18 and 20, but I was able to detect nuances that the lower end provided.

These also go up a little higher than more phones, which are usually in the 20 KHz range, Again, I am not sure I can truly hear sounds at 24KHz, but there is a discernible difference. I tested that end of the frequency spectrum with a few Ahmad Jamal albums since he tended towards the right side of his pianos.

One other thing that took me some getting accustomed to was the over-the-ear way of wearing these. I am use to in-ear or the old fashioned over-the-hear phones and I had to play around with these before I figured out how to place them in my ears perfectly. If you are use to over-the-ear you will probably not experience the learning curve that I did.

A few other features that I have come to expect from this brand are here: extra tips of different sizes, a hard case ([[ASIN:B00HPPL1M4 Brainwavz Hard Earphone Case]]) and a 1/4" adapter. I love the flat, tangle-free cable that is tougher than it feels. And it has an adjuster like a chin strap on a cowboy hat that aids in keeping these firmly in place with the over-the-ear way of wearing them.

This is definitely a five star set of phones (according to my way of grading, anyway), and one that I will not hesitate to recommend to fellow musicians. We tend to spend a great deal of time listening to music and these do an excellent job of reproducing it. My advice, though, is to take your time when you first get them because their true power is not immediately apparent. When you do start hearing the difference you will understand why I rated them so highly.

The player works fine attached to a portable speaker. Does exactly what you want it to at a great price. Only down side is the buttons are so small and not labeled so it is hard on my old eyes. Have a magnifying glass handy. :-) Not kidding about the magnifying glass though.

These headphones were very nice. They were easy to use. They were comfortable for my daughter. The quality was fine. They worked fine. They were attractive. We need a lot of headphones for online schooling, and this was fine. They were very reasonable. I would recommend them.  The microphone worked fine.

These are super handy. They hold my headphones perfectly without fear of falling down.  HOWEVER, I advise using a 3M wall strip and not the sticky pad it ships with. That way, if you change your mind where you want it placed you can easily move it without ripping the paint and drywall off. Ask me how I know...

This speaker worked fine. You could hear everything well. It worked just like it was supposed to.

It was easy to use. We had no problem with that. It wasn‚Äôt too big, which was convenient.

They really liked the extra features. The lights were so neat! This would be great for a child or an adult. It really is unusual.

This is a good charger, however, the port could be slightly too small as it comes unplugged easily. The box part of the cord (surge protector?) has been getting dangerously hot over the last two weeks. I have tried plugging into a wall outlet and the surge protector strip with no change. I unplugged a lamp from the strip and it seems to have helped. I am not sure if it is a long-term solution. Be careful with having this in the bed, etc. Keep an eye on the temperature.

SUPER easy on and off - Heavy weighted so not ideal for travel. It didn't fit my chrome notebook, but it did fit easily and snuggly to my Sony Vaio VPCEB33FM, my ASUS laptop, and my Dell Latitude laptop. The stamp out for the usb ports were a good effort, you punch out or cut out which ones you need. However my Vaio needs 3 punchouts in one section for usb ports, the cover had 2 in that section (there are punchout options on 3 sides (none in front where the SD card goes), because the punchouts are not a substantial design (flimsy, skimpy) I am able to squeeze in devices to all three.

I am not about to purposely test the shock absorption, it is certainly much better equipped with this cover in place were it to fall off my lap or desk unprotected.

The neat thing is the design of the bottom of the cover seems to aid in keeping the laptop cooler - so 2 stars for that!
This thing works good. Bluetooth reaches into my house from the curb

This is a nice speaker- I am bummed because I ordered the red and I received the blue- I didn‚Äôt want to deal with returning it because I wanted it right away for an outing. It is bigger than I thought- But I can clip it to my belt and walk or hike and it is nice and loud. No instructions came with it but you can figure it out and it synced right up.

[[VIDEOID:90e56caf53bb9127a941c450bd417db8]] A battery-powered radio receiver is a good piece of equipment to have on hand when there is an emergency. It can be used to receive important information when there is no power otherwise available. This particular receiver works well and it has the distinction of being one of the smallest receivers I have ever used. It is about the size of a cell phone and it is able to receive shortwave signals as well as AM & FM stations.

This unit is small enough to fit in a pocket and is comparable in size to my iPhone 6 in its case. This makes it ideal for packing along on a trip or keeping someplace where it can be out of the way but ready in an emergency. In my opinion, the size is one of the strongest selling points.

Turning it on by the switch does not turn on receiving. This turns on only the power to the LCD and from there the radio can be turned on by holding down the on/off button on the front. This is an interesting way to make sure the radio is not accidentally powered on, though it is slightly inconvenient. This feature suggests the ideal behind this radio is primarily emergency readiness.

There are a number of ranges set for AM, FM and shortwave on this radio that correspond to different locales. Operable range in one country may be very different than in another, and by separating these out into preset ranges enables changing the suitability for a locale a matter of pressing a button rather than tracking down a new device. This makes traveling with this radio very workable.

After turning it on I have had no issue with finding stations on each appropriate frequency range, though it was easiest finding FM stations due to the prevalence of such in the area where I live.

This is an interesting little radio. It works well, and it is able to pick up stations in different regions by simply changing the available range to scan. The size makes it easy to take with you. Though it is most clearly useful as an emergency radio it works well as a general purpose radio too. The price is nice too, making this an easy radio to recommend.

Disclosure: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at no/minimal cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.

I purchased this for two specific reasons: (1) safety because too many accidents are caused by drivers with a phone to their ear, and (2) I love music and my Droid X has become my MP3 player (among other things as well as a phone.

Installation was a snap, although I did have to read the directions, which were clear and easy to follow. In less than 5 minutes after removing it from the packaging I was listening to music through my car radio!

This device comes with a fairly short USB charging cable that connects to a port on the head. The length made it inconvenient, and it was pretty flimsy too, failing after about three months. I added a [[ASIN:B0042X8XQO PowerLine 90310 Auto Socket Splitter with USB Power Port]] (which cleared my console in my 2008 Mazda 3 with the GOgroove and [[ASIN:B000S5Q9CA Motorola Vehicle Power Adapter micro-USB Rapid Rate Charger]] plugged in), and the combination, while unwieldy, has worked perfectly ever since.

Music and calls are reasonably clear. I do have to turn my radio volume up when a call comes in, but that may be an issue with my phone and not the GOgroove. And, like a hands-free system should work, when there is an incoming call or you wish to make an outgoing one, the MP3 player feature in my Droid X pauses the music until I am finished using the phone. After calls are terminated any paused music will automatically resume.

For long trips where you pass through areas with radio stations, your clear signal set in one location may start to degrade and you will notice static. That is caused by you coming into the range of a strong FM signal that is competing with the one you selected. You will need to seek and switch to a new frequency when that happens. For example, if I am traveling from, say, Ormond Beach, FL to Jacksonville, FL, I will need to change my frequency twice going up and twice again returning. It's the nature of any such device and there is nothing that can be designed into the GOgroove to fix it - at least not at the price point at which this device is selling.

I've had friends connect to it with their iPhones, and it works without a hitch. The icing on the cake is the GOgroove remains paired with my Droid X, and automatically connects to it as soon as I start my car if I am playing music. This is a convenient feature that I wish my [[ASIN:B0047T79VS Belkin F8Z492TTP Bluetooth Music Receiver]] that is connected to my home stereo had - I have to manually connect to that device anytime I want to use it.

Overall I am thrilled with my GOgroove and if it dies I would not hesitate to purchase another. In fact, I am considering purchasing a spare anyway because I spend a lot of time in my car and life without this wonderful gizmo would not be the same.

I ordered this Oviitech Surge Protector Power Strip Tower 5 AC Outlets with 3 USB Charging Ports(3.1A Total), 4 Feet Cord Wire Extension, White and Gray, ETL Listed to review. Having multiple Power strips that lay flat, I was curious to see how this would measure up. My thoughts are below:
‚Ä¢ This standing power strip is well made.
‚Ä¢ It feels durable and the cord is thick and well protected in rubber.
‚Ä¢ The cord works well on our crafting table, as it has 5 plug in outlets and 3 USB ports. We can have multiple items such as a sewing machine, heat press, die cut machine, magnifying lamp, etc all plugged in it at the same. Not to mention you can charge your phone also at the same time.
‚Ä¢ It makes it so much easier to unplug and plug in your electronics as you do not have to crawl under your desk or table to find the outlet or fat laying power strip.
‚Ä¢ Because you can plug the cord in behind your desk/table, there is not a tripping hazard as with some extension power strips.
‚Ä¢ The distance between the outlets is wide enough that you can actually fit three plugs on one side and two on the other. So many times, power strips are made with outlets that are too close together so you only get half use out of them.
‚Ä¢ The base is sturdy, and it sits flat on the table/desk. Does not easily tip over.
‚Ä¢ It has worked exactly as it is described.
‚Ä¢ The quality is worth the price point. Probably exceeds it.
Overall, this is well made functional standing tower power strip. Well worth it‚Äôs cost. We will most likely be buying another for our den/office.

This sucker is strong, no doubt, but my phone is heavy. I have an S5 with an Anker battery case, and the stand, while strong enough to withhold the phone up, cannot grip the magnet as well, as such, the phone does slide down during my car ride, so I have to keep readjusting.

That said, the actual features are fine, even if the speaker on my phone isn't the best (seriously, who thought having the speaker on the rear of the phone was a good idea?). You may find that many of the reviews for the app say it's not great, but be aware that the app requires either this stand or Logitech's ventilator mount to operate. With either of those, you'll be good to hear all the features.
I tend to use the car radio more for music, so the lack of musical options on the app isn't a downer. What makes it indispensable for me is the heavy-duty stand to use Waze and to pick up or send the occasional call. Thus far, after a week of using, I've not had any issues with the phone.

The suction works fine, even if the dashboard isn't perfectly flat. It grips on without any wobble.

Bought this to blast xmas music on our golf cart for the annual golf cart parade and it worked perfectly!  SUPER great speakers... GREAT volume and clear sound.  Honestly, was surprised because it's battery driven.  Compact... I'm gonna eyeball about 9 or 10 inches across about 6 or 7 inches tall.  We played CDs but it also plays cassettes if you still have some of those.  Only thing I wish is that it had a remote control - it would be a 10 star then.
Paired easily with my Samsung Q60R soundbar. Sounds great. Speakers are small and inconspicuous. But, they have big sound.

Bought these for my ten year old son.  He LOVES them. He doesn't like wearing headphones much, but he's got these on for hours and hours each day. They are surprisingly light weight for their size.  My wife wants a pair now too.

I've been using these headphones for a week and I can't get over the superior sound quality. They feature terrific high end frequency replication and offer a bass you can feel. I experimented briefly with the Bose music app, but I have enough apps on my phone already and this connects fine as a regular Bluetooth device. In the end, the comfort and sound quality are the most important and not the other features. Both are great on this product.

These headphones have a really nice, sleek design. The ear cups swivel and can be easily adjusted to fit your head. The ear cups have what seems to be a soft leather or imitation leather padding that is comfortable and helps create a seal that blocks out external noise. You can adjust the amount of noise cancellation, so these are ideal headphones for both travel and zoning out.

The headphones charge with a USB-C charging port. At this time most of my other devices require a USB Micro-B, but I'm seeing more of he C ports and cables. A charging cable is included along with an AUX cable. You also get a very nice plastic hard case that zips closed.

The headphones have a minimal design with only three buttons. The only button that's labeled is the Bluetooth button. One really cool feature is that the front half of the right ear cup can recognize taps and gestures. Instead of feeling around for a tiny button, you can just double tap the ear cup to play your music or answer a call. You can adjust volume by swiping down or swiping up. The 20 hour battery life means these are always ready to play.

I'm sure this set of headphones has more features than I'll ever use. The most important thing is that they are very comfortable, easily adjustable, and sound terrific. If you love music on the go, these headphones are a perfect choice.

These headphones are easy to operate, do a good job cancelling noise in the room from televisions, kids, dogs and husbands. They are also comfortable. They were so simple to set up. I set them up on my laptop. I held in the square  button until  I heard that the speakers were on. Then I checked my laptop system information and ran the Bluetooth device and there they were. Put on one of my songs and I had to turn the volume  down quite a bit. They get plenty loud. I am very impressed with these headphones. I may be swapping out the ones I use nightly for these.

Although it's a great price on Amazon, I'd spend the extra $40 and get yourself a decent car stereo.

I installed this in my 2000 Toyota 4Runner with stock speakers and a 10" Kicker sub/200w amp. Althought it does the job, it doesn't do it with any real impact. It creates sound, and it functions, but don't expect amazing sound.

The biggest disappointment was the bluetooth performance. Although it's got all the phone gadgets, and includes a microphone, the connection with both my Android, iPhone 4 and iPhone 5 were all fuzzy. Yup - the louder you pumped the volume the louder the bluetooth fuzz was! It was really distracting, almost like using a tape deck aux converter. It's just poor quality.

I used it for about 8 months, but finally gave in and purchased a decent Pioneer unit that has crystal clear bluetooth connectivity, and much better control over stock speaker sound.

Just spend the extra money. Trust me.

Video quality stinks, front camera poorly located and is mostly obstructed, third camera is very difficult to connect and goes offline often, interior cam mic is very poor on audio quality.. I‚Äôve had $20 cameras with much better quality..

The Skagen Men's Hybrid HR Jorn Smartwatch is an elegant watch first and smart watch second. It is considered a hybrid because it is a watch first. Even with almost no battery life left, it still serves as a traditional watch with a stylish, all metal body and actual watch hands with glow-in-the-dark inserts for visibility without a front-light. In terms of thickness, unfortunately, this watch isn't any thinner than other Android Wear watches I've used.

For the "smart" portion of the watch, the Skagen is equipped with an e-ink display, which means that once the watch face is drawn, no more power is drawn from the battery to keep that display. This means that the watch will last much longer than a regular, oled-display smart watch. It is easy to tell that this e-ink display is of high quality because it does not have the yellow hue that older e-ink displays had. It is quite similar in quality to the paper-white kindle.

Beyond the screen is the software. The Skagen watch pares down the smart functionalities to only what a user may actually need on a watch. No games, no maps, no speakerphone functionality. Instead, the watch will track your workouts, show you notifications, and control your music player. It really is everything I normally do on my Android Wear watch. There are many watch faces, and multiple complications for customization. One can even use a photo as the background for the watch face. I did find that any watch faces with numbers tend to crowd out the UI and there is very little room for complications.

For all of this, Skagen priced this watch about $100 less than other smart watches so it really is a good option for those who just want a wearable that gives them the essentials.
Skinny  wire just what I need  because  my normal  wire will not work with  this temporary  amplifier

Pros: Cheap.
Cons: There is nothing special about these speakers in terms of sound quality. they sound like your average/below average PC speakers. Muddled high end, with almost not distinction in the middle and a booming low. good for a low end pc system, but not much else.

These caught my attention because of the cool led inside the charging case. Practical use though they kind of fell short. The sound wasn‚Äôt at all what I had hoped. I just needed enough volume to drown out the gyms sound system. But even outside without music blaring it was still oddly hard to hear. The ear hooks were a little too weak for my liking. I prefer something a bit more ridged since I‚Äôm using these as gym headphones. Over these weren‚Äôt terrible they were just ok. For my use (gym sessions) it didn‚Äôt quite fit the bill. But I think if you need a pair to have laying around as a backup these are priced right and a decent choice.

[[VIDEOID:42e094483f6e955d0420a8154e31c5fb]] At first, I though this is a disappointment. That this won‚Äôt be loud enough at the Ocean. BUT, this makes a nice small, compact, rugged outside speaker. No, it is not going to blow the windows out, but you do get a nice tone and small bass from this unit at max volume. This is now our new beach and pool side system. The charge last about 20 hours at 60% volume. One charge will last all day at max volume. Easy to charge and connect. The lights add a cool nighttime effect. This can connect to the APPfor light modes and sleep sound white noise, if that is your thing. Overall, an excellent product. I have tied simile speakers in this price range with horrible sound and very low volume.

Trust you found this review honest and helpful:-)

[[VIDEOID:7c51c8affe21df7ad48095fb4eeeab3b]] THE GOOD:
---------------
* Plug and Play if you know what you're doing. LOL! If not, you have some software learning curves. If you're using this to capture on your computer, then a popular software people use is OBS.
* But there are better quality capture devices for your desktop. Most people use these little usb versions on their smartphone to create a second monitor for their DSLR cameras. Watch my video, I demo two use-case scenarios.
* Colorful! Not your usual boring usb capture stick. I love red!

USING YOUR SMARTPHONE TIPS:
----------------------------------------
* The type of USB adapter you use will matter. If your phone has a USB-C port, then you'll need a female USB A to USB-C adapter. If it has a micro usb port, you'll need a female USB-A to micro usb adapter. I found that the ones with a little cord are finicky. A solid one piece, cordless usb to usb-c adapter solved the issue for me. Watch my video to understand what I'm saying.
* Many USB Camera Viewer apps won't work. It's not an exact science because you're dealing with so many variables such as app version, phone brand, android version, not to mention your hardware. Some apps gave me video, but no audio, some slam you with so many ads, it's annoying unless you pay. The best paid app is USB CAMERA PRO by Shen Yao, their free version is good too, but has ads. The best free app that virtually has no ads is USB CAMERA VIEWER by Homesoft, LLC. This is the app you see in my video demo. I'm using a Pixel 6 Pro.
* If connecting a media device such as fire stick, roku, etc., you will need to bypass HDCP, and you'll have to trial and error with the different types of splitters on the market. The bi-directional ones DO NOT work, at least they didn't work for me. I have a splitter by VIEWHD I bought years ago that worked for me.

THE BAD:
------------
* Nothing at all. At first, I thought mine was defective, but as mentioned above, I realized the adapter was the culprit. This product is 5-Stars!

I don't need my personal laptop at the office, just my iPad, but typing on the iPad screen was a pain.

I did NOT get any compensation from anyone for this review.
This is a great product and my review reflects it: If I could give 10 stars, I would!

This keyboard case is genius!
It does a great job protecting your iPad, the keyboard feel is great and the Bluetooth connection is reliable and makes sense!
The special function keys - like screen dim and brighten, cut, copy and paste - actually work!

What is so clever about this is that it uses the iPad's built-in magnetic-sensing strip (the one that holds the original cover to the iPad)
to turn on the Bluetooth keyboard:

When you flip this case open and put your iPad in place on the clearly marked strip, you can FEEL the magnetic "click" and then the keyboard wakes up and turns on. Instant keyboard and very stable when sitting on your desk.

If you leave it alone for a while, it shuts down the Bluetooth connection, to save battery life.
But press any key for two seconds, and it's back up.

If you don't need the keyboard, it's very easy to open the case and flip the IPad over and use it without the keyboard:
The Bluetooth doesn't connect unless you "Click" the iPad into the magnetic strip.

I've had to recharge the keyboard once, in two months of use.
But the indicator lights warned me well in advance and it recharged in about two hours.

Great product!

The keyboard feel is great, though the keys are necessarily small

I bought another case that had a rotating pivot for portrait and landscape use, but it had bad keyboard reliability (what you typed didn't always appear) and the battery failed after one charge.

This case

It does what it says it does.....accesses media files. Yeah, I also wish wish wish it was a true external drive where you could copy and access all sorts of files on your iDevice, but it is not. And that's Apple's fault, not the Gigastone.  However, I love this thing for travel so I can back my pics up when I'm away from my computer.  Only gripe is having to take the case off. If they had made both sides of the reader the same it would fit. But one side of the connector is slightly shorter than the other and it's just enough to keep it from seating. This seems like a prime example of form over function...it looks cool with that asymmetric look but it would have been better if it fit.

I love these headphones, they are easily my favorite. I always worry about these wireless headphones because I tend to be terrible at keeping them in one place, and these are quite pricey so losing one would really be unfortunate. They come with a really nice carrying case, it's a super durable case, thankfully, and I really like that it's easy to put the headphones in it (just drop it in and like a magnet kind of pulls them down). It's super easy to charge, and I really like that when I start using them a little voice comes on and tells me how much battery life is left. The battery life is also pretty impressive, I used them for hours upon hours without the battery running out, so I was pretty impressed by that.
The sound quality on these is amazing. I love how noise cancelling they are, I had my doubts with these being earbuds, that they wouldn't be that good at cancelling out noise, but these are great. I love how loud I can make it without affecting the sound quality.
I would highly recommend these to anyone, as I said these are hands down my favorite earbuds of all time.

I was looking for replacement headphones that offered great sound at a budget-friendly price. This was the perfect pair for me. They look sleek and expensive. The ear cups have good cushioning and are comfortable to wear for long periods of time. The play time is impressive. These are great headphones overall.

Thanks so much for taking the time to read this review. I hope the information that I've provided makes your decision a little easier.

Well, I'm not impressed by this unit. It works and is fine for basic stuff like a kids movie night in the back yard. As a alternative to a regular television, keep looking.

The bluetooth is only for external speakers not for streaming from a phone or tablet. You can mirror cast via WiFi though. Unfortunately, I wanted to use this in an outdoor setting with no WiFi. We ended up downloading the show to an SD card instead.

The picture quality is not 4K or really high definition by the time you download and replay from a card. It's tolerable for an outside gathering certainly, but not as an every day viewing option.

The included screen is pretty flimsy, but it does work. I would expect to see this in the hundred to hundred fifty dollars range at the most
Speaker is great and has amazing sound. Was easy to set up with my phone and play whatever I want with no problems. Super happy with this speaker.

It is harder and harder to find any radio that has an AM radio band on it, let alone a really good one. It is also rather difficult to find a decent radio that is not digitally tuned and controlled. This radio is a good solid radio with both of the above features on it.

WHAT IS THIS RADIO LIKE?
This radio is a good solid radio. It has a slide switch under the tuning bar which has three settings - OFF, AM, and FM. On the right side are two dials. There is one with volume that goes from Minimum to Maximum. The other dial is the tuning dial. That makes the tuning bar slide up and down for both AM and FM. There is a handle on top that flips up or goes down. There is a pull out telescopic antenna on the top for better reception. There is a place in the left side where you plug in the electric cord, but you can remove it if you prefer to operate solely by batteries. The cord is a little over 5 feet long. The plug is a two pronged plug and is polarized. There is a door on the back which slides off and allows you to put in 3 AA batteries. The door has attached hinges so you don't have to worry about losing the battery door off of the unit unless it breaks.

HOW DOES THIS RADIO PERFORM?
For AM I would say that it has okay reception It is not WOW but it is not terrible either. Since AM is not really dominating the airwaves anymore, I imagine that some people would not find this to be a problem. If you want really strong AM reception, this is okay, but you might be able to find better.

For FM reception, the radio is great. It pulls in quite a few stations and also plays them very clearly. The speaker is best showcased by FM. It is a full sound and impressive considering the size of the speaker and the basic nature of the radio. I found that it is a nice sound and enjoyable.

HANDLE
The handle has a bit of a recoil to help it snap back into place, but it does seem just a little bit flimsy to me. I wish it was just a bit sturdier. It is not enough to take off a star.

WHAT WOULD THIS RADIO COME IN HANDY FOR?
For those of you who are from the era where radios of this nature were commonplace, I am not writing this comment section for you. You already know what this would be good for. For those of you who think that In Tune, or other internet radio stations would suffice for any AM or FM radio stations, I would like to mention that during weather crises, that AM/FM and shortwave radio tend to be the only reception you can get if any. That includes disasters. At that point, internet is not an option, so it is important to have a back up communication capability to keep up on what is going on and any emergency information that might come up, or even information about upcoming help.

THE BOTTOM LINE
This radio is handy. It is a decent size, sturdy, and a solid basic radio. It gets decent reception and has a nice speaker which is especially nice for FM. During emergencies and times of crises, this is a good backup to have should internet not be an option. Running on both electricity and AA batteries, this would be a great addition to your basic emergency kit.

MY RATING
Despite the handle being a bit flimsier than I would like, it is still decent and a solid radio. I do not think that it is worth taking off a star.

These headphones are great! But the controls are a little wonky. You are better off using the device rather then the headphones to control audio playback & pick up & answer calls. But the sound is incredible. The the way they sit comfortably & securely in your ear is awesome. I would still recommend them if you need something with the controls in the headphones, in a pinch. When I saw that I could buy a set of these at a renewed product price, I jumped at the opportunity to save some money. Unit looked like brand new. Pristine condition....
I have been using Micca 3 Club speakers for a few years and really like them. But I have to say, these little guys are almost as good, if not better in some regards. I find the sound very pleasing. No, they do not have a pounding bass, but enough to please me. I really don't know how they get such well rounded sound out of such a small box.
I have these connected to an Amazon INPUT and small Kinter amp. Works great for my desktop installation. Keep up the good work MICCA.

I don't know what the problem is with these earbuds but they don't stay in my ears. All I have to do is slightly move and they fall out. What a waste of money. I will throw them away as soon as I can find them since I got so frustrated and threw them across the room.

.. until I dropped them once and the left earbud stopped working. But for the price you can buy two more of these and still pay less than for the AirPod pros (which I have). These are great, but AirPod pros have better nosie cancelation and fit in the ear for me. However, these have a Bluetooth range 10 times better of AirPod pros (at least on Android phones).

I got this wireless buds cause I lost my previous pair of tws buds. It comes in a cheap box with minimal packaging. As soon as you take it out of the box you question the quality of the product. It feels light and made of cheap plastic. But as long as it performs it's good right?

Well let's start with the positives. The sound quality is excellent. Not too bass-y which is what I like. It is clear and the sound separation is quite nice. I noticed instruments in some songs which I haven't heard in my previous wireless earbuds. All in all this is a great sounding earbuds. You can also use it mono or one at a time.

But that is where the qualities end. The ANC is bare minimum. There's no app support. And whenever you try to switch the noise cancelling mode it goes to ambient sound first then you have to change it again. Sometimes the taps doesn't register properly.

The mics on it are ok. It picks up a lot of noise but in a quieter environment the calls are good. But I dont know if it's my product or in general, the mic only seems to work properly on the right earbud. The left earbud barely picks up my voice.

The main issue I had with this earbud is the Bluetooth connectivity. It would disconnect randomly in the middle of calls. One time it kept disconnecting and reconnecting a few times in the same call. When listening to something the track sometimes skip randomly. And there is no clear indication or it doesn't let you know that it's low on battery. It just dies when the buds run out of juice.

The battery life is average. Not bad but not outstanding either. Around 5 hrs on the earbuds itself and with the case it lasts me around 2.5days I'd say. (On average I use the buds 3.5-4 hrs daily)

Avoid. Within the first hour of use the left earbud (the slave) had been cutting out. The audio even froze up making this grinding noise as it repeated the last few milliseconds of playback over and over and over. I thought it was my phone/app so I turned off Bluetooth so the buds would disconnect. The weird noise kept going until I put them in the case and took them out again. Oh yeah, and the case looks bulky and awkward in my pocket. Very little noise isolation‚Äîthey provide two sizes of ear tips but neither provided a good seal. I had my hopes up, but connectivity glitches like I mentioned are inexcusable for the price point.
I am very happy with the sound and overall fit.  However,  the headphones start to hurt on long calls when wearing glasses.  Overall it is s great product.

looks nice, but blue tooth pauses in the middle of the songs, Screen doesn't shut off. Keeps displaying AM, CD, Bluetooth ect. over and over never stops. Customer service said thats what it does. I hated that it didnt shut all the way off.

This usb type-c dock is very, very nice, but it isn't quite perfect.

First, a clarification for those who aren't versed on USB Type-C ports: There is a wide range of features that a Type-C port will support -- it's all up to the manufacturer. Just because you have a Type-C port, it doesn't mean you will be able to use all of the features that this dock provides. Unfortunately, you will need to dig into the online documentation or forums for your device to find out what you will actually get.

Windows PC -- Almost all Windows PC's will be able to use the SD/MicroSD reader, the Ethernet port, and the additional USB 3.0 and USB 2.0 ports. On my minisforum u700, this dock provides two HDMI ports and I didn't bother testing the VGA port. So on my PC and my laptop, I'm able to take full advantage of this hub.

LG V40 -- I'm on the T-Mobile service running their Android 10 rom. In this ROM, LG provided a little-know desktop mode similar to Samsung Dex that makes the phone work almost as well as a desktop PC. In this mode, the phone takes advantage of the SD/MicroSD card reader to transfer pictures and files, connect to your network through the ethernet port, and provide a large-screen experience through the HDMI port. Connect a mouse and keyboard and you have a great desktop experience. Plex and Netflix works extremely well in this mode.

Nintendo Switch support -- NO

My gripes about this dock: Being an 11-in-1 dock, this really should have a 3.5mm headphone jack, instead, they provided a VGA port. If your computer has a type-c port, would you really NOT have an HDMI monitor/tv to plug it in? Also, the lack of support for Switch means that I'd still need a separate Switch dock when travelling instead of having one dock that supports all of my devices.

While I had seen similar products I had never been in a situation where I could mount a dot on an outlet until now. We recently moved into a new home and I was able to utilize this on our patio - though it required a few adjustments.

By utilizing the plug included with the 3rd generation Echo Dot and snaking the cable around and through the inner hoops of this bracket you can secure the dot to the outlet within the bracket as one solid unit and still have access to everything you need.

Obviously this mounting method necessitates easy access to an outlet that will be located where you want your Dot.

I installed this on our patio and because it‚Äôs installed outside it‚Äôs on an outlet that has flip open covers so the plug could not sit flush. I was able to still have this work by adding a small 3 plug adapter I had and securing it with a zip tie. This solution has worked well and also given me a place to plug my Bluetooth speaker that I leave paired with the Dot.

This is a great mounting bracket that allows for a clean, sleek mount without a bunch of wires showing. Definitely a product I recommend.

it's a small speaker, it's not meant to be used for noisy parties‚Ä¶ I listen to music with it, use it with my cellphone and iPod, I watch movies on my laptop in my room, it more than loud enough! The padding on the shoulder straps make a HUGE difference for this sized backpack.  I transferred my iPad Pro 12in plus a few music material into this bag, and I could hardly feel the weight unlike my older backpack!.  Stylish and I have received plenty of compliments and it is beautifully/sturdily made.  Opens up wider to make it easier to pull out paper documents. ample of dividers in the main compartment, not for bulky items though.

I had to laugh when I saw the gold tips on this cable: while gold connectors might make sense on cables that carry electrical signals (analog or digital), they're irrelevant for optical cables, the tips are just the mechanical connection into the socket which aligns the optical fiber-ends. So there's no difference between this tip and the black tip of other cables like this (such as the Amazon Basics one).

That said, this cable does fit into the proper sockets just fine, and works as well as the other such cables I've tried. I used it to connect my SBX4 sound card with an Fiio BTA30Pro DAC, and listened to it with earbuds as well as external speakers, didn't experience any problems. I didn't expect, and didn't perceive, any audio superiority to the Amz Basics optical cable I had been using, so there's no reason there to prefer one over the other. Physically though this one is just a bit more stiff, so I tend to prefer the more pliable Amz cable. If that's not a concern, I would recommend buying whichever is available and cheaper.

I had to use a continuity check to be sure which wire was negative and which was positive.... it does matter so speakers are not out-of-phase.  Both outside wires are the outside shell of their respective sides and both inside wires are the inside of their respective sides.  The colors on the RCA plugs do not match the colors on the wires.  This should come with a simple wire diagram, but it does not.

There are a few things that set the review sample I received apart from most other bluetooth speakers. At the top of the list is sound pressure level because this is the loudest bluetooth speaker I have ever tested. Literally, this can compete with waves on a beach, which can get pretty loud when the tide is changing. I tested it from three rooms away from my writing desk and it could easily be heard. In that respect it could provide background music for a flash mob, which is way beyond the power of most other speakers, which are designed for personal listening on a desk or night stand.

The sound quality is also a cut above. While I have tested speakers that are better, this one is still on the short list of my favorites. The speakers are large and powerful, and they do a remarkable job of handling the high, mid and low frequency bands. As advertized the bass is pretty intense compared to ninety percent of the bluetooth speakers I have owned or tested (about fifty!)

In addition to volume and sound, this is ruggedized. I mentioned that it could compete with wave noise at the beach. It can also withstand moist and sandy environments and being banged around. It's not waterproof, but is designed to resist it.

While the product description and specs are complete I do want to highlight a few features that I personally love. First is ease of connecting this to my phone. When you turn it on it immediately beacons its presence (and announces it in a human voice.) Do a scan from your device for other bluetooth devices and this pops up immediately. A simple touch pairs and connects it. If you have an NFC-enabled phone like my Galaxy Note 3 it's even simpler. Just touch the device to the NFC logo on the speaker and you'll get a message on your screen asking if you want to connect to the speaker.

Finally, time and distance claims are accurate. This actually will play longer than most speakers. The claim is twelve hours. I had it on and playing for ten and it probably would have lasted another two hours. So say at least ten hours to set expectations. It also claims to work from 25 meters, which is significantly more than the normal 10 for bluetooth. I tested mine at about 18 meters and it did not falter - the music streamed with no breakup or dropouts.

Basically, if you want to play your music loud and still get decent sound this is the speaker for you. It has a lot of features that I did not mention (but are listed in the product description), but the defining one is sound pressure level.

I have gone through many Bluetooth speakers and had yet to listen to one that had such depth of sound as this Bose SoundLink Revolve.  I know it's not the first Bose SoundLink Bluetooth speaker, but it's my first and it blows away all the others that gather dust around here.  Visually similar to my Amazon Echo, I had to let Alexa know that she has a competitor in my home but reassured her that she is still loved.  I can't talk to this Bose, but each time I turn it on, a generated female voice alerts me to the battery life remaining and what device it's pairing with.  Setup took only a minute, the manual is only a few words and diagrams, and after a full battery charge, it's still going after daily use for what seems like dozens of hours.  I'm serious, I have not plugged it back in yet because I want to see what happens when the battery nears death.  I did not want to wait to write this review because I'm so impressed with the audio that is generated from this little speaker that can also withstand being carried outside without harm.  Of course, I'm not willing to test it in the rain, but have to say that my neighbors could not believe the music was coming from this little black speaker.

This keyboard is comfortable to use thanks to the fabric, and doesn't feel cramped despite the 12" size.  Keys feel solid and type well, with medium-high resistance, and are somewhere in the middle between quiet and noisy.  The keyboard isn't as noisy as most mechanical keyboards (like a Cherry blue/green) but it's still noisy enough to bother my wife if I'm using it in bed when she wants to sleep.  The backlighting is well-balanced, enough to make keys clear and easy to read but not so much that it looks freaky at night.  The magnetic attachment to the surface pro works like a charm, and is so easy it's almost fool-proof.  It still feels expensive (compared to similarly priced mechanical gaming keyboards) but does its job well.

This is a lightweight set,  and they are about as good for their price.  There is a slight tintiness when using them, but for a quick earbud in my laptop or Kindle Fire,  it serves the purpose.  I like the sound for my Youtube music or IPOD.  However,  the lengthy wire will get tangled if not careful.  Nice packaging.

Since there are detailed specs in the product description I will not repeat them here. Instead I'll use my personal experience with this kit to explain why I rated it five stars.

I used the review sample I received to extend the range of my ancient [[ASIN:B000BTL0OA Linksys WRT54GL Wireless-G Broadband Router]] (which is still working as well as when I purchased it ten years ago!) I removed one antenna from the Linksys, used a [[ASIN:B005IKGTXY Bluecell SMA female to TNC male Coaxial Adapter/Converter]] to adapt the included cable to the antenna connector, plugged it into the power supply and checked my home dead spot.

My dead spot is the master bedroom and my phone is always complaining about 'unstable WiFi connections' when I am in the room. I used an app called [[ASIN:B004EBZX6W Wi-Fi Analyzer]] to perform the before and after tests.

Before I installed this booster kit I was getting a strong reading of -45 dBm near the router and an absymal -80 dBm in the dead room. After installing this kit the signal boosted to -55 dBm in the bedroom, so this booster kit works as advertised.

It's practically worth its weight in gold if you do have dead areas in your WiFi coverage. Based on my experience and how easy and fast this is to install I rate this as a five star product.

I replaced the speakers in my Dodge Dakota Sport edition club cab.  These trucks come with what they call a high quality sound system.  Maybe, but the two I got to replace the original 5 x 7s in the back (they fit perfectly), blow the originals away.  Much better frequency response range, better clarity, and minimal distortion.  Worth every penny.

I'm not eager to award a product with a single star, but the [[ASIN:B007YYUUA0 BlueAnt T2-BK-USEN-US Endure Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black]] has earned one measly star.  I've been using a [[ASIN:B00177YJFM Plantronics Discovery 925 Bluetooth Earpiece (Cerise) [Retail Packaging]]] for four years without complaint and would recommend that headset hands down over this one.  I'd definitely not recommend the BlueAnt because of it's poor design, lousy fit, flimsy construction, terrible pairing and most importantly, undesirable sound quality.  There are many other bluetooth headsets available with better characteristics at a much lower cost, so I'd investigate others and try them out if you can.

The WD_Black 1TB D50 Game Dock has quality written all over it. Metal construction for heat dissipation, thunderbolt support, nice RGB lighting, and a fast NVMe drive. It is quite obviously geared toward the PC Gaming crowd, but which segment?

The build of this product screams high-quality gaming accessory. Its outer design is reminiscent of a cargo container and its collection of ports are impressive. Each USB port is well labeled with its speed (4x 10Gb/s Type-A and 2x 10Gb/s Type-C), two thunderbolt ports, one of which outputs 87 watts of power, one displayport, one network port (gigabit), and one 3.5mm headphone jack. Add to this, the 1TB high-performance NVMe drive. All in one sleek-looking, compact container (pun intended).

It is obvious that this dock is geared toward the Gaming Laptop crowd, whether its for gaming or for video/graphics production work, but I find that it really doesn't make sense for me. In my tests, this product does not work without the power adapter (it really should be able to power itself through the thunderbolt port). This means an additional outlet that's drawing power at all times. This would make sense if gaming laptops can actually be powered and charged from the 87w thunderbolt port but I have not seen a gaming pc with discreet graphics that actually accepts anything in that range.

So what other advantage would this product provide? External storage through a fast Thunderbolt connection. At $450, this product provides 1TB of additional storage. Which 2TB NVMe drives available for much less, I would opt to upgrade my internal storage to 2TB instead.

Then that leave the docking station. The ports are all of the high quality and your monitor, network, keyboard, mouse, headset, and speakers can be connected via a single thunderbolt connection. This is convenient, but I don't think this justifies the price as there are many docks out there that work just as well, albeit through a USB 3.1 connection instead.

WD has really done well to package a lot into this dock but is charging a premium for it. Personally, I think that there are just better ways of achieving equal or better results when it comes to upgrading a gaming laptop.

**update**
Coming back to think about it some more, I realized exactly what niche WD was going for: Macbooks. Some Macbooks have only two thunderbolt ports and all of them are not easily upgradeable so this product does indeed provide a value to those consumers. But then does it make sense to spend an additional 35% of the price of the laptop (Macbook Pro 13" is $1299) to address problems that Apple introduced into their laptops? I guess if you're already in their ecosystem, it's par for the course. That's not to say Apple is the only one. Microsoft has made their products impossible to upgrade as well, but none of these are actually gaming laptops.

SO first and foremost, they have the size clearly listed- it's on me for not looking at the dimensions. I honestly had no idea they had Bluetooth pieces this big though! It's genuinely bulkier than any headset I've used in the several call centers I've worked in and the only way to be able to semi comfortably use this is to use the piece that goes over your head and makes it a headset. Great for people on the road a lot/ truckers! But for the common person, this is wayyy too bulky and goofy looking.

Bulk aside- the sound quality is great. Cancellation of background noise works really well! Battery life is great. It's an amazing Bluetooth piece if you can get past the humongous size!

Finally I found a device that worked so I could plug my VHS tape player into my PC and use software to create digital files from our old tapes.

When I began this project I really didn‚Äôt think it would be near as difficult as it ended up being. I tested a couple similar devices with minimal success - I could achieve video transfer but no audio.

Even with this device I struggled and finally found the only way for audio to transfer was for me to toggle the switch on the side to 16:9 - theoretically this should have nothing to do with sound but in the 4:3 setting I have no sound transfer.

The single sheet of instructions are abysmal. Set up is relatively straightforward unless it doesn‚Äôt work. The first thing I would try is switching that toggle switch on the side.

If you are looking to transfer analog VHS tapes to digital using your PC, I recommend downloading OBS Studio (free software) via obsproject.

This device does get warm during use. Since I only used it for limited amounts of time for my specific purpose it wasn‚Äôt an issue. If this was to be used long term for connecting a game system to a TV I would question its longevity.

While this worked for my purposes it is a bit glitchy. I got it to work with time thankfully and was able to accomplish what I set out to do.

This is an ok product but not outstanding.
it would be better if it came with a microphone but good earbuds regardless. I bought it for a gift and no complains.

This VERBATIM WIRELESS SILENT MOUSE & KEYBOARD COMBO (Graphite; 2.4GHz with Nano Receiver; Ergonomic, Noiseless, and Silent for Mac and Windows) has a keyboard that is every bit as good as the other excellent Verbatim keyboards that I‚Äôve owned over the years. The keys are comfortably shaped, and have a nice responsive touch. With this particular Verbatim keyboard, the keys are totally silent when depressed and released. The mouse buttons are equally silent.

The wireless keyboard and mouse operate via transmitting radio signals. Both need two AAA batteries to operate (4 batteries are included). Inside the mouse‚Äôs battery compartment is a small radio receiver that must be unclipped and plugged into a USB port on your PC or Mac for the devices to work. Also, the mouse must be turned on. Once the receiver is plugged in, the computer‚Äôs OS will set up the devices automatically.

I like this keyboard and mouse combo a lot--especially the smooth-as-silk mouse. A great thing about these radio-controlled devices is that you can use them with any computer that has an available USB port, without having to disable or unplug a wired mouse and/or keyboard that is already installed. The wireless combo will work right alongside the wired combo.

The sound quality of these speakers is fine.  Unfortunately, I can't position them so that I am in the "sweet spot", so all the sound appears to be coming from the speaker I am closest to.  This makes sense, but it doesn't help me.  To those who say, just move the speakers - I can't.  My placement options are limited to a single location and it means I am closer to one speaker.  As mentioned in the headline, a balance control would solve this issue.

The description on this headset is inaccurate, it states that it comes with in-line volume control, but it does not have any volume control at all. (Attaching screenshot of description at time of purchase in the event the description is changed to accurately reflect available features). The sound quality is good, the over-ear speakers are comfortable, and the mic works well but it is little on the soft side in terms of volume.

Wonderful sharp clear screen, and reasonably lightweight if holding rather than propping up. I have had my original Kindle for years and prefer the operating system over a tablet - I don't like the constant app updates etc., that you get with a tablet. I am delighted with my 10" Kindle and love the fact I am familiar with how it works and what it can do. I have not yet used audible books or streaming on it but I have no doubt it will be good - sound on music and other audio is great.

Speaker freezes and skips. At first i thought it was the music apps i was using but it was the speaker! Ontop of that the sound quality is terrible and staticky! I returned this. I would not recommend.

Update: company sent me a new complimentary speaker. It skips/freezes but not as much as the one I originally ordered. ok speaker.

Its definitely waterproof. I dunked it under water the first chance I got and it still works.  I use it in my boat with the water splashing on it all the time and it's still going. I haven't held it under for longer than a minute though. The sound is great. But with a boat motor blasting u can't hear unless it's right beside you. I love this speaker. Works flawlessly with my iOS device. I do not use the UE app on the App Store and the unit functions just fine without it. This speaker is great. It is a good value for the money.

I work from home and I am on the phone 5-7 hours a day. Need something comfortable.

The ear piece fits on my ear well and the material is nice. Should work great

Cons: After 2 weeks the light indicator to let you know when mute is on stopped working. Mic is very sensitive and picks up the movement of the USB cable, no extra cable came with it or adapters
