I wanted to find a cheaper alternative to my wife's wireless Bose headset, something with decent noise cancelling for flights and work. So far I've used Bose, the MPOW H5, Treblab, and Woltix with ANC.

Nothing will compare to Bose noise cancellation - but these Woltix are actually really nice for the money. The MPOW H5 don't have as good audio clarity as the Treblab, but at the end of the day I got noise cancelling headphones for the noise canceling. I ended up returning the Treblab and the MPOW H5 and I kept the Woltix because they are more comfortable than the MPOW and had the best low-price ANC. The MPOW also had some sound interference issues randomly when the ANC was on, and the Treblab had a slight hiss to them when ANC was on.

I ended up keeping the Woltix brand. They just work, they're very light, and they are not too tight on the ears. The Active Noise Cancellation isn't as good as Bose, but they actually work pretty well for a $65 set of wireless ANC headphones. For the price, I'm very happy.

The ONLY thing I don't like about these is that there is no battery meter display on my iPhone when these are connected via bluetooth. With the other brands there is a small battery meter. I have no idea when these are low, so I just charge them like once a week.

So, quick breakdown of my experience with these wireless ANC headsets:

Bose: Best noise cancellation, good audio, comfortable, but definitely expensive!
Treblab: Best audio, worst noise cancellation (you can hear a slight hiss when turned on), comfortable, but large and they don't fold down too small.
MPOW: Good audio, good noise cancellation, but was getting some weird sound interference with the ANC on sometimes. Tight on ears.
Woltix: Good audio, good noise cancellation, most comfortable (way lighter and less tight on the ears than the MPOW), and fold down the smallest. No battery meter displayed on phone.
I can see that these will last only a few wears.  Be careful when placing on earbuds. Will rip very easy.

These are so great i've ordered another in case they quit making them. SO comfortable which is what i wanted. yet have a nice sound. I have a pair of Bose, which has a great sound. But after wearing them for very long, i feel like a rhino has been clamping onto my ear.  So these are better for having on long periods.

Great value, well made, works perfectly! It setup instantly and paired with my phone right away. Sound thru this is flawless like I have a cord hooked directly into my car stereo- highly recommend this bluetooth adapter!

I own a lot of little speaker sets and this one is by far the most portable, easiest to bluetooth pair, and sounds the best for its size. I had no trouble pairing it with my iPad. I did, however, have trouble pairing it to my iMac. It kept giving me errors and I finally gave up. I can't speak to whether or not it was easy to pair with another Jam Plus speaker, as Amazon did not send me two as first was noted. I would definitely recommend this speaker. We actually took it on vacation last weekend and had it by the pool. Everyone there commented on how loud it was and what great sound it had for its size. So... thumbs up on this one!

UPDATE 9/12/13 - I received an additional speaker and so I thought I would provide an update. I absolutely love these little speakers. They have an incredible sound and a great bass for their size. They really do jam. I thought one was great... two of them synced are exceptional. We love to travel and these are the perfect size for that. So, I would highly recommend these speakers.

This is the best little alarm clock I've ever owned. It is cute and functional and has a radio and adjustable volume controls. Two alarms can be set at the same time.

The FM radio comes in great and I have it set on a favorite station. You can program in stations and then you can wake with the radio or listen for a specific time before going to sleep. There is a nap, sleep button which is very useful. I press the radio button, then the sleep button and the radio turns off automatically after a preset time ( 15/30/60/90 minutes).

This also has a nice big snooze button on the top so it is easy to turn off the alarm when you want to sleep a little longer.

What I like is that you can adjust the brightness of the display so it doesn't light up your whole room at night. However if you want it to act as a night light, you can set it on the brightest setting.

Also, I find this useful when charging my little speaker I use with my CD player. This alarm clock has two USB charging ports which is very convenient. I can charge my kindle and the speaker at the same time! If you have a cell phone or iPad you keep by the bed, this is also a good feature as there is also a line-in jack so you can play music from your phone on the alarm clock speaker.

The only negative I'd say is the AM radio which does not seem to work very well.

The instruction book is however great and makes setting this clock up easy. It seems the company who makes this alarm clock really did think of everything. My favorite thing to do is climb into my warm bed, put on the radio with one touch of a button and read to my heart's content.

I think you will love this alarm clock and it doesn't take up a lot of room on your nightstand.

~The Rebecca Review

OnePlus already has standard buds which are more expensive than these. I've tried those and was fairly impressed with them for the price compared to other leading brands (*cough* airpods). I'll be honest, I wasn't sure what to expect here with these "Nord" brand ones. Nord is supposed to be OnePlus' value brand, and the price reflects that. I've tried out headphones that cost more than this which I didn't care for, so I was a little anxious.
However, I have to admit I'm fairly impressed. They sound better to me than other wireless earbuds at this price range. While they aren't as well made as the standard Oneplus buds, they aren't bad at all, especially for the money. Much like the Nord phones themselves, Oneplus seems to know how to make a value product that punches way above its price tag.
I know the brand has taken a hit lately with their Android 12 offerings (still holding out for OOS13 to fix this colorOS mess they are in), but I can say with confidence that their earbuds are pretty great and worth considering whether or not you are a fan of the brand.
They lose audio for like .5 seconds, every 20 minutes, I also thought the ear shape would be useful but it actually hurts my ear somewhat, If i use for more than an hour

I have been using this kind of mouse for the last 10 years and I bought mine from Fry's Electronics and it's time to leave a review about this product. This mouse by far is probably the only mouse you'll ever need, It works in Macs, Windows and even Linux OS. This mouse is great specially when you're playing 8 ball pool in Miniclip.com. It also helps to prevent having cramps if you're using a mouse all the time and you really don't need to move this unit for the cursor/pointer moves every time you move it with your index finger and the controls are on your thumbs. I had terrible cramps every time I'm using a regular mouse but not with this mouse and I'm glad I don't have those cramps anymore. This is another great product made by the people from Logitech and I highly recommend this!

These headphones had a mixed reaction in my household. My daughter at twelve likes to spend some time with headphones on connected to her MP3 player. She has literal headphones. I showed her these headphones- or ear buds with loops on them- and asked if she would try them.

Her reaction was that she did not really like them because they had a suction and made it feel uncomfortable on her ears. They did stay in place very well and allowed her to do a lot of activities she could not do with her headphones on. She just couldn't see to get past the suction feeling.

I, on the other hand, like the tight fitting ear rubberized buds because they lock into the ears and close out interfering noise which I appreciate when working outside and trying to block out annoying noise like our next door drummer on days when I just don't want to hear it.

The earphones are comfortable and do stay in place well for activities like gardening and running. They are nice.

Some people might not be able to get past the suction feeling, but if you can, these are nice and will stay in place during active times.

Based on the reviews of these wireless phones, I was concerned that they might not be large enough for my head and neck, and if said head and neck were any larger/thicker, they would likely be too small. (I wear a size 7-1/8 hat and my neck is 16 inches in diameter.) However, they fit fine, and seem nicely comfortable and lightweight. The phones do seem rather delicate, so I'm not sure they'd do well at the bottom of a gym bag or left unprotected in direct sunlight on a hot car seat or dash.

I had no problem charging and pairing the headset with my Samsung Infuse 4G i997. The sound quality is not bad for the price point. I found I had to dial back on the bass settings using my Poweramp player, but the player seems to work well with the phones. I also bought a Kinovo Bluetooth USB adapter for my laptop, but haven't attempted that pairing yet. (Also haven't made or received any phone calls, but music quality and comfort are my primary focus.)

Overall, three hours after receiving the items I'm very happy with the "Kinovo Experience." Will re-post if my opinion changes.

Bad fit, terrible sound. I put these things in and in but a moment could tell I made a mistake. Sound was muddy and the fit was wonky. My 20 dollar anker earbuds sound and feel better. The search for a real upgrade to them continues...

When I talk to my friends for hours on end the last thing I want to do is hold my iPhone in my hand up to my ear or even be on speaker phone. My husband does not like hearing the speaker phone when he's trying to concentrate on his iPhone. It takes too much effort to talk on a speaker phone for hours. So as soon as I answer the phone I switch over to these headphones and talk through the microphone in the headphones. Perfect!

My friend who calls me once a week sounds like a radio DJ, in fact he used to be one but the headphones make him sound that way just naturally. It is really cute. He's always had a nice voice but this makes him come through like rich stereo sound. At first I thought I was talking to a stranger, but got used to his new voice sound.

You just have to hold the button down for a few seconds and an AI voice tells you what the headphones are doing. So if you are finished with the headset you just press the middle button and it tells you the headset is off. So that saves on battery power and makes it easy to know when the power is on or off. I find that I can make these the best volume easily and have it now where I don't need to change it at all.

My friend who calls me every week told me about these headphones and I bought them on his recommendation. I had these years before I got an iPhone because I prepare ahead of time!!!! Now that I have a new iPhone 14 I'm happy as can be with my headset. Since the microphone is built in this is perfect for phone calls but it also works like a regular headphone if you want to listen to audio on your phone. I haven't started listening to music on it yet but will report back when I do. The sound is just superior to any headphones besides my AKG K553s.

~The Rebecca Review

I really love this tablet aside from the poor sound and very short battery life. I'm sending it back because I use it for watching movies which I can barely hear. I turned off the power settings which causes the low sound and now the battery dies after watching 15 minutes of a movie. I wish it was better.

Update: Returned this Memo Pad and purchased a Lenovo Yoga which is amazing. It has Dolby sound, great front speakers, and a 16 hour battery life. Please do not buy this Memo Pad. The sound and battery are horrible compared to other tablets. Save yourself the return. The people writing comments must work for the company because the product is defective.

The good news is that it DOES work, and sounds pretty decent for a cheap no-name brand. If you've installed a double din stereo before, it should be pretty familiar and straight forward.
But let's just jump right into the odd design. Why is there an "external mic" option that is RIGHT NEXT to the internal mic? Usually an external mic is supposed to be mounted somewhere closer to the driver's mouth (up by the visor or mirror, or over the dash by the steering wheel, etc). The purpose is to get better sound, and either having the internal one as a backup if you don't want to mount one, or using it to pick up ambient background noise for NR filtering. Having an external nub right next to the internal one makes ZERO sense at all! Why even have one?! If anything, making it lower than the internal one seems like it would get WORSE sound, and if the position were so good, why not make THAT where the internal one is? Not to mention it looks weird as heck.
The features seem to be functional at least, but it has a pretty noticeable lag to the user interface. If you're expecting an OEM style menu experience, you might be disappointed. This feels like an old-school web browser loading pages when you open up a feature. Compared to modern units like, for example an Atoto F7, this feels like something a generation older at least.
I want to give this at least 3 stars for functional purposes, but the truth is I know that you get a much better unit for not a lot of money more. I can't really recommend it unless it is on an extreme sale.

I was not ready to invest in a set of Apple, Bose, or Sony headphones, yet I was afraid to buy the cheapest headphones available. i wanted something that wouldn't ruin my music, or break the bank, and based upon other reviews, I believe I found a happy medium with these Anker headphones The bass doesn't sound over amplified, or pushed and it has a nice balance in the mid and high ranges.

At first I used it with my phone, and was terribly disappointed, but on my computer and other bluetooth sound systems, they sounded fantastic. I later learned I would have to re download my entire Apple Music library to enjoy higher bit rate music, so I primarily use these with other devices.

The battery life it amazing. I have not had to charge them in almost a month after daily use of an hour or so. When the battery does get low it takes only a few minutes to get hours of use thanks to its quick charge technology.

They are lightweight, comfortable, and the sound quality is surprising decent for an inexpensive set of headphones. About my only complaint would be that the controls are not as intuitive as I would like, but overall I am very pleased with this purchase, and would highly recommend them.

[[VIDEOID:43c05867cbfd5de7e61827ebef7e53fa]] In my opinion this soundbar is just as good as any high end version- the sound quality for us is perfect.

I purchased three of these stylus and use one each for my HP Omen with Windows 10, my Google Nexus 7 Android Device, and my Apple iPad Pro 12.9. They all work wonderfully. With the number of things these headphones can do, it almost seems like you could ask them to make you a sandwich and the response would be, 'do you want tomatoes, yes or no?'

They do not pinch my head nor do they slide off if I happen to be walking around while wearing them.¬† They aren't as hot and thus sweaty as my old wireless set. ¬†

The noise cancellation is almost too good.¬† I didn't hear the bus arriving or a car honking at me when I was waiting to cross the street.¬† Even with the sound turned down low I could still hear it while standing next to a busy street.
It worked using the alexa voice commands and making a phone call was easy and worked just fine and the sound was good.¬† Even without a boom it had a good mic and people understood everything I said without distortion.
The only thing I didn't like is that they cup the ear and press on underside of my ear at the eustachean tube (not a doctor) and it was a bit irritating after a while.¬†¬†

I wish they were a different color, brown is just the ugliest color and I don't know why everything this year is some vile shade of mud.
needed a bit longer cable than came with speakers, this works great!

My first pair, one of the earbuds the sound got really low, nothing worked to fix it. Returned for replacement.
Second pair, after a couple of months the same thing happened, but now they are out of warranty and I cannot replace them. I did not pay $200 for 1.5 years of use, this is BS. never again, will buy Airpods as much as I dislike Apple.. Reading online it looks like this is very common.

Edit: Added one star back, just tried using them again after 4 months and they are working again! Also, I deleted the app and reinstalled it, including the earbuds plugin. Make sure to delete the app completely by going through all the apps installed. Wait about two weeks and reinstall the app. This is what I did, might work for you. Also make sure to drain the earbuds completely, plug them in to charge and while they charge connect them through the freshly installed galaxy app.

I've tried out several sleep masks and this one is BY FAR the most comfortable both in material and speaker size/positioning. The eye holes are covered with a very soft fabric and the piece covering the nose is breathable while keeping the light out. The headphones are small but mighty - great for a back or side sleeper! I was a little concerned with being able to feel the charging cord, but even with it on my pillow side, I haven't noticed a thing. Pairs seamlessly with my cell phone for listening to music or even taking a phone call. Highly recommended!
What a great idea of placing these on the edge of the desk.  if you are in need of a USB extension and not also requiting a powered connection this works great and can place clamped to a desk.

Although the JBL Balboa Sub10 delivers very good performance for a relatively modest price, I would never refer to it as "the little subwoofer that could." That's because it's far from little; this thing is quite big by my standards. However, considering that the function of a subwoofer is to reproduce low-pitched audio frequencies, I'll accept that fact that it's the size it needs to be do its job well.

Because I live in a multi-family building and have neighbors with which I share walls, I have not been able to crank up the volume beyond medium. That being said, I have been quite pleased with the bass sound and have not experienced any distortion with this subwoofer at the volume range that I have used. Audiophiles who do not have cost as an object will no doubt want a more expensive subwoofer than the Sub10. However, for the rest of us who are just looking for a dependable, reasonably priced subwoofer for our sound systems, the JBL Balboa Sub10 is a worthy contender.

As someone who wears headphones often (I've worn out more than one set) I really appreciate these. They are so comfortable. The sound is wonderful and the mike works perfectly (great for recording and dictation.)

Best of all, the USB connection makes set-up a breeze. I have several microphones and a set of speakers--no confusion! Everything just works when I want it too. LOVE!

This is a great TV!

Don't waste money on a 1080p picture. The 720p/1080i picture of this TV is indistinguishable from 1080p.

The SCREEN BURN is slightly annoying, but nothing to get into a stink over. You'll only notice ghost images if you look for them, and they are not permanent.

The REFLECTION for the plasma was also a concern for me, given that my TV is in a room with six foot by six foot plate glass windows. I hardly notice reflection unless the images on the screen are pitch black.

Other reviews speak of the infamous PLASMA HUM; I don't hear it.
The SPEAKERS on this TV are perfectly acceptable.

For additional research on plasmas, I found a great link:
Benefits & Misconceptions about Plasma
[...]

I ordered this mouse for my wife to use with her new Chromebook & she loves it. She likes the large, domed style with the thumb relief & hasn't been happy since her old Microsoft mouse died. It has more buttons than I know how to use (forward & back on the thumb side). I'm not sure if she even uses the thumbwheel but it is large, grippy & rolls smooth with light detents. We have been using it on a finished wood table & it moves smoothly & doesn't have any issues with the laser reading. The mouse requires the included USB, receiver dongle which stores in the bottom of the mouse & is easy to swap between computers.
I had to look up what the CPI adjustment button is but it is pretty handy in that the speed of the mouse can be adjusted from just the button on top. The mouse takes a single 'AA' battery. I prefer my rechargeable mouse but this is better for her.

I selected this mouse/keyboard combo to work with a laptop I use every day. I wanted a full-sized keyboard and I was less concerned about the mouse because I prefer trackballs anyway. So far I have no complaints at all about this combo set, though I am especially pleased with the keyboard.

This is a basic mouse/keyboard combo that connects via an RF receiver. The keyboard is a full-sized US layout keyboard, and the mouse is a basic 3-button mouse. These are marketed as having silent keys and clicks, and that interested me in particular.

The keyboard is indeed nearly silent. I love the quiet operation and I love the feel of the keys themselves - they have a soft-down feel when pressed. I read one of the other reviews that stated that the keys stick a little, and I have not found that to be the case for me. The mouse is also quiet and it seems to work well, though it is nothing special.

This combo works well under Windows 10, Windows 11 and Linux. I have not tried it elsewhere though I have no reason to believe it wouldn't work on other platforms.

I am very happy with this combo set and expect years of service from it. It does live up to the claim that operation is very quiet, the keys have a nice feel to them, and the combo is priced reasonably.

I have been using the Bose Companion Series 3 speakers with my desktop computer, and was happy with that setup. However, I decided to try something different. I purchased a Lepai amp from Amazon and after reading the reviews of the small speakers on Amazon, decided this was the best deal. These speakers are a steal. Great sound and incredible bass for such small speakers. I could not be more happy with these.
Update: Now that I have been listening to this speakers for a couple of months, I swear they sound even better than before. Even more happy with them.....

Needed to plug in lights and speaker system behind bookshelf in our home. The low profile plug is amazing and the USB ports let us plug in an Amazon Echo on a shelf as well. All wires are hidden behind the shelf so everything looks really clean and nice now. Perfect!
Sent a not NEW LPN returned camera with the tamper seal broken.  This is the second time !  Misleading ad.

-sound quality not the best

It's pretty amazing to me that you can pack so much data now in such a tiny drive. It's about the same size as my Logitech mouse "nano" receiver.

The drive capacity is almost exactly 32 billion bytes (that's really 29.8GB, not 32GB, but the marketers have defeated the engineers on this). For some reason it was connecting at USB2 on my front port, where other USB3 drives connect just fine. Once I got it connected on another port at USB3, I did see better behavior. However, file transfer speeds are limited by Windows (and perhaps my computer hardware) more than anything else. Even transferring to/from an internal SSD drive I didn't get sustained speeds over about 38MB/s (that's megabytes, not megabits). I've read tech journals that say that the smaller USB3 drives can't transfer at the same speeds as the super-duper larger ones, but for real-world file transfer (as opposed to lab benchmarks) it doesn't seem to matter. Suffice it to say that I get about 10x speeds on USB3 drives vs. USB2 drives, and this one works as well as my other USB3 drives.

The drive came with a basic file encryption program (you can download it from the Lexar website as well). This easy-to-use program encrypts files using AES-256 (more detail wasn't given); you can buy an upgraded version which allows upto AES-1024, and has a few other features. Each file you encrypt is stored in a separate folder hierarchy (labeled the Vault), there isn't a separate encrypted file system. It's probably secure enough for general consumer use, and is certainly a convenience making it easy to protect your data. There was a Windows version and an Apple version of the program, so I think it means that encrypted files can be shared with either type of system. Not being a Mac user, I couldn't verify this.

Overall, this is a very nice product for an attractively low price. There are 64GB and 128GB versions as well for those who need more storage.

I have worked with a lot of Bluetooth speakers and I have seen a good variety in features and sound quality. I have a set of Monster headphones and they are excellent; I expected the same from this speaker. It‚Äôs a good speaker, but it has a weakness in the sound profile.

It pairs and connects quickly and without any issue. I was able to connect it to my computer without any problems and it was ready to go in less than 20 seconds. In terms of connection speed via Bluetooth, this one is slightly faster than most.

I really like the fact that the speaker has a slider switch for power instead of a button you have to hold down. It makes knowing the speaker is on very simple and it also makes it very simple to power off. This is a big plus to me and is one of the best features in my mind.

I tested the sound quality fairly extensively and make a few important observations, most of which were positive but there was one important issue. The speaker has good volume (controlled by the source) and excellent operational range - I went as far as 30‚Äô and there were no cut-outs or crackles, a good sign. The sound profile though is slightly problematic. The bass is strong - very strong - and is enough to dominate the whole sound output. Many speakers and headsets are heavy-handed on the bass, so this is not totally unexpected but is a bit heavy for my tastes. The highs are good and everything is clear and crisp. The midrange is very flat to the point of being practically non-existent, likely because the bass is as high as it is. Because the midrange is so flat, the output has a tendency to be dull and lifeless.

This is not a bad speaker and it is a decent choice if you want a small and strong speaker. But, be aware that the sound profile is unbalanced.

I really like the AmazonBasics line. This case fits the new iPad Pro 10.5 inch models. It has the wake/sleep feature, the ability to use it as a stand by wrapping the front of the case under the tab in the back. It says it is also supposed to have an elastic piece to hold a pro pen, but my model does not have that little piece of elastic. As for functionality, it works well. I don't expect a case to last on my iPad for its life, because like my phone, when I see a case that intrigues me, I have to get it. All of the slots are where they are supposed to be, so you don't have to remove the case to charge or insert audio plugs.

I'm very impressed with the quality of this keyboard cover. I honestly was not expecting to be as nice as it is.

I can speak from experience when I say that cats, coffee, and a MacBook are NOT a great combination. I lost an earlier MacBook Pro when cat and coffee collided over the keyboard, so when I purchased my new MacBook Air 13", I knew I wanted a keyboard cover.

This one has a lot going for it. It fits beautifully -- lays flat, the key covers are precisely where they should be, there's no slippage or any feeling of insecurity about the cover shifting position. It's transparent except for the colored key caps, so the underlighting of the MacBook Air keyboard shines through. It's quite thin so it doesn't add much in the way of bulk, either -- but the material feels like it will survive heavy use without tearing or puncturing.

I especially like having all the keyboard shortcuts printed right on the keys themselves. My version, the OX X shortcuts, is easy to read, and the colors actually mean somthing (blue = primary shortcuts, pink = finder, green = safari, orange = iWorks/Mail/MS Office). It's a nice touch that lends a bit of color to the rather drab aluminum face of the MacBook.

If you've never typed on a keyboard with a cover, it might take a little getting used to. It has a "softer" feel, but key action/etc. is not compromised at all.

Overall, I think this is a good product, a nice gift for someone with a new MacBook, with bult-in usefulness beyond protecting the keyboard from inadvertent spills and dust.

(Although a sample was supplied for review purposes, opinions expressed are based on my personal experience with this product.)

Time stamp for this camera is incorrect, so I downloaded the OD Cam hoping to be able to set the time. After the camera has been powered up, you single click the power button to activate wi-fi. You will hear a voice say wi-fi on and you'll see a blue led light blink along next to the solid green light.

But it would never connect to the camera. The app is pretty quirky, half-baked. Once you turn on the app, it's immediately working, it will say "Connecting device..." But what is it doing? I haven't even selected their wi-fi SSID yet. Well, even after selecting the "EP7_XXXX" id, the password of 12345678 doesn't work. It keeps saying "check wi-fi and try again," then you'll hear the lady voice saying, "Wi-fi off." So it automatically turns off the wi-fi once you can't connect.

So I've been using this without the app, and without proper time stamp. There is a learning curve to understanding the camera angles when you're wearing it on your head. The camera can swivel, so you can record your funky toes, or point it up and record your water stained ceilings. LOL! Once you're happy with your recording, you can take it to your pc to view your files. There is no need to remove the micro sd card. When you plug it into your pc, the lady voice will prompt you to press the video button for removable storage mode, or the photo button for webcam mode.

Video quality is not that great, so I'm subtracting 1 star for that. I'm also subtracting another star for the half-baked app and connection process.

I purchased two [[ASIN:B0036RA5EA Allsop Metal Art Junior Monitor Stands]] for my work monitors. Since I have my own monitor for my other computer, I also wanted a monitor stand for that which is why I ordered this.

This one is very nice but it is larger than I expected. It is 20 inches wide (side-to-side) and 11-1/2" in depth (front to back) where as my Allsop stands are each 14-3/4" x 11" respectively. Had I purchased two of these for my work monitors, I could not fit them on my desk.

Nevertheless, this mesh stand is beautifully made and has a drawer that easily slides in and out. The front drawer is protected in back from sliding out the other side. The right side pockets offer additional storage. If one has the room, this stand is perfect.

This would have received five stars from me except that it is not level. As you can see in the first picture, one leg is a half inch too short so it tilts back and forth like an uneven chair. However, once the monitor is on the stand, it is not too noticeable. Due to the large size, I am using this to elevate a speaker I have and since it is sitting on carpet, the uneven leg is not an issue for me.

I always thought I wanted these speakers for my patio. We do have some Bose outdoor speakers connected to the house under the patio and they have worked fine. Now, after you go through WWIII with your spouse (because he will invariably press the reset the button and turn his rock off) and finally figure out how to get the speakers to pair (take your finger off the button when it says it is pairing). Then you can turn on iPhone or whatever smart device you have and turn your Bluetooth on your phone on. Then select a song and play. Your phone volume up and down is what makes the speakers go up and down. One more thing - everytime you want to use the speakers, you will have to haul them in to where you have a laptop or computer and charge them for 4-5 hours. Then take them back outside where you want to let them make sound for you. Yes, you will have to go through the speaker pairing again until you hear the speaker says "your device is connected". Then turn the Bluetooth on your smart device back on and connect via your phone again.

I purchased this for my '05 Subaru Outback, which was made before the days of USB ports and 3.5mm jacks being regular features of cars. I used this in conjunction with two other devices - an iSimple IS31 (ASIN: B002U5XPBE) and a YIPIN HEXHA Quick Charge QC3.0 USB Step Down Converter (ASIN: B0918CR35N), as well as a couple cable adapters. I installed it in the oddball center compartment above the Subaru's media console, so it is normally out of sight, and I can store any cables plugged into it in the compartment when no device is in use. The step-down adapter ties into a cigarette lighter which is inactive when the car is not turned on.

I checked my dimensions and runs first, deciding to install near the media console and run the wires behind the radio. I already had the iSimple and its own audio jack installed in the center console, so I was just going to tie this into the existing setup. Install was easy, if a bit fraught, due to the brittleness of 15+ year old vinyl and having one-shot at drilling the hole for it. I forewent the rubber gasket to I'd have a more flush mount, so you have to get the dimensions right within 1/16". I ended up using a stepper bit, and then an X-Acto to finish the hole.

The port sits quite nicely in place, the included nut makes it easy to tighten everything down. You might want a little bit of threadlocker on there so it doesn't vibrate loose, but it's not strictly necessary. You can shave down the back of this adapter a bit if you need the wires to make a tighter bend - I had to do so - but be careful, naturally. The port, even without the gasket, sits about 1/8" over the surface of the panel, so it isn't perfectly flush. However, it is tight enough that it is out of the way and will probably look more or less in place on a black panel.

For me, exercising care to get everything looking nice and clean and stock, it took about two hours total, not including the iSimple install - which was about two hours itself, with the same level of care - and the step-down converter, which was maybe 30m with the soldering.

So far the unit performs perfectly, power is transferred without issue - it seems to charge quickly, but I can't attest to full QC3 compatibility. The only odd-ball issue is that it looks like USB connectors don't seat all the way into the USB jack - some silver is exposed, more than you would expect. Not sure why this is, but it is the same with multiple USB plugs. Doesn't affect functionality, but might give you pause or encourage you to try pushing in hard to get it to seat fully.

Would recommend.

I purchased four Bluetooth speakers for my house over a several year period. I have a [[ASIN:B007ZG03DG Bose Wave Bluetooth Music Adapter]], which is not very good and a [[ASIN:B00MPMK3GW Goal Zero 94014 Rock Out 2 Green Solar Rechargeable Speaker]] which does not work when paired with some devices and, when it does pair well, it usually lacks the powerful sound I am looking for.

I also purchased an [[ASIN:B00SNBCBBY ION Audio Block Rocker (iPA76A) | Portable Bluetooth Speaker]] at Costco which I absolutely love. As a result, I wanted another one of these but they were no longer available at Costco and I did not want to pay more for it on Amazon. Therefore, Costco had this speaker for $79.99 plus tax. Although, I love my Block Rocker a tad more (because I do not like the lights on this one), this is an excellent speaker. It pairs well with many devices including my Nexus 7, HP Omen, and iPad Pro. The sound is powerful and seems like surround sound indoors. I purchased both ION speakers for indoors but they are more for an outdoor environment.

When indoors, the AM/FM radio does not work well even with the antenna. I also do not need the microphone feature and do not like the lights for my purposes. If I were running a disco or was just playing music for a party, then I would love the lights. There are many versions of the lights including a star formation, pulsating to music type lights, just a movement of light colors, etc.Every time I turn the unit on, I have to cycle through all the light settings to turn the lights off. I wish it remembered my last setting but it does not. What I do like is that it automatically turns on Bluetooth and is ready for pairing. My other ION always require I wait a few seconds and then press a Bluetooth button to start the pairing. This speaker has the option but it is usually not needed. Also, the battery lasts a long time. I have used it for several hours already and it remains fully charged based on the indicator.

I love this speakers sound. It is extremely powerful and loud. The extra I am free to ignore.

The Jawbone speaker looks good, is small and light enough and can be easily carried but the sound quality is poor "tinny".  Purchased a Bose bluetooth speaker instead and am 100% satisfied with it's performance.

Most people who have set up audio video systems have had the frustrating experience of reaching the final step only to realize they were missing a critical cable. Many people spend large amounts of money of the newest audio / video technology then use old cables which, in essence inserts a weak link. The quality of the final signal can only be as good as the weakest link - that certainly shouldn‚Äôt come from a cable.

This is a high quality 6ft HDMI Cables with 24K gold plated ports capable of high speed data transmission. It is made with the newest technologies in mind. It is robust enough to handle 8K and is built to last.

I‚Äôve found 6ft HDMI cables are the perfect length most of the time for connecting the majority of entertainment systems - cable box to TV, DVD player to TV, game consoles to TV, sound bar or system to TV. Having the terminals played in 24K gold is the standard in top quality audio / video transmission.

In regards to the quality of the materials and craftsmanship - this is an outstanding cable that everyone will have use for at some point. This is a perfect cable for any home entertainment center.

This cable is an excellent value that I would definitely recommend.

I really wanted to love this keyboard. Having a wireless keyboard to type on a propped up laptop while studying was my solution to really bad back pains. And for the first 2 days I loved this keyboard. The keys don't jiggle when typing, everything about the look/design/feel is sleek and smooth. The integration with my macbook and my iphone was seamless. The keys fought off dust and crumbs for a week.

HOWEVER:

1) Please be wary of the fragility of some of the keys. I had only been using the keyboard for the first day or so when I noticed that my "-" (dash key) was loose. Upon further investigation with a magnifying glass, a small piece of plastic had been broken, which was why I couldn't snap the key back into place. I don't bang keys loudly or carelessly when I typed, and given that I hadn't had the keyboard for very long, I assumed it the product arrived with a defective key. After a few days, I looked at my F2 key (bluetooth key)- I touched this key maybe ONCE while connecting to my iPhone- and found it LOOSE! I can't snap it back into place because of the same broken plastic issue.

2) Logitech does not have/provide spare keys: When I called Logitech to inquire about spare board keys (rather than returning the entire keyboard to Amazon, because I did really love it besides this key popping problem), the customer service representative offered to replace the entire keyboard, which is great, but he also made mention of the fact they they DID NOT MAKE/PROVIDE spare keys for this model. This means that in the future, if just one key becomes problematic, the customer will have to go through the struggles of shipping out the entire keyboard, etc. I confirmed with the customer service representative that they did IN FACT not make spare keys (I was shocked), but perhaps I had spoken with a particularly new/tired/unversed representative.

All that being said, I am awaiting for a replacement from Amazon (I figured the shipping would be faster w/Amazon's superb customer service), and will see whether the new keyboard presents with problematic keys.
Hope the above two caveats help.

Clipping (AKA crackle) can be heard in loud passages from local FM classical station. It is as if the signal strength is made too strong - but how could that be? Whereas the simple single wire antenna (which just turned up after our latest move) provided with the Sony box works fine. Could it be that the Bingfu antenna overdrives the 75 OHM FM antenna input?  But how could that be? Or perhaps the antenna itself has a weak internal connection that fails to carry the most strong signal? FM is Frequency Modulation, not Amplitude Modulation so the amplitude stays the same, right? So why clipping? OK. You get the idea. This Bingfu goes into the junk box for reuse as... what.

**update** these headphones have been great until recently. Even though the battery is fully charged they will shut off without warning and will not sync when I turn them back off.
These are the best Bluetooth headphones I have ever had. The battery lasts a really long time, they don't fall out when working out, and have a good range for staying connected when walking away from your device.

we've been using this daily for about 8 1/2 hours twice a day in the  milking parlor since it arrived and I honestly think it's one of the best speakers we've had.  The sound quality is great, it lasts through an entire milking (8 1/2 hours) and still has power to spare (one red light is still lit when we plug it in), it's gotten wet, dirty, and been dropped a couple times and it's still going strong!  Honestly I couldn't say enough good things about this speaker!  PLUS, some of the proceeds from the sales go for a great cause,... if you're looking for a wireless speaker, this is a definite winner!

We got this camera so we could check on our dog while we are away from the house. The setup was pretty easy and quick. It comes with a cable to connect it to the Ethernet or you can use the WiFi. My biggest complaint about this camera is the app used for it. The app is what needs work. It‚Äôs clunky. Very clunky. Also the instructions on it aren‚Äôt great, and the app it seems like the text was written by a non native English speaker.
The two way communication function works, but‚Äôs it‚Äôs not great. It does cut out intermittently, so we use it primary only for the camera function. I don‚Äôt know if I would buy this camera for another room in my house, I would probably want to try another brand with a stronger app.
Love the JBL Speaker. Easy to pair with phone. Sound quality is great!
the part where you scroll up and down the volume broke apart after first few days. I spent more money on different microphone instead.
Needed something to allow me to easily hang my JBL speaker, this fits the bill nicely. Not a single complaint.

These live up to the brand and quality of Nautica.. hands down they did not disappoint! Ordered in navy- I love these were Nautica‚Äôs signature color- very sleek and sharp looking. A switch to the latest iPhone had us in need of a wireless option.. and these stepped up to the task.

Impressive sound quality- we needed no nonsense and dependable option to conduct corporate business from home. What better endorsement then to report-headphones surpassed expectations in functionality and no tech failures.. along with a crispness and clarity in verbiage. Nothing muffled or distorted by poor sound.. word recognition was precise- which is a huge plus with business dealings in finite numbers/details! There‚Äôs no room for error which is a lot of pressure for any headset and yet, these stepped up!!

Love the ease one can switch from music to phone- buttons are easily accessible and no nonsense to use.. the kind you memorize after x1-2 uses. Loving the ability to hang around the neck.. Trust me you wont misplace as they‚Äôre holding till needed! A perfect feature for exercising.. Magnetic heads come together to secure a complete circle around the neck. Simple overnite charge provides plenty of battery life for the entire next day.. such a nice piece!!

Not just ideal for chit-chatting purposes.. these deliver surprisingly deep bass! Crystal clear sound allows for exceptional acoustics- you can actually hear the precise notes being played.. I‚Äôm impressed and for $40- I have nothing but praises for price, quality and aesthetics.. a total trifecta! Hoping this info helps your decision- stay safe everyone.

As a radio host, a good over the head headphone is a must. I love this noise canceling headphone, as it helps me concentrate hosting the show, and the design is so simple and fresh. The sound qualoity is amazing! I'm enjoying the music I am playing!
This soundbar provides great sound and is very easy to install. It's nice-looking, small, and fits under our monitor. We like it very much.

The headphones were pretty good given the price. I was looking for a standard, comfortable quality cheaper set for airplane rides or relaxing at home and saw this product. It doesn't feel flimsy or cheap quality, but for some reason, mine stopped working in less than a month. I do know I dropped it from my bed to the floor, but that shouldn't have caused the headphones to break entirely (no physical damage as it was maybe a 2 foot drop).

Going to look out for another pair of headphones, maybe a better known brand and hopefully will not have to re-order after that.

Edit: Rachel from oneodio reached out (without me having to even contact them myself) and worked with me to get a replacement sent over. Received it and it's working great like before!

Purchased this to have remote control of my iPod Classic when playing through my home audio system. Remote works great and overall I am satisfied. The ONLY flaw is the audio quality when connected through the unit base. Audio is low and distorted when connected via the base...solution, plug audio into the iPod headphone jack. For the price, this product is an excellent choice.

I‚Äôm a trucker and my radio in my truck does not have Bluetooth, but it does have an auxiliary jack - which is needed to use this. Pairing was very easy and pairs automatically after setup. Sound quality I think is quite good. I stream Sirius from my phone. Battery seems to last 4 - 5 . It comes with a cig lighter type plug to charge it, but I don‚Äôt use it and directly plug in the charging cable to the transmitter so I can leave it in the radio jack. I‚Äôm very pleased with this unit.

Ok, I can't give you the detailed run down of all the good and amazing things those speakers can do (not a tech buff), BUT, they sound soooo much better than my old set. I originally bought them for my TV/Receiver, since our boxes there don't do much anymore. I (again not tech person) had no idea that those can't be used with my yamaha receiver, so this is something to keep in mind while ordering them. I decided to use them with my PC, since I listen to a lot of Pandora and I can tell you, the difference is astounding. We had a pretty good set of PC speakers and we do listen to a lot of rock and metal music, but those blew me away. They are a bit pricy for PC speakers, but I will keep them anyway, the sound is just too good.

The equipment I needed to connect didn't have RCA ports, but had a 1/4 inch stereo port. This adapter got the job done! I was able to connect my composite speakers with these adapters. No complaints. 5-Stars!
Perfect case for my speaker

This little speaker has incredible sound even with the water running.  The sound is clear, very easy to setup and use.right out of the box. Battery life seems to be great if you power off each time. Also, the bluetooth has a pretty good range for when you leave your phone else in the house. This has a visual and voice to let one know when it is powered on or off.

I am not a fan of these earbuds - which is no surprise since I was not a fan of iPhone earbuds. I just can't get these situated in my ears properly without hurting. I just have an issue with quite a few earbuds and end up using earphones instead, which is not easy if you are trying to sleep. The sound is okay and my granddaughter will most likely love these - they will match her mouse.

I like the versatility of this mount. Many options to mount a camera or phone using the screw with the platform that folds to different angles, or using the clamp. Ability to mount an external light is nice. Feels like a solid unit, and it quite stable. The legs are plastic and do not have a real positive lock when open, so it doesn't feel as stable as I'd like when fully extended. Overall it's a decent compact mount to carry around for the price.

I bought a blur set from this company because it was Amazon's choice and had good reviews.  However after about 4 months having it it died and will no longer turn on. Also the battery life I'd about 8 hours at best. I have had different earbuds that lasted for a whole 24 hours before needing charing

THE GOOD:
--------------
* You get two headphones.
* Colors are perfect if you happen to have one boy, and one girl.
* Bonus headphone jack splitter is included.
* Built in microphone.
* Headphones are limited to 94db safe volume.
* Ear muffs are very comfy.

THE BAD:
-----------
* Nothing at all. Because of Covid, schools are asking that our kids bring our own headphones for computer time. These are perfect for that purpose. 5-Stars!

These seem a bit fragile, but I've used and abused them now for a while and they've held up like champs. Sound is clear and nice, though lows are not too pronounced. For the price, get a few pair. Well worth it!

The headphones are great. They sound amazing and the quality is terrific. I have a serious gripe though with the twisted cable. It tangles constantly. I have let it just sit and spin and it still feels like it wants to bind and tangle up. I really dislike that aspect of these headphones immensely.

First of all, these speakers sound just great, they really do. I'll echo the comments that the cords are an awkward design, depending on where you place them in relation to your sound source and listening position.

The power on-off button is on the top of the subwoofer, but the volume up-down control is on one of the satellites. And the sub's level control is on the sub itself. Aside from just plain being a bit weird, it means you're going to have to keep both the sub and one of the satellites within easy reach. Also, the cord that connects to your sound source is attached to the sub (as is the power cord); combined with the controls on the sub, this is just plain awkward. I'm using these speakers at work, and I have the sub on the floor under my desk. I'm controlling the volume from iTunes, so that's cool. But it would be very annoying if I had to be using the speaker's controls all the time.

A minor annoyance is the shape of the metal legs for the satellites. They are sturdy and look nice, but they take up much more space on my crowded desk than I'd like. Other speaker systems use more vertically shaped satellite stands, which take up half the space. These satellites are much more squat.

I also have one of the better Logitech 2.1 systems, which also sounds great. But Logitech puts all the controls on a little control unit that you can keep in easy reach. (And also has a headphone output too.) That's a much more convenient design. But between the two, the sound of these Altec Lansing speakers is superior.

Here's the dealmaker for me -- the bass control on the subwoofer can be turned all the way down, so the sub isn't putting out any sound at all. This is a great feature because it lets me play just the satellites late at night, and I'm not disturbing my housemate in the adjoining room.

I've been using this for 3 years now, plugged into the obd2 port for power in driving and parking mode. It has yet to fail, the video is pretty good and the audio is good as well. Temps get pretty extreme here with lows of -60¬∞ F and highs of 110¬∞ F on occasion, it gets much hotter inside the parked car and my cam is still running true!

It's too bad Amazon isn't selling this version anymore, otherwise I would recommend it to anyone and everyone!

I ordered the 'Emart Heavy Duty C Stand Max Height 10ft /300cm, Adjustable Photography Stand with 4.2ft/128cm Holding Arm 2 Pieces Grip Head and Baby Pin for Photography Reflector, Softbox, Monolight' for review and would like to share some of my thoughts.

I have been using this C Stand for some time now and I would like to first say that this is my very first C Stand so I don't have anything to compare it with but I can say that this thing is a beast and is very sturdy. It was very simple to set up and I appreciate the fact that it comes with the Baby Pin, which I use all the time with this stand. My only complaint is that adjusting the arms can be a bit of a pain as you really need to loosen them quite a bit, then pull them apart manually to separate the teeth to allow the arm to freely move. Not having had or used a C Stand before, I am not sure if this is a common issue with other brands or not, but I would think that there would be a spring in the arm mechanics that would push the teeth apart when loosening the clamps and make the adjustments a bit easier.
With that said, I still love this C Stand and would highly recommend it, as it is very well built aside from the clamps issue. It is as described, and very heavy duty indeed.
I have several of these.  They are easy to install and love that I can use one app for all cameras.  Great color and audio

My Pioneer Elite receiver runs super hot, but this really helps cool down it's Passive Radiators. The USB will be great for some people...others may need to go for a 100VAC version. Luckily I was able to snatch a USB output from the cable box.

Recommend, it's pretty quiet and helps cool your equipment down.

my son built a gaming computer last year but I'd bought the case for him - not based on performance but because I thought it looked nice... as it turns out it had no sound dampening padding and it sounded like a jet taking off when it started up and when playing certain games it became such a big concern we took the computer to the local repair shop just to make sure everything was working like it was supposed to.  When the Thermaltake Suppressor tower came up on the Amazon Vine program I jumped at the chance to get him a case with padding to dampen the sound - and so far this has been excellent.  He's opted not to do the water cooled thing since he doesn't overclock his computer and the fans keep it cool enough but it is nice to know that there's plenty of room if he'd like to go that route in the future.  When I first showed my son the picture of the case he was sure the see through side would prevent it from dampening the sound but this case still cut down the noise by probably a good 75%. --- and there's way more room in the case for him to add other components or whatever later down the road.  It's an excellent case and we couldn't be happier.

[[VIDEOID:7cc17d49b6d953fb7dabe1f7014939]] The Sony 65" Bravia XR X90J TV is a super impressive TV. You definitely get what you pay for. Sony is a brand I have trusted for many years. I actually have an older model of this TV that I love and even though it's older, it still works like a gem!

First of all, the instructions for set up are super easy to follow. It comes packaged nicely in a box where it is protected with styrofoam and cardboard. The TV is also covered in plastic for extra protection from scratches. It comes with 2 legs that automatically lock in that does not require any screws or tools whatsoever! The legs are labeled 1 and 2, so pay attention, as there are corresponding numbers on the back of the TV. If you are looking at the back of the TV - 1 is on the left, and 2 is on the right. The TV is lightweight and the legs lock in so easily. I cannot review the wall mounting aspect of this, as I chose to use the included legs.

The back right of the TV has all of the connections: 4 HDMI's (3 & 4 for 4K), cable, remote, ethernet, video in, headphones, optical, and 2 USB's (500 mA Max & 900 mA Max).
The power cord connects on the back left side of the TV.

The remote is super convenient if you use streaming apps! I have YouTube, Netflix, Prime, and Disney Plus. There are buttons for each of these apps which instantly takes you to them. The remote is sleek with a nice design, and is easy to use with no issues.

If you use a Firestick, it connects super easily to the TV. You can still use your FireStick remote if you choose, and get the 4K experience.

We have an older version Xbox One which we connected to it, however it is not 4K. To get the 4K experience, you will need an updated Xbox which has 4K built into it. We chose to disconnect the Xbox and run directly through the TV.

After powering up the TV, you get walked through the setup process. It's very easy to follow and to set up the Wifi. The only thing I didn't care for is that when setting it up, it asks about Samba TV and to sign up for emails and communications. I really don't care for this SPAM and didn't wish to add any additional apps. The set up is through Google TV, which is basically the master for all of the apps.

The refresh rate is amazing. The picture quality at 4K is out of this world. Even the sound quality through the speaker is great without using surround sound! There is also no lagging at all. My TV is in the living room which has a kitchen right behind it. Sometimes the kids are in the kitchen while watching TV and I would notice a glare on the screen on my old TV. With this TV there is NO GLARE!! Which is amazing!

Overall, this TV blew my mind away and it's the best I have ever owned!! If you are looking for a TV with outstanding quality from a trusted brand, then this is it.

Also, the delivery service was different from what I have used before, however they had amazing service and kept me in the loop as to when it would be delivered, and the delivery was perfect!

I've had this camera a few months. The install went pretty well. I had to reboot a few times to pick the camera up, but once it was recognized, that has worked well. The camera does not clamp securely onto my external monitor. I fixed that problem by getting a separate flexible arm that clamps onto my desk and holds the camara. I love the physical lens cover so I can easily control when the camera is capturing an image. The picture quality is great. I love having an external camera instead of relying on the one on my laptop so my laptop can stay connected to the docking station and I don't have to try to get it moved over to the center of my desk every time I have a videoconference. Unfortnately there there are two remaining problems that are making me now decide to look for another camera:

1. Echos: When using this camera, is it causes an echo on videoconferencing that others can hear. I cannot hear it. It is so annoying to others that immediately people start talking about it and asking if the call can be done using some other audio. It definitely happens on Microsoft Teams calls as others have said in the Questions section for this product on Amazon. I can't remember if it happened on Webex videocalls also. Others have said switching the audio source solves that problem.

2. Wide View: This may be standard on these cameras. I'll find out when I shop for a new one, but the view is much wider than my native laptop camera. I can't find any way on the camera to "crop" it so that it shows only the person during videoconference and not a lot of what is to the right and left of the person. I solved that problem by installing OBS Studio and the OBS virtual camera. OBS allows me to crop the picture and then uses that video as the "camera" in Microsoft Teams. That works very well to get a good cropped video, however, the image quality went way down and it freezes up sometimes, so it is not a great solution because I end up not having smooth starts to videoconferences with all the troubleshooting I have to do to get OBS, the webcam, and the conferecing software to all work together.

I hope I can find a camera that works seemlessly so that the now much more frequent videoconferences, thanks to the pandemic, will go more smoothly.

I love this! I have not used the microphone, and may not use it. But, I do a lot of work in my large Garage for ceramic selling online. I spend hours and hours there, always cleaning, organizing, packaging and storing my supplies. So, I love this because it is loud, and I can play it from the Laptop or the Kindle Fire. There are lights. It is not huge, and it is not large, it is just right. I will try to hook it up to the new computer that is minus a tower.

I can carry this to the garage and back to the house. I listen to music all the time. I had no trouble getting it to play. I can use it outside when I work in the yard. There are not a ton of buttons to mess with. It is simple and the sound is wonderful! Battery life seems good. I love this!

It had been a while since we needed to be able to use a device like this, but finally we had the chance. Here is a brief outline of the experience.

WHAT IS THIS LIKE?
This is a power inverter which uses the power of the car to enable you to power up simple things like a laptop (as long as it does not have too high of a draw), cell phones, tablets, etc. You can also use conventional plugs for something like a mattress inflating device etc. The cord is pretty short that comes with it, so you have to have longer cables if you plan to use this in the back.

There is the option to use the cigarette lighter in the front (if you have one) or the battery itself if you are camping for instance using the black and red clamps that come with this.

HOW DOES IT PERFORM?
This is not a "move your house into your car" type item. It is sufficient to charge phones, tablets, laptop that is not too high of a draw, but it is not going to run a household on a campsite. For us inflating a mattress and using it to recharge phones and a tablet for games is what we purposed it for. It performed very well for the task.

CAMPING
Our son who is a bit of an electronic tinkerer managed to get a car battery that was from a junked car, charge it on a charger at home and then take the inverter with him camping using the car battery as the base to work from for the week that he was camping. He ran Christmas lights at night, MP3 player recharged as well as a speakder and then used it sparingly to keep the phones charged and mattresses filled. The inverter worked beautifully and the campsite was the "home away from home"

NOTE ABOUT INSTRUCTIONS
I found the instructions lacking in this, but if you look around online, or have a tinker guy in the house like our son, you will be just fine and find what you need to run it.

THE BOTTOM LINE
For a handy device that works from your car, or as our son rigged up a car batter from a junked car for a camping trip, this is a great little inverter to have. It has short cords, but if you make sure to have longer cords to reach the back seat if traveling, you should be able to make it work.

MY RATING
FIVE STARS. I like this little thing, and even though it is not overly powerful, it suits our needs just fine.
These headphones are amazing!  Fantastic quality at the best price!!  Amazon Basics is the way to go!

I just returned a much more expensive brand of headphones for bad sound and a faulty cord. At less than half the price of the more expensive headset, these are just amazing. The sound is great and they work very well for meetings and things. I don't happen to be a gamer, so I can't speak to that, but they are absolutely fabulous for regular use.

These are really, really high quality earbuds, especially for the price. The sound quality is actually pretty amazing. I had a middling-quality pair of those "Inked" earbuds attached to my laptop at work. The sound quality was always disappointing, but I had sort of assumed that it was probably due to the laptop sound card, etc. Then today I attached my new Sony Fontopias and wow...what a difference! Yes, they have bass boost, but not so much that it overwhelms the music.

These headphones are also surprisingly comfortable. They aren't the typical in-ear shape that gets jammed all the way into your ear, but there's a little more to them than the default "sort of hang in the outer part of your ear" that you get with the default iPod earbuds, for example. I like the hybrid, in-between quality and they fit me pretty well. They're not noise-cancelling, but the sound is so good that I really don't notice other office sounds (not even my disgusting cubicle neighbor who eats cookies like the Cookie Monster and sounds completely disgusting - now you know why I need to listen to music at work!). I'm so happy with the sound quality and comfort of these headphones, I'm willing to give then four stars in spite of one very major drawback:

THE CORD IS RIDICULOUSLY SHORT.

I have NEVER seen such a short cord on any pair of headphones, earbuds, headset, etc. that I have owned. I measured the cord from the jack to the point where the "Y" that goes to each individual bud starts, and it is barely 2 feet. TWO FEET! People, that is SHORT. So I'm going to go to Radio Shack at lunch today and buy an extension cord/adapter. So unless you're going to sit right next to the source you are connecting the headphones to, whether it's a computer or MP3 player or stereo, you'll need to add the cost of an extension cable to the price. Trust me - it's way too short as sold, like it wouldn't even stretch from my iPod in a backpack to my ears if I was walking around.

Otherwise, awesome headphones.

The Hyperion auto dash camera is a decent dash cam for the money. It is easy to install and the suction cup holder is very secure. You can choose three different video resolutions; 1296P, 1080P, or 720P. The higher the resolution the shorter the recording duration before the video starts loop recording. You can increase memory by inserting a higher capacity memory card, it comes with a 16GB memory card installed already and it can take a 32GB or up to a 64GB memory card. The recording modes/video files are, Crash detected, Loop-recording, Parking and Photo. You can plug your camera to you computer with the supplied cable to transfer the videos or you can pop out the memory card and put it in a card reader on your computer to transfer the videos. You can also update the camera the same way, if there is an update to the camera.

The camera has other functions as well, it has Advanced Driver Assistance Systems (ADAS), Lane Departure Warning System (LDWS), Front Collision Warning System, Front Vehicle Departure Warning. They seem to work, but I wouldn't rely on it. It just give beeping tones and sometimes it seems random whey they go off, also if you pass other drivers or vice versa it beeps as well. The good thing is in the menu settings, you can disable the alarms and it doesn't affect the camera recording.

Installation is pretty simple, it comes with a long power cord that can be easily concealed under the trim. The only thing that might be a problem is you need to plug it into the cigarette lighter, so if you don't have another lighter plug outlet, you would have to unplug the camera to for example plug in a cellphone charger. The camera does have a rechargeable battery built in so it can run on battery power for a while, but you have to have the camera plugged in for a while to charge the battery first.

Overall, this is a nice camera and I am very happy with it.

I've got 5 kids, I camp, I collect flashlights, and I'm a gamer, so you can imagine how many devices I have that use USB for power!  This is the largest charger I ever saw, and it is as quiet as a regular sized one. [[VIDEOID:2212eb120f801d8851a76eb4e94985a0]] This is a really cool way to make your head unit act like a tablet. If you have Android Auto in your dash, you already know that it is pretty cool but a watered down experience of the full blown OS on your phone. It also relies on your phone being plugged in. This device eliminates that by having its own complete Android operating system on a stick that appears on your display, completely independent of your phone. Complete with play store and streaming apps! It is a very cool concept and pretty useful, but sadly I hit some snags along the user experience:
1) You have to wait 30 seconds for it to boot every time you start the car.
2) Unlike Android Auto on your phone, you need to supply an internet connection (you can use your phone as a hotspot if your plan allows and you have enough data, but it is extra steps involved every time you boot if you want to connect)
3) There is no shutdown/sleep. When you turn off the car, the device abruptly dies and has to start fresh again each time. Aside from the long boot up each time, this leads to two potential problems:
3a)The time/date resets every time you turn the ignition. If you don't have a network connection for it to grab the correct time, it will default to thinking it is Dec 31st and 7am. Every. Single. Boot.
3b) Anyone who knows how operating systems work can vouch that if you are in the middle of a write operation (saving a file, updating an app, etc) storage could become corrupted if power is immediately shut without warning to the device. There is no warning to the device, it's either on while the car is, or dead when the ignition is cut. Heck, even if you leave the ignition in the acc position so it remains powered on, if you turn to the ignition position, that momentary cut to the power while the car starts means another 30 second reboot and the time reset to 7am. Very annoying.
4) There is no pinch to zoom option, which some apps (like maps) assume is available for the user experience.
5) Bluetooth support from a phone is very poor. The unit can tell you that a call is coming in, but you can't answer or initiate the call without exiting the UI and either going back to the head unit menu, or controlling it from the phone. Also, no phone audio (A2DP) is played from the phone because the MStick is using the Bluetooth profile for its own audio.

In a nutshell, a lot of these caveats could be worked around with some design changes. The stick could be built with a small internal battery much like a phone or tablet, so that it can sleep when the power is shut off and wait for the user to turn the car back on without rebooting from scratch. This would also solve the time reset issue.
The same way that there is a button on the nav bar to pull down the notification shade, there could be a button to enable pinch zooming within apps that require it.

There could also be a built in way to attach another display, perhaps mirror to a phone or remote desktop in so that you can set up all your apps, etc, at home in the comfort of your wifi instead of doing all of this outside in the car. Everytime I wanted to try something, I had to tinker outside in my driveway and run down my car's battery and/or waste fuel keeping it running for no reason. Little things like that would make a HUGE difference in the end user experience. This product seems like more hassle than it is worth for the average user, but is an excellent proof of concept if you want to, for example, have Torque running on your car display but not upgrade the whole stereo to an Android powered one.
BUT, then again, it sort of begs to wonder why not just get an Android tablet or old phone and mount it on the dash and leave the radio to connect with your phone? The user experience might be better than working around the caveats that this introduces.

I've recently purchased this BT headset and the first thing I did was install the latest firmware due to the reviews I've read. While it does most of what they advertise the BT connectivity is really poor unless you hold the phone in a stationary visible position from your phone or while it's stationary on a table. If you put it in your pocket or even in your hand with a normal hand swing the sound stutters and is not worth using. I've purchased a 60 dollar pair of similar BT ear buds without all the extra features but it sure does work reliably in a way you would expect any headset to work. I've written their technical support for assistance and this is what they told me after a few emails back and forth explaining my issue and running their tests. Here is their final reply, I didn't put in the agents name as to not hold the agent responsible directly for this issue.

(Bragi)
Apr 5, 10:26 CEST
Hello Derek

Thanks for getting back to us with the results of your test.

I understand The Black Dash has some issues when being connected to an external device via Bluetooth, specifically when using it outside. In certain cases we have had a few customers who experienced similar issues like you. As you performed the range test and got a positive result, we can confidently say that your unit's Bluetooth hardware is generally working correctly.

Nonetheless, this is not an excuse for your Bluetooth dropouts. Bluetooth, in general is a technology that offers us the possibility to pair The Black Dash to many different devices, due to the technology's widespread usage. Never the less, it is also a technology that comes with disadvantages. One of those is the actual dependency of the surroundings as you discovered already. That actually means that Bluetooth works very well in closed surroundings where you have surfaces that reflect the Bluetooth signals. However, when being outside with no walls at all, the Bluetooth range very much varies. Having your external device in your right side pockets, your The Black Dash should work independently from the outside surroundings.

Again, this is not an excuse for your Bluetooth dropouts, but rather an explanation for this behavior. Furthermore, we are doing our best to regulate Bluetooth performance with our firmware settings, and every update should actually improve Bluetooth performance.
We hope you can understand that.

All the best,
(Agent name)& your Team Bragi‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã

I had an iPod 2GB Nano and wanted to get something with larger capacity. I did some research and finally bought the Walkman. I was around for the very first Sony Walkman casette tape player, so the idea of getting a Sony MP3 player was appealing.
After using it for over a month, I find it a great little device. The battery life is amazing. I charged it over two weeks ago and have used it on multiple three hour car rides. I also had it hooked up to a speaker in my office and left it on for several hours and it stil has battery life.
It took me some time to get used to the navigation, but now I am fine with the difference between the Walkman and the iPod. The sound quality is good and although the volume could be better, it is acceptable for my use.
The major problem I have with the unit is the software. Sony included one of those mini disc's which loaded a couple of software programs on my computer. The main program is one which allows you to drag and drop files from your computer to the player; however, it doesn't work. I dragged a few tunes to see how it worked and then started dragging all the music. The software kept accepting the tunes, but after it "loaded" for about 2 hours, I discovered it had only loaded the first set of tunes. The rest, and the two hour wait, was for nothing. The software also has a "delete" function, which also doesn't work. It tells you that it delets items from the player, but they are still there.
So, I junked that software and decided to use the Windows Media Player. This is ok, except that the Media Player has a very odd way to create playlists. There are some round about ways to create the play list and I have finaly learned how to do it, but it took way too long compared to iTunes. The other odd thing is that when you create a play list it has to be from tunes on your computer, not on the device. Then when you sync the device to load the playlist, it may or may not put duplicate versions of the music on the device. Sometimes it finds the songs on the device and sometimes it does not. So, I ended up with multiple copies of some songs. The device software is also pathetic. It doesn't allow you to create playlists on the device, and as others have noted, there is no way to delete items from the device without using the software.
I finally just had the computer recognize the device as an external drive and was able to load songs and delete them with no probme.
Despite the isues, I still like the device better than my Nano. For one thing it has an FM receiver, which works great. Now that I have come to terms with the crappy software, it works great. So, if you are looking for an alternative to the iPod, this is a good option. Just stay away from the software provided by Sony and you will be fine.

I wanted to use these to replace some older bookshelf speakers in our living room, currently connected to a streaming Alexa-enabled player. I like that these have two auxiliary inputs so technically I can attach it to our audio system and ALSO something like our home theater receiver, and occasionally use Bluetooth to connect to a phone when needed. These are much nicer looking and sound really good compared to my old speakers, however I'm rather annoyed that everytime they power up it defaults to Bluetooth again. My audio system gets shut off at night and turned back on in the morning via a switch. I really wish the speakers would go back to the last setting used, or perhaps have a way to change the default. As it is right now, every morning we have to find the remote and press Line 1 to hear the music, despite the player trying to play. Even worse, if we can't find the remote, there's NO WAY to change settings on speaker itself. This just seems like an unnecessary extra step and it has made some of my family members prefer the old speakers instead, sadly.
It is very unfortunate because these otherwise have the potential to be so incredible! But this is a usability fail. It should at the very least recall the last mode used.

The Jabra Talk 35 Bluetooth Headset is great.
