It fits comfortably in your ear. There are extra ear attachments that allow you to wear over the back of the ear or just inside.
The quality is clear.
The battery life is decent.
If you live in a handsfree state like I do (Georgia), this is the perfect little investment, especially if you drive an older model car that is not Bluetooth enabled. And I especially like this option better than some of those other cellphone accessories (that you mount on the dash or on the window).

I received this as a free review sample. Although it's designed for notebooks, I am using it for my 10.1 inch tablet and for that it's perfect.

One of the main reasons why I rated this so highly is the protection that it affords. Part of the reason why it's so slim and light, yet protects so will is the interior has an arrangement of raised, circular shapes. They provide cushioning on both sides of the interior. They also greatly reduce shock in the event of a fall. I tested that by taking a functioning - but no longer used - Acer Aspire One notebook and dropping it from waist level inside this bag on a hard floor. There was no physical damage to the exterior of the Acer and it powered up and operated normally.

The exterior of the bag has a spongy feel that also diminished shock, so the protection is twofold. Other features I love are the heavy duty seams and zippers, and even the color scheme. On the latter, there is enough red to catch my eye when I am packing my gear and doing a visual scan to make sure I did not leave anything behind. I have 'forgotten' black cases in the past, but this one is hard to miss.

Do be aware that there is a slight chemical odor to this bag when you first unpack it. That will go away in a day or less, but it's there and you need to know about it before you make your final purchase decision. Also carefully read the part of the product description that states, ' If your laptop screen size is 14 inches, and the maximum thickness greater than 28mm (0.11"), please do not select this bag.' That will save you some frustration if your laptop is too large for this bag.

USB Type-C is just a super complicated situation all around. The ports themselves can be USB 2.0, 3.0, 3.1, 3.2, thunderbolt 3 or thunderbolt 4. I'm probably missing something there. That only covers data transfer speeds. For power, a Type-C port can be rated for multiple voltages and amperages. To protect the consumer from disaster (or they try anyway), each type-c product needs to be equipped with a chip that allows it to negotiate the speed and voltages. This includes the cables. The situation with cables is just as complicated. A cable may only be able to charge at 5v and not carry any data. They may carry only usb 2.0 data. Better ones may be rated for high speed data but not high wattage. Others have both high speeds and are rated for up to 100w. Good luck trying to find the right cable once all of them are dumped in a drawer somewhere.

This 240W USB C to USB C Cable 6.6ft is yet another odd one in the bunch. It is rated for high charging speeds but is only USB 2.0 for data. Why is it necessary though? I have a Dell Inspiron laptop that has a discreet NVidia RTX 3050 processor. This means that it has a high power demand.

This Dell was also designed to charge only from a USB type-c port and the input power must be 130w. So began my search for a charger that I can take with me when I'm away from my desk. I was able to find a macbook style charger that outputs 140w but I didn't own any cables that were rated for higher than 100w.

I came across this cable and connected everything up. During boot, the Dell's firmware still detected a low-powered charging device, but when I booted into Windows 11 and checked its power settings (after reconnecting the charger to the wall), Windows did not warn of an under powered charger as it normally would. I was then able to use this charging setup to play a graphics intensive game for over an hour with no sign of GPU or CPU throttling.

In the end, this cable allows me to have a portable solution for my laptop without having to lug around a standard laptop charger. It works.

I received this as a free review sample. As a music stand light it's functional, but not ideal. As a night light or even a clip on to a book for night time reading when your partner of sleeping this is truly useful.

Be aware that it's small and even at max illumination with all LEDs active it is not glaring. That is a good feature, but the tradeoff is as a music stand light you may have to keep adjusting the goosenecks to get optimum illumination.

The goosenecks are a little on the thin side, which is another reason I think this is best suited to clamping directly on a book or headboard (if you can find a spot that the clamp can grip). On a music stand turning pages too briskly can change the position of the LEDs; not a problem when reading a book, but not the distraction you want when playing an instrument.

Bottom line: if you are looking for a light for your music stand carefully comparison shop. If you are looking for a portable and effective reading light you will love this one.

First of all, my first order arrived with a small crack in the wooden cabinet and it would not turn on. I am going to give Sangean the benefit of the doubt and assume that it was shipping damage even though the box from the outside did not look like it was damaged, so I won't let this affect my rating.

But this did give me a chance to test Amazon's return policy, and I must say it was great. When I realized that I had to return the radio, I went to Amazon's website and clicked on the radio and selected "return." Then I was prompted to print a return shipping label to attach to the box when I sent it back. By the time I did that, there was an email in my in box from Amazon telling me that they were shipping a replacement to me via UPS Air. So I packed up the unit in it's original box, attached the label I had printed, and then the next day when the replacement arrived I gave the box to the UPS driver. Of course, all of this was at no additional cost to me. I was quite impressed with the whole process.

Now to the radio itself. Overall I am quite impressed with it and I am giving it four stars. For a radio of it's size, it sounds great. I have never heard a radio that small with the tight bass response that this one has. And AM radio sounds better than than it does even on my Onkyo receiver that I have in my family room.

The radio with it's wooden cabinet looks great on my nightstand and you can just tell by looking at it that it is a quality product.

The tuner's sensitivity on the FM band is good with the external wire antenna that is supplied with it. Selectivity between adjacent stations is also good. And I am getting good stereo separation when I listen with headphones. I do have one small quibble however. There is a button to switch any FM station to mono, but you have to do this individually for each station. It would have been better if you could toggle between stereo and mono for all the stations at once rather than having to do it individually for each one.

AM sensitivity is pretty good using the built in antenna. Weak stations in my area come in better than they did with my old clock radio, but I still do have some problems with the very weak stations. I could probably improve this if I bought a good external AM antenna, but I don't think I will bother to do that since I don't really listen to any of the weak stations anyway.

One reason why I got this radio was because it has a line in jack. I have connected my Directv box to it so that I can listen to the Directv music channels through the radio without having my TV set on. All I had to do was to go to Radio Shack and buy a Y adapter with two RCA plugs on one end and a 1/8" plug on the other. It works like a charm.

I also like that the display has large enough numerals that I can read it without my glasses on. However, as others have mentioned, the display defaults to the radio station frequency or the RDS display rather than to the time. To get the time display back I have to tap the display button, and it's hard to do at night in a dark room. I think it would have been better if it defaulted to the time in the first place.

Another quibble that I have is that the power button uses a bright blue light which is distracting in a dark room. They shouldn't have made it so bright. That will take some getting used to.

Also, as others have mentioned, setting the alarm is needlessly complicated as is turning it off. You need to hit three different buttons to do it. I am starting to get the hang of it, but I wish they would have just included a button which toggles the alarm on and off.

But overall I am rating this as a good four star product that could use some minor improvements. The most important thing to me is the sound quality, and that is unmatched for a radio of this size.
This speaker for the price is excellent. Great sound!

This thing is excellent!  They have thought of everything.  Case is sturdy and the fit and finish is right on.  Bluetooth connects quickly and easily, as does the magnetic connector between the case back and the keyboard.  Only >slight< criticism is the feel of the keyboard - one of the best portable keyboards I've used, but still not what you'd expect from a native Mac product (a little smaller and a touch less travel), but everything still considered, it's very good.

I ordered the 'Lorex 1080p HD Smart Indoor Pan/Tilt Wi-Fi Security Camera with Person Detection, Two-Way Audio, and Smart Home Voice Control' for review and would like to share my thoughts.

This is a great value indoor security camera. The video and image quality is decent for the price of this camera and the pan/tilt works great which gives this camera even more value. Setup was super easy and the App used to access and control the camera works great on my Android device. I am able to use this remotely to keep an eye on my pets while I am away. Overall I am very happy with this camera and love the value, quality and features.

Works like a charm. I used the same wiring that my cable hookup used to use before I canceled it. I have split the signal four ways but I did not need an amp. I am about ten miles from the transmitters.

I like it so far, I am using to provide additional ports for additional drives on my Mac mini. I like the form factor. Small lights make it great in a darkened room. I ordered a new cord the day after receiving this. Its a little bit short of my use case. I think most users would have no issue with it. However, I ran mine through a wall drop to hid the wiring and this defiantly added some reduction in available length to use. As to speed it seems to have no issues, copying files and so forth. Currently I am running 2 time machine drives and 2 clones drives with no issue in addition to a Cache drive and several other smaller drives. I love that it provides enough power for my non powered drives.

I chose the Plugable brand because the wife already has a Plugable docking station and it works well beyond my expectations. Plus its clean lines helped make it a no brainer.

The only con, I have is its easy to press the power button. Be careful how you pick it up or you may accidentally press it.

I finally decided on its permeant mount location, cable tied to a mount. It works really well, I am pleasantly surprised at how good it is. I had bad results from a hub in the past and that left me with lack luster desire to be bitten again. However this little Champ works wonders and I am glad I spent the money.

You can see it in the attached picture near the top of the ethernet cords and the switch.

These are nice speaker/mics  Definitely pretty good quality for the low price. However, I have run into an issue when used  on RT21V MURS radios. They seem to work fine for a while and then the radio locks up with no transmit or receive. I have not seen this lock up on these radios using the standard PTT buttons. I also have other model Retevis radios and don see this issue. Not sure why these RT21V radios do this an=nd am trying to find out. Maybe there's a sensitivity adjust in programming?? Don't know. I'd give these 5 starts  if I could get around the lock up issue on the one model of radio,

- I have tried so many different SD cards from various manufacturers, at various price points, in the name of trying to save a few bucks. It was really important to me back when a 128GB card cost $50 or more. They all do the same thing, so what‚Äôs the difference, really?
What I've found is that it can be extremely aggravating to put up with when the card does not perform well or does not perform at all. I have heard warning stories about cards that are advertised as one size and actually are another size, causing data loss. With that in mind, I have never tried using the very cheapest card or too-goo-to-be-true card deals. But I have purchased cards on sale at the drugstore or even tried some strange brands. What I have come back to is that it‚Äôs just not worth the trouble now that prices have dropped so low. When I am trusting 128 GB of data to a single card, it‚Äôs just not worth my time and aggravation to have a card that won‚Äôt perform. Furthermore, SanDisk cards like this one are all FAST ENOUGH. I‚Äôm not a pro photographer, and I don‚Äôt have time to figure out whether a card is Class 1 or Class 3 or whatever. I just want it to be good enough that it can keep up with my devices.

I have now purchased several SanDisk cards, and each and everyone of them has arrived in perfect condition and works perfectly every time. They are faster than any other card that I use and I've never suffered data loss. I am putting this card into my Fiio X5ii Digital Audio Player, and it works just fine. During the initial data transfer I have already noticed that the speed is adequate, and I never experience skipping when playing uncompressed high-resolution audio files. I have the same card for my Nintendo Switch, and it works perfectly.

The prices on these are so good now you have no excuse but to buy good name brand like SanDisk. Just buy it and don't worry about it.

No issues to report with this hub. Transfer speeds are what a USB 3.0 Port should be. Supports well even if all of the ports are being used simultaneously. The Powered part of this also makes it great for me to charge all my devices while i am working. when i have a lot of projects going on ill have my project storage devices all plugged into my 4 port then all my charging devices (Phone, Tablet, Wacom Tab for drawing, Battery Pack, USB powered Fan, etc) plugged into this. The Supported USB's with a 1amp output puts the charging through this on par with most wall chargers (not including quick charge devices or the non standard 2+ amp chargers) and keeps me from having to buy a separate USB charging Hub. All in all awesome hub. Cord is kinda short for me but i have my PC mounted on my wall above my head so its probably not a concern for most people.

The Asus has a sleek look with its silver brushed metal lid and slightly rounded sides. Between this and it being JUST under 5 lbs, it makes for an easy transport if you want a laptop to carry around.

I noticed immediately the ultra-fast sleep mode. As soon as the lid is closed the laptop goes into immediate hibernation. After opening lid and clicking to un-hibernate, the laptop is back to active within 2-3 seconds.

The touchscreen has a sleek design with a black outline around the active screen that frames the look of the screen nicely. If you put pressure on the top of the laptop lid it does not affect the screen at all which tells of the durability of the laptop casing. The touchscreen has very nice vibrant display graphics that allows it to be seen easily from various angles without too much glare.

The visuals of the screen are great, which make for impressive video viewing. Picture is great and graphics are very crisp whether it is a Powerpoint still picture on display or a movie. The audio is great, too. While not a gaming pc, this is a nice one for video/audio usage.

It is a very thin and elegant design. The DVD multi recorder fits nicely along the side panels along with three USB ports, a microphone jack, SD slot, network slot and HDMI port.

The grooved out design around the touch pad is a small detail that has a nice impact on the overall look of the keyboard and touchpad (the touchpad is a bit of a different design with the 'clicks', but honestly, at this point with various keyboards for various devices, I'm used to things being different and just roll with it. But FYI to buyer). Keyboard is nicely laid out with light/'chiclet' touch keys and touchpad is sensitive without being too touchy. Considering that I also have a Asus Ultrabook S500-CA with a twitchy as heck touchpad OOB, this is a welcome relief.

Battery life appears to be great as well. I had the machine in hibernate for approx. 6 hours after machine was fully charged and the battery was not even down past ¬Ω charge after all that time. And while in use, it does last about 6 hours. Considering the size and weight, that's pretty good.

Now for some negatives (or at least not so greats).
Fan vent is on the bottom which can be seen as a negative to anyone that works with the laptop sitting on their lap. I would imagine that the fan would be blocked in this instance and would not function properly and possibly allow machine to overheat? Gonna need a cooler for this one while using it for any length of time.

No SSD at all?

It barely comes in under 5lbs. As stated, I also have a ASUS Ultrabook S500CA, which is a 15" screen and weighs less. It also doesn't have a DVD drive, so.... You're definitely adding weight here for that and a few other options (and losing USB and other ports).

No full Microsoft Office Suite/software (you'll have to pay to get more than a trial version or use something else). Just making that clear. - edited as before I had stated 'Windows'. Sorry for any confusion.

All in all, this is a responsive laptop with impressive visual and audio that can be useful to an everyday user. It probably has some drawbacks to someone needing serious processing (no SSD), but for a lot of users, this one is good. I like ASUS, I find them to be reliable laptops, their designs tend to be good, and this ultrabook is no exception.

For everyday use, I'd give this 4.5 -5 stars. Anything else, take off a star or two.

These plus the Bluetooth amp I got for under $100 is an awesome deal for great music, decent volume, clear tones and good bass (given that these are only 6.5" speakers).

I bought these speakers for an outdoor sauna (not steam) along with this nifty little $20 Bluetooth amp,
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B074FR4B7H/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

This combination sounds really good when streaming my iTunes library from iPhone X (it sounded even better when I downloaded the free VOX app with *equalizer* to lower the highest frequencies a tad and raise the mid bass slightly. The speakers have good bass and really crisp treble so the EQ smoothes it out and makes it richer without being shrill). I just now tested them on the table but it really sounded great! I can tell, it is going to be amazing in a 6' x 8' sauna. I have a small Bose bluetooth player, which is phenomenal, given its tiny size is amazing, but still the bass can't approach like this. It sounds good but couldn't saturate the room fully and as deeply as this obviously will.

It took me awhile to figure out what to get for a sauna, weatherproof/water proof obviously, and low to the ground (the lower 2ft of the sauna are much cooler than the warm spot). I first got Polk Audio ceiling mount speakers and built an enclosure and they sounded really bad, but then they advertised self as better for theatre and not higest fidelity, I found out later.
Well I really like the echo dot. The speaker is ok but I added another speaker for music.just wish it had a off switch.

The speaker has a lot bump and clarity for a small pair.  Better sounding than a pair mini speakers.  The USB powering makes the speakers real convenient on a desk (not a lot of plugs & wire tangling.)

I was hesitant in purchasing a large TV online without at least seeing the same model at a store first, but I saw this TV with a good blu-ray/3D glasses/Shrek combo that was difficult to pass on. My girlfriend was doing everything she could to convince me not to buy a huge, expensive TV. I was tired of my Samsung 32" LCD TV and wanted something bigger. I still can't believe I pressed the submit order button, but I'm glad I did. I spent 30 minutes weighing the pros and cons while the TV was in my shopping cart. I wasn't sure if it was my imagination or a sales tactic but the quantity shown was going down as I refreshed the description page for this TV as I was deciding. After submitting the order I went through the "there's still time for more research and cancel the order" phase and spent a couple more hours looking up reviews and trying to not look at my gf directly in the eye that night...I survived and a couple of days later two guys carried a giant Samsung box up to my place. The TV is HUGE compared to my old 32" LCD.

Physically this TV is beautiful, thin, it has a clear border, and has Samsung's smart tv WIFI access. The picture quality looks great with deep blacks and vivid colors. There are many options to adjust the picture and sound. My friends come by to play games sometimes and I found out that this TV even has a game mode. Another benefit of this model is the realistic 3D effects. You have to wear the 3D glasses to enjoy the 3D effects, which will add to the cost of the TV if you didn't get in on the combo deal.

I did find a dead pixel on the screen during my trial period and called Amazon to exchange the TV right away. I was amazed how easy it was to process the exchange and schedule the delivery of the TV. The delivery company Amazon used didn't provide very friendly or timely service but that's not Amazon's fault. The only thing I wasn't informed of until I was surveyed is that the TV delivery service includes setup and disposal of the box and packing material. Those lazy delivery men didn't even offer any of that service but even if they did I wouldn't let them touch my new baby. The second TV didn't have any dead pixels or other issues. I've been enjoying the TV so much it took me almost a year to write this review. I highly recommend this TV for value, it's features, and great picture quality. It has other cool features such as the ability to stream Netflix through WIFI and use your Android phone as a remote control. I was laughing the first time I downloaded the remote app on my Samsung Galaxy phone and tricked my gf into thinking the TV was changing channels by itself.

Pros:
- great picture quality
- lots of customizable settings
- gaming mode
- realistic 3D
- huge 59" screen
- loud speakers
- Samsung smart tv WIFI DLNA support
- use Android phone as TV remote as long as you have Samsung's remote app installed.
- stream netflix on the TV without extra equipment
- software update through WIFI
- connect your laptop to the tv via HDMI cable to use the TV as a computer monitor.

Cons:
- heavy TV
- slight buzz noise when TV is on but not really noticeable unless it's really quiet.
- you will be watching more TV than normal.
- your friends and family members will come over sometimes uninvited to watch TV or play video games.
- wish it had more ports

This unit is large and not at all like the dimensions listed on Amazon. It is 5 inches high (top to bottom), 8 inches deep (front to back), and 16 inches in long (side-to-side).

WHAT COMES IN THE BOX:
- one speaker unit with both left and right speakers inside the large housing
- one power cord
- one FM antenna cord / wire
- one AAA battery
- one remote
- three user guides; one in English, Spanish, and French (I love this because I can keep the instructions in English and throw out the others)
- one limited 1-year warranty insert

FEATURES:
- Bluetooth speaker
- CD player
- FM Radio with ability for 30 preset radio stations
- Ability to operate controls via remote or front of the unit buttons
- Clock
- Sleep / timer function up to 120 minutes in 15-minute increments
- LED Dimmer
- USB terminal that supports USB memory (thumb drive) in FAT 16 or FAT 32 format
- Line In port to plug in an external audio device such as earphones / headphones

The sound this produces when I play my CDs was awesome and music to my ears. I also paired this speaker with my Google Nexus 7 Tablet (2013 version Android device) and my iPad Pro 12.9 and experienced moderately powerful sound there as well. The FM radio was staticky but that was due to the location of where I placed my unit. When I did receive a station, the sound was great.

In summary, this produces beautiful sound. As a Bluetooth speaker, it does not produce as powerful a sound as my [[ASIN:B00SNBCBBY ION Block Rocker]] but it is still good. The addition of the FM radio is a nice touch. I also like that it functions as an LED clock. The instructions and operation of the unit take a bit of getting use to and can be confusing but I was eventually able to figure it out; although I may have to consult the pamphlet every now and then. Overall, this is a well-rounded unit for indoor use but the unit is larger than I expected. It is as large as those old AM/FM amplifiers from years ago and has a retro 70‚Äôs look (see attached picture).

PS For those who are interested in comparisons, this is my sixth Bluetooth speaker. I ordered five other Bluetooth speakers over a several year period. I have a [[ASIN:B007ZG03DG Bose Wave Bluetooth Music Adapter]], which is not very good and a [[ASIN:B00MPMK3GW Goal Zero 94014 Rock Out 2 Green Solar Rechargeable Speaker]] which does not work when paired with some devices and, when it does pair well, it usually lacks the powerful sound I am looking for.

I also purchased one [[ASIN:B00SNBCBBY ION Audio Block Rocker (iPA76A) | Portable Bluetooth Speaker]] and one [[ASIN:B01N17AQ7U ION Audio IPA88 Tailgater Flash Wireless/Bluetooth Speaker]] both from Costco. I absolutely love the Block Rocker (except for when paired with my iPad Pro) and I only like the Tailgate Flash. The lights on the Tailgate Flash annoy me because they have to be turned off every time I power on the unit. Nevertheless, the sound from the ION speakers are usually awesome. The IONs are the only ones I use frequently indoors (even though they are more of an outdoor Bluetooth speaker). They are battery powered powerful speakers and the sound is intense. If one wants Bluetooth only with the capability of travelling with them without having to find a power outlet, then these are worth considering.

I also have a [[ASIN:B01MUG5WIN Sony XB20 Portable Wireless Speaker with Bluetooth, Blue (2017 model)]] which pairs well with my HP Omen Laptop and moderately well with my Nexus 7 and iPad Pro. However, this has to be charged first just like the Goal Zero speaker that I dislike.

PS My boyfriend connected his iPad 3 to this one's Bluetooth and loves it for listening to Podcasts. In order to get the volume as loud as he wanted, he also used the volume controls on the side of his iPad in conjunction with the volume knob on the Toshiba. On another note, he mentioned that the controls located below the CD player are very small for someone who has eye problems and I would agree with that. What I find inconvenient is that the button to open and close the CD player is there so that when the CD is open, I have to put my hand underneath it to close if I am not using the remote. Nevertheless, he loves this Toshiba just like I do.

This thing cannot be too loud. What that means is there is not enough headroom. I played "Infinity War" when I got it at max volume and not once did I feel like it was too much, but there were points where I felt like it was not enough. The subwoofer can barely be heard.

What was the point? Maybe I should return it.

I am totally loving this speaker because not only does it look super cute but the speaker itself has amazing sound and bass. I am so loving it and loving the look in my room. Finally, a speaker that not only works great but also sounds great and looks great sitting out even when I am not using it.

[[VIDEOID:961e8303052349a219f95007cea9bb50]] This little suitcase is amazing!!! So simple to use with really great sound. This is loud enough to easily fill a medium size living. I was hoping this would be loud enough and it certainly is. Really good speaker system for the asking price range. In fact, if I have it turned up half way in my living room people complain they can‚Äôt talk!

You can certainly hear more nuances in your music!!!

Trust you found this review honest and helpful:-)
Works well with MacBook Pro and a KVM [[ASIN:B01MUAP2J9 IOGEAR 4-Port DisplayPort 1.2 KVMP with Built in USB 3.1 Gen 1 Hub and Audio (TAA Compliant) GCS1934]]

As an old, retired guy, I find technology still significantly impacting my daily life in two ways. The first is that I spend a lot of time every day online - either gaming in my favorite MMO or binge watching the various streaming services. The second way is that I keep in touch with my far-flung network of family and friends via social media. Now, my desktop pc handles the first of those two very nicely. The problem is that I can get immersed for hours in gaming or in a good streaming show. Social media notifications break that immersion, causing me to move away from whatever I was doing to see what the latest notice was about. If I don't, it could be quite a while before I get around to checking my social media and responding to the messages there.

This is where a tablet comes in. I figured it would be nice to have a tablet that quietly beeped new notifications and allowed me to just glance over at the latest notice to see if it needed a quick response or not. Little did I know how hard it would be to find a low end tablet capable of that simple task. This is the fourth tablet I've tried and the first one which could do that one simple thing for me. The other low end tablets quickly crashed and burned for a variety of reasons. This is the first that actually continued to work after the first few days, giving me the notifications I wanted and that I could check out at a glance.

There are some issues with this tablet that folks should be aware of. The sound is tinny enough that I wouldn't listen to music or audiobooks on this thing. The visual quality is sufficient for modern movies and tv shows but vintage ones do look a bit fuzzy. The charge doesn't last quite as long as I'd like it to. The tablet needs to be charged twice a day, even when it's just sitting there beeping when a text message or email comes in. Charging once a day would be nicer but it is what it is. Still, this is the first low end tablet of four I've tried that actually does the simple task I want it to do. So for that, I have to give it a solid 4 star rating.

After using surge protection for audio, video and computer equipment for more than 30 years I can definitely say not all of these products are created equally.

While surge protectors will often boast of great protection, more often than not they are more multi outlet plugs rather than actual protection.

I have thoroughly tested this surge protector and it has passed all of my testing. While only rated for 700 joules, this is typically adequate especially when your home has proper grounding. Often similar devices pass my tests initially yet fail after the 1 or 3 month mark - that has not been the case with this item.

The way this is designed allowed me to utilize this in my bathroom to have all of my toiletry accessories charging at once yet have everything compact and tucked away. It‚Äôs nice that this doubles as a nightlight that has adjustable levels of light and automatically turns on and off.

The only thing I wish was different was if on the sides the outlets were more widely spaced to allow for larger power blocks - with that being said having 6 outlets should allow most users to have more than enough.

The 3 USB ports are definitely a nice addition as this helps avoid having to use plugs for USB powered devices. There are 2 standard USB-A ports and 1 ultra fast USB-C port.

This is an outstanding surge protector and nightlight that has proven itself through extensive use and testing.

This is definitely a product I recommend.
Worked great first use, this is second time using it, bluetooth no longer works, can't tune in radio stations. Probably keep, works with aux cord.

I bought this for my elliptical machine.  I really hate exercising,  but I have to do it so I thought listening to audio books would help motivate me.  I needed the phone close enough for me to hear properly,  but I was a little worried that it might fall if I just prop it up on something.  This is the perfect solution.  It holds my phone securely and stays clamped onto the machine safely.  It's also big enough to hold my tablet so I can watch videos if I want,  too.

This bluetooth speaker joins a long list of similar devices designed to bring big sound from a small device. It does this nicely. It boasts multiple speakers pointing in different directions (listed as "omnidirectional") including a passive radiator for extended bass frequencies. This wont give you the "thumping" bass tones that some people might enjoy, but rather a full range of clear and accurate, natural sound. Pairing was easy (as most bluetooth devices are these days) and it comes with it's own charger. Definitely recommended.

I have a camera cage that I used to mount directly to my Manfrotto QR plate, but would require tightening up frequently on a job (cage would start to have some play after an hour of use). I realized the cage has two mounting holes (originally designed for attachment to a rail system), so I put a second 1/4" screw in my QR plate, and now I have two points of security which not only prevents needing to tighten the screw, but the slight wobble is nearly non-existent now. I realized afterwards that these screws are not only useful for mounting UNDER the cage, but actually super useful for mounting TO the cage as well!
The cage is riddled with 1/4" holes, and in order to tighten an accessory like a microphone mount, the threading on the screw and cage and accessory need to be rotated usually. In other words, if the accessory is mounted in the wrong direction, turning it will also turn the screw, and tightening up the screw might once again move the accessory. These have clearance underneath the threaded part of the screw, so they can actually spin freely once inserted into the cage. That means I can hold an accessory in place while tightening the screw, and it will lock in tight the way I want it to face. Very versatile and useful part of any kit!

Let me start off by saying, I've had the QC 15 and 20's. I've used Bose over the course of a decade for my travel. I wasn't planning on getting a new headset and was fine with my qc20 for a bit. But the gel like earbuds hurt after a long day of work. I happened to check out the sony mx4 during the prime day sale, but after watching the reviews online decided for the bose 700.
I use this about 8 hours a day. All of my calls are through my computer. I need something that's comfortable and can handle the extended use. I got this because the sony had really bad reviews on the call quality.

Call quality- no issues here. Given I'm using it in a small office with the hum of the AC.
Comfort- Extremely comfortable. The weight is minimal and doesn't give off that heavy sucking feeling after a few hours
Bass- It's ok. I'm not using it for hardcore bass anyways.
Noise cancellation- My office is in my backyard. With neighbors mowing their lawn throughout the day. This has helped filter it out.
Bose app seems pretty cool. But since it's connected to my laptop, I haven't had time to tinker with the settings.
Controls- I'm used to tactile buttons, but am not opposed to this.

I have a few trips coming up and I'll test these on an airplane soon.

I have had these for over a year now. They sound great, if they don't, play with your phones equalizer. The bass is fine and it doesn't have that annoying all treble hiss that some headphones have. The battery last a long time so if I forget to charge it with my bike lights, it isn't a problem. They stay in my ears just fine.

Someone mentioned the volume on the headphones and the phones own volume. I have had my phone turned low and the headphones turned the volume up just fine. I am not sure why they are having an issue. I have a Samsung S20, so maybe their phone is different.

The one con I have is that the ear tips and wings fall off all the time when you have them in a bag. It could be my fault but it is still annoying. I have now lost a wing and am trying to find a replacement.

[[VIDEOID:b16291f439f0a8f55991c25ab956bec0]] THE GOOD:
--------------
* Aesthetically, a very unique build.
* USB dongle housed in the bottom with a unique compartment door that simply connects by magnets. Watch my video. The usb dongle also stays in its slot via magnetism.
* 7 customizable buttons.
* No need for a mouse pad. Works on any surface.
* Can drag and drop work across devices. Read below...

THE BAD:
------------
* For instructions, they might as well give us a sheet that says, "Search Youtube to learn. Good luck!"
* I could not connect to my Pixel Pro 6, it kept saying, "Cannot connect to HP Creator due to incorrect pin or passkey." There is no such pin for us to enter. You've all connected bluetooth devices to your phone, right? It just works. This is a rare case, where it didn't work, and it gives you this message. So there is some firmware issue that HP and Google need to iron out.
* The feature I'm most intrigued about is the "WORK ACROSS DEVICES" feature. You can supposedly drag and drop content across different operating systems. When you advertise something, and you give no directions, then it better be something that simply works, but it's not. I connected the mouse to a PC as well as a mobile device, and I cannot drag and drop. I've connected it to two PCs and I cannot drop. To use either device, you need to switch devices on the mouse. Once you switch, you can no longer control the other machine. There is obviously something I'm not understanding, perhaps a setting I need to turn on, perhaps a software I need to download. It would be helpful if HP gave you some directions. This is so annoying and so infuriating to be honest.
* Then a lightbulb went off.. Youtube!!! So after searching Youtube, I did eventually learned how to do this. Search YT using this phrase, "HP 930 Creator Mouse - Everything you Need to Know." At the 6:56 mark is where he discusses this across device feature.
* I think it's pretty funny HP, Apple, Dell, etc. All the big boys now don't feel they need to teach their consumer base about their products. They just know that all us Guinea Pigs will be smart enough to eventually make our way to Youtube. LOL!

I'm usually not this harsh on products, but the reason I'm so upset is because I wasted so much time tinkering and searching their useless HP website. This is a Vine product, so it didn't occur to me that this product has already been selling and there are already youtube reviews. I didn't think it be on YT yet. I'm knocking off 3 stars for the lack of direction. Hey, I'd have more respect for HP, if they just include a card that says, "To learn how to use our product, search Youtube." LOL! 2-Stars.

These are not compatible with iPhones. They will not connect to the Samsung buds app so there is no way to tweak or access the features. They do connect via Bluetooth but you might as well just get a pair of $20 headphones because there is no way to make changes to the settings or access features.

I listen to a lot of music, usually electronic music though I listen to a little of everything. I have worked with a lot of different speakers and I have gotten very sensitive to the strengths and weaknesses that speakers bring to the table. I had high hopes for this speaker ‚Äì I have always had excellent results with Yahama products so I expected the same from this speaker. It has not disappointed me.

The speaker itself is about the size of a cantaloupe ‚Äì not huge but not tiny either. It's the right size for a bookshelf or as part of a larger sound system.

I did not completely understand what was meant by ‚ÄúMusicCast‚Äù until I started working with this speaker. In short, it is a wireless speaker that communicates over a wireless network (not Bluetooth). Using an appropriate device (like an Android tablet) the speaker is easily connected to the network and the software on said computing device allows for turning the speaker on and off and for streaming music to it. My service of choice is Pandora, and I had no trouble at all streaming a channel from Pandora to this speaker. The software comes into its own when you have more than one speaker, all of which get controlled separately and can stream different music from the same source device. So, given a sufficient budget (these speakers are not cheap), you can have different music playing in different rooms, all controlled from the same device.

The application is not perfect though I have been able to do everything I want with it ‚Äì play music from local storage, stream from a service, increase/decrease volume and twiddle the sound profile a bit.

The sound quality is excellent, particularly when given a little volume. The bass is solid but not overwhelming which is great ‚Äì the trend of late is to overdrive the bass which drowns out the rest of the sound profile, so having the bass not overpowering the overall profile is a big plus with me. The midrange is excellent as well and the music has the right depth as a result. The highs are bright and crisp. At lower volumes, the bass washes out which is has been the case with every speaker I have used. At higher volumes, I was unable to get the speaker to distort.

I am very happy with this speaker. I primarily use with with my tablet to stream music from Pandora, though it is useful for playing music from other sources too. It is expensive, but the sound quality is definitely there. If you like the idea of being able to add multiple speakers to your sound array and you want to design your sound system from the ground up, this is a good choice.

I received these as a free review sample. Note: these are NOT bluetooth. They are wired ear buds that should fit any device with a 3.5mm output jack.

My rating is based on both sound quality and price. The list on these are in the twenty buck range, but the sound quality, in a blindfold test, would fool you into thinking that these are a tier above other buds in this price range.

The mid range and lower end of the frequency spectrum seem to be emphasized, with highs a bit compressed. These are perfect for casual (and even some critical) listening. An audiophile would probably not like the bias and compression, but most other folks will appreciate it. I mentioned the 'lower' end of the frequency spectrum. At the lowest end it is deep, but not thumping (although it will reproduce 20Hz, which you can feel if not hear.) For anyone listening to acoustic or lightly amplified music, and especially music that uses a big chunk of the audio frequency spectrum (for consumer phones), these are surprisingly good.

There is a disparity between the product description's claim that there have flat, tangle-free cable and the actual cable, which is tangle-free, but round. I want to point that out because one of the things I check when reviewing is any differences between product specs and claims, and what you actually receive.

Basically, these are priced at the upper end of entry level phones, but are good enough to pass for high end intermediate level phones.

Absolutely the best sound for the money. Bonus, the pairing is really easy to use.
I have to admit some bias for JBL. I've had and still use my original JBL 100 studio speakers from 1976. I won't give them up. Never needed repair. Hope I didn't jinx myself.
The Flip 5's are right up there as far as quality. Buy 'em you'll think so too.

I use these to listen to podcasts while I'm doing many other things. I forgot my phone in another room one time and the bluetooth never disconnected. I love these especially because they were less than $25. Since I've never had bluetooth earbuds, I have to remember to turn them off or they completely lose power. But that's the worse thing about them. Having to remember to charge them. I love that the two sides connect with a magnet so I'm less likely to lose them. ETA: I've had them for 7 months and don't take good care of them but they still work just fine. This was a good use of my money.

This is my second pair. I love them because they‚Äôre designed for smaller ears so my ears don‚Äôt start burning or hurting when I wear them. They also do lock in place and won‚Äôt budge when you‚Äôre sweating your life away at the gym, or if you‚Äôre passed out in the library. They do a decent job of cutting out sound too! I had my first pair for 3+ years and didn‚Äôt treat them like precious gold by any means - left them tangled in my bag, left them in my car through hot/cold weather, probably say on them, used them constantly, and so on. I love these little cases! I ordered the 4 pack so I could share with my family. They are perfect for storing your earbuds! My teenagers each keep theirs in their backpacks. Great sound quality. They fit perfectly and are very comfortable. It includes four different sizes of ear caps. It‚Äôs so nice to be able to wear earbuds that don‚Äôt hurt my ears while keep other voices or noises out. The price is great for such amazing quality.

The one important thing to note when buying electronic equipment is that once you pop, you can't stop. Every time you think that you have the perfect system, something else comes along that you absolutely HAVE to have, which leads to something else, and so on ad infinitum.

Having bought new surround sound speakers, we needed a new DVD player, and then, naturally, a new receiver. The weight of this system is a big plus, being less than half the weight of our old one, but the new one's not as aesthetically pleasing with those shiny silver buttons.

Leaning over the shoulder of my resident techie, I can now advise as follows:

1. You cannot connect a turntable to this receiver; there are no phono inputs. Not good for those of us who still have LPs.

2. It's DVD-Audio ready for the audiophiles among us.

3. Setup is relatively easy, controlled by two buttons only: a multi control button and the input selector button. This can be irritating if you need to adjust the tone after you have finished setting up, since there are no separate bass and treble buttons, and you have to go through the setup menu again. You can however adjust the level of the surround speakers and subwoofer from the remote.

4. No onscreen display available

5. No switched AC outlets to allow you to plug in other components.

6. In addition to the receiver, the universal remote can be used to control a TV, tape, DVD player/recorder, VCR, CD player and the radio. This reduces the number of remotes you need around you. It has a weird shape that takes some getting used to, and I still use my separate remotes - guess old habits die hard.

7. Input jacks on the front make connecting camcorders, video games, etc. quite easy.

8. When listening to music or looking at a movie, there are SFC (Sound field control) modes which you can choose to enhance the sound environment. For music there are six modes (live, pop/rock, jazz, etc.), and for movies another six (action, drama, sports, etc.) However, to the untrained ear, like mine, I cannot detect a significant difference if any of these modes are selected.

Overall, the sound from this receiver is quite good, very clean, though it doesn't seem as powerful as my old receiver (a Technics SADX930). This could be due to differences in the calibration of the volume control, but since I rarely play it at very high volumes this is a non-issue. The centre channel seems a bit weak compared to the other channels, but with so many sound options to choose from and customize, it is very possible that I may have missed something and need to tweak it some more.

A very nice receiver for the price and features.

Amanda Richards, December 14, 2004

I received this as a free review sample. The tripod is fixed height and can raise your camera or phone 5.5 inches. Depending on the device, the lens can be raised even more. For example, with my Kodak Easyshare the center of the lens was elevated to a little under 6.5 inches when mounted, and my Note 4 phone just under 7 inches.

While the legs are fixed the head will rotate to just about any position you want within its range of rotation. It will rotate 360 degrees and the tilt angle appears to be 45 decrees (I did not have a protractor of drafting angle handy to measure it.) The increments, within the movement range, are infinite. Note that the tripod can support up to 2.2 pounds and size-wise, a camera with an 85mm lens. My Note 4 fit within the phone adapter, so that is not an issue.

The shutter release is somewhat generic. That is a god thing because like every other one I own it will work with an app called Camera 360 if your version of Android or iOS is not supported. You will not need the app if you are running Android 4.2.2 or newer, or iOS 6.0 or newer. This works for movies and stills, but you have to first place your 'cursor' on whichever mode you want manually, then use the button to control off and on. Also, it functions like a mouse of sorts until you invoke the camera app. On my main screen when I pressed the Android button it brought up the app on which its 'cursor' was resting on. Another feature is you can still stream music to phones or speaker via bluetooth while the shutter release is active.

(WARNING- This is an IN DEPTH review of this stereo to help anyone interested in making an informed buying decision. If you prefer a more brief summary, see section marked THE BOTTOM LINE)
------------
In my house there is a variety of quality of audio items. There are those who really don‚Äôt seem to care what kind of quality, as long as it is not too bad. Then there are those who really want to hear definition of sound but they can tolerate lower quality. Then there are those who are so sensitive to audio that they will go on in great depth to analyze and evaluate anything related to stereos whether it is the CD player, bluetooth player, headphones, speakers, and fine tuning of sound.

This stereo system was picked to replace a very old Onkyo which is hanging on, but not for long. Let‚Äôs see how this measures up.

WHAT IS THIS STEREO LIKE?
First of all, the write up when I had the opportunity to get this stereo said it was a mini stereo system (different than it is now). I expected it to fit where my other stereo system is which was also a condensed system. Boy was I surprised. This system is a LOT bigger than I expected it to be, but still will fit where I wanted to put it although much tighter than I thought it would.

This system has a CD/bluetooth base to it. There is a dial which is rather large on the front that deals with volume. The CD player has the usual controls on it and there is only an FM radio, no AM. There is an infrared remote which has all of the controls you would need to run the stereo.

LIST OF CONNECTORS
FM Antenna terminal
Line 1 and 2 terminals
Speaker light terminal
Speaker out terminal
USB input on front
Headphone jack on front

MEASUREMENTS
Receiver: 11 x 11 13/16 x 5 5/8
Speakers: 12 x 10 3/4 x 16 5/16
Speaker cords approx 2 ft

HOW DOES THIS UNIT PERFORM?
The CD drawer in the bottom right corner operates about average as far as loading and reading. When playing a CD there were not any problems. As far as the equalizer goes, there are only five functions (one is flat- ewww). For this price there should have been more or customizable options.

The equalizer options sound okay, but the two that we choose most often for a variety of music is jazz and rock. Pop, flat, classic seem lack luster for all of the CDs we tried including classical, rock, country, jazz, hip hop, etc.

Despite limitations, the sound did separate well on one of our CDs which has very muffled and quiet background noise at the beginning of a song that we have never heard clearly before.

SOUND QUALITY
The highs come through pretty well, due to the two tweeters per speaker. The mids and lows depend on the music. They tend to suffer more. It booms but not overly clearly. This is more of a mediocre sound that is designed to pump at very high volumes such as for a party. This is not high fidelity sound if that is what you are looking for.

SPEAKER LIGHTS
Although they are interesting at first, the lights seem kind of odd. For the price, it should have had better options. You can choose colors that stay on and do not blink or change out of seven choices. You can choose to have it flash and change color continuously, or you can choose to have the lights flash fast and change continuously, or you can flash the light in white. None of the settings go in time with the music.

You can also opt for no lights on as well. The lights do connect to the speakers by a second wire- it is not in with the speaker connector.

BLUETOOTH
The bluetooth took a while to recognize on the phone. We used android. Once it was paired, many types of music from old to new tracks, and older songs were not as clear or loud as newer tracks. As far as decoding from the bluetooth, it sounded pretty good and did not drop once.

RADIO
The FM sound on this was good and no complaints. Reception was pretty standard, nothing remarkable, but not horrible either.

REMOTE
Remote has to be pointed directly at the receiver. There were a few times where we had to press buttons twice because it would not pick up the signals. The remote itself is black and very small, which makes it easy to misplace. Marking it with neon paint is something we are going to do to make it harder to lose.

PROS
Nice and loud
Picks up highs very well
Bluetooth and CD player in one both work well
Two tweeters per speaker is nice

CONS
Remote very small
Lights sometimes are annoying
Wires are way too short- speakers can not be separated to put in corners of room
Speaker wires are proprietary to the receiver with special attachment (can not use other speakers)

THE BOTTOM LINE
If you want to have a good middle of the road stereo with nice separation of highs and decent sound, you might like this one. The lights and loud capacity also make this a great party unit if you like to fill up a large room or house with sound. Remote works okay , but speakers can not be separated very far. Due to proprietary speaker connections, the only way to change that would be to splice the wires if you are good at electronics.

RATING
This stereo is rather high priced for what you get. It does not have any bass boost, or customizing options for the equalizer. The sound is loud, but not overly high quality. Although this is not a bad unit, it really is not jaw dropping either. I want to give this THREE AND A HALF STARS due to the price and what you get for it. Unfortunately there is only a choice between four and three stars.

-Item works well
-easy to connect phone to (both iphone xr and iphone 11)
-easily connects when coming back into the car (if you leave your bluetooth setting on on your phone)
-sturdy
-good quality
-quality sound
-would recommend

THE GOOD:
--------------
* Beautifully crafted high end speaker.
* Built like a tank, it weighs about 7 and a half pounds.
* Three ways to position the speaker: Flat, on it's end, or mount it on a wall (bracket sold separately).
* From what I can tell, it produces beautiful sounds. However, I'm not an audiophile.
* 105 watts, 79dB bass, and 96dB mid-range.
* Awesome charging design. The round object you see in the pictures is the charger. The usb-c goes into this object, it then docks magnetically to a round slot in the back of the speaker. Contrary to other reviews that said you're in trouble if you lose this charging device, the back of the speaker has another usb-c port for charging. So if you lose the round object, you're not in trouble. I think it's there for tactile purpose. Without it, you have to constantly turn the speaker around to look for the charging port. With this magnetic charger, mounting and dismounting is a breeze. BTW, Ethernet and Line In is hidden under the rubber cover of this round charging slot.
* Works with Airplay, Chromecast built in. If you have a google smart home, you'll like this. My wife is an Apple person, I'm Android. She's been taking over the speaker with Airplay.
* 16 hours of play time after fully charged.

THE BAD:
------------
* Not necessarily a bad, but more like a reality nowadays. You have to hunt for the user manual at their website. No user manual is included.
* Bluetooth connection was easy with some of my devices, and was very difficult with others. My MP3 player took forever to find the Level. Not sure if the issue is with the Level or with the player.
* Tested it with my Fire TV Cube. Does not work well. I have to connect/disconnect several times to get audio to the Level. But when I change apps, I lose audio again. To be fair, this wasn't made for TV. But cheap $50 Bluetooth speakers can work flawlessly with media players, why not a $1300 speaker?
* On the speaker, there are 4 touch buttons that are for favorites that you can customize. Such as spotify, pandora, etc. You can also long press to save a Google Voice command for each button like Play some music, what is the weather, etc.. Initially, I thought this meant Google Assistant was built in, but it is not unfortunately. It's only good for four phrases. Upon further research, I realize that they do offer this same speaker on their website with Google Assistant built in. They have an option that you can choose with or without Google Assistant, and it's for the same price. I guess this option is available because some people don't like smart devices listening in their homes. This Amazon listing is WITHOUT GOOGLE ASSISTANT.

Even with some of these "BAD" things I've listed and discussed, I still rate this speaker 5 stars because it's the most magnificent speaker I've ever owned.

These look great in my theater.  I ceiling mounted them.  The sound quality is good, and the connections were easy to make.  Fishing the wire was a bit difficult, but I found Youtube videos to help me.  The speakers have a very good range, and I'm using them for whole-house audio.

The wide angle lens is wonderful. The field of view and the speed (light gathering ability) of the lens can only be rivaled by high end camera and lens combinations costing six to ten times as much (admittedly those are superior in many other ways as well). Still, the point is that no other compact point and shoot camera can rival the field of view and speed of this one. Nevertheless, some things come up short of fair on the LX3.

The shutter lag is terrible. I am a very instinctive shooter that is quite capable in photojournalist style candids but I am almost always defeated by this camera.

I am not a photophile or electronic gadget spec sheet bench racer. I've done wonderful 8x10 prints with a 6MP camera and 10MP is enough to get prints after substantial cropping. I have huge film scans when I need them but I cannot realistically show dozens of megapixels on screen or in print for more than a handful of images. I also shoot in .jpg and it's great. I can't imagine the agony of terabytes of raw data jamming my PC.

I love the LX3 video quality for movies. It's ideal for Youtube and even Youtube HD. I do not like the Quicktime .MOV format or the weak compression algorithm. I wish it had H.264 and wrote an .MPG type format. It still beats the data format from a DVD camcorder though.

The audio quality for movies is terrible. Again, I'm not talking audiophile critique here. For comparison, my Sony DSC T9 (ultra compact point and shoot) has far better sound.

I hate the manual aspect ratio slider. If I shoot movies I want 16:9 but for stills I want 3:2 (of course). The LX3 requires that I remember to both turn the dial and slide the switch or I will end up shooting 16:9 stills.

Overall, it's a great camera. I hope they get the rest sorted out by the time I expect to buy another one in about 3 or 4 years.

Overall, I give this product 4 stars (knocking 1 off for battery life), but the system that backs it 1 star. My rating above is on this product, not the system.

TrackR

and Tile is the best so far.

Pro's

Con's

I received this as a free review sample. The reason why I subtracted a star is the grabbing arms are not spring loaded. Indeed, they are a friction, pinion design that makes it a little more difficult to insert and remove your phone while the assembly is attached to your windshield or dash.

Also, before you make a final decision, make sure your phone will fit. The maximum width is 3.5 inches, and that measurement is absolute. My Note 4 would fit when I removed it from its case, but with two of the cases that I swap it between, it would not fit. Take that into account.

This will definitely stay where you attach it! It even adhered to the pebble grain covering on my vehicle's dash, but it was a but too awkward there for me. It is perfect on the windshield, though and that is its final resting place for me.

It's also rock steady, so if you are on bumpy roads the display is not apt to jiggle, which is a nice thing of you are glancing at your phone's GPS map (something I do often.) Basically, this is a decent mount, but not the best (in my opinion.) On the other hand, it's definitely not the worst either!

(WARNING- This is an in depth review of this laptop. My goal is to help those who are truly interested in making informed buying decisions. This is done from an experiential point of view of most consumers and not highly technical. If you prefer a shorter summary, see paragraph titled, THE BOTTOM LINE)

WHAT IS THIS LAPTOP LIKE?
I have had a lot of different tablets, laptops, desktops, and have built my own systems over the years. One thing I have not had is a hybrid laptop which changes from tablet to laptop and back again. I was not too fond of a 15 inch size as I tend to like smaller laptops, but I was willing to try. I am SO glad I did.

COVERING/CASE OF LAPTOP
This laptop is a thin profile, but feels very substantial. The bottom does not have tiny little rubber feet like some HP professional laptops I have had, but it has solid large rubberized pads that are 1 inch by a half inch. There are a decent amount of vents in the bottom as well. The top is a slightly textured metallic top (etched look) and not shiny. The hinges are very strong and hold the screen in a variety of directions solidly. They do not budge until I move them again.

SIZE
I am amazed that this is the first 15 inch laptop that I actually enjoy using! The size and way that it works makes it fantastic for me. I can tilt the screen in any direction and use my hands on the screen or keyboard in laptop mode which is a pleasure.

KEYBOARD
The keyboard is soft touch and rubberized key-wise. As soon as I touch the keys, a back light comes up so that I can see what I am doing. The back light goes out in 15 seconds or so when the keys are not being pressed. There is a full numerical keyboard and plenty of room between keys for my medium sized fingertips. It is also spaced well for those who have longer nails.

SCREEN
The screen is shiny. It doubles as a screen as well as touchscreen. The view on the screen is fabulous as it has a full HD 1080 resolution. The colors are not as intense as the Saumsung Galaxy Tab S2, which is one of the most amazing color screens I have worked with. Since I am a person who likes color, I like color intensity in my screens. However, this screen is fine and is by no means pale, it is just not quite as intense as I am used to.

TOUCHSCREEN
When you flip the keyboard back, the touchscreen clicks into place. You are given the option to choose the touchscreen if you want so there are no mistakes. As a tablet, I have found that it is very accurate and works quite well. I have put it through a lot and so far, I have only had a few instances where I was frustrated for a second, but it was easy to correct.

OPERATION
This turns on so fast it is almost jolting. My laptops, though usually professional level, often take quite a bit to boot up. This one, however is so quick it always surprises everyone here.

As for operations, I have found this to be a very fast and easy to use system. Load up is quick and the only problems I have from time to time are due to wireless and not really the fault of the laptop.

Turning it off sometimes makes me laugh out loud. Press button. BAM! It‚Äôs off.

WINDOWS 10
I am not a fan of Windows 10. But unfortunately that is pretty much the choice for any laptop at this point. This laptop seems to handle it very well.

GAMES
Because Windows 10 is not as game friendly as previous operating systems, I have not had the time to mess around with games with this. I have avoided Windows 10 until now, so I have not figured out what if any games will work with this. I will update when I do.

RUN TIME
Charging seems to take only a few hours for a full charge. The run time varies between 3 and 5 hours depending on what I am doing. I will say this- I rarely run it into the ground in one sitting, which makes it very helpful for me.

VIDEO
Runs very smooth on here. Using a DVD player means I have to use the USB port to run my independent unit and be in a stable position to do so. Works well. Beautiful to watch.

USB PORTS AND SD READER
I have found the USB ports to work very well. No problems to this point. Load up is fast. Using the SD reader is also a pleasure. The photos load up fast and due to the high resolution screen viewing them is really detailed and helpful. I have not installed professional graphics software yet to test this system for photo editing.

TOUCH PAD (AND FRUSTRATION)
The touch pad on this laptop is a bit challenging to use. There is a finger reader which I do not use, but the buttons are hidden in the pad itself and not two different buttons. The pad is pretty accurate as far as tracking. The only problem I have is location. When I rest my left hand on the rest area, sometimes it interferes with the touch pad and causes things to go a bit crazy at times. I am not pressing ON the touch pad, just in the area next to it.

SOUND
The sound is not tinny or awful. I find that it is sufficient for most of the applications I want to use it for. If I prefer to have a better sound, I use my Soundbot speaker and that gives me even better sound for movies and videos.

COMMENTS
I have to say that although the touch pad situation does frustrate me now and then, I do love this laptop. I have always wanted a hybrid because since I started using tablets, I would always catch myself touching the screen when I was using one of the household laptops and it was frustrating.

This unit is really nice. It is so fast and easy to use, it surprises me, honestly. It is so easy to switch between tablet and laptop modes and I find it a pleasure to work with for photos and movies.

THE BOTTOM LINE
This hybrid is VERY fast, easy to use, and boots up and shuts down so fast it is startling. The screen is a pleasure to look at, although not as color saturated as Samsung can be. So far, USB and SD works great. Sound is good enough for most applications. This is easy to use and not at all cumbersome. I love that I can touch the screen even in laptop mode if I am frustrated with the touch pad. I am very happy with this laptop/tablet hybrid.

RATING
FIVE STARS! I will update if I have anything else to add in the future, but at this point, I am very happy with this.

The Sony extension cord for headphones works especially well and makes my husband happy when I'm watching movies late at night. This works with my computer, DVD player and stereo. This cord also works with the AKG headphones and the K240 version makes everything sound amazing. The cord is lightweight and the nine feet extension makes it much easier to enjoy music a little further from the source. Now I can sit on the other side of the room and watch a movie on my computer or enjoy late night movies without disturbing my husband.

~The Rebecca Review

Great player, no issues whatsoever. Pulled out of the box, connected, pulled firmware, and played.

Have been renting blu-rays from Netflix and all have played without any problems at all. Fantastic playback, both audio and video.

Netflix watch-it-now is EXCELLENT. I believe we may give up cable all-together. The quality is somewhere between regular television and DVD.

DVD's play without issue and the upconversion is really noticeable. A great feature, for sure.

I am surprised by how comfortable this headphones fit. These are an upgraded version. They offer many features includig Bluetooth and they are waterproof. I personally tested them! The sound quality is great. I have been using them in the car and while listening music and a little gaming with my kids! I like that they leave your ear open to heat if need be. It does come with earplugs if you prefer. Very cool headphones. I recommend you give them a try!

These headsets are light, comfortable, and do a great job with noise cancellation.

They do NOT have a longer range than my 10 year old Logitechs though, so don't expect the range to be much greater than your basic Bluetooth.

My biggest gripes are:

. When you click on mute in Zoom or Teams with your mouse, you hear a loud MUTED. When you click again, UNMUTED. Every single time. It's super annoying.

. The On and off switch is a tiny slider that you can only really move with your nails, and it has 3 positions, Off, Dongle, Bluetooth. It's easy to pass up the middle position and all together it's not easy and comfortable to turn on and off. And not something you can easily feel for while on your head.

. Finally it doesn't have USB C. In this day and age, why not?

These don't have a great fit and the audio level/quality isn't great. For the $100 price point, I'd 100% feel ripped off. These perform more like some $20-30 headphones. The colors are cute but it ends there really.

I use these with my laptop and the sound is very clear. For myself, I like a little more bass and they could be a little louder, but my wife thinks they are loud enough. ;-) All in all this is a good speaker for use with a computer.

While this little speaker packs a punch volume-wise .. it just lacks the bass that other more expensive speakers have.
I do like that it stays ON with my echo dot and aux cable.
But music sounds a little too tinny, distorts on higher volume and not enough bass.
Still for the price .. it's a decent speaker

In the end I went with a JBL FLIP 3 .. and I am a lot happier now :)

The WEWATCH Video Projector with WiFi and Bluetooth is a basic projector that has all of the necessary features that one needs.

The description of this product may lead you to think otherwise, but this projector is not really a "smart" projector. It does not run on Android and the built-in user interface is quite basic. Yes, it will play videos and show photos from USB drives and it has WIFI... for whatever reason (I didn't really look into it because I simply plugged in a FireTV). The bluetooth, on the other hand, does have a function. I'll get into that in a bit.

So for video input, you have two full sized HDMI ports, a VGA (for those ancient laptops that your office may have lying around?) and a USB port which outputs enough amperage to run a fireTV, so no additional power adapter necessary.

There is no automatic keystone adjustment, but what is there works well. You can adjust the four corners up and down, although I found that it still seems to have some bloating in the middle no matter how I adjust it (could be a problem with my projection screen and projector positioning). A tip for doing the adjustment: If you aren't able to move the corners in the direction that you need, try adjusting the zoom first. By zooming out, it allows the corners to be pulled up or down more.

Audio is as expected in that it is not winning any awards. It can get pretty loud, but it still sounds empty. This is where bluetooth or the 3.5 mm headphone jack comes in. For wireless audio, you can either pair a bluetooth speaker/soundbar to the projector itself or you can pair the speakers directly to the FireTV or whatever dongle you're using. The advantage of pairing the speakers to the projector is that they will work for both HDMI inputs. If you really wanted to get full surround, you'll have to extract the audio out of the HDMI wire. Basically plug the HDMI into an audio receiver, then the audio receiver to the projector. The receiver can take care of decoding the surround depending on your setup.

For the brightness, the 1100LM beats out many other projectors of this price and resolution. You can really tell that the picture just pops. It will work well enough in a dimly lit room, but you can only truly appreciate it when the lights are completely off.

Overall, this is a low-priced projector that will work well for outdoor, temporary use, or even a permanent setup inside the home.

These fit well and feel good on my head. I love that they're wireless and I am no longer bound to cords. They connect and stay connected to my computer's bluetooth, my phone, my tablet, and my tv with no problem. Audio is great for all of these devices from music to television, audio is all very clear! Noise cancellation works great on these, I love to put them on sometimes just to drown out any noise and clear my head. The bass on these is fair, it's not as booming as some more expensive headphones but it has a fair amount. Personally I don't want a lot of bass in my ears as too much of that can be bad for your hearing.

These are the most premium headphones I've owned and I love them! If you compare these to really high end headphones- you'll be disappointed all around. But if you look at the price point and what you get- you'll treasure these. For the price point you can't beat these in my opinion!

These are comfortable for a few hours wear, work great in pairing with my cell phone for music or phone calls.  I can't imagine buying a different bluetooth headphone.  These don't hurt my ears, have great sound, excellent controls and the neckband (or whatever it's calle) is so much nicer than the alternative designs.  The sound quality is excellent as well.  When purchasing a set for my son, I couldn't resist a set for myself

LOVE this speaker. It‚Äôs great. You can change the colors, and if you or a friend have another one of these you can sync them so you can have music off of more than just one. These are amazing. Great qulality. Ours was dropped a few times and it still worked with no issues.

I've used cheap Wyze cameras as well as more expensive cameras like Arlo in my garage, but wi-fi is pretty iffy there. I wanted to see if the wi-fi receiver in this HomeHawk beats the Wyze or Arlo, but unfortunately, that's not the case. The HomeHawk struggled in my garage as much as the others did. As a matter of fact, I couldn't connect to it at all. So right off the bat, that is something to note... that paying more for a camera doesn't necessarily mean better wi-fi receivers are inside the camera. This isn't something I'm going to subtract a star for since no cameras on the market can help with my wi-fi situation, that's something that will have to be remedied by wi-fi extenders.

Now once I move this camera indoor, with better wi-fi reception, to monitor the backyard, it does the job wonderfully! The app is great and full of features. Be sure you select the proper MODE. By default, it was on BASIC and it did not do any recordings. I realize I had to change it to PROTECTION mode or 24/7 mode. Or, better yet, you can create your own mode! You can determine if it will record 24/7, or only when it detects motion. You can determine the duration of the clip. Now that is pretty cool! The default is 10 seconds, and for several weeks I thought I had to live with the default, until I discovered that I can actually change this by creating my own Mode. You can determine if it will notify you for every motion detected, or only for human detections. Lastly, you can name the mode anything you want, then select it and you're set! I've only used Wyze, Arlo and Homehawk cameras, and without a doubt, this Panasonic software is the best of the bunch. 5-stars!

We use this base everyday in our office to store my boy's chromebook and tablet. The base is weighted and has a thin rubber lining on the bottom. The slots have ample room, even if your tablet has a thick, rubber case around it like ours does. This has never tipped over, and is easy to use. It fits phones, tablets and laptops!
