Good sound and great non-twist cord. My only real complaint is the shape - since its rear is so large the fit is uncomfortable at the edge of the ear canal. If it tapered just a tiny bit toward the speaker, I'd use them more.
These are better then the original ones that came with the bluetooth. These are comfortable and more flexible.
None of these cheapo cameras have audio thats any good. Anything at high volume is distorted. I wish they would put a compressor mic of some kind on these. Picture okay but audio stunk..returned
I really appreciate that this fan has a rechargeable battery. We went camping for a couple of nights over the holiday weekend and thanks to this fan, we stayed comfortable in the heat.

I love my Sony surround system from 2008. I still use it today, but it lacks the bells and whistles of today's tech such as bluetooth. This product solved the issue! It was easy to install. They provide you with both regular composite cables, as well as an optical audio cable. I connected the optical audio to one of the available ports in my AV system. I also used a regular smartphone type power adapter. They do provide you with a usb-c cable for power, but it requires usb power adapter, which is NOT included. Any adapter with a usb port that you normally use for smartphones will work. Then turn it on to either Transmitter or Receiver mode, in my case, Receiver. My smartphone was able to see the adapter immediately and paired. Music sounds super! 5-Star item!

Works as expected.  Very easy to pair with your smartphone and listen to audio files through the car speakers.  Some of the buttons are small for large hands/fat fingers, but you do not have to change the settings frequently.  A great workaround if you have an old stereo system without any formal inputs.  Been reliable for several months of consistent use.

10‚Äù Flexible silicon Neck. 12 SMD bulbs. The overall length is 17‚Äù. Perfect for when I travel using my Chrome Book or using my laptop at night in the livingroom and don't want to light up the whole livingroom with a regular lamp. Weighs under 3 ounces.

Really good and budget friendly 2.1 system for your desktop

If i had to say in one line: "had a cheaper 2.1 before, but after i replaced it with the Logitech i'm never looking back!". Don't go cheap on the speakers, especially if you enjoy listening to music and enjoy at least a decent quality sound. Won't lie i've heard much better sound but only from a lot more expensive sets, for the price you can't go wrong with the Logi.

I especially enjoy the big weighted manual volume control, you can easily fine tune your sweet spot there, and i also want to mention the bigger than usual front speakers others brands i owned over the years (decade?) were a lot smaller and they usually have that plastic feel to them.

The quality of sound is good and enjoyable i don't hear the box sound that i usually do with small speakers. Even though i don't listen to bass heavy music i cranked the subwoofer almost all the way up, to meet my expectations of overall sound and music quality.

Highly recommended set if you are in the market of 2.1 speakers.

I would have done a video review but I'm not sure how to top the ones already posted :)

Anyhow I would just like to add that this little webcam is wonderful! It's really nice that it has auto light correction because I'm tired of having to use "auto-fix" on my pictures! I have tested it out by using my main light (ceiling fan light - the brightest in my room) and also with just a small desk lamp, both producing very good images. Good enough that you can see the name of the water bottle behind me on the floor, I thought that was neat.

Also the filters are fun to play with. I guess once I learn how to edit a video I will try my hand at youtube.

As far as the video capabilities, I use the video aspect every day as I started a personal vlog. The built-in microphone is excellent! I also use my webcam for Skype calls/video conferences. So far I have not experienced any lag. The microphone is very sensitive... I recorded a diary entry when it was raining the other day and when I replayed it I could hear the raindrops very pronounced. Glad my dogs weren't barking.

If anyone wants to see the clarity of the images, I used my webcam to take a picture of myself today which I'm using as my new profile picture on here.

I have triple monitors and have tried sitting the webcam on each with no issues. The brand of monitors I use are Dell, and two Acers. 17" WS LCD, 20" LCD, and 20" WS LCD. The installation was very easy, I was up and running in about three to five minutes.

In summary, I believe it was an excellent purchase for the price. I have no complaints to add.

Contender for best mouse I've owned, going up against the Logitech g900. They are very different mice, for different people though.

PROS:
-excellent feel. the ergonomics are on point, and it's honestly a pleasure to hold. slides nicely on any surface, weight is perfect, and fatigue is zero.
-separate buttons. so tired of the trend of mice that have one piece of plastic on top, rather than individual cut out buttons. (e.g. razer deathadder) it looks nice, but feels like crap.
-the auto switch scroll mechanism. I miss it on all other mice now. my G900 has a mechanical button to switch modes, and while that is nice, it's not as incredibly satisfying and intuitive as the MX master
-beautiful. my office mates are jealous
-LONG battery life. I forget it needs to be charged after 3 weeks to a month, which is about when it starts blinking at me. (I use it 4-8 hours a day at work), and when it does charge, the charge port is in a perfect place to not impede your work.
-excellent bluetooth. I leave it on my desk at night, and when sit down with my laptop it wakes right up and immediately works. I've had some input lag issues with it, but those are few and far between, and can be fixed by flipping the switch.

Neutral:
-the side scroll wheel. It's a nice feature, but doesn't respond all that well in GIMP or chrome. it's always either too sensitive or not enough. that said, it's the best side wheel i've ever used. they must be hard to do right or something.

CONS:
-mine came with a bump in the scroll wheel, due to bad molding. normally this wouldn't be a complaint, but for a $100 mouse (at time of purchase) it better be absolutely perfect.
-back and forward buttons are tiny. you get used to them for sure, but a more conventional layout would be a lot better, and more efficient.
-the gesture control button. might as well have just omitted it. It has its uses, but it's so awkward to press (the actual button is on the seam of the plastic and the metal) that it is 99% of the time easier to just do the thing the gesture was replacing. now, if the button had been under where your thumb rests naturally, this might have been in the pros category.
-the omission of side clicks on the scroll wheel. I can see why they wouldn't on a non-gaming mouse, but I would like them just to assign controls to.

I wanted to add outlets to the inside of a shelf, and this was a PERFECT accessory to do it! The flat plug means that I can plug it in behind furniture and still have the shelf against that wall, and the screw mounting holes let me mount this strip inside behind the trim where it is out of sight. Now we can plug in lights, smart speakers, charge phones etc all without a mess of wires going to the inaccessible outlet in the wall. The built in USB is really welcome as well, since most of the things being plugged in are often just USB anyway. I'm very happy with this!

I have been working out of detached workshop behind my house & set this in front of my house to capture the circular drive. It's not excessively far but it's out of range for a bluetooth device reach. It rings if anything goes through the circle (where the Camaro is) or down the drive past the house. I have tested it by walking at the very edge of the drive & it hasn't failed to alert. I may adjust the settings down before I move the receiver inside because it picks up a lot of cat activity. I didn't realize how many neighborhood cats stroll through my drive early in the morning.
I wanted to check this out before I committed to a mounting place so I set it under that oak tree. I thought it might be too shady to maintain the solar power requirements but it's been there a week with no issues. It's so discrete I'll probably just keep it on the rocks & move it closer to the tree. The mounting hardware is pretty nice, though, with a ball-jointed mount that sets up easy since it comes apart & has a lot of adjustment.
The receiver has three or 4 chimes & none of them are subtle. It also has another 30 or so songs. Some are holiday themed which could be fun if you were expecting guests for a party. It has some public domain tunes from the Baroque & Renaissance period as well as some contemporary tunes like "Music Box Dancer". I currently have it on what sounds like a mariachi band playing "March of the Toreadors" from Carmen which is kind of hilarious but I can't imagine what maniac would want to be alerted by that in their house ever. Most of the rest of the songs are like that.
It is hard to find a better subwoofer under $200

I've been using these almost everyday since they arrived and AM LOVING THEM!! These are the 2nd pair of Santana bluetooth I've ordered (the 1st being from the "oye" line) These are head and shoulders better than those. They are super easy to connect to bluetooth tooth. I've used both my phone and my computer as devices with ZERO problems or drops. The sound is freaking AMAZING! I started off with Soundgarden's 'Slaves and Bulldozers' and from the 1st second of that baseline it felt like I was enveloped in sound. I then listened to Lana Del Ray to hear a airy, female voice and the sound was pure and ethereal. You can hear each distinct part of the music. The bass is balanced and not overblown. I use these on my morning walks everyday so now they just play all random stuff. They are comfortable and even if I sweat in them, they wipe clean to a like-new product. The charge lasts for a solid 24 hours. The controls are ergonomically in the correct place. These headphones prove that music is indeed the best invention in the world!

These work great on airplanes and you can‚Äôt even hear the blaring announcements. And you just put your palm against the right headphone to be able to hear ambient noise. You can control the volume and skip tracks just by swiping the right headphone. Easy blue tooth connection.

These are awesome headphones. Some of the most comfortable headphones I've owned. The headphones are covered in a clothlike material that helps absorb and whick sweat during a workout.
The noise canceling is good but not great. The battery life has yet to leave me stranded and I've gone for a week without charging with fairly regular use.
The sound is clear and sounds crisp but I feel like it is lacking bass.

I found these headphones to be pretty good. I don't understand why others were complaining about the cord length. If you want to be able to move around more, get BlueTooth headphones! The computer itself is fine. It was originally sold to a university in California, and half the warranty had been used while it sat on a shelf. I had to have the warranty put in my name, and that took several days, so I could get it repaired. Still out 1.5 years of warranty! What even! The box was slightly worn, and the cables were dirty even though the box was sealed. I made the mistake of thinking it had a screen protector on it and tried to pull it off. Y'all, it was part of the screen. The seller refunded me the difference in price between a new item and a like new item. Since this already had a registered owner in Dell's system and it was some trouble to transfer over, I'd say it was conceivably like new but not new. I used that difference in price to pay for the repair. [Note: they did initially not want to make up the difference until I provided pictures of dirty cords, etc, and offered to escalate it to Amazon's customer service. But they did eventually grant the refund in difference. But it took weeks to get the difference in price and then to have the warranty transferred to me. I was *this close* to going through Amazon to try to return the whole shebang because of being misled. But they finally came through with a compromise I found acceptable. And I am otherwise happy with the computer.]

Here are my thoughts on the machine itself--unrelated to the seller:

PROS
- Terrific resolution. Much easier to read screen text.
- Lots of variety in color configurations for different light environments.
- 32 GB of memory really makes a difference over my previous 4-8GB.
- SSD is likewise fast and the whole system is quiet.
- This list of pros is short, but they are the most important things to me. Everything else is small beans.

CONS
- It is unbelievable how hard it is to get to the USB ports, etc, on the back! I literally have to use needle-nose pliers to plug or unplug USB devices--and a flashlight and contortions. I've read it's because the speakers didn't leave a lot of options for where to put these, but it just ridiculous.
- The sound is not as good as I expected. My last Dell AIO had JBL speakers and I don't think I realized how good those were. To be fair, the sound is fine, I was just expecting to be blown away by the six speakers on the bottom.
- Poor webcam placement. It's on the bottom at a really weird angle. Will probably upgrade.
- Onboard mic is also worse than what was in the Inspiron 2320. Remedied by purchasing a separate mic. But on a system this expensive, the mic and webcam should be premium, not barely useable.
- The screen would buzz softly at anything less than 100% brightness. A workaround is to reduce brightness via Radeon Pro graphics board. SOLUTION: go through Dell community customer service boards to update the VBIOS.
- The color temperatures sometimes get really off after the monitor goes to sleep and wakes up. I put a shortcut to Dell Premier Color in the taskbar and just reapply the setting, and it's fine. Still shouldn't even be a thing that happens on a machine with this price tag.
- Not a fan of the included wired mouse and keyboard, so I swapped out my own. I'm guessing this was originally meant for a computer lab where you wouldn't want someone to walk away with the peripherals.

OVERALL VERDICT
It took a while to get everything sorted, some of which was my fault. But I did get it sorted. The lower price from the seller comes with the tradeoff of losing some of the warranty and it taking extra time to get the remaining warranty transferred to me. But it still cost thousands less via this route than it would have otherwise. So worth it, I guess, if you've got the time for shenanigans.

This alarm clock is easy to use and I love the small portable size. It does need to be plugged into the wall, but it comes with an adapter. It connects easily to Bluetooth and there are different alarm modes. It is easy to set. The only thing that could be better with it is the sound quality. It has barely any bass.

I have an Android Auto head unit in my car, but it requires a direct connection to my phone to work. When I'm in a hurry, I usually throw my phone in the holster of the car and start driving... I don't have time to dig out the USB cable and carefully plug it in, it's an extra step that I often decide to skip and just stick with Bluetooth audio instead.
This cable changes everything! Now, the cable is magnetically hanging next to the phone already, all I need to do is wave it near the bottom of the phone and CLICK! It connects and starts Android Auto!
I had previously tried another similar magnetic cable, but it seemed to only work well as a charging device, it wouldn't send the data necessary for a connection like Android Auto over the USB cable. I'm happy to say, this one DOES, and it's every bit as wonderful as I hoped it would be! I can't speak yet for longevity, but so far I'm pleased with it. The unit comes with enough plugs and tips for my wife to have one in her phone as well, and of course enough cables for both of us to charge when not in the car as well. It IS a little bit of a finger magnet to have the little nub sticking out on the bottom of my phone, I wonder if eventually that will shorten the life of my USB port or the tip, but for now I'm very happy with it and would strongly recommend it for anyone in my position!

This phone A10s is basically the worse version of the old Galaxy S7 Edge from seven years ago. Slightly higher battery capacity - 4000 instead of 3600, same screen size, but the quality of the screen is not as good. S7 screen glass is much better quality, it's smoother and it's scratch resistant. A10 touch screen response time is worse than S7. There is some kind of a split second lag which feels strange after using S7.

Unlike S7, A10 doesn't have wireless charging :(

Blue light functionality doesn't work when I flip the blue light button. Button is there but functionality is not. No physical home button anymore.

NFC is not supported, can't pay in the store using this phone. Item specs here says "Connectivity NFC" which is misleading. Old S7 supports NFC.

Sound is HORRIBLE for single built in speaker. Comparing to old S7 playing the same song this phone is missing low frequencies, sound is flat and unimpressive, no Dolby. S7 sound has lots of volume, low and high frequencies and it feels like surround sound, like movie theater experience.

Dolby Atmos is disabled on A10 for built in speaker. Adaptive sound functionality is completely missing, nada. When I plug in earphones, Dolby Atmos gets enabled but doesn't make any difference and left ear piece is much more quiet than the right one. The phone doesn't distribute sound equally between the left and right ear pieces.

Not possible to opt out from sending Samsung all your phone logs info. All preinstalled apps had rights to mess up phones operation system and access everything on the phone and send your private info everywhere. I had to go through every setting to change that. New icons look ugly.

Good features are dual sim and a radio tuner so one can listen to the local FM radio without wi-fi or cell service. It still has a jack for wired ear phones, the wire is used as an antenna for the radio tuner. Fresh battery holds charge better than a seven years old Galaxy S7 Edge. It was easy to set up and install applications from Google Play. Phone is unlocked and can be used overseas.

It's an OK unlocked budget phone for everyday use that works with certain carriers only. But lack of NFC, no wireless charging, and bad sound is a big No.

What an amazing router at such a great price! I did a lot of research before I bought this. Because my previous router was a TP-Link router also, I was skeptical about this one at first. I was actually leaning towards a $300 Asus gaming router (I don‚Äôt game that much, I just wanted something powerful). But truth is, my previous TP-Link was just end of life‚Äîalmost five years old. I‚Äôm pretty certain that WiFi tech was going out. I found an article titled something like ‚ÄúBest 2020 Routers‚Äù by Tom‚Äôs Guide and this was his #1 ranked router out of 10! After reading some other reviews and resources about it, I pulled the trigger. This router quadrupled my speeds (which wasn‚Äôt hard to do I suppose since my previous internet speed was so intermittent and slow).

I am extremely satisfied with this router. I‚Äôm a lv 4 IT engineer for a big company, and I can tell you that this is a quality product. You are getting the quality of these expensive gaming routers for half or quarter the cost. And the newer admin interface is very easy and simple. The setup for this router was easier than I‚Äôve ever experienced. I have 25-30 wireless connections by the way and this thing is handling it like a champ. My other router really struggled with that.

I highly recommend this whether you‚Äôre technical or not, and whether you‚Äôre needing lots of bandwidth or just for basic internet usage.

Since the [[ASIN:B009S4FMB6 Jabra SUPREME Driver's Edition Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black/Silver]] comes with a headband, I tend to use it with the headband.  Unfortunately, my hair is thinning because I lose some each time I remove the headset.  Regardless, this bluetooth is extremely easy to synch with my Droid and it's recognized each and every time I turn on the Bluetooth in the car.  I wear this only for driving and I don't care that passersby give me funny looks, it works great.  The earpiece is larger than most contemporary bluetooth devices, but it's cushiony and comfortable for long drives.  The microphone is sensitive and responsive.  I haven't had a complaint yet with any call.  Slipping the earphone onto the headband is a simple task, and I find that I'm wearing it 90% of the time, preferring that to the ear wire and no band.  My main criticism other than the hair pulling of this design is that it takes some getting used to to operate the touch controls as well as turn the device on and off.  When off of the band, it's an easy feat, but no so when it's attached and you can't bend the microphone down completely.  Since the battery is really long lasting, it hasn't run out of power yet in the middle of a call.  Because you have options for charging this set, you're a step ahead, and with an adjustable headband, it fits most head sizes.  It's a good set.

Would not pass through my PS4 Pro in 4k nor my Xbox One S in 4k. These were super easy to install and so far have lasted great on trips to and from Wisconsin (we live in Chicago). They're extremely durable so far, and have held fine in slight rain and regular wind conditions. I usually ride in the city so have easy access to hide from the elements, but it's still nice that these will take a beating every once in the while when I'm on the long expressways.

The sound is loud and I'm always able to hear my music, whatever I'm playing. So far so good and at the price I'd say these are a great option for "lower" end bike speakers.

Overall rating 4.5, rounded up to 5. I don't think there's anything better for this price.

I wanted a "better" set of wireless earbuds for casual music listening: I wanted either AptX HD or LDAC, good battery life, and comfortable to wear for at least an hour or two. (I specifically ruled out over-the-ear headphones because I can't wear them very long, and ruled out wired earbuds for convenience. To me these are acceptable compromises.)

I was considering the Sony WF-1000XM4, but didn't want to pay that much for casual listening. I was also considering the new Soundcore Liberty 4, which on paper seems to be a great product. But I decided to try this "Liberty 2 Pro Upgraded" pair to see if was good enough for a lot less money.

So far I'm really very pleased: the sound is excellent for all my favorite music genres: classical, country, pop, rock, and latin pop, and after replacing the earpiece flaps and cushions I'm finding them very comfortable to wear as I work at my desk.

Important: to get the sound right, I had to do several things. First, I downloaded the Soundcore app, connected the earbuds, set the audio quality to LDAC (in settings). Then on my Android phone (Pixel), I went to the bluetooth advanced settings (usually hidden under developer options: do a web search for more details), and set the Audio Codec to LDAP, the LDAC quality to 900kbps, and made sure that the other BT settings (such as sample rate, bits per sample) were at the highest for good audio. Finally, I went back to the Soundcore app and played with the equalizer settings until I had what sounded best to my ears. The app has a neat little personal-hearing tester, which is worth a try, especially if your ears are getting older. After all this I had nice clean well-balanced sound. You might try different EQ settings for different music genres if you like, it does make a difference, but perhaps not huge enough to matter.

I've read many grumbles about LDAC, but I wonder if those are based on using the default settings: in my experience getting the settings right makes a very big difference.

PS It seems that the LDAC settings on Android go back to "best efforts" everytime the earbuds are disconnected. Quite annoying: I have to set them back to 900kbps every time. The other settings are stable.

The premise with the ENSGO TC7 8‚Äù Teleprompter and others like it is to find a lens adapter that fits your camera and then screw it into your camera... then let your camera hang, by those threads, from the teleprompter. What??

First, the product: included in the box of the ENSGO TC7 8‚Äù Teleprompter is a set of lens adapters for common lens sizes going from 49mm to 82mm. There's also a bracket for a phone mount along with a couple of foam pieces to use with the phone adapter. Lastly, a bluetooth remote control for use with teleprompter apps.

If one follows the included directions or even use the product images as a guide, this would be the setup: Pick the correct adapter size and screws it to the lens of the camera. The adapter then slips into a slot in the main body of the product and from there, the tripod is mounted to the teleprompter or the camera. In either of these mounting scenarios, the thread holding the camera to the adapter is expected to hold the entire weight of the camera or the weight of the teleprompter + tablet. Please do NOT do this.

I use two tripods for this setup. One for the teleprompter and the other for the camera itself. I have yet figured out a secure bracket that would allow the camera to mount to the teleprompter without putting pressure on the screw threads.
they lose the stickiness on the pad too quickly.  lost one lens caps already.. not a happy camper at all

I got this to serve as a portable speaker for my phone and it works great. I looked at a few, and the JBL brand caught my eye because it usually means high quality.
This thing is easy to use, has a nice sound and pretty good battery life. I've used it in my home office and also taken it on trips so I can play music in the hotel room or campsite.
It's also a pretty good speaker phone if you want to use your phone to make conference calls. For $30 it's a great deal.

This is a horrible product and a pathetic attempt at a more affordable item by a company that has the reputation of being better than this monstrosity. There is no bass (despite a knob that claims to be such). The clarity sounds like a rock band sinking under mud all while trapped in a well. The wattage depicted is a total lie. Even if backed by an amp, this speaker will fail to deliver the promised power. I don't recommend this to anyone; except back to its company with a dunce hat on it that written on would read: "Wha what what... Please start over and try again."

[[VIDEOID:cba94cf54ae6b2ddff8698dab81d68e3]] These style headphones are great. They don‚Äôt sit in your ear but just outside. Which makes it so you can hear what‚Äôs around you. This is important for walking at night and being safe

These are comfortable and easy to wear. I think the finish is nice and my first impressions are really good. They are easy to pair and they function well

I listen to music all day at work and I also enjoy listening to music at home and as such I spend a lot of time with headphones on my head. This is one of the more unusual headsets I have used, more in terms of their appearance than for their features or quality. These are decent headphones with some very interesting features though the sound profile is a little off, particularly in the highs.

I received the blue and yellow headset and these definitely look like headphones for kids. They almost look like toys, though in use they have revealed themselves to be a bit better than toys. The main features they offer are Bluetooth connectivity, FM tuning, direct audio connection via 3.5mm cable and hands-free connectivity.

When I received these, they were completely dead and needed to be charged up. It took me a little time to realize they were not broken, but once I plugged them in to charge the problem became very clear. I was then able to work with them. So, if you receive these and cannot get them to work, try plugging them in first.

I was able to pair these to my computer and they connected without trouble. The headphones identify themselves as ‚ÄúKB-2600‚Äù. When I had them connected to my computer they worked fine and they did not stutter or skip which is all you really can ask for. I did not try testing the range.

I discovered, quite by accident, that this headset has a full-blown FM tuner and it can scan for channels and make channel presets. It actually works surprisingly well and I found myself listening to a station coming from 50 miles north and it was surprisingly clear. Most headsets I have used to not have an FM tuner so finding these to have a tuner was a pleasant surprise.

I loaded up some music and listened very closely to the sound, and unfortunately I found an issue with the sound profile. The bass is good; it is about right, not overdriven and not soft. The midrange is slightly strong but still quite good. The problem is in the highs which sound muddled and flat. When listening to vocals the sound is not particularly sharp, instead sounding far away. It is fixable with an equalizer, but with small music player or phone an equalizer may not be available.

Comfort-wise, these are actually more comfortable than their looks would suggest. I personally like a headphone that clamps a little tighter on my ears but these are better than some of the other sets I have used. The pads on each phone is a mildly firm leatherette material that is comfortable and does not heat up as much as one might expect. The headband itself has a very soft pad on it that provides a very nice cushion between itself and the head.

These are very interesting headphones and they have some cool features. Except for having a deficiency in the high range, these work well and they are quite comfortable. If you get a two-color unit it is a very good choice for younger listeners.

Disclaimer: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at no cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.
This stereo splitter made it easy to hook up my iPod to a couple of Bose revolve speakers.

This is a fairly good mouse.  Its one flaw is the battery receiver compartment.  The lid feels flimsy and pops up if the mouse falls off my desk but when you go to open it the release on the bottom and it doesn't release easily.

First thing's first, it is important to understand what you are getting. This isn't a VR headset - you aren't going to be bringing these on a trip to play some beat saber. These are simply a screen that you can strap to your head.

Now that we have that out of the way, lets go into the things I love about these. Plugging these into a device is (usually) a breeze and you can get to consuming your content on a virtual screen in no time. The included blackout shade is a great addition, giving you the choice between maintaining situational awareness of your surroundings, or closing yourself off to the world and immersing yourself in the content.

I particularly like using these on a plane. It is great to be able to shut out everything that is going on around you and just watching content without your seatmates peeking over to see what you are watching. I do recommend using in-ear headphones since on or over ear types of headphones can get uncomfortable when combined with the glasses.

If you wear glasses, I suggest purchasing prescription lens inserts - it will really make your experience just that much better.

I think it is really smart that these are powered by whatever device they are plugged into. This allows the device to be less bulky and lighter; hence more comfortable for long term wear. The downside being, your device will consume power quicker. This can be mitigated with a wireless charger (since your glasses are plugged into your device).

I am not a huge fan of the iphone adapter solution, but it does work, and I find the experience better on iphone than other devices I have tried (samsung phone, iPad pro, and laptop).
Just spend the extra money and get this good tablet. Screen is awesome. Speakers are great has Dolby app. Works great. I got this to replace my daughter's two year old fire tablet.

I am going on vacation in a few days and when I go, I like to take a speaker with me so I can listen to my tunes or even podcasts. This speaker delivers decent sound and is easy to use. I was able to pair it with my laptop and then on my iPhone without any issues. Listening to Alan Parsons now. I did have to increase the volume with my phone before I was able to lower it with the speaker

It's getting better. Wish I had originally checked the dot pitch better. The curved screen is nice with no dead pixels. Buy better speakers because the built in sound is terrible.

UPDATE : Bought this over a month ago and find that I like it better and better. Added a star from 3 to 4. I guess it's a learning curve from getting around the quirks. Bought some cheap speakers and that really helps!

We've been using an older first generation Portal and like it very much. I was not expecting to be so impressed with this one, but wow have they managed to improve almost everything about the original! It still has the very cool zoom-and-pan style camera feature that follows the subject, as well as all the fun filters and of course my kids' favorite, story time... but the polish and style of this unit is really premium. The speaker is fantastic and LOUD if you want it to be. The clarity and bass rivals my bookshelf speakers so well, sometimes the kids play music off it and I could have sworn they were using the speakers in the living room. But the biggest improvement over the previous generation is the ability to run off battery power and move around. The "portable portal" honestly makes so much sense, I wonder why the original stationary style ones came out first!
Make no mistake, it is NOT a tablet, it is not thin and won't fit in an attach√© case nicely. It is wedge-shaped making it stand easily at an ideal angle, and even has a cut-out handle to pick it up and carry it to a better location for video chat. This is great for bringing it to wherever my kids happen to be congregating currently, and it can be put back up on the shelf when done to charge. Like the original Portals, it has Alexa built in and can act as an Echo for most things, however it is very tied into Facebook's ecosystem. That means that although it seems to run something akin to Android behind the scenes, this is NOT going to offer a standard App store, and even things like Youtube are not available for it (licensing issues with Google I'd suppose). However there is a browser, and you can navigate to YouTube and play it from the website just fine, although a proper app would be much easier to navigate. It does have Plex support, which I found interesting since I have a Plex server. I never thought I'd find Plex available where Youtube is not! Meanwhile, between Youtube in the browser, Amazon Music through Alexa and content on Plex, there are plenty of ways to make it a music streamer on that glorious better-than-it-should-sound speaker. And the camera works just as well if not better than the OG Portal!
Calls over FB Messenger or Whatsapp work well, and of course the camera / mic not only have a switch to toggle, but the camera has a physical cover that can slide over the lens in case you don't trust Facebook not to snoop. But that's another story.
All things considered, this is a solid product.

For a $125 this is a complete ripoff.  I bought two pairs of Logitech headphones.  This one and the Logitech ClearChat Comfort/USB Headset H390 ($25).  The microphone and the headphone quality are the same and they look almost identical.  The only difference is that the $25 pair has a mute button on the cord.  I have been buying Logitech for over 10 years and I am shocked that they would pull something like this.  Usually with this brand an investment of $125 would have a more noticeable boost in quality.  This item is a complete ripoff.  Buy the $25 pair and you'll come out on top.
Fits my earbuds case well, I have room for the charger and additional buds. Protects and I like the clip. Would recommend

Although this review may seem to be "a little late", I do think that my experience with the earlier model of this Sony is appropriate. I bought a KDS-60A2000 in January of 2007 so I've had it for a few months over a year. As most of you will recognize, my unit is a 60" SXRT from the previous model year.

Like many of you, I did a lot of Internet research before settling on the Sony - it was very highly rated by a number of sites. The final straw was live viewing many sets side-by-side on the same program from the same source - it was a no-brainer - the Sony had at least as good a picture as any Plasma in the store and the price couldn't be beat.

I use Verizon's FIOS fiber optic service and have the unit hooked up through my home theater audio. The picture - indeed the HD experience - is simply awesome - especially live sports - like ice hockey.

I did "tune" the picture using the DVE (Digital Video Essentials) HD optimization DVD and it remains the sharpest, most accurate picture that I have personally seen (including the high-bucks plasma sets). I've had absolutely no problems of any kind and there have been no regrets on purchasing this set.

Another tidbit: I also purchased a Logitech Harmony 880 remote control and am able to control the Sony, the Verizon HD receiver, a Yamaha home theater receiver and a Sony upscaling DVD with a single click. It's programmed via the Logitech Internet site (using a USB connection) and can handle about any peripheral you might have. I've got a bowlful of unused remotes now. It's a little pricey at $150 but it has contributed to my HD enjoyment by simplifying the mechanics.

Nice Quality.  Definitely an improvement over what  I have been using.  $1350+ worth?  Meh....  I wish there was more metal in the headband so I knew it wasn't going to break.  I wish the audio cable could plug into either left side or right side and that it was one sided removable for ergodynamics.  I wish instead of a  coffin box that it came in, that it came with a nice armored carrying case with a caribiner.  To bad it didn't have a slide mechanism so that I could experience closed air vs open air.  Sometimes where you might wear these things could get noisy outside and you don't want that to encroach on the sound.  They are comfortable.  I have heard things in music I haven't heard before or I can hear it more clearly, it's like listening for the first time, gives you that thrill back again.  Great sound as promised.  No going back now.  I got these for work so that I could hear the guys clearer on a teleconferencing session.  I like listening to music as I work, so...I splurged.

Nice audio monitoring system

It goes in your ears pretty easy and I like the design

The case it comes in feels sturdy and durable. It would be pretty good I think for traveling and bringing it places

Overall I think it‚Äôs nice
It's not actually any better than the built in microphone on my old all-in-one desktop. Has lots of noise and artifacting. I will probably never use it again.

These seems like pretty standard earbuds

I like the design and think they‚Äôre nice. Sort of remind me if AirPods

They look cool and I like the case for keeping them organized and making sure they don‚Äôt get lost. Easy way to charge them too

I am a graphic designer and web developer on a budget and this Acer CB272 bmiprx 27" Full HD Monitor is a great addition to my home office where I do the majority of my creative work.

I have another large monitor connected to my MB Pro using an HDMI cable, but I have experienced issues with Photoshop unless my displays mirrored. This monitor has a VGA connection, and I believe that is the reason I can use this independently as a secondary display without my images blacking out. This monitor has 1 x Display Port, 1 x HDMI, 1 x VGA, 1 x Audio-in, 1 x Audio-out. VGA and audio cables are included,

This frameless widescreen monitor has a small footprint and can pivot vertically. I think that's pretty nifty since I have never owned a monitor that could do that before. The screen height is adjustable to 4.7", with a tilt angle of -5¬∞ to 20¬∞, and 360¬∞ swivel for perfect viewing without fade I can adjust my screen when I adjust my position or change places.

So far I have not experienced any light bleed along the edges and I will update this review if that happens over time.

You don't have to spend hundreds or even thousands of dollars for a high-quality display. Been there, done that and won't do it again because technology becomes much better and cheaper over time. I splurged on a twelve hundred dollar display several years ago and this monitor offers excellent image quality at a much more affordable price.

My professional recommendation is... buy this monitor and go have fun with all the money you've saved.

I like Alexa, her voice is crystal clear and the music sounds as if it's come from an expensive speaker!!!
I chose the Alexa Echo due to its small size!! I also chose the darker color so that my Grandchildren would not notice it! This way I don't have to worry about them touching it!!

We have been needing a good alarm clock in our house for so long . I saw this and knew it sounded like a perfect alarm for our house . I was not expecting anything spectacular but was super happy with what arrived . It is by far the best alarm clock Iv ever owned . The Bluetooth syncing feature for the time is just amazing and my favorite thing about it. The phone charging top is my 2nd favorite thing . The ability to use either of my watch chargers with us is a big bonus. I have a reg usb I watch charger and a usb C Iwatch charger I just got from amazon and it also works with the clock ! So many features ! I like having an FM radio to use in the house now ! It‚Äôs been years since Iv had a working FM radio in our home . It really exceeded my expectations . The speakers could be a better quality but for an alarm clock it‚Äôs not bad . It‚Äôs better than the iPhone speakers for sure . Sometimes I listen to books and my daughter likes to listen with me and my iPhone just us t that loud . This made it so we both could hear the book being read . I am Very pleased with this clock . It‚Äôs a good design . I know my son wants one for his room now that he‚Äôs seen how cool it is . We really rely on our cell
Phone alarms more than anything but now we have this and it‚Äôs kinda like our backup in case my alarm fails for some reason . It‚Äôs happened before and was a disaster . It‚Äôs been nice having a reliable clock set to the exact same time as my phone.

I don't usually purchase products that require earbuds because I have considerable hearing loss. However, I took a chance on this little radio and I am VERY glad I did. I can hear this radio extremely well -- it has a tremendous amount of volume power considering its size (4" long, about the size of a cell phone). It has AM & FM bands, stereo/mono setting, can be used w/out the earbuds as a regular radio. It also allows memory pre-sets of your favorite stations. The radio attaches to your belt via a removable plastic clip.

If you use hearing aids,you will need to remove them to use the earbuds, of course. I suppose you could try a different headset device -- one that can be used WITH hearing aids. I have found that I can hear this radio very well with the use of the earbuds. Again, my hearing loss is severe-to-profound, but I can hear this baby!

I HIGHLY recommend this radio for use with or without any type of headest. It takes two AAA batteries, which seem to last in this device a very long time!

A top-notch product! GO FOR IT!

The Fire HD 8 (gen 5) had screen mirroring.  This Fire HD 8 (gen 6) does not.  Screen mirroring is an android function that allows you cast exactly what is on the tablet screen and the audio to a TV wirelessly.  Removal of this feature was unexpected and was the main reason I bought this as I'd read that was in the Fire HD 8.  But not in this one.

I have a bose soundlink mini... this thing sounds like a clock radio compared to it... no bass, glassy sound... ugh, now I have to return it.  I also have a ihome single channel 3" tiny speaker from 6 years ago and that sounds better.

It has been at least five and a half hours since I started wearing these. They are very comfortable. I was in the bedroom with the dogs, listening to iPods on my iPad and I couldn't hear my husband squawking or his high volume television show. It was like heaven on earth. The bluetooth between the headphones and my iPad paired seamlessly. I only had to go into the bluetooth settings and select this headphone. I liked the sound, too.  It was a very nice experience from box to using the headphones

The best in the market! I replaced a 350. It is much more comfortable! Quality is fantastic! I do 5 to 7 hours of concall per day . Dump anything else you have and get it immediately. The sound quality is outstanding.
Also even on a bicycle up to 10 mph people think you are at your desk!! You can also drive with a window open and strictly no noise.
I tried more than 60 Bluetooth headsets and only this one is the best

Connection is weak. Cuts out when in pocket and in wifi heavy areas, such as the gym, which is astonishing as this is equipped with Bluetooth 5.0.  Sounded fantastic and the price is fair, but the connection is really bad.

I normally avoid in ear earbuds and use wireless headphones or do without. My ears are small and most earbuds hurt within minutes, but I have one really inexpensive set that works ok, but if I'm outside working in the horse barn, they can get sweaty and slippery. These are far better than I expected.

They come with three different size ear bud attachments so you can get the right fit - the smallest set fits me well and they don't pinch or hurt even after an hour of wearing them. The over ear hook isn't hard and it's thin enough to fit over each ear love when with my glasses on. I work with horses and the associated barn chores so that means sweat and lots of movement which can be a problem with earbuds. These have impressed me. After daily use for a week, they haven't fallen off, slipped out of place or lost the connection to my phone despite sweating, shoveling, riding and high heat.

The sound quality is fine for my needs. I listen to mostly audiobooks and some classical music while out with the horses. I can clearly hear the violins vs a harp or French horn without distortion. The only real complaint is when I get a call. I can hear the caller clearly, but they say I sound like I'm in a tin can.

Picked this up on the gold box deal. Moved from my 25$ a month plan on my LG Optimus V to this one.

In hindsight, while I am not entirely happy with the phone, it is a step up and I kind of don't regret losing the cheaper plan I was grandfathered in on.

Pros!
Battery life is pretty nice.
Screen is bright, looks great.
TONS of room to install apps. As I mentioned above, my old phone was an LG Optimus and had a whopping 200~ megs to install them.
Beats Audio is actually pretty nice.

Cons!
Worst wifi I have ever used in my life. My touchpad, android tablet, old LG phone, etc all got 2-3 signal bars out of 3 while in my house. I barely even get the first little dot indicator on this one.
Not exactly a thorough instruction manual (moving from 2.2 to 4.0 is fairly different).
Phones shape is just, odd to me. It's not flat, and that little bar at the bottom pokes out strangely to me. That being said, I didn't take off any stars from the review for design issues. If it works, it works.
Cell camera is kinda "bleh" but then again all of em are. BRIGHT LED flash lights up the subjects but also washes out the photos.
Worse/slower data than my old LG on the same network.

Basically, as I mentioned before, while I don't entirely regret losing my 25$ monthly plan and moving off my old LG, paying 10$ a month more for literally the same thing stings a bit when I don't like the reason I moved that much. It's a great phone, but there are some fairly strong cons to me about it, the major one being the weak wifi signal.

Still, it cost me 50$ on the gold box deal, so if you can find it for around 50-60 and are upgrading from an older phone model, it's probably worth it. I would not, however, pay MSRP for this thing or anywhere near it.

Virgin Mobile does have some awesome reps though, and when I called in to transfer my phone (mid month, and I wanted to see if I could keep my old month or if I had to start a new one), they peeked at the call record and saw I had only used ~20 minutes. Had me swapped out and going in about 5 minutes and the phone was working for texts in about 10 mins.

4 stars for virgin mobile, 3 for the phone. If the buggy wifi gets fixed soon, then it'd be a 4 to 5 star phone. That slower data than my older device is really what kills the review for me.

This is a terrific laptop backpack. It is lightweight, but sturdy. My Dell desktop-replacement laptop doesn't fit in some backpacks, but it slips into this one perfectly. I bought a briefcase-style case which does fit, and that one has room for my Fire too, but not much else fits into it except the charging cables. This one is different. Not only is there plenty of room for (in addition to the tablet, phone, wallet, and glasses) noise-canceling headphones and snacks, but cables, a camera, a sweater, your personal travel pharmacy, a magazine or two, and more. In fact, if you're just going somewhere overnight, this might be all you need. There are many well-crafted pockets, all accessible from both inside and out. The padded backpack straps are strong and comfortable.  There's also a handle on top and a wide strap along the back so you can slip it onto your wheeled bag for those dashes across airports between planes. Wonderful backpack for business travelers, writers, or anyone who can't do without their electronics.

I like this style Jensen as it does more,better than higher priced Sony boom boxes I've had.The LED display is great,and it takes more motion without skipping.No having to bang on it like with Sony.Plus,the burgundy color gives visual pleasure over black.It sounds great.Just don't make a habit of blasting the speakers or you might get a slight sound in one at high volume.I've had 3...1 given as a gift.Very satisfied.

Bulky but overall, has a good battery life. The sound could be much better, but it gets the task done til a better speaker can be purchased! If you are looking for a great clearness in sound, "This Speaker is Not It"!

The sound quality is muffled as though you are under water. The headphones feel a little bit sick and bulky around the ears and the headband is non-adjustable, so I'm me it's it's a little wide. There is no noise cancellation as you can hear everything in the environment around you and the sound from the headphones seems to diminish overtime in comparison to your environment. There is no volume adjustment control only a stop-start button on the microphone attachment. Does down my microphone attachment does not work (tried it on my phone & game controller).  The only Advantage is that you don't have to use Bluetooth, everything else about these headphones is trash!

So, I have this backpack, and it is kinda weird. You have to see my pictures as it is a different style than what is pictured in the description. I don't really care for it as it is awkward to handle.

--It is a basic looking back pack. I like the bright orange in contrast to the black. That is likely the only feature I really like.
--The bag is deep. It measures roughly 21" long, this includes the top portion being unfolded, as that is usable space if need be. @17" wide
--The access to the main compartment is a velcro closure with adjustable hook straps for added security (and to keep added length folded down). Unlike many backpacks, there is just one slit opening across the top with velcro to close. Most backpacks have a zipper closure, as well as going a bit down the sides, for ease of access. I'm not fond of how my bag is styled in that way.
--Inside the great nylon cavern of the main compartment, it splits into several more compartments and pockets, including a lightly padded pocket.
--exterior pockets included two open side pockets that would be great to stick a water bottle in or an umbrella.
--two good sized compartments on the front- one zippered, one velcro flap closure.
--one rear zip pocket, as well as what appears to be a pass through strap of material- perhaps for use on a luggage handle?
--padded shoulder straps are comfortable. Straps include d-rings for clipping keys, or whatever to.
--overall feel is good
-I cant for the life of me find the USB port that it claims to have. I don't see anywhere for headphones, etc.. so I don't know what is going on.

The part that makes me really not like it is the main opening. First, it is deep, which can be good or bad depending on your needs. But, the top folds over way to easily. So it takes some major rooting around to find stuff, and the flap wants to fold down, and if it manages to fold down, it is easily closed tight by the velcro. This is super annoying if you want to get into and out of the bag repeatedly. I'm just like STAY OPEN. If it zipped, it would be better, then at least if it folder over it would be easy enough to get it, but with the velcro closing it up, it is irritating.

The other aspect that I dont care for is the hooks on the front. Well, they are anchored on the front, but since they are used to help keep bag closed (in addition to the velcro), when they aren't hooked, they are dangling down the front. So you have those kicking around in the front, and the shoulder straps and all its extras kicking around in the back. It isn't as clean or stream lined as it could be. It feels frumpy, I am sorry to say. I was hoping to replace my every day carry bag- I like to have a little cross body purse, plus a back pack for all my additional daily needs. This might get old quick as I try to get used to the odd features.

We're still getting to know each other. I can't get schedule reminders, or Bluetooth syncs. What's funny is if the tv is on and "she" hears her name "she" perks up. Don't let an Alexa commercial come on... too funny.
Used these to route speaker wires - wish the cover locked into the base better.

I have an HP laptop I want to use in the field for running an all-day event stream without needing to tether to a wall. I thought something like this would be a good move to keep it charged since the battery only lasts about 2.5 hours running the stream (it's CPU intensive). However, this laptop does not support USB-C PD charging unfortunately (I was hoping it did, there is a USB-C port, but sadly only output is supported), so I had to resort to using the AC part. Now, I know converting DC from a battery to AC requires quite a bit of power loss, but one recharge of my laptop from single digits to 80% practically wiped the power supply out. I definitely would not be able to charge the laptop more than once off of this, and I have my doubts it would even make it all the way to 100% without dying honestly. I was really hoping it would last longer. If you have a PD-compatible laptop, this might work better for you. I DO love that it has an AC outlet for emergencies, and I'll probably take this with us camping because it is pretty cool to have. But the product description implies this is a good option for charging a laptop, but for the price I've seen better options I think. At the very least, I wish this had a automotive-style 12v DC port so I could try getting that kind of charger for my laptop (less power lost since not inverting to AC), but alas. The only real laptop charging options are AC and USB-C/PD, and if your laptop doesn't use the latter, the first is a pretty inefficient option.

This is my second set of neckband speaker I have. I listen to music a lot, pretty much all the time especially when I am at work. Thankfully the environment allows me to use this neckband speakers to listen to music that way. It is actually safer to do that than having headsets on which can isolate you and could prevent you from realizing what is going on around you. That is why I like using these types of speakers or bone conducting headsets, so I can still hear what is going on around me.

This one in comparison to my other one especially is a lot lighter, I barely notice that it is there really. It is not as flexible as my other one but it forms nicely around my neck and really works and fits well that way. It has just the right amount of buttons that allows me to blindly control it without having to take out my phone to move onto the next song, change the volume, pause the music in case I have to talk to someone and really do anything I need to.

The sound quality is very nice and you can really get a good volume going with this so no worry, you will still have plenty of volume if you want to blast music into your ears. It is very easy to use and to connect to your phone. I have a Samsung S20 and had no issues at all. I get about 7 hours or so of music which gives me about a work day worth of music and charging doesn‚Äôt take that long. My other one does have more staying power and does charge a bit faster, but by having these two I can now alternate, while one is charging I can use the other one. Very happy with this one but if anything changes I will update my review.

I have tested and reviewed literally hundreds of Bluetooth speakers and while I am not a fan of music that is particularly bass heavy I found this speaker produces rich, vibrant sounds from all wave lengths. It produces more than ample volume for most any setting and has several connection methods.

While I have tested and reviewed Bluetooth speakers costing far more than what this does, the sound quality from this speaker rivals them. In relation to the sound quality this speaker is simply incredible.

In regards to charging time and battery life, both are outstanding. In my tests charging takes about approximately 3 hours to charge the built in 5,000 mAh battery and the speaker lasts a solid 4.5 hours at max volume - 12 hour with volume midway (of course this will vary a bit due to exact settings).

There are multiple ways to connect to this speaker including Bluetooth 5.0, which can reach much further than previous versions, through an AUX cable, a 3.5mm jack, SD card and you can even connect via NFC (Near Field Communication).

I have taken this speaker with me to the pool for the last couple of months and have been thoroughly impressed with its performance. The battery, being 5,000 mAh, it‚Äôs much longer lasting than most allowing for all day listening and the sound quality has been outstanding.

This speaker is rated IPX4 meaning it is tested and proven safe for splashes - technically, a device with a level 4 water resistance rating can survive small water jets projected by a 6.3mm nozzle at any angle.

If you have 2 of these speakers they pair for true surround sound producing a full, rich, encompassing sound environment that is hard to believe can come from a pair of small Bluetooth speakers. I have the larger version of this speaker and pair the two together outside by our pool for a really amazing sound quality.

This battery and speaker comes with a bit of weight - 2.31 pounds to be exact, far less than the larger version but still heavier than most Bluetooth speakers.

This is an all around great Bluetooth speaker that I certainly recommend.

All my earbuds require a micro USB and all the cables that come with them are short. This is long enough to be useful and does the job. Pretty durable - I‚Äôll be getting a few more because everything is coming with micro usb now and those annoying short little cables that aren‚Äôt easy to work with.
This is an awesome speaker. So small yet so powerful!

My child has hearing problems so I was concerned about him using headphones that would further damage his eardrums.  These are great as it limits the volume but still allows him to hear. I have used them myself to check the safety and they work great. They are comfortable to wear, easy to connect and long battery life.  We both use them all day long and the battery lasts.

These are more narrow in person than I realized from the description - that's ok. The four inch length is excellent for small indoor projects and the narrow width has actually turned out to be useful as well. I have several of these reinforcing a couple of decorative pieces on an enormous outdoor holiday wreath. You can't even see the zip ties. I also used a couple to repair the broken Velcro strap on a horse show championship neck drape so it can be displayed. No sewing required. Again - these ties are small enough to be nearly invisible.
Bought the 508UAB. I am seriously impressed for a bargain bin car stereo. Good sound, receives radio stations well, Bluetooth connectivity is excellent. The controls are easy to navigate.
I have one of these hooked to my TV and the other hooked to my computer and I just switch out which one needs to be plugged in to my portable speaker so I don't have to move cords around.

I got these in and LOVE how small they are! They go right in my ear and I connect them to my phone pretty easily. Then I start playing music and walk one room away from my phone in the house and it starts cutting out and disconnects completely. I walked like 5 or 7 feet away when it cut out. I then connected them again and put my phone on top of my car outside and walked about the same distance and it disconnected again. It has extremely short range.

SO I started carrying my phone to listen to music but then the problem is, these headphones fall out non stop and don't stay in my ears. Just problem after problem with these and I've never had a pair so awful! I've had dollar tree headphones I loved more than these!

I am not the target demographic for this device: middle-aged empty nester who loves to watch sci-fi, thrillers, and horror. I have a number of these brilliantly simple, highly configurable lights. They are perfect in the bedroom where, depending on our intended mood, a variety of different colors or modes might be appropriate. I have two in the living room, hiding behind tropical plants at a 3' height, on either side of the big screen, about 5 feet away on each side. I have a routine set up to turn off all the lights in the room and engage campfire mode in both lights at 45% brightness with a single keyword. Voila--instant torchlight in the jungle (or romantic candlelight - take your pick). I am a colossal LOST fan, and this lighting is perfect for watching LOST, or anything scary or dark. And if I need a different effect, that's only a few words away.

The simplicity with which these set up and configure themselves is so good it makes Apple products jealous. If you have an Alexa on your Wi-Fi network, simply plug the Glow in to a power source, open the Alexa app on your phone, and the light will auto-connect to your network and add itself to Alexa. It will then prompt you to configure it with a name and add it to any groups, etc. Utterly simple. If the setup fails, it might ask you to scan the barcode on the back of the booklet it came with to get it going, but this has not been my experience - they have all self-configured and join the network seamlessly.

For those of you complaining this does not have a mic and speaker - folks, it works WITH an Echo device. It is a light - that's it. If Amazon built Alexa mics and speakers into this it would cost double--and I am positive they are developing just such a light ...for which you will pay $60+.

Normally, these are $30/ea, but they were 45% off on Prime Day, so I added a few more. There are indeed cheaper (and much more expensive) smart mood lights on the market, but if you run Alexa at home, this is hands down the best way to do it. Seamless.

It baffles me that Amazon does not have a whole range of lighting products which work exactly like this. They easily could. Give me one of these on a larger scale (12-15") and make it weatherproof for outside on the patio, please.

This is a good sound bar for a tv that is lacking sound. If you have a tv that already produces a loud enough sound that you can hear it well- this probably isn't for you as it won't fill the room with sound like a giant surround sound system and it really doesn't compliment a tv with already good speakers. But if you want this just to music in the kitchen or for a smaller tv, yeah it'd work great for that! I got it for a big tv that I could already hear on though and thought it would add some "boom" factor like a theater but was severely mistaken. Apparently that's just all sound bars as I've tried multiple ones now. They won't give you a theater booming sound or surround sound at all... But they're ok if you don't have super high standards.

Honestly I don't get the soundbar hype and would recommend a surround sound or a pair of larger speakers.

The VModa Crossfade 2 Wireless Headphones are great! I love the color (matte white and chrome), which I consider to be neutral or unisex. They look sleek and modern. The packaging is a lot smaller than another pair that I have.  They fold up nicely which makes them small and compact. They fit nicely into a carrying case. They are easy to set-up, wireless (although they come with an aux cord) and Bluetooth enabled. Charging the headphones is pretty easy (usb cord), and the battery life is great. More importantly, the sound quality is good. You can control the volume easily on the ears of the headset. The mic picks up sound well. The ear muffs are comfortable, not too loose or too tight. The sound is clear, sharp and does not bleed out. They are not too bass heavy.  And while some may frown at the price, I think the quality of these are better than Beats and Bose, but comparable to Sennheiser. My kids and husband each have an older pair of VModa‚Äôs, so I can attest to the quality and durability of this brand. They are made to last, so I expect several years of quality listening and enjoyment. I‚Äôd definitely recommend these.

The monitor looks great & is very portable. I don't game so I'm not an expert on lag but I don't notice any in day to day use. I do travel for work & work from multiple locations & this has been wonderful for setting up a 2nd screen. It works best when plugged into the A/C power adapter but it can be powered from my laptop from a single USB-C cable that also provides the video source.

It is very thin with the stand/cover so it easily fits in my laptop backpack. The packaging it shipped in is nice & sturdy & has a lot of foam which made me question whether I should be unceremoniously chucking it in my backpack but it hasn't been damaged. The screen & case stand do weigh a little over 3lbs so the addition to my backpack is noticeable.

The case/stand was a little confusing to put on but it works great. The surface is grippy enough to tilt the monitor all the way to the edge. The speakers are about like laptop speakers in volume but lack low end.

it looks like it would work, but maybe not the right thing for my headphones, (earphones) normally use with an iphone or something... but they have a mic and 2 prong output so i thought it might work... i might be doing something wrong, any advice would be appreciated.  they are from monoprice like $78 noise canceling headphones

I have worked with a number of trackballs, my most successful being a Logitech M570 which served me well for years. I finally wore it out and after some research I purchased the Logitech MX Ergo to replace it. I have had it about three days, and it has already proven to be exactly what I had hoped and more. It‚Äôs not perfect but it‚Äôs close.

I was attracted to the fact that it works both as a wireless mouse with a USB receiver as well as a Bluetooth mouse. I have two computers on my desk, one being a Windows 10 system and the other being a Linux (Arch-based) system. My old trackball worked with both though I had to move the receiver between the systems, so I went with the assumption that this one would also work with both.

I connected the trackball to my Windows system via Bluetooth and it has been flawless in operation. It connects without intervention and it works exactly as expected - all buttons work as they should and the operation is very smooth and predictable.

I plugged the USB receiver into the Linux machine, pushed the channel button on the trackball and it immediately started working on the Linux machine, even though it was still paired to the Windows system via Bluetooth. It works exactly as it should and I have had absolutely no issues with the trackball on my Linux installation. So now, I can switch back and forth between the two systems with the push of the channel button and without having to connect or disconnect anything. It simply works, and the switch-over is fast. The take-away for me is that I no longer need two mice on the desk.

I friend came over with his MacBook and there was no issue at all with connecting the trackball via USB. We did not try connecting via Bluetooth.

The trackball has a metal plate on the bottom that is held in place with magnets, and depending on how the plate is attached the trackball can be tilted to ease wrist strain. The plate serves another purpose too - it adds a lot of weight to the trackball. Even without the plate, the trackball is hefty and has some mass to it, but the plate just makes it even more so. For me that‚Äôs a positive; others may dislike the added weight.

One of the things I have missed has been a tilting scroll wheel. This trackball has one and I have been enjoying getting used to that feature again.

One thing I did notice is that there is no CD/DVD in the package for loading drivers. This isn‚Äôt a big deal, and it‚Äôs easy enough to get the drivers from the net. That said, the trackball just seems to work when you attach it, without any issue. For me it has absolutely been plug-and-play, on every system I have tried.

If I could change one thing - I would have made this trackball a little bigger. I have big hands and I struggle to find a trackball that‚Äôs an absolute perfect fit. This one is close. For the large majority of people it‚Äôs going to be spot on.

I am very happy with this trackball and have no issue with recommending it. It works great, connects easily, when connected to two different systems it switches at the press of a button, it has a bit of heft to it and the tilt is adjustable for wrist comfort. It‚Äôs really all I could ask for.

[[VIDEOID:823984d4540bea76b48755e23ef24f8c]] Seems like a nice set of AirPod style earbuds for the price. They‚Äôre way cheaper than airpods but look similar

The case is nice ithink for storage. Seems a good way to keep track of them and charge them

Overall I think they‚Äôre nice and look pretty cool

For a moderately priced speaker I am very happy. Its versatile and sounds great. Does fine with water though I wouldn't suggest immerging it. Has great bass and the changing lights are a cool addition. Colors also appear to change with the beat of the song which is also really cool as well. Comes with a standard charging cable (micro usb) and and aux cable which is great if your bluetooth device stops working or you want to save phone battery. Overall, great buy

Replacing my altec lansing speakers from the early 2000's. Honestly, I'm not an audiophile. My altec speakers were pretty good speakers too, and I can't tell the difference. My upgrade is simply cosmetics. This logitech set is black and sleek, looks more modern. My altec speakers were grayish, very early 2000's design.

I like the nifty wireless controller that looks like a little echo dot, but it's smaller. So coming from speakers in the early 2000's, my first question was.. Can this function like old school speakers if I don't care for all the tech? So I simply used the 3.5mm connection method from my dell to the logitech, but there was NO SOUND. So you have to at least power up the wireless controller for the first time. Because under the controller is a button to switch from bluetooth to wired. Press the WIRE option, and you will then get audio. After this, if you remove the batteries and take away the wireless controller, the speakers will continue to work as 3.5mm connected speaker. You just have to turn on the wireless controller on the initial set-up. So this is good. My concern was what if the wireless controller is lost or damaged? If that happens, then you would like the speakers to go on like old school speakers connected simply by 3.5mm. So I'm happy to report, this will function without the wireless controller module. I'm not even sure turning on the wireless controller in the initial set-up is absolutely required. Your PC my pick-up sound the moment you plug in the 3.5mm jack. For me, I had to turn on the wireless controller during the initial set-up.

Another thing I wondered is if I connect a bluetooth device, say my smartphone, to these speakers, then disconnect, will the speakers automatically revert back to wired? The answer is no. To connect to a bluetooth device, you have to press the bluetooth pairing button under the wireless controller, and it will stay in this mode even after you disconnect. You have to press the "wire" button to get back to 3.5mm.

One more thing, the left and right speakers have 2 slots in the back to insert the stand. So you can configure it to stand vertically or horizontally. Conclusion... I love the sound, the sleek design and the technology. 5-Stars.

Great look and sound. A bit cheaper than Apple products.

Pros:
Great sound for earbuds. Bass is descent and volume max is good.
Light weight.
Easy to turn up volume and change tracks. Just a tap or swipe of your finger. Auto pause when you take out of your ear.
Nice look and they stay in my ears quite well.
Connects easily to my iPhone Max
Does well at staying connect at like 30-40 feet.
Battery lasts 20 hours, way more than I need it to but nice just in case. also has charging case.

Cons:
Still a bit expensive compared to other brands.
They are bit bigger than the wired apple headphone buds. So if you have smaller ears it might be an issue.

What the hell, I took it to my car, plugged it in my cigarette lighter, programmed my radio to the station on the unit and then instinctedly pressed and held the blinking telephone icon.  Viola'!!  It worked perfectly.  It synced right up to my Samsung Note 5.  I can now listen to my on demand sirius shows and use it to answer calls through my car speakers.  It sounds wonderful and was extremely easy to set and use.  That's it.  Should have done it a year ago.  I paid more for it than it is worth now and now it is actually discontinued, but I don't at all regret the purchase since I have no intention on upgrading my car anytime soon and this works perfectly.  If you can get it used, save the money and buy it.

There are many, many true wireless earbuds out there. What attracted me to these were the features that they boasted: Wireless Charging, Active Noise-Cancelling, and bluetooth 5.1. So how does these earbuds compare to some of the cheaper offerings and does it justify being twice as expensive as some of them?

In terms of price, these earbuds can be considered cheap. Comparable to the mid-tier brands out there such as Anker and MPow, and much, much cheaper than Bose and Jabra brands. Still, there are many that cost half the price.

With the pricing in mind, let's look at the good of these earbuds:
+ Long battery life -- I'm on my fourth hour of listening to an audiobook and the battery is still showing 50% on my phone.
+ Battery status reporting to phone -- I'm sure most of the recent bluetooth headphones and earbuds do this now, but it is still nice.
+ Type-C port for charging -- The move to type-c as the standard charging port for all devices is happening and I'm glad NANNIO didn't cheap out and use a micro-usb. One less cable to worry about.
+ No app necessary -- The passthrough and ANC features can be turned on by tapping the touch controls twice.
+ Google Assistant Support -- Tap three times and Google Assistant launches.
+ No ugly microphone stick -- The tear-drop shape of these buds look much better than the ugly sticks that Apple's products have, in my opinion.
+ Smooth transition between left-only, right-only, and stereo -- These earbuds allow one to choose to use only one earbud while keeping the other in the charger without having to pair the other piece separately. It's something that I take advantage of on long drives. I keep one bud in the ear to listen to my audiobook and switch out when the battery runs out.

The bad:
- Not low profile -- The Anker SoundCores is pretty inconspicuous in the ear, but these NANNIOs, being white and sticking out more are anything but low profile.
- ANC not very effective -- The ANC levels are adjusted to be pretty minimal on these buds so while it is possible to hear the difference between the feature being on and off, it is also noticeable that only the lowest hums are cancelled out. Earbuds simply aren't good for ANC. Buds simply don't fit perfectly in the ear canal and when the jaw moves, the fit shifts. By this fact, there is always sound leaking through, reducing the efficiency of any ANC system. In earbuds, ANC is really just a gimmick.
- Passthrough needs to have wind noise reduction -- The reason for passthrough, in my mind, is to be able to hear surrounding sounds if wearing earbuds while running. It uses the microphone on the earbuds to pass external sounds through, but when running, there will always be wind noise. Without wind noise reduction, it makes this feature useless. I don't know of any earbuds that have addressed this issue.

So why did I still give these buds 5-stars? Because it is priced perfectly for what it is and what it promises. It has more features and quality that makes it better than the lower $30 dollar earbuds, but isn't a brand that can demand over $100. The features that are promised are delivered and any shortcomings are expected, as described above. With these buds, I get
