This is the most amazingly satisfying electronics product I have ever bought. The features are many and easy to learn. I especially enjoy some of the audio and video adjustment features:
Audio: DRC setting helps bring up quieter sounds while controlling loud peaks. Great for taming those annoying audio surges in 'background' music or battle scenes, etc. The Dialog feature lets you adjust the dialog perception so that you can hear the voices better over the background sounds in the soundtracks.
Video: You can adjust the Sharpness, Brightness, Contrast, Gamma, Hue, Chroma Level and BNR (block noise reduction). Each one has several levels to choose from and you get to sample it as it adjusts, so you can skip back and forth and compare the difference before you decide what to settle on.
The USB mode has great, easy to navigate menus. You can also record to your thumb drive from a CD that you are playing. There is a choice of different bit rates to do this and you can record individual tracks or all tracks. Very user-friendly menus for all these choices.
This unit has too many features to list, especially for someone like me, who is not quite fluent in tech terminology. Suffice it to say that it performs all the functions beautifully, the manual is very user-friendly and not only tells you how to adjust/change the various settings, but also explains the technical terminology in real English, so you know what those settings actually do when activated.
I do love the region-free feature too. But for me, this is more ho-hum, since I already owned one - a far inferior quality Philips one.
About the only thing I can think of to improve the user-friendliness of this product would be to have an alphabetized index in the manual. But, since it's only a 61 page manual, it's not such a big issue overall.
Another suggestion I would have would be to allow it to record audio from DVDs also. So often, the audio track on a DVD sounds so much better than the soundtrack that is published on CD (i.e.: Brassed Off, Eyes Wide Shut), although I recognize there may be some copyright issues with that concept.
For the record: I am getting a second unit for my upstairs TV. Have I mentioned that I love it...? This is a really great product!!!

I normally think of storage media and batteries when I think of Maxell. That said, this is my second pair of Maxell headphones. My first pair is an ANC set that isn‚Äôt perfect, but they‚Äôre far and away better than I would ever have expected. These phones are not ANC phones, they‚Äôre just wireless listening phones. I was hopeful that they would be as good as my ANC phones in terms of sound quality, and Maxell has not disappointed me. They‚Äôre not perfect but they‚Äôre better than you can reasonably expect from the asking price.

Up front, let me say that I am not a big fan of on-ear headphones, and these fall into that category. I prefer an over-the-ear phone which to me is more comfortable. These aren‚Äôt bad for on-ear phones. This comes down to preference. If you are cool with on-ear phones, these will work for you, but if you have to have over-ear phones then you should consider other options.

The pads are soft enough, though they aren‚Äôt super cushy like some others I have used.

Being Bluetooth phones I immediately connected them to my phone. The connection went off without a hitch, though the phone was slower to find these than I had hoped. Once connected, they have been stable and reconnecting is much faster.

The real test is the sound profile. On my ANC phones, Maxell worked a miracle and got the sound profile nearly perfect even when the noise canceling is turned on. With these phones, the sound profile is not precise but it‚Äôs very balanced and better than average. The bass is strong but not throbbing like most headphones made these days. I like bass, but I don‚Äôt appreciate the insistence on pumping it so heavily that it gives me a headache. The midrange is full and music sounds like it has some depth without sounding like it‚Äôs playing from the bottom of a well. The highs are bright and clear, though on specific frequency ranges there is the slightest hint of distortion if you really look for it (and since I‚Äôm reviewing these, I went looking for it).

I cranked up the music as high as I could, and there was only a hint of distortion in the highs. And I had a headache when I was done.

Build-wise, these are not too bad. I would not pack them in a gym bag or anything like that, but these should work fine for a long while as long as they‚Äôre cared for properly. There‚Äôs enough flex in them to make them durable enough to survive some rough handling, but at the end of the day they‚Äôre primarily plastic - a drop from the right height or being crushed in a book bag will break them.

These phones are under $50 as I write this. What‚Äôs really distressing is that I have phones that are north of $200 that do not sound as good as these. Maxell knows how to make a good headphone that competes well with more expensive phones - I have two very different pairs to prove it. It begs the question - why are they only making budget headphones?

I would rate these slightly lower if the asking price were above the $50 mark. But, at the asking price you‚Äôd be hard-pressed to find headphones that sound better.

I'm somewhat particular about my music and my headphones and have specific things I look for. I'll try to touch on those items in this review.

Sound Quality: obviously most important. I look for solid bass (not boomy or hyped). And clear trebles (not sizzling or hyped). These headphones performed okay on both counts although it did seem the bass was a little hyped. I have some expensive headphones that these did not compare favorably to. I also look for general clarity in vocals... here, they did good... nothing nasally or buried in the mix. The exception came when turning on the noise reduction circuit. More on that later.

Comfort: okay, I have a big head (size xxl hat). So comfort is important to me. These headphones are adequate in that regard. I had to extend them fully, but at full extension they fit me properly and comfortably, sealing off around the ear. They did not completely surround my ears as some studio monitors do, but they did cover my ears. The padding is decent and I was able to listen for a reasonable amount of time before they became uncomfortable pressing on the perimeter of my ear. If your head/ears are smaller, my guess is they'd be plenty comfortable.

Noise reduction: I'm not used to using this feature and wasn't sure how to test it, so I simply sat down next to an air cleaner I have in my home and tried turning noise reduction on and off to see what happened. There was definitely a reduction in the noise... mainly in the lower frequencies. It didnt completely eliminate the sound of the blowing air, but what was left was a thinned out version of the original noise. It was definitely an improvement in the level of noise. The only thing I didnt care for was that there seemed to be an impact on the sound of the music also. Again, the noise reduction thinned the music and left it a little nasally.

Controls: straight forward controls. Theres a slider to turn noise reduction on and off and an adjacent button to activate the phone function. Since the phone button was just below the slider, I kept accidentally turning on the phone when trying to activate the noise reduction. Better button placement would have helped.

Overall, I was reasonably impressed with these headphones. Especially considering the price, they seem to do well. They come with a nice, soft sided carry case and needed cables. I expect I'll get some good use from these.

WARNING: THIS IS A LONG REVIEW, BUT I MAY HAVE SOME ANGLES ON THIS OTHERS DON'T :-)

Wow. I really like this modem. This is a barebones rock solid dead simple workhorse.

It's got a plug for the cable and one ethernet (RJ-45) port out and I think an on/off switch.
That's it. It makes a connection. And hasn't failed since I got it a month or so ago.

All I had to do was call my ISP and give them the MAC address (on the sticker on the device)
and they updated their tables and that was it. Turn it on. It goes through the startup cycle. Takes a few minutes to connect like they all do and that's it. Set it and forget it.

What prompted me to get it, is I don't like having to rent the modem from the ISP @ $10.00/mo forever. This literally pays for itself in 16 months, and most people will have their Internet connection for many times that long, and time flies. So it's a good investment.

It doesn't have phone connection like the ISP's modem did. So I called the company/provider that owns copper phone lines in the area and ordered landline service. I'm a nerd/techie and don't care what people say about landlines being for old fogeys, it's like having a backup generator ... I know I can use that landline if the power goes out or if the cell tower gets overwhelmed (too many calls or cell traffic at once), or there's radio interference in the area. Technically cable phone is a 'land line' (hardwired cable connection to provider) and the battery backup in the modem (which the ISP charges more for), could give you emergency phone service in an outage, but a cable phone connection can (and does) fail for more reasons than copper wire phone service does. (Those copper wire connections are called POTS - which stands for Plain Old Telephone Service), and copper wire phones are the most reliable.

Having a separate modem from a router is optima for a few of reasons... Generally hybrid units of anything do everything okay, but nothing optimally (for example combination modem-router units like my ISP rents out). Better to keep the modem separate from the router. Then you can swap either out independently to upgrade as needed, disrupting less of your own network configuration doing so, and also help avoid a single point of failure. Plus, you might be able to score a router in a pinch on shorter notice than a cable modem if the router is the component that fails. Then you can choose the router you actually like, for whatever reason, and don't have to settle for whatever bundling du jour your ISP decides is right for you (even if it isn't).

That gets me to the other point. What DID the ISP decide was right for me (but wasn't)?

For awhile my ISP modem connection was dropping briefly in the middle of the morning. My computer came back up connected to the ISP's 'general public' wi-fi connection to their router which did not work for me and I'd have to keep manually switching back to my own internal Wi-Fi LAN (network). That was not only inconvenient but it forced me to investigate was was going on there.

I learned my ISP gives lets passersby connect to their rental-modem's Wi-Fi signal, without giving me any way to disable that service! That really pissed me off to learn. The idea is that people driving around who have accounts with the provider can get internet access around the neighborhoods. If I was a passerby, that could really help me, so at first glance maybe 'why not, be a good samaritan'.

But wait! There may be more too it than that.

Besides the fact that I don't like it (for good reason), they give me no control over that 'feature'!
And I see some downsides. What's good for the ISP isn't necessarily optimal for me.

What I don't like about that 'service' is that one or more people could sit outside and suck down bandwidth (e.g. slow my connection down), unbeknownst to me. It also might cause the unit to use more energy and put out a stronger wi-fi signal than it needs to. Which health conscious people are well advised to be aware of. Wi-Fi is radiation. Not strong and may not ruin your life, but it is a stressor at a cellular level, this is known. And strong signals, persistent signals and people who are more sensitive or have immunity issues can be more vulnerable (headaches, sleep disruption, or worse). But I like Wi-Fi so I settle for whatever unknown health consequences I may not be aware of.

Also it makes me wonder if a hacker might be able to use it as an additional point of access to my home network.

I also wonder if it's 100% clear to law enforcement at first glance who might be visiting sites or doing something nefarious from the connection point. Might it look like the owner is doing something that a passerby did (and even if they can sort it out later, what if it takes awhile to figure out and they make a bad assumption?)

Anyway, I don't have that problem with this modem and I'm just much happier with it all the way around.

Plus it's blazingly fast.

Projectors for home use are typically set up for home theater systems. I have seen a number of systems set up with projectors suspended from the ceiling, and I have seen a few that rely on being mounted on a table top. This is a table top model and it is a very good and easy-to-use projector.

This is a 300-lumen projector which is fine for home theater systems, though it would be a little underpowered to use in a larger room or something like a small church. It is good for small presentations too and is a good option if you want to take it with you for meetings instead of keeping it permanently placed somewhere.

There are several input sources for which the projector is configured. For testing and experimentation I found it easiest to work with HDMI though I was able to use some of the other sources as well. It accepts VGA (which is great for older computer systems and other hardware), it can read files from an SD card or even a USB drive. Using a USB drive or SD card, this projector becomes very compact and portable and doesn't even need an external source of input.

This projector even has a pair of speakers inside so you can use this projector for the entire A/V experience, though you will get better sound from a dedicated sound system. This projector is capable of receiving sound as well as outputting it.

I used the HDMI input to feed the image from my computer to the projector and it did a fine job of displaying my desktop on the wall for me. I was also able to configure Windows to use it as an extended display so I could then look at PowerPoint on the computer screen and use the projector to output the slide show. This is very, very convenient and makes this configuration ideal for presentations. I was able to adjust the focus manually and get the image as sharp as I wanted too.

The remote with this unit is great. It provides full access to the projector's functions, so if the projector is on a shelf out of reach the remote is sufficient for any adjustments you may want to make. If you prefer not to use the remote or have some reason you would rather directly interact with the projector there are several buttons on the top of the projector that give access to the different functions. You can change the input source, power on and off and get into the menu system which allows you to tweak all manner of settings: brightness, change the resolution, update the firmware from USB, set the date and time and more.

This projector does output a lot of heat ‚Äì to be expected from a projector with a bright light in it. Make sure that you have decent ventilation in the room when using this projector unless you want the room to warm up. I did notice that when the projector is shut off, the fan stops too which is a minor disappointment ‚Äì I would rather have had the fan continue for a few minutes afterward to cool down the LED.

This is a nice projector. It accepts a lot of different input types, it works well for small rooms and home theaters and it is easy to take with you due to the small size. It is especially useful if you want to run your video or presentation from either USB or from the SD card. If you're looking for a small-scale projector, this is a good choice.

Long story short, I installed Linux and have kept Windows via dual-boot for games, but I'm done using Windows as a daily driver. This radio worked fine. We live in an area with hurricanes so we like to have one of these for safety. It is also good if you are camping. You can get the weather and music. We were happy with the quality. We would recommend it.

I'm returning this item for an exchange. I hope the other one works better. The Bluetooth function does not work. It takes a long time to connect and before a song is over it will stop working. You have to cut the system on and off and un-pair and repair your device to reconnect and it will still cut off, again and again. Besides that. Instructions were not detailed. I mean I figured everything out but some stuff should be explained better plus there are typos/errors in the instructions! Right on the first page. (It's not reassuring that I got a good product if you all didn't even take the time to proof read the instruction book). The remote does not work that well either.

For variety, the Altec Lansing UHP606 Backbeat Pro Reference Earphones are a fine change from my Ultimate Ears SuperFi 3 Studio Noise Isolating Earphones when my ears need an alternate bud phone.  If the lighterweight and more flexible cables are bent and wrapped around the back of the ear as they are with the Ultimate Ears, the length is just about equal.  These are simply the cables into the ear buds.Both have a mini plug w/ a right angle, but the Altec Lansing is about 1/2" further extended when inserted.  The cables are less rigid than the Ultimate Ears and are encased in clear plastic rather than the more usual black.  They look cute.  The sound, on the other hand is only average.  I like the zippered small case which is included and most ears likely will have a satisfactory fit from the included assortment of silicone tips.  External sounds are restricted with a nice tight fit, but the range of this audio could be improved.  The price is what I expect to pay for an average pair of ear buds which are better than many, but not the best available.
13 months after using just a few times, one ear muff came off & is literally impossible to put back on

We've set up and used security cameras before in our home, but this is the first pan and tilt one that we have used. Set up took about five minutes. We plugged it into our router with the cable that was provided. We installed software that located the camera and now we can view the camera through the web browser. We plan to install the app to our phones eventually. The camera is easy to control. We have used it primarily for spying on the cats so far, but I'm sure we'll come up with other occasions. The infrared camera works well even in low lighting or darkness and the images are pretty clear. You can set it up to detect motion and then email you when it detects movement. We're having fun playing around with it right now, but there are a lot of real-life applications where this will be handy to have.

*I received this for free in exchange for my honest & unbiased review. My thoughts & opinions are my own.

These headphones do not cancel the noise in the traditional sense.  It's more like a white noise generator that adds a layer of static to block out quiet noises. It makes them louder in my opinion.  Nice quality headset if you can get it priced in the single digits. But as for noise canceling, it does not do that.

Bought one for each of two grandchildren for their new Fire 7 Kids tablet for Christmas a few months ago. I also bought children's headphones for each. The tablet (with case), the charger, and the headphones are all able to fit. It's super lightweight for them but also very durable!  Love that it has a handle and that the handle velcros together. Very very happy with this purchase!

I have been using an older Philips 28" soundbar with a wired passive sub woofer.  When I saw this unit on sale at Amazon I decided to give it a try.  It is also 28" wide, but includes a wireless powered sub woofer allowing me to place the sub anywhere in the room were I could access a power socket.  Set up is really easy.  Took only a few minutes.  Had to spend a little time understand the leds that display the various sound settings.  The sub connect automatically.  After I was sure everything was working as it should, I programmed my Harmony remote to control it and everything else connected to the TV.  No problems doing that.  So all in all I am very happy with the performance of this unit when compared to the one it replaced.

I like these headphones for their quality and price. I have these and Samsung Galaxy buds. The Galaxy buds win in terms of convenience and features due to me having a Galaxy phone, but the X5 wins in terms of volume and bass. I like to listen to music with bass and the Galaxy buds just don't have that at all, plus noise cancelling is gimmicky on the buds and eventually I have to up the volume to truly drown out all noise, which is easier to do with the X5. Both headphones shine in different respects. When it comes to interacting with my phone I prefer the features provided by Galaxy buds, but when it comes to listening to music and comfort then I prefer the X5, plus the X5 is way more economical. The mic on both for calls were not impressive. They work well enough in a quiet room but when I'm in my car I have to turn off my AC to use them (the AC isn't blowing on my face, they just really pick up on the air blowing around in general). Overall I don't think most people will be disappointed with this purchase.
Color is pretty. Have not tried the microphone. I did try it with a movie trailer and it sounded good. Good price good sound. Buy it.

My kids like to watch videos/play games on the computer or iPad, and not only do they want to block out other noise, but the rest of us don't want to hear what they're doing. My husband also travels often for work, and likes to have noise-isolating headphones for his flights. We've owned a few different brands of around-the-ear headphones, and we've found the Sennheiser HD 429 to be both lighter (I don't feel like a helicopter pilot in these) and more durable than most the others (my 5yo is hard on gadgets!). The sound quality has been totally sufficient for our needs. I would agree with other reviews that the cord on this is a bit flimsy and is also unnecessarily long. I've doubled-up the extra length and put a tie around it, so it feels a bit sturdier and doesn't get in the way of anything or get caught.

Instructions for this item were really clear and it was easy to setup. All I had to do was remove the plastic strips from the under the ear buds then they pair with the case. Then I turned my bluetooth on and found the item and they paired to my phone without any problem (I have a Samsung Galaxy S10+). I would have given 5 stars but the tap functions dont work so well. You are supposed to tap twice to pause or play music. This usually worked about 3 out of 5 when I tested on both ear buds. I tapped faster and slower to see if that would change the results, but it didnt. When it came to the three taps for previous/next song, the ear buds seemed confused and began pausing and playing the music at times. Again, I couldn't tell if I was tapping too fast or slow. This functions worked about 1-2 times out of 5 tries. The range is great though. I was able to leave my phone on my bed and walk out my front door (about 20 ft away) then outside to my front door and there was no static or insidication that the connection was fading. The volume is great as well with both or one ear bud in.

What looks like a flash, acts like a flash, but is much more than your average flash?

This gadget provides a painless backup solution for businesspersons and students who can't survive without their trusty laptop/netbook/notebook and the information therein. Even for users unfamiliar with backup software, the Echo software included on the drive is a snap to use. Once the backup drive is inserted into a USB port on your computer, it will take you through some simple steps to configure the backup. You can choose the easy predefined Automatic plan or you can choose the more advanced Custom backup plan. There is a Quick Start Guide, also included on the drive, which provides a brief explanation of the options that are available.

When configuring your Custom backup profile, you can specify which file types you want backed-up. You can select ALL files, or there are some basic ones such as text, spreadsheet, presentation, music, videos, photos et al that you can select. There is also an OTHER category where you can define other file types that may be important to you, for example, zip, rar, pdf, etc. In addition, you select which folder(s) you want backed-up, set filters if required, and set the number of versions of files to keep, a useful option if you accidentally delete or modify a file. There is also the option to select an Automatic backup which activates every time you plug in your flash drive, and Live which continuously backs up your modified files to the flash drive without your intervention.

Restoring files is just a matter of clicking on the Restore menu button, selecting the files and/or folders you want restored and setting the location where to restore the files, then hit RESTORE. Alternatively, if when creating your profile, you had decided not to password protect it and encrypt it, the files can be accessed quite easily from directly on the root of the backup drive in the My Backup folder.

To backup another computer, you would have to install the software on that computer and set up another backup profile.

This version of the Lexar Echo has only 16GB of storage capacity, and is really too small to back up more than one home computer with music and video files; it can barely back up one computer, much less two or more. On the other hand, it would certainly be good for business people on the road since they will generally be using smaller files and the backup is a no-brainer.

While it has a good feel to it and the retractable connector saves losing caps, it is a bit on the `chunky' side and competes for space with other USB devices. It can also get damaged if you're not careful when moving the laptop around and it gets hit during the process, as it sticks out quite a bit.

I did not check for backup/restore speeds nor did I follow up on the 2GB of free online backup space which was offered in the setup. It appears this is no longer available at DMAILER, the backup software manufacturer; but instead I was guided to check YuuWaa online backup services.

Extremely handy for business or school use, and especially for people who have senior moments and accidentally delete or write over important files on a regular basis.

Amanda Richards, July 8, 2011
The audio on my Mac was terrible until I installed these and got dome ear buds--now, there's no trouble.
It‚Äôs super cool that the screen moves.  Speaker is nice.  But it keeps bumping into the wall!  I‚Äôve set the boundaries and ‚Äútaught‚Äù it how far to turn but it seems to forget

Not too bad a pair of headphones, They stop my little ones from grabbing my Beats. I bought these at a local retailer, in a spur of the moment for a long road trip. (5+ hours) They do charge rather quickly. In less than 20 minutes they were fully charged. So the kids could use them while on the trip.
I personally would have preferred that they could be charged while in use, they cannot, and immediately shut off when its attempted. My kids love to allow their devices to get super low on charge. I removed 1 - 1/2 stars for the charging decision. I also remove 1/2 star because they feel slightly off when wearing them. The kids however have never noticed the wearing issue. They seem to like them a lot. Though my son told me he'll be sure to keep track of my Beats. I figure it has to do with these being on ear and the others over the ear. He's just like me and prefers over the ear. Chip off the old block.

The wife and I have been able to watch TV and talk this evening in the hotel room. Where we use to always hear this or that. Its nice to actually not have to say "turn it down" before talking. They have used them for hours today. I purchased the blue/grey and the green/grey for my boys. For their price and easy of purchase they will certainly be on the upper end of my re purchase list if its needed.

These are the best earbuds I have ever had!  The sound is clear, they can get loud, I only need them half way up. They come with a bunch of different sizes of accessories, and the case is magnetic so when you put them away you just have to put near the case, very cool.

This is not a speaker that will broadcast dance music to a big party. On the other hand, when you're watching a movie on your laptop or doing some work while listening to music, it is the best! Even working in the kitchen, again listening to music on your laptop, the sound is incredible.

When I was laid up following foot surgery; this little speaker brought such brilliant sound into my room. There's a different tone between being set on tile vs carpet. Each one has its merits.

This is well worth the money.

This product description doesn't do this product justice. I am impressed. I am already a fan of Sanag products, so I expected this to be good. It is. I'll list everything I can think of below.

I have been looking for an easy to use fitness watch for my 70+ years old mom. She mentioned interest in one, but I am not sure how much she will enjoy it. While I like fitbit (been using that brand since 2015) I didnt want to get her one if she wouldnt like the technology. I looked through what I already own, but nothing seemed right. I have a garmin that I wouldnt have anyone new to fitness watches use (hate that thing). I have an Amazon Halo, which is great but its attached to my account so I cant have her try it. And I have a weird off brand tracker that I got a few years ago that it too complicated to use (clunky app, slow to respond swiping). I basically need a tracker to be easy to use (both the tracker and the app) and be something I feel comfortable having my tech adverse mom use. I chose this based on what I read in the description AND my positive experience so far with Sanag.

I figured I would try this watch for a couple of weeks before deciding if it would work for her. I have been wearing it day and night for a little over a week, and I may not give it to her.. because I love it. haha

I'm just going to bullet point the features I have noticed so far:

--waterproof. I wear it 24/7. Though I do take off for showering, I am just used to doing that. I also clean homes for living, and this can take a beating.

-- easy to find, install, and use App (da fit), many customizations, options to set up.

--pairs easily with bluetooth; no hassle.

--interesting color, nice feeling band. Very secure feeling. Though, I'd prefer the band to be a little longer.
I have a 7" wrist, and this just fits. Will be fine for my mom who has very petite bone structure.

--super long battery life. I charge my fitbit sense every other day. Other than initial charge, I have not yet had to charge this. I'd say they are accurate on their 7-14 day charge on normal use, or 30 days on standby. That being said..

-- blood O2 measurment is on demand. Not automatic. Just go into watch face or app to measure. It keeps track. Heart rate can be continuous measurement or on demand.

--Can choose from many many many watch faces. So many different styles, some are super cute. Different faces depending on what you want to see, ie just the time, time and date, time, date, steps, hr, cals burned, etc. If you have a few that you like, then you can scroll through what you have used in your watch itself to to select one, or you can go to the app to select one.

--steps are accurate as far as side by side with my Fit bit Sense. Same steps (within 20 steps) when worn side by side on same wrist.

--gorgeous display- very colorful and easy to read

--easy to navigate with swiping; very responsive. Easy to back out from selections.

--on watch can see time, date, steps, heart rate, 02, blood pressure (havent checked yet for accuracy but I will), weather, sleep data, exercise specific date (and tracking), alarms, timers, music control, camera shutter control, and settings notifications (can set up to see notifications from many sources such as email, phone calls, texts, FB, IG, Whatsapp, etc etc ect-- huge list that can be turned on for notifications to allow to come through if you want. Can pick and choose).

--on watch can select options such as "do not disturb", brightness settings, lock option,
--can connect to google fit
--can keep track of other health trends (menstrual, for example).
--can set a step goal, reminders to move, reminders to drink water

I am not sure if there is a spot to adjust how long the face stays lit when looking at something. As of now, it goes black after a few seconds. Much like other fitness watches.

--App has all this same info, with ability to look at more details

--VERY easy to navigate app.

REALLY an impressive gadget. I think some of it will come down to preference. I am still getting used to it, and sometimes I find the outer button is easily pressed by my bent wrist. I have accidentally changed my watch face that way, but I am seeing now that if I end up on that screen I have to make sure I am setting the face by swiping up (otherwise navigates to another face by swiping left/right). Litte annoyances that will vary.

For all that it offers, for the ease of use especially compared to some name brands, I am compelled to go 5 stars. If we could do half stars, maybe 4.5. But I like it more than 4 stars. Overall nothing glaring bad or super negative comes to mind. I'll update as I learn more or think of more, or experience something different (good or bad).

reasonable price at $79 (though I had a coupon which really helped make my decision), any higher and I would go with namebrand.

I really like these... the flat wires DO help them not to tangle... Has a "universal" tip as most things do this day and age... worked with my brand new LG G4 cell, my old rotary dial IPOD and my Kindle 8" HDX. It comes with 4 (2 sets) of extra ear cushions. I feel that I have smallerish ears and I have a hard time finding earpods that are comfortable and will stay in. These work great. Comfortable and they have stayed in. Mind you, I am NOT jogging with them in. I only wish they'd come with a zipper case to hold them in for convenience. At the price point, you'd think they would. It does also have a microphone and I have "tested" that... worked. It has a little attachable pinch clip to keep in place as you move around. The foam tips are sort of like memory foam, but almost a bit softer really. I think this both helps them stay in AND retain comfort. The sound is very clean and clear - for an adult anyway. The tips are cornflower blue if that matters to anyone... I think the pic is very clear and representative. I will update if there are any issues.
UPDATE: 6/29/2015 I have used these earbuds a number of times... one of the issues I have had in the past is that this "shape" of earbud doesn't want to stay in my ear... (tiny ears?) but these DO stay in.. I think it's the type of foam tip... seems to grip a bit better? To be fair, again, I am not jogging with them in... I am mostly in a sitting position using them. The "flat" wires really do help them not get all tangled... having stay that.. they also resist "wrapping" a bit too. This is probably good. Otherwise you'd break the wires inside. The kiss of death to any wired accessory. Also, I've been informed that these are going to start coming with carry cases!! Yup. That would make them 5 star in my humble opinion and I'm keeping them in my "save" pile for a possible second order.
UPDATE 7/26/2015... Still happy with my purchase. I am informed by the seller that they are now including a case. This makes it definitely a 5-star value and worthy of a purchase. Will update if there any use/wear issues to report

I ordered this remote to use with a Kenwood head unit I already had on my boat. Upon delivery, the unit had 7 small cracks along the side edge of faceplate. The cracks coincided with the 4 screws that secure the front faceplate to the rear housing (there is a seal between the front face and rear housing). It appears that excessive clamping forces of these screws caused the cracks. Being in a marine environment, the cracks are completely unacceptable as moisture and condensation can easily work its way into the unit. I returned the remote for refund and ordered a second one in its place. When the second remote arrived, careful inspection showed that it too, had cracks along the edge of the front faceplate. The second remote had 2 cracks. Emails to Kenwood didn't help at all (i even included pictures) and they said they've never heard of such an issue before. Based on the design aspect alone, I HIGHLY doubt this is an isolated event to both of the remotes I've seen. I'm sure many MANY more of them are damaged during production. If you have this remote, make a close inspection of it but BEWARE as Kenwood customer service has warned me that they will refuse warranty work on any item that appears to have physical damage. With this unit, it comes damaged OUT OF THE BOX. Copy and paste the link to see 3 of the 7 cracks in the 1st remote.

[...]
