I think this is safer for walking my dogs at night because it allows you to hear the world around you while also listening to your book or music

They seem nice overall I thought

[[VIDEOID:bc7d953b53202cbc545b59aabfc6aabf]] THE GOOD:
--------------
* Tiny, but packs a punch.
* IP67 waterproof, so just relax by the pool with it.
* Touts 16 hrs battery life.
* USB-C charging port.

THE BAD:
-----------
* It might not be loud enough. Especially if you're outside, around a noisy pool, etc. In a quiet house, it's sounds pretty good. The speaker is supposed to specialize in bass, so what better song to test it out with than LL Cool J's Going Back to Cali? Watch my video. I'll go 4-Stars!

The price on Amazon says $150 but I don't remember paying that. Maybe I did.  I use this device to record when I do tours and interviews. This year, 2021, I purchased a 32gb digital recorder that transfers data and recharges via USB-C. I transferred the files from the Olympus to the Evida v618 by audio cable and may find a new home for it since getting data off of the recorder is not simplistic.

I ordered these to replace a lower powered set for birdwatching in my back yard. These had good reviews, and were affordably priced, so I thought I would give them a go. They are perfect for my needs, which is viewing birds at a feeder or on our fence about 10-20 yards from our porch.

They are a decent size and heft, without being too large. They have a good field of vision and are easy to focus. I added a more padded strap, but it does come with a basic strap and a decent little case with a shoulder strap. If I were taking them out camping or in the woods, I might upgrade the case, but for my use it is perfect. I was able to immediately identify a bird with these that had been visiting my feeder and I was unable to see enough detail with my old smaller and lower powered binoculars.

It's pretty fast with an AMD 6300 but I was having problems loading both the USB controller driver and the USB 3.0 drivers from the install disk..Nothing worked on my front panel but audio and the thing wouldn't recognise my Asus D1 Audio card. I finally got all the drivers loaded correctly in devices/my computer and I'm still not able to run a USB 2.0 or 3.0 hard drive, only flash drives. In addition,
I can't back up anything , not even from SATA C: to F: which is an empty, formatted drive. I've tried everything for the past month to the point of pulling my hair out and am now convinced it is simply a cheap, junk board and I got what I paid for. Too bad because it is snappy but will be my first and last Gigabyte board. My seven year old Asus FM1 mobo runs circles around it in ease of setup and reliability.
This is a great portable mouse. I like that you do not need a USB Bluetooth adapter.

At first the tile wouldn't ring the phone, which is the item I'm always looking for. I was disheartened but I emailed the company and they got back quickly with instructions to turn off bluetooth for 15 seconds and try again. That worked. We'll see if it stays working. Every time I used the app I get a message saying the app is disabled, even though it's not, which is mildly annoying. Otherwise, I'm pleased with the system so far. I am one who loses everything so I'm putting a lot of faith in this. I haven't used it during a real loss, and hope I don't have to, but the tests around the house are good so far.

I listen to audiobooks to fall asleep at night so I wear "sleep" earbuds as to not disturb my wife. I usually buy the soft silicone type, which never have good audio quality, but does the job. They usually break withing a couple of months because I tend to tug on them a lot when I sleep so this time, I decided to try out these ceramic Wired Headphones with Microphone.

My initial impressions of these earbuds are that they have better sound quality than the other sleep earbuds that I've tried. They also have excellent build quality. There are silicone reinforcements at all of the wire connection points to protect them from failing due to tugging and the shape of the earbuds are as flat as possible.

When in my ears, these metal earbuds do not protrude at all, they lie flat. I tested by lying on my side to see if they would hurt but they seemed okay because nothing protrudes. Then after a couple of nights, I found that while direct downward pressure doesn't hurt, the earbuds do hurt when they are nudged from side to side, which happens when I'm shifting positions at night.

So overall, I'm still using these earbuds and have gotten used to them, but they do still hurt occasionally, depending on how much I move at night.

Okay, it's my fault for not reading the warnings, but these are cheap and aren't worth the money.  They are Dollar Tree quality and the earpiece parts fall apart.  I purchased these for my students and should have spent money to buy traditional headphones instead, since I'm back to square one.

If you're listening to music with this, then this is exactly what you want for the money. The quality of the product in person is fantastic and is true to the pictures online. The antenna is literally 39.5 inches long which looks absurd when fully extended. I would also recommend not fully extending the antenna however because it is very flimsy on the last foot or so. The stereo is also very heavy on the bass (especially for how small it is). Anyone that hears this unit will immediately be impressed by the volume and bass extension from such a small unit. In fact it's actually /too much/ bass for me some of the time because I like to listen to certain talk radio stations. I wouldn't recommend this for anyone wishing to listen primarily to talk radio. The sound quality is a tad bit sub par to a discerning ear if you're picky but I don't mind it because it looks great and I have other speakers for more pure listening. The sound quality still sounds great for the reported 85 db SNR.  The Bluetooth aspect works seamlessly. Once you set it up, it will auto-connect when in range. Just don't expect perfect sound quality. If you're not a critic and you love bass then this is what you want.

I got this as a present for my boyfriend. He loves it. He takes public transportation everyday to work. The best part of this briefcase is that it's slender enough which is perfect for maneuvering in tight cramped places such as public transportation. It's a well made piece of luggage.

I received my Tayogo Wireless Bone Conduction Open-Ear Headphones this morning and used it the entire day. While the sound quality isn't as good as a true on-ear headphone or earbuds, the advantage of a bone conduction headphone is the ability to keep your ears open to your surroundings. It was exactly what I needed.

It was a little bit odd to feel the bass vibrating my head at first, but I soon got used to it. I really did like this style of headphones.

At the end of the night, I plug the headphones in and I see the charging light come on. A couple of seconds later, it goes off and from then, I couldn't get any response from the headphone at all. No matter how long I try to hold the power button, it just won't turn on.

I realized that I forgot to first turn off the headphones before plugging it in. I believe that may be what caused the problem.

Quite disappointed to have a device work only for 1 day.

The earbuds themselves are a little large and uncomfortable in my ears. However I only paid $10 for 5 pairs so I was not surprised. I am only using these to listen to audio books so the quality doesn't really matter.

This is an incredible deal 80 GB Android operating system lossless music player that will play YouTube Spotify or any app that I've tried so far nice color screen very nice touch screen with a 3.5 mm headphone output USB c to charge it and it takes a MicroSD card as well. This unit comes with in the box the player a protective Case Case a USB c to USB a charging cable with a USB a to USB c adapter a 64gb micro SD card I mean it's incredible value actually in the audio sounds exceptional. About buying another one while they're still this price and having a spare. Customer support with this company is the best I've ever experienced with any company.

I use my buds and headphones for more than just walking and talking and playing games. I also listen to podcasts at night and because these cannot endure enough battery life, I am stuck with either my headphones or earbuds. Other than that little issue, these are darn nice in-ear headphones. If you read the Amazon page, it will give you a lot of information on how to use them and how to tell which is left and right and what functions they do on the right and left.

I was so excited to get this new Jabra. I haven't worn one lately. I charged it up and paired it with my iPhone 7+ and downloaded the Jabra app to make adjustments and to enable your Jabra to do all kinds of things - like message readout, email readout and others things. Not all smartphones will have the compatibility to do all the extra things, so make sure you download the app and follow instructions. Anyway, I hooked up my Jabra and it informed me that after a full charge, I had 6 hours. I chose to listed to podcasts on my iPad. I woke up in the middle of the night and the Jabra had my ear hurting and I had to swap to my headphones. I don't toss around, I sleep on my back in a recliner to prevent me from moving around. One thing I really noticed that irritated me, was that I never got the full sound from the Jabra unless I held it close to my ear with my hand holding it in place. Maybe I have weird ears, I don't know. But this is not a device I got enjoyment from.

My 20 year old son is a computer programming major and is a big time gamer. He has been in need of a new backpack for a few months now and was happy to see this. It's well padded and offers a lot of protection for his laptop. It has a lot more compartments and pockets than standard backpacks have. It seems well designed and definitely geared toward gamers. He was thrilled to learn that there was a rain cover. When he's walking on campus during rain, he will put his backpack under his raincoat which is always a bit awkward. It took me a while to find where this rain cover was stored. There's a zippered compartment on the base of the bag  that stores the cover. The straps are not super comfortable, but they're okay. Zippers work well. Overall, it's a good gaming backpack.
Video works fine audio was bad had a very bad noise in it.  Ended up getting another set top box from cable company so much easier.

I've previously paid a lot more for headphones that were no better than these.  I use them on my computer and my MP3 player while in my home only because I hate when sound leaks from my headphones in public and people can hear what I'm listening to, however, for around the house these headphones are great.

Amazing sound. Took off one star because it does not allow you to connect to a new device until you've manually disconnected from the old device.

I have the Bose speaker too, the Anker speakers are a great economical alternative to the Bose.
Got this for a friend to use these 3.5mm corded headphones and a charger with his I Phone 7. He loves them - 41 year old Vet.

I got a couple of these where Spotify offered them @ 50% off $50 sale...
I'd say Its somewhere between 2-3.5 stars.

Pluses:
* The Bluetooth works well.
* The features are kinda cool (pressing the side of the headphone to stop/play/forward/backward playlists).
* Above feature even works with Spotify on my Windows computer.
* The wire where you plug-in w/o using bluetooth is kinda cool so can use without using power.
* feature to share the bluetooth w/ a wire to a friend is cool. Me and sis watched a meteor shower and I played some tunes we could share w/o disturbing our quiet suburban neighborhood.

Minuses:
* I'm 5'3" with a small to regular-sized head, and it feels too tight and hurts ears after 30m-1hr. Almost a deal breaker.
* The headphones themselves feel tight, but also don't wrap around your ear like some headphones and dont stay on tightly. Like they are the size of your ear which I don't find very comfortable.
* The power button and USB charger port are right in the area where the headphone can rotate (and be half covered by the plastic).
Its annoying to access those buttons sometimes .
* sometimes accidentally activate the touch feature. Could be set to be less sensitive.

This is the second one of these audio extractors I've bought and the second one that doesn't work.  It either shows picture and no sound or sound and no picture. Very frustrating.  Tried switching everythng around and got same results frustrating

Great headphones and they come with a cool travel case

Update: after two months one side stopped working. Tried to contact the seller using the information from the product warranty and I have yet to receive an answer.

I installed these on an iMac computer. The speakers are smaller than I expected from the pictures. They are approximately 7-3/4" high by 3-1/4" wide by 5-3/4" in depth. Installation was extremely easy and took a few minutes. The AC power adapter piece slides and locks into the AC power supply. After that the audio cable gets attached to the right speaker from the computer input to the headphone jack on the back of the computer. Then the cable rom the left speaker goes into the slot by that name on the right speaker. The AC power adapter then gets plugged into your home outlet and the cable end goes into the jack marked DC power on the right speaker. After this it is just a matter of adjusting the computer volume to 75% on the computer and then turning on the right speaker by adjusting the knob to the volume desired. One improvement I would recommend is an on/off light for the speakers.

On the back of the right speaker, plug another device into the AUX IN to listen to a different audio device.

I played a few tunes from an iTunes playlist both with the computer volume and then again with these speakers. To my ears the sound through these speakers is crisp, clear, and deep. I love them! In my opinion, this is another great product from Bose.

UPDATE: Watching videos on the iMac with this system is awesome. My boyfriend and I love the acoustics and feel as if we're in a theatre.

I purchased this cable to extend my right hand Logitech Z623 speaker 10 additional feet.  Works perfectly (not all do for this app).  Perfect signal transmission, no degradation, double shielding prevents power source hum in the background.

While I tend to use wireless headphones most of the time, there are times, such as when flying that I need wired headphones and these are AWESOME.

These headphones are equipped with an iPhone Lightning Connector which is the perfect size to fit through the opening in the case on my iPhone, it snaps into place without issue and provides a stable connection.

The set comes with the headphones, a rubber squeeze case, 3 sets of silicone ear bud tips, 3 sets of silicone ear bud wings, and a wire clip.

I found that the preinstalled tips and wings (medium) fit perfectly for me.

The sound from these headphones is excellent - from the rich bass notes to the vibrant midtones to the bright treble. I tested these headphones with a wide range of audio - from audiobooks to jazz, heavy metal, country, classical and blues - everything sounded amazing.

The noise cancelling feature works really well on these headphones. Noise cancelling is a complex process where a processor must detect ambient noise, both frequency and amplitude, through the microphone and then ‚Äúblock it‚Äù by creating an exactly opposite noise thus cancelling out the ambient noise. Some noises are more easily cancelled than others and some processors within headphones do a better job at cancelling than others. I have to say I am thoroughly impressed with the noise cancelling these headphones achieve.

The microphone picks up perfectly on calls in my tests the other person had no issues hearing me crystal clear.

The control module allows you to easily increase or decrease the volume. Start / stop / pause music or answer / end calls.

These are a great set of wired headphones that performed very well in all of my tests. This is definitely a product I would recommend.

‚≠êÔ∏èAs with all Drew‚Äôs Reviews, if I discover something new about this product - good or bad - I will UPDATE my review. I believe in creating detailed, complete reviews because, like you, I depend on them when I am shopping. If you found my review HELPFUL - please click ‚¨áÔ∏è below!‚≠êÔ∏è

These little earbuds come with their charging case and a USB cable to charge. They were 30% charged when I received them so I plugged them in overnight to fully charge. The red light on the case never went off or changed so I don't know if it's supposed to when fully charged.  The sound is clear, not a lot of bass as I would prefer but at least they have a good crisp sound. The buds are also very comfortable to wear for awhile.  They did not irritate my ears at l. I have to get used to the sensitivity of the touch button on the bud, though. They are very sensitive to touch and if you're trying to adjust the fit, you'll be pausing or forwarding a song in the process, but that's just my issue. Happy with these and looking forward to using them often. They paired quickly to my android devices and the directions included were simple to follow.

I'm pleasantly surprised by this sub. I took advantage of a huge savings on Amazon (had to wait a few months to get it, but that was ok). There are tons of features built into the panel and the power this projects is amazing. I have a large open living room, so finding a sub that can fill it was pretty hard...but this is the one. If you can afford it, go for it.

**Update 27 Nov 2010** After a few days of playing the new Gran Turismo 5 I'm amazed at how much power this sub has. I have my PS3 on top of the sub and it nearly fell off from the vibrations. I'll update later once I've updated the other speakers in my setups...currently they're the lim-fac in my sound system.

I deducted 1 star because there is only 1 HDMI port on this TV, when there really should be 2.

I deducted another star because they put a label right on the screen itself that left behind residue upon peeling it off. This is unacceptable on a television.

The TV is lightweight. The picture is pretty good for a $130 TV. I like that it has both RCA audio out jacks and a headphone jack. If you really want a small size TV, this is certainly one to consider.

I was expecting some high technology with this Bluetooth adapter. I find that it really isn't needed on any of my computers or laptops. They already have blue tooth. But, you never know when you might run into an old desktop that needs to have Bluetooth, so it is something to hang on to. Just in case. Who knows, your preinstalled Bluetooth might fail, this gives you a backup so you can keep going along with your work or play

Seems like a pretty standard pair of headphones

I like the design and think they‚Äôre pretty basic. Plug them into your device and there ya go. Just make sure you‚Äôve got the port for them

Overall I think they‚Äôre nice headphones for the price and I had good first impression
We are enjoying this for looking at stamps and coins.

My husband has a Clavinova - an electric piano that has programs for different typs of music. He uses headphones and the headphone plug is a larger one. So, needless to say, he uses the bigger 6.55 male size for headphone/piano. If he listens to his smartphone, he can change the plug to the smaller plug size into the larger size and listen to the headphones with that plug. He always can use these types of devices.

I have the Jabra 35 headset also and this one is noticably different with regard to the quality of phone calls, but that's really the only material difference I can find in my day to day use. The other unit does offer some noise cancellation effects that this one doesn't have and people you call can definitely tell the difference. My husband said that he could hear background noise much more clearly when I called him from this 15 than with the 35.

As far as battery life, this thing is really solid. I've used for three hours on two different days without recharging between days. I primarily use it to listen to audiobooks while I'm doing my barn chores and checking fence lines. I have noticed that I'm pretty limited with the distance I can stray from my physical phone before this headset begins to stutter to lose signal - it seems to be about 20 feet with my Sony Xperia phone.

The case is a nice color and of decent quality.  The only problem is that the stand of the case is on the same side as the speakers.  Depending on the surface you are sitting it on your sound may be a little muted.

Second update. Played Stone Angel DVD. Froze for 3 minutes at the 1:16 mark. Played the same scene again using my Sony upscaling DVD. Played perfectly. Replayed the same scene again in the BD 60. Again froze at the exact same point. Definitely a BD60 problem. My firmware is current.

Update: Joined Netflix. Two Blue Ray movies so far. Slumdog Millionaire played perfectly. However there was an 11 minute freeze on Benjamin Buttons. Freeze from 1:16-1:27. I rebooted twice and tried different fixes. Nothing worked. I was never able to view these 11 minutes. I have the latest firmware update.

Original review. I came close to a 3 star rating. Contrary to other comments, I think the remote is confusing. I'm still using the manual when I watch TV, and I know my wife will never use it. I have my Sony DVD with upgrade ability on top of my Blue Ray, and plan to use it on regular DVDs. The Sony remote is so easy to use, and so feature packed. This Panasonic has excellent Blue Ray quality, and great sound. Just watched Slumdog Millionaire, played to perfection.

Firmware upgrade was painless, easily downloads You Tube (turned out to be a very enjoyable feature). Watched Neil Diamond in concert, from You Tube, to my TV, in VG quality. However, I just joined Netflix, and am disappointed there is no Netflix capability. I knew this when I ordered, buy I didn't realize how expensive the Amazon VOD program is. I will probably replace this new Panasonic with one that downloads Netflix, and give this to my daughter. Don't want Roku, though I have read mostly good things about it.

My equipment. Maganavox 720 P (not high end, 3 years old, but stunning picture). Hooked Blue Ray using component cables, since TV will only display 720 P. Sony receiver-no HDMI inputs. It's 10 years ago, but was high end. Using Linksys router, Linksys switcher. Roadrunner Cable running at about 6 MB.

This works great running it from a U Turn Audio Turntable.  Does exactly what its supposed to do for a nice price.  Haven't had any issues with it whatsoever.  Purchase with confidence if you are looking for a phono preamp.

I got these to use for watching video on my Kindle at night. I have some hearing loss and I find it's easier to hear with something like this. These are light and comfortable. They paired quickly and easily. The only problem and it's kind a show stopper is that the audio and video are out of sync while these are connected. As soon as I turn them off everything is fine. Would love to know how to fix that because out of sync makes me crazy after a few shows.

The HP 7 inch Digital Picture Frame (model df730p1) was the quickest to set up of any digital frame I've used.  My first impression upon receiving the box was that it was packaged economically, a plus in my book with no extraneous styrofoam materials for protecting in the box.  I was then impressed by the actual frame which is described as, "Dark Espresso Front Concave, 1 Decorative Paper Mat, double color: White on Espresso."  It's lovely and the paper matte gives it a more finished appearance.  This frame can be rotated if desired, as can the photos.  I looked at the quick set up guide, read the very complete manual and then removed the frame from its package, plugged it in and turned it on.  The internal slideshow began in seconds and I was eager to replace the graphics and pictures with my own.  Seeing that this has a calendar, I switched from the default date in 2008 and set it to the current date and time.  Options exist to display the calendar with the photo in the upper corner or to have the time displayed in a small font, but I selected neither of those options and went for just the pictures to be run in a slideshow at 5 second intervals.  Being able to set a schedule for images is a great advantage, allowing for the slideshow to cease when it's not needed to run.  I set all these things with the intuitive little remote control which can be attached to the rear of the frame by the enclosed magnet.  Smart option.  The LCD screen is 480x234 and the image is very clean.  With a 5-in-one card reader, you can use SD, MMC, XD, MS, MSPro or MMC.  This model has an internal memory of 128 MB which supposedly can run up to 800 compressed images and there is also a mini USB port.  A little dial on the side enables you to adjust the brightness of the image.  Only JPEG files can be read and there is no speaker, so keep in mind that it's a visual frame.  Most menu options are very logical and easy to follow, and a majority can be accessed via the device itself, without using the remote.  Although the remote action does take a second or two to register, I've found that preferable.  All in all, I think this is a very nice frame in this price range and would not hesitate to recommend it.

This speaker is great.  I've got an Echo Dot in my bathroom connected to this and I can hear the sound clearly in the shower (the Echo needs to be really loud to hear without this, since it isn't in the shower with me).  Even when I'm washing my hair under the water, I can still hear the music, but I don't wake up the sleeping baby in the next room.  Okay, that's a pretty specific reason to want one of these, but there it is...

My daughter loves this. Very cute, stylish looking headphones, and surprisingly comfortable to wear. My kids especially don't like earbuds, so the over-the-ear style like these are a welcome alternative. I was actually impressed at how much noise isolation they provide... it really blocks out the outside sound, you end up yelling when trying to talk without realizing, and that's not even when there is any music playing! Sound quality is OK- not as amazing as my brand name speakers, but good enough for what it is. A little echo-ey, but a worthwhile compromise for the over-the-head style and this level of noise isolation.

The echo is great, and Alexa is great. I only wish that the volume ring was back in this version... I miss it from the first generation echo. In comparing the sound fro the first-generation echo, I can't tell much of a difference. The sound is better on my Google Home. On the Echo, sound is a bit flat to my ears. The Microphone picks up very well though, as good or better than my Google home, and the first-generation echo.

I loaded paper and ink without even reading the instructions - just super easy. BE AWARE the FIRST package you get of paper and ink do not do a full 10 prints - it's like a "sampler" (lots of misunderstanding about this) - after that you get the full 10 prints.  I'm using it to print old photos from my hard drive to give to family members and it cleans them up nicely.  It's just so easy to use it's amazing BUT you are restricted to their products - which luckily are not that expensive given the cost of other ink and paper packages.  I just need to figure out how to resize photos that won't fit in the size limit of the photo - I'm sure there is editing software out there that does it but I've never done much picture editing so if anybody has any suggestions it would be appreciated. I'm trying to not cut off the people on the ends of each size. I've tried it horizontal and vertical but it just won't shrink it down.  It's also pretty fast and cool to watch as it layers each color on the page. Hasn't failed once - all errors have been mine.  Do wish it had some suggestions about editing or at least tell you if you CAN use editing software with this.  Also - always leave it ON to keep the ink from drying out.
I picked an extra one of these up so I could have one at my office and the other on my nightstand. Quality audio and a convenient way to charge your tablet

I bought these for my daughter. She is allowed to listen to music and podcasts at school, and these are stylish and unobtrusive. She has been enjoying them, and we will be ordering another pair for my other daughter. Seems like a good basic daily-use set of earphones. I cannot speak to the audio quality, as I have not tested them myself. But they are still working after being toted around by a 6th grader, so that's something.

after having it for a few months, I would not recommend it. Unlike the Alexa in your home where you just speak, there are several conditions that just be in place for this to work. As a result, I never use it.

However, as far as integration with my Toyota Prius goes ( and there is a very good chance this is Toyota), it is not as easy as the one you use at home. You must be on the right mode- for me it's the bluetooth mode. You won't hear it if you are tuned to am or fm.

It is slower to respond. At home you say Alexa (baby pause) and then your request. In the car, it's Alexa (WAIT) . . . then speak your command. Half the time it dissolves into no response.

As a result, I don't use it as much as I do the ones at home. And in case you think I'm a rookie, I have 4 Echo products in my one bedroom condo. So I recommend it with reservation. I still want it, I don't want to return it, but it needs work, not sure who to blame.

These are incredibly uncomfortable. My ears don‚Äôt particularly stick out, but these headphones squash them and hurt after several minutes. An oblong ear pad would have been an improvement.

Given that they sync with my car and phone, I have to fumble to switch to phone audio if I get a call while somebody is using them in the vehicle. Would be easier if they had a built in microphone.

Also, if you have hair longer than an inch, it‚Äôll get caught in the joints and get torn out.

Aside from that, easy to set up, good battery life, okay construction.

Purchased this for a new build, retiring my seven year old system for a more modern and faster platform. This monitor was icing on the cake. Arrived packed securely without any dead pixels. Picture is clear and crisp with great color. Large display with full 1080p resolution and a very fast reaction time excellent for gaming or movie watching. It has a variety of ports including HDMI, DVI, and good old VGA. I cannot comment on the speakers as I own some high end Logitechs and have never bothered to hook up the built in audio. In a pinch, I suppose, it is nice to have it in case I ever need it.

Bottom line: I recommend this monitor to anyone looking for a quality product at a good price.

I'm not sure what regular people do with this,  but I bought it for my wheelchair.  Sometimes I have to go out in the rain and it can get a little hectic trying to control the joystick with one hand and hold onto an umbrella in the other.  This is perfect for holding the umbrella.  I simply clamp one side to the handle and the other side to the back of the chair.  It's easy enough to do on my own,  but it's strong enough that I don't have to worry about the umbrella slipping and bonking me on the head.

I got this receiver to use with my Logitech computer speaker system to connect wirelessly with my phone, my laptop and my TV depending on my needs. It works and sounds great! The sound quality is better than expected and it has a few different input/output options (auxiliary, RCA) . It never turns off and has a blue light on top so you can easily see when it's in pairing mode. I haven't tested the distance on it because I have an open floorplan and all of my devices are within 15 ft of the Esinkin. The first one of these that I ordered came in as a dud, no light, no pairing with any device. I contacted the seller and they responded quickly, asked for my address and sent me a new one right away. Customer service was awesome and I'm glad I got the new one because I love it!
Used this to connect my ps4 to my receiver and it works great. Product feels durable and works great.

This review is for the rock bluetooth 8" speakers. I figured the larger size speaker would provide better bass and better sound compared to the smaller 5 1/2" models, but I have not been impressed. The bass is lacking and the sound generally sounds weak - like the radio in an old car or an AM transistor radio. . . just weak, somewhat tinnie. Fortunately I got them through Amazon Warehouse (used like new) for half the price of the new ones, so I'll go ahead and use them til they die. I've gotten spoiled by the great bass and sound my little Bose Mini Soundlink puts out, so when it's time for patio/pool/landscape speakers, next time I'll probably spend the bucks on Bose.

I bought this for my smart tv. Im having issues installing and tried everything and wasted hours. There is no video showing how to. Is there an app involved here? So frustrating!
As far as sound goes it is powerful. You can tell just by turning it on. Im sure itll work fine with a computer but thats not what I bought it for. I guess I'll have to take one day just to work on it as I have a list of other things I have to do. I will update after I figure this out.

UPDATE.
I have a Samsung smart tv and just purchased an upgraded Firestick.
I finally got the Soundbar connected! Had to go to settings and then to bluetooth. Sigh.
I love it and apologize for giving a bad review. It's a keeper.

I love the concept of bone conducting headphones, and if you haven't tried a set before you really should! The sensation is a little unsettling at first but when you get used to it, you are rewarded with the ability to hear deep bass in your sounds without covering your ears completely the way ear buds and over-the-ear headphones require. They're not for everyone admittedly, but I love that I can feel/hear the sound and still be aware of my surroundings and able to respond if someone calls my name.
Good bone conducting headphones are easily 2x-3x the price of these, so keep that in mind. This is not going to be an alternative to a big name brand set. However, they aren't terrible either, and I kind of like them for the novelty of it at the price point.
If audio quality is your primary goal, understand that for the same money you can get a very decent pair of traditional headphones that will outshine this. But where's the fun in that?
4 stars for the novelty of it, but I give the sound quality and cost value only 3 stars.

Does not automatically connect to Bluetooth. I have to connect every time I get in the car.
Very difficult to obtain and update the FM station.

These headphones look great and the sound quality is nice but I don't think they actually feel very nice. The headphones themselves are a little hard and stiff, not to mention they're rigid when it comes to adjusting the size. They don't move nearly as smoothly as headphones I've tried at much lower price points.

The bottom line is even though they look nice and sound decent, I'm going to reach for these less because they're just not as comfortable as other pairs I own (some of which cost less than this pair)
This is a very nice case for my old Tab A. I like the color and texture of the cover. I also like the pocket on the outside for the occasional document or headphones.

The GOOD:
These work well for hearing dialog and hushed speaking, or when it's accompanied with a lot of background noise in certain movies and tv shows. Also work well if someone is hard-of-hearing, so that you don't have to crank up the volume on the tv (the volume of each headset is individually adjustable). We've found it also works well if one person watching tv while others in the room are playing games or watching something else on their tablets.
The BAD:
These are extremely Line-Of-Sight. The base unit has to be aimed directly where you're seated, and if you're sitting just a couple/few feet to either side, you'll start getting more & more static. If I stand up to grab something from the other side of the room, the static will overtake the tv audio dialog completely and I have to take them off my head. Seems strange that the technology is so limited on these, requiring near perfect seating placement. I'll even get brief blasts of static just by raising my hand up to my face, as it seems to partially block the signal coming from the base unit.
Overall worth having but could definitely be improved.
The sound is off but it serves its purpose. I have a Bose speaker so üòÖ. But for the price? It looks good and the sound is decent.

This item turns your iPhone or iPad into an FM receiver. Simply download the free app, plug in the phones using the Lightning port on your device, set up your favorite FM stations and your favorite EQ settings and you can listen to FM over-the-air broadcasts of your favorite FM radio stations near you. This is not a streaming device, it's an FM chip tuner in the earbud line. If you don't have a radio nearby but have your IOS device and these phones, now you do!
Junk I've had headphones eairbuds for one year and 32 days I've had headphones eairbuds for one year and 32 days They quit working

This Bluetooth speaker has great sound and I like it better than the Bose Soundlink I returned.  The bluetooth pairs quickly and the sound is very good.  My only complaint is if you have it plugged in to charge, and you turn on the speaker, the charging stops until you turn off the unit again.  That is why I deducted 1 star.  If you plan to use this not as a portable devise, but just keep it on your shelf there may be better options.

I mainly use [[ASIN:B002GOYU0O 12 pc Velcro Ties Reausable Electrical Wire Cable Strap]], which meet most of my needs. I also use these and like them a lot.

Where these come in handy, and even augment my preferred strap, is they are nearly immovable once you tie them to a brace of other anchoring point. For example, if you are setting up with a keyboard, the stand makes a good anchor point for cross-stage cable runs. This is especially true of Z-style stands like the [[ASIN:B0002F6JH6 On Stage 2 Tier Folding Z Keyboard Stand]] (although X-style stands work well). This does take some pre-planning because you do not want to interfere with other musicians or, worse, create trip hazards.

Because you loop the narrow end through the eyelet on the wider end and pull this strap has more holding strength than someone who is only running cables on stage and in a studio will ever need. Frankly, I augmented my preferred brand and model with these because of cost - and they are worth every penny. At 8" you can safely run more than a few instrument, speaker and microphone cables through one anchored to a frame like the Z-stand I mentioned above, and still keep the strap sufficiently loose to prevent stretching or breaking cables run through it.

Think of it as one more handy tool in your bag of tricks if running and managing cable is one of the things you do. I purchased a half dozen packs for my needs.

I've been trying to use the cube with DTVNow for a few months now and have reset to factory defaults, deinstalled app multiple times and still have the same issue, which is the video and audio will stutter when starting the app after being dormant overnight or idle for several hours.  If I restart the Fire Cube, the app will work ok.  It's never been as fast the Gen 2 FireTV box we had but I was willing to deal with that for the slick device control the Cube offered. Not being able to use my primary  TV streaming service is a show stopper. Shame as it could have been a great device, I suspect it's a processor and/or lack of memory issue, but not certain. Will be selling it CHEAP and replacing with with a ROKU or Invidia Shield.

It's comfortable for my medium sized lady hands (I can rest my hand on the mouse) and I love the features (scroll wheel, forward and back buttons), but like others have said the scrolling is choppy. You have to really focus it to get it on an window close button for example. That said, it's my best choice for a Logitech unifying receiver mouse. The M325 worked very well but was too small for my hand.

I just wish it worked as well as my Logitech MediaPlay mouse I bought a decade ago. Unfortunately that has a giant USB receiver and I work on a Macbook with only two USB ports and also use a wireless keyboard.

Ugh, no perfect solution for me.

Like most households today, we have so many cables. It seems like every device needs a different type of cable, be it HDMI, USB-A, USB-C, USB-mini... it's nuts! I personally can't wait for all of our devices to be switched over to the current industry standard USB-C so I can at least reduce *some* of the clutter! But until that day comes (if ever), I am trying to at least organize our cable collection to where we can grab what we need without having to sift through a sea of black cables, examining all of the ends looking for the right one.

Enter these Avyxm USB C to C 4 foot cables. I chose the red and LOVE THEM!! They are very vibrant and bright making it stupid easy to quickly grab the correct cable for our USB-C devices!! The cables are nice and thick but still with a bit of bend allowing for maneuvering around furniture legs or nightstand lamps without putting a kink in them. And one of the biggest props? These cables FAST CHARGE everything I've connected them to. Our Samsung Galaxy S8 and S10 phones, my new Fire HD8 Plus tablet and my kids' Samsung S10 plus phones. The 4 foot length is perfect for bedside nightstands although it is a little too short to reach the couch and still use the phone or tablet in a comfortable position -- so I'll be grabbing a couple of the 6 foot cables for living room use.

Bottom line... the color is fantastic, the build quality is supreme, I don't expect they'll ever kink given their thickness, I love the braiding and feel of the fabric -- overall a high quality product that I have and will continue to, highly recommend!
Ear buds lack strength to capture Bluetooth signal if more than two or three feet away.
It didn't work for me. I wanted to use a Bluetooth keyboard with my Windows pc and you can spend time to eternity and it still won't work..

I got this product because I like to ride my stationary bicycle while I watch a film on my computer. In the past, I used a set of headphones for audio. However, the cable was cumbersome and got in the way. With this product I can listen to my computer without having annoying wires interfering with my enjoyment of the film.

The headphones are high quality and feature great sound reproduction. The purchase price includes headphones, a transmitter, a power cable, a micro USB charging cable, an RCA converter cable, a digital optical cable, and a 3.5mm audio cable. The USB cable can be used to charge the headphones, or you can use the transmitter which features a headphone cradle.

I elected to connect this to my computer with the 3.5mm audio cable and it works great. The headphones have a volume key which is easy to operate while you're wearing them. This is a high quality item that is comfortable to wear and provides good sound. The packaging is also very attractive which makes this a thoughtful gift idea.

[[VIDEOID:2e7c0a6adbe4e28b15ec850150bf83ab]] Please check out the pictures that I provided for size and picture quality comparison between the TOUMEI Mini Projector and the [[ASIN:B008BUQ16S Vivitek Qumi Q5]].

**If you read through the entire review, I hope that I can provide some information that may help you get the most out of this projector.

THE REVIEW
I already owned a QUMI Q5, which was $500 when it came out and I really like the projector but I found that I did not take it with me very often when I travel because while the projector is small, it did not have built in battery and could not be powered by USB, requiring me to bring a power adapter. It also did not have Android so I had to bring a separate device such as a laptop or firetv. What this meant was that I ended up having to take up a lot of space in my bag for all the accessories necessary just to make the QUMI work.

The TOUMEI solves both problems for me. It has a built-in battery that should run for a couple of hours and can be charged using a USB charger (which I would bring with me anyway). Just remember that you need a charger with a high amperage (2.1A at least). With the built in Android, don't need to bring an additional media device. All I need to pack is the projector and its remote control. With the HDMI port, I still have the option to connect a laptop or FireTV to the projector (see caveats)

As you can see in my pictures and video, the TOUMEI looks just as good, if not better, than the QUMI when projecting a 30" picture. Fun fact: The TOUMEI was running on battery power when I was filming my comparison video. Projection brightness isn't lowered because it is running on battery power.

So for my use, the TOUMEI deserves its 5-Stars. I also want to give props to TOUMEI for updating the projector from Android 4 to Android 7.1.2. That's a 3-version jump! With that said, the projector is not perfect.

CAVEATS:
- Netflix not supported (See tips for workarounds)
- In HDMI mode, there are no keystone controls and auto-keystone doesn't work. This means you are forced to front-project and the projector must be level to the screen. I wrote an email to TOUMEI support and they were quite responsive. Unfortunately, they do not have a solution for this.
- Bluetooth mouse doesn't work very well. I've tried two bluetooth mice with the project but the pointer jumps around the screen, making it hard to use. Using a logitech usb mouse/keyboard worked well and mouse movement was smooth.

TIPS:
- Streaming apps: There is a builtin app called freeclick. From there, you can install a version of Amazon Videos and Youtube that works with remote control navigation. You can also install Netflix from there, but it is a very old version that was designed for touch/mouse input (see Netflix tip).
- Better UI: I was able to install "Leanback Launcher for Fire TV" (search google and click on the xda-developers link). Leanback is the codename for the launcher that is built in to Android TV. It is a more modern-looking launcher than what the projector came with. Also install "TV App Drawer" from the Play Store to show all apps that the Leanback Launcher hides.

- Better UI Alternative: I also tried out ATV Launcher from the Play Store and that is a launcher that looks just like the Leanback launcher but has more options but some are locked unless you purchase the PRO version.

NETFLIX:
The newer versions of the Netflix app no longer support any Android boxes that aren't on their "white list" so only version 4 or earlier work (Netflix is at version 7 as of this writing). So while the Netflix that is included with the projector works, it is old and you really need a mouse to use it. There are a few workarounds that you can try though:

- Miracast: While there is a builtin app for casting an android phone to the projector, it is buggy and doesn't retain the phone's aspect ratio, stretching the picture out. Instead, install AirScreen from the Play Store. The popup ads can be annoying unless you pay to remove them but AirScreen is the most stable Miracast receiver software I've used. It also supports Apple Airplay, Google Cast, and DLNA. With AirScreen, you can cast Netflix from your phone to the projector.

- FireTV: With the HDMI port, you can connect a FireTV to the projector and take advantage of all the great services that Amazon provides. Just remember that in this case, you cannot adjust the keystone in any way and ceiling mounting or rear-projection modes are not available.

- Kodi: As opposed to what you may have read, Kodi is not illegal. It is simply a great video player that supports addons. There are some addons that are bad, but Kodi itself is not illegal or malware in any way. So basically, only install Kodi either from their official website at kodi.tv or through the Play Store.

Kodi has a Netflix plugin (Search "Netflix Add-on [input-stream]") and click on the Kodi Community Forum link. Again, this plugin is not illegal and does not circumvent Netflix security in any way. You are still required to provide your Netflix login. I will not go into the installation instructions here because it will make this review even longer than it already is.

I hope that I was able to help some of you with my review and tips. Thanks for reading!

I got the "acceptable" unit for total $17 (sorry), one foot pad is missing, I'll innovate. Firstly, I had wanted the chrome front but couldn't afford it and didn't want to wait a week; when I saw this used for the price I just pushed the button.

From the pictures you would think the front is all matte black, it is not. It's actually a very dark brown and the controls are a dark bronze, in shiny metal; closer to chrome aesthetic and looks far better with more tones than the photos would suggest. I'm actually happy I bought the darker color now seeing it. I tried to capture this on my pic, but it's too dark and still doesn't capture the wonderful appearance.

Plugging it in and turning it on was instantly satisfying, easy to use controls, no stiffness, good quality, lights work, radio is a deep amber or orange. Nice wood, looks and operates easily and great.

Tuning to a somewhat hard to get classical station locally was surprisingly easy and the signal came in loud and clear, unlike the other radios I've tried from Amazon. It felt like an old stereo where you didn't have to give it thought and was instinctive in the first 30 seconds without the difficulty and poor reception and static and crackling of tuning and volume controls or pops of turning it on nearly all cheap modern radios have now.

Bluetooth connected and performed seamlessly, perhaps a little softer than the radio but not horribly so. And the sound... On both radio and bluetooth the sound quality is superb; *just* enough bass without being muddy and the treble is good and clear. Bass in the voices and high pitches in the music, and very loud without screech or static at still low volume on the knob, with room-filling sound on FM and bluetooth.

This is the most pleasing product I've purchased from Amazon in a long time, especially in the radio category.

Update: After trying several others, I bought a second one! Like New $21. The only thing I notice is neither sits perfectly evenly, there's a slight wobble, even with all four feet pads. No biggie. Love the radio, excellent big sound, bass, but not muddy. Best radio on Amazon, and a true "table radio".

When the lockdown started last year, I decided to look for an external webcam for my laptop. I talked with a couple of friends who recomended the Logitech 920, so Iooked on Amazon and was shocked at the cost. It normally went for about $60, but when I looked it was $200. I wasn't going to pay that high a price, so I tried a couple of low cost alternatives, both of which I had to return.
Then I found out about the Emeet webcam from a friend of mine. He said it worked great and so at $27, I decided to give it a try. I'm glad I did because it's a great little webcam. The camera iteslf is high quality and auto focus. It has a wider field of view than my laptop camera and also has a decent microphone. I'm very happy with the purchase and now use it most of the time on Zoom calls. If you are looking for an alternative to the 920, this is definitely it. The only issue is that I wish it had a privacy screen, but the 920 doesn't have one either so it's a fair comparison.
If you are looking for a good webcam grab this one, it's a great deal.

I selected this bluetooth adapter for my daughter's computer so that she could use her wireless headphones with it. Overall, it does mostly do what it claims, but there are some issues. It found her headphones right away, but uses 5.0 tech, not 5.1. The sound works great if she remains in her room, but will encounter static at distances much less than 65'. The price is too high for what the adapter can do, and the static is very annoying.

Using this to cool down my DAC, which runs pretty hot (only passively cooled). The difference felt is amazing, now the top cover actually feels cool instead of burning hot.

I'm using the dual 80mm version as well to cool down my Pioneer Elite receiver.
i love this little speaker its nice and loud !!!

Upon opening these headphones I was immediately disappointed with the weight of them. They're completely plastic constructed and feel very light and flimsy. The mic makes a clicky noise when you move it. I got this to make phone calls since I work from home but found that the person on the line would occasionally have difficulties hearing me, which doesn't normally happen with my normal headphones. For the price I think I'd try something else.

I'm a musician with a home studio. With several sets of headphones all getting old, I decided to invest in some new ones. I've had good luck with Sennheiser in the past so I wanted to check out what they were currently offering. After reading lots of reviews, I decided to give these rs175 rf's a try. I was a little leery of them being wireless but trusting in the Sennheiser name, bought them anyway. I wanted them for general recording and playback.

Pros: Excellent sound... flat, uncolored. Clear detailed, etc. All the qualities I've come to expect from Sennheiser. Wireless setup was virtually nothing... plug in the base where you'd plug in the headphones and you're done. Turn on the headphones and start listening. The stand serves as the charging station and placing the headphones on it is straightforward and secure... not clumsy at all. I have a fairly large head with proportional sized ears... (size xxl hat). The ear pads fit completely over my ears and completely seal very nicely around them. You won't be bothered by outside sounds, nor will your spouse be bothered by what you're listening to. A quick check of the range shows I can go anywhere in my average size home without losing the signal. (I didn't try going outside).

Cons: The only negative is that there is a bit of latency. If you use them for listening to music or even tv, you won't notice it... but if you turn on speakers at the same time and listen to both, you'll notice a very slight lag in the headphones.

Bottom line: these are excellent headphones, quality of build and quality of sound are both first rate. But if that latency is an issue, you probably shouldn't be looking at wireless anyway (I suspect this occurs on any wireless system).

The wallet may be marketed as a phone holder, but it is a wallet first and foremost. It is attractive and the zipper functions well, with very shiny gold colored hardware and a nice wrist strap. Aside from some stitching that I am concerned might become loose because the stitch gauge is too long, it is very well made and very utilitarian. It holds quite a bit, including a phone, making it a good accessory to carry when I don't want to take a purse or backpack with me. Since it is closed by a single surrounding zipper, I don't hear the phone if it rings unless the volume is turned to the highest and the zipper is left with an open gap. All in all, I have grown to like this wallet more and more each day.  The leather is holding up beautifully and I can't tell you how often I am asked about where to get one.  It is a really good value, too.  Sample  was provided for review.
