I prefer trackballs like this one to regular mice, and I like the fact that this one is bigger than average so I decided to give it a try. So far I am pleased with it, though it isn't perfect.

DELUX is not a brand with which I was previously familiar so I wasn't sure what to expect. My requirements are fairly simple - it has to work with a dongle and it needs to work under both Linux and Windows. It definitely meets both of those requirements nicely and it has not given me any issues. I usually do not use mice with Bluetooth connections so this feature, while useful for connecting to multiple systems, is wasted on me. The dongle, however, is immediately picked up by the Linux kernel as well as by Windows and I was able to plug this in and go with no delays and no effort.

This is indeed a larger trackball and it fits my hands wonderfully. I have the hands of a gorilla and finding mice and trackballs that fit me is a challenge and I usually end up settling for something that is less than ideal for me. In this case, the trackball feels good in my hands and there is no strain on my thumbs as I don't have to stretch my hand in weird ways to reach the ball properly.

Other reviewers have mentioned that this trackball tends to skip. I have not observed this issue, though I have not had it long and I have not tried to use it with the computer more than a foot away. I also have not tried connecting via Bluetooth, which is when I have had troubles in the past with pointing devices.

One thing that would have made this trackball better would have been quiet clicking of the buttons. This is not a quiet device in use, and after using a more quiet trackball it is quite noticeable.

One important oversight is that it does not come with a battery. It takes a single AA battery, and I expected one in the box. Every other non-rechargeable pointing device I have purchased has come with a battery in the package. I am not sure why the decision was made to not include one here.

This is a nice trackball and I will be using it quite a bit, particularly on my Linux system. It's a good size for me and so far it has worked well. It would have been nice if it was quieter when clicking, and I don't know why there was no battery in the package, but these are smaller issues. I'm pleased with this trackball.

Great device for people who have invested a lot of money in nice speakers and sound systems but are not Bluetooth capable. Perfect for playing music from phones and tablets. No problems connecting and setting up.

Most of the headphones with which I have worked have been active noise canceling (ANC) phones so I know a lot about those, but I also have other headphones too that I like. I was unaware that 3M even had headphones, and I was also unsure what their "Quiet Space" was all about. It's an interesting solution that works fairly well. Overall, these are good phones, though there's one area that could use some slight improvement and that's the sound profile.

These are over-the-ear phones and they are actually quite comfortable. I like how they feel on my head - they fit snugly and I can tilt my head without losing these phones, but they don't clamp down super tight either.

Build-wise, these are more substantial than the price suggests. I like the size adjustment in particular which is designed to last and should not fatigue with use.

I powered these on and they quickly paired and connected to my laptop. The range is good and I was able to walk a fair distance away without losing the connection or having the sound get crackly or having it skip. With no feed coming to them they eventually powered themselves off, saving battery but potentially frustrating the wearer if this is unexpected.

Just putting these on I was surprised by the amount of noise isolation. Without even turning these on they drastically reduced the ambient noise in the room, even effectively blocking out the sound of a running fan. I have had very few headphones that have as effective sound isolation as these, and that's a huge plus right out of the gate. The Quiet Space function adds to this, but not like ANC phones - it injects white noise into the cans so all you hear is a gentle but constant hiss that overrides most other noises. It's not deathly quiet with these on, but you won't hear most other sounds in the area when they're producing white noise. This is a very different approach to sound cancellation and it works.

The sound profile is the one area where these phones could use a little improvement, though these are not terrible and are better than some big-name phones I have used. The bass is not overdriven but it is not muted either, and this is refreshing since most manufacturers overdrive the bass. The highs are clear, though not shrill. The midrange, however, is flat to the point that music can sound slightly hollow. It's an easy fix with an equalizer and is better than one particular big-name manufacturer's similar flaw.

I like these phones and will be working with them more. They take a different approach to dealing with ambient noise and surrounding distractions than what ANC phones use, and they seem to work well. They're well made, comfortable and reasonably priced.

Good product. I got this so I could listen to music on my PC at work. When I first tried using it, the sound was a bit odd. Like tin. The ear buds that I was using sounded fine on their own. But I changed out the ear buds and the sound was better. So there was just something strange about that particular cord and earbud combo.

Before this stand, I used another Fellowes one for my laptop at home, and it proved its worth--for a while. However, with my new desk setup, I needed something which I could use while changing the height and angle of my laptop screen in a way the old stand simply couldn't. I have a Unicomp keyboard and Logitech mouse which I prefer using, and my "home" laptop needed a better stand.
Enter this Lift.

I've seen many angled laptop stands, and that's what I had in mind when I wanted to switch my old one out. Plus, my old one was better suited for the monitor at work, so I wanted to take that when I had the chance. Finally, I had the opportunity to get an angled one, so I jumped on it.

I'm not using this stand with my laptop by itself. I'm using it as a supplemental to "lift" it up with my home desktop setup being my keyboard and mouse. For that, the stand works marvelously. The angle and height are just about right; I no longer have to arch my neck uncomfortably forward. Plus, I can take my old stand to work and finally have proper posture there too.
I can't see using this by itself. My hands would quickly become painfully uncomfortable. Heck, I can't stand using keyboards with their built-in mini stands. I honestly don't know why they're there; the angle cramps my wrists very fast.

So for my use, I think the stand is great. There's even some empty real estate near the back to put things under, and it seems sturdy enough overall. It's currently holding my Toshiba 17" Windows PC, which is snugly fit.

(SEE END FOR UPDATED COMPARISON TO SAMSUNG GALAXY 4)
I have ready many reviews on tablets, and have found most of them to be why a certain tablet is better than another to the nth degree with all kinds of technical jargon which really just pits one expert against another. As a person who tutors people who are not technologically savvy, I am going to review this tablet from the point of view of someone who has not had one before and whether or not this is a good choice if you want to get one.

I have been told by several business people and those who claim to be very tech savvy that they have gotten rid of their laptops except for occasional spreadsheet work in their offices or at home. Can you get rid of your laptop by getting a tablet like this? Let's take a look.

WHAT IS THIS TABLET LIKE?
SIDE SWITCHES
This tablet is around the size of an ipad mini or a Kindle. The on off switch is on the upper right hand side (with screen facing you) and below it is a rocker switch just below the power switch. There is a space between the two buttons which will allow for elastic bands should you want to get a case for it that has them. That will make it so that the tablet will not be turned on and off by accident. The power button has to be pushed and held for a moment before the unit turns on.

SCREEN
The tablet screen is shiny which can be annoying, but that is the nature of the beast.
The touch sensitivity is excellent- I did not find any problems with response time or lag.
The orientation changing when you turn the screen around is also well set. It works nicely and is not overly sensitive.

INPUT
To input into the tablet, you have a choice to either type or speak what you want the tablet to do. I have to say that this tablet responds very well to either set of input. After working with several i-pads, my daughter constantly raves about how this Acer tablet is superior in the way it responds to input with the microphone than the i-pads are. I have not had any problem with typing into this tablet beyond what I normally do on any unit. The microphone occasionally mistypes a word, but it is not nearly as bad as I expected it to.

Response time of the tablet is excellent. I am quite impressed with how quickly it responds to input without lag or difficulty.

APPS
I have put a few apps on this unit which tend to be popular with tablet users. Sketchbook Pro is one of those apps. I really like it. The response time is good, and the app seems to work well on this tablet. I also love the radio app which allows you to listen to radio stations in the area or around the country. With a case that folds into a stand, it is a great panel to use in a room where you want to listen to the radio.

Quite a few apps that come in the tablet already are handy and easy to use. The screen is quite intuitive and easy to use.

INTERNET USAGE
This tablet is wi-fi accessible to the internet which means that you can not go out in no-man's land to use it like you can an android phone, but you have to be near a wi-fi station to use it.

The wi-fi response time is excellent- although it does occasionally lag when the signals get weak- something that all wi-fi units will do.

Android is a Google engine so everything you do will be monitored by Google or you will be using something they have designed to get where you want to go. You can find other ways to purchase apps if you don't like the Google store, however, such as Amazon.

This tablet comes with McAfee virus scan which is not a huge deal, but I am not sure how to replace that yet, should I desire to do so.

CAMERA
I am not a big advocate of phone and tablet cameras. This one has a decent camera to use on the back, and an adequate camera on the front of the camera to use for Skype which is pretty much all you need. If you want a really nice camera, buy one. For quick pictures to capture something you want to show someone, then this will be fine.

PROS
Easy to hold
Screen responsive
Speech recognition works well
Good fast performance
Boots up quickly
Clear screen makes reading books nice
Good colors for photos on the screen (better than laptops)
Power button hard to accidentally turn on or off
Learning is pretty intuitive for first time users

CONS
Wi-fi only
Not as easy to use as laptop for extensive typing
Can be a bit clumsy to use at times (the nature of tablets)
Start up literature is a bit underwhelming for first time users

THE BOTTOM LINE

CAN YOU GET RID OF YOUR LAPTOP?
Can you get rid of your laptop to substitute this tablet? My answer would be no.

Even if all you did was go on the internet to wander through web sites, using a tablet is a bit cumbersome if you want to do any kind of extensive writing. If you use the microphone, it will probably be pretty accurate, but you will still have to use the keyboard to correct what is used.

For occasional internet usage, watching videos, movies, and reading books, this tablet is fabulous. I think it works beautifully. I would say that it is just as nice as other more expensive tablets and you will invest a lot less money in it.

If you want a tablet and do not want to pay a fortune for it, this is the way to go. The Acer Iconia A1-830 is an excellent value and I use mine a lot. I just could not substitute it completely for my laptop. I prefer to have a choice in my browser, features, and fine tuning or replacement of parts should I desire to do so.

I do find that having the tablet helps a lot when I want to quickly do something on the internet and don't want to boot up my laptop. This tablet is pretty quick and I like it. If you are a tech fanatic and have to have the biggest and best, you might find fault with this tablet, however. It is worth a test run in any case.

UPDATE 3/4/2015 SAMSUNG GALAXY 4 (8 inch) vs ACER ICONIA A1-830
I have had quite a chance to get to know this tablet over time and also to use a Samsung Galaxy 4 8 inch tablet in comparison both on its own and with a keyboard. After working with both tablets, I have to say that I still prefer the Acer over the Samsung and here is why:

-Acer has slightly smaller screen area, but is easier to work on
-Acer has the return and menu buttons incorporated into the screen instead of on the side so it rotates with screen
-Acer surface is less shiny and has less glare
-Performance of Acer is the same as the Samsung in terms of speed
-Wifi of Acer is as good as the Samsung
-keyboard of Acer is much easier to use than Samsung (the one in the screen)
-set up of the Acer is much easier and user friendly
-voice commands on Acer works MUCH better than on the Samsung
-Samsung speaker is a bit nicer than Acer, but I use a bluetooth speaker for best sound anyway.
-Samsung battery does last a bit longer than the Acer, but the frustrations of the Samsung still make me prefer the Acer.

All in all, I have to say that I have tried to honestly look at both tablets and give them a fair comparison and I still like the Acer better. The price is better and the ease of use is better too. The microphone on the Acer seems much more responsive than the Samsung. The screen of the Samsung is a bit more dense in terms of pixels and color perhaps, but the glare is more annoying. I also get very irritated at the side buttons on the Samsung. They are static (stay put) and when the tablet is on its side, it is way too easy to hit a button that screws up what I am trying to do on the Samsung. This is especially true when I am trying to type something and is VERY frustrating.

There is one thing about the Samsung that I really wish the Acer had and that is longer battery time. The Samsung does run a little longer than the Acer without having to recharge. The speaker on the Samsung is a bit nicer, but with my portable bluetooth speaker as my main source of listening, I don't find that to be a problem for me.

So, after time and the chance to use the Acer and the Samsung so I could compare them, I still really like the Acer tablet better. Because I do a lot of graphics work and computer work, I still would not get rid of my laptop or desktop, but I do save a lot of time using this tablet when I want to look up quick information and cruise the internet.

UPDATE March 2016
I wanted to take a moment to update you concerning this device.

As time has gone on I have enjoyed using the Acer Iconia A1-830 very much. It is a nice tablet for an affordable price.

HAVE I HAD PROBLEMS?
A few.
-tablet went nuts as if a baby were in charge of it and had five Redbull drinks first. I rebooted and cleared out some programs and all was fine.

-I could not move my information from my device to my PC- this was solved, but it has taken a lot of research, effort and time. The support at the Acer site is rather pitiful to be honest. That is one thing that I will say about this, is compared to Samsung, Acer does not support their devices as well as they should, but then again, the price is a lot less too.

IS THIS STILL WORKING?
Yes., I use it daily and it still is working. I keep the HD less than 60% full as I do with most devices as they tend to work best that way. I find that it connects via wi-fi at times when other devices in the house do not. I also find that the battery wears down a lot less quickly if I turn off location and even wi-fi if I don't need it.

NO UPGRADE PAST KIT-KAT 4.4.2
There will be no upgrades to Lollipop or beyond, so if you want a more modern unit, then try for something new.

MY REVIEW STANDS
I now have a Samsung Galaxy Tab S2 that I am using and it of course passes the Acer by a mile, but then again, it is a much more expensive machine too.
I can now use my favorite headphones with my new phone!

Let me preface with a little about me. I'm a 50 something woman who mainly uses headphones while on the treadmill (walking not running) or when traveling. I'm not an audiophile by any means. I absolutely love these headphones! These are the first Bluetooth headphones that I have used personally. It was quick and easy to connect with the Bluetooth. It also comes with a cable so you can connect it to your phone or device that way if you prefer, or if you don't have Bluetooth. The ear cups are really comfortable. The noise reduction seem really good, especially when compared to the earbuds that I was using before this. I am very pleased with how nice the sound quality is. For my purposes, it's excellent! I saw my husband admiring these and I made sure to let him know that these are MINE! We'll see how that goes!

Sitting in a hotel room now... there is an iHome twin speaker/alarm clock/iPhone docking station on the night stand.  I compared the Altec with the iHome and the Altec is a better, fuller sound.  This is a good speaker and very nice to travel with.
Great headphones. I loved them. Totally happy with them. Sound is perfect. they are very confortable also. They look very stylish.

Works great for my Windows PC at work which doesn't have Bluetooth. I use it in conjunction with [[ASIN:B01M2ZOLLP FOCUSPOWER F10 Mini Bluetooth Earbud Smallest Wireless Invisible Headphone with 6 Hour Playtime Car Headset with Mic for iPhone and Android Smart Phones(One Pcs)]] and it transmits great. It's super tiny and unobtrusive. I have not used it for transmitting files, only music and video streaming.

You know those kids walking around with Air Pods, well, i have officially became that with these. I live in noise neighborhood(downtown seattle), so I do everything to get a decent sleep.

These are not noise canceling earbuds but they have good seal so it does block great amount of noise.

What about when you go outside and needs to be aware of surroundings? There's ambient mode which works like hearing aids.

Its not the loudest, but its enough. I guarantee you. I had Jay bird X4, and I ditched them for these. I had beats, which is louder but I love comfort of these.

Of battery life? Top notch. Since I got it, I haven't ran into situations where I'm music less. Of course I usually have my case charges and put my earbuds when not in use, but some says, I would have them in for at least 4 - 5 hours. I sometimes charge one earbud and use the other, so if one does run low on battery, I can just swap them out.

I got these on sale for under $30. Love them. but I admit I hesitate to expect a long, healthy life for them. They sound genuinely excellent (unbelievably good for the price!) and are actually very comfortable (love the fabric for the ear pieces), but the cord is super-thin and flimsy-feeling. Unless it is a lot stronger then it looks & feels, I fully expect to accidentally get up one day with it plugged into my PC and accidentally rip it out of the headphones (at this price point you do not get removeable cords). This cord is only about 1.5mm in diameter and does not inspire confidence. Cord length is fine for most uses, despite other reviews stating the contrary--it's shortish, but at about 5' it's fine for me--I use it either sitting stationary, or connected to a device I am holding or carrying in my pocket. If these headphones had a tougher/removable cord, I would be perfectly happy. Note: Sennheiser really does conquer all--these were $26 (I think) and sound better than anything else I have tried lately (including Beats--terrible), including many sets costing much, much more.

Traveling with kids- x1 always forgets, loses, damage or misplaces cord to charge their device- causing total crisis mode! Ha.. motherhood in the century of technology!! Luxtudes electronic travel case is a solution to allow ‚Äúone system to rule them all.‚Äù The hard exterior protects from damage to cords in transit. A layered design doubles internal space to hold ample items. We packed: wall butts, iPhone cords, x1 AirPod, x2 headphones, x2 battery boosts, speaker for x4 kiddos and myself!!!

Best yet, with roomy space the size is quite small and unpretentious, easy to slip into carry-on and TSA check no prob! The bonus.. as one‚Äôs batteries run low I‚Äôve got whatever needed at arms reach- in x1 place.. AmAziNg!! Interior elastic straps, pockets/pouches + movable walls hold content secure- keeping a ‚Äújack in the box‚Äù of tangle from popping out when opened! Reinforced handle lets you carry with confidence.. A total solution I‚Äôd recommend without hesitation. Hoping info helps decision- stay safe everyone.

I have an older (2009) BOSE SPEAKER. I needed to convert it to Bluetooth.
Ordered this. I simply plugged it in to the docking station, carefully! There are fragile pins to take care of.

This projector is just the one I've been looking for! All the functions are so compacted into this small projector, it is light weight (only 1.92KG) which allows me to bring it to different places for movie nights and the sound quality is so great that I do not need a external speaker!

For the attachment picture I used my phone to project and the pixel is still very high. This quality exceed my expectations. I purchased this product because my old projector broke and this is like a total upgrade for me.

Could not get this to work with my other speakers in the house and you know who I can‚Äôt say now because she‚Äôll be yelling. Yes can I help you? But you have to buy two of these to get stereo out of instead of using your existing, which is quite odd and I‚Äôm not spending $400 for speakers so in my opinion unless you‚Äôre rich and can afford two of these don‚Äôt buy them.

I needed this for my workshop in order to mount along my shelving unit allowing me to leave certain things plugged in all the time while still providing ample plugs for powered tools - it has ended up working very well.

I mounted this to my heavy duty steel shelving which was in the best location for me to utilize the plugs for my battery chargers and have the maximum mobility as I work with other power tools.

I have tested the surge protection claims and they check out - tripping exactly as they should. Often similar products will test accurately when new yet fail my tests at the 1 or 3 month mark but this unit has continued to pass every test.

The only thing I would prefer is if the power cord was 10 feet rather than 6 which would allow for more flexibility in placement.

After thoroughly testing my conclusion is this is really an outstanding product that I definitely recommend.

I love these headphones for late night television watching while my husband is asleep.
I can walk around and even leave the room while wearing them. This is the third pair of
headphones that I've owned now, although the others were more expensive. Both of the others developed sound problems and "stretched out", making it difficult to keep them on my head! This time I decided to buy an inexpensive, used (refurbished) pair, with the idea in mind that if I have the same problem with these, I'll just toss them out and buy another pair!

The trick with this antenna is not getting frustrated with moving it around and pointing it in the right direction. I mounted mine on the hand rail of my apartment balcony, second floor and now receive all local channels 4-68. Channel 68 being about 45 miles away. All are received in full green in windows media center, without using a preamp.

Previously I had it mounted under and bolted to the 3rd floor balcony to try and keep it out of sight. Reception was iffy on 4 favorite channels. I then moved it to its' present location with the idea that the antennas footprint is considerably smaller than all the satellite dishes mounted on balconies throughout the complex. The mounting bracket and pole that come with it, are the same type satellite dishes use, Very strong and versatile. You will need to buy some good bolts, I used 4, 5/16" x 1- 1/2" Galvanized Lag and flat washers, I predrilled 3/16" pilot holes first. I just thought I'd mention that for those not fastener savvy.

I would guess the antenna mount alone is worth 1/3rd of the entire antenna cost. Recommend a good quad shield coaxial cable with the thick, sollid copper wire. A shorter run is better if possible. I only have about 12 feet to my PC/TV.

Once I figured out how to mount this antenna correctly, a month ago, I haven't had to adjust it.

These were purchased for my elderly mother to use with her Kindle. Fantastic result, she can hear the audio book more clearly than with the other headphones I had for her. Really eliminates the outside noise so she can focus on her book.

I really enjoy my samsung tab2 7.  I watch a lot of videos, read a large amount of ebooks and also listen to audiobooks.  Its great outside, even in the sun.  I get a great deal of use out of it when I wake up during the night.  I can read a book without turning on the light and since I also got a very nice holder which rotates it makes it easy to watch videos or read in bed. Worth every penny!!  Its great when I just finish a book and can find more by the author and instantly buy it and have it on my galaxy or on my Iphone. I love this technology and it works great with amazons kindle ebooks and audiobooks.  If I am reading a book on one device it lets me know where I left off reading on the other device that is awesome!

I like this at least as much as the Performance MX, but it would have been nice if Logitech included support for its previous devices in the new software. Having software for my previous Logitech devices as well as the software for this seems unnecessary. They all use the same receiver.

I selected this keyboard/touchpad with the idea of using it with my tablet. Admittedly I mistakenly thought it was a Bluetooth keyboard which would have made it suitable for my tablet but this turned out to be a misunderstanding on my part. That said, it has proven to be a very handy keyboard in more ways than I had originally planned. In particular, in addition to working with Windows and Linux it works with Raspberry Pi which opens a whole world of possibilities for this keyboard.

This keyboard is very small, barely bigger than a Hershey bar, and it has a full set of keys as well a touchpad and mouse buttons on the right side. This is sufficient for doing pretty much everything you‚Äôd want to do, including surfing the web, text editing and software development. Granted, the size makes it less than ideal for some of these functions but it does work as a full keyboard/mouse combination if you want to use it that way.

Right out of the box, the switch was on and the keyboard had completely drained its battery so it had to be plugged in and charged overnight. This was a surprise but was not a big deal, just unusual.

When connected to a Windows 8 system the OS recognized it and immediately it was usable. It required no special drivers, no configuration changes or anything else ‚Äì just plug it in and turn it on. It worked the same under Linux as well.

The real test for this keyboard/mouse was on a Raspberry Pi system. The keyboard connected and worked without a glitch ‚Äì expected since it worked fine with Ubuntu Linux but not guaranteed as the kernel was known to work but the hardware was not yet tested. With a second external keyboard connected it was possible to type on both at the same time and also to use the other keyboard as a regular keyboard and the other just as a mouse.

There are a number of other SBC types and designs out there, and there is no reason that this device should not work with any of them that have a Linux-based kernel. Embedded Windows system should also support it as well.

Though I have not really tested the full range it is good to at least 10 feet. At that range the system still recognized input from the keyboard and touchpad without any issues.

So far I have found only one issue with this keyboard and that‚Äôs the space bar. I habitually press the space bar in the middle, and on this keyboard the press sensors are on the ends. The spacebar is not quite stiff enough and when pressed in the middle it bows instead of pressing down on the sensors, thereby not registering the press. To get it to recognize the press I have to press on the ends specifically. This is a minor irritant and is a very small price to pay for what this device offers.

This is a very small but fully functional keyboard/touchpad combination that works with multiple configurations. It connects easily and so far has given no real operational issues. Keep in mind that this thing is extremely small, though, which is great for portability, mobility and economy of space but less pleasant for systems that aren‚Äôt being transported anywhere.

Disclaimer: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at no cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.
Very happy with speaker quality & sound. They go up pretty loud & work in my office setting.
Does NOT FIT my Nuvi 660 as claimed. Rubber clamps do not fit my Nuvi as claimed.

We have Suddenlink cable, internet, and land line phone service and had been happy with our three year old router and their modem. Until we moved to a new house. The arris modem was dropping signal significantly every single day - we either had super slow or no connection for hours. I had the cable guys out here four times in 61 days to fix the problem. I was literally ready to just cancel Suddenlink and move to AT&T for internet, but decided to try this Nighthawk combo first.

It was spotted instantly by Suddenlink when I called to give them the new modem Mac address, so the connection was just a single phone call to start. No drama. I have 9 daily devices on WiFi and three TiVo receivers that connect via Ethernet or WiFi plus the land line phone. There's four Ethernet connections and two phone connections on the modem, plenty for our needs.

It's been almost three weeks and I've noticed an astonishing improvement in our initial connection and reliability. Rather than daily outages, we have had five total in three weeks and none lasted more than 15 to 20 minutes. Stability of the signal has improved and our speeds are double what they were with the arris modem - we're actually getting the high speed service we pay for. The router is also projecting the WiFi far enough that I no longer need to use a secondary extender to get WiFi by the pool and patio.

I like the Genie app with this. The ability to check channels, reboot the router if needed, and see which devices are online is very handy. I also like the clear, bright lights on the front. At a glance you know if there's a problem. Bottom line for me is that I haven't canceled our services from Suddenlink because this unit fixed 90% of our problem.

I use this cable with my [[ASIN:B0036B8A20 Kustom The Defender 5H Class A Guitar Amp Head]] and my [[ASIN:B004XFHWKE Kustom Defender 15 Watt Class A Guitar Head]], both of which I connect using this cable to [[ASIN:B0036B8A2K Kustom The Defender 1 x 12 Guitar Extension Cabinet for 5H Head]].

The CBI cables are well constructed (built like a tank, actually), and the 1/4" fittings mate perfectly with the amps and cabs. I am sure that the clear, clean signals I get from my amps are because of the exceptional construction of these cables, which appear to be engineered to provide optimum signals over a wide range of conditions. They are sufficiently heavy duty to meet the rigors of constant use, and are components that can make or break your sound. I highly recommend this model, especially for connecting amps to cabs.

Back in November 2015, I purchased this used AMD 1065T from M&D. I installed it a few days later (Nov. 7) and it had been working fine since that time until July 12, 2016. Then it failed suddenly, no BSOD, nothing. Hoping that it was my five year old power supply, I replaced that with a new one. No joy. Today, I replaced the 1065T from M&D with the 925 that I had replaced with the 1065T. My system started up with no problems, so it is definitely the case that the 1065T from M&D has failed.

I should say, given the nature of these devices, how they are used, etc. that I don't and didn't overclock this device. But given the sudden failure of this CPU, my bet is that a previous user did overclock it. My experience with AMD and Intel CPUs (all new) has been that properly installed and used, they don't fail. I did not expect that a used CPU would fail at 7 months of use.

I did not make use of Amazon's two year protection plan, more the fool I. M&D consider their posted policy of 30 days refund/return to be adequate customer service. You will not as I do not, when your used M&D CPU fails after a few months. Unfortunately, the used market is the only way you can get one of these CPUs, now. If you're not willing to kiss your money and effort goodbye in a few months, get Amazon's protection plan, because M&D will not help you at all after thirty days. Their response to my request for a replacement: "Are [sic] warranty is limited to 30 days." Genius!

My son likes creating music on his computer. He recently purchased $300 speakers to use with his computer specifically for making music. His desk is not very big, plus it's a standing one that goes up and down as needed. There's no room on his desk for his speakers and even if there was, he would worry that they would not be stable on the desk. These speaker stands are solving his dilemma. They're a nice quality and very durable. His speakers are little larger than the shelf on the stand, but it doesn't seem to be an issue. Assembly was easy. He decided not to thread the cables through the stand mainly because they wouldn't be long enough since they have to reach the back of the computer. These stands are working well for what he needed.

I was looking for wireless earbuds because I lost my last pair. This one was on sale, and the price is very good, so I decided to give it a try. I just received them yesterday. They work right out of the box. The sound quality is pretty nice with good bass. They easily paired and connected to my iPhone. But I prefer to connect one of them to my iPhone and one to the laptop or connect two earbuds independently to my iPhone. The only thing I don't like is that the left and right earbud show the same name on my iPhone -  S8. They should have used S8-L and S8-R, so I will know which one to connect/disconnect. It may be just my personal preference. It says the earbuds are with IPX8 waterproof, which protects earbuds from rain and sweat during sporting, running, jogging, swimming, shower, and yoga, etc., but not for diving. It is an excellent feature because most others are IPX5, but I haven't got a chance to test it yet.
It buckles instead of a clamp.. Is much better than the stock strap

Works with the IPad. The flash drive itself works very well and I like its compact size.  I gave the flash drive three stars because it is cumbersome to connect to the lightning connector of the IPad if the IPad is in a cover.  The lightning connection on the Drive needs to be a little longer.  You have to remember that the flash drive has to be charged up to use it with the IPad. The IPad battery seems to deplete a lot quicker when using the flash drive. Just discovered there is a limit on the size of a PDF document you can open with the SanDisk software. The audio playback quality is good.  The unit can be convenient to use to transfer documents between an IPad and a computer rather than using other software.  I could see where it would be useful for a student.

If you cut the cable cord your previous provider will most likely not want the dish itself. This unit has a clamp that will probably work on the old post. No new holes to drill in the roof, assemble it, pop it on the existing post, connect the coax cable that already runs from the roof location to your tv and voila.. I believe my OTA antennae picture is even better than the one I used to get from my satellite dish. I do miss the ability to record right now but for the savings of over $800 I can live with it. Any suggestions for recording OTA programs are welcomed.

Sometimes, old school wired earbuds work pretty darn good. For the price, these work great. These are the type I would give to kids, being they will break them in some manner. My grandkids went through so many pairs of earbuds. When you can get your hands on ones that are not very expensive, that work well and they will use, it is a win win

Another rare five-star review. I have the full size Echo which I got when they were offered fot $99 to Prime members only. I have preached the virtues and benefits of an Echo since the day I received it. I was finally able to talk my mom into a Dot the other day. Normally she's got her television blasting to help her sleep and I worried about the Dot's smaller speaker not being loud enough. It's been a week and though there's been some learning curve she hasn't once had the TV on and she's sleeping better. Extremely glad I was able to talk her into a Dot. It's loud enough for her, she's only had to skip a few songs that were too soft. I'm glad she got it and she loves it.

I've had this model for several years, and I lost it 2 weeks ago. I a world of personal music (MP3) I find this small radio is still my favorite source. If for nothing else instant information. I has great sound long battery life and you can plug in external speakers.
This little radio (and a couple of AAA batteries) is what got me through 2 weeks of no power during Hurricane Sandy. Worth the investment.

I use these cables for connecting MP3 devices and such, and also for connecting my Razr cellphone, using the Motorola Phone Tools software on my computer. (Note that for the latter purpose, you can actually use Bluetooth if you want to, and have the capability on your computer.)

Cable works perfectly, no problems or hassles. Construction quality is good. This is pretty basic technology after all.

Over All these headphones are a good deal for the $. However don't expect anything but mediocre quality with the sound quality which because distorted and then corrects itself. Thus seems to happen if watching a movie with a lot of sound affects. The fit is good. Better than those cheap buds that are constantly falling out of the ear. But again, for the low $ it is an overall good set of headphones. Worth mentioning that the packaging was nothing more than a plastic sack. I thought that odd for a brand like Sony.
Bought this on a whim and use it all the time.  Great speaker for such a low price.  Very loud too.

This is a VERY cool device.  Packaged with the antenna variety pack provides out-the-box reception across a broad range of frequencies supported by this software defined receiver.  Following the quick start instructions on the rtl-sdr blog web site, I was up and running with a Windows 10 laptop in under 10 minutes.  I played with the thing for an hour straight!  So many neat features, and I've only scratched the surface with lots more to learn.  Great for visualization and spotting frequencies with signals, much faster than scanning for frequencies on my handy-talkie.  Great for beginners (no HAM license required since it's receive only, no transmit) and great for licensed HAMs looking to broaden their view across a wider world of RF.

I personally do not like the trend of airpods/earbuds, I find them to be uncomfortable. So I am glad that some companies are still making quality standard headphones, with wireless.
EASY TO CONNECT - my phone and computer found the device, labelled "B12" in bluetooth and had no issues connecting it up.
SOUND QUALITY - sound is great, with rich full bass. The noise cancelling works almost too well, as my daughter was using them and could not hear a thing I was saying
COMFORT - solid design, comfortable, does not pinch

Great headphones, would buy again!

I had these speakers installed into the rear doors powered by the ct sounds 120x4 amp. I also had a pair of Meso 5.25 originally for the back doors and they also blow the surround then started that irritating rattling sound. I can't do the work myself because I had back surgery recently after being send back home from overseas serving this nation. . I can't be bending and twisting BUT I need my sound. I know the plandemic has lowered the attitudes of a lot of workers and that could be the reason for the lowered or POOR quality. I do need this item replaced as soon as possible. I NEED MY SOUND ct!

I had Bose in my Audi S8 but I ripped that trash out of my car. I wanted a clear up grade. I originally wanted a full ct sounds system in my S8 with 2 12""EXO 2ohm Subwoofers and the amps reccommended for powering them I was thinking it would be the TEAM 7K.1 but they're nowhere to be found. I just didn't want to put a lot mix of different brands in my S8. I do have my AudioControl units for sound processing though.

I also have my Audi Allroad and I was gonna put a similar system in that too. I've been waiting on CT Sounds to catch up on orders for the EXO & TEAM products.

Bad Call Quality
Call quality is not good at all on these Samsung headphones. Other party barely can hear you. I wouldn't recommend it if you are trying to use it for making phone calls. My regular headphones which came with my S7 phone work much better for phone calls. The reason I bought these so I could use it's noise cancellation along with calling feature. Because I am a frequent flyer and fly every other week. But Its active noise cancellation feature is just OK but not really worth the price.

This must be assembled from a handful of smaller pieces.. reviewing instructions and using common sense will help a lot. I DO suggest the buddy system when setting up for sure- it makes the process so much easier! It also ensures being careful not to crease the screen.. Just note- sizes may not sound big when ordering but, I was surprised just how big 120 size screen really was!!! (Maths never been my strong point- so maybe this was just me.. but a quick size reference before ordering will give you some real time idea!)

Used indoors- we didn‚Äôt need water weights.. but have if/when necessary. Not sure how easy they‚Äôll be to use if using on a camp out‚Ä¶ Water can be sparse- I‚Äôd probably weight down with sandbag or cinder block?

If following instructions it‚Äôs a bit contradicting to state‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúDo not fold or roll screen.‚Äù To store in the provided carry bag- The only way to fit the screen in is to roll..?? Carefully doing so, we blindly followed and hoping it won‚Äôt cause any issues- I wish it provided more clarity in this department!

As for screen itself.. just be sure to eliminate any light source from behind it since it can offset the picture from projector light on front side. Doing this gives a solid image‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs awesome! Used at our teen sons bday party with group of friends- we set up big screen in our game room and all had a solid view of movie marathon- zero complaints.. a huge node from a picky crowd!

Overall, as our 1st screen purchase.. it was so much better then using the wall or a sheet tacked up like we have! You cant believe how much it enhances the picture. I do wish screen protection was better and a few less pieces to build (capable for younger crowd to set up..) Otherwise, it‚Äôs ideal. Wouldn‚Äôt hesitate to recommend- hoping info can help your decision.. stay safe everyone.

First thank you for your product!!  It worked..it made our Visio tv Bluetooth compatible with our soundbar and subwoofer!!!  So excited they all work together.  I struggled with different online support places and couldn't get the TV to work with my subwoofer...finally I found your product. The whole issue was my Visio tv was not Bluetooth until I bought your product and I even kissed it when it all paired together...it was like. FINALLY.. THANK you for making this product to create happiness in my life!!

I use them with an iPhone 7 plus

Music sound is fantastic with deep bass.
Super comfortable , they do not hurt at all and stay put.

Now for Bluetooth calls, it seems that only the right ear works. It does not bother me.

Love them.
Not pleased with the volume level as this speaker is not loud nor has booming bass like the description said

This is a very good quality smart surge protector. It has a great mix of features for the price.

Pluses
1. Outlets are widely spaced for large wall "wart" power adapters
2. Smart outlets can be remotely controlled through the app (iOS & Android)
3. Voice assistant compatible
4. USB-A ports allow for additional device charging
5. No "hub" required to use remotely

Minuses
1. Only 6 outlets
2. 2.4 GHz Wi-FI means you need to enable the 2.4 GHz radio on your Wi-Fi router/access point in order to connect to the surge protector remotely
3. USB ports only go up to 5 amps (no fast charging)
4. Only rated to 600 joules, on the low end of surge protection

You can use this surge protector without enabling the smart capabilities. However, once you download the app to your device and connect to the 2.4 GHz radio of your Wi-Fi router/access point, pairing to the device
is pretty straightforward. Using the app is easy and allows for some pretty cool programmming, such as timers to turn on & off the outlets. I haven't tried out the voice assistant capabilities, but I'm assuming they work
as intended.

This is the second of this type of device that I have purchased. I have one at work, now one at home. They make my life so much easier. Before I bought the first one I didn't realize how much frustration and time I was wasting plugging and unplugging peripherals. Now everything is all in one spot, and I don't have to search for anything. I even have my wireless phone charger plugged into it both at home and at work.
I have connected to it my wireless mouse,my wireless charging pad, my headphones, my external storage that has my music on it.( I do take back and forth to work). Also the black and white braided cable is my iPad. I've not had any issues with connectivity. I've also used the VGA connector during meetings for educational purposes.

This is a terrific monitor that is going to make my work day a lot easier. First of all at 27 inches it is huge. I included a picture to show you how much bigger the monitor is than a typical laptop screen. Also, the monitor does not have the glare that is created by my laptop screen. It's like the difference between a matte finish and a glossy finish on a paperback. The glossy finish starts to tire your eyes at the end of the day, and the matte finish keeps you fresh. I'm finding I don't have to take as many eye breaks with this new monitor.

Installation is easy. The stand is solid and goes together without any tools. The TV also locks into the stand with no tools and has both a vertical and a tilt adjustment. There is a set of control keys along the side that allow you to make adjustments to the picture. I turned down the brightness to try to match the screen of my laptop. It came with a VGA cable, an audio cable, and a power cable. There is a HDMI plug in the back, but no HDMI cable was included with the purchase price.

Note that you have to use the button on the side of the monitor to turn it on, not the switch located next to the power cable. This is a very nice monitor.

When my much more expensive Bluetooth on-ear headphones broke I was a bit frustrated and decided to go back to something cheaper. As expected, this product is less comfortable and clearly uses cheaper materials and construction, but I can't really complain given the price. The sound quality is fine as far as I can tell. The battery life is decent but noticeably shorter than my previous headphones. Also, the low battery warning is a very annoying loud series of beeps that repeats periodically until you charge it. So if you just want to listen for 5 more minutes or get through the last couple of minutes of that video and then charge it, well too bad, because the beeps are going to annoy the **** out of you until you charge it. Also, the pictures in the instructions were not clear to me at all, and it took me a while to find the charging port (you have to tilt one of the earphones to reveal the port which is otherwise hidden behind the headband).

Also, unlike my previous headphones, this one does not work well with my tablet's media volume sync (when the headphones are turned on they always revert to a default volume, they don't remember the last volume used), so I had to turn sync off to avoid constantly having to recalibrate the volume of the headset relative to the tablet.

I've only had the August EP650 for a couple days now, and there are a number of quality, comprehensive reviews -- so I thought I would write something specifically from the perspective of someone who hasn't owned a stereo Bluetooth headset since they first came out.

The tech has come a long way, and I'm really quite pleased by how good these are for the price. If you're like me and have a bad recollection of the early days -- with the flaky connectivity and the terrible, tinny sound -- you'll be pleasantly surprised.

Build quality feels pretty decent for the price; comfortable; buttons are easy to find with the headset on, and I've been putting them on while taking public transit, without playing anything, just so I can concentrate on reading, and not the prattle.

So, thumbs up. If you've not been happy with Bluetooth cans in the past and don't want to spend too much to check them out again, the August EP650 is a very good option.

What a difference.  I did not have a slot for a network card.  I had previously bought a usb network adapter but was not receiving a good reception for my wireless.  I bought this product and all I can say is that I am one happy camper.  I am not dropping off the internet anymore and I can see more network broadcasts from the frequency I have now.  Very impressed at this item.  And the price was right to boot!

My teenager loves it, uses it for online gaming. He had it for few months now. His friend bought a much more expensive headphones which already gone bad, these still last and quality is good. He is very happy.
really nice case. great protection for my bluetooth headset. love the color and feel.  Love the caribiner  clip cuz I can clip it to my bag strap and not have to waste space inside the bag. love it.

Looks like I have the privilege of being the first person to review the BA M25 speakers. I picked up a pair of these on Christmas Eve and have been playing them constantly over the past 2 weeks. My focus has been on 2 channel stereo recordings instead of movies. My set up is through an older Denon AVR 610 receiver that I have had for almost 20 years. I was initially impressed with the smooth, balanced feel of these speakers. Good mid range, nice high end, but not too bright, and a very strong bass response. The M25s defy their size in producing bass tones. Give them some break in time before making a final assessment. These speakers excel at producing music performed on real instruments. The do a great job on jazz, blues and acoustic folk styles of music. Vocals come across nicely as well.
Boz Scaggs "But Beautiful" CD of standards sounds great. Upright bass, piano and vocals make you feel like you are in a small jazz club. Diana Krall "Live in Paris" also plays very well. Nice piano, guitar & vocal reproduction. Jorma Kaukonen's "Blue Country Heart" CD showcases some great finger style acoustic guitar. Very natural acoustic guitar tones. Linda Ronstadt's "Winter Light" CD has some of the most powerful vocals you will ever hear and the M25s reproduce Linda's voice and backing instrumentation extremely well. The sound is never strained or harsh. Initially, I was a bit more apprehensive on some CDs with lots of bass. They sounded like they were trying to overcompensate on bass, but this has evened out over the past week. Eric Clapton's "Pilgrim" CD has come serious bottom end and the M25s produce very deep, tight bass response. Peter Gabriel "So" is a similar story. Deep, tight bass response that does not bottom out. Paul Rogers "Muddy Waters Blues" is a treat on the M25s. The opening track features some acoustic delta blues guitar, followed by a chorus of female backup singers and later some nice Strat blues guitar tones. It all sounds great on these speakers.
The look and finish on the speakers is impressive also. They are finished in a polished black exterior with a leatherette finish on the top, back & bottom. They look like a piece of fine furniture that would fit into a modern style of home d√©cor. These speakers are very expensive though. I got a demo pair at less than half of the $399 per speaker list price. I don't think I would have bought them at full price. I have been listening to Boston Acoustics speakers for over 20 years. I still own a pair of A60s and a pair of A120s that have served me well over the years. The M25s have replaced the A120s as my primary speakers in my living room due to their sonic capabilities and their stylistic good looks.

Update 6/24/14 - After listening to these speakers for 6 months, I continue to be even more impressed by the Boston M25s. I bought these thinking they will do until I can find better. While there are better speakers out there, I have concluded, after many demo sessions, that I would need to spend at least $1500-$1800 or more to get some form of improvement over the M25s. Short of stepping up to KEF R300 @ $1800, B&W CM5 @ $1500 or Aperion Verus Towers, the M25s deliver the goods with very balanced & neutral sound, great detail in the upper register and sold bass. Highly recommended.

This case is NOT what I expected. Packaging was horrible to begin with. Upon opening the plastic bag was beat up and all the Silica gel beads that keeps dampness away was all busted. I had to rush to the trash can to prevent beads from falling onto the ground where my pets walk.

Now to the case... THE MOST P.O.S. case I have ever seen or felt!!!! Once you get past the manufacture packaging it comes out all flimsy and oversized!! I placed the latest Samsung Note 10.1 into it. The expandable teeny cords hold the device in but the cover is what makes it freaking flimsy. It's the part that is way oversized and over laps my device and does not even come close to auto- shut off. The cover is so overly sized ( way too much room between device and cover) that even the magnetic closure does not work or doesn't line up. I should also note that they must have used a very cheap magnet because it does not "lock on" to front cover.

All I can say is that if you hold the device by hand the cover dangles pretty bad. In addition to my complaint the cover is also used as the part to help your device stand hands free. But... upon laying the cover down and setting it up, you can see the cardboard bend down and not flat on the surface. Perhaps a tougher cardboard and proper dimension sizing for devices would work much better.

For the price...use your money towards a stronger cover/case that offers the same features. I do NOT recommend this.

This great radio picks up AM and FM stations with clear bright sound. There is a separate National Weather Service station. It runs on regular AA batteries or you can generate power for it by turning a crank. It doesn't take many turns to make it work.

There is a flashlight with bright steady light, or several flashing patterns to summon help. A metal loop on the side allows you to attach it to a belt or backpack with a carabiner or strap. It's made of lightweight but sturdy plastic. There's a power output and a socket for a headphone.

In an emergency, batteries may well run down. Electricity may fail, but you will usually be able to turn a simple crank to keep in touch with news and weather.

I found Bose's latest wireless headphones to be a fairly serious disappointment, which was surprising and frustrating after having bought 5 or 6 pairs of headphones over the years, along with speakers and a Wave Radio. I *like* Bose products.

Let me start with the positive, to be fair.

1. They sound great.
2. They stay in my ears. (A feature Apple did not think to include with their glorious AirPods.)
3. The Bose connect app on the iPhone is slick and useful.

The negatives.

1. They are very big and jut from my ears in a way that looks comical. I've seen other people compare them to the bolts on Frankenstein's neck, but for the ears. Actually, though, it's worse than that, because their weight makes them droop. So I'd describe the look as more Frankenstein Eeyore. If you have hair that covers your ears, you will probably be ok. But I am close to bald, so I can't really wear them in public. Since I bought them to wear during my workouts at LA Fitness and while coding at work, the fact that they make me look silly is a show stopper.

2. Given the look issues, I'd love to wear them when I listen to music on my computer at home, but they don't pair properly with Windows 10. They have a voice profile and a music profile. No matter how I fiddle with my PC, based on advice from the various threads on Bose's support forums, I cannot get the music profile to activate. The reason this is a problem is that the voice profile only plays music in one ear, and at far reduced quality. Like it's-being-piped-to-your-ear-through-Satan's-toilet quality. Bose's suppport forums have various threads about this, and it's clear that some part of Bose's software group either doesn't get it or is trying to avoid publicly stating that they can't fix the problem. They claim it is Windows or software differences on various PCs, but my Apple AirPods work fine as do Bose's SoundSport Wireless headphones (though they lack a mic, so the scenario is somewhat different).

3. I wish there was a way to hear audio in both ears while making calls. You can do this with the AirPods.

First the disclaimer that I got this in the Vine program. That being said, I always try to be fair, honest and objective in my reviews. That being said, I am a little disappointed in this Sharp system. As the ad specified this was good for small spaces, I set it up in my bedroom (as I have a 32" Samsung flatscreen there with no additional sound support). Here are the pros: Set up was not difficult (although it did take me close to an hour to do by myself with the instructions). Sound is clear, bass tones are adjustable and I found the overall quality sufficient for a small/medium sized room. Here are the cons: First, as another reviewer has written, the fan in the bass unit is audible. Make sure you set it somewhere further enough away from where you are sitting or you will be distracted (regardless of how loud you set the speaker) by the hum. The other thing I wish Sharp would have done is make this a wireless device. I think this is why it took me so long to set it up trying to hide/wind the wires inside the carpeting so as not to be seen. To me, wireless is the way to go particularly with a sound system. I actually had bought another unit for a set up in my den http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004MME6S4/ref=wms_ohs_product which is a Panasonic. Cost half the price of this unit and I honestly prefer it over the Sharp. Shop around, this is overpriced for what you can get elsewhere.
Great little speaker with great sound!

[[VIDEOID:331807d8d8d087a6f9d617912336adb7]] I ordered this ‚ÄòDeity V-Mic D3 Pro High SNR Super-Cardioid Directional Shotgun Microphone with Rycote Shockmount for DSLRs, Camcorders, Smartphones, Tablets, Handy Recorders, LaptopÔºåBodypack Transmitters, Wind Shield‚Äô for review.
Let me start by saying that I have never owned an external camera mic as I never really had much use for one until recently, so I don‚Äôt have anything to compare this one too other than the on board built-in mic from my Canon 60D. When I first received the D3 Pro I was totally blown away by what looked, and felt like a quality device. The included hard case is really nice (see attached images) as is the included Deadcat or Wind Muff, although it is a bit tricky to install as it fits so snug. The difference between the onboard built-in mic and the D3 Pro is like night and day (see attached sound check video). In the video I state that I have the ‚ÄúVolume‚Äù on the mic set to 4 and it‚Äôs actually called the ‚ÄúGain‚Äù control which was actually set to 5. Even in the slightly breezy conditions during the outside test I did not use the LCF or Low-Cut Filter, which can reduce light wind noise. The Mic has LCF settings for 75Hz, 150Hz and Off. The D3 Pro also has a built in rechargeable battery via the USB C port on the side which is nice and much appreciated. I don‚Äôt want to carry around extra batteries and these days I much prefer USB C charging on newer devices. I can‚Äôt really report on the battery life as of yet, because I have only done a few short video sessions and have yet charged it since the initial full charge once I got it.
Overall I am really impressed with this D3 Pro and feel like this has absolute value for the price and I highly recommend it.

Edit 11-20-2018

Mobile app iOS,

I noticed as some others have that I was unable to see a camera remotely yesterday. I had previously setup and tested the app with just 3 cameras. Nothing would bring the new cameras into view. Well almost nothing, I removed the app from the phone and reinstalled it, now all cameras are showing remotely.

Original :
I was a low voltage installer in years gone by and this brought back memories of why I no longer like crawling in attics at this age. Seriously though the unit is superb. Its not that bad of an install, its just me hating crawling in attics after having done it for so many years.

It came packaged really well. I was surprised at how well it was protected. We purchased the 16 channel NVR for future expandability. I put cameras all over the place. They are arranged to keep track of important areas as you would expect. The image is great. Better than I had hoped for.

The cables are not really internet ready, each cable only has 4 wires in it. I would rather have had a fully functional cable.
Upon taking the DVR out of the box, there was a small rattle inside, more of a piece of plastic moving around. Like a broken tab during assemble.

Installation activities.

The cables also a little short for larger homes, though they do sell longer versions. In most of my use cases the cables were fine. It's just 3 were all the way across the home in a far corner. I could have used another 10'.
So, I simple ran my own cable and terminated the ends. No big deal for me. However if you think you'll have enough and your getting close in your estimation, you better have one or two longer ones. The 60' cables seem to be a standard in the security camera kits.

The cable protector/environmental protection covers are a little large, not overly so. Just notating it here for others. You'll need to make sure you have extra room behind the camera. Most people will not see this issue. Make sure and use a drill bit big enough for the protector to pass though if it will be placed inside a wall, or overhang etc. You are not just drilling a hole for the cable. Look at the camera and you'll see the size you need to make it. I also ended up needing a longer HDMI cable, the one that came with this was about 6' I needed a 10' due to my particular situation. Not a mfg. fault, just my use case. So this one went into the spare bin and one in a 10/12' came out.

The first day, I needed to arrange things in my AV closet, and add a plugin. You may wish to have a licensed electrician preform this, if it's needed.

We started about 1 pm and finished about 7 putting in the NVR, 3 cameras, pulling 3 new wires, terminating those wires. The second day we started at 9 am and finished at 8 PM, with the remaining cameras. Though we had some extremely challenging placements this day. Your install time may or may not be this long, or it could possibly be longer.

Use :

As to the cameras they work really well, I was surprised at how well the picture looks and the microphone, well its as another user put it almost too good. You can go into settings and turn down the volume., Make sure you do that for cameras that are internal, aka in the house. If you using a monitor it may not be necessary that much. But ours is piped into the living room tv, and the kids or I, leave the volume up. You'll clearly know it when you switch over to the camera system and click on the camera.

Notes:

For anyone looking for answers here its also a good bet to look at the Swann forums. There are some good topics from other users there as well. Especially for users who may be asking more technical or unique issues. For anyone looking at this I would suggest also looking at some youtube videos there are a few that go over some of the options in the NVR settings. Like setting recording limits etc. Motion detection and so forth.

End results / Opinion:

I am more than pleased with my purchase, it far lives up to my desires. I wish I had bit the bullet and done this earlier on. Like years ago, but oh well its up now and I am more than happy. It's a little large purchase, money wise. But I personally think it was well worth the money at least for us.

This replaced a wireless competitor and its leaps and bounds above it.

I like having a pair of wired headphones in the house, nice to not worry about having to charge your headphones. I was purposely looking for headphones that are more flat on the outer part, so it makes it a little more comfortable to sleep with, and also use with multiple devices. Not expecting much in the way of sound, often the wired headphones have more treble and are usually good for audiobooks, or voice, more than music. I hooked these up with an adapter for a couple of different tablets, phone, and laptop. They sounded different on different devices, makes sense, so my phone, wow awesome bass, in a wired headphone? Okay, cool, and on my tablets with turning off my equalizer, the sound was crisp and clear and still had some bass, but great too for podcasts. I like how snug these fit in the ear, but I changed out the little plastic ear covers for some others I have, and I have to say, that snug fit makes them much better with more noise being filtered out. The longer cord is good too. So surprised how good these sound, and for the price, good deal.

Except for the long connecting wire, these headphones work well in the gym. You need to wrap the long wire, and tape it, then keep in your gym shorts while exercising. After that, they work well. They do not get smelly or loose quality if worn frequently in the gym. And, the light weight design works well with any exercise. As for use as a studio headphone, maybe not so great. They keep out noise, but due to their design, do not have enough padding to keep out high level noise. Again, at the gym, that is good, so your buddy can get your attention.

My rating would be a two star if used by somebody serious in the music industry. For my use, it has worked just fine in the gym (except for the cable wire being too long.)

I tried with a couple of USB-C phones and the output was great on my car's aux input. I like that it's a single cable with a male on both ends, so no adapter to go from a headphone jack to an aux cord, this is all-in-one, nice and clean.
It's still not quite as nice as the Quad-DAC you'd get from something like LG's headphone jack, but these days you don't have much of a choice on a modern handset anymore.

I read the reviews on this speaker and they were spot on
Great speaker and great price. I'm going to purchase another one for a better sound effect.

I love my Echo Dot. It is quick to respond and sounds great. BUT there is one MAJOR drawback...it must be plugged in
, there is NO battery backup! So if you use Echo Dot as your alarm clock (for example) and the power goes out, be prepared to be late for work. Also, there is nothing on it to indicate that the power is out so you won't find out until you go to use it. The sound quality is great and it's extremely useful when plugged in but it's not as portable or reliable as it obviously could be.
Works with any computer with the mini-displayport (modern Macs, Microsoft Surface Pro, Lenovo Carbon X1 etc.). Transmits video and audio via HDMI.
Good headphones for my tween son. He likes them. Says they fit well and are comfortable to wear. Now if he can just keep up with them!
Relatively inexpensive.  My preferred model of "running" headphones.

I did a LOT of research before purchasing this little speaker. My needs were pretty simple: I wanted a wireless speaker that could connect with either my iPhone or iPad to use on the nightstand. I like to play music before I go to sleep, so it needed to be small, but have great sound.

Based on the reviews here, I finally decided on this one, and I'm happy to say it's PERFECT!

It charged quickly connected to my MacBook Pro -- about 2 hrs, maybe a little less. Turned it on, turned on the iPhone, went to the "Settings" on the phone, found Bluetooth, and there was the JAM XT. Selected it, and voila! they paired. Entire set-up took about 10 seconds.

I listen to a lot of classical music, so my first "test" was the Brahms "A German Requiem" -- lots of highs, lows, soft, loud, etc. Strings, voices, woodwinds, brass -- it's all in there. I listened carefully for distortion -- everything was set on "medium" volume -- and I'm happy to say I heard NO distortion at all. Everything sounded great -- nearly as good as my Bose system, but without the bass resonance.

OK, so I haven't had this very long (about a week), so its durability remains to be seen. But I'm impressed with the quality and style of this. If I notice any issues, I'll update this review.

Meanwhile, I can now fall asleep to great sounding music from a small-footprint speaker. And that's exactly what I wanted.

We had some trouble finding a radio that can be used for our 2008 Honda Fit, we just wanted to add USB, a clock and bluetooth and tried out 2 before we found this one. The issue is, once you remove the factory radio, the clock is gone as well, so the radio had to be customizeable to show a clock too. This was almost the hardest part, find a radio that does show the clock if you want to, so for the price, it is a awesome model.

It is easy to install thanks to multiple videos online and the functionality is pretty decent. This is not an orignal factory radio, so they had to cram in a lot of items into a small space. How to make a bluetooth call requires pressing 3 buttons to make one call (while you are driving), but it works great. We are very happy!

Like almost everything about this. I have to Alexa's in the apartment and having a similar "companion" in the car is perfect!

I only wish I could name it differently (my oldest is Alexa and the youngest in Echo). The App doesn't allow to change the name or what to call it like it does for the other in-home Alexas.

I have an older Audi and the audio is via cable. But the actual integration is via bluetooth with the phone. My phone can also connect to the car-phone via bluetooth and this unit is clever enough to know when to let the phone part connect directly to the car and when to switch to Aux audio.

Good product for the money. Works as it should. I think a clamp would make something like this more versatile as there were places I wanted to use it but because of the type of attachment it didn‚Äôt not work. Overall though, a good product.
Great idea to keep headphones tangle free! I also really like that it doesn‚Äôt take up a lot of space in my purse or add extra weight!

Just purchased LG monitor 29UM68-P on Amazon.com

Three major issues. At the end of the day I have to return this broken monitor.

1. Built-in speakers do not work.
2. Drivers from supplied CD cannot be installed, error message appears "No INF file found in the current directory" after clicking on the CD's setup.exe file.
3. Vertical green line on the screen cannot be removed.

Going to the LG's website[...]

After I found my model on the LG website :

29" Class 21:9 UltraWide¬Æ Full HD IPS LED Monitor (29" Diagonal) 29UM68-P

and click on it, nothing happens. No page with drivers opens.

I called LG support and all I hear was the answering machine.

I have to return this monitor since the green line is a hardware damage. We tried different golden plated HDMI cables and nothing worked. Greed line is showing up without any computer attached, as soon as monitor is powered up. This is really a bad piece of hardware. Now I have to pack it back to its box and go through the hassle of returning it after several days of troubleshooting and installation and my credit card being billed. Wow.

Pros
Sound quality is good for a Bluetooth headset. Could use a bit more bass but is not a deal breaker. Great with pandora music. Pretty impressed.
The headphones fit over my ears and were comfortable to wear for an extended period of time.
Paired with my iPhone 5 without issue (iOS 7 Beta 2).
These are not noise canceling headphones. I have the Bose QC3s and I would not expect the AE2w Bluetooth headset to perform as well on an airplane. But does drown out our air conditioner!
What is really awesome is I can walk away from my iPad and still hear my music, for quite a distance!
Comes with a cloth carrying sack.

Cons
Having a phone conversation with these headphones was a bit odd as both ears are covered which means that your own speech is a bit muffled making for an strange sensation while talking. I prefer the Bose BT2 for taking phone calls.
Includes a micro USB cable for charging but does not include a wall charger. People have so many chargers these days this is not really a big deal but I thought I would mention it.

I received this as a free review sample five months ago and have been using it for around four months. This is a rear view monitor only - not a dashcam - and it works far better than one of the combination rear monitors/dashcams that I have also used.

Since there are a large number of reviews that cover this in detail I am going to keep mine brief. Here is the single thing I do not like about it: the terrible documentation. On the other hand you can have this professionally installed for not a lot of money, which is the route that I took. If you are a do-it-yourselfer installing it right is less than an hour job (according to the tech who installed mine).

What I love is the clear visual behind me. The camera works in dark and low light, and the display has sufficient clarity and resolution to easily see what is behind you and estimate distances. If you were to purchase this as an option on a vehicle I shudder to think of the cost, but for less than one hundred fifty bucks professionally installed this is a bargain. And if you do install it yourself you can knock a C-note off that cost.

If you parallel park frequently this is a perfect way to make that easier. For rural driving this may not be a needed accessory, but for city use it's a convenience (and a safety feature as well.) Do note the information in the product specs too because they are clear about what this will and will not work with.

The color is beautiful. They seem to be made well. I purchased these to replace my Apple iphone earbuds, which I did not like. I had to keep adjusting them all the time. These are really good and stay in place with nice sound. So far so good!

Blows away all my bluetooth speakers. Wow this thinh rocks the neighborhood. Have used it for BBQ, at the park, playing basketball, while working on the yard and it doesn't miss a beat. Get it and never need another Bluetooth speaker seriously.

My family uses a lot of backpacks. We use them for travel, storage, camping, hiking, and transporting a lot of things wherever we need to go. Let's see how this one measures up..

WHAT IS THIS LIKE?
This backpack looks like a pair of jeans. It is black canvas with contrast stitching that is beige. It has a lot of tacking stitches and reinforcement stitching on it.

CAPACITY
This has great pockets and storage. It expands a lot to hold many things. The inside back has padding to keep things from poking through to the back. The main compartment is large enough to hold a LOT of books or other things. It has a small zipper compartment to hold keys, change, cards, etc.

FRONT POCKETS/COMPARTMENTS
The front compartments are very nice and large. The first one is quite deep and will hold small notebooks, pads, and other smaller things- but it is fairly deep so it will hold a lot.

The next front compartment has a pleated angled pocket which will hold quite a bit too. There is a small zipper compartment above that (all of these on the outside easily accessed) that holds small items and will even hold a phone.

SIDES
The sides have elastic pockets on them which will hold bottled water or other things you might need to stick in there.

LOOPS
There is a band of loops which you can use to put things through or hook them to.

SIDE BANDS
There are bands on the side which are adjustable that you can use to pull in the backpack if it is not full so it does not stick out so far.

SHOULDER STRAPS
The shoulder straps are padded and comfortable.

WAIST STRAP
The waist strap has pockets on each side which are shaped like fanny packs. They zip shut and hold many things too.

ROLL STRAPS
At the top of the shoulder straps are two straps that are adjustable that you can use to put a bedroll or other similar object. We have also used it for a tripod for camera.

ZIPPER QUALITY
The zippers on this are very nice quality and heavy duty looking.

WATER REPELLANT?
This seems water repellant, but I have not had it out in a pouring rain storm yet, so I can not report on that kind of water. It would not hurt to spray this with water proof spray like you get for camping equipment just to be safe.

OVER ALL PERFORMANCE
Whoever designed this, really thought it out well. I am VERY impressed with the way it is set up and how it works when on my back. We all like this one and it gets a lot of use.

THE BOTTOM LINE
Well designed and thought out, this backpack will give a lot of storage room if you need it, or you can adjust it for lighter loads too. For camping or urban journeys, this is very versatile. I am VERY impressed with it.

MY RATING
FIVE STARS. One of the nicest out there and very well set up. I am impressed with this one.
