I gave five stars for a reason I didn't just gave it for a fun first thing first it will definitely amplify any headphone with nice pudgier sound to it second reason would be that I also use this for my car audio system I don't know how but it will also make your car audio system sound good I don't know how does it do but the sound just becomes very good and third reason would be that I also use this with any portable iPod speaker system if your system isn't loud enough this little thing will makers it louder with distrotion free sound and all I'm saying is that you could not just use this with only the headphones but whole lot of other things you could use this little thing I have no idea why people gave only 1 star because this amplifier rocks and one more thing I only paid like $7.50 and I know you can't beat that!!

These were basic earbuds. They worked fine for the price. I could hear them ok. They were not as adjustable as they could've been. They are small and easy to carry. Convenient for a plane or somewhere you don't have a lot of space.Overall a decent buy.

The sound from this tiny speaker will surprise you. It is AMAZING! It's real loud and very clear. I have a Doss also and this one has much better sound & costs approx 25 % less $. I can also use my microphone on my phone while this speaker is on. You don't get that with all speakers. It charges quickly and the battery lasts about four hours before you need to charge it again. I carry this thing with me everywhere because I love to have my music with me all the time. This fits my needs perfectly!
My on off switch broke after four months and the seller replaced it and paid for my shipping.
This company is stellarüåü

I'm hard to please when it comes to wireless earbuds.  I've got a dozen or so mostly samsung and a couple of random purchases.  But anker's battery life blows them all away.  My phone's microphone is not functioning well, so I use ear buds pretty constantly.  I would have to charge the other ones daily, sometimes more than once.  With these I'm charging the case about once a week and the buds about once a day.  And they are usb-c, so that helps immensely with travel and only having to bring one type of charger with me. I was a little nervous about getting a renewed pair, but these have been perfect.

Most of my experience with Logitech products has been with keyboards and mice, though the company has made products in other segments as well, such as video surveillance systems and Modula-2 compilers. This is the first set of Logitech speakers I have tried and used, and I was expecting them to be a solid mid-range offering. They‚Äôve proven to be better than that.

These speakers are not very large, about as big around as the lid on a container of oatmeal. They‚Äôre heavy, though, and in addition to the main speaker they have a bass subwoofer on each. They feel very solid and should hold up under some abuse shy of being dropped on a concrete surface.

My first test was to connect them to my phone via Bluetooth. I plugged them in, turned them on and they immediately started broadcasting their ID. My phone immediately saw them and I was able to pair and connect them without any issue at all. Based on my experience there, the Bluetooth connectivity is excellent. I later tried to connect them to my computer by the audio cable ‚Äì simple and easy as should be expected.

The main question when using a set of speakers ‚Äì how do they sound? In a word: excellent. The bass response is solid but not overdriven, the midrange is warm and has good depth, and the highs are sharp and clear without being shrill. I was expecting a more subdued sound profile, but Logitech did a good job with getting these to sound great. I would stop short of calling these audiophile quality, but the large majority of users should be happy.

I bumped up the volume and tried to get these to distort and I was unsuccessful. They remained clear even through the full volume range. I set them in the kitchen, turned up the volume and went to the basement as I was still able to hear the sound clearly ‚Äì through the ceiling.

I do have speakers that sound better by a little bit, but they cost three times as much and they‚Äôre quite a bit larger. Considering the price point and the size of these speakers, these are much better than one could realistically expect.

Update:Replacement speaker works perfect. Battery last all day at work, sounds good for 15$.  I like this little thing. It can take falls at 3 feet...  First one didn't want to connect via bluetooth or shut down after a few secs after connection.

The JABRA STEALTH BLUETOOTH HEADSET guide is titled "Getting Started in Under 5 Minutes"--and the guide does not lie. The basic setup took me less than 5 minutes, even though I had zero prior experience using a Bluetooth headset paired with a cellphone. And in under 15 minutes, I had voice dialing activated (a feature that depends on your phone), so that I could use the headset to place and end calls with voice commands transmitted to my phone (a Samsung Galaxy S4).

My Jabra Stealth headset seemed to need a brief charge (a USB/MicroB cable is included) prior to accomplishing a Bluetooth pairing. However, I may not have been pressing the Answer/End phone call button correctly at first, to activate pairing--the "button" is actually a long silver piece with mic holes, that moves up and down when you press the "Jabra" marking. Once the flashing Bluetooth indicator light appeared, my phone found the Jabra headset immediately, paired with it, and connected. I can also use NFC to quickly connect my phone with the headset.

The headset charges completely in about two hours, which gives you about six hours of talk time. Once it's even partially charged, a pleasant female voice announces how much talk time is available when you turn the headset on. The headset is so lightweight, it's barely noticeable when you're wearing it. You do want to experiment a little with the included selection of ear gels and ear hooks, to find the one that fits your ear most comfortably. You can wear this headset in either the right or left ear.

I would recommend visiting the Jabra Stealth web site, to watch a short instructional video, look over the FAQs, and download the Jabra Stealth User Manual (a .pdf file). The .pdf manual is slightly more complete than the Getting Started guide, and has an additional section on "Handling Multiple Calls" (you can place a call on hold). The FAQs tell you how to set up the Jabra Stealth headset to work with two different mobile devices (but only one device will be able to use voice-activated dialing).

I like this headset a lot, and plan to use it for answering calls handsfree when I'm driving. The sound quality is very good. You have to use the volume controls on your mobile phone, because there are none on the headset itself, but I'm happy enough with that tradeoff in return for such a small, lightweight headset.

I already have a Bose system (worth about $1500) that I use in my living room. I was looking for a system for use in my family room with a new 3D television I had bought around Super Bowl time. I got the Sony BDV-N7100W system and I can honestly say that at about a third of the price of the Bose, the Sony excels with sound quality. I love the wireless speakers and have them spread out over about a 25 ft. area. The sound is incredible with strong lows and highs. The 3D Blu-ray player is also flawless in quality and completes my home theater system to a T. My teenage sons absolutely love this system and are spending more time now in the family room than the living room (solely for the reason on using the Sony). For the price, this Sony system can not be beat. The quality is wonderful, it's attractive and compact. Not a bad thing to say about the system, go for it.

Let's get one thing straight right away: THESE ARE NOT SUNGLASSES. They are blue-light blocking at best, or just mildly tinted most likely. I took them out of the box and thought "Oh cool! These are the kinds of glasses that get dark outside and transparent when you are inside!", but nope- I wore them for a full hour outside and they didn't get any darker or exhibit any sun blocking properties AT ALL. So that's false advertising right there. They aren't for use in the sun. They don't darken anything.
As far as audio quality... they are a cool concept, but again, falls short of expectations. The open ear design means the speakers have to work harder to be audible. That means they often make those tin-sounding rattles that tiny speakers make when cranked up too high. This is definitely NOT cool for music as most of the fidelity is lost right off the bat, and adding insult to injury is that they often don't get loud enough to use outside. I'm not saying using it in a crowded subway terminal (that you can just forget about completely), I'm talking about even just going for a stroll around my suburban block with some birds chirping and the wind blowing lightly, maybe a car driving in the distance. I tried listening to a recorded lecture (since music was a lost cause), and they couldn't get loud enough to hear clearly. The microphone for calls was OK in my test, so I guess they are cool as a way to take a phone call without wearing a headset, but that only works if you're wearing these anyway as sunglasses. They aren't sunglasses, so you wouldn't be wearing them anyway, and you wouldn't be wearing them for music, and you wouldn't be wearing them to make a phone call either because they rarely get loud enough unless you are home alone... in which case you can put your phone on speaker and avoid this whole mess.
In conclusion- its a good idea but executed poorly and does NOT live up to expectations. I'm surprised there are so many good reviews on this product. I can't think of a time I would use it.

This is a good usb hub. It is compact, so naturally it is a bit difficult to add more devices. It has an external power supply which seems totally optional, but I suppose it depends of how many devices you are plugging in and their power consumption. It has front and rear ports, which is good if you are hooking up communication devices like a Bluetooth USB, mobile hotspot USB or wireless mouse USB flash drive. You should put as much distance between these devices as possible.
Small, compact, easy simple setup. Quality speakers with BIG sound. Expect nothing less from Logitech.

I just received this iPad Min 4 and I love it. You can tell right away that it's lighter than my iPad Mini 3 and the sound is much better in this iPad Mini than my iPad Mini 3 because with my iPad Mini 3 I would have to use either speakers or headphones but I don't have to use them with this iPad Mini, I mean the sound isn't going to blow you away or anything but it's pretty good for this size tablet. It's really fast, which I love and I was just watching videos on Youtube and the picture was so beautiful, very vibrant colors. Now my iPad Mini 3 has a beautiful picture but to me the iPad Mini 4 beats out the 3. So i'm very happy with my purchase, I think the iPad Mini 4 is just perfect.
Bluetooth did not work.

I was so happy to get these headphones and today I used it on my first conference but my mic didnt work correctly at all. I should have gotten the regular ones without the mic. But I cant return it now because I threw the box out.

$22 down the drain. I can't believe that. Just get the ones without the mic.

I finally took this bluetooth for my car out of the package and tried it out in the car.  It's a hit.  Since I have no intention on buying a new car and my satellite radio stopped getting satellite, i decided to give this a try before going and replacing the radio with a new unit.  I'm so glad that I did.  It works perfectly without any feedback whatsoever while using my phone to play music, books, or talk on the phone.  Now i can save that extra $300 that I was about to spend on a new radio system for a bill.  This will be perfect for my next road trip since i can use the apps on my phone to listen to books and satellite radio during the drive.

We have replaced several of these for the same issue. It just recently started happening to us, though. The audio and video will not sync up properly. So we hear something, but it is not in time with the video. So we either hear their voice and then the mouth moves, or the mouth moves and then we hear the voice. We have tried to sync them manually following instructions given by the support team and what we found online. It isn't perfect, but it is better. After a little while, it is VERY noticeable again. It is not limited to one application, either. We have seen it happen on Prime Video and YouTube TV. I have not had these issues using our Smart TVs. Since it works fine on Smart TVs, and since it is not just one application, the FireStick TV Stick 4k is the last remaining culprit.

When we used Hulu+, it would just kick us out or lag forever. Did not have as many issues with that when I used either a Smart TV or my PS4. Just a horrible product. I am going to try to get Rokus for my other TVs and see if that helps at all.

I did not use Alexa or voice commands very often, so I do not have a large sample size, but it seems to work fairly well for those types of functions.

This is a very sturdy unit and the keyboard is great for typing.
My main complaint is you can not use speakers with this keyboard that do not have a volume control.
For some weird design reason, the Audio Line Out on this dock is not controlled by the iPad volume control, or the keyboard volume arrows. But the keyboard Mute arrow works - go figure!
Now my iHome portable speakers are worthless as they don't have a volume control.

[[VIDEOID:727b79be559d6bc8023b267becc505bd]] I bought this for my husband who against my wishes LOL loves to sing in the shower. And he's always trying to prop his phone up on the sink so for Christmas I came across this and so far it works really well lol. Very easy to set up it took a second to hook to his phone through Bluetooth and it was very easy to charge. So far it sticks to the wall and the sound quality is pretty darn good.

I have 2 JBL and an LG portable Bluetooth speaker and this was too large for any of them. One of the JBLs was barely long enough to be held by the straps but I didn't feel confident in how secure it was. The other 2 were just 2 short. I didn't think they were small speakers but apparently they are too small for this Mount

It's small, smaller than I expected. The remote is small, light, and easy to handle. Picture quality is outstanding, as you would expect. The voice search feature works beautifully, and as of now has recognized perfectly everything I've said to it. Very nicely done, Amazon.

The out-of-box presentation is elegant. You have to connect the power adaptor, and the HDMI cable to your TV. (That means, your HDTV.) You have to put the 2 batteries (included) into the remote, and then turn it on. Configure it for your WiFi Internet connection, and you're good to go. Amazon has already thoughtfully registered the device to your Amazon account, so there's absolutely no additional setup necessary.

Why only 4 stars, and not 5? Well, the Roku gets 5 stars because of the many dozens of additional channel options with the Roku. However, all your favorites are here on the Amazon Fire, including Netflix, Hulu, Pandora, for example.

Should you get the Roku vs. the Amazon Fire? You'll probably be happy with either, especially if you don't think you would bother with all the additional channels available with Roku. For the usual things, the two are essentially identical. If you need a wired Ethernet network connection, there is a Roku model with that, and the Amazon Fire (like many other boxes) uses only WiFi. However, the Amazon has the nifty voice search feature, which is a clear improvement over Roku. (And I've been a Roku fan since it first came out.)
Noise cancellation is very poor and sometimes hurts my ears. However, for regular headphone use they are surprisingly good for the money. The battery life is exceptionally stellar.

OK, so I waited awhile before purchasing my first pair of earbuds. I finally decided I needed the so that I could watch videos/etc. while sitting in public spaces (coffee shops, libraries, etc.) without disturbing anyone.

Bear in mind that I'm 71 yrs old and although I spent my career in IT, I was a SOFTWARE person, not hardware. So anything hardware related is always a bit intimidating for me.

These were relatively easy to set up. Pairing with my iPad and iPhone was a breeze. They seem to hold a charge quite nicely. The noise canceling feature is wonderful! Very happy with that.

I'm a classical musician, so I'm kind of picky when it comes to speaker sound, and I experimented these earbuds using a variety of my favorite classical hits. The sound I'm getting is excellent -- a bit surprising as I wasn't expecting it to be as good as it is.

No problems so far -- highly recommended!

This adjustable tablet holder is fairly straightforward. With the clamps manually extended, then slid into position, the holding is reasonably easy to use. When clamped into place, it does seem to hold the tablet firmly. I was attempting to use it with my kindle (including its cover) and the extra thickness of the cover didnt seem to be a problem.

This has a 5/8 inch mount that will screw directly onto a mic stand, which is how I intend to use it. It also comes with a clamp to allow clamping it onto the shaft (allowing a mic to still be mounted at the top). So I wanted to try that... it turns out, even using that clamping system, the whole thing was held firmly in place! Impressive!

I'd definitely recommend this tablet mount... my plan is to use it in front of my elliptical machine for workouts.

Awesome headphones!! My son is autistic and hates certain noises. He uses these headphones ALL the time. I have been through over 50 pairs of headphones and ear muffs. He loves these and they are durable and work fantasticly. I highly recommend. It's a great product for the price.

My desk gets crowded with the bulky 10-port USB hub I had been using so when this review sample arrived I was immediately pleased with the size. It is the perfect complement to my ThinkPad T61 which comes with three USB ports to begin with.

I will not repeat the exceptionally helpful review that Daisy S posted on February 11, 2014 - she thoroughly tested the specs and gave some pointers for also using this via the OTG interface on tablets. This also works on any OTG-capable phone using her approach because I tested it on my Galaxy Note 3.

A big plus is this not only works with USB 3.0 interfaces, but is backward compatible to earlier versions of the USB spec, including 1.0. That means that I can use this on my legacy devices around the house, as well as my newer 'toys'.

The final thing that I like about this hub is the construction. The manufacturer did not cut corners on cable gauge and the small details like strain relief, precision made connectors and other areas that cheaper brands do. The quality is there and this does work as advertised.

Navigating on a pc screen requires a mouse of some sort. They have come a long way over the years, with more features and more comfort. One that is great for those who like to add a little color to their navigation is this wireless mouse from PEIOUS.

Shaped for your hands, this mouse is comfortable to hold and click. It‚Äôs easy enough to use and you can‚Äôt feel any strain on your hands, so it earns good marks there. But the feature that is most appealing is the lights. You can change the lights to different modes and even shut them off completely, if you prefer. I like that the lights are soft- you notice them, but they are not so bright that they distract from what you are doing.

The bluetooth works okay on this mouse and one of the more unusual features is that you have to plug it in to charge. With most others I have used, you need to supply batteries, but this one charges by plugging it into a usb outlet. It‚Äôs nice not to have to buy batteries, but it also means you need to have a usb nearby for charging purposes. I consider this feature a plus, as I hate having to search for batteries when the need arises.

To conserve power with this mouse, there is a switch to shut it off. Plus, it will automatically shut off, to preserve power, if there is no movement for several minutes. This is good because, with regular use, you will need to recharge this more than you realize and saving power makes a difference.

Computers need a means for navigation and that requires a mouse of one type or another. You could go for the boring, ordinary mouse with buttons to click and nothing more, or you could have a little fun and get this wireless mouse from PEIOUS. I vote for the latter. It might only be a mouse, but the lights and the elimination of batteries make this a standout mouse and one I recommend.

Long story short, my review sample was immediately recognized by my Samsung Galaxy Note 3 phone when I plugged the dongle into one of the ports on my [[ASIN:B00KMKKJWW Unitek USB 3.0 hub 4 port Bus-Powered OTG hub]]. It was also immediately recognized and functional on my ThinkPad T61 running XP.

As great as it is, you need to pay attention to details when unpacking it. Specifically, the cardboard insert in the retail packaging has a web site for the manual. That is important because this thing will make no sense to you without it, unless you have used one of these before. The manual you will want to download is for model KP-810-10.

Basically, the dongle is cleverly stored in the body of the keyboard, and the key is to find the small power switch, which is on the upper left side. After that you are literally up and running. While this makes a wonderful remote for a PC doing presentations, it's even handier connected to any android phone or device that recognizes an OTG connection. That is where this thing excels. However, for Windows PCs this is also optimum because it has Windows keys.

If you need a remote for a Windows PC, or want a convenient way to interact with your OTG-capable phone or tablet this may well become your best friend. I can actually get real work done using this and my Note 3 phone. That is why I gave it five solid stars.

I work in a middle school special needs classroom. We have 2 autistic boys in the room who spend their daily computer time watching movie clips from various children's movies and TV shows. They usually watch the same clip over and over and over. It gets really annoying and loud with 2 different soundtracks going on simultaneously. They were using ear buds when watching their clips, but those broke before the holidays. After a week of no headphones, I decided to order these for them. I actually ordered 3 pairs, one for each of our classroom computers. These aren't super high quality headphones, but they are working great for our students. Yes, it would be wonderful if we had some of those nice, padded, over the ear earphones, but we don't. Since these were purchased with my own money, this was what was in my budget. I'm not sure I would order these for myself, but for the students, they do the job!
These are great headphones. The price was just right. Very easy to pair with my phone, laptop, and iPad! I bought 3 pairs because I liked them so much!
A mediocre MP3 unit. Not that intuitive to use or to load music on to it. Sound is better than expected for a unit in this price range, particularly when paired with good headphones.

Overall, for a low cost over the ear earphone, these are very impressive! I've purchased and returned several in the 30-$100 range. All with major issues w/ bluetooth, sound quality, and overall quality.

If you are used to $200+ noise cancelling earphones, these are not in the same caliber, but are one of the best pair I've found that are under $200.

Pros: Easy to connect to bluetooth,
Long range of bluetooth (able to walk about 40-60 feet away, and outside of the house). (This was comparable to my AKG $300 pair).
Looks are nice
Quality of materials (while plastic) seem durable
Size of ear piece is much lager than most, and fits well over my ear! Better than the AKG's and other's I've tried.
Fast charge, and long battery life.

Cons:
Not noise cancelling. Things are quiet, but I prefer to hear a little road noise when I'm walking. (so for me this is a plus).

Overall, I think these are a great option, and are thinking about getting a second pair.

I received this as a review sample and have been using it for a little less than a week. At the time of this review this tablet is shipping with Android 4.4.4. Before I dive into what I like and why I rated it so highly I want to set expectations.

This DOES NOT come with bluetooth, and the screen and cameras are not especially spectacular. The screen is readable (easily so) and has nice, vivid colors. However compared to even my Note 3 phone it falls short. As the cameras, for some reason tablet makers seem to skimp on those as though they are an afterthought.

Since there is no bluetooth you are stuck with the internal speaker or using phones. The internal speaker is not what I would call optimum for listening to music, but the included phones are surprisingly decent. I also connected one of my bluetooth speakers that accepts 3.5mm input and the sound was excellent, so while this does not have bluetooth, you can still stream music to it.

Another thing it does not have is bloatware that every other tablet (and phone) seems to be plagued with. That is one of the reasons why I rated this so highly. But the real reason why I gave this tablet five stars is price. At the time of this review it is selling for sixty bucks, which is not a bad deal for an entry level tablet - especially if you want to browse the web, stream music or wile away the day on facebook.

It is a complete package that includes a stylus, soft bag, charger and cable, and OTG adapter. The latter allows you to connect USB peripherals to the micro USB charging port. I tested it with a keyboard, then a mouse and it recognized both. The USB charging port is another thing I like - it;s a micro USB type, which is a major improvement over some entry level tablets that I have tested that use a non-standard barrel connector.

You can add a 32GB SD card using a TF adapter. I tested it with an old SanDisk Ultra 32GB MicroSDHC Class 10 UHS Memory Card that was immediately recognized. The application manager allows you to move some apps to the SD card, so as you add your favorites some will be eligible for running off an external card (depending on the app, of course.) Browsing the web, using Google's location feature and maps, and Youtube all performed with no lag or issues. In fact I would put the performance head-to-head against my Verizon Ellipsis 7 4G LTE Tablet, Black 7-Inch 8GB tablet. Do note, though, that if you have all services turned on and are constantly using this tablet you are going to get about 2.5 to 3 hours of use time if you are not connected to a charger. For some folks that may be a deal breaker, so take that into account.

Basically this is a stripped down, but very functional tablet for folks on a budget. If you can live without bluetooth and will be using it near a power source it's a decent tool (or toy, depending on your outlook) at an affordable price, It is a perfect first tablet for someone who also has an Android phone, and is definitely useful for folks addicted to the web.

I bought it for use with my tv. We have a smart tc with terrible speakers. Well, more like the sound is terrible with some apps, like Netflix or Amazon Prime- where the volume is sometimes not able to go up enough to really hear it, and I have sound sensitive ears. So I bought this thinking that it could lend a boost to the sound. I was able to get it to work with the cable, and the DVD player (the two areas that really don't need help), but could not get it to function with the tv itself. I tried all options, and I am either missing something or it just doesn't work with the tv. So while that issue *may* be on my end alone, I will just rate it on the actual sound.

The sound it produces is definitely a boost over what I am used to with the tv speakers. It doesn't have a dynamic sound, but it isn't flat either. Not directional, more in the front sound. Clean though. I think it would be better for use with a phone, tablet, or even lap top- where you just need some clean volume. It is long, but it is sleek. It can be controlled from the unit, or with the remote. The remote is uncomplicated and makes sense it its layout.

So while it ultimately isn't working (right now) for MY purpose (I aim to figure it out), it is a nice speaker, at a decent price point (I wouldn't got higher), and the options it provides is nice. Normally I go into mega detail on items like this, but there are already plenty of reviews that go over the specs nicely. So in short,

-Long charge
-Easy blue tooth connectivity
-Comes with connectors
-comes with remote for volume, power, and switching between outputs
-easy to follow short instruction pamphlet
-TF card option
-USB
-AC adapter
-built in microphone (which I haven't used, and have no intention of using)
--slim, sleek design
--has great volume capacity, not super dynamic- but different ears will pick up different sounds. I am attuned to nuances, so I can tell that this speaker doesn't go there.. BUT I still recommend it, overall.

I figure out anything else, or if I get it working for my needs, I will be back to update. I hope my little bit helped, even if it was just reinforcing the more detailed reviews. Take care, and enjoy your day :)

EDIT!!! Perfection!! OK, so I took one more try at trying to get the sound to work with Netflix & Prime. I was watching Captain America last night, and could barely hear it despite the volume turned way up. I realized that the last time I had tried to use this speaker for that, I may have had the tv volume down and of course it wouldn't pick up on sound. For cable, you want volume on tv down as it is running through cable box and you the sound to only come through this speaker. For roku, etc, you would just plug it into the headphone slot, and hence want the volume up. The addition of the speaker totally amplifies the sound AND it did a great job with the sound nuances of the movie. It didn't just add volume, it enhanced the overall sound. SO this really impressed me and I knew I had to come back to update my review. I already liked the speaker at 4 stars, but now I am really happy to have this in my life. It makes ALL the difference in our program watching as we typically use Netflix and Prime daily and it is frustrating that the volume is greatly reduced. Now it is better than ever. The sound is large and fills the room, and I can hear various other tones and bass within the movie- so I guess it depends on the source not just the speaker..

PLEASE PLEASE, do not buy these cameras and the doorbell. I did not listen. Now I am not going to use a lot of big words to describe the problem. I am just going to tell you the truth. I am 70 years old and I purchased these cameras because I live alone and I wanted security. I am not secure and I do not feel secure. I purchased due to all the advertisements and because Shaq endorsed them. They do not work and the customer service really sucks. One day I was put on hold for 45 minutes then hung up on. The supervisors are no help at all. I purchased 3 floodlight cameras and 1 doorbell camera. They all are malfunctioning. The doorbell does not alert until the person is long gone. What is the purpose if the incident is over before you can even see it. Then you cannot even pull the incident up for about 4-5 minutes! You have to wait to see who was at your door and that's not safe. in 4-5 minutes someone could already be in your house!! I have horrible neighbors who are interfering with one of the floodlight cameras and literally making it go off every 1-3 minutes. I've called ring over 52 times since October of 2019. They cannot or will not resolve the issue, other than tell me the camera cannot be tampered with. I KNOW THAT IS NOT CORRECT! If you buy these cameras buy at your own risk. I am here to tell you that they do not work and customer service will not help you when they fail and they will fail!!!! Shame on you Shaq O' Neal. Shame on you Amazon for buying and selling this mess !!!!!!!  On my last recent call to Ring I was told that the cameras do not work in real time. The representatives say whatever they want to try and get you to hang up. I'm 70 not senile. Someone named Richmond told me that! The commercials show the people walking up, you activating the sound and talking to the person. One of My problems is the people are already gone before the camera actually activates. I would look into buying something else if I could afford it. You have a choice. DO NOT BUY RING. Do not be tricked like I was.

Compared to the Duracell Inverter we have, the quality of the battery hookups is a bit cheaper and thinner. However, this little inverter is adequate for the job of recharging ipods and cell phones. Although this unit says you have up to 175 watts, that is peak power. Consistent wattage is 130 so you want to be sure that what you have to use on this needs to be consistent with the 130 wattage instead. I would not go above that, as 175 is PEAK.

The unit is easy to use, you can plug it into the cigarette lighter in the car and it provides power to the USB port for easy recharging. There is a little fan on it and a light to indicates that it is working. I also tested out the battery usage, and it is great to use for campsites, or other areas where you might need to have a way to run simple 130 watt (or near it) electrical units or recharging of cell phones, etc.

The packaging was great- quick open and easy to get to. No struggling with plastic packages that are frustrating, etc.

This is a great simple inverter to have on hand for recharging of various USB friendly components. It worked quickly and efficiently.

Comparing any headphone to Sony Studio, the sound quality-- stage, stereo separation, loudness, instrument separation, instrument tone, bass response, surround channel -- fails to measure up, or even come close. By far better than Sennheiser which makes grand pianos sound tinny, this set has undesirable elements at the far reaches of either side that don't appear on Sony. Not a fan of the 'V'.

The sound is fine. It's what I would expect from quality tweeters and a reasonable size woofer with a decent driver. It does not compare to a decent set of bookshelf type monitors like the JBL LSR series but the price is far lower so I guess they're ok for PC speakers.

But the excellence ends at the sound. The speakers do not have an analog signal input from the computer (there is one at the puck for a MP3 player or whatever). Instead, the signal comes via USB. The problem is the speakers do not come with any drivers. Bose assumes you have the drivers already on your Windows installation. That's a very bad assumption as many people do not have the drivers (just do a google search on Bose Companion 5 drivers to see). There's no help from Bose here. The drivers cannot be downloaded from their web site. I called Bose's tech support and after half and hour they were not able to solve the problem. I eventually solved the problem myself on my Windows 7 Pro 64-bit install but I think it's terribly lame that Bose cannot provide the driver for their product. If I wasn't using the pre-load install of Windows they assume everyone uses, then I would be screwed.

So exactly what do I get for this odd USB input in lieu of a standard audio input? Nothing except incompatibility and the inability to use the speakers apart from a full blown PC. The audio quality and features are not improved by USB audio input. Period.

Room mode correction should be a straightforward feaure on speakers like these. It is not. Although my sound card supports it, the Bose speakers do not have the DSP to do it independently. The lack of sound-card independent RMC doesn't justify the high cost of these speakers. If it were included, the price would look a little better.

I installed the Companion 5 system on an Ergotron cart. The two speakers fit perfectly under the monitor the way I wanted (I removed the stands). The acoustimass is bulkier than I would have liked but I think it's fair to say a smaller module would not perform as well and for most under-desk installs it would be fine. What I do think it's fair to complain about is the poor design of the acoustimass module case. Despite being very heavy, it features a plastic rear end-cap that is fragile. Come-on. For the price, give me painted steel not brittle plastic. The case is also oddly shaped with curves that prevent anything but a bottom-down mount position. The case is not designed to be mounted in a down-firing position, up-firing or on it's side or upside down. The case is also not equipped or rated to be flown or ceiling mounted (it could fall apart and drop parts on people below). Bose should know these are all viable positions. Not everyone can have this thing on the floor with like six wires running out for people to trip over -- seriously, that is totally not acceptable in a public space.

Bose has a habit of not publishing Watts RMS specifications for their amplifiers or speaker handling abilities. I sort of understand not wanting to confuse consumers who don't understand driver efficiencies, but at least give us some max. 1 meter SPL's so we have some clue how loud these things are. As it is, the Companion 5 is loud enough for a PC system in a fairly live medium-sized residential room. It's much louder than my Wave system which proved way more anemic than it was made out to be. The Wave is useless except in the smallest bedroom. I use the Companion 5 primarily in my kitchen (on the Ergotron cart). The kitchen is fairly live but has some acoustic paneling to tame some of the reverberations. If I were putting this system in a small classroom, I would think twice. As a PC system for someone who sits right in front of it, it's obviously perfectly good. I probably wouldn't even use it at half-volume sitting that close.

Keyboard is not too bad...unfortunately, keys have a habit of becoming stuck sometimes, and certain combinations of keys don't work properly...for example, pressing two keys together like CTRL and Win don't work...

I've heard about these foam tips for quite some time, but staved off as the gel ones that came with my [[ASIN:B000FUESSU V-MODA Bass Freq Earbuds (Bling Bling Black)]] worked just fine. The bass is great, and the gel bud tips enhance the sound even further.

Nevertheless, I decided to order these just to see what the fuss was about. Many other reviewers seem to give them great reviews, so I, what with me being a bass freak, decided to give them a whirl.
At first they're excellent, and fit extremely comfortable. After a few wears, though, they seem to lose their greatness and tightness. HOWEVER, and this is a big however, they once again expand to perfectly fit the inside of my ear. Not sure how that happened, but they went back to how they first fit, but even more comfortably.

If that's not the case for everyone, and the foam tips just collapse with time, then I'd say avoid these. BUT because with my experience they retained their fit inside my ear, and were indeed customized over time to fit perfectly, then I tout these to the extreme. Just go to the product page and make sure they fit your earbud headphones. They're a bit pricey, yes, so not necessary if what you have works fine; they just provide more comfort and enhance the bass for me.

I liked this little USB Microphone, ZAFFIRO Computer Microphone Plug Play Studio PC Microphone. It was good that it was so small and just took up a little room. It seemed to work okay. The quality was fine. It was very easy to use. It worked fine. We had no problems and I would recommend it.

Make sure to search these based on what laptop you have. Mine is a MacBook Air and it fits perfectly. I keep a standard (thin) notebook in there, and a few pens in the front pocket. Can‚Äôt fit much more, but it seems to be durable and high quality. Great zipper & fabric. Exactly what I expected.  Reasonably priced. Happy camper here!

I damaged my audio jacks and needed a replacement for my laptop.  Rather than spend $1,000+ for a new laptop, I bought this.  It works fine and produces good sound quality.  It should work with other devices with a suitable USB port.
When placed in the case and it's closed, it squishes the headphones. Not my favorite part of it but it does what it's suppose to do!

The case itself seemed pretty sturdy and like it would hold up, but the speakers were really muffled and did not get good sound. I enjoy my music and need my speakers to sound good. I returned it and looking for another case.

It‚Äôs so big, takes up a lot of room. Does connect easy, doesn‚Äôt go in and out of the slot very nice though for plugging in.
Sound quality is out of your speakers & not the device.

Just a phenomenal cpu. This is probably the best upgrade Ive done, coming from an i7 7700k. I had 30 days to use and figure out if I wanted to stay with this or go with the latest AMD cpu.

Work- I used to have trouble running programs that were either too complex or inefficiently coded that it led to stutters, hitches, delays or freezes. One program that always caused massive trouble for me over the years was the Think or Swim trading platform. I originally upgraded to the i7 7700k and it could not handle more than 2-3 chart at a time running the time and sales and L2. Run some side charts and you could forget about trading, especially at the open when calculations need to be run at an extremely rapid pace. I even added a total of 32gb ddr4 3400 ram and it still wouldnt run properly. Arguably, the program is encoded really inefficiently requiring much more from the CPU than necessary. Ive tried many different trading programs and this one caused the most trouble. After stepping up to the i9 9900k I can now run this inefficiently encoded program on my main chart screen, with two different tickers having 4 different time frames each with its own L2 and time and sales, PLUS 15 side charts without a hitch! Also im running my browser with at least 5 tabs open and video/audio running. Absolutely amazing. I never thought I could get it to work like this.

Gaming- even if the cpu doesnt run at 100 pct it affects the quality of the experience of the gameplay, especially for demanding games, or just poorly coded, inefficient ones. RPGs fall into these categories. I.e., Kingdom Come Deliverance. Video and streaming is flawless as well.

Vs AMD- Performance isnt always about raw numbers, if there are too many peaks and valleys, it affects the quality of the experience. I havent personally compared it directly to the newest AMD cpu, but having looked at the side by side comparisons, AMD cpu seems to put out better numbers for work-related applications, but clearly on the gaming side, intel is superior. From my observation, the quality of the experience with Intel was greater because the frame rate was consistent with much less, if any micro stuttering, which you can see with the AMD chips. As a result, Intel's presentation was more effortless and smooth. With the AMD setup, you can see some graying/discoloring/hazy effects in demanding scenes. It seems like AMD is an overcharged chip that experiences these dips because of that, causing a deterioration in the experience. AMD is perfectly fine for work I presume, but not for me when it comes to gaming. Intel performs like a more refined, polished product. This is just based on my personal observation of their performance in these two different areas.

Overclocking- its perfectly fine using it the way it is. No need to overclock, but of course you can overclock it. I run mine 16 hours a day without any problems. Top recommendation at the asking price these days.

I have tested many earbuds that range in price from $10 to over $100, and I must say these sound very decent in this price range and better than some that cost twice as much. They are very bass-midrange centric, but the sound clarity is superb, and they have not distorted at the loudest volume I could stand. I heard instrumental detail I would not have expected in a pair of $25 earbuds. I thought the heavier bass and midrange would seem unbalanced and bothersome, but it wasn't after listening to a range of music for a few hours. I haven't tried them on phone calls yet, but if the music sounds this clean and clear, I am sure my phone calls will as well. I will update my review if it doesn't live up to my expectations. So far I like these earbuds a lot and highly recommend them.

THE GOOD:
--------------
* Bottle is an ample 16.9 oz.
* High quality microfiber cloth included.
* 2 types of spray nozzles included.
* Some robot stickers... good to give to the kids I guess. LOL!

THE BAD:
-----------
* Nothing at all. A pretty impressive kit that I started using immediately. Been seeing some smudges on my screen. I've seen these smudges for over 500 reviews now. LOL! Yes, I can be lazy. But now that this bottle is on my desk, those smudges are gone. 5-Stars.

I have the grey TrackR Pixel and I am using it on our spare garage door opener. It's the opener we give to houseguests to use while they are here and on more than one occasion, it's gotten misplaced. Hopefully, this TrackR will cut down on aggravation of hunting down the opener n the future.

Once you load the TrackR app on your phone, it gives you pairing instructions via Bluetooth and you're ready to go. You have to allow the location permission in the app for this to work. There's a large button to press for location of the TrackR and you can make some small customization of the alert sound.

Actual use is a bit limited. My TrackR can't be found or alerted once I get more than roughly, twenty feet away from it. If you know your misplaced item is in a specific area this might not be a problem. However, if you have it on a key and dropped it without realizing it, you may be in trouble. The crowd source search option might work well in a large city, but in our small town, there aren't going to be many folks using these gadgets....much less within twenty feet of a dropped garage door opener out in the wild. For my needs this will work fine though.

This little BT amp is better than my high-end 50 pound amp from 20 years ago. Makes my studio headphones and IEMs sound as good or better than my dedicated headphone amp. AND it's portable. Battery life is not as good as claimed, but good enough for everything else it does very well. The newest version of software is easy to use for recreational listeners and audiophiles, reliable, detailed, and provides explanations that are very informative and interesting. Also glad to find fine tuning of left and right volume controls since my IEM and maybe my ears differ by a half decibel in sensitivity (helps to recenter and open the stage).

Pros:

1. It's a Bose
2. Relatively easy to set up even for a non-technical person
3. As would be expected, great sound
4. I didn't expect the ear buds to be comfortable with that funny looking rubbery plastic thingy that fits into your outer ear, but I was wrong (using the smallest size - it comes with three sizes) Plus, they don't fall out of your ears if you make sudden movements.
5. Control for volume and the audio jack are on the same speaker, so easily kept within reach
6. Sleek modern look
7. Not designed for noise reduction, so you can still be aware of what's going on around you.

Cons:

1. No "off" position - the volume can only be turned down, but not off
2. Speakers are a little on the large side if you're limited for space on your desk - just over 7" tall, 3" wide and just about 6" deep
3. Ear bud case is nice, padded and zippered, with Bose logo, but is too big to fit in your pocket. My iPhone actually fits comfortably inside the case.
4. Ear bud packaging requires a chainsaw and jaws of life to open

Overall, a good acquisition for me as my computer speakers went kaput some time ago, and this is way better.

Amanda Richards, January 1, 2013

I am using this amplifier to boost my Chaowei Antenna. Very pleased that the amplifier pulled in more channels as soon as installed than I was getting with only antenna. The channel views are also more clear with amplifier.

I give it 5 stars with 2 caveats. First, it's not stated in the description that it recognizes fewer formats when in BT mode and the instructions seem to be lacking in detail, so it took a while to figure out how to access all of the functions. Hint: You can only access playback functions while in BT because BT, itself, is a sub-folder, so you have to back out of BT to do other things.

Ultimately, I gave it 5 stars because a) i had just a few songs in the missing formats and b) once I got past the navigation issues, it works quite well and the company was very helpful when I needed them.

Update: Turns out as I loaded more music I found a lot more music that wasn't found while in BT, including some albums where some of the songs appeared and some didn't. Al in all, it's kind of clumsy to navigate in BT and BT was the feature I wanted most.

However, it sounds good with the earbuds that they provide and it's size makes it convenient. The 8gb are plenty if you don't have a lot of music. I do, so I added a 32gb sd mini-card which is as large as it will take.

Been using this for a few weeks now and I'm so happy with my purchase.  Nice & clear, easy to use, no static,  don't have to change the station at all (I have an hour & 20 min commute) the Bluetooth works perfectly. I love this thing

For five dollars, this was almost too good to be true. I love this case. It fits my new 7" Fire HDX perfectly - the tablet just pops into the four corner slots and stays put. The cutouts for the speakers, power & volume buttons and the charging slot are all easily accessed and functional. When the case is open & folded back, the hand strap is tight and sturdy, allowing you to securely hold the Fire while reading or playing a game - sort of reminds me of the feel of an old school paperback with the front cover folded back. The case adds no weight or real girth to the Fire, still fits into my handbag and the center console of the car easily. This case does put the Fire to sleep and wakes it up when completely closed, which is nice for battery savings if you use your Fire like I do - it's feeding music and audio books to my car's stereo system via the Bluetooth streaming, but there's no reason for the screen to be running or the XRay lyrics info etc while I'm driving. I can set the Fire to stream my audio content, shut the case and go on with my business. I don't understand why anyone would spend $40 or $50 on another case - this Poetic product is awesome & at these prices I can have more than one in different colors to match my handbags.

These earbuds are the best ever! I've tried a few brands, lots of Apple, and none compete with these earbuds. Most of all because they are so ergonomic / comfortable. The wires go over the top of your ears and the wire molds to your ear however you adjust it. So the earbuds never fall out and all the weight is taken off your ear canal area. They are also low profile and I can even comfortably lay with my head/ear on a pillow. The microphone works great for phone calls. And the buttons are marked and with 3 individual buttons so it's easy to know which one you're pushing without looking. I also love the shirt clip, minor as that may seem. Makes using the buttons much easier. I've only had these earbuds about a week. They seem sturdy. I'll update my review if they stop working. This will be my go-to earbud from now on!! Love them!!

I've had two phone calls with this so far, and I love the fact that I don't have to put the dirty phone up to my ear to take a call. The downside though is that even if I'm not walking around, the call seems to break up a bit. Not sure if this happens when the cord naturally moves around, but it shouldn't have such a loose connection to cause the call to break up. It could have been the other party I was talking to, but I talk to him often and he made it a point to tell me I was breaking up (and had no idea I was using this), so I don't know. But the sound quality is utterly amazing, just as good as if I hold the phone up to my ear. And I often take dictation, so the receiver makes it a lot easier to type, especially since the phone tends to echo the "clacking" of the keys and cut the speaker off so I miss some words they have said, whereas the receiver does not.

[Great Sound]

As noted in some of the other reviews this pair of headphones has great sound for its price range. Sound is quite neutral, without the bass emphasis of a lot of headphones at this range. Highs are also good and not muted. The cable is also very generous in length, which is great as my computer is far away from my chair. Finally, the headband adjustment is exceptional. I have a fairly large skull and most headphones I've purchased have not fit well. However, this one fits perfectly and even has more room to expand. The only comfort downside is that the pads have quite a stiff covering material. This is not so great for comfort for long use sessions, but not too big of an issue as you can replace them eventually if needed. The thicker pad material would make the headphones last longer...if it were not for the major issue I describe below with build quality.

[Disappointing Build Quality]

I've had my pair for about 1.5 years now, and today the headphone snapped at the joint between the top band and where the extension band slides out. See attached photo. You can see that there is a metal band in the headband to provide elasticity and resistance. But the extension band (the part that slides in and out) doesn't have a metal band inside of it. This concentrates stress at this transition point, causing the plastic to snap here eventually. I noticed that the plastic on the other cup has also started cracking. The plastic itself feels quite brittle and is about as thick as the metal strip in the headband. I think the fact that I have a large head and had to extend the headphones out only hastened their demise as this put more stress on the plastic-only part of the headbands.

[Conclusion]

This is a great sounding pair of headphones for their price, but alas I cannot recommend them anymore due to the snapping of the headband. To fail after about a year of use is a bit on the low end. My previous pair of similarly priced headphones lasted over 10 years without the headband failing (only cable had become worn). I think you *might* be OK if you have a smaller head and don't have to extend the headphone band too much, but if you have to expand it to near its maximum, it will probably snap off like mine did.

First and foremost, I need a convertible backpack which allows for transport - all materials needed for the long days on campus (grad student). In addition, I need the professional aspect to function as a briefcase. Solely on those points, this bag fits the bill. (BTW - no discount or freebie here for this review - I paid for this!)
PROS:
1. Material: feels and looks professional, good color, seems at the very least to be water repellent
2. Zippers: seem strong enough, especially when loaded - two of them house the briefcase handles
3. Padding: quality - on the backpack straps and particularly the section directly meant for the computer
4. Compartments: although the pictures do not necessarily show this, there are zippers on the outside, and inside, a pocket with divisions for pencils/pens/highlighters.

CONS:
1. Backpack adjustable straps: are on the lower part not allowing for easy adjustment while on your back
2. Lower connection backpack straps: hidden - cannot see whether sewn in well or not
3. Strap to hold computer in place: oddly long, which would allow for movement and sliding around, something you don't want your computer to do when inside
4. No compartment/pocket for a water bottle (my pet peeve)
5. PRIMARY (HUGE) ISSUE: Backpack straps which rest on upper trapezoids (left and right) are situated in a very uncomfortable position when fully loaded. I'm unsure if it's the angle or the placement, but the straps are too close to your neck and would cause pain. Primarily for this reason, I'm returning the backpack. Sad because even with the other cons (more annoyances than anything else) if it were not for this one, I would've kept the backpack because the pros outweigh the cons.

Pictures: It's important to see how a backpack will perform in my daily life. Therefore, the pictures provide a sense of how much stuff this can carry, with the contents both packed and unpacked.

Contents: Lenovo ThinkPad T460 in neoprene case, keys, 1 1/2" loose-leaf binder, yearly planner, scientific calculator, computer power cord, small cosmetic case, large cosmetic bag which houses pens/pencils/highlighters/usb drive/mouse/headphones and wallet.

Final thoughts: if only used as a briefcase/shoulder bag, this may be for you. However, if the primary purpose is to function as a backpack, good luck. I think another reviewer mentioned the oddly-placed backpack straps, but sadly, I ignored that advice.
In addition, cannot ascertain the strength of the shoulder strap as I didn't want to break the seal, but it is pictured.
This gadget made my old tv bluetooth to my earbuds. I plugged it in and it is perfect. There is no difference in sound quality if it is charging or not like the other reviews said.

I don't know how it happens but I somehow ended up buying over 20 pairs of bluetooth headphones over the course of my life. I'm also finding that I can't pass up a good pair of bluetooth headphones.

So of the over-head style bluetooth headphones, I've run across problems with short battery life (had one pair that lasts only 3 hours), too tight against the head, presses on the ear (supra-aural) and gets sweaty, active noise cancelling that can't turn on independently of the bluetooth function, and no carrying case.

This pair of RCA Active noise cancelling headphones don't have any of those problems. I sit at my desk all day with an air outlet behind me that is constantly blowing. I'm able to use them the entire day with music playing without the batteries running down. I don't keep the noise cancelling on the entire time but when I do, the fan noise is completely blocked out. Being circumaural headphones, the ear cups completely surround my ears and do not press on them. In addition, the spring isn't too tight to make me feel like my head is being squeezed in a vice.

As far as sound quality, because the speakers are not pressing against the ear, the sound seems to have a wider-room feel, making me feel even more like I don't have headphones on.

Overall, I'm quite satisfied with this purchase and don't feel the need to splurge and buy the much more expensive Sony and Bose products.

I had high hopes for this headset especially after seeing all the reviews. The ANC isn't really that great and if nothing is playing there's an annoying hiss. Also unlike the original crusher wireless when bass hits on these headphones vibrate like crazy which honestly is quite annoying where the originals did not do that.

on the pros though, these are much more comfortable on the crown of your head where the original crusher wireless would make the crown of your head hurt.

Do I think it's worth it comparatively from it's cheaper older model? Jury is still out.

I received my headband as a review sample. I want to note that I did not experience any drops in streaming as noted by other reviewers when using this with my Samsung Note 3 phone, but did have some issues with my Samsung Tab 3 10.1. The latter has some bluetooth problems that are well known, so I am attributing my issues with Tab 3 flaws and not this headband. I briefly tested this with an HTC One Remix with no problems either.

This headband is unique in that it was designed with real, strenuous sports in mind - or at least activities that make you work up a sweat. As such I tested my streaming as noted above with my source devices (phones and tablets) at least twenty feet away. That simulates where you would place those devices during a game of tennis.

It does seem impervious to sweat, although I would not call it sweat-proof. If you use it heavily and frequently you'll need to clean it at least weekly - see some of the top rated video reviews on this page for instructions for that because it is a bit tricky disassembling it the first time.

Also note that it's a snug fit on my head, which is size 6 7/8. I am guessing that if you wear a men's hat size above 7 1/4 it will be too snug. Take that into account.

Sound quality is excellent in my opinion. For the past nine months or so (at the time of this review) all brands or phones seem to have taken a major leap in that respect and these are no exception. The high frequency response of the phones is clear at max volume and the bass is deep (but not thumping). The mid range seems to be the sweet spot, and is rich and full. The volume itself is not super loud, and it is not noise-isolating. It does keep out most ambient noise though, and while these are not perfect for critical listening they are excellent for casual listening during sports and other strenuous activities.

If you want phones that stay in place regardless of that you are doing, and also demand respectable sound quality these merit consideration. I have not researched the market, but these are the only headband phones I have come across among the dozens I have tested to date.

When buying a product like this, it's wise not to go into the transaction with great expectations. In my case, this was a risk free trial, having won this item at a games arcade thanks to my considerable skill at spending vast quantities of money to win wonderful prizes such as shot glasses and lop-sided teddy bears.

Howz it work?

1. The machine looks like a CD player (or possibly like one of those cheap rolodex thingies that are made to look like CD players)
2. It comes with one pair of blue topped discs, and a 30ml bottle of liquid for cleaning CDs, DVDs, Game discs and the like.
3. It also comes with one pair of beige topped discs and a 10ml tube of cream for repairing discs.
4. Choose which set of discs you need, press the button to open the lid of the machine, and then insert them in the holes. You'll need to turn each disc until it is securely anchored (rotate it counter-clockwise until it stops)
5. Note that the left side is labeled "Dry" and the right side is labeled "Wet" (It's a bit hard to see if you're not looking for it)
6. Apply the appropriate solution - 4 drops of cleaning liquid or 3 small dollops of repair cream - on to the disc on the "Wet" side
7. Place your disc data side down and close the cover.
8. Plug in the machine (110/120V) and press either the "Clean" button or the "Repair" button on the front of the machine.
9. It will automatically turn itself off when the process is finished. (You won't have any problem knowing when it's done - it makes an awful racket when it's working)

Pros:

1. Dirty and scratched CDs, DVDs, Game discs and the like can be given a new lease on life.
2. Cleaning only takes a minute, and repairing just four minutes.
3. Easy to operate

Cons:

1. Looks cheap
2. The cleaning and repair solutions are supplied in tiny quantities (30ml and 10ml respectively) which are used up in no time at all.
3. Replacement kits of discs and solution are comparatively expensive.
4. Noisy

However:

1. It really worked to repair an extremely scratched PS2 game disc that would no longer play in the system. In just over 4 minutes the game was back in the console and working like new. (Some of the scratches were still visible - apparently the solution forms a coating over scratches)
2. It cleaned dirt and fingerprints from an audio disc without any problems.

So, in summary:

This machine does what it claims to do, but will need replacement cleaning/repairing kits very quickly (sold separately). It appears fairly sturdy, but I can't see it giving years and years of faithful service.

Game discs in particular are very expensive, and having this machine on hand to keep them working can be a worthwhile investment, particularly if they are subject to the usual abuse by generation iY.

Amanda Richards, August 30, 2010

I've sought a pair of wireless earbuds for a couple years now, both for general use, and for when running/working out. I originally purchased a pair of Blueant Pump earbuds a few years ago. They are completely waterproof, and have over-the-ear hooks designed to keep them firmly attached during vigorous activity. Those buds are very solid overall, but have a couple critical flaws that prompted me to keep searching. My ideal earbuds would have the following characteristics:

* truly wireless
* strong battery life
* in-ear "wings"/arc support, as opposed to employing over the ear hooks (I sometimes wear glasses and also hats which I didn't want competing for space with the ear buds)
* excellent audio (music and phone calls)
* hear through/ambient listening capable

The Blueant pumps lacked the ambient option, and also had a cable connecting the two buds, which prevented me from effectively performing weight lifting exercises while laying down, since the stiff cable would bump against the bench when I laid back, and knock loose the earbuds, breaking the seal in my ear canal.

After exhaustively researching my options, I decided to give the Powerbeats Pro a shot (in spite of the over the ear hooks), as well as these earbuds under review, the Sony WF-SP800N model. I decided against trying out the very popular Jabra Elite Active 75t, due to the shorter battery life relative to the Powerbeats and Sony options.

The Powerbeats Pro are indeed comfortable, and do a great job staying in place. What I learned is that they do not offer listen-through audio, (which I need for situational awareness when running/biking), and the audio when taking phone calls was incredibly scratchy. This was not a Bluetooth connectivity issue, because the phone played streaming Spotify audio just fine, and the cell phone was in my pocket the entire time, so distance was a non-factor. I found that I could manage to wear glasses at the same time as the Powerbeats buds, but it was slightly awkward. Additionally, I noticed some worrisome discussion on Reddit about the long term battery life of the Powerbeats Pro model, and so for those factors (and considering the high cost of this item), I decided against the Powerbeats Pro earbuds.

The Sony earbuds have performed fantastically. Initially I was disappointed because there was an unbelievable amount of wind noise on my first run using them. The fit felt sloppy and I was concerned about them dropping out of my ear. When I got home, I switched the earbud tips for the largest size. That made all the different in the world. The wind was largely sealed out (there is still some), and the music jumped to life. The fit was true, and I had no problem with the earbuds falling out, even when I went out of my way to shake them loose.

Battery life promises to eclipse even the mighty Powerbeats Pro, and the Sony model offers ambient listening. The water resistance looks to be at least the equal of the Powerbeats, and phone call clarity was excellent. All this at a price more than $100 less than the Powerbeats.

I will update this review if my opinion changes significantly as I get more time in with these Sony earbuds. Based on my initial experiences, I strongly recommend them, for both athletic and casual use. They are excellent.

For less than half the cost of a typical DAC/ Headphone AMP stack, this item gives you both in one package, saving you money on cables and space on your desk. I highly recommend this product. Customer service and post-purchase support has been wonderful!

While this performs in the top tier of products with balanced connections per ASR, it isn't truly balanced internally. The balanced connections are provided for convenience. Since you can't hear a difference or measure a difference, it doesn't matter. The engineers at Aoshida / SMSL know how to optimize a product for a price point. If you receive more enjoyment from spec sheets than the extra money in your wallet SMSL has other more expensive products to purchase that are internally balanced with very similar performance.

Great features include:
* More than enough to drive 300 ohm headphones.
* Integrated power supply, so you don't have a brick or need to find an extra USB connection.
* Included useful remote.
* Quality feeling front button.
* BT is easy to pair and fine for convenient streaming when not engaged in critical listening.

Things to keep in mind:
* Included USB cable is a bit short. You may want to purchase a longer USB input cable.

Reasons to look elsewhere:
* You need to drive a high impedance headphone, such as something with 600 ohm impedance.
* You want a DAC/AMP that is internally balanced.
* You need something portable to with a built-in battery that fits in your pocket to use on the go.
* You need your DAC/AMP to have a sub out, for ease of connection to a sub. (If using with a sub, you can normally connect the C200 to your SUB. Then, you would connect the sub to your speakers.)

The meFoto Globe Trotter Air Tripod has a nice feel. It opens and closes easily. It also adjusts easily. You can make it into a selfie stick. Recently, I have wished that I had the ability to watch DVDs in bed without having to watch on the big TV. I also would like to take it to my shed with no electricity so that I can play art classes without having to rely on internet at all.

HOW THIS CHARGES
This charges using the type C cord in a few hours.

PICTURE
The picture is decent. It is not like watching an expensive bluray or TV screen, but it is fine for close up watching.

OPERATION
I have had no issues operating this. It is pretty easy and the set up is not difficult to adjust.

SOUND
That is where we lose a star. Even at the highest setting of 20 this is so quiet that if I run fans in the summer, it is hard to hear with the player right in front of me. Headphones would solve that, but I don't always want to wear them.

THE BOTTOM LINE
I like this set. It is fun to play with and allows me to watch my English tribute of nightly Hyacinth Bucket episodes where no one else has to listen to it and complain because I play it too much.

MY RATING
FOUR STARS. If the sound was a little bit louder and better, I would like this more. As it is it is still okay.

I have a super large keyboard that I only use a fraction of, so I thought a smaller keyboard might make it easier for me to use. It immediately began working the moment I plugged in the nano USB receiver into my Chromebox. Worked flawlessly and quietly. As a writer, I am on the keyboard 6-10 hours a day and I have worn out two keyboards by wearing off the lettering, but to be truthful, I put the small keyboard away after the day's end, not for any problems with it, just that I realized that I needed to weight and feel of the heavier, larger keyboard. But I am keeping it because I like it and I can use it on my Chromebook. So as I can't attest to longevity, I can say it works well, is light, and instantly connected to the computer.

I have an LG TV 47" so I thought another LG product might be the best course of action (of course the money involved had to do with this decision), so I went to my local Best Buy to get a glimpse of what is out there. Besides this LG sound bar they had quite a few choices. I quick referenced them to their reviews and came to the conclusion that most sound bars are just about at the same level in terms of overall performance. I did see a Bowers and Wilkins?, priced around $2200, which is way more expensive than the tv itself (but was taught that audio is supposed to be the greater investment for the true tv viewer), and this sound bar frankly was fantastic, truly a thing to behold. But $2200 Buckaroos are a long way from $300 and I did get the tv at a great bargain price, so cheap instead of expensive became the call of war.
For what I got this soundbar does everything I wanted done. It was very easy to install through the optical option, and even though the first unit I purchased had troubles pairing with the subwoofer and was returned immediately, the second was the charm and now it works very nicely with the added plus that it certainly did not require a Kamikaze investment. Works very well and it adds a great sound capability to the living room in our home which was the intended site. Some shows are better than others but even the subwoofer does its magic and is a lot of fun to crank it up once in a while, specially for the internet type movie sites (like Netflix, Amazon, Vudu, etc.) that come with the smart tv and required some sort of subscription. Their sound, specially amazon and netflix, was way below average and even at maximum volume on the tv it was very sad. I could hear it but one of the members of the tribe is a little more than a little hard of hearing and was always having trouble (probably the main reason why I decided on a sound bar in the first place).
Needless to say this soundbar delivered what was expected of the product and now my living room is one loud area and when the subwoofer is doing its thing you can feel it kind of in the furniture itself, like some of the controllers in PS3 with the added vibration. Minor thing but rather invigorating, for the whole room now sounds like a mini theater without having had to add several speakers coupled with tedious connections, which certainly I am not qualified or inclined to want to do myself. I just put the sound bar in the same table in which the television rest and the subwoofer about 6 feet away and voila! Just waiting for the neighbors to reassure me as to the loudness, kind of like its baptism when they finally complain (makes you feel a little bit proud that you are putting enough noise to draw the attention of nearby houses, silly but what can you do sometimes?), so for now I am very happy with the purchase and glad that when necessary I have the equipment to raise the noise way higher than it was capable before. 4 very solid Stars!

It folds up small and doesn't take up much room, is light and works like a champ.

This little ACER ASPIRE SWITCH 10 LAPTOP has a display to die for. To my eye, it's as clear and sharp as the iPad Mini Retinal display. And the display is quick! Pages load fast, and the touchscreen is very responsive.

In designing this little "convertible" laptop, Acer got the concept exactly right. The display and keyboard together constitute a small notebook computer that is just large enough for doing real writing work. (As long as you don't type too fast--there is a slight delay in communications between the keyboard and display.) The built-in, buttonless mouse works smoothly, and I like the feature where you push the lower left or lower right corner of the mousepad to left-click or right-click. (You do have to watch that you don't move the mouse pointer off target when you click.) This laptop even comes with a one-year subscription to Microsoft Office 365 (software is installed, the activation code is in the box).

But the "convertible" laptop is also a standalone tablet with a sensitive, fast touchscreen. The display lifts off easily from two tabs at the back of the keyboard, so that you can check email, shop online, or search the Internet without holding up any extra keyboard weight. When you're done using the tablet, the display clicks back onto the tabs, and the laptop closes up like any standard laptop (so you don't need a tablet cover, or even a screen protector for the touchscreen). The settings that allow you to shut down or put the laptop to sleep when you close the cover work as usual. The display can also be detached and reattached facing backwards, so that the keyboard becomes a display stand.

This little Windows 8.1 laptop can do a lot of things. The display/tablet has a webcam, stereo speakers, a microphone for sound recording, a microSD card slot, a microUSB connector for connecting to USB devices, an HDMI micro connector that supports hi-def digital video connections, a headset/speaker jack, and a DC-in jack for charging.

The keyboard has a single USB port. I used the USB port to connect an external CD/DVD drive and play music from a CDROM. The USB port is also useful for file transfers via flash drive, or for backing up files to an external storage drive. Because this little notebook has only 64GB storage capacity (other tablets have 16GB to 64GB storage capacity), you will almost certainly need to back up music, pictures, and other files to an external drive or to cloud storage eventually. But you can also copy files off the tablet without using wireless or connecting the tablet via USB cable to another PC, because the tablet/keyboard combo is a full-fledged Win8.1 computer.

I like this ACER ASPIRE SWITCH 10 a lot, because it is so compact, portable, extremely lightweight, and versatile. And I even like the Windows 8.1 operating system, which makes a lot of sense for a small tablet computer like this one.

I bought this because I needed another firestick for another TV.  I have the first generation already.  Man is this faster and just seems to work better. Pros:
1. Wireless BT works great. 35 plus feet. I've tested using in another room from my phone about 30 feet with the door closed. Did not drop the signal.
2. Noise isolation is very good. Can't hear my kids yelling and the dog barking.
3. Quality of sound is very good. Bass is good.
5. Charge lasts at least 4 hours from my testing. They will last longer but I have not tested beyond that. They recharge in about an hour or so. Standard USB connector for charging is good. So I can use other cables if need be.
4. Fit works very well after getting used to putting them on. They do not fall off during jogging or other high motion exercises.
6. BT connects automatically after first setup. My other BT headphones do not and it's an extra painful step that these allow me to skip.

Cons:
1. Fit gets to be uncomfortable after longer uses. This is acceptable, as these need to be secure in your ear so they don't fall out while moving around or exercising. I would not recommend if you will be using for longer periods of time, as comfort will probably be an issue. Not as much a Con on the product but the type of headphone.
2. Profile could be a bit smaller. They sick out a bit far but not any more than other BT headphones I've seen. I would have liked to wear these under my motorcycle helmet but they stick out too far.
