If I hold my hand a few inches from my neck in between the headset and the Bluetooth dongle the sound starts to cut out - and i'm literally 2 ft from the computer tower at chest level seated and the dongle is plugged into the front of the tower. I got up and walked out of the room for a total of about 8 ft and lost sound pretty much. Also the package it came in was ripped open - so I know it was a return from someone else.

I use these earbuds for long periods of time, listening to music, podcasts, and audiobooks. I am very happy with the sound quality, which is clear and full. They're comfortable to wear (even for extended use) and I've found them to be quite durable.

I bought this to remotely trigger 3 very inexpensive speedlites I picked up (also Neewer brand). I figured one light can be fired via light trigger in slave mode, and I'd like at least 2 receivers. Works well as long as the batteries are good!

Fresh batteries fixed it, however. I guess it needed more voltage to fire the speedlight than my semi-used batteries had. So lesson here is: Keep fresh batteries in it, and you'll be great!

I have purchased 6 different kinds of headsets trying to find that correct fit for when I exercise. I run 8 - 10 miles at a time so earbuds fall out when I sweat.  I threw out my Sony (ear wrap) headphones before my last run out of frustration. They won't stay in so it sounds like a walkie talkie at best.  Yesterday I stopped at Walgreen's and picked up the IHIP head phones.  FINALLY!!!  A headphone that stays.  They are a solid fit and for $16 the sound is just fine.  Surprised to see the other ratings so low.  If you want something that will stay in at an affordable cost then this is a 5 star product. I also saw a complaint about bass.  I was listening to BassNectar on my run and honestly it sounded just fine. I'm a fan for the price.

With the right tips, these sound fantastic. I can imagine with further "break-in" and maybe some customization, they will be phenomenal. They are a little bass-heavy, but nothing too detrimental.

For reference, here's what I used:
- Samsung Note8
- VE Odyssey HD DAC
- Poweramp v3
- songs ripped from CD into FLAC using EAC

Here's my previous experience:
- 1More Quad
- Audio Technica ATH-M50x
- Sony WH-1000MX3
- Technics EAH-AZ70W

These sound better than the Technics, but not nearly as good as the Sony. With that said, these wired headphones aren't exactly the best spokesperson for staying wired. I'm all for wired for both audio and video, but I admit that wireless options like the Sony and Technics make me a believer. With the right codecs and setup, you can achieve wonderful results.

There is supreme comfort with these IEMs. With the right tips, I got them fitting snugly in my ear (but there is some trial with error), and there is a metal right around the ear to allow the wire to stay in place. But I question whether these IEMs are worth the price. For $300 you can get cheaper IEMs (imported) with better tips and cables and still have some change in your wallet. And with the push into wireless around the same price range, Shure really needs to push their technology and rely less on their name. Their name alone certainly commands attention, but the wallet is stronger.

I picked up this little beauty to replace both an ancient and cranky 5-disc CD Player and a single disc DVD player. I now have breathing room in the old entertainment center, so even my antique turntable can take a creaky spin every now and again.

Seeing that I can't connect a toaster without help, I called on my trusty better half to unravel the mystery of setting it up. In non-technical language, a.k.a. plain English, this is what you need to know about this mighty machine:

1. The manual needs a lot of work. It's neither user-friendly nor idiot-proof. Ditto for the boxy silver remote.

2. It is easy to set up if you already know how to do that sort of thing. (We have component video connections to the TV and digital coaxial connections to the receiver.)

3. It gives excellent sound from both CDs and DVDs. With the benefit of 5.1 surround, movies like Master and Commander can literally move you, and CDs have never sounded better.

4. It is as convenient as a 5-disc CD changer as it is a 5-disc DVD player, except that when you're playing more than one CD you'll need to put it in "CD Mode" first.

5. It can easily play different types of media, such as audio Cds, MP3s, DVDs and those other mysterious formats - just put in the discs and play away.

6. The video quality is very good on a regular TV. You can set up different pre-defined picture quality modes, or customize to suit your own taste if you're a techie or a buff. If you have difficulty making up your mind, ignore this option.

7. The player is chock full of options, but you have to explore for yourself, which can be a bit confusing until you get the hang of it. Read the manual, you say? See Item 1 above.

8. There's on-screen information for MP3s and photo CDs, with different views available for the contents. (Groups/folders or entire playlists)

9. I can't comment on the progressive scan feature, since I don't have an HD or HD-ready TV - yet. (Still waiting for that lottery win)

10. It is supposed to play DVD-Audio discs, but you need 6.1 channel inputs on your receiver to play them. Unfortunately, our receiver is lacking these inputs, but then again, I am also lacking any DVD-Audio discs.

Electronics buffs will probably say that it needs a bit of "tweaking" to get it to look and sound just right, but it looks and sounds great to me. All in all a very good player, perhaps excellent when you factor in the price.

Amanda Richards, October 1, 2004

[[VIDEOID:d3ebc84f3d3fd77b0d4bf01d2a1d3ade]] I had very specific needs/wants with a smart watch and this watch takes care of those. However, I knew what I was getting into and it was a choice - appearance, size, basic function vs feature rich and huge!!!

This is a beautiful watch that suits for a delicate, feminine appearance without being bulky. While not light, it is very comfortable to wear, even while sleeping. My previous regular watch was a simple Timex Indiglo. Small, silver, lovely and functional. But I wanted the notifications and step tracking so I wouldn't need a separate fitness device. I then got an ASUS Zenwatch 2. Loved it! Feature rich, great interface, but larger than I wanted and looked like a calculator on my wrist. I lost it and have been attempting to find something to replace it. I purchased a modern fashion smart watch, but the dial was huge and didn't suite my taste. Then I found this one. Right size, right look, right features (steps, find phone, notifications, etc). I've had it a week and here's where I am.

Physical - beautiful silver appearance with a delicate look. Band is flexible, very comfortable and easy to put on and take off. I have a 7" wrist and removed one link using the INCLUDED link removal tool. This is a fantastic add on to this watch.

Display and interface - bright and clear. Images are simple, but pleasing. Fonts are nice. Scroll is reasonably responsive. Lots of options for faces including your own custom. My only gripe with the faces is that I wish you could choose the custom features to display. I would have liked a battery status with my custom image. Touch screen is responsive, though I find my fingers are large and I have some issues periodically controlling the small buttons for stopwatch and timer. Stopwatch and timer can't run in the background, so you can't scroll through the watch while using them. Would need to set an alarm from the phone instead. The find phone feature is virtually worthless. If you're any distance from the phone then the Bluetooth disconnects and you can't send the find signal.

Notifications - I am happy with notifications overall in that I actually receive them and can read enough to get the gist. However, you can only see the last message received. Also, you can only scroll to a set number of characters. The messages are prefixed by all of the people in a thread. So if you have a group of 6 people in a message, all of their names will be displayed, and then you'll see who sent the message, and then it will start the message, but it will be truncated to a limited number of characters.

Phone app - leaves A LOT to be desired. The grammar in English is awkward. Determine to select, state for steps, etc. The tracking is wonky in that it's per day and you have to select each day from the calendar. There are no charting or trends with the exception of a chart for the single day of sleep. Tracking for blood ox, BPM, and blood pressure in the phone only keeps if it's started from the phone. If you start it from the watch, it doesn't log it.

Battery - Goes for at least 3 days so far with the tilt-to-view and auto heart monitoring off. I like that the charger is a plate that the watch sits in.

Even with all of this, I am happy with my watch. I know the limitations, but until there is a comparable alternative, I'm good with this one.

I have a good tangle of cables in my home office for a variety of devices that require a micro-USB cable. Most of these cables are very nondescript and I have no idea who made them, though there are a couple of them that have manufacturer names printed on the plugs on the end. Most are plain black and are mostly indistinguishable from one another. These cables from Magic-T are absolutely the most easily identifiable cables on the desk and it has made it very easy to assign cables to every device on the desk. But, there is more to these cables than just pretty colors.

The most obvious advantage of this cable set is the colors. Each of these cables is a different color and none of them are black or gray - there‚Äôs blue, pink, orange and green. And, even more important than the color is the fact that they are insulated in nylon weave, not plastic coating, which in my experience holds up a bit better under stress and the result is a more reliable cable.

The plugs on both ends are metal shielding with a plastic base, sufficient to give these strength for the connections. The cables have been inserted in the bases and attached within, not attached to the plug base, but those connections are very tight and seem to be solid so I am not concerned about them pulling loose.

Each cable is about six and a half feet in length which is much more convenient for me than the regular 3' cables.

These cables are capable of high-speed charging so if you have a device and a charger that are both capable of high-speed charging then these cables will work well for you. I used one for my tablet and a high-speed USB charger and the tablet did charge faster than when using a lower-grade cable.

I want to mention the pricing. As I write this, the price on this set of four cables is about $9. That‚Äôs about $2.25 per cable, and the cables are of good quality. The price can change of course, but at the current price this is an absolute bargain.

There‚Äôs something else I need to mention. The manufacturer offers a 12-month warranty on these cables, and to me that‚Äôs just amazing. For a cable that costs less than $2.50 per individual cable the manufacturer thinks enough of their product to back it with a 12-month warranty. I doubt I would ever need to use the warranty for one of these, but it‚Äôs reassuring to know the manufacturer believes in their products.

It is hard to find fault with these cables. They are made well, they are easily identifiable and they are very inexpensive. This is a fine set at a great price.

While I've never bothered with a webcam before, having one now, in the middle of the pandemic, seems like it will be useful. As an old guy with a number of health issues, I am staying at home all the time and haven't been venturing out at all. Rather than actually going to the doctor's office these days, the webcam will allow me to teleconference routine medical checkups. It's also good for keeping in touch with family and friends I can't see face to face. Just this evening I spent time in a Google video chat room talking with a dear friend who lives in another part of the country. Then I checked in on Facebook video chat with one of my sisters. Talking with someone in a video chat is much nicer than chatting by text or visiting over a landline phone. So if you don't already have the capacity for video chatting, you might want to think about getting a webcam.

On my Windows 10 desktop, this really is a plug and play piece of equipment. No software or other downloads needed. One of the minor issues has to do with setting this webcam up for the first time. The instructions are minimal and of no practical use. At first, I kept getting error messages when trying to use the webcam to make a video chat call, with no clear indication of what the error was. Some trial and error efforts showed it to be a simple problem. I needed to give the device both camera and mic access before it would work. Once I figured that out, I was easily able to make calls without any further error messages.

Another minor issue was that when I first tried to put the webcam on my desk, it kept flipping over on its side. So I had to make my first video call holding it in my hands. Later, after the tight coiling of it's cord eased up, it sat just fine with no tipping.

Then, if I held the device too close to the computer screen, sitting just over the speakers, the webcam would pick up enough of the other person's voice to set up a feedback echo. Moving the device away from the computer speakers easily solved that.

Finally, the video on my end was okay but not great. I looked green but that may have something to do with the lighting in my room. Still, I loved chatting with my friend and my sister. Both enjoyed the fact that I looked so green and neither seemed to have any problem hearing me. This is the first webcam I've used and I'm pleased enough with it to give the device a 4 star rating.

This works great to split the audio signal out of an HDMI feed- we use it to send audio to our surround sound system while using our home projector for an immersive theater experience. We used to have an Amazon Basics version of the same thing, but it did not work very well- sometimes the Amazon version would need to be set via a button to change 5.1 or 2 channel or passthrough sound since it wouldn't always remember the setting after a power down, but this unit has a physical switch so it will be hardcoded upon power on. Also sometimes with the Amazon version the sound wouldn't pass through to the video device (it would always send sound out the analog audio jacks, but only sometimes also out the HDMI- it is supposed to do both). This one seems to consistently do both, as it should.
I'd like to also add that THIS COMES WITH EVERYTHING! It has Two HDMI cables, a digital audio cable, an analog cable, etc, ALL IN THE BOX. A fantastic package that does exactly what you want.

Never thought I would want an all-in-one computer because you can't expand it at all, but with USB you don't really need to, as you can add external USB drives or devices (printers, scanners, etc.) easily or even use USB flash drives.  Of course you can't add memory, but this comes with 8 gig, which is really all you need these days, unless you are a gamer.  This has a nice large display screen with a clear picture.  Will be great for watching video.  Has a built in microphone and video camera.  Tried the microphone with Windows 10 assistant Cortana and it works great (even though it warned me that it might not).  Comes with Windows 10 pre-installed.  All you have to do is customize a few local settings (time zone, language, etc.) and you are ready to go.  Because everything is built in to the screen, setup time is very fast.  You plug it in and turn it on.  You do have to put batteries in the wireless mouse and keyboard, but they are included, as was the USB stick needed for the wireless devices.  Was up and running in no time.  The wireless mouse and keyboard is nice, but the keyboard is a flat keyboard and I much prefer an ergo keyboard, so I probably won't use the keyboard.  My biggest problem in the past with wireless devices is that they go through batteries fast.  This keyboard and mouse have on/off switches, so you aren't using up the battery when you aren't using the computer.  With everything built into one unit, you might think it would be pretty heavy.  It is heavy, but most people could move it without difficulty.  There is a lot to like about this system and not much to dislike.  I was disappointed that it didn't have more USB ports.  There were only 2 on the back and 2 on the side.  One of the 4 is used for a tiny USB stick that is used for wireless communication with the keyboard and mouse.  You'll quickly run out of USB ports, so you may need a USB hub, if you have more than a couple of devices to hook up.  The 500 gig hard drive is a little small by today's standards, but should be big enough for most people.  For lots of data storage an external source is really more ideal than saving on the C: drive.  You might be able to get a little more computer for less money, but it seems to me that the pricing is not that bad, considering what you get.  Also includes McAfee internet security and some cloud storage (although small and you have to do things to increase it or pay for more space).  Overall not a bad value and ideal for limited space.  No cords and wires to deal with.  You have only the power cord to deal with.  I was also impressed that it included an optical drive.  Many newer systems (especially laptops) don't include a DVD drives anymore.  Performance seemed a little slow, but nothing significant.  I think most people will be happy with this system and it will meet the needs of all but the most demanding users.

I own the [[ASIN:B00MVXUACM Koss SP330 On Ear Dynamic Headphones Black with Silver Accents]] (current price $105.52) and I love them because of their comfort, good sound, and overall quality. I selected these headphones because I wanted to have a spare set and also to see how these would compare to my Koss.

I tried these headphones on the iPhone 5, iPad 3, and a Dell Latitude E6430 laptop and on all of these devices the sound was fabulous. It was actually more stereo sounding than my Koss.

PROS:

- The stereo sound is crisp and slightly better than my Koss.

- I LOVE, LOVE, LOVE the electric blue color which is called "candy blueberry."

- A headphone port on each earpiece provides the user with the ability to share the headphones by plugging in a music share cable which is NOT PROVIDED. A music share cable is not really needed in my opinion because all headphones come with one cable. While my boyfriend was listening to music on his iPad, I just plugged in my Koss cable to the side of the headset he was not using, and listened to the same music through my Koss headphones while he was using these.

- I like that the provided headphone cable can be used in the left or right earpiece which enables me to switch sides when I want.

- The headphone cable has an in-line MIC control for Android, tablets and other devices. Based on my research, an in-line MIC means there's a built in microphone that is built into the cable which should enable the wearer to answer calls without removing the headphones. I was able to get this to work on my boyfriend's iPad and iPhone and he was able to talk and hear through the headphones. There is a one button control on the in-line MIC which lowered the volume.

- The headphone band is adjustable.

CONS:

- The only CON I see is that they are not as comfortable for me as I would have liked. I used these a few times for a period of several hours. Even though they can be adjusted, I wound up getting a headache with extended use (more than 2 hours). So in this sense they were not as comfortable as they initially feel when just putting them on. The Koss headphones I own are the only ones I've ever tried that have been comfortable on me.

OTHER THINGS TO NOTE:

- The Amazon product page says that a music share cable is included; this is not correct nor is it really needed because if you are sharing just plug in a cable from another pair of headphones to the extra port on these.

- According to the manual, it takes 20 hours for the headphones to break in. It says the sound mellows out over time.

In summary, these headphones are great. They have fantastic stereo sound (at least to my ears), the ability to share by plugging in another set of headphones, and an in-line MIC. They are adjustable and relatively comfortable but not as comfortable as my Koss. The color is also attractive.

I am really enjoying the sound quality from these as I needed to switch from a corded headset to something wireless. This is Bluetooth but the Bluetooth chip works well and doesn‚Äôt seem to have issue where it disconnects from my laptop and connects to my phone (I‚Äôve had this with a few speakers).

The mic works great as I do user testing and the sound quality is important for good feedback as a tester.

I was pleasantly surprised to find out that the chip isn‚Äôt needed unless Bluetooth isn‚Äôt available on the device. There was no issue with connectivity either as my laptop recognizes the USB Bluetooth chip and automatically paired with the headset. A plus for me since my laptop tends to lag.

The headset has a good/decent look to it. The earpieces are squishy and comfortable. The headset adjusts easily. The plastic seems to be of decent quality so putting them on and taking off repeatedly should not be an issue. Very pleased overall.

This case has a great adjustable shoulder strap and has a solid velcro loop on the back so you can attach it to a belt or bag. This case is built really well, but it is much smaller than I anticipated.  First, let me qualify this review by saying if you own the professional line of lenses, then some lenses might not fit.  I shoot with a Canon 5D III and almost all my lenses I have are the L series.  Some did not fit at all.  For example, my Canon 85mm f/1.2L lens would not fit in the case at all, and my Canon 50mm f/1.2L was so snug at the top that it felt like it would have been forced in there.  The case narrows a lot at the bottom.  This is ideal for some lenses because it keeps your lenses more secure, but for most of my lenses, it was a tough fit.  It did fit my 135mm, 24-105mm f/4L, 17-40mm, and my 100mm Macro lenses in it perfectly. So, it will work for most lenses that are no more than 3 inches in diameter for the glass (about a 77mm thread) and I would say no taller than 4.5 to possibly 5 inches.  It's built really well and is a nice little case, so I would recommend on this condition to just pay close attention to the size and match it up with your gear.

First and foremost- What every prospective tablet user needs to consider: What am I planning on doing with my tablet?
For most users, tablets are for entertainment and are considered a luxury item. They aren't good for working on school work, or anything that requires a lot of typing, so for most people, these devices are for consuming media (news, videos, social networks...).

Why pick the Wifi only:
When I was looking at Xooms at the local electronics establishment, I was confronted with the decision of getting the $599 Xoom Wifi or the $799 Xoom 3G/Wifi (upgradeable to 4G at a later date at no cost). For me, while 3G was tempting for convenience, it was still a pretty easy decision to buy the Wifi only device. With the 3G, you are tied into a service contract. If you go with Verizon's service (which is advertized with the device), you only pay $599 for the device, but you have to pay $20 a month for 24 months. On top of that, you can only use 1GB of data. For a device that is going to be used for the consumption of data (especially videos), I don't want to be limited to only 1GB. Another decision point was the fact that I knew my Xoom would be used mostly at home, where I have a Wifi network, or at local eatting establishments that provide free Wifi. The real nail in the coffin on this decision was that my 4G phone is capable of wireless teathering and my data plan is unlimited- taking that into consideration- there really is no need to pay for an additional data plan.

The Device- an out of the box look:
Out of the box, you find the approximately 1.5 lbs device, power cable, and a couple booklets. I would have been nice to have a sleeve for the Xoom, but Motorola doesn't provide any type of protection for the tablet. I made sure to pick up a [[ASIN:B004S748UY ZAGG invisibleSHIELD for Motorola Xoom (Screen) (MOTXOOMS)]] to make sure my screen stayed pristine. The device is a solid little tablet. The back id 4/5 aluminum and the top part of the back case is rubberized plastic.

The hardware feels solid. Additionally, the layout of the device generally makes sense. The power button was a little confusing, but once I found it on the back, the idea really grew on me. It will be a little wierd when it comes to accessories, but I have no complaint about the device itself. Next to the power button, there is the HD camera lense with LED flash. Having an HD camera is nice, even if shooting pictures on a tablet isn't really practicle. The back of the device also includes stero speakers that are surprisingly loud for a device of this size.

All of the connectors (power, usb, dock...) are all located on the bottom of the device, except the headphone jack. Not sure I am a fan of this oddity, but I have yet to use headphones, so it is not really an issue to date. Also, the volme buttons are located on the left side of the device and are sufficiently easy to reach and use.

On the face of the device, there is a forward facing camera- this is great for video chatting. While GTalk works, Skype currently does not support video chat on this device (app issue, not hardware). There is also a light senseor- I hate the light sensor- I sometimes find that the brightness of the screen changes abruptly by a huge amount because I accidently put my thumb over the sensor. The best fix for this is to just turn off the auto adjustment.

Orientation:
Deviating from the norm, the Xoom is built to be oriented in landscape mode rather than portrait mode. With the 10 inch screen, landscape works great. I find that I am able to thumb type on the on-screen keyboard without straining much to reach the keys in the middle. The size is really what makes landscape work well with this tablet. In portrait, I (like many others) find that the device is a little bit hard to balance- feeling a little top heavy. It isn't so bad that the device is difficult to use- it just takes a little getting used to.

Android:
The android 3.0, Honeycomb load on this device is great. Many who don't use android or are iPad users will probably find that the device will take a little bit of learning to get used to. I am an android user (though my phone has an older version of android), and found that I was able to fully use and understand the device in 30 minutes of playing with it. The learning period may take up to a day, but once you fiure it out, you will notice that the controls really make sense and are easy to find when you need them.

Overall, I love this little device. There are some minor little design dislikes, but nothing that impacts my 5 star rating of this device!

My first GPS was a hand me down Magellan that I could never get to work. My second was a Navigon 2100 max 4.3-Inch Portable GPS Navigator with Text-to-Speech which I absolutely love. Next was the Nextar SNAP5 Super Slim 5-Inch Portable GPS Navigator which I seldom use. This TomTom XL 340M LIVE (Lifetime Maps Edition) 4.3-Inch Portable GPS Navigator is better than all, but I still love the Navigon for it's quick re-routing and ease of operation. That being said, I'll describe my experiences over the past few weeks of owning this GPS.

Out of the box, it's necessary to hook the GPS up to your computer to check on the maps and register the product. I did remove the extra voices to create some space as was recommended by other reviewers, saving them to my computer before removing them from the device. I wasted time trying to find Tom Tom Home and like another reviewer, was able to get it through an internet search. The website listed on the box (as I recall) was not accurate and it's not intuitive. Once I had the software downloaded and installed, I began confirming that I had the most recent map installed. This can be done only once. I reviewed the online manual because there was none included and that was no big deal for me. No papers to lose. Although I did not register for the Live option or provide any information (payment), I've used the live services to do a Google search for a POI and the gas prices has already been used 3 times with success. I'm not crazy about having the computerized female voice as the only option for "speaking" street names, and the names are not always pronounced correctly or even completely, but it does work. The Navigon is far superior in this regard. The Tom Tom accesses satellites very quickly for me and I don't find myself waiting ever for the device to start navigating. The POIs are far superior and easier to access on the Tom Tom. Rerouting options were not intuitive for me and a friend showed me the way to select specific options. The mount is lousy in my opinion and the GPS has popped out on too many occasions for me to be comfortable. It's the weakest link for me in the entire package. I did have the audio set to automatically change with the speed of the vehicle but that drove me crazy with a computerized female voice yelling at me as I was driving the Beltway, so that's been changed and she's set at about 70% consistently. I wish I'd had this GPS a week earlier because I received a $150 speeding ticket in the mail from DC through a Radar unit. Once I recover from the shock and guilt, I'll travel the route again within the speed limit and see if the GPS warns me of the radar unit. It does alert me of the red light camera installed (but not operational) which is permanently installed on my street corner. The first few times I heard the alert, I had no idea what was going on, until I read the online manual again. I now also set the speed alert to let me know when I'm exceeding a speed limit, but the limits have not always been current. One day, I will notify Tom Tom of several routing major screw ups I've discovered but that's going to have to wait until I have some time on my hands. The Navigon is superior in this regard of more direct routing and fewer errors. All in all, I like this and would recommend the product. Perhaps when my Navigon Fresh Maps subscription expires I'll remove the second GPS from my car, but for now I just can't give up Sarah (the Navigon text to speech voice).

Seem like nice covers for AirPods. They can fit other wireless earbuds too

Silicone feeling material is nice and looks like it‚Äôll do a good job.

Overall I think they‚Äôre nice

Disclaimer - I've only had these for about a week so far and these are the very first Truly Wireless Earbuds that I have ever owned.

I purchased these earbuds on a great sale while waiting for another more expensive brand to get restocked, and honestly didn't expect to much from these. First impressions were that they were quite cheap however after using them for a little while now, I've come to appreciate them even more. Even though these are my very first Truly Wireless Earbuds, I feel that after tons of research and watching reviews, I know what to look for in sound and quality. There are so many budget wireless earbuds on the market right now with so many more on Indigogo (which from comments and reviews I've seen and read, I will NEVER buy from). This makes it quite hard to know what to buy. For me, I have been waiting for that perfect very small and discreet Truly Wireless Earbud with amazing sound. The Iyesku YK-T02 TWS Sport Earbuds didn't hit that mark for me but at the price I paid, I honestly can't complain.
Pros:
1. Bluetooth 5.0 - This was one of my main requirements when searching and the YK-T02 has it.
2. Easy to pair (I am using the Samsung Note 8) and pairing was very easy. Once the buds are initially paired, they connect super fast once you pull them out of the charging case.
3. No loss of connectivity to either earbud. I've seen a bunch of reviews where this is an issue with MANY other wireless earbuds on the market. Even some of the more spendy ones.
4. Fit is very comfortable and seem to be very secure though I have not put them through the test of running nor exercise. However I don't think this would be an issue at all.
5. Sound quality is decent. More about this in the Cons.
6. Tons of ear tip options. Most earbuds come with a few extra sizes but these come with a plethora, for that perfect custom fit.
7. Quite small and discreet.
8. Small pocketable charging case.

Cons:
1. Sound. As I stated in the Pros these sound "good" (for the money) but the Highs are quite loud (Mids and Bass are not) and almost hurt when the volume is turned all the way up. Mids are not to bad but the bass is nearly non existent which was a huge let down. HOWEVER let me say, once I played with the ear tips and found the right fit, Highs, Mids, and Bass are much better, but still not what I would have hoped for but again these aren't "High end" earbuds right?
2. Because the volume of these buds are quite low, Audio books are hard to hear when in a loud environment.
3. No satisfying magnet to hold the buds in the charging case like many others on the market. (The case does click shut to ensure the buds wont be falling out.)
4. Speaking of the case, my first impression was that the case felt very nice and lightweight, but it does feel cheap.

Final thoughts:
Like I said earlier in this review, if you can get these from Amazon on a lightning deal or with a coupon, I would say grab you a pair, but just don't expect these to compete with higher end buds. These would be great for the kids and anyone that just wants a good pair of Truly Wireless Earbuds that wont break the bank.

This speaker we use when we want sound enhancement to watching YouTube, which does a great job in enhancing the volume, but sound quality is just so so.  Now with Apple Tv you can flick YouTube onto your Telly. Would I carry this speaker on the go, nope.  Easy to use, just connect the plug and away you go.  Useful if you want to Skype with friends and family as it does enhance the audio for you if you are hard of hearing!

Needed a receiver that would allow us to have a decent sub (not expensive), fill the room with sound efficiently and have enough HDMI hookups for DirecTV, 3D Blu Ray, gaming when needed, that had airplay and was easy to use remote.
Plus was at a decent price.

H/K AVR1700 met those expectations. It was between this, Yamaha 473 or 573 units or Pioneer 1122. I went w/ Harman Kardon based on reviews, price and expectations of use. I have a 7.2 system that can shake the house in the basement for sports, movies etc. Our LG 47LM8600 would be matched to the system and we realized we didn't need anything more than 5.1 for the Living Room based on setup downstairs and with our L/R being somewhat small and open to dining/kitchen this unit would be a good match.

1. I missed getting this at the $200 sale price, but willingly paid the $270 price to get it via prime and have the Living Room up and running for wife and family. I would expect as the 2013 receivers come out the sales price will return.

2. First set of speakers was the Polk Audio RM6750 HT speaker set. Unfortunately 2 were shot rather quickly. RMA returned to Newegg and got different speakers to match receiver from Amazon. Polk Audio PSW505 Sub (which works great with the 1700's LFE sub Hookup), BIC Center channel to match my Axiom M2 Bookshelves I brought down from the loft game system and the two additional Polk Audio RM6750 satellites for the rears. - H/K auto setup worked like a champ for surround sound, but for our setup I tweaked it a bit for the subwoofer. Easily done in manual mode.

3. Setup the Panasonic 3D Blu Ray via HDMI - no issues, You can even match names to HDMI inputs on back so they match the buttons on remote.

4. Setup DirecTV inputs (SAT/Cable) - no issues worked well and we can get 5.1 sound on channels that have it encoded.

5. HDMI out to LG tv. didn't' realize doing this at first took away the TV's sound. Which is OK since receiver sounds better than plain tv. it just requires another remote to be used for the process. Later today I'll look at making either or both the DirecTV / Harman Kardon Remotes universal for the system and thus streamline the 4 remotes we have out.

6. Remote is OK, buttons are somewhat readable for an older couple but reading glasses help til I have them memorized. switching things around and getting to H/K's setup required downloading and reading parts of the manual. Yes it doesn't come with the system. I had to download it. 8mb file

Overall - Very good purchase so far (3 weeks). Good sound - probably a bit more tweaking to do yet. Since it feels like the volume is about half way up for a presentable sound. was same w/ Polk Audio speakers too.
Easy to use, remote is decent (not great), wife said it looks good and there aren't a bunch of buttons for the grandson to see and go and try to push. it seems streamlined in looks.

cons - Manual had to be downloaded to figure out a couple of buttons and "How - to's". I missed the very low sales price.

Anyone with a phone that is missing the headphone jack knows just how annoying that is.  Normally I use BT, so this isn't an issue, but I recently had a need for regular headphones and I couldn't connect them.  Even if you use BT, get one of these to keep in the house!  Now I won't have to have that problem again.

I prefer to use a camera that is separate from my smartphone in most cases (though having a camera on my phone does come in handy). My DSLR also has a video mode but again I‚Äôd rather keep that separate, in this case because of the SD card capacity. I was interested in this video camera, mainly because it has the features I need in a video camera and it is relatively inexpensive. So far it has proven to be worth its asking price. It is not a high-end camera by any means but it is fine for general use and it is priced reasonably.

I‚Äôll start with listing what‚Äôs in the box: the camera, a remote control for the camera, the microphone with foam wind guard, a cable to connect the microphone to the camera body, batteries for everything (3 different kinds), a carrying case, a 32GB SD card (not sure what class), a USB cable, an HDMI cable and a user‚Äôs manual for the camera as well as the microphone. Everything you need to get started is already in the box.

The camera is very lightweight, more so than my Sony camera which is more solid and heavy. The Sony also cost several times more. The light weight and plastic housing makes this camera feel somewhat cheap, though that is more cosmetic. The weight is actually an advantage as it helps with one-handed filming where a heavier camera would cause fatigue faster.

This is a 24MP digital camera and while that is not the best resolution available it is better than I would expect at this price point. Video comes out clear and smooth for the majority of projects. If you really need a higher resolution (in which case you‚Äôre probably doing more professional work) you likely will need to spend much more.

One area of disappointment for me with this camera is the lack of optical zoom. The zoom is purely digital and in my experience a digital zoom solution is never as clear and accurate as an optical zoom. This camera is no exception and I find the digital zoom to be almost useless to me. It has some uses when not zoomed far, but when zooming in closer and closer it becomes clear that the image quality suffers.

The camera does have a fairly comprehensive menu system and is easy to navigate. I did find the user manual mildly helpful in better understanding what the camera can do for me.

Overall, this is a decent little camera, especially when considering that the cost is quite low. It is not a top of the line camera and it does lack an optical zoom, but for the price point it is a decent consideration if you need a video camera suitable for taking on vacation or for class projects.

I can't even put into words how much I love this tablet.  I have an iPad and also had an Asus tablet that was a huge piece of junk.  When I got my Lenovo (who I named Lenny) I was skeptical because of all of the issues I had with my Asus, but this tablet is the best on the market in my opinion.  The sound is Dolby Digital and the graphics are better than some tv's I have in my house.  I love the stand that is attached but the best part is the battery life.  I can go a full week without charging the tablet even when watching movies.  If you use the tablet for general use it will give you about 20 hours of battery life.  My ipad now sits in a drawer and I sent my Asus back to Amazon.  It as a headphone jack on the right side and you can buy an attachment keyboard that slides into that spot so you can use as a laptop.

It lights up everything beautifully. See picture if shashimi (sushi) that I took at night. However I've only used this light 3 times since buying it because the battery won't hold a charge. I'm down to my last 20%. I've used the wall charger to charge it all day, but it doesn't hold. Now reading the reviews I'm concerned it may be a lamp problem too. I think it's the battery, however but this really upsets me since I paid for a working battery and didn't get one. I feel CHEATED, but it's probably just poor product quality control. Now I have to buy a new battery because they sent me a faulty product. Also there's no indicator light on the battery like the ad and instructions say there would be. And the cord to charge the light is very short. This is only an issue because I'm plugging in the light to use it. However, plugging the charger in didn't make the failing battery last longer.

The quality of sound on these is quite good, its nothing thats going to blow your hair back but you'll be very content based off price. The microphone stands out above all other earned based microphones and I would say is its premium defining feature, the crispness and sensitivity makes audio in most call environments easier than face to face contact and will be my standard wear for corded contact microphones until they make a new version. Ace Product

I was so pleasantly surprised on how well thought out this monitor arm is designed. It was easy to install and easily adjustable. I loved how there were tiny holes near the clamp to store the provided tools. You can also route the wires through the base of the stand/arm which is a nice feature. I WILL be buying this again!

This item was great for what I needed it for.  The gripper that hold the  edges of your tablet could have been a little longer as my IPAD has a rugged case.  Overall this item clamp to my microphone stand nicely and serves its purpose.

I bought this mouse because the shape mimicked the Microsoft mouse I've been using with my desktop PC for ages. I recently purchased my first laptop and I wasn't sure I was going to like using the trackpad. The mouse is pretty cheaply made of thin and brittle plastic. There isn't even a storage space for the USB receiver it was shipped loose, rattling about in the battery compartment.

The mouse works. It fits my thick, stubby fingered hand okay. It's affordable as something to throw in the laptop bag in case you need a mouse for something quick and infrequent. If you're going to be using a mouse all the time you might want to invest in something a little better than this.

I purchased these primarily for use with MS Teams and other conference calls while working from home since people occasionally complained about audio from my Apple AirBook and AirPods (and other Bluetooth headsets). Long story short - No more complaints!

Noise cancellation due to ambient room noise is very good. Other conversations even in close proximity seem to be muted fairly well. Since these do not go in your ear, there is not reduction in room noise for you‚Äî only for people on the other end of the call.

i also hoped to be able to listen to music and other audio while working with them. Sound quality is good for news but is lacking for music. At high volumes, music with a lot of bass will cause an annoying vibration.

Other features: + I like being able to answer and hangup with a button press., - I‚Äôve yet to figure out if it‚Äôs even possible to advance to the next music track, -I got it to connect to 2 devices simultaneously once but haven‚Äôt been able to do it again and couldn‚Äôt figure out how to switch between the two.

The sound is good and substantial but not so different from other earbuds in this price range and serves my purposes but I really liked the way the buds fit in my ears.  The kind of hardwired part of the cable wraps around your ears to make the bud more stable while running which was a huge benefit for me.

To mention right off the bat, I am not even an amateur radio operator, just someone who enjoys radio. I find radio to be far more romantic and compelling than modern methods of broadcasting. Staying up late in the night and turning the dial with the soft glow of the tuner, the sound of static and mystery that can sometimes accompany radio broadcasts offers something truly genuine that you can't get anywhere else today. That feeling is priceless and not duplicable (If that was even a word).

Anyway, this radio is good quality and contains the capability needed to reach further than most others. If you enjoy radio as I do, a clock radio, ghetto blaster or home stereo won't cut it. If you know what I am talking about, then this radio is for you. I've stayed up many nights listening to Coast to Coast AM on the internet, but it lacked the feeling something like this radio will bring you. I was unable to pick up a station on my home stereo to listen to CTC and was forced to use the internet. The internet provided a clear, stereo sounding broadcast and was very clear.

The CC Radio has been spoken about on the program for many years. I finally picked one up and am very pleased with it's performance. I can now pick up the radio broadcast of Coast to Coast AM and with all the nuances I expect of a a late night radio broadcast. When interesting speakers talk about compelling topics, a crystal clear internet broadcast does not move you inside. However, using the CC Radio, the slight static, the slight fading in and out and all other fantastic experiences you can only receive using a real radio, it has the ability to make you feel and even send chills up your spine. There is just something a good solid radio can do for you that nothing else can and the CC Radio delivers on that 100%.

You will not be disappointed and I really need to get my license.

Great affordable external speaker with good sound.  We like to watch movies on our laptop and use this speaker for the sound.  Its has good quality sound.  I have now purchased one for personal use and two as gifts and each of us are happy with the speakers.  They are small and portable so when we travel we take it along.
These headphones are amazing and they really do improve hearing the music without blocking your peripheral hearing.

This low-priced, "no frills" stereo audio/video cable, offered by TedUnlimited LLC, comes without any retail packaging (no annoying plastic bubble or clamshell). The cable (red, white, yellow RCA connectors) seems to perform exactly the same as the equivalent cables that arrived with my cable box, VCR, and DVD player. The picture and audio quality is perfectly satisfactory (no noise, adequate volume) when used with a small (26") Sony HD TV.

The RCA plugs have wafer-thin curved metal "prongs" instead of solid rings, and do not connect to the sockets quite as tightly as do the solid-ring plugs on my other cables. The plugs look like the plugs on this similar--and possibly the same--product: [[ASIN:B000V0DY70 RiteAV - Audio Video RCA Cable 3ft]]. If your VCR, DVD, TV, and cable box are close together, the three-foot cable length is a big plus, because there is less cable to add to the cable tangle in back.

I purchased this cable as a replacement for a defective one left by the cable guy that was delivering too-soft audio. The cable is perfectly satisfactory for my simple, ordinary setup. It gets a 3.5 rating, rounded down to a 3 (it's okay), but it could easily be rounded up to a 4 (I like it) because of the low price.

[[VIDEOID:c8aba7ffbd252ac11229497fd6bb19e4]] Seems like a nice record system. I don‚Äôt have records but I like the speaker setup and thought they were a good size for a medium sized room to play music

I like the design and the finish. The wood look is very retro and i like the style.

It seems easy to use and setup but contact an audio professional if you need help

Overall it seems like a nice design and setup

We are a family of noise cancelling headphones. What I loved about these phones:
1. Great bass and really enjoyable experience whether music or audible books;
2. I have a big head, they fit comfortably as the design allows for a great level of flex on how the ear phones fit on your head;
3. The functional buttons are on both sides! And they are big enough that you can without pressing the wrong button. Too many times, the high end phones cram all the buttons on one side - why?
4. The noise cancelling works! We tested with our air conditioner on - it‚Äôs a rattler. Totally stripped out that noise and still enjoyed listening to my music. Great to use on TV with Bluetooth. Used it whilst I was walking in my concrete jungle environment. Totally enjoyed listening to audible books.
5. Comes with a beautiful case and add ons for airplanes, or connector if you don‚Äôt want to use the Bluetooth functionality. Bluetooth was easy to connect to our various Bluetooth devices: android and Apple.

This is not compatible with the note20 ultra. Do not buy if you want to charge ur phone and listen to music at the same time waist of money for my phone might work for my MacBook but I already have a headphone jack,  very disappointed.

So, I thought this would be just like any other stereo jack and what not but no it turned out this was an awesome stereo jack that I don't have to worry about the stupid thing breaking apart from each end because that is what happens all of the time with my other ones that isn't braided but is just the plain plastic stuff. This audio cable is awesome just for the braided cord alone because I go through these cables at least one every two months because they keep breaking at the ends. This one I think might actually last because there isn't a way for it to break. It works great too and is tip top quality. If you hate going through these cables as much as I do then totally get yourself one of these and save yourself some grief. This one is awesome! Totally recommend! Oh, and this is the perfect length to use in my car to hook my phone into the audio jack. Totally perfect!

My husband hates it, but I love it! LOL. The birds waking me up is so nice instead of the blaring of the radio or a buzzer. The gradual lightening of the lamp to imitate sunrise was really helpful during the Nov, Dec, and Jan months.

For the price, this portable CD Player has excellent sound quality and extra features to make it perfect for outdoor sports or light jogging and walking. The Anti-shock protection feature really works and the backband headphones are comfortable to wear and seem to stay in place fairly well.

The CD player has a grip band accessory that also works for attaching this CD player to any belt loop. I like the compact design and the simplicity of the features. You can buy an AC adaptor for home use.

The real beauty of this CD player is that you can use the program play feature to play up to 32 tracks in any order you wish. This is a good feature if you want to listen to just a few tracks on any specific CD. The program deletes itself when you turn off the unit. You can also use the random play feature.

~The Rebecca Review

I received one of these as a review sample and for what it does it deserves a full five stars.However, I am docking a star because there is a learning curve, due in part to sketchy documentation. I''ll get the challenges out of the way first.

Even with the included documentation it's difficult to figure out some aspects of this case. Some examples: there is a pull strap on the hard, snap-in holder for the iPad that is held in place by two labels that say 'do not tear'. That strap is intended to remain as is and the friction and pressure of the iPad will hold it in place. The instructions do not mention this and I removed it anyway because it looked like a temporary shipping solution.

Secondly, there are adjustable straps on the right and left sides of the case that prevent it from fully opening and remaining open. They are probably unnecessary and do create confusion. This case is not designed to fully open like a conventional case - it's designed to slide the iPad in and out using the T-shaped track. If you do want to use this as a conventional case you need only unfasten the two side straps and it will operate as such.

On the plus side, this case if one of the best I have come across with respect to protection. You can literally drop it from shoulder height and it will protect your iPad. The shoulder strap is designed to function as a set of pockets as well as a comfortable way to carry your iPad. And the material from which this case is constructed is built to take a lot of abuse and last much longer than your iPad.

Bottom line: this is a little over complicated and under documented in my opinion. However it's also ideal for folks who need a fairly rugged case. While the video on this page implies the target customer is a business user I think it's more ideally suited to first responders and folks who work in harsh environments.

I have owned both the 2 and the 3. I love the quicker charging 3. I keep them with me all the time. I love the ability to have them paired once and then they work across my all apple products. iPhone, iPad, Mac (multiple).

Cons:
The new control module. I would love to be able to take the control unit off the 2 and place it on the 3. I often do not get the controls to work on the first time, too spongy feeling for my preference. I would give it a 5 star if the control was better. I loved running with my 2 and how precise the controls were. I wish I had not give the 2 to my son, and I would take them running with me and keep the 3 for all other tasks.
Also I prefer the responsiveness of the power button on the v2.

All in all I am happy with the purchase as they are great and I can train myself to work around my issues above. I will anxiously wait for the next version. I must be happy as even with my noted issues I have purchased 4 sets of these for myself and family members.

Edit: The latest release 10.3 has alleviated most of my issue and the headphones seem more responsive to me. I have not changed my star rating as they still are not as responsive as my previous version.

These speaker pins were exactly what was needed to connect our stranded wire to the spring clip connectors on our speakers. Constructed like a Banana Plug, the pin head guarantees a good connection. The color coded males come 2 to a box, enough to hook up a pair of speakers. Being a staight pin reduces the chance of crossing the leads. The price is very low and includes fast shipping. Sring clip connectors have some shortcomings.  Unless the wire is cleanly stripped and cut to exacting lengths, strands of wire can be loose and short the hot to ground leads.  Also, they can be inconvenient as the wires must be disconnected when moving the speakers or cleaning and dusting near them.  The more often the leads are reconnected, the less the tension holding the wire becomes.  These shortcomings can create noise, stastic, even cause an amplifier to turn off or cause component repair problems.  These inexpensiive connectors reduce the chances of such problems while making a professional looking connection.
Little speaker with big performance. We use it in the golf cart. I highly recommend this.

I received this as a free review sample. Since Vince McLaren's exceptionally helpful review of August 21, 2016 covers what I also discovered, take the time to read his (and mark it helpful because he did an excellent job.)

It took me a few weeks to get around to writing this review because I needed to order an adapter for the 1998 Ford Explorer it was destined for, and also to have it professionally installed. The adapter I purchased is [[ASIN:B01ES32D7C Fits Ford Explorer 1998-2001 Double DIN Stereo Harness Radio Install Dash Kit]]. There are other kits by different brands for most vehicles. One of those will allow you to install (or have professionally installed) in older vehicles where this system will add some modern touches.

The reasons why I subtracted a star are the touchscreen is not as sensitive as I had hoped (not unusable, but frustrating sometimes), and the instructions are not that great. A professional will have no problem installing this unit, and there is a comprehensive wiring diagram in the product photos on this page. If you are planning to do the install yourself, refer to that photo to get an idea of the complexity of the job.

For me, the bluetooth capability and radio make this is great bargain in my opinion. I have a back-up camera that attaches to a license plate holder that adds that feature (you will need to provide your own camera, but they are inexpensive.) While this will display videos, you will need to load them via the TF card slot because this has no DVD (or CD) slot for that kind of media. Frankly, streaming music via bluetooth obviates the need for a CD (in my opinion), and I do not foresee myself ever needing to use any video player in the driver/front passenger compartment of a vehicle. If those are important to you, this is not the in-dash solution for you.

My overall impression is this is a good - and very inexpensive - solution for upgrading in-dash entertainment and hands free solutions in older vehicles. Before you plunk down your money, though, make sure that this will fit your vehicle, and that there is an adapter kit available for installing it in your vehicle's make, model and year.
This a really good stand alone speaker!!  Easy set up, play time is great!  Would definitely recommend!

My son recently built his own gaming computer and was looking for some external speakers to go with. These speakers provide decent sound. He's not an audiophile by any means, but for his gaming purposes, he's pleased with the bass/treble souds that these speakers give. There's no sound distortion when it gets loud. These are definitely an improvement over the speakers that are built in.

Wow Heos vs. a $$100 bluetooth boom box, no contest. My bluetooth boom box connectct every time. My Heos gives me a nice red biking light on my way too expensive amp.
Used to love Denon, but their software chumps need to get the boot.
NIice hardware, but their software sucks.

I recently purchased a new [Windows] laptop that has a Type C connector, and I selected this unit to get more USB ports as well as the card reader. So far it has worked out well for me and it seems to work as designed, and with no tweaks or software installation required.

This little unit is small and it easily fits in a shirt pocket though the cord does impact the way it fits in said pocket. It‚Äôs a little bigger than a comb but smaller than a candy bar. It feels solid and well-made and so far has shown no signs of fatigue or weakness.

I plugged it in and the fit was very snug so I had to work with it to get it plugged in properly. That‚Äôs actually a positive ‚Äì it should not come unplugged unexpectedly when I move my laptop or plug something else into it, a problem I have had on occasion with MicroUSB devices.

Windows recognized it immediately and it didn‚Äôt seem to need any extra device drivers or anything to make it work. It picked up the Ethernet interface as well as the USB hub, and that‚Äôs really all I would expect before plugging in anything else. The card reader works and I was able to read images off of the card I use in my camera through this device.

I have not yet tried it under Linux but that‚Äôs coming shortly. I also have an Android tablet with a Type C port with which I will try this device as well.

I have not yet tried the HDMI adapter. I have a use for it as my laptop actually does not have an HDMI port on-board and I‚Äôd like to attach it to my television to stream video.

Would I add anything? I would have liked to see an integrated wireless adapter or a Bluetooth receiver built in, though I have those built in to my system and adding those to this unit would drive up the cost a bit. I would probably make the unit slightly larger too.

So far, this device has been solid for me. It works right out of the box without any setup required ‚Äì plug it in and you‚Äôre ready to go.

I have an old Toshiba TV that I bought from a friend who moved, and never got the remote. I've also got some stereo equipment that is missing the remote. It's actually been really hard to find third party replacements that support these obscure products, so I've been using an old LG phone (V20) from back in the days of IR blasters to program them. It's annoying because the phone is getting old and clunky and the battery has to stay charged, but at least if I lose it I can use Google services to locate it.
This universal IR is the best, and replaced ALL of those features now! It actually pairs with my current phone via an app, and you're able to really easily program the different functions and devices, and thanks to the app's UI, it is easy to understand what you are doing. It works great with the audio equipment and Toshiba TV, and if I misplace the remote the app has a find feature! So cool! I'm very happy with this device and I recommend it. I'm going to go put my old LG V20 on ebay now because this was literally the only reason I kept it!

Bought these to clip earbud cable to my collar on the back of my shirt. Eliminates a lot of the pulling and snagging on my wired buds. For my wireless earbuds, I have the kind that wrap around the neck. The problem with those is when you take one out to rest it on your shoulder, it eventually slips down as far as it can and pulls on the other ear. Or when jogging the cable would get lopsided and if I turned my head to check for traffic, it would pull on the ear. Hooking this up eliminates all those hassles. Wish I'd thought of buying these sooner.

One tip for folks who want to fix the "playing out of order" bug when copying files in an audiobook folder over, on MacOS you can use the following command to ensure that a folder's contents are copied to the xtrainerz in alphabetical order:

rsync -rv --ignore-existing <source_dir> <xtrainer_dir>

Then, the files will play in the correct order on the device. This command will skip/ignore existing files if they already exist for whatever reason.
I purchased the speaker for my friend she came over and heard mine and I told her it wasn't my phone it was my new speaker so for her birthday I bought her a new one she loves it

It doesn't get much easier than this to enjoy music with no cords or wires. So nice to not have a cord to contend with!! Set up was easy and sound quality is great. Paired easily via bluetooth with iphone 7plus. So far, these have been very comfortable to wear and stay in my ears while I'm working. I ordered specifically because of the diamond coating. I work in an environment that has dust and particles flying around all the time and wanted something slightly more durable. Can take them out and put in pocket too without worries that they'll get tangled and thrashed. Well done, Anker.

I bought this for my son who is going to camp this year.  I wanted him to be able to record some memories with his friends and capture the beauty of the forest.  I know my son well enough to know that he might lose it so I didn't want to spend a lot.  This is definitely budget friendly,  but it is a much better camera than I expected and it came with extra accessories.  The set includes a tripod,  a carrying case,  and an extra battery.  The attached microphone has a cover to protect it from the wind so it's a great choice for the outdoors.  It's very easy to use and the picture quality is better than I hoped.  It even has a zoom feature.

Had one for over a year now and bought a second one for a private bedroom in case something happens in there. The buttons and dialer are great and will work the distance probably in any size house. The speaker phone part is not as sensitive as I would like, if you fall in one room and push the button, it's hard to hear a person that fell if they are too far away from the speakerphone part that is in the base unit. That's why I bought a second one. I did a lot of research among these with both a monthly plan and just the dialer like this one, and this unit is far better then almost all the others I looked into. My dad wears his on a Necklace around his neck

AND - about 6 months ago in 2012 - it probably saved my 94 year old Father's life !! Just like on TV, he fell and just couldn't get up by himself - pushed the button to call me - and I heard him in the background saying what happened and in 5 minutes I was there helping him. AND, if we weren't home or not close by his house, he also has the red emergency button for 911 if he couldn't reach us. That red one always works and tells 911 something is wrong and the location.

It Works !! and it's not just for old people that might fall down or worse, you can program it to call anyone and also has many other programing options. Definitely a great unit.

I was unsure about this case/keyboard because I like one that opens like a book & stays standing open. But thought I would try it. The stand is very sturdy & connects to the keyboard base w/ 3ea small but very strong magnets, and BEST of all.... I didn't have to pair the Bluetooth keyboard, it was automatic!!!!! This feels very rugged yet light weight. I traveled w/ it & it worked wonderful. Thank you! Well worth the price :-)

I got excited to see one of these small portable LED style ones that actually had a decent native resolution (most of them can accept 1080p, but are in reality only 800x600 resolution, or sometimes worse... 640x480!). This one is actually capable of displaying 720p of real dot resolution, which should make it at least as sharp as my Viewsonic and other traditional HD projectors. Ok, perhaps I'm spoiled, but I'm comparing this to our Viewsonic 720p projector that, to be fair cost me 3-4x as much.
And for the most part, it DOES work, however there are some caveats to its use. First of all, it doesn't seem as sharp as my 720p projector, even though it should have the requisite amount of dots. It's OK, its definitely better than the cheap 600p projectors, but something just isn't quite there when comparing side by side. It also doesn't get all that bright, but I suppose that's expected from the LED tech being used. You'll need black out shades or use it only during the night. Then there's the color- it isn't great. It works, but it has a cheap color reproduction that looks kind of flat and lifeless. Dark scenes sort of all blend together and become nearly impossible to see. It lacks the vibrancy of even an inexpensive television from decades ago. It gets the job done, but hardly the "theater experience" if you've been waiting to see that latest action/vfx film the way it was intended. It will look better on your TV at home, the only thing this has going for it is the large projection experience. For example, if you just want to give your kids a backyard movie night and don't care that the color and detail won't be as great as your indoor system, it will do the job on the cheap. I personally would not give up my mid-range projector for this one.
One thing that I found particularly annoying is that rather than the optical zoom and focus dials found on usual projectors, there is only a focus and tilt dial. No zoom. That means you have to physically move the projector closer or further to get it to reach the correct size you are shooting for. That actually got in the way of using it in a couple of specific places my other projectors can be used at optimal sizes.
That's not to say it gets everything wrong- I DO like that it is small and light and can even be turned on it's back to aim at the ceiling. That's something my big projector can't do, due to the airflow and cable management sticking out the rear. It also has a standard 1/4" 20 threaded tripod mounting point, so you can place this onto a tripod and get maximum mounting freedom. That will come in handy as I've always wanted to watch a movie in bed on the ceiling. But otherwise, don't think this projector will be as good as the other mid-rangers out there. This is still very much a low end projector. You'll have to spend at least 2-3x as much to get a decent home theater style experience, and much more if you want a high end one that will handle FHD/4k to get the real deal. This is more of a specialty use item.

I recently purchased a monitor and keyboard to use at my desk. I have been using ThinkPad laptops exclusively for a few years.
I selected the Preferred Pro USB Keyboard. I almost went with one of the TrackPad keyboards ([[ASIN:B00C32FWJC ThinkPad Compact Bluetooth Keyboard with TrackPoint - US English]] or [[ASIN:B00F3U4TQS Lenovo ThinkPad Compact USB Keyboard with TrackPoint - US English]] ), because I love the TrackPoint. However, I needed a numeric keypad, and I didn't like the idea of having a separate one. I chose the Preferred Pro on the strength of reviews. I was not disappointed.

The keyboard is comfortable to type on. They tops of the keys are textured, and they feel nice under my fingers. The key travel feels wonderful, and I can type faster on this keyboard than on a laptop. The built-in wrist rest is also very comfortable to use. The only issue I've had with the keyboard is that I keep hitting the Windows key instead of control because I'm used to the layout being Fn-Ctrl-Win. I'm sure with time I'll stop making this minor mistake.

Pros: Traditional key layout and spacing. 3 simple lights for Caps Lock, Num Lock, and Scroll Lock. Keytops are slightly textured. Great Key travel. Built-in wrist rest. Professional black, dark gray, & blue color scheme.

[[VIDEOID:5cccf65ebb09ed8723542bed292c2771]] This Sharper Image USB Fan with Soft Blades is stylish, sleek, compact and SAFE! Between the lamp and my laptop it can get uncomfortably warm in my work area so I thought this would also be great solution to keep things cool. My laptop gets pretty hot because I push the processor really hard and my cooling pad isn't always sufficient.

WHAT I LIKE ABOUT IT...

The metal frame has a slim form factor and does not take up valuable space in my crowded little work area. I could even hang it on a wall hook if I wanted to keep it off the surface, which makes it very versatile.

It has 2 speeds, is relatively quiet and moves a lot of air. It's very effective.

Flexible blades keep it safe around fingers and pets.

It works great and does what I need it to do while looking pretty stylish. It's the type of product you would expect from Sharper Image in terms of quality and style and I cannot find anything not to love.

I'm a fan of Panasonic's electronics, and have been since I first used their GH camera line for work, and the DVX prosumer cameras before that. I was excited for a chance to replace my working headphones with ones from Panasonic, however I found it interesting that the plug type was NOT MENTIONED on this listing! The last pair of headphones + mic that I ordered came with a USB plug. It worked fine on my laptop, but not on my phone or tablet, obviously. I want a regular headphone jack, as in 1/8" or 3.5mm (whatever you want to call it!) to be compatible with all my things, and not rely on the limitations of bluetooth.
I was a little bit nervous about buying this one since it doesn't say anywhere that it is, in fact, a standard TRRS headphone-jack sized plug, but I'm happy to report that it IS! And the sound quality is what I expected from Panasonic, a good value for the price. One thing to note, however, is that this requires both sides have a wire going to the plug. This is a seriously old-school design that I almost forgot existed. Modern headphones have a single point of cable that splits to the other side in the band, however this is more like earbuds in that there's a wire going to each side.
It's not a deal breaker, it works fine and some people may actually prefer that look, but personally I'm worried about it being another point of contact that could get snagged/rip/break/go wrong, and actually prefer the more modern single-side cable style. But this is still a great pair of traditional tried-and-true headphones!

What I really like about this desktop is the fact that you can adjust the level of the heights you wanted. It is very heavy duty so you can put a lot of stuff on it. I use it as my DJ station so the speakers are a little heavier than the ones you would normally use with a computer. Be careful when you let it down that your hands do not get caught underneath. Thank you for reading my review. I hope it will be helpful for you. God bless you and yours and may the rest of your life be the best of your life.  OZ

I recently acquired a pair of Able Planet Sound Clarity (SC hereafter) headphones, just 6 days after purchasing a pair of Bose Quiet Comfort 15 Noise Canceling headphones (QC15 hereafter). I got a very good deal on the Able Planet phones, which is the main reason I bought them. With both sets in hand, I have been able to do a side-by-side comparison between them. Bose is generally regarded as the Gold Standard when it comes to active noise canceling phones so this review is spun in that regard. I have not had a chance to try the Sennheiser offerings, so I cannot comment on those.

In summary, the Able Planet phones compare reasonably well against the Bose phones, but there are some trade-offs between the two. Which set to buy depends on the personal preferences and intended uses.

First off, the phones look very similar to one another. The general design is the same, with an over-the-ear design, soft pads and an on-off switch for noise cancellation. There are some very distinct differences, though, that are not obvious at a glance. First, the detachable cord plugs in somewhat differently, the SC having a jack that this flush with the phone and the QC15 having a jack that is inset within the base of the phone, with a molded plug. The battery compartment is also accessed differently, the SC having a sliding cover exposing 2 AAA batteries and the QC15 having a flip-up cover for a single AAA battery.

Another visible difference is in the cord that is included with the SC phones - it has a volume control thumb wheel. The QC15 phones have simply on/off. I like being able to adjust the volume without fiddling with the source such as a computer.

Comfort-wise, Bose has an upper hand on Able Planet. While both have an over-the-ear design which covers the ear, the SC cup is a hair smaller and as such it cannot cover the whole ear as easily as the QC15. That said, the SC phones are still comfortable and the difference is minor.

The noise canceling aspect of the SC phones is very good but it does not compare to the QC15 headset. Standing next to a running air handler that is roughly the size of a minivan, the SC is able to wipe out a good portion of the noise to make the level comfortable. The QC15 wiped out the sound of the air handler completely, to the point that it was difficult to tell if it was even turned on.

I was interested in the Linx Audio aspect of the SC phones and at first I was very disappointed. The high range is somewhat dampened, "S" sometimes sounding like "PH". However, the mid and low ranges are solid and are very rich, whereas Bose sounds good but has remarkably less depth. The QC15 phones are primarily noise canceling phones, and sound quality is secondary to that. The SC headset achieves a better balance of sound to noise canceling.

Once very distinct advantage that the SC headset has is that the phones will work without power, though noise canceling does not work in that case. The QC15 requires a working battery and must be turned on to work at all.

Right out of the box, my SC phones were defective. I contacted Able Planet, hoping I could get some advice on how to adjust them, but instead I got an RMA number. Less than 2 weeks later I had a new, working pair in my hands that work much better than the initial pair. Customer service at Able Planet is very responsive, professional and courteous. With the LIFETIME warranty on their headphones, Bose cannot answer with their 2-year warranty.

Which pair to buy is a matter of preference and intended use. If the intended primary use is noise cancellation and comfort, Bose is the right choice. For listening to music with the ability to engage noise canceling when needed, Able Planet is a better choice. Considering the 2-year Bose warranty against an Able Planet lifetime warranty, though, is hard to ignore.

As I use my phones for listening to music more than anything else, I use the Able Planet headset as my primary headset and I keep my Bose headset as a backup.
