My AT&T/Direct TV salesman talked me into buying this worthless overpriced junk to somehow enable voice commands for my DirectTV remote (they are about the only tv service that has a remote without it).  Didn't work.  3 IT people in the family worked on it for over 2 hours just to get it connected to the Internet.  The only instructions I found on the Internet about using it to voice control my remote basically required "hacking" and reprogramming the Echo.  So gave up on that and cancelled by Direct TV service to go back to my old service that had voice commands and a wonderful search engine built right into the remote.  We did get it to stream music - and it sounded like a scratchy LP. So I have to buy expensive speakers for that? I'm out of table space for all of this and hate ugly cords running everywhere.  I'll just stick a CD in my DVD player or computer and listen to the music I want to listen to.  Siri on my iPhone has a better search engine.  It seems like every device you want to connect to (and I really don't want to connect it to anything - I simply don't care) costs more money for special equipment that will work with the Echo.  Spent HOURS of research on the internet trying figure out it's vague instructions.  The only time I need a smart anything is when I'm in my car and need directions - Siri does that quite well most of the time and I don't need to buy anything else.  In my home I have two computers, my iPhone and television.  All are pretty smart and keep me well informed on news and weather.  I have enough noise in my life - I don't need a device that just adds scratchy noise.  As far as music streaming Sirius is a huge waste of money so I stopped that service and decided my hundreds of CD's and/or an MP3 player can play all the music I want to hear.  I don't need any more complications in my life and I'm sick of trying to get devices to talk to each other - and the echo is the worst example of this.

The sound quality of these earbuds is excellent, with Bluetooth 5.3 technology and Hi-Fi stereo, I can clearly hear every note and beat of my favorite music. One of the features that I really love about these earbuds is the LED power display on the charging case, which shows me the battery level of both the earbuds and the charging case. This helps me to keep track of the battery life and avoid any surprises.

The earbuds themselves are comfortable to wear and fit securely in my ears. I can wear them for extended periods of time without any discomfort. Plus, they are compatible with iPhone, Android, and Windows devices, so I can use them with all my devices without any issues.

Overall, I am very satisfied with my purchase of the Bluetooth Headphones True Wireless Earbuds. They are a great value for the price and have exceeded my expectations in terms of sound quality and features. I highly recommend them to anyone looking for a reliable and high-quality pair of wireless earbuds.

I like the sound of these earbuds way more than I expected: they're clean and clear through my hearing range, and I didn't even have to fiddle with the EQ settings to get there. I also have the Liberty 2 Upgraded version, and while those are very good, these are clearly superior.

I did use the Soundcore app to update the firmware and enable LDAC: you'll definitely want to do this before you begin using them. Also, there are other settings on the app you might find useful.

They are also very comfortable to wear for long periods (I use them at my desk while working), and even using LDAC (which uses a lot more power) the battery lasts as long as I've needed so far. The case is nice and compact, and of course charges the earbuds quickly. The only thing I would grumble about (and now I'm being very fussy) is that I have to turn the earbuds over to get them into the right position for the case.

Another note: Anker was offering a "used like new" item for a much lower price, so I decided to try them. I'm very happy I did, since they really were just like a new product, seemed unused (probably a quick return). All the earpiece bits were new, of course.

Highly recommended for excellent sound and comfort at a very affordable price (new or used).

OK, first the pros. The price was very reasonable and knowing that it was low priced I did not expect it to perform like a $1,000 TV. Also, it was easy to set up. It was easy to pick up and place on my stand. Also, the legs were easy to attach. All I had to do was get a Phillips screwdriver and screw in four screws. Also, it looks sleek and modern. And I like having three HDMI ports which is rare for a set in this price range. It's good that it has both analogue and digital audio outputs as well.

Now the cons. First of all, I don't like they way you have to change inputs. On my old TV all I had to do was press one button on the remote and toggle through the inputs. But on this one you have to first hit the input button on the remote, then you have to press one of the arrow keys on the remote until the input you want is highlighted, then press the OK button. That process is way too cumbersome.

Secondly, I am not satisfied with the picture quality. Since I got it yesterday I have been trying to adjust the color settings to get the picture the way I want it but I just can't seem to get it right. What really irritates me is skin tones. Fair skinned people look like they have a bright white light shining on their face. Also, dark scenes such as at nighttime are too dark and it's hard to make out anything. Adjusting the brightness settings helps somewhat, but then when the scene changes to daytime it is much too bright so I have to turn the brightness down again.

I am debating whether to send it back. I hate to have to try to put it back in its box and then ship it back to Amazon. I think I will wait a few days to see if I can get the picture right. I will update this review after I decide what to do.

I bought 2 of these around Christmas 2021. One for myself, and a friend of mine as we're both avid users of AirPods Max.

I received the "Version 1" of the product, while my friend received "Version 2."

So let's get into it!

I assembled version 1 and to my distraught face, the stand was incredibly wobbly. The pole piece mostly didn't fit the screw cuttings in the metal and overall the product was incredibly dissatisfying and took forever to essentially assemble wrong (since correct assembly was impossible).

Meanwhile, my friend raves about how great it is (he got version 2). So seeing some folks had similar issues, I contacted support. About a week later I received a very nice message back. The thing I appreciate most is this wasn't a simple PR cut and paste. This sounded like it was directly from someone who really cared.

He took my address and promised to ship out a replacement with Version 2 immediately. Not only that, he actually explained in detail the issues I had experienced and how they had fixed them with Version 2. He even went as far as to confirming version 2 was shipped to my friend.

They explained they had requested amazon remove version 1 but were rejected. So, if you receive a wobbly version 1 product (the serial number is on the top of the base stand), they ENCOURAGE you to contact them and they will happily replace it with version 2.

So, the product was jacked, which this company admits. They're doing absolutely everything in their power to correct the issues and are a fantastic example of how you build customer trust.

Thanks again for everything.

Version 2 of this product is absolutely fantastic, sturdy, does not shake or move at all. The metal is very nice looking and makes for a great set piece on your desk or otherwise. As soon as you pull your headphone off, they reconnect as you're used to when pulling them out of the case. Similarly when you place them on the stand, they'll disconnect instantly.

Great stuff and thanks!

So last thing to check if no sound but VU meters moving and headphones sound OK. Yes, the factory installed speaker wires were pushed too far into the connectors so the insulation prevented metal-to-metal contact. Solution: back out the speaker wires an reinstall. Just trying to be helpful. 2 days later: noted clipping and crackle in the FM radio at peak signal. As pointed out elsewhere, this is a bad FM radio. Occasional click/pop on the CD.

I really like this speaker system. My other speakers are iPod specific so it is nice to have one that takes just a mini stereo, although it leaves you with the dilemna of where to put an iPod when you connect it. I also like the indoor outdoor options, although this is definitely not a weather proof solution.

The sound is very nice although directional so it sounds a little tinny if you are not directly in line with the speakers.

Pros
+ Universal
+ Nice Design
+ Easy Controls
+ nice sound
+ optional battery power

Cons
- No great place to mount an attached ipod

This was a perfect power strip for me for use in my bedroom.  My nightstand has several items on it (Alexa, phone charger, lamp, white noise machine) and I only have a two outlet wall unit. This power strip is great, it only has a 4 ft. cord which makes it perfect for my arrangement (so no lengthy bulky cord) and everything fits in well. I also love the design and color. Although you can't see it behind my nightstand, it has a great textured look to it and it is crisp and clean. If you are in the market for a shorter length power strip this unit would be great for you. Highly recommend.

These Chromebooks are a weird hybrid of tablet and real laptop. They don't do everything can full laptop does, but they do more than a simple tablet. Oddly enough, there is a place for these. This is the second one we've had in the last few years.

This one is very light and easy to grab and use in the armchair or while on the road in the passenger seat. The screen is vibrant and the colors are true when watching a movie or looking at your photos. The beauty of a Chromebook is having super easy access to everything stored in your existing Google cloud account - photos, books, passwords, contacts, email, etc. This syncs exactly like your phone and tablets do so you can switch between machines and still keep current.

I've been pleased with the battery life on the Acer. It can go with light use and sleep mode a couple of days before needing to be charged. It has no trouble connecting to and staying connected to our WiFi even outside on the patio. I've connected my Bluetooth headphones and watched a movie with it and it works fine. I like this and find I'm grabbing it more often than I thought I would.

First for the pros: Beautiful looking, sleek, shiny and artfully designed to fit any style room. Relatively easy to install (being a non-techy person I actually followed the verbal audio instructions easily and flawlessly). The wireless woofer is an asset with no ugly wires (as my previous Panasonic system had)and amazing (loud) bass tones. The sound is amazing (which I expected from Bose). The cons: I am having a difficult time using the remote control which is supposed to act as an all-in-one device (supposedly so I can get rid of all these little dedicated remotes I have for the DVD, television, cable, etc). For whatever reason, the device sticks frequently or doesn't respond to commands and I end up reverting back to the old standby remotes. I am disappointed that a company like Bose couldn't have perfected something like this better. But then I keep thinking, maybe I did something wrong, not sure. The only other con is the price. If this was in a $700-1000 range I would tell you to snatch it up in a heartbeat. But for $1500 you are honestly paying for the name (and the status symbol bragging rights to say you own a Bose system). Wait for the price to come down and grab it. You honestly won't be disappointed with the sound quality nor the set up (and, who knows, maybe it's me in not being able to get the remote to work properly with all my other devices).

It's hard to hate on this drone when it is flying. Mechanically it performs very well in the air. The camera is great & the camera stabilization works very well. The app has been a frustrating experience that has kept me from fully exploring the capabilities of the drone.

After the last app & firmware update we have experienced freezing of the video feed, disconnects from the phone & disconnects from the radio. The good news is that, in the last case, the drone dutifully returned to its starting spot. I didn't have those issues before the update but I did have others.

I have put in a couple of tech requests & their support is very good. In some cases a confirmation email the same or next day & resolution in another day or so. In one case a very nice young man called me to talk me through a gyro calibration.

We have enjoyed using the camera to fly it around the neighborhood. The camera function is fantastic. The attitude adjustment for the camera is intuitive & handy. I'm still learning to fly by the screen so I like being able to "look" up & down to make sure I'm not about to hit something and figure out the location by looking at landmarks & streets.

On the drone platform, the camera can be set to track a person with just the camera & the drone stationary or have the drone follow the person while tracking. We used that to record my daughter's color guard practice. It also has a "point of interest" feature where it flies circles over a particular spot & the operator can start or stop recording while it it is circling. I'm thinking this will be cool for parties this Summer when we can finally have people over again. For now I have is top quality shots of the top of my camper & green pool.

It camera mode it performs very well as a stable, tracking camera. The camera gimble has a lot of range to track a person moving about & the tracking works well. If the person moves out of the frame it will not re-aquire them though in my experience. The camera can be mounted on a tripod or used as a hand-held "camcorder". On a tripod, it kind of hangs off to the side & down so it will interfere with some tripod setups. It is also a bit bulky to use as a camcorder but the stabilization is so good I forgive that. In either configuration a phone has to be used to stop & start recording or take pictures which I do not like & I hope they put out a bluetooth button for that.

The controller is small compared to the ones I used for model airplanes & it is easy to hold. There is no attachment point for a lanyard. The phone is held on a mount that extends out & up & puts the phone in a good place to see but puts a lot of weight up high. The gimbles have a rubber gasket around that makes them water resistant & doesn't interfere with their operation. The controller charges with a mini-usb (ugh) & connects to the phone with included USBC or Lightning cables. The cord going to the phone could be a little more tidy.

The case is nice, thick foam & will hold everything needed to fly except maybe a second battery. It's sturdy enough to put in checked luggage (with the batteries removed of course).

The beginner mode is seriously slow & a good way to get used to flying especially for someone who is learning nose-in hovering & other basics. It also makes a very stable camera platform.

A couple of observations:
I am not great at sorting out things on the app & would prefer robust instructions. I had no idea that the aforementioned gyro calibration was something I could perform myself or that I should have known where to look for it. It took me several tries to figure out how to turn on the tracking features (it has to be "started" after turning it on).

This is my first serious drone so I can't adequately compare it to other models. I used to fly model airplanes & helicopters decades ago & I tend to try to fly these quadrotors like an airplane in line of sight flight. This model seems to resist that more than others that I have flown & tries to force a flat plane rather than let me bank it & swoop around (I hope that makes sense).

I worked in a hobby shop for several years when I was younger (a long time ago). This is exactly what people who came in dreamed of buying; a small, aircraft that could fly in the backyard or far away that doesn't require a steep learning curve to fly or maintain. The camera adds to the fun & makes it useful.
This product is made of cheap plastic.  It is overpriced.  In a few months, when USB C is added to iphones it will be obsolete.  It did not recognize my USB device (audio interface).  Returned.

I bought these for my mom and me. She likes the old fashioned in line earbuds.
First glance and feel, they have a nice feel and the material is durable. I like the magnet that holds the earbuds together. Its a decent case to hold everything together.
Sounds quality is not as impressing. The noise cancelation is not truly noise canceling. Phone calls are not very clear and microphone doesn't make me sound clear. Music is not the best if you like heavy bass songs.
For the price I expected a little more.

No longer will the kids camp out in my space where the wifi is the best. No longer will the RING doorbell disconnect b/c of weak signal.

These were easy to get up and running and running they have. Zero service interruptions now.
I lightly dampened the cloth and wiped the screen clear of all smears. Exactly what I was looking for. I'll buy this again and recommend it.

I have a wireless mic that I want to use with my camera, however the receiver has a hardwired 1/4" jack and my camera uses a standard headphone sized 1/8" jack. I've been using one of those adapters to go from 1/4 to 1/8 that sits at the end of a cable, and those have always given me grief.  This is much more solid connection as the cable IS the adapter. It is much more reliable and has been great so far. I highly recommend it over an additional adapter on the cable.

My spouse tends to fall asleep with headphones in, so they break often & has used up all my spares. Needed to get an inexpensive bunch that still sounded good to keep in, so that we have a handy supply. These fit the bill, they sound much better than I expected, and the price was good.

*updated 11/2022 - I keep ordering these as spouse loves them but destroys them constantly. I like to keep a good supply in stock for him.

These headphones are a different class product than my other cheap earphones. These have great noise cancelling properties, and the sound is AMAZING! The ear pads are comfortable and fit over my ears well.  They help suppress the ambient  sound. The headband part folds up small to fit in the beautiful protective case.  The sound on these headphones are excellent. The bass and the treble sound great without bottoming out.  The volume control and skip forward buttons are easy to access.  You can also use these as a phone headset. The Bluetooth is easy to connect when you know what yhe name of these are. I don't think it comes up as "sony headet" as i believe it should. Thats my only complaint- its hard to figure out Bluetooth item it is on your phone.

Luckily, both cables are working as advertised. I am hoping for longevity, as we all know many 3.5mm patch cables can fail after a while.

The cables seem well constructed for their reasonable price.

I have one going from my TV's headphone jack into an expensive external speaker. The other cable is going from my iMac's headphone jack into another nice speaker. Sound quality is as expected and desired.

I got these for my 6 year old, who loves them. His old headphones hurt his ears after a while, but these are nicely padded and comfy. Sturdy for kids too. Love the cloth-like cord also, seems more durable than a standard cord.
It clamps onto the desk and is easy to use.  It doesn't take up workspace on the desktop, but is still easy to access.

I love listening to audiobooks as I work so I often have my wireless headphones in my ears for many hours at a time. It‚Äôs amazing what a difference these memory foam replacement ear pads tips have made in terms of comfort.

Before I got these I would find my ears sore after having my earbuds in for 3 or 4 hours, these form to my ears perfectly so I‚Äôm able to listen all day without my ears ever getting sore.

As with any ear pad tips you‚Äôll have to figure out what size fits you best. I‚Äôve found the medium size fit me best. After I figured that out I ordered another set in all medium size so I could switch out all my ear bud tips.

These are well worth the price as they will help you enjoy both your earphones and whatever you are listening too exponentially more.

I definitely recommend this product.

Thanks for reading my review. I enjoy writing them as I value reading other‚Äôs reviews when I‚Äôm making a buying decision. I regularly update my reviews to reflect any changes I may discover and to include helpful tips you may need if you purchase the product. I will always make every effort to answer any questions I can as it is my pleasure to help.

There is a constant commercial on the home screen to try and get you to buy a new book.  Very annoying.  The charging usb was absurdly short with no adapter.  Battery life for me is maybe a day, I like to use headphones with audible books and listen to when I am doing housework or yard work.  It is only as good as your wifi.  so if your wifi is spotty, so will your download.  For the money I paid and the promises made, not worth it.

The polk website gives more realistic frequency information.
The 30Hz - 20kHz is a little deceptive. Notice the "Lower -3db Limit" is 50Hz.
For example, the 8 inch speakers:

Overall Frequency Response 30Hz - 20kHz
Lower -3dB Limit 50Hz
Upper -3dB Limit 20kHz
Nominal Impedance 8 ohms
Recommended Amplifier Power 20 - 100 w/channel
Efficiency 90 dB

The sound quality is so much better than the other Echo dots even the Echo Show I have. The speakers are a lot nicer. I got it when it was a special that the colored light bulb came with it. My daughter loves the light bulb. She loves how it changes colors and the whole room changes that color. It is nice how Alexa will turn the light one when asked.

So we needed new computer speakers and of course the kids liked the ones that light up üôÑ

I was looking for something not too expensive and has decent sound quality- enter this pair.

For the price they are just right- easy to hook up, don't take up too much room on the desk, plus the sound is very good- even on the kids computer games üòÄ
We use this occasionally it's okay. Not extraordinary. Pretty much what you expect from a speaker around $20

Bone conduction headphones have become quite popular and because of this, there are many to choose from. This specific model is quite minimalist. A thin metal frame with the vibration units and electronics hanging off it.

In terms of comfort, there is no adjustability to the metal frame so it may take some getting used to because the frame may feel like they are too big or too small depending on your head size. For me it felt a little bit loose but I came to realize that it actually stayed where you place it and it really wasn't a problem.

For sound quality, this bone conduction headphone will never match a nice pair of over-ear headphones but that really isn't what it's for. By leaving the ears open, one is still able to stay aware of the surroundings, making it great for cycling and jogging where hearing the traffic is essential for safety reasons.

A pair of earplugs are included with this product and with one or both in, one can really appreciate the difference between regular headphones and bone conduction. You can still hear the music (or in my case, audiobook) through the earplugs because of the bone vibration but all outside sound is cut off. This means that you'd be able to listen to music over the sound of a loud machine.

I have tried a few different pairs of bone conduction headphones and these are the ones that I have stuck with so far. The buttons maybe be somewhat limited (just two buttons that control volume and power), but they are easily reachable and not hard to press and the IPX6 means it's water resistant against rain and sweat.

I don't like the look, but it does the job.
**********update************
After using this a while I decided to buy one of these for my mom. The one she had was a real pain in the wherever!
We're both pleased with the swivel capability....it's something I'd always complained about on my old one that didn't swivel, which made a cramped area or not being able to use an outlet because the plug-end of cord was oversized.
I've also changed my 4 star to a five...

The form fitting is perfect and while I do feel my phone is highly protected, the case doesn't make the phone too large to handle or carry around (as you are aware the iPhone 6 + is already pretty big). While I like the idea of being able to change the back plate to different colors, I always stick with the black one. It's not a feature that I care much about personally, although it is neat. The case looks pretty mean overall and I love showing it off (as with most NewTrent products).

As always the screen protector is great and feels very similar to the actual glass screen and does not distort color or text. The buttons for sound are perfect, they depress smoothly and function the changing of the volume 100% of the time.

The covers for the charger, headphones and volume are difficult to open though. While I do appreciate the fact they are great to offer resistance to water and dust, etc. I do feel they could be a bit easier to open. They feel quite stiff and can be difficult to open (perhaps the tabs can be 'improved'). Another and more serious gripe I have is the inability to reach the vibrate/silent switch when it's cover is open. I have a very hard time reaching in there to toggle the switch because the cutout is too small.

The sound quality is good and I have no complaints there.

My phone has survived two nasty drops without a scratch.

If you want a case that offers top notch protection and looks great too - look no further!

I love music, so when I got PC headphones to help me block out background noise and do my work, I wanted to be sure they would be great for music.  The active noise canceling is a great feature, it works well.  The sound quality is as good as other pairs that I have owned in the same price range.  The notes claim it is optimized for gaming, but I found no problems using it for music and feeling like I was there.  I recommend them!
An easy and affordable solution. A little tricky to get these mounted so your speaker is perfectly level as each bracket might not be exactly the same.
Nice all around speaker wire at a very fair price.  Like the red/black combination.  Also very flexible.  Good buy...

These are an absolute steal for the price.  You're not going to replicate the sound of $150+ headphones, but they'll do fantastic for a young kid or someone who just needs something for voice communication

Fits perfectly on my new, "mid-2017" 15-inch MacBook Pro. Like others here, I have not needed to use the little pieces of stickum tape. It's really precision-crafted and fits flawlessly. It also seems to quiet the clacky butterfly switches a bit! With this in place, they make a nicely damped thumping sound.

I'm happy.

UPDATE: Just thought of something. This latest (2016/2017/2018) MacBook Pro generation has a reputation for unreliable keywords. In fact, Apple just announced an extended warranty. What actually happens is that tiny bits of debris get into the key mechanisms, which are exquisitely engineered and miniaturized... to the point that small pieces of dust can cause the keys to malfunction. This keyboard cover should really help that!

I‚Äôm ecstatic that I can hear TV again! I‚Äôm profoundly hearing impaired (90%) and this speaker system is the answer to my prayers and dreams!

I have it connected to my HGTV with an RCA adapter and my headphones are connected to the headphone jack on the side of the left satellite speaker. I have to keep my TV speakers set permanently off and only watch TV with headphones. (Otherwise I‚Äôd be evicted from my apartment).

The sound is crystal clear and the volume control is only halfway up! I‚Äôm amazed at the top quality and power of this Klipsch sound system. It‚Äôs like being at the movies!

I bought it ‚Äúused/very good‚Äù but my Klipsch ProMedia 2.1 THX Certified Computer Speaker System seems brand new to me. Kudos to the seller who did a great job of making it like brand new and In the original box and packaging. It arrived early, so I was pleasantly surprised.

As someone who has depended on headphones to watch TV, this is a Godsend. With other speakers I‚Äôve tried I had to put the volume at 100% and still couldn‚Äôt hear sound from the TV.

This is our first Amazon smart plug. Unfortunately the overhead light in our downstairs room, which we use as a library, doesn't work because there's the bottom half of a lightbulb stuck in it. (Yes, before you ask, we tried using a broomstick. We even tried getting it out with pliers. We're going to have to get someone in to replace the socket.) I plugged this smart plug in, fiddled with the Alexa app, scanned the included QR code, and voila, I had the plug working. Not using it for anything complicated yet, like routines; I just classified it as a light. Then took it downstairs, plugged the lamp into it, and said to the Echo Dot, "[name], turn on the lights." And there is light. "[name], turn off the lights" reverses it.

I need to figure out how to make the lights go on and off when I say "Lumos" and "Nox," but for now it's great. No Stygian darkness down there if I enter when the other lamp on its timer is off.

I've had the flat flipper ones you adhere to your wall, the rabbit ears, the amplifiers, etc. During the daytime, I'd lose all my channels. I'd rearrange the antennas and it didn't do any good. Total frustration.
This antenna ended all that. Plus, it looks neat on top of the TV. I'm an old relic and it's hard to impress me, but spending $ on this unit was a worthy investment.

I got this to turn my tv that is not Bluetooth into a Bluetooth for a speaker.

It‚Äôs very handheld and small - fits right in the palm of your hand.

It‚Äôs got lots of wires for easy hookup too.

I can't believe I fell for buying these expensive as hell headphones, all of the positive reviewers must not have ever made a trip to Walmart to buy headphones with rubber fittings for like $15. These headphones suck for the following reasons:

*Fit - what they do is force themselves against the upper portion of the ear which after a few minutes becomes extremely painful. The cord is longer on one side on purpose, BY A LOT so you have that wire hanging in your mouth/face the whole time due to the cord been coiled. I prefer to have cord hanging straight down and out of my face.

*Sound - no base like you would get from headphones that fit into your ear, I did not realize how much it sounds better when the headphones go inside your ear instead of been outside.

*Cost - you are paying only for the looks and packaging.

Positives:

I will keep the clipper that came with them, it is a very nice clipper and I will use it on my $10 set of headphones I been using at the gym. Too bad this clipper cost me $50.

Lessons learned: never buy anything for 2x than what it should cost.

Great sounding retro looking mini speaker. Sound quality is good and love the base quality as well. Like the AM/FM radio feature. Color combination and design is very attractive. Easily carry able.

[[VIDEOID:d6b7a8b9b0393d04acea3ab55126063e]] I love the huge selection of musical chimes. Everything from classical music, whimsy, holiday tunes, doorbell chimes, etc. I believe there are 36 options and I enjoyed running through all of them until I made my selection.

The doorbell works great, but Inserting the transmitter battery is nearly impossible. It took three people almost a half an hour to pry the battery cover off. Inserting the batteries into the receiver was pretty standard and I am not sure why they made the transmitter so difficult and user-unfriendly. They have included a pry-off tool just for that purpose. Hopefully, I will not need to change that battery for a very long time.

This kit arrived with mounting hardware and double stick tape plus a single 3032 coin battery for the transmitter along with a pry tool to remove the battery cover. The dual AA batteries for the receiver are not included.

I have the receiver standing on my desk and I am happy that "stand-alone" it is an option. This kit came with mounting hardware as well, but I like the idea of being able to move the receiver to whatever area I happen to be working in since I listen to loud music at work and may not hear it upstairs.

I paid $12.99 at the time of review and you cannot beat that! Had it not been so difficult to insert the transmitter battery I would have rated this doorbell 5 stars. It works well and I recommend it.

I received this as a review sample. I am not going to repeat the product description, but do want to point out that this is designed for counters with outlets near the work surface. I mention this because although the specs clearly state that the cable is two feet long, some folks may miss that.

This is basic protection. It is more of a breaker than a true surge protector, although the response time is one nanosecond. That's impressive. The clamping voltage, on the other hand is 600 volts, which is reason enough for me to use this on less than valuable gear like inexpensive power tools or lighting.

Since this is priced at eight bucks (at the time of this review), it has a basic price tag, so it's a decent deal for what it is. And basically, that is a power strip with integrated protection that amounts to a circuit breaker. Better than just a six outlet strip, which costs about the same. One thing that you need to also take into account is the fact that this does not have 'wall wart' spacing. As long as you are using two or three prong power cords it's fine. If you are using any type of transformer you are going to lose an outlet or two for each of those.

For what this is it's a decent deal as long as you understand its limitations. I am happy with mine, but I am using it on a workbench with low power and low cost appliances and tools.

I received this as a free review sample. I'll spare you a regurgitation of the product specs or paraphrasing the previous two reviews, but will focus on what sets this one apart from the pack.

The biggest surprise I had was volume. This is a relatively small speaker and most bluetooth speakers in this one's size and price range are designed as personal speakers that are meant to be nearby on a desk, night stand or counter top. I can clearly hear this one two rooms away indoors and even outdoors in areas with high ambient noise this can cut through and project sound.

Sound quality is neutral, and I mean that in a good way. While there is some bias towards the mid range frequencies it does not 'color' the sound of music being streamed to it. To be honest, this is not going to crank out heavy bass, so if you listen to bass-centric music you may be disappointed. On the other hand, the highs and lows are practically seamless, with a slight emphasis towards the mid range, so if you listen to jazz, blues or some forms of rock and Americana this speaker will probably please you.

One review discussed bluetooth range issues so I specifically tested that. Even two rooms away, which normally causes drops in quality, I was able to get crystal clear streaming with no drops in the music quality streamed from a Samsung Note 3. The distance is approximately twenty feet, but definitely not line of sight, so I am happy with that aspect.

While the product specs claim six hours of music, you can realistically expect somewhere between four and four and a half hours if you have the volume cranked. If you drop it to about a quarter - perfect for near listening up to two or three meters - you will get the claimed play time.

Nice and sturdy headphones, better quality than I was expecting. I ordered 1 pair of each color, to donate to kids in need for Christmas. I buy off Amazon and other sites, good deals for quality toys and other items for my Christmas stash box to give to various organizations to give to ppl of all ages, in need of a little help, at Christmas. I spent a LOT of time looking for an LED/LCD tv to go in my bedroom. I had planned to go smaller than 46'' but in the end I chose this TV because of the stellar reviews and the incredible feature list.

The TV came packaged well and setup was a breeze. I'm not using the stand that came with the tv, it is mounted on a floor stand so I can not speak to the previous comments having to do with the "creakiness" of the stand. The tv is amazingly beautiful. It has clean lines and a very minimalist look. I have always been impressed with sony's aesthetic qualities and this is no exception.

I decided to purchase this with the 3d bundle and ps3 even though I currently already own one. I have been watching 3d content and also playing Gran Turismo 5 in 3d. It's very addicting and I can see myself spending way too much time lying in bed watching movies with my dorky 3d glasses on :)

I have since ordered the sony ht-ct150 to accompany this set and provide more depth to the sound stage. The speakers on the tv as suspected aren't really great, but I didn't buy the tv for that reason. I bought the tv for the incredible picture, the gorgeous design and the amazing reputation that sony is known for. And for all those requirements this TV does not disappoint.

The screw at the bottom fell off the first time I used this projector. I was not able to put it back, it doesn't stay. I have to use a book to lift it up. It's not stable.

Speaker is horrible, higher frequencies are absent. All one can hear is loud noise from the projector and lower frequencies. The sound is worse than in the older Anker projector.

I ordered a 'CHUYI Cute Animal Wireless Mouse Cartoon Hamster Shape Mini Travel Mouse 1200DPI Novelty Portable Optical Unique Small Cordless Mice with USB Receiver for Computer Laptop PC for Kids (Blue)' for review and would like to share my thoughts with you. This cute little mouse is quite adorable. Our ten year old daughter fell in love with it when it arrived. It connected easy to her laptop and has a great battery life. It has not had any issues with connection and moves smoothly across a mouse pad. It does feel slightly smaller than a normal mouse but seems to fit her hand perfectly.

Overall, the quality meets the price point, works well and is a great little mouse.

I agree completely with John M., a 3 star reviewer. Except for the number of stars he allocated...
It is really hard to navigate the menu(s). The sound is OK and the unit looks really cute. But I wanted to give this to my 84 year old mother to listen to music and audio-books. There is no way that can happen. The buttons are too stiff and she would never be able to figure out the menu. I am a pretty tech-savvy person and I am having a very hard time with the menu navigation myself. Not sure the unit is working right because it seems to constantly run into dead ends in the navigation. Either it isn't working right, or the controls are not applicable consistently.
At the very least, there should be some pretty comprehensive instructions with the unit. Not the totally simplistic, totally incomplete ones that I received. Very disappointed. The only reason I am giving 2 stars is because it does work somewhat... and it looks nice. There is some potential here, but major fixes need to be applied!

Being a Mac user for decades, it has been some time since I've had the opportunity to use a Windows based computer, so I was eager to try the Windows 10 operating system on this convertible notebook computer, also a first for me. The Acer Aspire R 14 R5-471T-79YN has far exceeded my expectations in form and function, despite the learning curve I'm experiencing. I won't get into the Windows 10 system, but will say that I can definitely see the influence of the Mac operating systems on its development and I am impressed. Perhaps I like it more than many users might simply because I can't even remember the last Windows system I used being that even my remote work situations tend to not use these computers now.

The Acer is not as lightweight as a tablet, of course, but it's also not the weightiest notebook of this size, and the brushed metal texture of the case is appealing. It looks sleek and feels good when the computer is used. I find the keyboard to be very comfortable, the touchpad is positioned well and the silver edging surrounding it is a nice contrast. I do not like the position of the power button which is directly beneath the power plug, as I find that if plugged in, I have to fiddle with it to turn on the computer. The USB ports, HDMI port, SD card reader and volume control are all easily accessible and have functioned well so far in every case I've used them this week. The speakers are a little odd, but that makes sense since the convertible form of this means that when used as a tablet ,the rear speakers will face the area between the folded computer. To my surprise, I find that the sound improves in tablet form, better than when used in laptop or tented configurations. I have mine set to ask if I want to switch to tablet layout because I found that it did not always respond appropriately when set to automatic conversion. The true HD makes this a very nice system on which to watch videos and with external headphones or speaker, either cabled or Bluetooth, it becomes a great system. I would actually consider this one to be best suited for entertainment, and would imagine that it is excellent for games although I have not used it for that purpose at all. The touch screen is very responsive, but it does take some time to get accustomed to the responsiveness. The computer is very fast, very quiet, very cool (temperature), and it starts quickly. I rather like the lack of an optical drive because that keeps it quieter and lighter, yet allows me to add a peripheral drive if I want or when it is needed. I rather enjoyed streaming a movie from my Amazon Prime directly to a non-smart TV. I've used this in the kitchen in both the tablet and tent configurations using the Kindle app and much appreciated having a larger screen than when using my Kindle Fire for recipe following.

For the price, I think this is a great convertible computer which comes with a single year warranty. I intend to give this Aspire a workout and hope that I never need to discover how the Acer warranty service performs.

I've tried a couple of high quality headphones and earphones lately, and have to say that these are probably the best. The sound quality is exceptional, for pc, iPhone and mp3 player listening, providing clarity and definition of both bass and tremble. It was easy to pick up elements to the song that other - lesser quality - earphones left out, and the Munitio earphones were comfortable to use (in part thanks to the three different sizes of earbuds that they provide to ensure the best fit).

The microphone and the control buttons work well with any Apple products, which is nice (one day it'll be great to come across a universal product), and the design is appealing with the thick, flat cord (which isn't entirely tangle-free but less likely to knot up like some other earphones I've come across, especially those which are fabric wrapped) and the bronze accents. Munitio provides a nice, flat bag to carry your earphones in which can be easily tucked into a pocket or bag.

There are probably higher end earphones that provide just as good if not better listening quality, but for the price, I'd have to recommend these.

These came bundled with a keyboard I purchased from a different source ([[ASIN:B0130VVOOG Casio PX360BK Key Digital Piano]]. I have not only used this cable pair to connect the L and R outputs to a mixer, but I also have used them as L and R out to a pair of small powered speakers from my [[ASIN:B00UBJ6ZM2 Soundcraft Ui12 Digital Mixer with Wi-Fi Router]] and they worked well in that role too.

The construction is excellent in all respects. They are siamesed together, but ou can easily separate them if you need two separate cables to run to separate speakers (if you use them in that way.) Or you can leave them as are to keep your cable runs cleaner. If you do decide to keep them as are I highly recommend that you tape the places where the pairs split because they are very easy to peel back and separate.

A final factor is price and quality. I also own a set of [[ASIN:B001UAM2ZU Monster StudioLink Interconnects - 2 Meters - 1/4-Inch to 1/4-Inch]], which are much more expensive (and shorter), and these are their equal in both construction and noise-free performance.

I stream a lot of spotify through my phone and love this flexible solution for listening while I am charging. I had been using Bluetooth but this feels like a more secure and consistent connection to my stereo.  It is well built, small and aesthetic.  It does what it promised and works well, glad I got it!

The one I purchased was a different machine #, didn't have bluetooth, but was a faster processor and a few other upgrades. Needed BT so I installed a BT daughter card out of my old T61 that had a bad Invidia chip. Works like a charm and now can do skype meetings without being tethered to the system.

These are rugged, fast, work. I'd take an older one of these (I did) over a new something else any day (I did). Went from a Samsung Ultrabook (admittedly a great system too) back to a 3-year old one of these. Cheap, but still fast and has everything you need. No CD/DVD, but most don't have them anymore and using CD to USB is fine.

Case is magnesium alloy and breaks the fins for the cooling fan easily. That was a bad design. Otherwise, it's a perfect system that is more than a netbook, but not the weight and size of a lappy while still having a good size screen and almost full-size keyboard.
Great for my older Cannon camera and some old portable speakers. Log enough to use anywhere and it's pretty tough.

Crisp hi-res touchscreen. Nice aluminum case. It's big but thinner and lighter than a 17-inch HP Envy. It works fine as a regular laptop but then you can flip it over into a tent, use it with the keyboard flat against the ground or even as a big tablet. The hinges feel very solid and the display will rotate any direction you turn it.

It's way more than fast enough for home and work. The SSD is great. The Intel graphics don't seem to lag and you can even run games with decent framerates. The speakers are good enough. The screen can get reflective if there's a lot of light behind you. The battery says it last 7 hours though with full screen streaming video it lasts three. There's a sliding shutter over the camera. There's not a lot of bloatware, just a few apps that are easy to delete.

A friend of mine bought one of these to take video of his kids. I tried it. It works fine for what it is and takes decent video, and I can see why people may not want a full-blown camcorder, but in the market today it makes no sense. Do yourself a favor and just buy a plain old digital camera instead because almost every cheap digital camera can do what a Flip does except better and sometimes for less money too.

Take for example the Canon SD750, which does everything the Flip does and much more for just around $30 extra plus a few bucks for a larger memory card. It takes good VGA video exactly like a Flip, plays it back on a 3-inch color screen with sound (four times larger than the Flip's 1.5-inch screen) in four different speeds of slow-motion if you want, has a real 3X optical zoom and a 4X digital zoom (Flip is 2X digital zoom only), uses SD memory cards that can easily and cheaply be upgraded and changed (with Flip you're limited to 2GB only and then you have to offload, while a 8GB card costs around $12), and like the Flip it can also play back video directly from the camera through a TV.

BUT you can also record video in different resolutions, with effects such as B&W and sepia tones, at different frame rates from 15fps to high-speed 60fps, either in full automatic exposure or with manual tweaks to things like white balance, with stop shutter action where the camera will take one frame every one or two seconds and then play it back as a video, etc. Or you can just leave it in full auto mode in which case it takes less than three seconds from the time you turn it on to the time you start recording. It gets along with Windows just fine without any software all (it comes with software but you don't have to use it). And of course it takes fabulous 7.1 megapixel regular pictures with an enormous number of features.

I use the Canon SD750 as an example only because I'm familiar with it. But almost any digital camera will do what the Flip does and more, and many of them will do it for the same price or even less. So to me at least it makes no sense to get a Flip unless you're willing to spend more money for simplicity or only want it for the cute factor.
Sounds good for a small speaker, I have 2 of them connected to a sub woofer for my fire tv stick.

They work really well. Zosi is a GREAT security camera company with EVEN GREATER PRICES. I have an 8 cam, 4k system w/2GB HDD and it was barely over 400$. Compared systems were 800+. Their products are made really well to be from China. They also DO NOT have a security problem like 100s of other cams manufactured in china has. (PLEASE DO YOUR RESEARCH BEFORE BUY NEW CAMs OR DVRs, THERE IS ALOT OF BAD COMPANIES WITH SERIOUS FLAWS, ALLOWING YOU TO BE HACKED VERY EASILY)...
These plugs were needed for my audio add-on to my Zosi DVR. They fit tight with zero wiggles, and for the price I was amazed 4$ for 10 plugs. (Cant buy just 2). I have used these plugs for audio and video. My old non DVR cams work great with the DVR using these plugs no video loss over 100' distance and once I find an audio device that's worth a damn I'm sure the audio will be top notch. They worked perfectly with the mics I returned and never had issue 1 with the plugs but the mics were total garbage.. best buy cams with built in audio. Wish I spent the extra 100$ for audio and I woupdnt be in this predicament now..

All n all good price great tight fit and no signal loss on either video or audio.

I work in video production and sometimes need to record narration for my work. I have an expensive Rode mic system that I use with my cameras, but I decided to see how a permanent mic setup like this would do. First of all, the amount of equipment you get for the money is insane. The pop guard and arm are pretty awesome, but it turns out my desk didn't have a good place to clamp an articulating arm like that. Thankfully, it also came with a little tripod base so you can have it sit on the desk instead. The USB sound system uses a standard RealTek Audio chip, so it's pretty universally compatible and offers excellent sound quality. In the past sometimes the PC's audio input 3.5mm jack produced extra noise on account of the PSU creating some sort of line humming. With a USB audio interface, that's a non-issue.  I'm impressed with the response of it, it managed to pick up my voice and not a lot of background noise (my computer fan can get loud sometimes!). The only hangup is that I spend some time trying to figure out how to get it accessible to my recording applications. For some reason it kept complaining that the sample rate of the mic didn't match. It did, but the computer kept complaining. I ended up going into Windows sound settings, changing the sample rate, then going back in and changing it back and THEN it worked. It's been good ever since. So, still an excellent mic with impressive quality for the price!

If you're looking for a cheap pair of headphones that you don't have to be super upset if you lose, or a spare pare to keep somewhere just in case...these are it! For the price, they sound quite good and they seem to be very durable. Sure, you're not going to get the same audio quality as a $60 pair of earbuds, but these sound very good, not overly tinn-y and with a good bass. If I lose this pair, I will buy another just like it. I'm quite pleased with it.
Also love that it comes with multiple sizes of earbud attachments, as I have small ears.

It was easy to install.

It was just a matter of connecting the (included) optical audio cable from my tv to the device, and then connecting the (not included) RCA analog audio (red and white) cable from the device to my stereo, and then connecting the (included) power adapter to the device and plugging it in.

I wanted to get audio from my one-year-old UHD tv to my 6-year-old vintage-style analog turntable/cd player/Bluetooth receiver/radio receiver/cassette player.

This device does exactly that.

The volume on the tv and on the music center both work with this device connected, so I can choose how much of each one I would like to use at the same time.

My only complaint is that when I switch between tv inputs, there is a fast popping sound which is harsh and annoying although it only lasts a fraction of a second every time.

I don't think I asked a lot in a iPad cover, but I'm impressed how well this cover has delivered. Mostly I was looking for functional protection and a look that classy looks. This cover delivered both in spades.

Protection:

I love the way the iPad is held in place by the four rubber corner holder. The case makes contact with the iPad in the most minimal way and does not allow grit to get between the case and the ipad to scratch surfaces. I have never had the iPad slip out of these feet either, it is very snugly held in place.

The outside materials are rugged and there are 3/16th inches of touch material between the iPad and the harsh world. It will not protect it in a long fall, but it is safe from scratches and smudges.

Looks:

I was originally looking for a leather case for looks, but this is just as classy as the leather cases I have found for twice the price. I like the leatherlike surface and the black with white stitching is subtly striking. I even like the Belkin logo, it's a cute representation of the human form.

Functionality:

The magnet is well placed to hold the case closed, then when open, it holds the front flap securely attached to the back of the iPad. Magnet strength seems to be strong enough to be functional. Also well designed are the multiple positions the case folds into. It has a great adjustable angle fold for watching movies and using my bluetooth keyboard.

I don't use the camera ever, but this case does have a strategically placed hole so it is available.

Failings:

In general this is a great case. The two things I can think of for constructive criticism are the inside materials and the fact that the magnet causes the iPad to wake in transit. For the inside material, it is a velvety black material that picks up dust. Not a huge thing, but noticeable. As for the magnet, I guess this is not uncommon, but I do completely power down the iPad if I am putting it in my laptop bag. Otherwise it occassionally turns on and runs down the battery. Again not a bad thing and not an issue in general.

Summary:

All in all, I love this case. It's classy and functional. Recommend.

These headphones are soft and non-sweating. I wear these all day to talk on my phone , and listing on social media. Most headsets tend to make my ears sweat after wearing them to long..but not these. They Light weight and foldable.and the sound is evenly distributed in both ears. Love them

I needed a small blue tooth speaker because the Echo Dot sound quality just wasn't cutting it and i would like to add music to whatever room I am working in that may not have a device. I have an Echo Dot 2nd and 3rd gen. The 2nd gen is tinny and the 3rd way too bass centric and boomy, but still better than this speaker. The sound quality doesn't blow me away, in fact, it is pretty bad. Not enough bass and not much of an improvement over my Echo Dot Mini 2nd Gen. Wow, this is so disappointing. The speaker paired easily with my phone and laptop, but had an issue pairing with the Alexa app via blue tooth. The controls are a pain to see in low light. As long as you keep your expectations super low you will be happy.
----Update-----
Lost another star after buying the Doss Touch speaker for $4 more. The Doss has MUCH better sound quality and paired to Echo Dot instantly. The Oontz seems to be having difficulties with Alexa. Probably going to return this and buy the upgraded version of the Doss 20W because I am much more impressed with that speaker as a whole. The sound quality on the Doss is more balanced and it has True Wireless Stereo so both can be used simultaneously. At first it was about being an upgrade to the Echo Dot sound quality, but now it's about better sound with every device. I was never happy with the sound on the Oontz to begin with and now it's completely unacceptable after trying a much better speaker within the same price range.

These headphones took some time for me to get used to how they feel in my ears. I'm coming from mainly using the Apple Earpods and was used to how those felt in my ears "at rest", and comparatively these always felt like they were going to fall out. Once I got used to the different feel, these were worth it in my eyes for the better sound quality. Not sure about durability yet, but so far it seems that these might last longer, and at $10 less than new Earpods for a better product, no complaints here.
Works perfectly  just what I needed to plug my stereo headphone cable to a keyboard amplifier also a multi track recorder

I have worked with GPS navigators from several manufacturers, including Garmin, Magellan and TomTom. Each unit has its strengths and weaknesses. My favorite GPS unit up this point has been another TomTom, an old Start 40 which served me well for several years. I was interested to see how much the series has changed since I got that older model. It has changed quite a bit ‚Äì more than I expected. I like this navigator, though I can see a few things I‚Äôd change.

First off, I have the 6‚Äù model which is a beast. I am used to a 5‚Äù GPS which I have been using, and it took some time to adjust to the larger screen. This is not to say it bothers me; it just is enough of a difference to require getting used to it. If you are upsizing like that, be aware that it takes up more physical space and placing on the windshield might require replanning.

Out of the box, I powered it on, connected it to my WiFi network and downloaded over 6GB of updates. That‚Äôs a huge update. The map it holds is obviously the largest component to be updated, and it covers all of the US, Canada and Mexico. While it is nice to have all that coverage, I personally do not need that much map and would have liked the option of only having the US map on-board. That would cut memory requirements. My older model was limited in memory and the map grew until it could no longer fit; I can see the potential for that happening again.

For navigation, up to this point I have stuck with the default settings, except with the 2D/3D map setting.

My first trip with this unit was to work. I did not use it to navigate, I only used to to show the map as I drove. It found my fix quickly (one of the reasons I like TomTom navigators) and when I was driving it updated the map smoothly and quickly as I reached new features. It displayed road names, it showed the placement of certain POIs like gas stations, and because I was driving at sunrise the map switched from night mode to daytime so I got to see both maps.

I‚Äôll state for the record, I am not fan of the daytime map‚Äôs default color scheme. I almost always use the 2D map, not the 3D one, and it uses a set of pastel colors that might be somewhat soothing on the eyes but they‚Äôre quite drab. I‚Äôd rather see a bolder map that makes features stand out more. Another thing this unit does not show is road symbols like the interstate shield, instead opting for just small-print words. I can live with that but I do prefer the symbols.

On the way home from work, I used the unit again, but this time to guide me on an alternate route. Friday afternoon traffic in this area is typically awful, and the route home is almost always snarled by at least one accident (sometimes as many as 4-5). I chose to follow a route I knew would take two hours to get home, though it moves the whole time. I loaded the first point into the GPS and it dutifully guided me there, taking me on a fairly optimal route. When I got there, I then told it to take me home and I was quite surprised ‚Äì every other GPS unit I have used has tried to make me take a U-turn to go back the way I came to get back on the interstate (the source of the problem), but this one did not, instead taking me on a route that would connect me back to the interstate about 20 miles south. Knowing this was also a bad route traffic-wise, I made a planned turn in the middle of the route, skipping another 20 miles of interstate. Instead of insisting I turn around, the unit again adjusted my route and took me on almost the exact route I had planned to take anyway.

What impressed me is how quickly the unit rerouted me without trying to put me back on the original route it chose. This is quite different from most units. Normally I get ‚Äúturn around when possible‚Äù or ‚Äúrecalculating‚Äù over and over ‚Äì not this time.

I finally did let it put me on the interstate, about 5 miles from home. When I reached my exit is showed very clearly what lane it wanted me to use, and it was very obvious when I was to turn.

I use the American female voice that reads street names. She enunciates very clearly and is easy to understand. Many GPS units sound tinny or have a buzz when the voice is active, but this one does not. My old Start 40 sounded clear too and did not buzz. I think perhaps TomTom does a better job with designing their units for sound.

One thing I use my GPS for is speed tracking. When in an area where there are no posted speed limit signs, it is nice when the GPS shows the speed limit and your current speed. For this one, though, the speed display is very small. It‚Äôs out of the way which is good, but I‚Äôd prefer a larger display or at least some ability to make it bigger. If there is a setting for that I have not uncovered it yet.

My primary complaint with this GPS is actually the menu system, which I find to be very clunky and odd. I don‚Äôt like it, and preferred the older menu system. It is workable, regardless.

Most GPS units that offered traffic do so through a special antenna or attachment in the power connector. Rather than offer this, this unit instead gets traffic updates via your phone through a Bluetooth connection. This is a double-edged sword. On one hand, it does not require that the unit be plugged in all the time and it becomes much more portable. On the other hand, it means that it pulls data and if you‚Äôre in an area where there is no data connectivity your updates aren‚Äôt available. I‚Äôm still deciding if I like this arrangement or not.

This is a good GPS with a little room for improvement in a few areas. The screen real estate is nice, and it navigates very well (better than most others I have used). It enunciates clearly and updates en route smoothly and quickly. The menu system is a little clunky, and there are some display settings I think could be better. Overall, though, this unit gets the important things right. It‚Äôs a good unit at a competitive price.

This headphones works good enough. I bought this because the Jabra headphones seem to always cut out. I bought the Jabra because they can support 2 devices at one time. These however can not. Also, the loop for the ears don't always work well, but they do manage to stay on the head most of the time. This might be because of my big head, but the issue is no real adjustments can be made.

Purchase this to play my old cassette tapes.  I think it could had been less digital on all the control keys, knobs would had worked better but that is a personal preference.  The speaker sound is very good and projects over a long distance.  Light weight and portable is a plus too.  All features works well on the boombox.

Having recently dug my music collection (odd how we go back into hobbies after years of stagnation), I took time to curate my setup (and by setup I mean my Note8 with a USB DAC) for optimal listening. Until recently, but "best" headphones were my Shure Aonic 4, which are excellent for the price range. The cable it comes with is okay, but preferably replaceable. It comes with an inline mic and makes a lot of feedback-noise when moved. I know cables are a mixed bag when it comes to audio equipment, so I shied away for years. But rather than place the emphasis on audio-quality improvement when looking at cables, I realized I'd rather get a cable if it looks and feels good. This one fit the ticket.

This is the only cable I have that's meant to be swapped with MMCX in-ear headphones. They pair well with the Aonic 4. First, I'll get the problems I have out of the way.

Since this cable is meant to connect with around-the-ear IEMs, there's a plastic wrap near each MMCX adapter. It makes wearing around the ears easier, but putting them on initially takes a few tries. They are easy to tangle, even if I use the "roadie wrap." Putting them on while on the go proved to be suboptimal; I have to be sitting or standing to put them on.

Sometimes I get some feedback noise, but rarely. Definitely not the same as the stock cable that comes with the Aonic 4.

The biggest problem I have is that the end connection disconnects nearly every time I use the cable. Having a modular cable is awesome, but the connection from the cable to the audio jack doesn't lock. I expected there to be a click, indicating it's on and snug, but no such thing. Since I use this cable while on the go, it's connected to my phone, which rests in my pocket. At least once the cable end will come loose. It's easy to press back in (just a little nudge will do), but it is rather annoying.

Now for the good.

The cable feels awesome. I get now why people prefer to upgrade certain cables. I care very little for how much the audio quality is "improved" (there's too much immeasurable subjectivity in that area), but having a cable that doesn't tangle easily and is very light makes enough of a difference to justify the upgrade. The cable is soft to the touch, though I don't doubt its ruggedness in the long term. The MMCX connectors snap satisfactorily into the Shure IEMs; at least those haven't come loose. The metal ends and Y-splitter are very nice and definitely attribute the cable with a premium look.

This cable has sold me on the reasons to upgrade headphone cables.
This is decent speaker for the price range. Plus it's water resistant. Seems to be made well and it's pretty durable.
I‚Äôve had a pair of Sony Studio/Professional  headphones in my life since the early 90‚Äôs. They‚Äôve been great all these years. Love em.

This SanDisk memory card was valuable with my SensaClip MP3 Player. By adding the 8GB of music, the player has two locations to find music. Internal and external. I used the Window media player to burn the tunes. Once the memory card has been burned with the 700 to 1000 music songs, it can be transferred from one player to another. So, for example, I had two SensaClip MP3 Players, and one got damaged in the washing machine. Dah!!! Tell me about it. Baddah bing, baddah bong!!! Ok, I tried to take out the memory card, and put into my second player. Wow, all the songs were still there. I am not sure why, but that brought me amazon to by more memory cards to store my music. And, 8GB is enough for me as a set of music. I'm just playing melodies.

Hope this review helps you.
Wont connect to my iPad or iPhone. Shows up in Bluetooth settings but wont connect.

My last several keyboards and mice have been Logitech products, specifically the Wave keyboard and mouse combination. After one of our keyboards met an unfortunate demise I bought this combo set and so far have been very pleased. I have found a couple of things about the keyboard that are less than ideal but so far there have been no major issues.

I will talk about the mouse and keyboard separately.

The mouse is an M705 Marathon mouse. This seems to be the mouse model that comes in many of the Logitceh combo packs and it is a good, all-purpose mouse that seems to hold up very well (this is actually the second one we have in the house now). Though by appearance alone it appears to be a little on the small side, it is actually a comfortable mouse for people with larger hands like myself. It's a five-button mouse with probably the best scroll wheel available on a mouse. Using this mouse, working with Windows 8 on a non-touchcreen device like a laptop is actually not too bad.

The range on the mouse it good, I have been able to use it on the computer from across the room (approximately 20 feet), which makes it very suitable for use on presentations or working in an environment where multiple systems are in use and space is somewhat a limited.

The keyboard is the very first solar powered keyboard I have ever seen or used. It is a full-sized keyboard with a full set of keys, but running across the top of the keyboard are two banks of silicon solar cells that gather light. They don't take up a lot of space and they're not unattractive.

According to the documentation, the solar cells charge an internal backup battery that can hold a charge for up to three months so this keyboard is not slaved to brightly lit areas 24/7. There is a downloadable software application that gives a health report on the battery and the light level that actually is very interesting even though it's a straightforward and simple application. It's fun to load the application and then move a light source closer to and farther from the solar cells to see the meter change.

The keyboard required a bit of adjustment for me. It has the chicklet style of keys, not the raised square block buttons that most other add-on keyboards have so it has a completely different profile than a standard keyboard. If you don't mind the keyboard that comes on a laptop, then this one won't be an issue either, but if you prefer a raised-button keyboard then this might not be the keyboard for you.

Many keyboards have separate physical keys for special functions such as launching a calculator, email or working with audio. This keyboard does not and instead relies on a function key and F1-F12 key combinations. That's fine, but if you're used to having separate keys for accessing these things, there is an adjustment to be made.

There is one primary negative that I have found with this particular keyboard. The tilt legs are very small and flimsy so I think it's a matter of time before they break off. Be gentle with this keyboard if you use the tilt legs.

I do like the unifying USB receiver. Logitech has moved to such for most (if not all) of their product line and it definitely cuts down on the number of physical USB devices plugged in to the computer or hub. Attaching new devices is painless so it's possible to run multiple devices from the one receiver (I think the limit is 8 separate devices).

Overall, I like this mouse/keyboard combo. The mouse is excellent and the keyboard is also good. While I think the tilt legs are the weakest link when it comes to the keyboard I do not regard that as a deal breaker though it does mean that a little caution is required when working with it. My experience with this combo is good.

me and my significant other likes to camp alot, whenever we get a change. i am an early riser, so i usually wake up and go observe the nature. i have seen people bird watching, or observing nature with their binocular, and every time i would leave the national park, the 1st thing on my itinerary use to be "when i get home, i am going to order binoculars and it would just slip out of my head. so i finally i pulled the trigger. these comes in a nice carrying case. i have tested them outside of my house and the range is phenomenal. i just hope i wont forget to pack them on my next trip, otherwise i am going to be extremely sad haha

Hi!

I was very excited about this camera, having used the GoPro exclusively until now.

However, I have to say that I was extremely disappointed with the camera, the website support, the smartphone apps, and the PC software.

I found the camera manual extremely short on important info, such as what I could and could not do while the camera was attached to my computer via the USB cable. There are no instructions anywhere (that I could find) for using the Connect app. I guess they figure people will just touch the screen in various places to see what happens. I was surprised to find that I could record from the Connect app, as info online said that all I could to was "frame" camera shots.

In addition, the camera itself did not work well. The Storyteller software did download and install the latest firmware. Here are some of the things I encountered:

1. The camera would "hang" regularly, as in every time I used it. The only way to "reset" was to remove and replace the battery.

2. Bluetooth communication only worked about 50% of the time, using iPad, iPhone, and iPod.

3. I often had to "reset" the camera (battery re-install) for it to be recognized using the USB connection.

4. Record OFTEN didn't work!! I tried to demo the camera to several people and it would not record unless I re-installed the battery.

5. The camera often would not STOP recording! I would slide back the record switch and the RECORD light would remain on under it and on the bottom of the camera. Again, the only resolution was a battery re-install.

I could find no help for ANY of these issues on the website. I am VERY frustrated by the fact that they do not offer telephone support.

The Storyteller software is terrible, and very lacking in support. It is necessary to eject the camera every time its configuration is reset! This is very frustrating when the camera was only recognized by my computer on a seemingly random basis (I tried all my USB ports and even a different cable!).

I like many things about the Contour much better than the GoPro. However, GoPro has the industry momentum, and if Contour wants to slow that down and gain some traction of its own, their product will need to work better and be much better supported. I think the Contour is a better camera, but the few problems I had with the GoPro were resolved quickly and easily with the information they provided.

I hope this product gets better. Until it - and the support - improves, I can't use it or recommend it to anyone else! :)

hb

UPDATE: Received a call from Contour Tech Support. They "schooled" me on the fact that everything taking place in this camera requires the SD card. There isn't even a little on-board memory. Thus, if the SD card doesn't work exactly right, neither will the camera. Without an SD card working perfectly, all you have is a piece of hardware! They suggested that I format the SD card with the utility at [...] (SD Formatter), and then re-format in the camera. I have already sent back the camera, though!

This is a pretty good case and keyboard for the iPad mini 2, but there are a few drawbacks. There's more positive than negative, though.

First, the negatives: (1) the backspace key is not in the top right corner, it's one row below. You will hit the "=" button way more than you want to while looking for the backspace button. (2) the apostrophe is on the L key and you have to press the Function button to use it. You will type "it;s" way more than you want to. (3) there are extra keys on the keyboard such as cmd, alt, option, and a weird symbol that looks like a swirly for which my iPad has no function that I am aware of.

Now, the positives. They keyboard is smaller than usual (of course) but pretty easy to use with a little practice. The screen tilt function is fantastic. It can hold the tablet at an unlimited amount of angles. The screen can spin 360 degrees so it can be used with the keyboard as a prop in a triangle format, with the keyboard in the back for movie watching, or out flat for typing in bed with the tablet propped up on your knees. I like how it makes my tablet into a mini laptop. I also love how the keyboard tucks in behind the screen for coloring or sketching with a stylus.

The case is very sturdy, made of a rubbery feel type material, and nice to look at and touch. Not cheaply made at all. It has lights for charging, battery, and Bluetooth pairing. All the holes, speakers, and cameras are exposed where they need to be. I have a tempered glass screen protector on the iPad and it does not get in the way of the case at all.

The keyboard does add some weight to the tablet, but this does not bother me. Overall I am very pleased with this product.

I‚Äôve owned this power bank for 2 years and it has been an exceptional and reliable source of power. I use it about once a month for a week at a time when I go RV camping to power my laptop. On its own, the laptop‚Äôs battery would only last at most 2 hours. But with the laptop plugged into the power bank, after I‚Äôve used my laptop for 2-3 hours, the power bank charge has only dropped from 100% to as low as 77%--that extrapolates to 8-13 hours which is way more than I would usually need. So I no longer have to worry about my laptop running out of power. When I‚Äôm done, I plug the power bank into my RV‚Äôs 12V outlet and it recharges back to 100% in about 4-8 hours depending on how low its charge is. Between my monthly camping trips, when the power bank sits idle, it maintains its full charge without my having to recharge it.

For the type of run-and-gun projects I do, if I can get away with plugging a mic directly into the camera ( often a single stereo 3.5mm jack these days) I will always prefer to do that than a dual-sound setup that needs to by synced in post. However, sometimes you need more than one mic, so what's a one-man-crew to do? Well, traditionally I would use a TRS break out cable, which essentially looks like a headphone splitter Y-cable, but splits the Left and Right channel into separate plugs instead of doubling them. That's great because I can connect one mic to Left and the other to Right, then split them up and remix in post as needed.
But this is much more elegant solution- It is essentially the same idea, splitting the L + R into two sides, but not only is it less messy since you don't have Y cables dangling, it also serves as a point in which to mount 2 coldshoe receivers directly to single shoe mount, essentially making this an all-in-one solution to turn a single mic input setup into a dual one. No additional hardware necessary behind the second mic. I love this solution, it looks more professional, it is more reliable, and I would definitely recommend checking it out if you're in the same boat as me!

PDF‚Ä¶. What does it do? PDF stands for portable document format. The best part of this, and most intriguing feature, is the Speak recognition. You can add a comment to your document by speaking into the computer. The info you spoke gets typed into the document.
