I am using the optical audio output from the TV to a Pioneer Elite Receiver.

I turned off Motion Flow because I never like that soap opera effect.
Don't know why any good TV ever has that option turned on.

Great TV

For several years, I‚Äôve been using Fintie brand iPad cases for my iPad mini, iPad Pro 9.7 and now for the 12.9 Pro  (4th Gen.). The composition notebook design is fun and appealing. This case is exactly what I needed: Something simple, has an apple pencil holder, and full coverage/protection to buttons and speakers.
I would give these speakers 5 stars if there was an option to turn the light off.
It works great and small enough to take to different rooms. Echo Flex - Plug-in mini smart speaker with Alexa. OZ

NOTE: This review is written for the Small, Bluetooth edition.

I have been using Wacom Intuos and Bamboo tablets for years, not really for graphic arts but more for digital handwriting and for use as an alternative to traditional mice and trackballs. My present solution is an Intuos 5 medium which seems to be about the right fit for my hands and my work space. The one drawback has been that it‚Äôs a wired solution. This new Intuos is a Bluetooth solution and it is definitely a step forward. For me the challenge is downgrading to the small from the medium, but it‚Äôs a good fit for me when traveling and when working in cluttered spaces.

To approximate the size, it is roughly equivalent to 7‚Äù tablet in size. It‚Äôs small enough to tuck away in a corner of a desk when not in use, and when it is being used it does not take up large amounts of real estate. The design itself makes it suitable for use just about anywhere it can be set down and kept stable - one of the reasons I like drawing tablets more than traditional mice.

The Bluetooth connectivity is new to me, and I was pleasantly surprised to find that this unit can connect via USB as well. So, if your system is like one of mine and the Bluetooth doesn‚Äôt work, this drawing tablet still will work.

I have it connected to my Windows 10 system. I have not yet made the effort to get it working with my Linux system, though I expect there will be some labor involved to make that work. I‚Äôll revisit that later.

In operation, this is a straightforward drawing tablet though it is an improvement over my Intuos 5 in some ways. Of course the Bluetooth is a step up, but I was surprised by the increased number of pressure levels which is effectively doubled over my old tablet - 4096 vs 2048. For someone like me, this is not a huge difference and I don‚Äôt take advantage, but for someone who is very serious about fine digital artwork this can be a huge benefit. For use in handwriting, it is not especially important as even 512 pressure levels (like my original Bamboo small) is more than sufficient.

When you register, you get a choice between three Corel titles, of which you can select two (for the medium you get all three). Some may find the choice difficult - Painter Essentials 6, AfterShot 6 and Clip Studio Paint Pro (2 years) - but for me, having AfterShot is more than enough.

There is a downside to this little tablet, though - the pen is mediocre. There is no comfort grip, changing the nib is a pain, and there‚Äôs a very limited number of replacement nibs for it. It‚Äôs the one weak spot in an otherwise nice product, and even then it‚Äôs not all that bad.

The hardest part for me with this specific tablet is the move from a medium to a small, but this this counterbalanced by the Bluetooth connectivity and the inclusion of the Corel titles, specifically AfterShot. This is a very nice drawing solution and is it priced nicely. I‚Äôd recommend the small for anyone either just getting started or experimenting; the medium is a better fit for those more experienced or needing more real estate. I would choose a different pen if available, though.

This is a review for the TK-408 switch.  I noticed the reviews seem to show up on several different models.  This model has the round PS/2 type connections for mouse and keyboard, and female connections for VGA. It also has audio connections, so you can use one set of speakers for several different computers. There are no USB connections on it.  All the cables are included.  I use this to switch between PCs; some reviewers mentioned trouble with MACs.  The only real issue I have encountered is that if I power up a computer that is off and I am currently switched to another computer, when I go back to the one that was off (that is now on), the screen resolution has dropped.  If I switch to the turned off computer while it still off and power up and boot up before switching away, there is no issue and then I can switch back and forth all day with everything staying as it should be.  It's just a very minor annoyance.  If the computers you are switching between are always on, it would never be an issue.  The other thing that I found out is that for me the audio was not of much use.  The reason is that I am often listening to music on one computer; when I wanted to switch to another computer to do some work, the sound stopped, obviously because now I was on another computer that didn't have music playing.  I ended up just hooking up 3 sets of speakers for my 3 computers.  A lot of space used up, but a better solution for me.  The sound situation is not a problem with the switch, as it was doing exactly what it should by looking for output from the line out on the computer that you are switched to.  Some reviewers mentioned problems with delay in the hotkey switching.  I haven't noticed this and usually it takes no more than one second to switch.  My switch uses ScrLk twice followed by the port number the computer is on.  I have tried out two more expensive switches that don't have hotkey capability and you have to press a button on the switch.  With Trendnet switches, you can do either - use the keyboard sequence or press the physical key on the switch.  I have had this switch in service for a number of years and the only physical issue I have encountered is that once in a while the master keyboard and mouse connections loosen up and have to be re-seated.  The switch has given me many years of flawless operation and so far has proven to perform better than much more expensive switches.  Very good value for the price and I highly recommend it.  I like Trendnet equipment so far and have some other products of theirs that also work very well.

It's easy to love this elegant little MP3 player. It's thin and compact (3/8" x 2" x 3-5/8"), and feels really great when held in the hand. It has the basic features that on-the-go people will use and appreciate: (1) a music player, (2) a video player, (3) an audiobook player, (4) photo storage, (5) text file storage [no docs], (6) a radio [FM only], and (7) a sound recorder. It allows you to set up playlists and slide shows, and to easily record reminders, memoranda, or other things (e.g., grocery lists, parking locations, inspired thoughts).

If you're not fussy about sound quality (and I'm not), the built-in speakers give OK sound. The supplied earplugs give much better sound, especially when the music player is set to deliver "full sound". In addition, you can get pretty good "room" sound by plugging a portable external speaker system like the [[ASIN:B0054QNL38 AmazonBasics Portable Stereo System for MP3 Players]] into the earphones outlet. The built-in software includes a nice "SafeSound" feature that helps you set your earplug or headphones volume at a level that won't cause long-term hearing loss.

With the supplied USB cable, your desired media content can be easily transferred from a PC running WinXP-SP3 or Vista or Win7 by using the Windows Media Player or File Manager. However, the device is actually intended to be used with the supplied "Philips Songbird" software. You will need to install the Songbird software in order to update the firmware (which I was able to do successfully). If Songbird works on your computer, it is certainly the best and easiest software manager for the Ariaz device. Unfortunately, Songbird didn't work well on my computer (my security software, NIS 2012, says that Songbird is safe but somewhat unstable). Fortunately, the Songbird software gives you a clear option to use Windows Media Player, instead of Songbird, to manage your device.

The 8GB of memory holds quite a few albums worth of songs--certainly there is more than enough storage space for the material you might want to carry around with you (some family photos, your favorite music, an audiobook, your memos to yourself).

Because this was my first MP3 player, I encountered a steep learning curve. The Quick Start guide told me to plug the player into a computer, but little more. When plugged in, the device automatically began charging and installing the Songbird software. When that was finished, Songbird offered to sync the device to my computer's music library. However, the Songbird interface is not particularly easy for beginners to use, and because of my inexperience with music downloads, it took me a while to figure out how to transfer music.

Also, I was initially baffled by the device's menus and apparent lack of up/down and left/right navigation buttons. Although the Quick Start guide includes a schematic drawing that depicts the device's physical buttons, I didn't notice the tiny dots that were representing the directional navigation buttons. On the device itself, the surface around the central "do it" button is perfectly smooth--except for four tiny incised dots, that are invisible unless you hold the device at the correct angle to the light. Until I downloaded the full user's manual from the Philips web site, I had no idea that up/down and left/right navigation was accomplished by pressing those incised dots. (You can feel the navigational buttons when you press them, once you know they're there.)

I would strongly recommend that anyone who purchases this sleek and delightful little device start by downloading the full user's manual. You can find the manual in the Support section of the Philips web site by entering Ariaz model no. SA3ARA08K/37 . The manual tells you how to get started, and also gives lots of good tips on importing different types of files, generating playlists, and adding and deleting items from the device.

Another problem that I encountered was a complete overnight battery discharge--when I locked the device to turn it off, instead of turning the device completely off by holding down the on/off button until the screen said "Bye". When the device is completely turned off after use, it holds the battery charge as expected.

At present, Philips doesn't seem to have a case for this particular MP3 player. A case that works for me--because I carry the device in a tote bag--is the [[ASIN:B0032EVXFW CaseCrown Double Memory Foam Compact MP3 Case]]. There is an elastic strap that holds the player on the right, and a mesh pocket that holds the short USB cable on the left. The earplugs can then be added, loose, between the device and the mesh pocket when you zip up the case.

Have been using the companion 2 series 2 speakers for several years and was very happy with them. Let me start off by saying I work in freelance video and I love how much I can fit inside this case! I've been using a Pelican 1510 as my go-to travel carrier, so that's mostly what I'm comparing this to. For starters, this is a longer case so in addition to my cameras, lenses, batteries and other accessories, it has a long open sleeve that can even fit a light stand or small tripod! For extra versatility, the whole interior can actually be pulled out (it has its own handle straps if you want to use it as its own carrier), which then frees up the ample storage space inside the case as a separate giant unit (see pictures to illustrate). There are also plenty of pockets on the inside, as well as the outside and front of the case. Of course, for a case this size there is the requisite wheels and carrying handle.
The only things I like better about my Pelican case, however, are the toughness and waterproofing. This bag comes with a rain cover which you can keep inside the case, however I don't like the idea of having to carry around a cover inside the bag, then take it out and put it on if it starts raining. The Pelican cases are air tight by simply closing them, no rain cover needed. The Pelican cases also are tough enough that they can be stacked under other equipment, thrown into a corner, sat on, stood on, etc, and 99% of the time come out unscathed. That's more than I can say for this bag. I bring this bag on gigs that I'm not worried about those things happening, because I can fit what I normally take in 3 separate bags into just this one. You could get a Pelican style case in this size, however it would cost quite a bit more than the asking price of this one. I think for the price this is a great tool to keep your stuff organized and ready to go whenever you are!

I bought this because my laptop keyboard began to fail.

Pros
- Inexpensive - I paid $19, including tax
- Both the keyboard and mouse work with Windows with no problems - so far.
- Batteries were included - 1 AA for the mouse and 2 AAA for the keyboard.
- Includes all standard/function keys plus dedicated media buttons. Shortcut keys for email, web home page, power and calculator.
- All of the shortcut keys work with no config - except the email key - see cons below.

On the con side:
- There is no LED to indicate that the keyboard is on. If there is supposed to be, the LED on my keyboard doesn't work.
- If you use Gmail or another online service, the email shortcut key may not be usable. I use Gmail and when I pressed the email key, Windows Mail launched. If this can be configured to work with online email services, Logitech provides no instructions in the box.
- Unifying receiver is incompatible with newer Logitech software and devices.
- The mouse is bare bones - left and right click buttons and a scroll wheel with middle click function. No next/back buttons, no tilt scroll wheel. This mouse is best for emergencies or for temporary use until you get a new mouse with better features, etc.

Bottom line - you get what you pay for.

I wanted to find a cheaper alternative to my wife's wireless Bose headset, something with decent noise cancelling for flights and work. So far I've used Bose, the MPOW H5, Treblab, and Woltix with ANC.

The sound on these are first class - really great highs, mids, and lows - tons of clarity (when active noise cancel is on...otherwise it sounds a bit muggy). Very comfortable and light. BUT - I got these because they are wireless with active noise cancellation, and although the ANC is effective, if you are in a quiet room you'll hear a slight hiss when the ANC is on - many people report the same thing in reviews, and it's true - you'll hear it. You won't notice this when music is on or during a flight. I often use these at coffee shops just to zone out and focus on work, and I could notice the slight hiss in quieter environments.

I've also used Bose, the MPOW H5, and Woltix with ANC. I didn't want to buy another Bose headset when my wife and I travel together. Nothing will compare to Bose noise cancellation, but the MPOW H5 and Woltix are actually really nice for the money. The MPOW H5 don't have as good audio clarity as the Treblab, but at the end of the day I got noise cancelling headphones for the noise canceling. I ended up returning the Treblab and the MPOW H5 and I kept the Woltix because they are more comfortable than the MPOW and had the best low-price ANC. The MPOW also had some sound interference issues randomly when the ANC was on.

So:

Bose: Best noise cancellation, good audio, comfortable, but definitely expensive!
Treblab: Best audio, worst noise cancellation (you can hear a slight hiss when turned on), comfortable, but large and they don't fold down too small.
MPOW: Good audio, good noise cancellation, but was getting some weird sound interference with the ANC on sometimes. Tight on ears.
Woltix: Good audio, good noise cancellation, most comfortable (way lighter and less tight on the ears than the MPOW), and fold down the smallest.
So far it's been running like a champ as a media drive for my system. Love the capacity (which is 2TB bigger than my last drive)! For the price and other great reviews, I of highly recommend it!

THE GOOD:
--------------
* Officially licensed Google TV OS. Which means you'll be able to watch all the usual suspects without any hassle of side-loading, or watching from a web browser, etc. When I say usual suspects, I mean Netflix, Amazon Prime, Disney, etc.
* EKO is the real deal. It's the same OS as what the Nvidia shield uses, the same as Google's very own Android TV dongle uses, the same as Tivo's 4k Stream stick, etc.
* EKO is an Australian audio/visual company, and a quick look at their site shows that they're very professional, and won't be a fly by night. They seem to aspire to be like Vizio, TCL, etc.
* 2GB ram, 8GB of storage is on par with all the low end streaming sticks on the market.
* Remote is terrific with short cut buttons to Youtube, Netflix, Amazon Prime Video, Google Play Store, and Google Assistance button at the top.

THE BAD:
-----------
* The charging port is micro-usb. It's all about usb-c now!
* In terms of pricing, they do not separate themselves from the more established brand names. So there's not a lot of incentive to try out a new company.

I'll rate this 4-Stars overall.

Clear crisp notes dipped in acoustic perfection. Listening to music on the AKG Acoustics Semi-Open Headphones is like falling in love for the first time. You may start to feel breathless as notes wash across soundscapes unveiled in moments of sheer amazement.

I purchased this to compare to another case that I own - the [[ASIN:B00V6I7NBE TOUGH Cardioid Condenser Microphone Hard Case with Dense Foam for Audio-Technica AT2020 / AT2020USB / ATR2500-USB / AT2035 Studio and USB Microphones]]. I am using that case to house a [[ASIN:B00DYD77WY Samson Concert 88 Handheld 16-Channel True Diversity UHF Wireless System]], and it was a tight fit. This one will hold my second Concert 88 system, and it does so with a lot more room and flexibility.

This case is significantly better than the Tough case. For one thing the diced foam is easy to remove. I had to use a box cutter on the foam in the other case because it was not completely cut through. For another, the three bottom layers of foam (described in the product description) make it more convenient to work with, as well as the extra depth and overall inside dimensions of this case. Bear in mind that this and the case to which I am comparing it are the same price.

I do wish there were more dividers included, and also that the long dividers would go across the entire width. However, for my purposes what came with this case is more than sufficient.

One final point of comparison - I believe that in the long run the Tough box will outlast this one because of design and materials. That one is all plastic, while this one is a combination of materials that over time are going to break if roughly handled. That said, I prefer this case and will probably order a few more for some other microphones that I own.

This is head-and-shoulders better than the cheapo webcams out there. Many webcams claim to be 1080p but actually either don't have the sensor or lens to actually resolve that much resolution, rather you get an up-sampled low resolution image in a 1080p frame. But not this one! This seems to have a properly sampled image which explains why it costs a little more than your average cheapo. The microphones are OK, they aren't great, but I always prefer using a headset or external mic anyway. I sit too far away from my screen to reply on camera mics. It won't compete with 4K brand name webcams, but in my opinion this can hold its own very well and does an admirable job for the money. It is definitely better than the built in cam on my old laptop, and adds a lot of value to my desktop for meetings. I recommend it for the price.

Using this cable to replace a broken I use in the car for Android Auto. The original USB cable that came with my Samsung phone starting having problems with frequent disconnects. It was time for a replacement.

This cable fits the bill. It's a little longer than I needed, but works like a champ. It allows the phone to charge at full speed using the car's 5v USB-A port. The phone no longer randomly disconnects from Android Auto. The blue color braid is icing on the cake.

Material is good quality and the color is as I was anticipating. Straps are comfortable on my shoulders. This offers ample room for not just my laptop, but a few folders and notebooks as well. There is padding where the laptop goes which is something I liked for just in case my bag is banged around some.

I don‚Äôt want to tell you a sad story but this one is the second amp of this model and it works fine. All I wanted was an amp tuner with duel channels for additional speakers outside. I have been through 6 different models from various suppliers, what a mess, look at their grades, it‚Äôs all bad to worse, why I don‚Äôt know. When was the last time you needed your car radio fixed or replaced...never! I even went to church and prayed but got rain instead. Good luck.

[[VIDEOID:mo4US5M5XC9DUY]]This case, the VERSO PROLOGUE (MARBLED BLUE), is so pretty, I'm going to use it for my Kindle Keyboard even though it doesn't fit quite as well as the case I've been using (the [[ASIN:B003DZ165W Kindle Lighted Leather Cover, Black (Fits Kindle Keyboard)]] ). Because the Verso cover is designed to fit a number of e-readers, and the Kindle Keyboard is the thinnest, the cover's "book spine" is a little wider than I'd like. But the spine itself is fun, showing a gold-stamped book title,"Verso II".

I tried this case with all of my small e-readers: the 1st Gen Kindle Fire, the Kindle Keyboard, and the Nexus 7. As you can see from the accompanying video slide show, the case works (or as the manufacturer would say, "is compatible with") all three. However, depending on the device, you may have to adjust the elastic bands so that they don't cover important keys or buttons.

The best fit is with the 1st Gen Kindle Fire. The device's power button and ports are at the center bottom, and the ambient light sensor is at the upper left corner, so the case's elastic bands interfere with nothing. The Kindle Keyboard is a good fit. The case's elastic bands come close to covering the outside keyboard keys at the lower left and right, but the bands can be pushed back for clearance; and the bands don't interfere with the Keyboard's power button on the lower edge. The Nexus 7 (which is slightly larger than the Fire, and slightly thicker than the Keyboard) is a snug fit, but the case still works. The elastic band at the top right must be pushed back to clear the Nexus 7 power and volume buttons located on the side edge at the top right. Although the case covers the Nexus 7 speaker on the back, the sound is the same whether the tablet is in or out of the case.

Once adjusted, the elastic bands stay in place, because there is a rubbery material on the underside of the elastic that grips the surface beneath it. (I have screen protector film on my Kindle Fire and Nexus 7, which seems like a good idea whenever a case holds the e-reader by elastic bands instead of a hard plastic shell.) This Verso case lacks any elastic closure, magnetic closure, or automatic wake/sleep feature. However, the case stays closed fairly well (like a book), and offers good protection if your device is placed carefully (not tossed) into a bag or tote. There is a pocket on the inside cover that is supposedly for "important papers", but it only holds a few thin items. Apparently you can use this pocket to hold your e-reader when the cover is folded back.

According to the retail literature that comes with it, the Verso Prologue Marbled Blue case is "compatible" with the Kindle Fire, Kindle Keyboard, Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 (7.0), NOOK, Kobo Wi-Fi, Kobo Vox, Sony Reader Daily Edition, Sony Reader Wi-Fi, BlackBerry Playbook, HTC Flyer, Dell Streak 7, and other 7" tablets (e.g., the Nexus 7). This case is extremely well made, using superior materials, and makes your e-reader look like a beautiful handmade book.

I researched soundbars on youtube and written reviews on just about every site I could find on all soundbars. Hours upon hours. Everything kept leading me back to the Bose 900. I was a little hesitant with reviews that mentioned how hard it was to set up and the app not working well. I'll just say I had zero issues with any of this. From taking it out of the box and setting it up , everything went seamlessly. Now maybe I got really lucky, but again, zero issues.

As far as the sound, it is exactly what I was wanting and more. I was concerned about my ceiling height which is angled and 12ft high at the highest point. I'll just say watching Dune exceeded my expectations. I heard sounds all the way around me. Maybe Im also lucky with my room set up, but it performed better than i expected.

I am using the soundbar by itself with no additional sub or surround speakers. The soundbar gives me more than enough bass and as far as surround im more than impressed. The dialogue is exactly what i wanted, etc.

I highly recommend the calibration from the get go. I never bothered with the standard settings and just did the calibration from the start.

All in all this thing met all the requirements. I may get the Bose 700 surround as extra enhancement, but I still feel its not fully needed. The Bose 900 does it all in my case.

One other thing is that some content might not sound the same, which is normal for any set up, but adjusting the settings from the app couldnt be anymore easier and i dont feel its a complaint. I guess if taking a minute to adjust a movie bothers you, well then so be it

I truly love these headphones for style. They are a little bulky but you can tell that style was high on the designer's list. I have been using a pair of Sennheiser headphones exclusively and I feel that the sound on these are a little crisper and the sound canceling is comparable. I have no complaints at all on the corded sound these produce. I'm a little less happy with the Bluetooth which works well when close to the bluetooth source and have a line of sight between the two. These work beautifully when listening to books on tape on walks - perhaps a little too well and cutting me off from the environment.

I do wish they would fold up a little smaller, so Sennheiser will continue to be my traveling headphones, but these have found a place wired to my computer for late night music and video enjoyment. The price is a little high for dedicated wired headphones though.

Let's cut to the chase, shall we?

This tablet is flawed. The drivers with the CD, as others have stated, are outdated. You have a choice of getting your PenPad drivers from either the Yiynova website, or alternatively there is a slightly newer version currently available from Waltop themselves. MAKE SURE YOU UNINSTALL ALL WACOM DRIVERS. I can't emphasize this enough - they can and will screw everything up and turn the hardest part (installing drivers) into a nightmare ordeal. Uninstall them, do a restart, and get the new drivers in there. Make sure you see Wacom's website for uninstall instructions, as there are additional files that you have to track down and delete to ensure they're fully gone.

After fiddling with the drivers, then comes the pen. The battery that came with mine showed up DOA, so I tried a fresh one. I can see the red 'on' light flash briefly when screwing the two components of the pen stylus together, but didn't find out until about an hour of frustration that you must screw the pen TIGHTLY together - do it with the pen on so you can see the red light come on and stay on when you've sufficiently tightened the barrel. Unfortunately, this also cascades into the rubber grip popping the side buttons slightly out of place when you're tightening it. A minor annoyance, easily corrected by shifting the rubber grip and gently pressing the buttons back into place, but still a bit of a design flaw that could be much improved upon.

I also noticed, with much confusion, that the on-screen tablet does not work outside of art programs like Paint Tool SAI and Adobe Illustrator. The cursor simply goes dead until you use a mouse to click back into one of those programs and then the on-screen tablet comes back to life. I'm not sure if this is how it's supposed to react or if there are still some issues regarding the drivers.

In spite of all this, you may notice that I still gave the tablet 4 stars. When the tablet works, it works very well. I've been spoiled by the pressure sensitivity of the Intuos4 for several years now, but the tradeoff of pressure for the ease and boost in productivity I've seen since working on the MSP19 is so worth it. It takes some getting used to if you've never worked with an on-screen tablet, but the learning curve is not steep at all. There is some discrepancy between where the tip of your pen is and where the cursor is on the screen, but you'll encounter this even with Cintiqs and I grew accustomed to it very quickly - just within an hour or two of initial use.

Weight-wise, the monitor has a bit of heft to it, but it's not unmanageable. The adjustable stand in the back is a very nice addition, and I've found that this tablet rests comfortably in my lap if I need to get up close. It's easy to pick up and move around as needed if you don't want to buy the adjustable stand add-on. My only lament is the lack of hotkey buttons, which I hope will be included in future models.

If you're like me and you're agonizing on whether to go with the 10" model or the 19", stop wondering and spring for the 19". It's a third of the price of the newest (and smallest) Cintiq models with highly comparable specs. You have more space to make wide, sweeping gestures, and you will save yourself a lot of pain and hand cramping since you have a ton of real estate to work with.

Despite its shortcomings, I am extremely happy with this tablet and hope to see the company take their success further into the future with better, sleeker, and more responsive models. Wacom could use some healthy competition.

I've waited 4 months to write a review for this and I must say I'm more than happy with it. Perfect smart TV with everything you need. It works perfectly and I don't see why one shouldn't buy this for such a great price. The video and audio quality is great and so is the entire TV itself. I wouldn't compare it to a $1000 TV but for the price it asks, Vizio E32-C1 is absolutely perfect.

Highly recommend it!

I purchased this 12.9'" iPad Pro keyboard case and have been using it pretty regularly for a few months. The key travel height is comfortable, and accuracy has been excellent. Reminds me of my MB Pro keyboard when all the keys still worked. I would love to find this Bluetooth keyboard available for laptops.

This backlit iPad keyboard and trackpad was probably the least expensive model ($35) at the time, and I wasn't expecting much, but I took a chance and I am glad I did. It paired quickly, and it was easy to connect the trackpad feature via accessibility settings.

The RGB lighting is around the keys, and I would have preferred it if the letters were translucent and lit up as well.

My only complaint would be the rigid frame on the case. It made me a bit nervous, and felt like I had to force it a bit, but it fit well once I got it in. I wish it were a bit softer and more flexible at the corners.

Overall, I would say it's a good value and would recommend it.

I listen to lectures on headphones when doing chores around the house and often can't hear people trying to get my attention. I've seen neck speakers before, and I thought it would be a very cool option for me as my family gets kind of annoyed that I can't hear them and they can't tell if I'm currently listening to something.
But I'll be honest, after trying these, I'm not really loving them. I had a pair of sunglasses speakers that aimed sound towards my ears, but this sort of blasts sound out and around me. Like, not even towards my ears. Basically, it seems just as loud to someone else in the room with me as it does to me, which then begs the question of why not just use an external speaker at that point? The call quality was just OK as well. The one thing I can say is that the build quality seems quite good. It feels really durable and made with premium feeling materials. But I just can't shake the feeling that for the asking price, I'm missing the point of these. Shouldn't the speakers be facing upwards towards my ears instead of blasting at each other in front of my Adam's Apple? Seems like a weird design that might be missing the mark.

This is my third echo dot 4th gen. We also have a 3rd gen we use for weather and notifications. The 4th gens (especially those with a clock) are perfect for the bedroom. Music sounds pretty good and voice recognition is great. This particular dot we use in the master bath and it's a massive improvement over the old Sony speaker we used to use. I'm a pleased customer.

You will not be disappointed with these earphones. I use mine at night to listen to podcasts (note: also keeps spiders out of your ears). The sound is great and the noise cancellation superb. I have a number of headphones and some work better than others. When I sleep at night, I always wear my headphones. All I hear is what I am listening to with these. Some of my other noise cancellation headphones don't cancel the noise as much. Others don't have as nice of sound. I like these so far the most.

with today's need to have so many applicanes to create the home theatre effect (that is my husband's job) and then there is me, the wife who is technology challenged: the harmony is easy to set up to capture almost all appliances we have and for me - I just press one botton to get to each application (dvd, blueray, music, watch tv). the 'help' button is very useful too ... a little help desk feature. Just remember to point at the applcances when you press the buttons (I tend to move the remote away too quicky and sometimes one piece of the applicance does not switch on/off - but there is always the help button). our older one broke (my fault!) and it was no brainer to replace it with the same one. I love it and so will many wives who has a husband who like his gadgets.

Cons
cant do RF, althugh the 890 model does this and it would be good to have bluetooth to do the playstation 3.

Lousy tech here.  It does work some, however, not well at all.  Let me repeat, it does not work well at all. I guess you get what you pay for.  Forget streaming music to a bluetooth speaker, it will only work in spurts.  A real waste of hard earned money!

I love this tv, it is definitely a masterpiece! Very well made and fantastic quality. Deep blacks, vivid colors, natural skin tones...

Not the thinnest tv on the market but a great tv still! Easy to set up and get going. Slim feet that slide into place with no tools- only have ONE configuration. 2 USBs, 4 HDMIs, Ethernet, optical & headphone outputs, & a mini a/v input. Operating system is Google Tv which works smoothly and has lots of apps built in. Works with Google Home and Alexa.

Has some intrusive ads on the homepage. You can go into the settings/privacy/ ads to opt out of personalized ads though. You can use your remote microphone to do voice commands on the tv. It also has the nice shortcut buttons for Youtube, Netflix, Disney+, and Prime Video.

Sound has tweeters on the side. It upscales the audio to give you a surround sound effect. Acoustic auto calibration which when you go to your sitting area with the remote and start this- it sends these crazy alien laser blaster sounds out of the speakers for a couple seconds and your remote reads them so the tv can process the information and adjust your speakers accordingly. It will then adjust the speakers so it sends sound to where you're sitting to give you the best experience possible!

The cognitive processor in this puts more emphasis into the areas of the picture that you'll be focused on- definitely makes a noticeable difference!

XR TRILUMINOS PRO technology gives you better color accuracy and depth.

XR Contrast booster gives you better contrast.

Very deep blacks with very little light blooming (meaning it has very even brightness across the screen.) The screen has PLENTY of brightness, that is definitely not an issue with this tv!

Ambient optimization option which changes your screen based on the ambient lighting in the room. Controls brightness and color tones. There are settings to optimize the screen for Netflix, Imax, Cinema, Etc that are amazing!

Motion is great, it has 120 hertz which keeps up with the action very well! You can adjust the Motionflow settings to your custom settings or just set it to auto and let it do it's thing.

Comparing it to the other top Sony models:
If you're on a budget and this is on the higher end of that, you might look into the Sony X80J- it's also a 2021 model and is 4k Ultra HD. It's not quite as nice of a picture as this Full Array but it's still a great tv! Otherwise if you can swing it- this X90J Full Array is definitely a fantastic choice! If your budget can STILL swing more though, you might even look into the X90J OLED tv, it's picture pops even more than this Full Array. Whatever your choice, you'll love any of them! I have all 3 models and we absolutely love each and every one of them- the X80 and X90 line are just fantastic tvs at a really fair price point.
The quality exceeded my expectations. This is a nice roomy, sturdy bag. Holds pistols, extra magazines, ammo, headphones etc. Perfect to take to the range!
Product is junk. Right earbud stopped working.  Only solution was to mail back the product which I don't have time to do. Wouldn't send a new one or refund. Don't waste your money

The above title says it all. It looks great, but it becomes useless when I can't use it as an earbud. When you are hearing music or you can listen to other party talk clearly but they can't hear you clearly. Returned.

I bought two of these for my Pi's. The nicely match my other items. There is ample space inside and the unit. The unit just plain feels better than a plastic one when you think about durability. I will buy again if needed.

However, the Samsung case has all the same flaws, is more expensive and not leather. Mine is from August 2011 and a solid Black color so I can't speak to the two other color choices. 11 ounces make the 1.3 pound weight of the tablet almost 2 pounds but that is what leather does.
LIKES-
black leather finish looks sleek, feels expensive & provides long lasting firm protection from scratches and nicks
The inside lining is attractive and protective
The back cover folds to into a stand with multiple horizontal viewing angles that hold firm
The elastic clasp keeps it closed and won't pop open like other closures can
the charging port is covered and protected when the case is closed
UNLIKES -
the charger can't be used while using the case as a stand
the camera lens cutout isn't wide enough - lol - you get a halo
the speakers need cutouts
The snug fit holding the tablet in place over the long haul loosens (neoprene rubber could be a solution)
When the snug fit loosens the pwoer and volume buttons slide under the cover *sigh*
There are extra cutouts that make no sense

I didn't want to bring my laptop to a conference to take notes, so I purchased this bluetooth keyboard to go with my Samsung tablet. THANK GOD!!! It held it's battery for the entire week of the conference. The keyboard quickly connected and disconnected upon opening and closing which prolonged the battery life. A great purchase!

Most people are raving about this camera because they are using it with their iPhones.

But if you don't have an iPhone, keep looking, there are other kits that will be more to your liking. Because of my lack of an iPhone (oddly, I just got one two days ago, so I may give this another try and then update the review if I like the camera more) I had to use the included link to the executable Windows program. The program is outdated (like from the days of VCR's and answering machines) and has no documentation.

By documentation, I mean there are minimal instructions and no built in help files. I was able to get it to work by running the software with a lot of finagling and figuring it out by means of hunting around through my past experiences hooking up cameras.

All in all, a bit of a disappointment, I was hoping to catch the wankers who keep spraypainting my carport.

Update - Still using this with the PC, just a note, you have to leave the PC software running to report. This camera works through an extension cord but not a surge protector. Not sure of what the range is and at least in our house, it needed to be on the same circuit breaker as the base, but this could just be weird wiring in our house.

A nice feature of the camera is a motion detection feature, so you don't end up with hours of blank unmoving street view for example. For the recording, pretty much continuously, it takes about 2GB per night (this is with camera on from about 9pm to 8am). There is a way to look at the recorded footage in super fast motion, so it takes about five minutes to watch the entire night's events (use VLC);'oh, hello again, curious kitty who keeps hanging out on my porch.'

This is not an outdoor camera, but we are using it outdoors anyways (tried placing it near a window, but glare of light on the window blinded the camera). I don't have any need to record stuff indoors. Because of the camera we caught a strange creepy person coming up to our house while we were out yesterday, they also visited the houses of two of our neighbors. If not for the camera we wouldn't have known about this. There are a lot of strange characters in our neighborhood and there have been a few incidents; nothing major, a crazy woman tried to break in while we were eating dinner, a man with dementia was wandering around our bridge, kids stealing wood from our woodpile, you know, ordinary disturbances, so this person was exactly what we wanted to see while we weren't home.

The software allows for up to nine cameras to be in use, I can't even imagine that, but it might be cool to have another to watch our backyard, we might be able to catch the raccoons or the river otter who we've only gotten fleeting glimpses of.

For a friend who has an older model car, did not have Bluetooth in it. She had tried numerous other options. That did not work. She liked it so well I purchased another for a friend for Christmas who's minivan also does not have Bluetooth. The only problem is sometimes the volume is up too loud and her car and there is an echo. She has a blast with it, can ask it questions, get the news. and she was very excited to find out that she would be able to listen to her apple music.  Google maps is a breeze

This is ideal for the person who has CDs and doesn't have the time, or want to bother, downloading them to digital. The Bluetooth connected to my car and my speaker at home for excellent sound. The built in speaker was nice but not robust. I love that it is rechargeable so no need to connect except when charging. It even has a jack for ear buds, and ear buds. It actually makes a nice gift for anyone with CDs

Bluetooth
CD Player
Built-in Speaker Stereo
MP3 Player
Rechargeable
USB

Ok, it feels cheap. Because IT IS. It is a great value for all of the features it has for about $70. What more could you ask for? Well, how about standard rackmount ears? The ones supplied dont have the correct screw spacing. I can only use top or bottom holes. Not much to complain about I guess. As with other reviewers the bluetooth is really really terrible.  I get 10 ft away and it either starts stuttering or drops the connection completely.

Well-made audio cable with gold contacts, does improve the sound over cheaper cables. I used it to connect a computer to my stereo (e.g., to listen to Pandora), and the sound was definitely clearer and brighter with this one than with the cheaper cable I'd used before (because that's what I had on hand).

One thing to note: my RCA plugs had very tight sleeves, so I was having trouble getting them on/off, and was worried about breaking the ports on the amp. I took a pair of small needlenose pliers, and gently stretched out the insides just a tad (there are six segments on the circular sleeve, so you need to do this in 3 places around the circle). After that it still fit snugly, but was no longer an effort needing a lot of muscle.

As others have pointed out, paying ridiculous prices for such cables is silly, they're mostly the same quality hardware with a lot more marketing. This price point is just about right in my opinion.

As I try to start all my reviews with where it's made, this one falls into the Made in China category. It's not an extremely expensive hi-fi unit, eben thou it says it is hi-fi, but for the price the sound quality should a lot better. It's like listening to an am radio station that goes in and out of range. The tuning is not a simple selector switch, but instead it uses a scroll wheel located right by the volume scroll wheel. I'm not sure what genius thought that was a smart location for it, because on a few a occasions I've changed the tuning by mistake. if your TV is like mine with an aux cord out, and no sound system, than you might run into the issue where the TV won't play through its own speakers when the unit is plugged in and your using it. This may be an issue if you wanted to use it as a audio booster if you are hard of hearing and want a separate volume control from that of the TV's speakers. Overall it was just poor experience with the unit. I usually love Sennheiser products, and they used to be made very well, I believe there high end is still that way. but like every company these days they sacrifice a lot trying to cheapen themselves to a price point that everyone can afford.

1 sleeping bag- mylar
1 raincoat/parka (has a hood)-mylar
1 drawstring nylon bag with toggle, mini D-ring clip, AND emergency whistle (sounds toy like, but it makes plenty of noise).

Sleeping bag is 84" long, and measures 36" wide (so 72" around). Depending on your gear, can be used as bivi sack for use over existing sleeping bag, or possibly as a makeshift tube tent. Or cut fully open for use as a blanket. Mylar material helps trap body heat. Options for use to keep you warm.

I always keep an emergency blanket in my car, and hiking packs. I got this because I like that ONE of the items is a RAIN COAT with hood (40" wide, about 80" around. Length including hood is @49", measured from shoulder down is roughly 37"). One way to not get chilled to the bone is to not let clothing get wet.

These are reusable. Whether you will want to try to reuse them is another thing. The material is durable enough for more than one use, it is really just a matter of getting it flattened out and folded to fit back into the bag (good luck). I unfolded and opened mine to make sure I had what was described and to make sure it would fit my 5'10" 265# body frame. But I just held it up to me, and all looks good there. Then I carefully folded it back up and was able to just get it back into bag. I doubt I would be as successful if I had fully fluffed out the material. Alas, all looks good, mylar looks fantastic. Pleased to have this. Whether one use or multiple, I find these products a must have for any car kit,hiking pack, get home kit, bug out bag, camping supplies, etc. This bag is tiny, and takes up very little space.

My son absolutely loves his Spiderman headphones.  I like that the sound on them cannot be turned to where it is dangerous for his ears.  This survived a vacation with a 4 year old who is pretty rough on things!

Just received my cozyphones and wish I had found them years ago. Light and comfortable is what I had been looking for and bought several pairs of over the ear phones, which worked ok, but the plastic cord always tangled up. These cozyphones have a nice, soft fabric covered cord. I just love that kind of attention to detail. I listen to old time radio programs to fall asleep and some ocean waves, or brown noise on my iPod and iPad. These headphones work great for both. Thank you cozyphones for a super product. I‚Äôll be buying a few more as spares and gifts. Highly recommend this product since I live in a very warm climate and these are not hot at all. Can‚Äôt wait to sleep tonight with my new cozyphones.

This really is one very nice looking cover. It makes me feel as if I am holding a real book instead of a tablet/ereader, and it does look a lot like leather (which it isn't). I really like the 'sleep' feature that this cover has, putting my Kindle to sleep mode when I close the cover, something I haven't come across in the other covers I've bought in the past. It does have a handy stand feature that lets you prop it up, in the horizontal position only. The fasteners to hold the cover closed and to keep the Kindle in place inside are rubber, but they do a decent job of it (and can be positioned to prevent any important ports/buttons from being covered). Of course, with this type of cover (fake leather, going for the appearance of a real journal/book), the speakers are going to be covered, but it doesn't have too much impact on the sound when you're using it.

There's been comments made on the smell of this cover, and I've noticed that pretty much all of my fake leather covers come with some sort of odor when they arrive. It usually dissipates after a day or two (longest might have lasted a week) and this was no exception - if anything, this was one of the 'better' smelling faux leather covers I've received. None of them were so awful as to be off-putting, in my opinion, but I'm aware that it's a personal thing, how much it affects you.

All in all, this is an impressive looking cover that has a few nice features and enough heft to provide some decent protection for your Kindle Fire.
Not compatible with my IPhone 7 Plus and it broke the same day before I had a chance to return it.  Not a happy camper.

Great sound,  noise cancelation, and look. Other than that, another company purchased jaybird, and they stopped updating the software for the earbuds and case. The fit is also not the best for me personally. Tried the large and medium wing fins, but both made my ears bleed for some reason. Small wing fins didn't feel like they would stay in. All in all, I'd say purchase at your own risk.

I was considering buying another brand, twice the price, and lauded the best speakers around, until I heard the sound coming from this baby. Download the app, pick some tunes, and be prepared to have your mind blown.

Super thin, huge 17" touch screen with colors that just POP, large touchpad mouse, and silent chiclet keyboard. These are just the initial impressions one would see at first blush when approaching this high-quality laptop. Look a little deeper and one would find that this Dell XPS 17 sports a powerful 11th generation I7-11800H cpu with a dedicated RTX 3050 graphics card with Nvidia's real-time ray tracing and 16gb of ram. A 512GB ssd rounds out the entire package.

The Dell XPS 17 is simply elegant and high-quality. I was able to upgrade this laptop to Windows 11 painlessly and the new UI just looks great on this screen. It runs silently during normal web browsing and video watching. When playing games, the fan kicks in and the cooling seems adequate, but I still have an external laptop cooler helping it along.

Speaking of games, this laptop will run the latest games, but being at the bottom of the RTX line of graphics cards, the screen's 3840x2400 resolution simply is too much for the 3050 to run at the highest quality. It means that one would either run at a lower resolution or lower quality. The resolution issue can be alleviated if one turns on DLSS for resolution scaling.

So that is one of the first problems I would point out with the specs that I have in this laptop. The RTX3050 paired with the super high resolution means one must compromise in some way. In addition, performance in VR is somewhat poor. Half Life: Alyx runs well at low quality settings but any higher and the screen stutters and can cause nausea -- this was tested through wired and wireless configurations.

The second complaint that I have for this laptop is that the only included ports are 4 usb Type-C ports, headphone jack and an SD card reader. It is great that the ports support up to Thunderbolt 3, but the fact that no Type-A ports are available, dongles will be a part of life. It's nice that Dell includes a dongle that sports an HDMI and a Type-A port, there is no ethernet or display port support out of the box.

A good 9-in-1 dongle will cost you at least $60 and even then, the quality could be questionable. I happened to have a 9-in-1 dongle, but the ethernet port seems to lose connection constantly. This means that either you take a chance with a $60 no-name dongle or you spend over $100 for a proven one.

This then brings me to the last problem that I want to point out. A gaming PC has very high power requirements. Currently, there is no Type-C product that will provide (or pass through) the 130W that the Dell XPS 17 will require. It means that the nifty dock that you bought to get the additional ports that you need? It won't be able to power the laptop. You can connect a 100W charger to the laptop, but you will get a warning from the operating system. So perhaps on travel, one can get away with trickle charging the laptop, but at home, you will always be stuck with taking up two ports, one for power and one for your monitor.

Overall, this is a GREAT laptop with high quality build, but at the current specs, some things just cause awkward situations that one needs to work around.

With this splitter I can keep my cordless headphones and mini speaker plugged in at the same time. This saves me a lot of time and hassles. I'm using this with a six foot extension cable and it works great. I'm so happy amazon makes it so easy to get what you need for musical perfection. I'm enjoying to listening to music with a mini speaker half the time and headphones the rest of the time.

~The Rebecca Review

I would give this one star, except for the cheap price.  The number one problem with mine is that the heart rate monitor does not accurately measure heart rate, or even close.  After 15-20 minutes of running, the readings fluctuated wildly.  At first it was 120, then 131, then a few seconds later 85!  I tried looser and tighter band settings, and also tried rotating the watch to position the sensor on different areas of my wrist (to detect pulse better), and it still never worked correctly.  I'm not sure if mine is just defective, or this product is poorly designed.  There are also a few other minor issues, such as the dull screen (see photo - very hard to read when outdoors) and also my device has randomly shut off a few times.  Overall, I would not recommend this product for anyone.  It's too bad, though, because the design is nice (as is the price) and the bluetooth connectivity and software work well.

I went on the search for a set of ear buds that would stay in my ears better than my Airpod Pros but with the same level of Noise cancellation. It seemed like the Sony WF-1000XM4 and Bose Quietcomfort earbuds were the top picks in this space. After a lot of research i went with the Sony earbuds. Besides their sound and level of ANC. i liked the fact the Sony earbuds still had a lot of playback control available from the earbuds and you can use either earbud individually. I also felt like the fact that they sit in your ear canal rather than on the outside would contribute to the noise cancellation.

The earbuds felt and sound good and the accompanying app was nice but the case had a cheap, almost cardboard feel. My main issues were, although the earbuds never actually fell out of my ear, I think their top-heavy design made them feel like they were always about to fall out. The bigger issue i had, which won't apply to everyone, is how much effort went into getting them to sit correctly in my ear. Even with twisting, and pushing, I could never get the right earbud to fit securely in my ear like the left one did.

After a day of wearing the Sonys i decided to pick up a pair of Bose Quietcomfort ear buds as i already had a pair of Quietcomfort 35 over the ears that i loved, i figured I'd give Bose another shot. As soon as i opened the Bose, I immediately fell in love. Besides the unboxing and charging case feeling more premium, the earbuds went into my ear effortlessly and securely. I wore them the first day and they stayed in place all day and sounded great.

Although the Sony WF-1000XM4 is a great set of earbuds, The Bose earbuds have the same functionality, sound and ANC but are designed in a way to comfortably fit a wider array of ear shapes and at a cheaper price. The Sonys are going back and the Bose are going to be my new day-to-day earbuds.

Doesn't over work my lap top like the Brio did.

It feels worth the 200, the Brio felt like a $50 cam. Absolutely worth the money and if you register purchase within 14days of delivery, you get 2 years warranty!!!!

I received this as a free review sample. I subtracted a star because in small quarters the fan can get irritating, and also the picture area is a little skewed. The latter is not enough to ruin a video, but combined with the fan noise I felt that this falls into the four star category. To be fair, this is about on par with other portable projectors in this price range and sharing the general form factor.

On the plus side, this is an inexpensive way to get a large screen TV (assuming that your wall is the screen), that does a credible job of projecting movies, TV and presentations. I tested it using a Chromecast and streaming video from YouTube to my phone, then casting from my phone to the Chromecast dongle connected to one of the HDMI ports in the rear. No issues and it was actually a treat. I also tested it with an old Roku in an HDMI port streaming a movie from Netflix. To be sure, neither experience compares to my HD TV screen and surround sound system, but this does not come close to the price tags of those. Bang for the buck this is excellent if you are in a budget.

Frankly, I did not test the other ports, but do want to point out that the 'SD' card port is really USB A that will take a flash drive or an SD card using an adapter. Actually, I think that is a plus as well because flash drives are cheap and a 32GB one can hold a respectable amount of movies, home videos or presentations.

Sound quality is not spectacular, but is definitely adequate. Overall, this is as good as any projector among the four that I have either owned or tested, and is better than some. It would easily be a five star projector if it had a quieter fan. If you can live with that you will probably love it.

I sit this way off to the side of my computer and when a friend calls on skype, I'll use this microphone while multitasking and they can hear me just fine no matter where I am in the room. Very nice microphone with very clear sound. NO complaints at all, very fair price, made very well!

I have had the latest gen Kindle DX since October 2010. I am a singer in a choir and use it to display my sheet music. It is well suited to my needs. The display is clear and crisp and is the size of a standard music hymnal. The catch is getting the music onto the device. Most publishers are starting to provide PDF versions of at least melody with accompaniment. However, being an alto in a choir, that isn't sufficient. I need the 3 or 4 part choral version. Also, it is formatted for an 8.5 x 11 inch page with headers, footers, and page numbers. I only need the music staff and lyrics. So I do it the hard way. I scan my (purchased & owned) hymnal or sheet music, crop it down to what I need, then convert it to a PDF. Lots of work, but the payoff is worth it. I no longer carry around 100+ lbs of sheet music and hymnals twice a week! Keep in mind this isn't for everyone. It requires a lot of time and patience, but once the music has been prepped and imported, it's done and ready when you need it. I assume after a year I'll have perhaps 80% of my library scanned. Then I'll only need 5-10 minutes each week to add the relevant music to a collection for quick access.

I also use the Kindle not so much for reading, but for listening. I love the text-to-speech feature. I use it for casual reading as well as my Cisco tech books. Funky digital voice and some unusual phrasing and pronunciation, but you can't beat having it read to you while your hands and eyes are otherwise engaged in other things such as driving or crocheting :D

I have used the web feature while camping. Nothing great, but you can check email, news, Facebook and other text or mobile supported sites. I've also used it when traveling to get directions or check Yelp while on the go. Since I don't have a smart phone this is actually a huge plus! One thing to keep in mind is that image intensive sites may crash the Kindle (due to lack of memory) and you will have to reload it to clear the issue.

The music player is lacking, but for an e-reader, I guess that's expected. You can load music and it will play in the order you loaded it. You can pause and skip, but that's about it. No actual controls or playlist features.

One major feature that is currently lacking is hands free page turning. Since there is no USB driver or bluetooth support, I don't foresee this ever being available, but it is definitely something to keep in mind. I also play flute and am unable to use the Kindle to display my flute music unless it is a single page.

So, for my needs, it's great. However, if you're looking for more media support or better web access, you should look elsewhere.
I purchased this for my Dell powered speakers.  The adapter worked just the original adapter, so I have no complaints.

There are other sized rubber rings to fit your earhole.  The Audi was definitely a lot sharper and clearer.  I also played joss stone and the voice was crisper. I wanted to get a wireless mouse and didn't want to take up a USB slot so I got this bluetooth one. It's great and I love it, but the one problem is that I hate the touch pads. They normally have a setting that if you have a USB mouse plugged in you can de-activate the touchpad, but they don't recognize Bluetooth mice in the same way.
Nevertheless I really like it, and it turns itself off when not in use so the battery lasts a long time. Great buy.
These headphones are as described. They work great drowning out all the noise while I am working out! Would buy them again. My kids also love them.

This is a decent sounding pair of budget friendly wireless earbuds. They aren't the best for the price, but they aren't the worst either. They're about normal. But one of the big features of this set is supposed to be the touch controls, however my daughter found them completely unreliable. Sometimes she had to touch them 5x before they registered to pause the music, which made her more likely to pull out the player and pause it there instead.
I'd say these are 4 star headphones except for that selling point failure, if you are buying these because of the touch controls, I'd have to reduce the score to 3.

I needed a speaker that I could plug into the TV through the USB port on the TV because my HDMI ports are in use. I did not receive a cable that would do that, even though I was assured all cables were supplied. There are NO instructions. NONE. I pitched this without ever taking it out of the box.

For the price, I'd expect a little bit of magic... They're great headphones, comfortable on the head, and the noise cancelling is great, but having to hold the power button for 3 seconds to turn on doesn't feel like a $300 pair of headphones from 2019. I wish they 1. Turned on automatically when you put them on, and 2. turned off or paused automatically when you take them off.

The volume control/touch control isn't intuitive at all, either. I like to think I'm a pretty smart guy, and I couldnt figure it out without reading the instructions. A product that requires reading the manual for full operation is a badly designed product. Just look at apple. They don't make a product that a 5 year old couldn't pick up and use. As much as I disagree with them as a company, they've set the bar for product usability, and at this price point I expect nothing less.

A $350 pair of headphones in 2019 that has little more in the way of user comforts than a $50 pair is kind of sad.

I use it for exercising, particularly running or high impact sports, calls, music whilst I am doing the housework, listening to audio books whilst heading out to do my essential shopping. I had been looking for earbuds that wouldn't continually fall out of my ears and started researching here on Amazon and was immediately drawn to these "earhook" headphones.  I was a little worried that they might be uncomfortable because I have very sensitive ears but I was pleasantly surprised by how comfortable these are. I just love the fact that I can wear them on my walks and while running around town and not have to worry about my earbuds falling out every few minutes. I would definitely recommend these earhook headphones for anyone who is tired of having their earbuds fall out of their ears all the time.

works very well with my Bose sound bar and not i can use my phone and Echo Dot to play my favorite music. i have my TV hooked up to my Bose sound bar and i hooked up the audio adapter with provided cables. when my TV is off i can pair my sound bar with my phone or Echo Dot. when i turn on my TV it automatically switches to my TV. i highly recommend it

This just arrived, and it seems perfect. My 2017 13-inch MacBook Pro fits in perfectly. The front pockets provide ample space for even my trackball mouse and the cables we have to have to use ANYTHING external since Apple decided to create bus ports that nothing will fit into.

Of course, if I didn't need those darned little cables, I wouldn't need a case at all. Thank God someone's out there to protect us in at least small ways from the problems created by the engineered obsolescence that is putting us in debt almost as much as healthcare costs.

Here's a hint, Apple and other tech companies. Weight isn't the only factor in portability. Anything gained in that area by the thin profile of this MacBook is lost because it's necessary to carry two or three little cables with me. The more pieces I have to cart, the greater the chance something will get lost. I feel the same way about eliminating DVD drives. Not EVERYTHING is on the Web, and free Net access isn't available EVERYWHERE. I feel like I'm spending more money for less functionality.

I haven't bought an external DVD drive yet because I'm running out of ports, but I think one might fit in the larger outside pocket. I'm not entirely sure, but the pocket is a nice size, so I think it might.

It's "almost" (see my edit below) impossible to find a negative review of the Audio-Technica ATH-M50x Closed Back Headphones. And I have to agree. Probably the best headphones I've ever owned. They've been available now for 10 or so years. You can't get this high end quality audio anywhere else for this price point. I got an excellent deal because I came across an Amazon seller, The Blucoil Store, who also included 3 high quality extra items for just about the same price as the headphones alone. My package included an extra cable, a solid hard plastic carrying case, and a FiiO A1 headphone amplifier.
The headphones live up to all the positive reviews, and the extras included made for a very good total price.
I would definitely recommend this product.
Updated 2/4/2021, 4 months later.
I still love these headphones. I have to laugh when I occasionally check the customer reviews and find that most of the criticisms are based on how these headphones were purposely engineered. Let me be more specific. Some of the negative comments include:
-others around you can hear what you're listening to. Oh well. Too bad. They should probably put on their own noise cancelling headphones. Which brings me to my next point:
-they're not noise cancelling. Yup, that's right. When I did my search for headphones, I specifically did NOT want noise cancelling OR wireless. Much prefer putting the money saved when not buying these options and putting it toward better cans.
-there is no microphone on the cables. Correct again. These headphones were not necessarily intended for those who want a set of cans primarily to support their cell phone addiction.
-they must be used with the company's proprietary cables to attach to the headphones. I'll take that and love it. Why? Because they twist and lock into the bottom of the can. How many times, with other headphones, have I moved too far, or stood up or whatever, and the cord would be ripped out of the cans!!
-too much bass, not enough base. Midrange too pronounced, or not enough. And they go on and on and on.
-the "best" (tongue in cheek) criticism stated that none of the included cables + the included adapters fit their computer. I don't know what kind of a computer this person has, but, well...you get the idea.
-and finally, and I quote, "I needed to add an EQ to make them sound like I wanted them to". Precisely! These cans are marketed for those who are looking for an accurate, unadulterated representation of the original recording. The way the musicians and the recording engineers intended it to sound. If one doesn't find that acceptable, and that's fine, include an EQ somewhere in the mix. As a matter of fact, I have more than my share of sound shaping hardware and software all over my system in order to taylor the music to my liking.
You need to like how the sound is reproduced, and this is very subjective. One person's likes are another person's hates, especially when it comes from those who love to sound like they "might" know what they are talking about.. I bought and returned a number of headphones because I didn't care for how they sounded. I kept these.
I do agree with one common complaint. The earpads do get uncomfortable after a while. I checked for aftermarket replacements, but many included their own negative reviews that they changed the sound quality from the originals. That's the last thing I want.
In my (very judgmental) opinion, you can't go wrong with these!

Although this was probably designed for apple airpods which are a bit slimmer than off brand ones, I did manage to get them into my regular earpods I use as well. It's nice that they were two cables on the box. The silicone rubbery feels make it harder to slip off my neck, which is something I like as well.
