Lets start by defining what this set is and is not: it is a set of devices that are designed to be aesthetically pleasing. It is designed to be minimalist. It is not designed to be ergonomic.

I liken the keyboard to the apple wireless keyboard; keys feel like a laptop and you can't adjust the angle of the keyboard unless you stack up stuff under the back of the keyboard.

I do like the design of these. They are good looking devices and have an interesting magnetic battery compartment. If sleek and minimalist is what you are going for in your work space, these fit the bill.

These devices are plastic. I don't find this to be a major drawback, but some might have issues with it.

I have already stated, this set is not ergonomic. The mouse is especially awkward to use (unless you like the generally flat styles mouses like the apple magic mouse). My everyday mouse is the Microsoft Arc mouse (the older hinged one, not the one that bends). If you like the programmable back button on your mouse, you will find that you miss it on the microsoft designer set.

Pairing is where most people seem to have the biggest problem with this set. I also had issues. I am running Win 7 64 bit and have bluetooth on the computer. I had the most current BT4.0 drivers, but still ended up having to check the manufacturer's driver site for an additional driver. Even after installing a new driver, I was only able to get the keyboard to work consistently. The keyboard seems to work well and even when I start up my computer. The mouse, on the other hand, was less forgiving. No matter what I did, I could only SOMETIMES get the mouse to correctly pair. The computer could see it, but it wouldn't save the device or even stay connected after the pairing was complete. I am sure with more noodling around, I could probably get it connected, but for me, it isn't really worth it (I like my old Arc Mouse better). I bought the set with the intent of using just the keyboard, so it was not really a huge issue for me.

It seems that this set is intended for devices that use with Windows 8 or above, so keep that in mind when purchasing. I am using 7 and it generally works, but it is going to be most dependent on the Bluetooth drivers you have installed.

Pro-Tip: Look for used sets. A lot of people buy this keyboard thinking it will be easy to set up, then return it when they realize that you need bluetooth on your computer or you will have to buy a dongle. Currently, there are sets that are like new at 30% the suggested retail (half what they are actually selling for). Buy from Warehouse deals and the purchase is guaranteed by amazon (just like any new item that is sold by amazon). I think the deals that can be had on this set make it worth while for someone who is looking to try out the set, but not sure if it will play nice or if they will even like it.

This works well and I love the unifying receiver. The only issue is it's too small for me. I have medium sized lady hands, but I can't rest my hand on the mouse - it's too small. Just not comfortable for me.

Love the product. I have several of them now.
Nice digital display.
And you can easily mute the speaker to avoid listening to alarms.

I brought this headphones for my everyday Office meetings. This head phone is very good and noise cancellation, sound quality and bass is very nice. The head phone is light weight, so i couldn't feel any difficulty to use for longer hour meetings as well.

Not being a techie, I am never too good at figuring out electronics. These headphones were fairly easy, however. They do come charged, which is very helpful. The instructions were very easy to understand. The charging wire is just the USB cable, in order to plug it into a computer. If charging from a wall outlet is desired, it is necessary to use the adapter from a cellphone or other device, not a real problem. The Bluetooth paired easily with my phone, but had more issue with a tablet. The headphones just recognized the phone and the light indicated that it was connected. I had to take the phone more than 30 feet away before the headset was in "pairing" mode. But then the Bluetooth worked fine. Mind you, I said I am not a techie. The sound is fine, as I am not into loud music in my head, I had to turn it down. It is necessary to remove the headphones to adjust the volume buttons, at least it is for me. For someone who has never had a set of wireless headphones, these are easy to use. I am very happy to have them.
Works great for cars that don't have build in Bluetooth.
We can‚Äôt live without it. It controls all of our lamps, Xmas tree, and more. very handy for asking questions.

I like that these earbuds came with a charger and different size of ear rubber cover. What I don‚Äôt like it is earbuds stays inside the ear  only 60 % of the time. It‚Äôs stressing me out that I need to be always on look out and not to loose them. I changed ear rubber to medium size thinking that maybe solution and will give a couple more days to try. I don‚Äôt know why apple EarPods stays without falling out even if I walk fast or run and others brand are not. Something wrong with design! Will keep you updated it I keep them or return them.

This is better than a lot of other speakers on the market but you get what you pay for. This is a lower/mid range speaker and that‚Äôs what you get. Everything works well but it‚Äôs not loud enough. Even on the highest setting it‚Äôs hard to heart music or an audio book while you‚Äôre showering.

I bought these because I thought the heavy bass would be nice during action movies... I was right, the sound for that type of thing is great. BUT they are super uncomfortable. I know that no headphones are one size fits all but they really hurt the crown of my head. I had to buy a protective pad for it which made a world of difference. Would I recommend them? hard to say but they are great for action movies.

Some of my devices lack really nice speakers, so I like to have a speaker handy so that I can listen to music or presentations as I go about my day. Let's take a look at this one.

HOW THIS COMES
This speaker comes in a foam liner inside a sturdy gift appropriate box. It has an audio 3.5 cord as well as a Type C charging cord with USB at the other end. It has a carry handle on it too. There is a basic instruction manual in a variety of languages.

BLUETOOTH
The connections are usually pretty stable, but once in a while depending on the device, we have to remove the speaker and reboot the device and speaker to get it to line up again even if it has already been connected previously with no issues.

SOUND
The sound of this speaker is surprisingly fantastic. It depends on the source recording, of course, but in most cases, I have to say that the sound of this little guy is really great. The top however, does move in and out so you can not block it or put anything on top of it or it can break the speaker.

MICRO SD CARD SLOT
I have to be honest here. I can not get the Micro SD slot to work correctly. I have tried many times to get it to play, but it won't. The directions say that you can hit the mode button and it will get to the micro SD card mode but it just sits and goes back to blutooth mode again. I am not sure why this is happening. The same card plays on other devices just fine so I know it is not the card.

AUDIO
I have also not been able to get my audio cord to work but I think that is because my old MP3 player I was testing it with was not working correctly and that is the only device I would use with that feature of this speaker.

CALLS
I don't use this with my phone so I don't answer calls with it.

CHARGE
A charge generally lasts me about 10 hours or so, depending on usage periods and how spread out they are. It takes between 1 and 2 hours to recharge.

THE BOTTOM LINE
This is a great small speaker. It is waterproof (I did not test that aspect at this point) and sounds great. The MicroSD slot has not worked for me yet, but otherwise it is a good speaker.

MY RATING
FOUR STARS. I like this but wish that the other features worked a bit more easily. I will update if I find solutions to the issues I have been having.

Needed Bluetooth for my Dell Windows 7 PC. Installed the drivers from the enclosed CD. Paired immediately with my Bluetooth headset.
No problems. Easy install and setup. Works every time.

We have a Bluetooth speaker with a short cord, so having to plug it in in our room while we were painting, we had to just let it dangle, which can't be good for the socket. I'm so glad to have found this inexpensive, sturdy socket shelf to boost the speaker and amplify the sound (and save the socket). Plus, you just can't beat using vertical space as additional storage.

We had the Fire TV Stick streaming media player with Alexa built in, includes Alexa Voice Remote, HD, easy set-up, released 2019, but occasionally the remote would become undetectable by the base and I saw that this one could control the soundbar and tv, so I traded it in for a coupon. The new system is very slow when we open up apps like YouTube and Twitch, so much so that my household has been using our old Google Chromecast for those tasks instead. Overall I really wish I had just kept the old system and cannot recommend this new one.

UPDATE: I am returning this fire stick because I just received and installed the 4K version; it works so much more quickly and easily! I would /not/ recommend the 3rd Gen fire stick with dedicated app buttons to anyone. Get the 4K even if you don't need the 4K definition!

Very good sound IF one is looking for versatile high end sounding clarity. Clarity comparable to my larger audiophile system costing10 times more. The bass is pleasingly present, deep, tight, and well defined. The mid and high end frequencies are very clear. While this system may not be meant to play very loud, it does fill a room nicely. The speakers took a couple days to break in before they started to sound natural and open. I hope they last a long time.

At first glance the Asus VivoBook V551LA-DS17T appears to be a nice touch-screen UltraBook-class computer, but it is a few steps beyond a typical UltraBook. Combining features of UltraBook systems and multimedia/entertainment workstations, this computer is what new systems ought to be. There are a couple of design decisions I would change and it's by no means a high-end gaming rig, but Asus got the important things right.

There are two things that set this system apart from a normal UltraBook. First is the inclusion of a slimline CD/DVD R/W drive. I have seen no other UltraBooks out there that include one, so finding one in this system was a very pleasant surprise. Carrying an external CD/DVD drive around can be inconvenient (especially when traveling) so having a built-in drive is a huge plus. Asus managed to include this drive in the system while still keeping the system to roughly an inch thick. The other differentiating factor that makes this system different than other UltraBooks I have seen (and not in a positive way) is the weight. This is a particularly heavy system and will make toting it around a chore.

I booted up the system and configured it for use and immediately went about looking for the utility for making recovery/restore DVD media. After searching the file system and the installed program list with no success I finally resorted to calling technical support. I spoke to a charming young lady who was exceptionally helpful and got me on my way to creating a recovery USB drive. So, from that experience I can say that technical support is courteous and helpful. However, I never did figure out how to make DVD media, but at least I can restore the system now should I have a need to do so.

After power-on for the first time it performed a bunch of hands-off updates and when it finished and finally allowed interaction with the OS it was loaded with Windows 8.1; it wasn't obvious if the initial OS install was 8 or 8.1 but that is irrelevant - 8.1 is what is there when the user can finally begin exploring the system. I spent a little time digging through the list of installed applications and was pleased to see that Asus did not load this system up with excessive bloatware. There are several applications I do not need and I intend to remove them - MS Office and McAfee protection services being among them - but at least what is there is not unreasonable. Interestingly, most new systems I have used have come with 1-2 years of internet security protection, but this system comes with just 30 days.

One design decision that really surprised me is that this system does not include a solid-state drive (SSD). I understand the reason - it drives up cost - but to me having an SSD in this system would make it even faster and make the battery last longer. This is by no means a deal-breaker but bootup times are slower as a result.

Asus makes a big deal about the touch screen on this system and touts it as more sensitive than most other touch screens. Asus' claims appear to be well-founded as the other touch screen systems available to me are nowhere near as responsive. After spending a couple of hours working with this system I unplugged my trackball and I don't think I will need it again for this particular system. If you are buying this system for the ability to use the touch screen, you will be pleased.

Battery life so far is excellent. I charged the system up completely and spent a good three hours using it for web surfing and typing up documents and the battery still maintains more than half of its charge. I plan to load up my development environment and see how the battery holds up under load, and I expect that to make the battery drain faster, but for typical use (surfing the web, writing document and watching online videos) the battery seems to be very much in the game.

The graphics system is provided by the Intel chipset and it is acceptable for most uses. It's not high end graphics but it's not terrible either. Serious gamers will not appreciate this system whereas most casual gamers and people using the system for more business-types of functions will be more than satisfied. As an experiment I had my teenage son load up Minecraft (an online game that uses 1st-person perspective) and test the graphics. He noticed that while the game played well enough it is not quite as smooth as a system that has a dedicated graphics card.

Wi-Fi connection speed seems to be about average with other wireless-n devices on the network.

One thing that really startled me is the quality of the sound system. Asus says that this is the best configuration for embedded sound available and I found the sound quality coming from the embedded speakers to be more than acceptable. The speakers are on the bottom of the unit and are visible via two inch-long slits in the case. In spite of the small aperture, the output is very good, better than one would expect.

With the slimline DVD and the decent sound quality, paired with the i7 processor and 8GB RAM this system is well-suited for multimedia tasks such as video production and music creation. It has the horsepower to handle the renders and so far has performed well while working on either audio or video composition. As I mentioned above I expect these types of activities to take more battery than less strenuous tasks but I have not spent enough time with these types of applications on this system yet to determine just how much they will impact battery life.

The touch pad is a bit better than average and is placed well. One issue I have with most laptops is that I tend to tap the touch pad while typing and on occasion I can highlight and delete a whole section of text unintentionally. So far this has not been a problem with this system and I think it has a lot to do with the way the touch pad is positioned relative to the open space on the keyboard. Asus includes a very nice utility (accessible by a special key on the keyboard) that makes turning the touch pad on and off very simple, so it's easy to eliminate any issue with it if it's "in the way" while typing.

The power adapter is odd and I am not sure I like it. The shape requires a little planning as it is a square block pressed against the wall when it is plugged in. Most adapters typically have the brick in the middle. So, plugging this adapter in when working in a cramped space could potentially pose a challenge. Another observation - the adapter gets rather warm.

I do not like the way the hard drive is partitioned right out of the box. It appears that the drive was simply chopped into two roughly equal partitions, the D: drive labeled as "data". I would rather have one large drive, instead of two smaller ones. This is a personal preference though and I am sure most will be indifferent.

I decided to toss in a Linux LiveCD and boot it up to see how well supported the touch screen is with a current distribution. The system refused to boot from it initially; to get it to boot I had to turn off Secure Boot in the BIOS after which I was able to boot up from the DVD. My distribution of choice for this experiment was Mint 16 with the Cinnamon Desktop. I found that there is basic support in place for the screen, though only as a standard pointing device (a lot like using a Wacom tablet) and not as a swipe and gesture interface. There are other distributions out now that are geared more towards tablets; I will try one of those and see how well it works out. That said, the fact that the desktop at least recognizes the screen as a pointing device and properly responds to it is a good thing.

A few other technical details: The system has 3 USB ports (two of them USB 3.0 and one of them USB 2.0), an HDMI port, an Ethernet port (which is not a given anymore when it comes to notebook computers), an audio out and a SD card reader. Given a choice I would have liked to have a VGA or DVI port to put the display on a second screen but that's not something I have seen on the most recent systems.

Asus has put together a very nice UltraBook-like system in this notebook. It's a nice workhorse for most uses and the touch screen is absolutely wonderful. The system's a bit hefty though and might prove to be cumbersome for those on the go, and the graphics system is not at serious gaming level, but the system is a solid performer and provides the best features of an UltraBook and a multimedia workstations in one place.

I received a review sample of this cord and charger combination and have been testing it thoroughly. The most striking feature is the three meter cable, which is the longest I have seen for any iPhone (or Android phone for that matter.)

My first inclination was to test the cable for failures because the length seemed excessive. It performed every data transfer and synching operation flawlessly. It also fast-charges like an Apple OEM cable. I was a bit surprised that this and the charger were not MFi certified (Made for iPhone/iPod/iPad). Other cables and chargers that I have received from the manufacturer were, but this is indistinguishable from the MFi and Apple OEM cables that I have tested - both visually and from a performance perspective.

The contacts on both the USB and Lightning connector ends are precision made and mate perfectly to the ports to which they were designed to connect. The outer jacket is thick, but not too stiff to make handling it a problem. There are strain reliefs on both ends to ensure a long service life.

This set includes a bonus wall charger with folding prongs. This has the same well made construction, and also puts out a steady 2.1A for fast charging. This charger is perfect for iPads too because of the output rating. If I had one wish it would have a second 1.0A port for those of us who want to simultaneously charge a phone and tablet - perhaps the next generation of this product will have that feature.

Bottom line: when size (in the form of cable length) matters this is one of the very few on the market that is a full three meters long. Add in the fact that this one is made to perform like an Apple OEM cable and the value should be apparent.

I have 2 of these Monster CableLinks Y-Adapter XLR Male (2) to XLR Female (1) splitter/joiner. They work very well and seem good quality. Well built. I use them to combine the left and right audio source from the XLR outputs from a mixer into a single XLR input of a powered speaker. Sound is perfect.

UPDATE (4 -> 5 stars)/ 9/20/2013 - This thing is $28 now! You'd be nuts NOT to get this case! I'm pretty sure they're taking a loss selling it at that price, maybe they're overstocked and trying to get rid of them? If you're going to buy this case BUY IT NOW!

Firstly, I just want to say if you want to SEE my PC check out the last 3 customer uploaded images, they are of my newly built PC in this case. If you can't find customer images, go to the main product page for this case, and click "See all 5 customer images", it's right under the picture of the case.

My current specs:
CPU: AMD FX 8320 (3.5GHZ stock) Overclocked @ 4.22 GHZ
CPU Cooling: Corsair H80 High Performance Liquid Cooling System
Motherboard: Gigabyte FX 990 UD3 AM3+
Power Supply: Rosewill Capstone 750W 80+ Gold certified.
SSD: Sandisk 32GB (I just use it for my operating system for quick bootups, nothing else.)
HD: Seagate Barracuda 1TB 64MB cache 7200 RPM SATA III
Graphics: Geforce 760 GTX 4GB 256bit GDDR5 (When I was deciding whether or not to order this case, this was my biggest concern, "Will one of the new big geforce graphics cards fit?" - YES it will! I MIGHT be able to fit another one in, but I really don't need another one, the 760 is a beast!)
Ram: 16GB Gskill Sniper Series DDR3 2400

Whew, now having said all that, EVERYTHING fits in this case. Is it a little bit snug? See for yourself, I don't think so, but some might. I also got a non-modular power supply so that adds alot of unnecessary cables.

The fact is though, my computer does NOT overheat. I monitor temps whenever my computer is on (with CPUID, free program!) and as an example, under a full load my CPU temp stays ~20C and my GPU can get up to ~60C on a warm day. Keep in mind though for the CPU I'm using a $104 liquid cooling system (I just happened to get a GREAT deal on it).

The see-through case is pretty cool too, I like being able to see the components plus with a liquid cooling system if any liquid starts leaking I can immediately take care of it, although I highly doubt it will leak.

Anyway, I hope this review helps, keep in mind I put alot of stuff in here with the 4 ram modules, and the pretty large graphics card (the Geforce 760 GTX is about 11.5" long, it's pretty big), but it does all fit!

Keep in mind this is a ~$50 case. For $50 it is a good deal, if you want a "better" case, you're going to have to spend more money it's as simple as that. People nitpick things like a flimsy backplate, or not having the best cable management, well the more you expect from a product the more you're going to end up paying for it. So take it easy on a $50 case.

I can say for sure it's better than my old HP desktop PC computer case. It actually FEELS like a gamer's case.

So all-in-all, if you're on a budget and looking for a nice computer case for $50 I recommend this case. It's got everything I needed and it's got everything 90% of people will need or care about. I'd buy it again.

I have a 10" tablet and it primarily gets used as an e-reader and as a music streaming device. It's a great device and I love it, but I do get frustrated with figuring out where to put it when I am streaming music through it. Although it is a relatively small device it does take up some room on the desk when in a stand case. I have tried suction mounts to attach it to a window and that works fine but the window cannot move and when the window is cold the suction mount lets go. This flexible mount for tablets is a very good solution for my needs and is far better constructed than suggested by the product description.

This is a simple mount in concept and design. It is flexible coil tube with a screw-on vice clamp attached on one end and an adjustable frame-style bracket attached via a ball joint to the other. In the box the unit comes unassembled and requires less than two minutes to put together. When finished, the whole thing is approximately 3' long.

Everything about this mounting stand suggests that it is built to last and is designed to hold up under heavy use. The coil tube is about the heaviest I have ever seen: it is roughly a half inch in diameter and is exceptionally stiff which makes it well suited for supporting the weight of the tablet. The item description here says it will support 2.2 pounds but it will support a little more than that (though I would not try to put much extra on there, particularly if the coil is horizontal).

The coil attaches to the vice clamp via a threaded machine screw assembly and it has enough threading to allow the coil to turn 360 degrees without becoming detached. This allows the tablet to be swung around a work area in an arch without having to really do anything that requires any effort. While this is great, what really caught my attention is that the clamp itself can be screwed to the coil in two ways at 90-degree angles (top or side) so that the clamp can be attached to an anchored surface that is either horizontal or vertical. This is one of those design decisions that just makes sense but I have seen very few manufacturers make this kind of effort.

The coil is covered by a very heavy plastic sleeve which protects the tube and makes flexing the tube easier on the hands.

The mounting bracket is connected to the top of the flexible tube by a ball joint, similar to the kind of joints many GPS navigators use in cars to attach to the suction base. When I first attached the bracket to the coil I put it on upside down, which is not a big deal except that the weight of the tablet worked against the joint and it tilted downward slightly. The bracket itself is a standard slider with a lever that presses against the slider which then catches on teeth on the frame to lock it in place. There's a fair bit of padding on the bracket to protect the tablet when it's being clamped in and when the position is being adjusted.

This mounting stand is of such heavy construction that it suggests the stand was designed for industrial use. While it is just fine for home use and is not out of place in a professional office, it is a good for a manufacturing assembly line or even a busy retail location.

This is a great mounting stand for tablets in 7"-11" range. The whole stand is very sturdy and solid and is build to last. Based on my experience with it I can heartily recommend it to any one who needs a mounting solution for a tablet.

Disclaimer: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at no cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.

[[VIDEOID:8c9fe6543edf9e4bd0345d22b1eaeac2]] Based on reviews, I wanted a HackRF One, but my auction order was canceled. Since the HackRF One was basically out of stock everywhere or well over $300 and I was too impatient to wait for a shipment from China, I decided to try the NESDR SMArTee XTR SDR in the meantime. It was less than $40, so there wasn't much to lose.

As you can see and here in my video, it works VERY WELL. I expected lots of static and poor performance since even the Great Scott Gadgets tutorial on YouTube had a fair amount of static in lesson 1. Granted, I likely have better signal strength here in South Florida, and I think my antenna is a bit better than the stock telescoping rod they were using in the video. Instead, the RTL-SDR gave surprising good performance.

That said, it's not a replacement for the HackRF One. The first thing you'll notice, if you attempt to build any of the HackRF projects, is that you'll need to drastically reduce the sample rate. The HackRF One can handle a 20MHz sampling rate; the RTL-SDR SMArTee XDR sampling rate is an order of magnitude lower - 2 MHz. Furthermore, the RTL-SDR is receive only and that definitely limits its capabilities. Even so, if you are looking for a cheap introduction to SDR, then definitely buy the RTL-SDR SMArTee XTR. You won't regret it.

I have had the opportunity to review many headsets and headphones over the years and without question the recent technological advancements have aided this area by leaps and bounds.

I can not recommend buying Bluetooth 5.2 enough over previous technologies if your devices support it. Nearly all devices that are Bluetooth 5.2 capable, including this one, will be backwards compatible with earlier technologies as well.

Battery life is outstanding with these headsets lasting a solid 5 hours each in all of my tests. It is easily charged using the included charging case which will allow the earbuds to be recharged several times from its one full charge. Since the earbuds can be used together for stereo sound or individually you can potentially double play time by using one at a time.

This unique charging case is powered via an included super fast standard USB to USB Type C cable. This case will allow the headsets to be recharged even when you don‚Äôt have access to electricity.

After receiving, I made sure the case was fully charged then confirmed each earbud had a full charge. After verifying full power within each earbud I followed the simple pairing instructions and had no problems whatsoever. Once the earbuds are removed from the case they first pair with each other then you simply pair with your Bluetooth device.

The design of these headset makes it so it fits securely in your ear and is relatively comfortable. As someone who has used many of these units, this design is not the most comfortable as the weight is all on the ear canal. I‚Äôve found headsets that are worn only supported by the ear canal can end up being painful when used for extended periods.

The sound from these headphones is decent - from the rich bass notes to the vibrant midtones to the bright treble. I tested these headphones with a wide range of audio - from audiobooks to jazz, heavy metal, country, classical and blues - everything sounded reasonable.

I have listened to both music and audiobooks through these as I moved throughout my home and it will easily pick up the signal through walls up to 25‚Äô away, and even more without obstacles. This is a decent set Bluetooth headphones.

While these are great for listening to music, how are they for calling? The sound through these headphones is absolutely outstanding - on both ends. That is not always the case. Many of the other headphones I have tested, while they sound good to the person using it - those who they are speaking to can‚Äôt hear them clearly. It is no fun having a conversation where the other person keeps saying, ‚Äúhuh, what did you say?‚Äù You won‚Äôt have to worry about that with this set.

If you are looking for a decent headphone set, especially one at a reasonable price, with decent sound and reception and has the power to last this is a great choice.

This is a very fast computer that is easy to set up and operate. The computer arrives suspended in foam packaging to ensure you get your unit in proper working order. The unit comes with a keyboard and mouse that connect via USB cables. I found both of these accessories to be ergonomically friendly and easy to operate.

The computer has a power button on the front along with a speaker jack, a headphone jack, two USB 2.0 ports, a USB 3.1 port, and a USB 3.1 type-C port. On the back there are 2 USB 2.0 ports that are used for the keyboard and mouse. There are also 4 USB 3.1 ports, an internet port, and various monitor ports.

When in operation, the computer emits a blue light from the front. The computer measures 12.5 x 6.5 x 14.25 and fits conveniently on or beneath a desk. The Intel Core i7-9700 processor is lighting fast and great for playing video games or streaming movies. This is a great computer that is perfect for professionals, students, or anyone with computational needs.

We were looking for a boom box that didn't require a phone for our 10 year old. We thought this would fit the bill perfectly, but we were disappointed. Although it is convenient that we can load the songs onto an SD card and pop that into the speaker, the controls are so obnoxious that we will be returning it. The volume up/volume down, song forward/song backward, FF/RW buttons are all the same two buttons! You hold them down to turn up/down the volume, you touch them quickly to change song. And you have to press HARD (for a 10 year old) to get them to respond. Try changing songs or changing volume only by the pressure of your fingers while pushing VERY hard! It's such a pain! Whoever designed this thing has never tried to use it. They could have taken up 2 cm more and added the very most important buttons: volume.

Plus the thing always turns on at MAX volume, causing everyone to shriek and cover their ears until you can madly try to turn the volume down.

On the plus side, it's loud and has decent sound. It's also quite portable. If the controls were good, we would have kept it. But they're such a pain to use, we will look for something else. (Never got the remote working--it arrived damaged.)

I took a video so you can see the quality for yourself, take into consideration that the lightning is not the best in my room, so my camera might not be soo good.

Please note, due to the size of the Amazon Firestick 4K you have to connect the included adapter cable that comes with the Firestick as the design places the HMDI in and out port too close together for the Firestick to be inserted directly to the box.

Also the box does not support CEC so any remote control functionality such as being able to turn the power on/off with a single remote will not work. It does split the audio as expected for both Amazon Firestick and AppleTV 4K and is a great convenience for splitting audio to a surround amp, etc. for older setups if you‚Äôre willing to have to use multiple remote controls.

My husband wanted a camera to put on an HO flatcar and run around his model railroad layout. He'd seen some videos friends made and was eager to try it. This unit is extremely versatile and comes with all sorts of features we didn't need and haven't tried, so you'll have to check other reviews for those. For example, there is no wifi at his layout and he hates smartphones, so we haven't bothered with that, at least not yet. We also did not need the waterproof case or some of the other amazing mounting brackets.

When we unboxed the camera and got it out of the waterproof case (took a little figuring out), the next challenge was to find the plugs for the charging cord and the card. The design is sleek and beautiful so that's a trick. Turns out,it's a black rubber flap on the bottom which hinges up. Inserting the memory card was the next trick. At first, I didn't push down hard enough. (it won't go in much at all if you have it turned the wrong way, so don't worry about that--I did.) You have to push down really hard with your fingernail to get it to go in. It has to be all the way in so the outer edge of the card is flush with the outside of the unit. Once we did that, it was easy to turn on and worked great. The camera resolution is absolutely amazing. It's hard to believe something this small and inexpensive could work so well. It isn't the best for the layout because my husband's model railroad has a lot of tunnels. As small as the camera is, it's too tall to fit through them, at least when it's upright. Now, the description says it can be turned. Maybe there's a way to do it that we haven't discovered yet. On that point, I need to add that, while the directions that come in the box are hopeless, there are lots of terrific how-to and unboxing videos for this camera on YouTube. If I can ever get it away from my husband, I'd like to record some of the beautiful hikes and drives we take here in western Colorado. There's a lanyard for your neck for outdoor activities and a bracket for the car. You can also use it as a nanny cam or to monitor your doggie with your phone when you are out. I think everyone is going to have one of these things eventually. One last point, when I was having trouble getting the card in right, I contacted customer service via email. They got back to me with a very polite and useful reply within 48 hours. This camera would make a great gift for almost anybody!

Had some doubts due to the price but this speaker delivers.  Packs a punch, probably overkill for indoors unless you are dealing with some ambient noise but outdoors is where this speaker shines.  The clarity at high volumes is  impressive.  I'm very pleased with the performance and value now.

The sound quality I'm getting from this thing connected to some Pioneer SP-BS22-LR speakers is good, especially for the money. The sound quality isn't amazing, but I didn't want it to be for this price. It's a great way to add sound to a bedroom or office where you're not trying for critical listening. Setup is easy, with high-quality ports on the back.

All of the problems are on the volume knob. The potentiometer control is cheap feeling, with no weight or satisfying resistance behind it. Again - not a problem at this price point. The problem is the BRIGHT BLUE LIGHT surrounding the volume knob like a halo, shining ALL OF THE TIME. It disqualifies this thing for bedroom use unless you hide it behind something. I draped a black sock over the front of mine so it wouldn't shine throughout the bedroom.

I would pay more for a version of this that had no LEDs in it.

Initially I purchased these as refurbs, sadly that didn't work out so well. However I liked them so much that I purchased new after Amazon took care of me.

If you're looking for audiophile sound, look elsewhere. If you're looking for good quality sound, easy pairing, and comfort than I've found these to be a perfect choice. I wear them for about 2-3 hours at a time at work, never feel fatigued by them. I find they stay in with little effort and range is good, as I often walk away from my desk. My wife uses hers at work as well but only with 1 bud at a time. She agrees the quality is better than the airpods she has as well.

Like I said, if you're interested in audiophile quality sound, then you'll need to look at other choices. I've found that these seal well an keep most ambient noise out, although there is a setting that allows a touch to let more in. Touch controls weren't the best at first but updates have pretty much got them spot on. Only occasionally do I have it register a single tap instead of a double.

Somewhat durable, I've dropped mine once or twice with no issues.

Overall a good choice.

I bought it to go with a fluance RT-82. I ordered the fluance pre-amp at the same time. For the music I listen to... Mostly metal, the dj-pre sounded much clearer than the fluance. The gain nob is great, lights are bright but electrical tape solves that problem fine. Overall very happy with this amp!

I have tested and reviewed literally hundreds of Bluetooth speakers and while I am not a fan of music that is particularly bass heavy I found this speaker produces rich, vibrant sounds from all wave lengths. It produces more than ample volume for most any setting and has several connection methods.

While I have tested and reviewed Bluetooth speakers costing ten times (and more) what this does, the sound quality from this speaker is really quite good. In relation to the sound quality I would place them on par with mid to high end Bluetooth speakers.

In regards to charging time and battery life, both are outstanding. In my tests charging takes about approximately 2 hours to charge the built in 4000 mAh battery and the speaker lasts a solid 4.5 hours at max volume - 8 hour with volume midway (of course this will vary a bit due to exact settings).

There are multiple ways to connect to this speaker including Bluetooth 5.0, which can reach much further than previous versions, through an AUX cable, a 3.5mm jack, TF card, USB flash drive, or FM radio - it even has a built in extendable antenna.

While it has a remote and I tested it and it works fine, I rarely use it as I connect with my phone all the time.

I have taken this speaker with me to the pool for the last couple of months and have been thoroughly impressed with its performance. The battery, being 4000 mAh, is much longer lasting than most allowing for all day listening and the sound quality has been really good.

This is an all around great Bluetooth speaker that I certainly recommend.
For the money it's a nice deal. Not the loudest speakers,so i wouldn't use for loud Rock listening but it sounds great for audio books or listening at a reasonable level for music..Recommended!

Heated blanket, Lamp, iPhone charger, Apple Watch charger, etc etc this power strip handled it all. Awesome that it has the third prong (lots of strips don‚Äôt) but this doesn‚Äôt handle oddly shaped plug heads. My rectangle charger takes up two spaces, but that‚Äôs a nonissue. As promised!

I have quite a few different styles of headphones and some others on the ear. I was really surprised how lightweight these are, which I'm happy with, I don't want something putting a bunch of weight for 2 hours or more. Inside they are easily marked for Right or Left. Connects great to an adapter I use for my audio player, connects no trouble to tablets or phones or PC. Sound is good, I have your medium average female ears I guess, so it fits fine over the ears and I have had trouble in the past with some headphones being too large, with these you can set the adjustment down and they fit really well. If you are a person with a large head, you might want to keep looking, but these do adjust quite a bit so it's worth a shot. I get really good sound no matter the device, and podcasts sound so good sometimes it's sounded like they were in the room. The sound you get can be excellent if you have a device with a good equalizer. I have been really shocked how good the battery has been. If it's fully charged, I could listen to music on my phone for a couple hours, and check the percentage and it's barely used any battery. I go to plug it in and it charges really fast. I've had really good luck with these. I don't expect them to be like Bose or something, but for an average user, these are good.

1. the earbuds broke off the stem after 1 month of use. too fragile.
2. the earbuds don't stay in your ear if you move your head.
3. the controls on the earbuds are too easy to push accidentally while you're putting the buds in your ear, which you have to do very often.
4. the part that goes behind your head is irritating, and gets caught in your collar.
5. attaching the whole thing to your head is very awkward.
These are great speakers, smaller than the logitech they replaced, and have just as much volume if not more.

Very nice power strip with 6 outlets and 3 usb ports. One pleasant surprise about this outlet is that the clamp is adjustable from side to side. By releasing 2 side stops, you can slide the clamp left or right. That is nifty! These will definitely be integrated into my new table build. 5-Stars!
After using it a year it's still my go-to favorite radio. Reception, durability, quality. And sounds great with or without high quality headphones.

[[VIDEOID:7e3257a7e1bff772f9422af6086f1ee0]] Looks: GLAMOROUS. The jewels are flawless. The rose gold is bright and beautiful. I think the Branding looks tacky.

Sounds: great! the shape is standard earbud shape so I had a hard time situating them in my ear to block out noise.

Feels: earbuds not so comfy, but the watch was surprisingly comfy. The Bands are not stiff at all. I love the size of watch face, a crystal clear display.

Functionality: VERY basic. The earbuds and watch offer few functions, but they do work well. They are easy to pair and operate.

At this price, you‚Äôre getting two nice products for $30/each. These are extremely basic versions of earbuds and smart watches. I personally am not a huge Jenner fan, never watched the show, so the names constantly displayed on the front of my watch makes it a no for me.

They worked with my iphone, but I will be going back to Apple Watch.

The headphones work great with the ipod, even when it's a couple of rooms over.  The sound is great!  Noise-cancelling works really well. The battery lasts for a long time. Although, the headband is adjustable if you have kind of a big head, the part across the top is uncomfortable. If they would have put some kind of cushion up there it would get 5 stars!

I will give you the down and dirty in short bullet form. Hopefully this answers most questions.

PROS of this product
* Easy to set up and use.
* Quality of the sound is good and it isn't heavy on the bass. Music is clear. The one speaker (mono) gives off great sound.
*Item is portable and sturdy.
*Item has Bluetooth function or you can hook it straight to your device. (I used my son's cord from his VModa head-set to connect to my android. ) Otherwise I used the Bluetooth function on my IPAD, IPOD and Nexus 4 (android phone) with no problem. The range or reception is decent. I didn't have any breaks in the connection, but I really didn't try to go too far. I tend to stay in the same room or in the general area, while listening to music.
*You can control the sound from your device or from the speaker. AND you can still pause your music using your device.
*Easy to charge. I really liked the fact that it is compatible with any USB or android charger. Meaning if you have an Apple device (ex., IPOD or IPAD), etc you can use the charger to charge this speaker. Or at least use the base portion of the charger. If you have an android, you can use that cord as well. The charge life for the battery is reasonable, and it even comes with a lithium battery.
*You can attach it to a book-bag or backpack (as shown in the photo), but I just place it where I want it to be and put it down. It is small enough (about the size of the palm of my hand) to fit into any purse, or bag without making it too heavy. Basically you can use this anywhere (in the home, camping, on trips, at the beach) and at any time.
* It's cute (I have the black. It kind of looks like a smashed soda can). Again, it's small. There are controls and indicator lights on the bottom of the device. The charge area is located on the top.
*Price seems comparable with other products of this sort (wireless speakers) on the market.

THINGS I WOULD CHANGE (not really a CON) about this product:
*The USB cord could be a bit longer. It was a little short for my tastes. But at least it's versatile.

So, as you can see, I was pleased with this product. The PROS definitely outweigh the "things that I would change" category. It had everything that made this a winner. It was easy to set up, and has decent sound quality. I definitely would recommend it.

I was hesitent to purchase this wire after reading so many negative reviews.  After receiving and reviewing this speaker wire, I'm at a loss to explain those reviews.  I am now retired but had spend a 40 year career working in electronics.  The wire was as described.  Excellent quality, 12 gauge.  It came with a red stripe to identify the hot lead.  The leads were individual strands of copper wire, not coated aluminum.  There was no large solid core surrounded by a few stand in order to cheapen construction while trying to meet the 12 gauge requirement.  The insulation was of high quality and easy to strip.  I've already run the entire 100 feet, it was one solid piece of wire and not pieces of different lengths as another has complained of.  I actually purchased this wire based on reviews at other sights, the reviews here were so bad, I had to see if the complaints were also present elsewhere.  They weren't.  I can't understand why many Amazon reviewers found so many problems when those negative reviews weren't duplicated at other sights (or by me).  It may be the luck of the draw but I am completely satisfied with the product.  It's actually worth quite a bit more than it's sale price, I must recommend it.

All I can add to the many reviews about the great sound and good looks is that the company is great too. They stood behind their products and left me very impressed.

I got these for a good deal after rebate, and was worried about the breakage problems I read about, but for the price I couldn't pass them up. I've had them for about 3 months now and I must say, I love them. I haven't seen any evidence of cracking, I believe that the problem has been fixed, or perhaps I got lucky. Either way, the quality seems great to me, both build and sound. I use them at work with my computer and it's great not to have to deal with tangled cords. The batteries easily last for a full 8-9 hour day and I definitely get a lot of questions about them from people around the office. Overall I'd have to say if you can get them for under $50 after rebate you really can't pass these up.

Edit: The headphones finally did break after about 8 months of daily use. Logitech sent me a replacement pair (which was really easy, no hassle, great customer service), which worked well for about 4 more months, and then the headband broke on those as well. When I called for another replacement pair, they told me that they were discontinued and instead they would just refund me what I paid for them. All in all, I'd say they were a great deal, but minus 1 star because they are pretty flimsy (I'd actually change the star rating if Amazon would let me, but I can't).
These sound great! They exceeded my expectations! I wear them when I‚Äôm at work while I‚Äôm up moving around they stay on my head and don‚Äôt fall off like my earbuds do.

This cable is the worst audio cable I have ever owned. It degrades audio quality to such an extent that my $200 ATs sounded like the cheapest pair you can pickup from a grocery store. [[VIDEOID:7aefece1e131fe9296e341bb71fdfbf2]] I like to mess around with vintage VHF television sets. I got a 1980 something G.E. set that's been giving me a lot of issues. First, a warning for you about the warranty. This Speaker Tower is very, very heavy. Should it break during the one-year warranty, as expected you will have to pay to ship it to Pyle. (I am OK with this.) But along with the item you must include a $50 money order to pay Pyle Audio to send the item back to you.

Most companies work by you pay to ship the broken item to them, they pay to ship the fixed item back to you under the warranty period.

OK, now to the product review:

Overall, I am disappointed with the quality of the audio and I do not recommend this item to people who want the best audio quality and I would not ever purchase it again.

If anyone out there paid even close to the full retail list price of $433.99, you have my sympathy.

This tower does have some positives. The ability to play either FM radio, an iOS device, or other music source (you will need a 3.5mm to dual RCA male cable if wanting to play directly from the headphone jack of an MP3 player, etc.). It would have been nice if they had included a 3.5mm input jack as well, especially at this price.

Some songs sound pretty good, but others sound muffled or muddy. Not crystal clear like you would expect at this weight and price, and from Pyle Audio. If you compare your songs through this tower and then through the $300+ Dr. Dre Original Model Beatbox as one wild example, you will hear the difference in clarity and quality from the speakers immediately.

But again, some songs do sound quite decent, and with that I can see why some give this tower a great review. But if you are like me and you want and recognize the best quality sound, you might be disappointed with this tower.

The instruction manual is very disappointing, as well. I, and most can figure things out eventually, but there will be some folks who might need to ask for help.

The FM antenna is a small hard wired wire. You cannot add your own antenna.

I got the black matte model, and it does look nice in the room.

I think this deserves 3 stars because I think there are some people who will enjoy this tower and its features and its small footprint and its look for the $171 price.

I bought the printer because it was affordable, and had lots of features. I wanted something with a duplex document feeder scanner, full duplex printing, color, and flatbed scanning. This seemed to have it all. As a scanner, it's pretty good if you manage to stay away from the HP software. As a printer, the quality is decent, but the ink situation is enough to make me never buy from HP again.

I'm sure HP read lots and lots of letters from angry customers complaining about their ink prices. Indeed, with other HP printers, it can be frustrating to be charged $35 when you run out of black ink. HP's solution to this can be seen with the 564 ink cartridge - the colors are $10 and the black is $12. Seems cheap!

Here's the awful truth: the black ink lasts about 30 - 50 pages. This is not an exaggeration. You need to replace the ink ALL THE TIME. The printer also has a bizarre habit of using ALL of the colors even when you're printing things that look black and white. So even if you're not printing very much in color at all, the printer will inexplicably run out of colors. Since the ink cartridges are so small, it seems like the printer CONSTANTLY has a low ink warning, and is CONSTANTLY stopping with out of ink errors. So even though you're only spending $10 - $12 on each cartridge, you're buying tons of them, and you need a huge stock for replenishment. This is HP's marketing department guiding the hand of their engineering department and delivering a crippled product. You will learn to hate this printer. It will constantly need your care and feeding, and you won't save any money on ink.

Here's a tip: in the print settings on your computer, you can tell it to use black ink only. That's a lifesafer.

Side note: the wi-fi on my unit has gone out twice. Out of warranty though, but the range on the Bluetooth is excellent, so not that big a problem for me. Don't know if it's endemic, or isolated.

[[VIDEOID:4cb340f4de38533c78e73a02371c27a3]] I bought these for my son who is on the autism spectrum.  Due to his sensory problems,  ear buds are out of the question.  We have also tried headphones,  headbands,  and even a Bluetooth hat, but he hated all of them. This is a real game changer.  It looks and feels like regular sunglasses.  They are very comfortable and the best part is that it doesn't have anything to do with his very sensitive ears.  The sound quality is great.  While you are wearing them you can hear everything clearly, but it doesn't disturb anyone else.  Even if you are sitting right beside him, you wouldn't be able to hear what he is listening to.  He has really enjoyed being able to listen to music or an audio book while working outside in the garden.

These earbuds have great sound, they fit in my ear comfortably and don't come out unless I want them to.  Great value for the price I paid.  I have paid over twice as much for similar earbuds and these sound way better.

I purchased four other Bluetooth speakers for my house over a several year period. I have a [[ASIN:B007ZG03DG Bose Wave Bluetooth Music Adapter]], which is not very good and a [[ASIN:B00MPMK3GW Goal Zero 94014 Rock Out 2 Green Solar Rechargeable Speaker]] which does not work when paired with some devices and, when it does pair well, it usually lacks the powerful sound I am looking for.

I also purchased one [[ASIN:B00SNBCBBY ION Audio Block Rocker (iPA76A) | Portable Bluetooth Speaker]] and one [[ASIN:B01N17AQ7U ION Audio IPA88 Tailgater Flash Wireless/Bluetooth Speaker]] both from Costco. I absolutely love the Block Rocker (except for when paired with my iPad Pro) and I only like the Tailgate Flash. The lights on the Tailgate Flash annoy me because they have to be turned off every time I power on the unit. Nevertheless, the sound from the ION speakers are usually awesome.

The IONs are the only ones I use frequently indoors (even though they are more of an outdoor Bluetooth speaker). They are powerful speakers and the sound is intense. However, I wanted something small and more portable and since the Goal Zero does not always function, I figured I would try this Sony.

What comes in the Sony box
- one Bluetooth speaker
- one micro USB charging cable
- one quick start guide
- one user guide - warns against using & leaving unit in a car or sauna but does not say much about how to operate this speaker
- one limited 1-year warranty insert
- one pamphlet about the SongPal app - a mobile app from Sony that allows the user to play music or audio from various devices and smartphones.

Features on the SONY

- It is rated as IPX5 water resistant (not waterproof but close enough; it probably will not soak through in a short burst of heavy rain). See link in comments section of review for description of ratings.

- It features a wireless party chain that allows a connection of up to 10 Bluetooth speakers at once. I did not try this feature. I am not sure if all in the party chain have to be Sony speakers or not.

- It has a speaker phone voice assist function to allow for hands free voice over IP through the speaker, which I was unable to get working.

- It lights up (great for party or listening to vibrant music). I love how the blue light pulsates to the music but it can be turned off if desired and once it is turned off, it remembers that setting until it is turned on again.

- It has a speaker add function for adding an extra Sony speaker for surround sound.

- It has up to 12 hours of battery life.

- It charges from most USB power sources including from the USB port on a laptop

These are the control buttons from left to right.

- Extra Bass Button (toggles on and off for extra bass); when held for a few seconds it turns off the blue perimeter light. I like that it remembers the last setting so if I turned off the light, the light will remain off until I choose to turn it on again.

- Phone Button for speaker phone assist; when held for a few seconds, it says the battery charge percentage. However, I found a quirk in the system. If I am charging the unit and turn it on to get the battery charge percentage, a woman‚Äôs voice came on and said 70%. However, if I unplugged the unit from a power source and turned it on, it said it was fully charged.

- Pause and Play toggle button

- Speaker Add button (Left/Right) for pairing another Sony speaker to this unit for surround sound.

- Minus button for lowering volume.

- Plus button for increasing volume.

- Power button for tuning the unit on. Once unit is powered on, hold the power button for a few seconds and then release it to pair a device to the Bluetooth speaker. Upon release, a female voice says ‚Äúpairing‚Äù and then it beeps once it is paired.

I charged the speaker for a couple of hours before the first use but I am not sure it needed it as the battery indictor fluctuated between 100% and 70% charged depending on whether the unit was plugged in or not. The connector port is located behind the tiny cover on the back of the unit. I had trouble opening this with my fingernails.

I paired this speaker with the following devices.

- Google Nexus 7 Tablet (2013 version Android device) ‚Äì the sound is moderately powerful.

- iPad Pro 12.9 ‚Äì the sound is okay; I actually prefer the powerful sound that is supplied by the iPad Pro‚Äôs own speakers over this Sony speaker. The system wanted me to install SongPal as an option; I found it under another name and after installation, the app said it would probably slow down my iPad so I immediately deleted it.

- HP Omen Laptop ‚Äì the sound is powerful and much better than the Omen‚Äôs own speakers.

- Dell Latitude E7470 Laptop ‚Äì the sound is powerful and much better than the Dell‚Äôs own speakers.

As usual, I am disappointed in the user guide. It does not describe each button. It only mentions the Voice Guidance usage and does a poor job at that. However, the quick start guide pictorially shows the buttons as long as one can decipher the pictures.

In summary, the unit is sleek, simple, and shaped like a super-sized oblong pill. It is heavy at 1.45 pounds. When powered on, a blue perimeter light outlines the speaker and pulsates to music. I found this speaker to be moderately powerful when paired with three of the four devices I tried it on. I did not like the sound with the iPad Pro. To get the best performance, I needed to leave on the ‚ÄúExtra Bass.‚Äù The battery-charging indicator is a bit quirky and untrustworthy. The charge percentage was different depending on whether I was plugged in or not. I like that it is portable and water resistant. The instructions could be better and until I figured out the unit, I initially had trouble pairing. When using the phone button, I was unable to get voice over IP to route through the speaker no matter what I did. Overall, in comparison to my very portal Goal Zero speaker, this speaker is better. Although it is an unfair comparison, no portable speaker has yet to compare to my two ION speakers. I would have rated this four stars if it were not for the lousy written instructions, the quirky battery charge indicator, and its failure of the speaker phone voice assist. I was also very disappointed in the sound with my iPad Pro. Other than this, this speaker is a good contender for the right application.

I put these headphones on, connected them to mt Walkman playing hi-resolution lossless flac files, and was Blown Away!
All I can say is WOW! Job well done Sony. I have 15 pairs of headphones up to $2000 a piece and this pair bows to none of them. You won't regret buying this pair! Cannot recommend highly enough. My favorite pair of bluetooth headphones. Call quality and battery life are excellent. Build quality and supplied case are top notch. I got the Silver version.
Awesome Bluetooth but eats AAA batteries very well

J. Chambers' November 4, 2014 review provides the complete specs that are missing from the product description at the time of this review as well as a helpful video. I will not repeat his information and encourage you to read it.

Like him I received my station as a review sample. What I like about this versus other surge protector solutions is this one actually has features that protects against electrical surges and spikes and provides the specs to back them up. That may sound like a no-brainer, but I have reviewed 'surge protectors' in the past that were really power strips with no real protection.

What I especially like is the small, convenient footprint. That, plus the three outlets (one what is spaced to accommodate wall warts), and the convenience of two USB charging ports. I will say that the charging ports are slow. On my Galaxy Note 3 phone using a high speed wall charger I get a 1% per 2.5 minutes charging rate. It's over 5.5 minutes with this station, but for overnight charging is not an issue for me. Do factor that into your purchase decision, though. Another thing to take into account is the slide out holder for phones is 7/16 inches fully extended and may not accommodate most phones unless you remove them from any protective case. I charge my phone flat on my desk top, so it's not an issue for me, but if you want to take complete advantage of this station's features you should measure your phone's thickness in its case.

Bottom line: I am totally pleased with this station despite some of the noted limitations. The convenience to me outweighs the compromises, which I cited to ensure that you are armed with enough information to make a purchase decision.

I upgraded from a year-old, previous-generation Paperwhite, mostly to gain the new inverted white-on-black screen mode that Amazon insists requires new hardware and to have built-in Audible playback over Bluetooth.

This unit ticks most of boxes, and after some debate I've decided to give it five stars, but there are some imperfections worth knowing about. It's mostly good, though, and often great.

Battery life
No complaints. In several long international flights, I've yet to run it down more than about 30%, either in long reading sessions with the front-light or in lengthy Audible playback sessions over Bluetooth.

Audible content
The Audible player works brilliantly. Excellent sound, simple controls (including playback-speed adjustment). It does work best if you don't have a screen password enabled, though-- that will get in the way if you just want to rewind a few seconds to catch something you missed. Playback proceeds even if you have a case closed, which shuts off the front-light and saves battery charge.

There's no headphone jack-- this is for Bluetooth only. Fine with me. I have Bluetooth-enabled hearing aids (cochlear implants, actually) and it's a true joy to be able to listen to books on this device. Thanks, Amazon.

Screen
The screen is pretty much the same as my previous-generation Paperwhite's, meaning not bad but could use more contrast when reading in a dark room using the front-light. Outdoors or in well-lit areas, it's fantastic and mostly glare-free.

More seriously, the lack of contrast mars the new Paperwhite's valuable ability to invert text to white-on-black. This is a marvelous accessibility feature for those with "floaters", vitreous separation and other vision issues. Unfortunately, when used with the front-light in a darkened room, such as when reading at night or in a darkened airplane, the black background is more of a medium gray. So this new feature is less helpful than it could be. In fairness, poor contrast is characteristic of today's e-ink displays, which provide perhaps 8:1 contrast. If Amazon can significantly improve the contrast, I'd upgrade again in a flash.

The screen is plastic and will scratch. Keep it clean and use a case. Even with a case (I prefer one of the various "origami" cases available here, which allow the Kindle to prop itself upright) it will fit nicely into a pocket.

The touch-screen user interface is the same as the previous-gen Paperwhite's. I'm not a huge fan of it; too easy to touch it when you don't mean to, and end up on the wrong page. But, the earlier button-driven Kindles had sort of the same problem, so whatever. I recommend a simple fix, perhaps as a Settings option: require a double-tap rather than a single-tap. How about it, Amazon?

Connectivity
The 4G/LTE capability is a nice speed upgrade from the previous 3G connectivity. Downloading Audible content requires a WiFi connection as before.

Unfortunately I'm finding that global connectivity with the new 4G hardware is inferior to the previous-gen's 3G radio. For example, my year-old 3G Paperwhite connected without issue in Saigon, but the new one won't.

The user interface for turning Airplane Mode on and off could be improved. As it is, engaging Airplane Mode cuts all connectivity including Bluetooth. So if you're in the middle of listening to a book when the time comes to put your gizmos in Airplane Mode, it will cut your connection. Better to do what the latest iPhones do, and have the device learn if your usage prefers that Bluetooth remain active.

Browser
It's high time for Amazon to replace the minimally-functional "Experimental Browser" with something more useful. I get it that Kindles are all about battery life and browsers can be major energy hogs, but c'mon, it's 2019, and this browser feels like a relic from 1996. Probably is.
Loves these headphones.  The sound was great, they didn't fall out of my ears, and they were comfortable. Now after a month they won't charge.  Very disappointed üòî
Does the job of providing microphone connection for headphones at a great price.  Sound is ok, what you‚Äôd expect for inexpensive option.

This is my first exposure to Panasonic Active Noise Canceling (ANC) headphones. This particular model is very inexpensive relative to most ANC phones on the market, and unfortunately the low price is justified. These phones fall short in a couple of important areas.

First and foremost, these are ANC phones and the ANC function does indeed work. That said, the degree to which it works is in line with the pricing. I have a very specific fan in the house that I use as a benchmark, as most ANC phones are able to nearly completely wipe out the white noise that this fan generates when on the lowest speed setting. The Panasonic phones kill a good bit of the fan noise but allow more noise than almost every other ANC set I have tried. In the office I tried these phones in an area serviced by two large air handlers that generate a lot of noise and these headphones did remarkably well though still not as well as most other phones I have tried in the same environment. Now, when compared to the likes of Bose, Panasonic does a very poor job but then again they cost maybe 15% of what Bose costs. When considering this price differential the Panasonic phones do a decent job with their ANC which should be acceptable by most for traveling.

One area where these phones fail, though, is in build quality. These headphones are extremely lightweight and they feel very flimsy and fragile. These are not the headphones to take when traveling frequently. To add insult to injury, they come with a cloth carry bag which offers absolutely no protection at all beyond serving as a dust cover.

Worse, though, is the miserable sound quality. I don't know if my specific headset is the problem but while I have a decent full range of sound, everything across the spectrum sounds slightly tinny and hollow. I was encouraged that Panasonic does not overdrive the bass as many manufacturers tend to do and instead delivers a fairly balanced spectrum, but this does not make up for the poor quality of sound. As these are inexpensive headphones I would never expect them to be audiophile quality, but the sound should absolutely be much better than it is.

I was encouraged to see that Panasonic includes a 2-prong adapter in the package, but then they omit the 1/4" adapter which is something I actually use.

Panasonic has made a very inexpensive ANC headphone and unfortunately the low cost is justified. While the ANC capabilities are within reason for the price range, the sound quality and build quality are severely lacking. If looking for ANC phones for the purpose of using the ANC function, and keeping costs low is important, then these phones may fill that need acceptably. However, if sound quality is in any way important, these are the wrong phones and will sorely disappoint.

I got this for playing video games on my PC. It was a step up from using the keyboard and mouse ‚Äî at least for my carpal tunnel. After about three months, however, the LT key would register as being pressed when I wasn't touching it. I eventually bought a DualShock 4 controller, and OMG, that is SO much better. It has a full range of sensitivity for both sticks and the L2/LT and R2/RT triggers. I use DS4Windows to connect by Bluetooth.

At first glance, the case looks very professional and sleek. The exterior is a nylon shell with a nice texture. It‚Äôs slick yet soft at the same time. The grain of the fabric doesn‚Äôt attract much dirt or dust which is a plus. The interior is lined with a soft material that is similar to that of a fuzzy blanket. It is gray and very soft. Your laptop is protected in all corners as your able to place it within a ‚Äúpocket‚Äù. The padding is ample enough to protect your laptop in almost all situations. I am able to fit my 13‚Äù MacBook Air and 11‚Äù iPad Pro within the bag. the outer two compartments are functional and have a thin piece of padding between the interior and exterior, which adds a bit of protection for the items you stow inside.

The one I received didn't work, and I returned it for a refund.  Plugging in one good optical source (ON), I noticed the output from each of the channels individually showed up as 2 red dots slightly skewed "oo" instead of one solid red dot "O".  This reduced the signal and probably corrupted it such that the signal could not be processed by my receiver.  This is probably due to an alignment problem within the device I received.
Low nose, and works great as a cooling fan for my surround sound receiver.

We had installed a 10 ft optical cable that served its purpose, but with just a little re-arrangement, we needed a longer optical cable. This 15 ft cable got the job done! Our surround sound system is from 2009, the Sony HT-IS100 Bravia Theater Micro-System. This cable connected from the HT-IS100 to our 2020 Vava 4k projector, and all is well. We are not audiophiles, but the sound seems perfectly fine. 5-Stars!

Great Soundbar, I'm not really a loud sound, type person, but this thing really improves on the stock TV sound output even on a fairly new Samsung TV. I was thinking it wouldn't make a difference. Boy was I wrong. Clearer sound and vocals too.
Looks great under the TV and makes the sound easier to hear, so I am sold. It goes really well with my Samsung TV. I love the TV volume controls the Soundbar, and. the auto on feature is very useful.

I received this as a gift from the Mrs. as a B-day present.

Edit 8-4-2018
I love having this thing hooked up, I can finally hear the sound so much better. Years of construction work have left me with less than ideal hearing. I can watch TV and not miss things. So glad for the gift.

I am using the optical output from the TV to the sound bar, so all sound from the TV is piped through the sound bar, the Xbox, Apple TV etc.

The sound of this speaker is great for what I paid for it and it is very loud. Louder than I expected. My only drawback for this, is that the voice prompt is too loud (it will say "Bluetooth mode, pairing, connected"... etc). Not sure if its possible to turn that down a little bit but overall its a good for speakerfor the price.

Unfortunately I  gave away my old computer, received this one and went on the road for a month, otherwise I would have returned it. The keyboard letters are the same color as the keyboard and are almost unreadable, and the speakers are broken. I didn't know that until I had begun my trip. Otherwise,  it's very fast and I had no problem loading drivers. The screen is acceptable. I hate paying a high price for something that is partially broken  that shouldn't be, and I have to put up with that.

I've got several sets of wired headphones that I like to use with my smartphone, so I was disappointed to find my new Samsung S20+ came without a headphone jack. Thats where this adapter comes into play. Construction is sturdy and the size is small. I like to leave them attached to my headphones and then I can plug those into my phone just like I used to. The sound quality is good, and the only downside is that you can't charge while listening... although that's the phone's fault, not this adapter. This adapter does exactly what its supposed to do.

It is, by far, the best GPS I have ever had. Big, bright, clear display; intuitive menus; useful information. So what's wrong. The Smart Link app that provides the unit with weather and other information. The connection is Bluetooth, but it often fails to relink after you re-approach the unit. And getting it relinked is sometimes painfully difficult. It will show the units connected on one page and not connected on another. It can be damn frustrating. There is also a feature that shows where you parked your car. I used it the other day, and it reported my car was 32 miles away. The weather is M-Powered. Problem is the M-Power iPhone app itself is not highly rated. One problem is that it will display a warning or watch area, but will sometimes fail to delete that map layer so that you can see the actual storms...which you can see with your eye and on the unit sometime later. Garmin needs to do some serious work on this feature.

If you are serious about what the Smart Link feature can do, do not buy this unit until Garmin gets serious about fixing it.

I am very happy with this purchase. I use it with my iPOD touch to listen to music from my computer and all I have to do is plug and play from my car's speakers. It takes less than 2 minutes to set-up and is a no-brainer. One reviewer complained about sound and I do notice that sounds with a strong bass don't translate as well, but all you have to do is change the settings on your FM radio- super easy and again, a no-brainer, for great sound quality from any device!! LOVE IT!!! exactly what I was looking for. WAY BETTER than itrip because I have one pre-set station that works forever and I don't have to constantly search for an empty station. AWESOME>

A lot disappointed. The sound comming out of these headphones is very clear and precise however, they don't crank up as I'd like. When I want to listen to music I want to be able to turn the sound down, I have my Galaxy grand prime at max audio and it doesn't matter what I do to these headphones, the sound remains the same. They still sound like 50% audio. I turn the volume knob up or down, zero difference.

This wireless keyboard/mouse combination is excellent. The wireless connectivity has always been highly responsive. When the keyboard or mouse goes to sleep, the first keypress or mouse gesture wakes the unit up, with nothing lost. The wake up is super fast and responsive and accurate.
I have never used the slot on the keyboard as phone holder but I do use it hold a pen.
I like the separate screen lock key because it eliminates the need for the 2 key Win + L to accomplish the same thing.
This keyboard comes with preprogrammed function keys which default to the manufacturers settings (audio volume increase/decrease/mute etc.) To use the functions keys for normal windows operations, simply hold the fn key and press any function key to accomplish this.

IMPORTANT: I have NOT had any of the problems posted in the review section!
I go through keyboards and mouses like tissues. On average, they last a few months and then deteriorate. Often times, because I have a tendency to drop the mouse a lot, they break pretty fast. The mouse included with this keyboard has held up well. As with most other mouses, when they are dropped, the batteries come flying out. To avoid this, I have placed a small piece of tape over the battery cover and case being careful not to cover the mouse's optical component. This solves the problem
I would highly recommend this product.

The functions are cool. Not only did it tell me my blood pressure but my heart rate and O2 stats

this was matched into our LG 8600 3D tv, Harman Kardon AVR1700 receiver in a small living room.
plays the disc well, is wireless and hooks up to my network. although I prefer the ethernet setup.
Product sounds great. We had to replace our RV outside speakers. We did have to open the hole a little. But other than that installation went very will.

Nice headphones but audio quality isn't quite worth the high cost in my opinion. At least as an all round headset for gaming and to listen to music.
