UPDATE: DIED after 2 months of use. I'm not a heavy or careless user of this kind of stuff -- this was plugged into a connector on my nightstand that also handled a mini-USB cable for my bluetooth speaker, and wasn't moved around at all. I tested it initially with my iPad Pro and my iPhone, but after the initial testing, it was used ONLY for charging my iPhone 6s usually 3 times per week or so. The first 6 weeks, it worked perfectly, and I was thrilled with it. Unfortunately, it started malfunctioning after 6 weeks (lights flashing randomly); after 8 weeks of use, it no longer worked at all. CANNOT recommend. Sorry.

ORIGINAL REVIEW: I've been living with this for about 10 days and I've had a chance to use it with my new-ish iPad Pro 9.7" and iPhone 6S.

So far, no problems at all. Functions just like the original cable except this one is longer and has some extra features -- aluminum housing on both ends is much more "solid" than the plastic and everything is well secured with no manufacturing defects that I could find.

Probably the best part of this cable is the LED light that tells you where your device is in the charging process. Pulsing red means it's charging; flickering green means it's almost done; solid green means it's 100%. The solid green light stays on for awhile (haven't been able to time it precisely as it seems to vary a little from charge to charge -- I'm thinking maybe a couple of hours or so before it goes off; then it stays off unless something "wakes it up" (a notification, a phone call, etc.). I charge the phone on my nightstand and I've had no problem with brightness, but then I sleep like a rock once I get to sleep and it didn't keep me awake, either. Some folks might have a problem, though, because the light is rather bright.

It fits just fine with my Speck case on the iPhone and the MoKo ultra-light case on the iPad.

I actually like this enough that I'll be ordering another one before I make my annual trip back home for the holidays so I can charge both devices at once. It's a nice cable, well made, great length, and I can tell by looking at it whether my device is finished charging.

One star ( there is no -1) since when I plugged it in, it "blew out" my new Samsung smart TV. Pic went black after a slight pop / arc noise and power light went out on TV. No recovery for TV and TV was brand new.
Both were plugged into a surge protector.
The new TV had been doing great 4-5 days before the antenna arrived and was connected as per directions/tech support first on how I should proceed in connecting it. If I should unplug the TV first was my biggest concern and was told no. WRONG ??
Called them back after the TV went black and told them what, when and how this calamity went down, so think they have probably changed that policy and told me the amperage could have been the problem ( in antenna) and took both items back.

Ill never know if this antenna picks up stations clearly.
Sent back with deceased TV.
My NEW Leaf flat antenna is great.

Trust you found this review honest and helpful:-)
These are small but very clear. Easy to replace my 7 year old JBL computer speakers. Same simple plugs.

I have been working with security camera products for over 20 years - over that time I have installed systems for businesses, corporations and individuals - from enormous multimillion dollar systems to single camera nursery monitors. I‚Äôve consulted on large projects and written about security vulnerabilities within networks for trade publications.

This is a field I know well. Over the years the technology has improved and become less and less expensive to produce. It is now practical to install security systems that would have only previously been used in commercial settings in residential.

As with all security systems my advice is never use cloud based recording - this opens your entire network to not only the company who you are giving blanket access too but also to hackers. The same is true for WiFi. Obviously WiFi is more convenient but if your privacy is a concern this really needs to be taken into account. Hackers have become quite adept at hacking into WiFi cameras and being able to not only watch your feed but control your cameras and access your entire network. If you choose to utilize WiFi cameras take the time to understand your router and employ proper VPN protocols.

Due to my security concerns with WiFi cameras my current security system is completely run through a dedicated computer utilizing the Blue Iris software. While this may seem intimidating to some, it is well worth learning and utilizing for the huge advantages in privacy and security.

I‚Äôve noticed many people have asked if this camera works with a Blue Iris and it does without any issue. Just update to the latest firmware. The remainder of setup within Blue Iris is straightforward. This IPC2387C supports PoE 802.3af and will work with 48V active adapters which are more expensive, but you can also rely on a PoE switch, which in my opinion is a much easier, straightforward option. Something to note, if you plan on powering via a DC cable this is not included.

The fixed lens size of 2.8mm provides decent field of view and the digital zoom is acceptable. The 1/2.8‚Äù CMOS 8MP image sensor is decent in low light, certainly not as good as 1/1.8‚Äù but I‚Äôve found the low light capabilities average in comparison to other similar cameras. The LEDs must be illuminating objects to provide what is considered ‚Äúcolored night vision‚Äù which is misleading.

The camera has a built in microphone that allows for sound recording, though no speaker so two way communication will not be possible with this unit.

In terms of storage, the IPC2387C utilizes H.265 which is currently the best option for video compression. I have had this set up utilizing Blue Iris software which I definitely recommend.

When all things are taken into account this is a solidly build camera, suited to outdoor environments, decent daytime / nighttime resolution, fairly easily mounted, and setup in Blue Iris was reasonably easy and straightforward.

While I would prefer to have pan and tilt capabilities at this price point that is unrealistic. Overall I have been moderately impressed with this budget camera and would recommend it for many security situations.

Solid pair of monitor headphones for DJs and Producers. Good bass response. Clear mids and highs.

Comes with a free 3.5mm headphone to lightning adapter for iPhone owners that prefer a non-Bluetooth pair of cans.

These are my 12 yo boy‚Äôs favorite head phones. He uses them for school work and for gaming. He said they are comfortable and the sound is awesome. He prefers having 1 ear uncovered. It‚Äôs easier for me too because it‚Äôs easier to get his attention when he‚Äôs ‚Äúimmersed‚Äù in a game. I feel like this is a pretty sturdy set too. We‚Äôve used it for a full month on a daily basis and have had no problems. They connect to Bluetooth smoothly and hold a charge for a long time.

I want to kick this review off with a key point, as the title states, the center button on the front of the speaker is the power button. I didn‚Äôt read the directions to see if this was mentioned, I just charged it and struggled to power it on when it was charged.

Outside of that the sound quality and overall volume on this is great. When it first powered on, the automated voice had me concerned as it doesn‚Äôt sound clean, but it seems to be just how it was recorded.

I turned on a song and naturally had to crank up the volume to see what it could do. I was pleasantly surprised and it didn‚Äôt have issues with quality (sometimes speakers get louder in volume and it sounds like someone just singing closer and closer to a microphone).

This does include a short Aux cord (2 ft) and the charging cable (but no plug). The charging cable is USB C that goes into the speaker (but still plugs into a standard usb plug).

I am very pleased here!
Fast & easy  install!  Wound up buying 4 after received overwhelming support from neighbors through nextdoor.com.  Took less than 2 hours to install- works like a champ!
I bring this backup during our family outings (all day at an amusement park, camping, boating, etc) where an AC outlet just isn't available.  Super convenient and doesn't take up much space.
I like the sound quality the battery life is not good and the earbuds keep falling out of my ears. I did put the small earpiece on the earbuds but even with that and not moving they fall out.

Although this mouse is fanciful, sleek and attractive, I'm about to give it to Freak the Cat. His record of catches lately is lookin' pretty slim, so I'm sure he'll be tickled.

EDIT: Just over one month of usage, it is not working. The mouse takes batteries and the batteries could not be bad yet! But the mouse died, and when I press it, I see a light come on, but it will not hold!

The mouse is generally designed to curve or flatten, so as to pack it with you when you travel with your laptop, I assume. In order to take it with you, you need to take the USB receiver and there is a convenient magnetic slot to hold that USB receiver. I'm quite that is an advantage with this mouse, to carry it with you, packs flat, receiver in tow.

The key elements in this design are: curve for comfort, flatten to pack, and it operates on a click tap, flick control. Now, granted there is a lot of auto rolling that the mouse does, that's great, but not worth the wear and tear of the forefinger.

The mouse is hard plastic, designed for cradling the palm. The controls are situated on the forefront on the glossy-covered top of the mouse.

The touch to scroll design is not always a simple touch, and I find myself tapping too much just to get some action going. You are to slide your finger up and down the strip, but believe me, it doesn't do anything often.

Takes Too Much Pressure to Click! My forefinger HURTS !
Second, Clicking on the left side of the mouse takes way too much pressure from the finger. I'm not used to pressing down so hard, just to get it to work.

There is a new feature here, that when you tap on the right spot, a small circle shows on the screen and an arrow leaves that circle indicating automatic scrolling. Well, problem is you can tap several times and still cannot bring the circle up. Sometimes, it pops up when you don't want it. But if you get it working right, it does a nice up and down auto scroll.

So, all in all, I do not like this mouse, and Freak the Cat is free to enjoy the usual pounce and mutilation he does to any mouse in his domain. .....Rizzo.

i purchased the protection plan for a Bluetooth headset. when i called to get my money back because the product broke they made me do a bunch of research and look up all the information for the product. they want to know if it is still under manufacturers warranty. He wanted information i didn't have and insisted that i call amazon to find out the manufacturer. After i refused to call amazon he transferred me to amazon without my consent. i don't think i should have to jump through hoops and do a bunch of research to find out if there are other warranties in place. I want Assurion to pay me for the product and then if its still under warranty they can do the research and get reimbursed. I don't have time to do all this.

I returned this product due to a subpar low range... The treble was decent, the bass was truly non existent.  I'm not an audiophile, however, my primary home theater speakers are Bang & Olufsens. I read a lot of reviews on how these speakers sounded, however, I was not impressed.  I have bose soundlink mini, this was about 20% of the bass of the bose.  If you are looking for full sound you will want to look further.  If you want an inexpensive speaker for work, or somewhere that bass is not a necessity this will be fine.

I'm in a cramped space and can't easily move around or add extra "stuff" to my computer area. This fits in just fine, does a way better picture than my original webcam and I like the various lighting options. I wish there was a camera cover for my own peace of mind but it's easy enough to turn to the wall. I've been told I sound just fine and I can see a truer picture of myself than I did with my old cam so it's easier to set up and align. Works great. Was easy to set up and easy to use.

Returned after a week. Piece of junk. Constantly pairing and telling[[ASIN:B00V81E5O2 Ecandy Bluetooth Headphones Over-ear Stereo Wireless + Wired Headsets with Microphone for Music Streaming,Hands-free Calling For iPhone,Nokia,HTC,Samsung,LG,Moto,iPad,PSP and enabled Bluetooth-black]] me it needs to be charged after a full charge. You get what you pay for.
LOVE LOVE LOVE this product. It's perfect by the pool to listen to our music. The speaker is great and clear, even at louder volumes. The bonus is the lights. It's a party all the time!

THE GOOD:
--------------
* Good quality kit with lots of articulation points.
* C-clamp included has a max opining of 3.4 inches.
* Phone/Tablet holder has metal extending bars. The really cheap ones are all plastic.
* The main stand, aka monopod, is telescopic and goes from 13 to 22 inches.
* Use the magic arm by itself, or attach it to the monopod.
* Terrific high quality little mini ball-head included.
* Universal 1/4 inch hardware, which makes it easy to combine with other camera accessories.

THE BAD:
------------
* Nothing really. It's a combination of plastic and metal, and priced just right. I highly recommend you add these clamps to make your kit even more versatile, here's an Amazon link: https://www.amazon.com/gp/customer-reviews/R1Z5WE52M3ZYXE/ref=cm_cr_getr_d_rvw_ttl?ie=UTF8&ASIN=B089VY9PLX

5-Stars!

I ordered the 'Soundcore Wakey Bluetooth Speaker Powered by Anker with Alarm Clock, Stereo Sound, FM Radio, White Noise, QI Wireless Charger with 7.5W Charging for iPhone and 10W for Samsung' for review and would like to share some of my thoughts after a few weeks.

First off, this thing is actually pretty amazing. The build quality is nice and aesthetically it looks clean. The sound quality is nice but not phenomenal. However for how small it is, it does produce decent sound and for a bedside alarm clock it does quite well. The wireless charging works great for my Galaxy Note 8 (and does in fact Fast-Charge) however there have been a couple nights to where my phone was not charged the next morning. The fast charger also works with my wireless earbuds which I attached an image showing the charge light on the Wakey, and the wireless earbuds case indicating charging. However for the wireless earbud charging, it does take some precise positioning to get them to charge. I noticed in other review that others weren't happy with the bright display light with no way to adjust it any dimmer than the lowest setting, however they must have updated that with a firmware update (which was super easy to do) as I had no issues with the display being too bright at night. I use the auto adjust setting which seems to work quite well as far as I can tell. Also I love the sleep mode sounds that you can adjust several (or just one) sound volumes to create your own personalized preference. I do wish that there were more sound options but the ones they provide are acceptable. I also wish that you could download and install more alarm sounds. Bluetooth connectivity is super quick and have never once had an issue with pairing it up to my phone. Really the ONLY issue I have with the Wakey is that to get the sleep mode sounds going, you need to connect with the app, and via Bluetooth connect to the device. No big deal right? Well my concern is that you will need to keep it connected for this feature to work. This means you will be connected to the Wakey ALL night and this kind of bugs me. It's just kind of creepy that the Wakey is connected to your phone all night while you sleep. I wish there was a way to just play your favorite white noise sleep sound by pressing a button on the Wakey device without having to always connect and stay connected to the app and your phone. The other gripe is that the plug design is huge and makes it so that I have had to move my nightstand further way from the wall to use it. Other than those two gripes, and the only reason for docking one star, the Soundcore Wakey is a very good product and a really great value.
*On a side note - I just tested the Wakey while watching some Youtube videos and the latency is not so good. There is quite a bit of delay and the voices do not sync up at all so I wouldn't recommend using the Wakey for listening to videos.

My daughter enjoys listening to music in bed and on car trips. The problem with traditional headphones are that they either fall our of her ears (earbuds) or are uncomfortable if she falls asleep (over the ear). This solves those issues. Although these are advertised as more of a eye mask with music, which I imagine would be a sensory experience to promote sleep, my daughter uses them more like a headband/sweatband to wear around the house. She just cleaned her room wearing them over her forehead and it reminded me of an 80's workout video. If it's cold outside, I think they'd make a pretty interesting alternative to keep your child's ears warm as well.
She says they are comfortable, and sound good, although I can't verify these claims since it doesn't really fit me. She likes them, so that's a win as far as I'm concerned!

These are by far the best earbuds I've ever encountered! The sound quality is unbelievably fantastic. And the amount of noise cancelation they provide is even better. The Bluetooth stayed connected for as far as I needed to travel away from my phone with no buffering to remain connected. If you are looking for amazing quality, and a sleek, comfortable earbud, these are the ones for you! I highly recommend this product.

Note: I would love to love this speaker set, but it has inconsistent performance with various devices. I received a review sample and was pleased by the sound when I plugged this into the phone port on my ThinkPad T61. The sound was clear and I could hear every note on the album that I use to test speakers (Miles Davis' [[ASIN:B000002ADT Kind of Blue]]). I use that album because the instruments in the ensemble cover low, mid and high range frequencies. The bass was a little thin, but with the speakers less than two feet away the sound was rich and I was happy.

Where I started to experience problems was when I plugged this into the 3.5mm port on my Samsung Galaxy Note 3 phone. There was static in the mix. The same with my [[ASIN:B00D029NNA Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 10.1 inch]] - static interfered with the music. My final test was to plug the 3.5mm cable end into an [[ASIN:B00AEJJRBK Avantree Cara Bluetooth 4.0 Handsfree stereo Car Kit with mic]] and connect via bluetooth. The sound was crystal clear.

I am not sure what conclusions to draw. It could be something wrong with the Samsung phone and tablet, although both work perfectly with headphones which I have directly plugged into their 3.5mm ports. It may be that the 3.5mm cable and interface on the input of this speaker is overly sensitive to impedance and the slightest deviation will induce static. I am not sure, but because I was unable to get the same quality consistently across all devices with which I tested these speakers I subtracted two stars.

Construction is exceptional, although I wish the design employed removable USB and 3.5mm cables instead of the fixed ones that provide power and signal inputs, and connect the two units. As it stands if a cable breaks it will take some skill to repair it. With removable, off-the-shelf cables a broken one can be rectified with a trip to an electronics store.

Overall, on the two devices that I tested with which these speakers worked the sound was spectacular. On the other two it was unlistenable. If you are connecting this to a bluetooth receiver it's probably a safe choice, but if you are connecting this to anything else I would proceed with caution.

The quality of the camera is good unless you are trying to record. I talked to friends first to be sure they could see and hear me (sound is iffy but I expected that--I use a separate microphone when I'll be doing a lot of talking) and got positive results. Then I tried to record a meeting and the quality of the recording left a lot to be desired. If you are just visiting or even working without trying to record anything this camera is fine. If you are doing a lot of recording, the quality isn't there - keep looking.

These are good Bluetooth headphones. They are a little on the large side, but don't fully sit in the ear, so for most adults, they should be fine. They are a little big on me, but still usable without being uncomfortable. They sit pretty securely around the ear. The sound quality is good, but doesn't block outside sound, which is good if you are using these for running or areas where you kind of need to still be able to hear car horns and such. Really, the only problem I have with these is the battery life.They have to be charged daily, even if you don't use them. They just don't hold a charge as well as I would like. But just remember to charge them daily, and you're cool.

For the price, this device is okay, but the user interface is pathetic. The touch interface is annoying because it only applies to half the screen. What's worse is when the device screen goes blank (to save battery life), you have to touch the screen - which performs one of the functions, like play or pause. It's quite annoying. The buttons of the touch screen are at the bottom and you can only navigate the interface by tapping up/down/left/right. So doing things on the device is a chore

I bought this for a friend and didn't spend much time with it - only to set it up. So I don't have an opinion of the sound quality or the build quality. However ... one comment on the latter. I've seen a number of reviews for this and similar products which reference the weight of the device and correlation it to the quality of the build. The 2 don't always to hand in hand. The Chinese have been known to add lead weights to devices to make them heavier so that people will believe it's better build quality or material than it really is. I don't know this to be the case with this device - just wanted to point out that weight may not be the telltale people think it is

BTW - the USB cable is SHORT. Probably only a foot at most. Also, it's micro USB, which is a pain in the butt.

The radio function required the use of headphones - as an antenna. Kind of a pain for Bluetooth headphone users. Also - if the headphones are plugged in, I presume you can't listen through the device's built in speaker (which is lackluster) or through an external Bluetooth speaker. I can't confirm this because, as I said, I only spent about an hour using the device.

FYI - the device has no internal storage. The 32GB is in the form of a micro SDXC card. This means if you opt to purchase a larger card to use with the device, you won't be adding to the 32GB, you'll be replacing it.

Works great! My husband had to marry it to the receiver somehow, and it didn't come with any instructions on how to do that, so if you are technically challenged, watch out. But after he did that, it works just like the old broken one.

For years I messed around with tripods for my lights stands. Although there's nothing wrong with tripods but sometimes, they take up too much space. So, what I like about the SmallRig 19"-39" Camera Desk Mount, 2 PCS Table Stand with 1/4" Ball Head, and Tabletop C Clamp for DSLR Camera, Light, Ring Light, or cell phone with the right adapter (that is not included with this kit). Or small projector, you can clamp your rig right on your desk for the gig. I also like that it has a quarter inch screw on the ball head that will go 390 degrees as you please and it's strong enough to hold a camera or small projector, if UNDER 22 pounds or around. And old boy, it is aviation alloy, with a matte surface that doesn't shine like some cheap plastic ones you know the kind. And what's really cool they give you 2. I also like that the clamps are padded, so it won't scratch your desk if it's two inches or less Jess. One more thing you can do with that quarter inch screw. is put your microphone on it too. I highly recommend my friend; to get your lighting just right every now and then. Thank you for looking at my review and I hope it is beneficial for you. God bless you and may the rest of your life be the best of your life be the best of your life.  Oran Z

A quality, long length cable to transfer audio from 1/8th inch audio jack (3.5mm) to a left right analog speaker system.  Works perfectly for an iPod, computer or anything with a standard headphone jack.  Clean, clear audio out of both left/right speakers.

There is netting on the inside on one side. I love that for my headphones however on the other side you could put cash or a car key. This is the perfect small case for its hard outer shell and it's nicely designed interior. I find that the outside scratches easily but the inside stays safe. Worth the price. Case not waterproof!

The Dynabook Protege X30L-J1331 is great. ‚Ä®
It is ultra lightweight. Weighs about 2 pounds.
‚Ä®It comes with a variety of ports: two usb ports, micro sd port, HDMI port, two type-c thunderbolt 4 ports, and a ethernet port. I find that most laptops today do not include a ethernet port. This is great because it is a direct connection that is sometimes faster than wifi.
‚Ä®There is also a port for earphones and it is Bluetooth capable.
And I really like the super long cord. It is long enough to move around without worrying about it becoming disconnected. ‚Ä®
There is also a fingerprint reader located on the computer.
‚Ä®One feature that takes a little getting use to is the left and right mouse buttons sit at the top of the trackpad versus at the bottom. This is a little inconvenient and will take some getting use too.
‚Ä®The specs of this computer are sufficient for the average user.
It has an 11th generation intel core processor with 8GB of memory and a 256 GB¬† hard drive.
There is a cover that slides over the camera. A nice feature that adds some security. ‚Ä®The laptop itself is a dark blue and looks almost black. ‚Ä®The monitor/screen is clear and bright.
The operating system is Windows 10 Pro. ‚Ä®It also comes preloaded with Opera and I added Firefox.
‚Ä®So far I have been impressed with the speed of how fast it works and how programs open quickly with no delay. ‚Ä®
This computer offers a lot of bang for your bucks.
It is a great computer for the home and for those (high school and college aged) students who like Windows based computers versus Mac ones.

I charged these up and then tried them out. They fit nicely in my ear and the ear hooks and ear loops help them stay in place. I have had issues with those types of things previously, but on this set, they do what they are supposed to do. I am thrilled about this. Now, what would make the perfect, is if the charge lasted 12 hours, I listen to podcasts at night and 8 hours isn't going to be enough. With podcasts or with sleep music, bass is not a priority for me. But, because I have depression, I sleep longer than most people, even on my medication. Sometimes, I will wake up in the middle of the night and hear an interesting podcast, and with these staying in my ears, it makes it easier. My headphones are great but one pair slips around alot and the other pair which is a much better pair, has a very sensitive on off on the ear muff. But both of those will hold a good charge, These House of Marley are going to make for a better night's sleep without constant having to adjust the other headphones.

Ordered for my teen son who disses on poor Alexa as a music source bc she cant work as hard as he would like to belt out the sounds to his menagerie of music.. Yess!! He‚Äôs the one who likes deep bass when listening to his tunes- whether it‚Äôs metal, classic rock, or even the 80‚Äôs‚Ä¶ the thump is what he loves for- and this Geektop blue tooth speaker will bring it! (May/not be good for all family members.. consider yourself warned!)

The sound produced is deep.. it has a depth that doesn‚Äôt distort so that‚Äôs a big positive- the only thing worse then booming bass, is distorted bass!!! What surprises me with this speaker- is the ability to hear the varied individual Instruments in the music.. Surprisingly, those can be lost in a lot of subpar speaker/stereos! ie., listening to the 80‚Äôs group ‚ÄúYaz‚Äù I asked who remade the song- come to find out it was the original!! I had just never heard a quality rendition of it to pick up on the keyboard synthesizer sounds in that specific capacity.. If that isnt proof enough- not sure what is!

Speaker easily connects to your device on first try and never had issue with dropping connection.. (if you‚Äôve had this angst before- you know how annoying it can be!) lights are a total perk.. fun flare and why not! Can be used with/without. But note: Music seems happier with lights. Ha ha!!

Nothing but positives- this does exactly as it says and does it well. Without hesitation I‚Äôd recommend for anyone who likes a little boom.. earplugs for mama optional! Hoping info can help make your decision- stay safe everyone.

The LOGITECH SOLAR KEYBOARD FOLIO is easily the best of the three Bluetooth keyboard products that I've tested. (The others are the [[ASIN:B004YIZXEC iHome Bluetooth Keyboard for iPad 1 and 2 and iPhone (IH-IP2101)]] (no case, about $40), and the [[ASIN:B007C0Y8NQ Targus Versavu Keyboard Case for the New iPad (3rd Gen), Wi-Fi / 4G Model 16GB, 32GB, 64GB THZ17101US (Black)]] (padded case, about $70).) Setting up the FOLIO is a snap: you slip the iPad into the flexible silicon easel tray, move the easel to the "Type" position, turn on your iPad's Bluetooth, and let the iPad find the Folio's keyboard.

The Folio converts your iPad into a "netbook" with an almost full-sized keyboard. The keyboard is virtually noiseless, has a pleasant, soft "touch" for typing, has the usual specialized function keys (including a volume key), and is big enough to easily accommodate my large hands. The easel has two comfortable viewing positions, one for typing and one for media viewing. The Folio offers full scratch and screen protection for the iPad, as both the front and back of the iPad are covered. The Folio is extremely slim and lightweight-- good points, in my view--but there is NO padding to protect your iPad from jarring or other mishaps. Whenever you like, you can easily remove your iPad from the Folio's silicon easel tray.

The Folio's Bluetooth keyboard is powered by the solar cells on the front of the case. To fully charge the batteries, you place the case face up in a well-lit room for about six hours. To check whether the batteries are sufficiently charged for keyboard use, you press the "Battery Status" button on the side of the Folio. A LED light will blink once in green if you have an adequate charge, once in red if you don't. No light means your batteries are dead and must be recharged, using the solar panels. (At first, I thought that my Folio's batteries weren't charging, because the "getting started" booklet made me expect a steady green LED light when the batteries were adequately charged. An excellent chart on the Logitech web site, under the question "What does the LED mean on my tablet keyboard?", cleared up my confusion.)

Without fail, the Folio turns my iPad 2 on and off when I open and close the case. (The iPad general setting for "iPad Cover Lock/Unlock" must be set to "On".) When I open the case, the LED light blinks briefly until the iPad finds and connects to the keyboard. When you turn off Bluetooth to save iPad battery power, your iPad will find the Folio keyboard again without difficulty when you turn Bluetooth back on. (The Folio only connects when the easel is set to "Type" or "Media Viewing" position.)

The only thing that I don't love about the Folio, is that you have to be quite careful when closing it. The edge of your iPad must be in front of the little "roll bar" at the Folio's spine, or else the cover won't fully close (and a hurried, careless, forceful closing could damage your iPad screen). Because this lightweight case adds an excellent physical keyboard to my iPad while adding minimal weight and bulk, I rate it at 5 stars ("I love it" on the Amazon scale). This is the iPad case that I will be using in the future.

Great sound quality - and, when working on the noisy tractor, my grandson tells me his classical music comes through without any tractor noise - which is something because that‚Äôs a noisy tractor!  They also eliminate our ability to call him for meals, so have had to resort to flags.  These are fabulous earbuds.  He says they‚Äôre the best he‚Äôs ever used.  Great choice!

Alex works great with this soundbar. Even with the sound turned all the way up it still recognizes mt voice.

Pros:
Easy to setup with the Polk app.
Very good sound for music and TV/Movies.
You can tell Alexa to turn it up or down and switch sources. I have it connected to Chromecast and Cable service.
Can connect my iPhone to it easily to play music from other apps.
The sub is wireless so it can be put anywhere in the room... It needs a power outlet of course.
My kids love telling it what music to play.

Cons:
The dial on top shows you the percent of volume, but it's kind of awkward to tell where it's at. (Not a huge deal though).
Without any doubt -- the BEST bluetooth headset I've used!

They hurt my ears pretty bad. I've had a lot of earbuds before and these are by far the most uncomfortable. These will also randomly disconnect from my phone even when I'm sitting next to my phone. It's weird

I had this installed in less than 20 minutes. Very easy. It does come with a template but I didn‚Äôt have to use it. There are 2 adjustable brackets and all hardware is included. I adjusted the width to snuggly hold my soundbar and it‚Äôs solidly in there! No issues. I recommend!

I love this bluetooth transmitter. Its fast and easy to set up. Set the switch to one of the 2 settings  (the manual will tell you which one) plug it in, turn on your headphones to syncing mode, and you're ready to go.  I use it while it's plugged into the wall, but it also holds a charge so it doesn't need to be plugged in to a power source to use.

For the price, this unit is amazing. If you are using built in smart TV speakers - this is for you. I have it connected using my optical out and RAW Bitstream.

Does make a buzz sound even when off. I didn't notice as I have it connected to a remote operated power strip and shut down the power to the wall entirely. The sound difference between 1-3 is negligible and 3-4 sounds like a full 3 decibel increase. They are not loud by industry standard.

Perfect for a small living room entry Home theatre. This is not for those coming from Bose or another high end brand.

Love this security system, the only area that I don't like is that you cant use your computer to monitor the cameras only your phones. I hope this feature will be available soon.
07/22/19 Update: These cameras don't have a two way audio, I was not aware of it until I had a need to use that feature, the time had expire and was not able to returned for a full refund instead I was offered 50% to 60% refund or a $20.00 credit to my account. It is too bad that the lack of this feature is not clear on the website.
Works great for when your car doesn't have Bluetooth! The pandora and spotify come out pretty clear from my phone to the stereo.  Got it for almost $10 less than it was at walmart!

In the age of electronics, we all need more ways to plug ourselves in and manufacturers know this. They have responded by added usb ports and regular outlets to everyday appliances and this added convenience was enough to convince me to get the Seealle Bedside Desk Lamp with USB Fast Charging Port and Outlets Power Strip.

This lamp requires a small amount of assembly out of the box. The assembly is simple, but it takes longer than it should due to the way they pack everything into the box. I know they do this to require as little space and as small of a box as possible, but the way the shade is inverted with the base stuck inside it takes effort to get loose. I was extra careful and avoided damage, but many people will not be so lucky.

Once assembled, you just need to screw in a light bulb, screw the shade in place, and set the lamp on your desired table. My wife needed a night light for evening book reading, so I placed the lamp on her night stand. She likes having two places to plug in her phone, and the added light is nice for reading. There is a master switch on the cord and this provides another way to turn everything on and off, including the outlets. Another switch on the side of the base also controls the outlet. This is why, when you plug something in, you need to check to make sure it is charging. If it isn‚Äôt, then there is a good chance that one of the switches is in the off position. The light can be turned on/off using either the switch on the cord or by pulling the vertical, hanging metal cord underneath the light bulb.

This small light looks good on a night stand, but it is slightly smaller than expected. It also seems rather delicate and due to the darkness of the shade, it may not produce the level of light you need. I find it fine as a bedroom nightlight because we don‚Äôt want it to be bright in this type of setting anyway, but other people might find that the shade makes everything too dark.

It‚Äôs always good to have extra outlets and lamps with added outlets are commonplace nowadays as manufacturers answer customer needs. I like that this light has two added outlets, but the lamp is small and I still cannot get over the effort it took to dislodge the inverted shade from the base when I pulled the lamp out of the box for the first time. So, when all factors are taken into account, this lamp rates as average overall.

This is an Asus Eee Slate EP 121-1A010 update; we've changed the rating from "Like it" to "Love it" and we're adding a couple more to the office. I chose it for a gastroenterologist friend who needed it for her medical practice. Now that patient records need to be digitized, she uses this tablet to keep track of all her business's management needs, which include patient vitals, records, and billing. In the doctor's own words:

"I log into Athena, which is our electronic medical record and practice management, and then all the info regarding a patient gets put in. So, the girls will use the tablet to populate BP, pulse, etc, past medical history, chief complaint, etc. Some of it is clicking onto specific fields and it will auto-populate with a touch. I think the ASUS Eee Slate is the perfect size screen by the way. I really like that one. The Acer (an alternate tablet which we tested) is good but, screen is small so it's difficult to maneuver over fields."

The doctor had been advised to get a Windows tablet and the ASUS fits the bill. She tried it and an Acer tablet so that she and her staff could get the feel of two different products. The Acer is considerably less expensive, has less memory, and lacks a few features that the Asus has. We had hoped to get tablets with the anticipated Windows 8 that MS announced around March 2011, but by August 8th, the anticipated release date was 2012. Failure to comply with new federal laws for digitized medical records means incurring penalties, so she wanted to have everything by September, hence these two touch tablets seemed to be the best choice as of August 2011. After nearly three months of use, it became clear that the Acer couldn't meet her needs, but the ASUS has been wonderful. The doctor and her staff can download medical templates and macros directly from her provider, Athena Health, onto a main computer or the tablet.

While her medical staff handles the initial patient consultations, the info can be transfered to or from a tablet into the office's mainframe computer, athenahealth.com, and to the doctor's own tablet via e-file or e-mail. They no longer need to transcribe handwritten information into the office's computer; it can now be done on the spot, saving time. The tablets can also be used to read Kindle books.

The ASUS has the added advantage of a wireless Bluetooth keyboard and a digital pen, which I believe can be an asset for anything that requires a signature, e.g. a prescription or an MS Office Word business letter. It also interfaces well with a wireless printer, but it does have USB ports. The ASUS also comes with a mediocre MS Office program that can be upgraded for a better version.

My initial favorites were the Apple iPad2 or a Toshiba tablet. However, neither of them comes with a Windows operating system (OS). Toshiba uses Google's Android (aka Droid) and Apple uses its own system. While you can change Toshiba's OS to a Windows OS, I wouldn't recommend it if you're not technically savvy.
I am using this keyboard on my smart TV. I plugged in the USB receiver and inserted batteries into the keyboard. The small size is great, and it types onto the TV screen perfectly.

In comparison to my Toshiba Satellite 15" with similar specs, this ASUS is about equal - there are definitely some things I like better about the ASUS for everyday use and a couple of small quibbles that bother me. First off the computer itself is about the same weight as my Toshiba so carrying it around is exactly the same and it fits in my existing laptop sleeves and bags. It does have a DVD tray so you can play movies & music and burn discs as needed (as does my Toshiba), but a lot of laptops don't offer this anymore, so this is a definite plus.

I do really like that the ASUS comes a lot cleaner out of the box than my Toshiba - almost no bloatware pre-installed. The basic Windows 10 and you can don't have to spend 30 minutes messing around with a bunch of garbage you don't want and won't use anyway. Additionally, the ASUS boots up about 20 seconds faster from off than my Toshiba and again from the sign in screen, the ASUS is still faster. The screen is very pretty and clear with a variety of images and video - keep in mind that it's NOT a touchscreen. I've been averaging about 6 hours of use with the battery before it hits the 30% mark - that is net surfing, watching some random videos, and mostly word processing. Leaving it on in sleep mode with no use - it went almost 4 full days before needing a charge. The wifi connects immediately and I've had zero issues with it dropping out either inside or out on the back deck.

I really like the keyboard and the overall shape of the frame on this particular laptop. My Toshiba has the keyboard just open and exposed and what happens is that the heels of my hands tend to slip upwards as I type or bump the space bar. Or my thumbs slide into the mousepad area and now my cursor has bounced someplace new & I'm typing in the wrong spot. The ASUS keyboard is slightly lowered and has a border around it - for me anyway, this design is MUCH easier to type with. (See the photo.) The shape of the overall frame is better on the ASUS than the Toshiba as well. The rounded corners and edges on the ASUS don't poke into your wrists after an hour of writing or research.

My quibbles seem small on the surface, but after almost three weeks of use, they are aggravating me. First - the ASUS doesn't keep time as well as the Toshiba. It's off by 2 full minutes. (See the photos) I've checked both a couple of times and set them manually at the same moment and within 24 hours, the ASUS has lost 2 minutes - it never loses more than that though. Second - The charger is smaller than every other one I have for the other two laptops and the Chromebook in this house. The other three are standard size, but the one on the ASUS is a tiny bit smaller and thus you can't use another charger for this laptop in an emergency. Third - the speakers on the ASUS don't sound quite as full as the ones on my Toshiba. Of course... no built in speakers on a laptop are really meant for full music enjoyment.

My bottom line is that at this price point, this is a nice machine and will do almost anything you can want with regard to basic internet surfing, movie watching, office work and the like. This is not a gamer's computer and it's not meant to be. But as a regular, go to every day laptop, it's a pretty good one. I want to give it 4 1/2 stars.

It was working great for the first few months...then I started noticing the battery would be dead the next day after a full recharge. Definitely not worth the $$$$, my cheap $20 earbuds were much more reliable.

These earbuds combine incredible sound in a stylish and functional package. I would give these more than 5 stars if I could. I had high expectations before trying these, especially in view of the price, and these earbuds blew those away.

Bang & Olufsen's engineers magically crammed a high-end sound system into a lightweight, wireless earbud. You have to hear them to believe how amazing these sound - clean, clear music across an impressively wide range. I noticed details for the first time in songs that I have heard many times before.

Beyond the sound, the craftsmanship and overall product design are outstanding. I don't know about the electronics as only time will tell, but the earbuds and the case themselves look like they will hold up to regular use without any issues. The leather and brushed aluminum on the case adds an extra-premium feel to the product.

Also, at first I thought the charging capability of the case was a bit gimmicky, but I quickly realized my error. It is so convenient to know that the earbuds are fully charged whenever I want to use them. I don't have a Qi charger, so I haven't taken advantage of the full wireless capability. But for me, it is not a big deal to use the USB cord when I need to occasionally charge the case.

To give some context, this is not a product I would have considered purchasing on my own. I've always thought of earbuds as cheap, portable ways to listen to music while working out or on the go - situations where the background noise means that you can't appreciate high-quality sound. However, after jumping at the chance to try these, they have completely changed my perspective on what earbuds can do. Excellent sound quality is available in a highly portable, convenient product.

The only downside I have experienced is that the touch controls take some time to get used to. I had trouble figuring it out at first, but after a few days I can usually get them to do what I intend to do on the first try. I prefer the minimalistic design, so this learning curve is not a significant issue for me.

I also like the Bang & Olufsen music app that allows selection of different listening modes that vary between - "warm", "excited", "relaxed", or "bright" sound profiles. Switching between the modes really gives the sound a different character. My favorite feature on the app, however, is the ability to select "transparency" of the music. A higher level of transparency amplifies your surroundings so you can hear what is going on around you. This does not give you spy-gadget levels of hearing, but it noticeably amplifies background sounds. I've been using these headphones at work, and I can easily hear when my phone rings or when someone knocks on my office door.

Last, the excellent sound quality carries over to phone calls. I have no trouble hearing the other person on the line, which is not always the case with the built-in speaker on my iPhone. Also the people I have talked to have had heard me clearly. This was an unexpected bonus, and I actually prefer to use the earbuds for calls now.

TL;DR: If you can afford these, you won't regret it.

[[VIDEOID:3d7cbced89ca7ccd1f2cca44a7204b3d]] The green glow is what sold me on these. I‚Äôve had a few pairs of this style headphones and they always stay on accidentally. It‚Äôs my fault, I forget to turn them off. Not a problem here! They glow really bright and that‚Äôs awesome.

Sound is pretty good and about right for the price.

Charging is easy to do in the case. I like these a lot !

[[VIDEOID:39f57150f79275f153991c4d149bb17]] Ok, first the good things:
-This supports Android Auto and Apple Carplay (we only tested Android)
-It takes a measly single-DIN slot and gives you a fold out touch screen display to make things like the backup camera, phone UI, etc, possible which normally would not fit in a single DIN space.
-I can't stress this enough, but IT HAS A VOLUME KNOB. I can't even tell you how hard it is to find a modern radio with Android Auto / Car Play support that doesn't rely on touch screen buttons!

That being said, it has some issues. As you can see in the video attached, sometimes it takes more than one touch to navigate the touch screen options. A more annoying issue, however, is the AM radio. You can't pick a station that ends in a zero! So stations like 550 which we wanted to listen to, simply CAN'T be tuned in! Even if you try to manually type it in, for some reason the dial pad starts reducing available numbers as you pick, as if they don't WANT you to be able to pick a zero as the last digit. It's very strange!

I'd say for the user experience it should be 3 stars, but I'm adding a 4th because it's kind of rare to find a radio like this that fits in the space it does and offers these features. This Ford truck had a busted radio from the 90s, and this is a VERY welcome facelift and upgrade. I really like it and think for the price you're getting a lot of functionality. Of course you can't expect the polish or audiophile sound quality of a Pioneer or Alpine head unit, or even the mid-range quality of something like an Atoto, so for the price considering how unique of a product this is, plus the included camera, etc, I'd say it's a good value for a truck like this. I just wish the AM radio weren't so weird!
These seem fine. OK sound, good battery life, simple controls. Just wish the earbud retracted with button push. Minor complaint

Okay, yeah, it's got a 128 LED lights and that's more and better than the ones that have only 60. . . or 96 lights. I already had one nearly, no exactly identical light/speaker to this with 96 lights. Now maybe there's a visible difference between 128 LEDs and 60, there pretty much has to be. But I have my 96 light speaker in the same shower nook as the new, 128 light speaker and Other than the large 1 I wrote on the bottom of the original speaker (96 lights) I can't tell them apart. That being long windedly said they're beautiful however many lights they have. As mentioned I have them both in the same wall nook in my shower and when I take a shower at night I use only the simulated fire from the two lights and it is awesome. The two speakers will sync into a stereo configuration very easily. Just sync once each and then turn them on. The speakers have decent sound as long as you remember they're small drivers running 5 watts each. More than enough for a shower, bedroom or out on a deck or patio for a small party.
About the only thing I don't like about these units are the white rim ring light and button lights for vilume, power, changing songs stay on the whole time and they're quite bright. I understand that you'll need to find the control buttons but the bright white lights detract slightly from the fire effect. They should either be orange/red to to match the fire effect LEDs or turn off after a short period of time. Besides that I really enjoy having these around. They hold a charge for weeks. Granted I only use them a few times a week for showers but I've never run them out of charge I end up thinking I should charge them because it's been a month or more since the last time they were charged.
Fun, entertaining light with a decent speaker, can be paired into stereo configuration. Good stuff.

My Insignia tv speakers are in the back. This is a problem when either the ac or heat turns on. Surround sound was too bulky for me, especially with my cats, so I tried a soundbar. This one was $40 with rave reviews, so I tried it. It was very easy to install with the good instructions. I used the optical cable. I can finally hear my tv. The remote immediately synced with my tv remote. I do have to turn the volume up every time I turn it on, but that's fine.

I've heard a lot of wonderful things about the Sony noise cancelling sets like these, and let me tell you: it isn't just hype. The sound quality is excellent, and the noise cancelling is eerily amazing. I put it on my wife and kids with the noise cancelling off and then turned it on to demonstrate, and you can see each them suddenly smile like "whoa". Like my Sony studio headphones I use professionally for work, the actual fidelity of the sound it reproduces is excellent, and the microphone for calls is excellent despite being up by my ears and so far from my mouth (other bluetooth headphones I've tried were good for music only, the mic being up by my ears wasn't good enough to isolate my voice from ambient sound, but this definitely does a great job).
The app gives a ton of control beyond what I expected to really customize the experience. For example, I have mine set to auto-pause if the headphones are removed, and to turn off noise cancelling when it detects me speaking to someone, and then resume playback when the headphones are removed/replaced. These features are all customizable, as well as many more. But you need the app. And this is where the cons come in:
1) You really need the app to get the most out of this. I was thinking about pairing this with my desktop and/or TV, but without the app you have far less control, and to be honest I couldn't even get it to pair with my phone using just Bluetooth alone. There seems to be a way according to the instructions, but I couldn't figure it out without using the app installed.
2) For a set that costs this much, I'm surprised at how scuffed up it got after one fall from about 3 feet next to my car. Including pictures. This happened the day I got it. I'm not sure if there's anything that can be done about that, pavement is hard to recover from if anything is dropped, but it's something to keep in mind if you're spending this much money on a gadget. My studio headphones have been roughed around for years and held up fine.

All in all, I'd give it 5 stars if it weren't so reliant on the app to get the features going and/or more resilient to being dropped. Feels like I should deduct one for that. But as far as features and sound quality go, this is a solid 5 out of 5.

The 10" is great for movies and reading things that begin with small type and need to be enlarged. One issue I've always had with 6" Fires and Kindles is that when I need to increase the font, it can become a little cumbersome because the screen is too small. The larger screen solves that problem. The picture is clear and the it sounds better with the 2 speakers. Overall, I find it to be complementary to my 6" Fire and regular tv/ Fire stick.
You can't beat the price for it's use as an entertainment device, when comparing to another tablet brand. It works better and is more reliable than an HP laptop I have that is only a couple of years old (not to mention much better customer service). I only wish I could use WordPerfect on it.

[[VIDEOID:e1357f8ba5ba18d5f83af1be700c2c42]] Of course you can't compare this to a high end earbuds, but you can't can't get a basic pair as good as these for $8 !
Sounds is good, wire length is long, and earbuds are small. They fit well in my ears and stay tight on them while doing exercise. Comes with additional ear pieces to get the perfect fit in your ear. Overall, this is definitely worth the money. Kudos to Amazon for making good products.

I picked up one of these mice on sale about a year ago. I love it. The battery lasts well over a month (despite the fact that I never turn it off). I love that it can be connected to up to 3 devices and the Unifying Receiver compatibility. I work in an IT office and we have displays that need to be restarted from time to time - having a receiver in that device makes it so much easier to login from my desk. I love the fact that I can remap the buttons on the mouse and find that I do use them more than I expected. Plus the scroll wheel settings are not just functional (the continued scroll and the ability to turn on and off clicking), but also satisfying. I would definitely recommend this mouse, especially if you can get it at a discount.

If I could fix one thing it would be bluetooth. I rarely use this (or my logitech keyboard) over bluetooth on my laptop. I find that it frequently needs to be reset leaving me scrambling to find a wired mouse and keyboard to log back in and reconnect the devices. I think this is an issue with my laptop or WIN10 more than an issue with the mouse since this happened with other brand devices as well. My ipads don't seem to have any issue saving and recalling the devices when they attempt to connect.
lovely addition to any audio desk set up

FYI You don‚Äôt have to hardwire it. Ring sells a Plug-in Mount for Floodlight Cams which allows you to connect it to an outlet. Easy peasy.

We love having this. It provides peace of mind as the thieves seem to be getting more numerous and bolder & bolder. Recently, using the speaker function, I was able to question/chase away some Dude who was literally dumpster diving in our neighbor‚Äôs big trash bin. He wasn‚Äôt just picking up roadside discards. With identity theft so prevalent, I worried he was looking for personal information. I was able to challenge him while safe inside our house. I said I was calling the police and he quickly left. I wouldn‚Äôt have felt safe going outside to confront him.

I love that the notifications come on my Apple Watch. So easy & convenient since I don‚Äôt tend to carry my iPhone on me.

The floodlight camera is also great for knowing when/where packages have been delivered so one can retrieve them before the porch pirates grab them.

However, the greatest pleasure is seeing all the critters who come through at night. Before the floodlight camera, who knew? One night there was even a pair of coyotes! Cool!

I want to add one in the back but the price has gone up by $30! Guess I‚Äôll see if the price comes back down. With the price of gas & everything else going up so much, the budget‚Äôs getting slammed. Sigh.

I got this as a gift from my husband with my new computer.  It is so adorable and the sound is perfect for my uses.  I may even use this little speaker outside in the summer or I might just another one for that!  Good value for the money!  The sound quality is good, it shipped fast.

I received this is a free review sample. For the price this is a bargain, but there are two things that kept me from giving it five stars. First is this does not use a standard micro USB style cable for charging. That means that unless you can find an easy source of cables with USB A on one end and the barrel connector this one has on the other, you are stuck with a three foot limitation of cable length. I have USB micro cables that are double that, and would have made this light all the more useful. Also, since I am using this as a music stand light if I misplace it for a gig I am out of luck because I do not own a similar charging cable (although I always have spare USB micro cables in my gig bag.) If you intend to use this as a fixed table lamp the cable issue will not be the problem for you that it is for me.

Second, the gooseneck is sensitive. If I bump a music stand with this light clamped to the shelf it will move far out of place. It's not stiff enough to hold if you do plan to use it with a music stand. For tables, bed stands, etc. it should work fine, though.

Here are some of the strengths: the lowest setting of illumination is perfect for stage use or if you want to read in bed without waking your partner up. At the highest setting it is definitely bright when lose in (about 1.5 meters), and - as Goldilocks said - the medium setting is just right.

Another feature is untethered to the charger this will operate for three hours at the brightest setting and half more than double that at the lowest. That means that if you are camping, on stage (or in front of a lectern) without a power source nearby you can still use it.

Finally, the included wall wart has a 2 Amp port for phones and tablets, as well as a 500mA port for charging this light. That is handy and all the more reason why the cable style for this lamp is a frustration - it could have easily been a five star product, and especially at the going price.

This iHome Bluetooth Keyboard arrives already charged, which makes it a snap to set up. To use with an iPad, you just (1) switch the keyboard on, (2) press the "connect" button, (3) use iPad Settings/General/Bluetooth to find the keyboard, (4) click on the name of the found keyboard, and (5) enter the code that pops up. (The keyboard requires iOS 4.0 or later to connect to an iPhone 3G or iPod Touch.)

The featherweight keyboard is quite reasonably priced. It's a little smaller than the keyboard on my Toshiba netbook (3.5" rather than 4" high, 9.5" rather than 10" wide). Because I have large hands, my fingers are somewhat scrunched up, but I was able to adapt quickly. The keys are flat-topped, rather than contoured. There are the usual "hot keys" that wake the iPad, go to the Home screen, adjust the volume, do fast forward/back, go to the Search screen, etc. The keyboard goes into sleep mode automatically after 15 minutes of inactivity. A USB charger cable is included, so that the keyboard can be recharged by plugging it in to a computer (or into an AC outlet if you have an adaptor).

This keyboard does not attach to the iPad, a case, or anything else. I like having a free-standing keyboard, because I can place it anywhere that's comfortable for typing, well away from the iPad itself. The keyboard is molded so that it is angled slightly upwards when placed on a flat surface, and it has nice rubberized grippers that keep it from sliding around on my desktop. A black, velvety-textured, drawstring carrying bag is included to protect the keyboard in transit or in storage.

Quality control could be a problem with this keyboard. Mine had a loose area at the lower right corner, which made the keys in that corner rattle. However the fix was easy: pressing down firmly between the keys settled the corner under the clip that was there to hold it in place. I like this keyboard a lot, and will be using it regularly with my iPad. I rate it at 4.5 stars, rounded down to 4 stars because of the quality control issue.

Works for Windows and Mac, so many don't!!!
It has the headphones out. We use this in for our sound system.
Has all the connections we need from sound board to other monitors.
And it has the memory card reader. Havn'e used that yet, but im sure I will.

Now that so much has gone virtual we need to update things for our services.
This has certainly played a huge part in making that happpen.
Very robust exterior too.

Very Satisfied with the performance.
Trust you found this review honest and helpful:-)

I'll be honest, I was expecting this to be another cheap off-brand mouse. I'm pleasantly surprised at how good it is- It looks pretty great, and rather than being covered in shiny fingerprint-magnet plastic like most cheap mice, a majority of the surface is textured (almost like a rubberized plastic). The USB receiver fits inside the body of the mouse for storage, which is great for travelling with it as I do. I've owned other mice that did that before too (an old Logitech), but unlike that old Logitech, this one uses a built-in rechargeable battery. To be honest, my Logitech mouse was great but after a couple of years the battery started making a bad connection inside (corroded contacts were keeping the battery from working), so I'd have to try to clean it off every few uses on the road to keep it working. With this product however, it seems less likely that will become a problem. Also, the ability to plug it in and charge it off the computer directly if it starts to die is a great plus!
My first impression was that the mouse was a little jumpier than I expected, but then I noticed the little button under the scroll wheel and discovered that it was for changing the DPI. Honestly, I'm not sure why they put it in such an easy to use spot, I feel like this isn't something that needs to change very often. But a couple of clicks on that button got me to about the mouse speed I like. I'm actually really happy with this product and although I was shopping around for a replacement Logitech, I think I'll keep this one in my travel bag instead!

Fit is so important with noise cancelling earbuds & for me, these are the best fitting of all the Apple earbuds for my ears. I only wish they had the same audio characteristics as the apple airpod pros so I could use them as a hearing device

perfect for the ipad pro 12.9: stores the ipad pro, the apple pencil, the pro's plug and wires:  great design, good material.  there is ample of room around the ipad, and you can put the apple pencil in the case if you wish, but safer to place it in the zipped pocket.

I had been eying up the [[ASIN:B00B981XQC Ion Audio Job Rocker Bluetooth Portable Jobsite Sound System]] for a while. I was interested in a highly rated Bluetooth speaker because I had been using my [[ASIN:B00MPMK3GW Goal Zero 94014 Rock Out 2 Green Solar Rechargeable Speaker]] with my Google Nexus 7 since last year but was disappointed with it because that was the only device that the speaker would work with. I could not use it successfully with my HP OMEN Gaming Notebook or my boyfriend's iPhone 5 or iPad 3.

I almost purchased the old Job Rocker but did not like that it did not have a USB port. Therefore, when I saw that this recently released Block Rocker IPA76C was on sale at Costco for $119.99 plus tax, I purchased one immediately and I am thrilled that I did.

FEATURES

- This Bluetooth speaker pairs beautifully with my Nexus 7, my boyfriend's iPad 3 & iPhone 5, my BLU Life One 4G LTE SmartPhone that I use only as a portable tablet, and my HP OMEN. All I had to do was press the Bluetooth button on the speaker after I activated Bluetooth on the devices.

- There's an auxiliary cable with stereo 3.5mm (1/8") input that can be used to connect a CD or MP3 player and such to the unit.

- A microphone is supplied with volume control. At first I had trouble getting the MIC to work but once I turned off Bluetooth, it worked okay. It's not a great microphone but good enough.

- There's AM/FM radio with 6 presets and a "rubber" covered antenna.

- This Block Rocker can be paired / linked with another one for even more amplified power.

- There's an On/Off power switch in the back.

- It has wheels, side carrying grips, and a luggage handle making it portable enough to roll it around like luggage.

- There are two 5V 1A USB ports for charging devices. I charged my phone with this port.

- When not connected to a wall outlet via the supplied power plug, the internal battery is rated at 75 plus or minus hours of battery life depending on conditions associated with temperature, age of battery, and volume usage of the speaker.

- The manual also says that it can be left plugged in indefinitely and it will not damage the battery (for those like me, who are not planning on taking this to a job site or garden party).

I'm truly impressed with the sound and functionality of this speaker; so impressed that I am tempted to buy another one. In addition to home use as a theatre producing surround sound experience, this would also be great for outdoor parties and construction sites and such where there is limited or no electricity.

I will update this review if I experience any issues but so far it's WONDERFUL! As I was leaving Costco, one of their employees said I was going to love it as he purchased one the day before. Also, at another Costco today, they were sold out when I went looking for another one.

In the comments section of this review, I attached a link to someone else's great video review on this product. He does a great job of explaining the features of this unit.

Better than I expected for the price.
Fits well. The fins make the difference
Comfortable. Plenty of earphones and tips
Good battery life
Easy to pair
Sound is pretty good. Not too much bass
Microphone work better than expected

Caveats
Takes a long time to connect to phone
Touch controls can be finicky
Case looks nice but is quite large
Does not access Google Assistant for me on Pixel 2. Might work for you though
No ambient sound mode

Easily comparable to the pair of Galaxy Buds that I had prior for a third of the cost. Excellent value

I‚Äôm in an office setting, my earbud case was on my letting which stays in my purse or backpack for work. The top came off, will not stay on and the little latch loosened up and doesn‚Äôt snap. I use my pods maybe three times a month so no actual wear and tear. Disappointed in quality.

Easy to use right out of box.  I'm impressed with the sound and quality.  If you are considering earbuds, try these out and save money!  They are really nice!  Happy with my purchase and it didn't break the bank.

We got this for my mom. She's lost her eye sight and misses reading badly. Audio books are amazing for her and the text-to-speach feature lets her even enjoy her magazines. I swear it's added a couple of years to her life - or at least joy to it.

Love these, but the controls are very sensitive and turns off easily with a light touch.

The sound quality is great and they fit comfortably. No problems with ears getting sore like wire earbuds.

Recommend.

I bought this when my computer was being fixed and I was using my phone for playlist and needed a cheap speaker. Had no idea it could get so loud without distortion. Really a good little speaker for the price. I haven't had it long, so I can't speak to the longevity.
Fit great but there is some lag in the audio

I have a GeForce 750Ti and I broke the HDMI output on it.  I bought this because I found that my video card can provide audio via the DVI output.  This is a good product.  There is one issue that I find when playing video.  There is a hangup/buzzing that occurs periodically and in close succession.  It isn't something most folks would put up with.  I cannot say it is caused by the cable.  It may be my card.  I obviously did something to make the HDMI port stop working and it is reasonable to question if that impacted the card overall.
Great headphones.

UPDATED REVIEW REDUCED TO TWO STARS JUNE 2019

We've had trouble with the remote for three months now. It works sporadically at best and has finally died entirely. This is a major problem because you cannot do important stuff with the sound bar without the original remote control. Such as.... rebooting it. If you change your WiFi network like.... getting a new router, then you cannot simply go to the app and update the connection. You must reboot the entire sound bar via the remote control only. WHICH DOES NOT WORK AT ALL. This design flaw has rendered the entire sound bar none functional because it cannot connect to the new Wi-Fi - going back to our old router isn't an option because it died. So now I have a sound bar that technically is operational, yet cannot be used. Our Bose 500 sound bar was able to be reconfigured for the Wi-Fi swap because it's remote works like a champ - it's also significantly simpler in design than the 700 remote. (I'll end up spending fifty bucks for a new 700 remote and that really aggravates me)

******* Original review before the drama*******

We've had an older Bose Solo 15 Series II TV Sound System in our living room for a couple of years and we've been pretty happy overall. I recently put the Bose 500 version of this sound bar in our master bedroom and was amazed at the difference, so getting this 700 for the living room was a no brainer. I mostly just expected them to connect as a group and have the same sound, but this 700 is better than the 500.

It's a long, narrow, sleek looking unit with glass finishes that makes it almost invisible in front of the Tv. Our Roku fits alongside without drama. The connections are via digital optical cable or the HDMI. Just turn off your TV speakers - not mute, off from the tv settings. You need to use the included wired headset to fully set the speakers for your room's accoustics. I'm using this bar with a 55", 3 years old, Sceptre dumb tv and a Room streaming stick - the connection was immediate and drama free.

You must use the Bose app to get full functionality out of the sound bar. The app let's you connect two or more Bose speakers with the tech and use them all simultaneously as a group to play music or audiobooks etc. The app also starts the set up for the Alexa link and the streaming services like Prime, Tune In, Bluetooth streaming and others. You can also set 6 favorites as one touch launch options.

Alexa works fine through the sound bar, but the response speed is noticably slower than through a regular Echo. I get a glitchy message saying "This unit is unable to perform routines" every time I say "Good morning". Good morning triggers a specific set of actions from Alexa to turn on our bedside lamps, the bathroom lights, turn off our porch lights, give me the weather and then our daily news brief. Despite that glitchy message, every morning, the Bose performs our routine flawlessly. It's weird, but not a big deal really.

The sound quality is excellent and immersive in multiple settings from music to a movie. The app let's you adjust the sound quality and balance with bass, treble and center. You can also set it for dialogue mode to enhance/clarify voices and reduce background noise - this is very handy for the news or a talk show. Take some time to adjust the settings for what your ear really likes and you'll be amazed at the fullness of sound and all the background details.

After two weeks, I'm incredibly pleased with the build quality, looks, sound and full functionality of both the 500 and 700 units. The 700 wins out by a nose over the 500 for us because the sound is bigger, but mostly because the remote control is better. The remote lights up when you lift it and you can find the buttons instantly. I programmed our TV to the Bose remote and it controls the sound bar, channels up and down and power for both the tv and the sound bar. Bottom line is that I am now looking at buying another 700 for the master bedroom and moving the 500 to our guest suite so we'll have the full set.

Aside from cutting out frequently, I absolutely love this gadget! This is so convenient when I want to hear my music on the lower level or upper level of the Tri-level home. I just lift it from the base and I feel as if my computer Itunes is with me wherever I go.

But, as I said, it does have its inconvenient moments.

I stream Pandora from the Iphone. Works very good, but I have not had enough experience. I prefer to play through Itunes library. And the sound is excellent. The sound permeates, and it is not as if you hear it from one corner of the room, so yes, the sound range is very good. The speaker feature is SoundRing technology. That is a very plus feature to me.

Convenience is the key here, as I take it outside for company or just working around the yard. Carry it to the bathroom for all your music while you bathe. The design is catchy, attractive and lightweight.

The speaker controls are on the ring in case you are not near the computer. This was a very easy set-up, and yes, it is convenient, compact and wireless. It operates cord and cordless, and has an aux-in jack where I can plug my MP3 and you can also connect to stereo components.

This is a treat!! .....Rizzo

Loving these headphones. The sound is awesome, no problems with calls or hearing them or myself. Love the bass with these too. They were easy to pair with my phone and tablet and work great. They also fit my ears perfectly and don't make my ears hurt after wearing them for a long time. These have also been super awesome to wear at the gym and haven't been anything but awesome.

These Earbuds are great. They have excellent sound quality. They are pretty noise canceling. They also come with three tips, so you can adjust it to fit your ear perfectly. They have a very long battery life. The only downside is that the box does not charge with a wireless charger. You actually have to plug the box into the wall to charge the ear phones. The logo is rubbing off on me on a bit, likely because of lotion on my hands when I touch them.
I have only ever used this brand of headphones and they last a long time.  Good quality sound.  They do the job for work.
Apparently got these back in mid 2020 for my ATH M50X headphones.  Been using them essentially daily for 2 years.  Still basically good as new. Very pleased.

My desktop tower pc has 4 usb ports in front, all of which are in use. So I thought it would be nice to use this adapter to give me some extra usb connections. Sadly, that won't work too well on my computer. The usb ports are high enough that the adapter dangles in the air because its cord is so short. Our fourteen year old nerd has a laptop which would work much better with that short cord and so the adapter was passed on to him.

One odd thing of note - I have a headphone set up that uses a usb charger. When I plugged that set up into this adapter, the sound through the headphones was noticeably higher and shriller than it was without the adapter. That was strange enough that I listened to the same song with and without being plugged into the adapter and the difference was very real and very noticeable. Why that is, I have no idea. I also don't know if that would affect sound quality when used with a streaming tv stick or other audio devices. Keep an eye on the other reviews as they come in here to see if this is a general issue or not.

Other than the cord being too short and the odd effect on the headphones I use, this does seem like a good product. It really is plug and play and it does provide extra usb ports at a time when we are attaching more and more stuff to our various devices. If I could use this with my desktop pc I would but our fourteen year old should be able to put it to good use with his laptop.

Now, I am not an experienced tech with laptops. I don't need to upgrade. I use it for watching streaming YOUTUBE, and checking my FAV websites. I will use it for Netflix movies, HULU TV shows, Kanopy, and other streaming. I don't need to upgrade, don't need any fancy gizmos and gadgets. There are sufficient ports and that is all I need. I attached a DVD external for music.

The laptop is heavy, and solid. I use it on a table and take it upstairs if I need. I like the feel of the keyboard and placement of the keys.

Two things I miss are: no backlit keyboard and the images (color) are not as bright as some laptops or desktops. The sound is good as I do play a lot of music with an external speaker. So, I enjoy it with enhanced sound.

I like the feel of the laptop, and mostly, it is a large screen! Hubby and I can watch something together if I am not at the tv. Yeah....nice screen!

I have used this for more than a month and I love it. Again, I don't know all the particulars of the techno stuff. I just use it as I see it. ...... a nice laptop!
My granddaughter loves these headphones. The design and sound quality are AMAZING!
