Bought this for my grandsons fiance who has to navigate the campus at night

I purchased this to mount a [[ASIN:B00RPJOQQ8 ViewSonic VA2465smh 24-Inch SuperClear MVA LED Monitor]] to a speaker stand (a very light weight [[ASIN:B006H0DY3C Adam Hall SPS023S Speaker Stand]].

Frankly this mount is far sturdier than the stand on which I mounted it, and is so well constructed and heavy that it's overkill for the monitor. My monitor weighs less than eleven pounds and I am pretty sure this mount could easily support a monitor twice that weight.

Note that you can rotate your monitor 360 degrees, going from landscape to portrait, and every angle in between. However, you cannot tilt the viewing angle. I am not sure why not since the gimbal upon which the VESA mounting plate looks as though it should allow it, but it doesn't,

The clamp that mounts to the pole has a thick, anti-marring insert that will protect poles. It's also one of the reasons why this mount is so heavy - the construction is very heavy duty. All of the tools you need are provided to mount this to a pole and adjust it. The four bolts that come with it are a bit on the short side, although they worked with my monitor (and you need to provide a screwdriver for those.)

I am thoroughly pleased with this mount, especially since I almost purchased an [[ASIN:B001TMCVDW Audio2000'S AST420Y Portable Flat Panel TV/Monitor Stand with Foldable Tripod Legs]], but took a chance on this at the last minute. That decision saved me a lot of money and accomplished exactly what I wanted.

We got this TV 3 days ago. First:,unpacking and setting the TV in place takes 2 people. Be sure to read the directions on the TV box. We laid the "face" of the TV on the dining room table covered with a bedspread to make sure the display would not break-- the directions say to lay the face of the TV down to attach the stand legs. Voila ! In less than 30 minutes the TV was ready to hook up. We are amazed at the quality of the picture. As my husband said, you can see every wrinkle, freckle and pimple on people . Today we were watching a bicycle race, and we both felt like we were dizzy watching the motion ! That never happened watching any TV before. The commands are very simple and displayed on the screen. As others have said, the most obvious setting to change was the picture . For some reason the default is dark... but easily changed thru settings. I am so glad I spend a the extra money to get the RU8000 , instead of the RU7100. Reviews convinced me to spend the extra money. Our old tv was 6 yrs old - light years in electronic time.
BTW. Firestick TV , Roku , Cable TV and new wireless headphones are attached. You won't be sorry if you buy this TV

You can read other reviews to hear complaints about Windows 8.

This is an excellent piece of hardware for the price. Without any upgrades, desktop graphics in Ubuntu are very snappy; I expected to have to install a separate video card, but see no need to. The RAM is upgradeable to 16gb by adding two 4g simms (there are 4 slots; 2 are filled).

The build itself is reasonable. For example: There is no case fan, but the case is designed for one so it would be easy to add. But, I see no need---the machine runs very cool (<35C cpu temp at low cpu usage).

There is one spare 5.25" bay (e.g. 2nd DVD) and one spare 3.5" bay (e.g. 2nd internal HD). There is adequate spacing for air flow around the 3.5" bays. There is no mount for a front case fan, but I think the 3.5" bay spacing is sufficient for low-to-moderate usage.

This is an energy efficient machine. I plan to keep it running 24/7 and am happy to see that it consumes 45-50 watts when idle-ish in Ubuntu (measured using a kill-a-watt).

I was confused by the location of the DVD eject button: it's on the right side of the DVD bay.

To enter the BIOS, press the DEL key repeatedly during startup. If that doesn't work at first, try "restart" from Windows. Try using a PS2 keyboard (purple circular connector).

The machine uses UEFI. UEFI is is common on new machines, but was uncommon a few years ago and is likely a reason why installing a different operating system is not as straightforward as one would expect. Note that along with UEFI comes a different hard disk partition scheme: GPT (instead of the older MBR). I had trouble installing Ubuntu, but was eventually successful. Should be easier now since I helped isolate a bug in the boot-repair package.

Reinstall tips:

* From the BIOS, try disabling SecureBoot and/or FastBoot.
* If installing Ubuntu, start with the Ubuntu UEFI community documentation (not the older UEFIBooting page)
* If nothing else works, try enabling CSM (Compatibility Support Module), which should allow you to boot without UEFI. Note that you'll need to revert your disk to using MBR---I had mixed success with CSM.

The Motherboard is Acer AAHD3-VC. The BIOS is American Megatrends Aptio. I found that Tiger Direct's "Specifications" page had more useful details about this machine.

I didn‚Äôt have high expectations for these headphones considering the price, but I was pleasantly surprised that the audio quality was pretty good and they are comfortable in the ear. If you lose them, there are four more to choose from!

What I wanted was something I could use to listen to tv/movies/music/audiobooks/NPR while doing other work on my desktop computer. The Fire Tablet fits the bill perfectly. The video is crisp and clear. The screen size works nicely for an old guy who's had cataract surgery and wears bifocals. Even the closed captioning I need these days is easily readable on this screen. The speakers are not master quality but are more than adequate for this non-audiophile. This is my first time using Alexa and I love how easy she makes it to get the news and weather before shifting back to Netflix. The whole thing integrates nicely with my Prime account. So far I've just begun to scratch the surface of the options available through Amazon. I wouldn't try to use this tablet to do any heavy computing. That's why I have a high-powered desktop. For the entertainment niche I wanted to fill though, this tablet fits perfectly.

There are some glitches. At times Alexa will freeze up for no discernible reason. Netflix can stutter at times too. This on a new tablet with only minimal apps, used one or two at a time so I shouldn't be overloading it's capabilities. For someone new to Fire Tablets and Alexa, there is a bit of a learning curve. It's not too onerous though. In a short time I expect to be using this tablet familiarly. Every computer I've ever used has had occasional glitches and there is always a learning curve on a new device. So far I haven't come across any deal-breakers and I can whole-heartedly say I love my new tablet.

I am not developed in the intricacies of depth and pitch and all that other stuff so I cannot comment on the quality of the sound.  The music sounds good to me through these headphones.  I like the fact that it folds up and comes with its own carrying case, this is the reason why I purchased these.  The case is a soft pull string bag, not a hard case.  Ear buds irritate the inside of my ear so I needed these type and I like them.  It doesn't squeeze my head, they are comfortable over my ears.  There is a note on the instructions that you are supposed to use this with smartphones and that there is no guarantee they will work on digital music players, and that the mic may not work on "unsupported" devices.  I took a photo of the instructions.  I didn't try the mic myself yet, but I only got this to listen to music and watch movies on long airplane flights.

There are lots of good earbuds on the market. What sets different brands apart are features. This one has a built-in microphone, true ANC, and a good battery life. The sound quality is crisp and clear. I wish there were more color options, but that's a minor issue. I highly recommend this product.

Thanks so much for taking the time to read this review. I hope the information that I've provided helps make your decision a little easier.

I received this as a free review sample nearly a year ago and have been using it at least twenty times a month. I use it for carrying microphones, adapters and miscellaneous electronics I use when performing as a musician. For protection this is ideal, and the inside and outside zippered pouches make this even more versatile.

It does an excellent job of protecting the delicate microphones and adapters that I store in it. I am not using the dividers as vertical separators the way they were designed. Instead, I lay them on top of the mics, and then store the cables on top. That arrangement is perfect, and the bag and insert are relatively light and sturdy.

Close to a year of constant use is testimony to just how sturdy this bag is, especially considering the times it have been accidentally stepped upon. Since the canvas part is so sturdy I am guessing that the insert will probably last even longer. One of the reasons is the overall construction, though lightweight, is of the highest quality. I am betting that if this were used for its intended purpose of protecting a DLSR or other photo equipment it would do as great a job as it does protecting my mics and other items.
perfect for if your phone case is too thick and your headphone cant connect

I bought this for my son who loves to listen to audio books on the bus in the morning.  The sound quality is great and it is very easy to connect to the Bluetooth.  The battery life is good and the charging time isn't long.  It's also a very nice hat and the fabric is super soft and warm.

Love the added benefits of this soundbar. The sound is wonderful. Especially watch movies. I like the looks of it and how expensive it looks. I love that I purchased this along with the Samsung Smart TV

I had a Galaxy S4 for several years. It was suitable and did the job. . . mostly. I was having some battery issues and my phone wouldn't update past Android 4.4. I was running into apps that needed a newer version of Android. I could have bought something cheap but I decided to treat myself and found the blue Galaxy S9 on sale for a decent price. I have to say I'm loving this phone.
The 5.8" Quad HD+ Super AMOLED screen is GLORIOUS! I run this is high performance mode with the brightness cranked up. Games, movies, even YouTube and TikTok videos look amazing. The curved edge I worried might be distracting but honestly I only notice in a couple games.
Sound is really good for a cell phone it has stereo speakers. Volume is more than enough.
Performance from the Octa-Core processor and 4GB of ram have not struggled to run anything I've thrown at it.
The camera is great. Maybe struggling a little in very bright light with a light colored subject. Otherwise, night mode gives great low light results. Video shooting is very nice with great slow motion results and a nearly unique super slow-motion recording mode at a mind boggling 960 frames per second is a lot of fun to mess around with.
Battery life is good, I got most of a day is high performance mode and could easily extend it by cutting things back to save battery.
The fingerprint sensor is quick to unlock and easy to use. A trick I found online to improve performance of the fingerprint sensor is to register the same finger more than once. It really works like a charm.
The look is sleek and sophisticated though I'm protecting that glass body with a nice Otterbox Symmetry case. The only real minor negative to the whole thing is this weighs more and is larger than my S4, a little hard on my hands and pocket but really, it's worth it.
I can't express how happy I am with this phone. I'm even buying props and things to use in creative videos and photo shoots.

I found myself in the market to replace my Belkin IPOD armband (the Velcro began separating from armband). I knew that it would probably be cheaper to just buy another one, than to try and repair it. Afterall, it didn't have to be especially cute, but practical and functional. Since I am planning a family (beach) vacation for the summer, I PLAN to start working out (my motivation being a vision of me in a bathing suit). But I ALSO know that I need something else to motivate and inspire me....so listening to music or an audiobook will definitely do the trick. The Griffin Streamline appears to be perfect for my 3rd generation Nano. Believe it or not, I wasn't wrong or disappointed. The Streamline is reasonably priced, and definitely does the job. It even looks a lot like my first one (Belkin), with the exception that the portion that surrounds the face of the IPOD is framed by hard plastic. This is the only thing that I would warn the consumer about....over time, I could see the hard plastic that surrounds the face of the IPOD cracking. Anyway, I haven't had any trouble selecting or manipulating the IPOD. The only drawback is the fact that you have to turn the Nano upside down so that you can access the earbuds and charger. The Nano fits snuggly in the case and doesn't move. The armband is adjustable and comfortable. And because I don't really sweat, I don't think that I will have to worry about the condensation collecting, around or behind it. The pack is slightly padded and appears to offer just the right amount of protection. With the exception of having to flip the device upside down so that you can access the cords, for the price and for what I intend to do with this product, it is absolutely perfect.

I've been testing this speaker system with my 10" Samsung Galaxy Tab2 tablet which had no problems connecting to the speakers with and without the app from the Android store.

Appearance:
Their product description calls this 'fun, trendy and modern'. But to be honest this looks, to me, like an appliance that fell out of my grandmother's 1950's black, white and chrome art-deco kitchen. It's not unpleasant looking but I wouldn't call it modern. When I saw images of the system online I had hopes that the neon green ring around the face would light up. Sadly it doesn't. The handle is also fixed in place and doesn't retract or collapse into the body. It would have been a nice idea so you could stack or store this more easily.

Sound:
It doesn't sound bad. Especially for being just two 15 watt wide range speakers in a ported (holes to help the bass sound better) enclosure. The bass is a little flat and the high end sounds a little... hollow but it is a lot better than the speakers built into my tablet. I've tried a variety of music; jazz, pop, classical, rock, punk and everything sounded quite good. I found I had to use both the tablet's volume control as well as the speaker systems volume controls to get real volume out of the system. They operate independently of each other.

Drawbacks:
I don't normally comment on price with items received from the Vine program but at the time I'm writing this review Amazon is currently selling this item for over two hundred dollars. Maybe the Bluetooth equipment is expensive but to me that's a LOT for just two speakers in a box. I didn't pay that much for my four speaker bookshelf system or the subwoofer equipped speaker system connected to my desktop PC. Both of which have far superior sound quality.

The battery indicator light only seems to light up when the system is charging. I charged this a week ago and used it for several hours at a time but I have no idea how much charge is left in the battery.

The biggest problem I had with this speaker system was when doing anything other than playing music. I thought it would be fun to add big sound to the games I enjoy on my tablet but there's a distinct lag between doing anything and when the speaker plays the sound. I noticed it most of all in my favorite billiards simulator. You would strike a ball...and then hear it happen, even system sounds such as keyboard typing noises, a 'blip' when selecting things played a noticeable time after they happened.

The App:
I won't say much about the app here. It's completely unnecessary to operate this system with your Android device. It's just poor quality programming that appears to have been slapped together at the last minute. It also doesn't match the documentation and features such as Bass Boost which are in the instructions but don't exist in the app.

Speaking of the documentation. I opened the box and found a large booklet and for one, brief, moment I thought this item was fully documented in depth and detail... then I opened the instructions and found there's twelve pages of English instructions which are poorly written and lacking in detail. The rest of the book is comprised of numerous other languages each getting their own few pages. Ah well. Turn it on, turn it up. Enjoy the music.

Excellent for sleep, great sound quality, easy to maintain, and works great. Easy to remove speakers and reciever,  Hand wash in baby shampoo, rinse, air dry, place speakers and pieces back in it is great for every day use.

This little box is solid!  It comes with a nice carrying case and was easy to setup.  As for sound, I have other speaker devices that provide a bit better sound quality.  The bass isn't very good, but it does get pretty loud for it's size.  The setup was easy and pairing was easy.  Using it for calls was easy too.  I want to use it a bit more, then I will do a follow-up review.

I have an mp3 player that has only a USB-C port. It came with USB-C headphones as well as a 3.5mm adapter for regular headphones that we promptly lost.

I really wanted this to replace those, however I tried with several pairs of headphones and NONE of them had sound using this adapter. It detected that headphones were connected, but no sound came out. Very disappointed.
For $10 at a close out store they work surprisingly well. Construction is good and there is ample cording. Rated at 3W I tested them out on music videos and they are fine.
Great present idea for camping etc. good sound quality and worth having around to just listen to music
Decent headphones. Sound quality is decent but not as durable as it appears. The actual ear piece falls off the whole earphone. Disappointed but they were good while they lasted.

This alarm clock is okay the numbers are not that large on the wall, the time on the unit itself is nice and bright. It‚Äôs very easy to set the time, alarms, and date, the radio isn‚Äôt that great very cheap sounding speaker. It seems like it will last and the presentation of it is nice looking.

I would be lost without my Kindle. I love it, absolutely love it. I was never much of a reader and got the kindle for other reasons like games and facebook and music or to check email maybe order something from Amazon but then I listened to my first audible book on it and it became my best friend and constant companion. But get this, I found a series of books by Christie Rich and then another by Stacey Marie Brown and they weren't available on audio - OMGosh, I was going to have to READ a book. I did. And now I love reading too. Between the two authors I have read 11 books and just started my 12th. Thanks to my Kindle, I am a reader - I am a slow reader but nonetheless a reader.

The ONLY drawback is that there can be a glare if you are out in the sun. I to believe they have glare resistant covers though and I will be looking into those. But seriously, that is the ONLY draw back. I love my Kindle!!

Got this speaker (Logitech USB Laptop Speaker Z305) for my Mac to amp up the sound during movies ... and just love it.  It attaches super easily, has great sound, easy-access on/off, and volume controls on the speaker which are readily accessible while it's on the pc.  Highly recommend.  Please note that I purchased this in 2011 when the price was $39.99 (just noticed Dec 29, 2012 price is now over $100!)

Just got done playing my starwars records and this player is awesome!!! Less than a minute to set up and the speakers get movie theater loud. If you are expecting hard pounding rattle the windows bass this wont deliver. This unit gives a solid across the board sound quality though. I was really impressed by this unit. Make sure you tighten down antishock screw. Owners manual will tell you where it is... Very important.
These wireless earbuds are amazing !! Very good sound quality and long lasting battery !! Definitely recommend them to anyone .

It has a good sound for a speaker so small. Must be sure it is charged or is charging when you are using blue tooth to connect. Does not come with charger but can use any android phone charger. Unfortunately, this died within 3 months time. so I can no longer recommend this product.

[[VIDEOID:1414bb37bbf9d7082c9e2b7784fbb922]] It‚Äôs green! Very green! Feels like a green sheet.

It comes with the clips you‚Äôd need to hang it from a stand.

This background will let computer programs put different backgrounds behind you , digitally. You could have a picture of the ocean behind you for example.

Overall it‚Äôs nice. Feels soft. Looks sturdy

Good product while it lasted. Used with my iPhone for long conference calls and training webinars. Liked the double earphone design and it proved to be very comfortable during extended wear. Unfortunately the microphone stopped working and others said I sounded distant or broken up. If it used more substantial wiring and connections, this would likely get four or five stars.

When I received my new laptop, I was initially dismayed to see how few USB ports it had. Not only do I like to use a mouse rather than the track pad, I also like to use a cooling tray when I'm playing games on the laptop. This USB hub is perfect for me. I'm able to plug in the bluetooth dongle for my mouse, and the cooling tray cord. It's nice and compact, fits easily in my laptop bag.

If you are appalled by the prices of HDMI cables in the brick & mortar stores, look no further than here.  These Mediabridge cables are well made and very affordable at a fraction of the cost of the HDMI cables available in stores.  I have had no problems with these.  The picture & audio quality I get are first rate.
Great subwoofer! Provides plenty of bass. Easy to setup.

I compared this cable with the optical cable I got with a SoundBlaster sound card, that I've been using to connect a Chromecast Audio to an external DAC, which pipes the sound into a stereo amp. I played a Scarlatti sonata with this cable and the other cable, and can detect no difference with my ears. (I don't claim this is a lab test, but with optical fiber at these short lengths and this limited frequency range, there really ought to be no measurable difference that would matter to human ears.)

So I'd say these cables are just fine, and they're sufficiently well made that I'd have no qualms about using them. I have to say though that I disliked the thick wrapping they gave this cable, as if the fiber were extra thick (that's a joke), or needed extra protection (it shouldn't need this much). And this heavy braided wrapping makes the cable heavier and less flexible (as well as uglier!), so I'm taking off a point for it, since I can find other such cables that are superior.
These are great.  Mine have been through the washer AND dryer, twice.  Still work great.  Also work well for phone calls.  I didn't even realize they had a microphone until today.
I am happy with the replacement aux cable that came in I broke the ones that came with the headphones .

They are simple and inexpensive earbuds that work as designed. Sound is crisp and clear. I especially like the small clip to secure the headphone wire to my shirt collar. That clip is my favorite feature of these headphones, I wish my others had this clip as well, but I can switch it to my other headphones, a nice touch. This is a good set to have for backup, or for when you don't want to spend much.

In full disclosure, I must admit that I miss my Bose Bluetooth speaker. Their acoustics are impeccable. The "Tribit XSound Go Bluetooth Speakers" only cost a fraction of my Bose speaker. I first purchased the "DOSS Touch Wireless Bluetooth" which is in the same price range; I returned that product because it lacked bass and was unimpressive overall. The Tribit, however, has plenty of bass for such a small speaker. Ironically, the problem that I have is the treble! I think it is an inherent problem with smaller speakers and not this particular device. I have installed an equalizer on my computer which mitigates some of the problems and makes the speaker sound very acceptable.

The pros:
‚Ä¢ The speaker is loud! It is perfect for a jam session in your bedroom. I'm not sure it is suitable for large or multi rooms.
‚Ä¢ The quality is good, and the speaker looks like a million bucks.
‚Ä¢ It has an excellent microphone that works well with phone calls and even to interact with Siri or Cortana.
‚Ä¢ The Play button allows one to answer, reject or end a call. It also can play or pause a song. Finally, it allows you to skip a music track forward or backward.

The cons:
‚Ä¢ While the bass is fairly impressive, the treble is slightly overriding.
‚Ä¢ The battery does not nearly last for 24 hours if you like to blast music as I do
‚Ä¢ The speaker can only be paired to one device at a time. If you are listening to music on the computer and the phone tries to connect, the speaker will sometimes disconnect from all devices. The speaker does have an av input one could connect to the computer but obviously, the speaker would no longer be completely portable. This could be a deal breaker for many.

After comparing this speaker with others in its price range, I realize that this speaker has such poor sound quality that I could never recommend it to anyone.

These work very well for taking calls int he computer or doing a virtual meeting.  They are faily comfortable though they could use more and better padding.  Sound quality is good, and the microphone works well.

[[VIDEOID:41e01469e050a0b681a41ebd6f97ac6f]] This amp is incredible!!! Quality sound with a 10 hour battery life! Great bass to for two five inch speakers! I don‚Äôt know of any amp in this price range with this quality and this many usable features. Seriously, how did they do it? This amp is magical and musical. I am so glad I tried it! I would gladly compare it to the big name amps, but my review would get banned! I can just encourage you to try it. I‚Äôm sure you will love it as much as I do!

UPDATE (2/21/19): So far, my clock is working well. I did buy a second clock, and succeeded in pairing it with my 1st Gen Echo Show. If you make a pairing mistake, you can press the clock's pairing button 5 times to unpair the clock and start over. Oddly, when the Show was correctly paired, the light turned solid orange. The Echo Show is hard to pair because it isn't completely integrated with the Alexa app when it comes to setting up a wall clock. However, for me, having two clocks, with visual timer displays paired to different Echo devices, was worth all the Setup hassles.

This ECHO WALL CLOCK does two things that I really want. First, it keeps accurate time by using an Internet connection (through an Echo device) instead of a radio signal (which can malfunction in bad weather or at Daylight Savings Time changes). Second, it gives a bright visual display of the time remaining on all the timers currently set with my first-generation Echo. (Yes, it simultaneously displays the time left on multiple timers.)

If my clock continues to work without requiring frequent Bluetooth re-pairing (as other reviewers have reported), I will order a second clock to pair with my Echo Show. The visual time-left display is very useful when I‚Äôm timing exercises or post-exercise ice treatments.

The instructions warn you NOT to try to move the clock hands. (Other reviewers warn that touching the hands will break the clock, or cause it to tell slightly inaccurate time forever if you succeed in replacing the hands.) It‚Äôs too bad that the clock does NOT have a plastic cover over the face--dusting it is going to be a problem. I put mine on a wall, to protect it as much as possible from dust, and from accidentally being knocked over.

SETUP PROBLEMS: Out of the box, the clock paired effortlessly with my Echo Show (using the option of asking the Show to set up the clock). However, I ran into a lot of difficulty when I tried to pair it with a second device (a first-generation Echo). The instructions do NOT make it clear that the clock PAIRS WITH ONLY ONE ECHO DEVICE.

Probably because I failed to start the second Setup attempt by using the Alexa app to un-pair the clock from the Show, the second attempt failed. It ended with a green light that has no defined meaning in the paper or online setup instructions. Worse, the clock no longer worked with the Show. Still worse, the clock did NOT appear as a device in the Alexa app; and the app did NOT display the clock as a Connected or Bluetooth device under the Show settings.

Eventually I found the clock under the settings for the Echo (subject of my second, failed Setup attempt). I was able to unpair it, delete it, and start Setup again. At long last, the clock paired with the Echo, and began working again (with the first-generation Echo).

However, I failed in all attempts to use the Show to set up the clock again. Those attempts always concluded with a red error light or with that mysterious green light. At some point, I had to remove the batteries and replace them so that the pairing button on the clock would work. Naturally I now dread having to pair the clock again with any Echo device, should the Bluetooth connection malfunction.

SUMMARY: The concept of the Wall Clock is great. I love my clock now, and really do intend to buy a second one, if the clock that I now have continues to work normally. However, I hope that later generations of the Echo Wall Clock will have a covered clock face, and that later versions of the Setup software will have much better integration with the Alexa app.

Pros: Cheap price, handles 4 inputs (would love to see more). One of the [very few inexpensive options] to extract and output a pure digital audio signal (coaxial) rather than the lossier and worse standard- optical. Basically does what it is supposed to do, which is rare these days. Remote control functionality works fine.

Cons: Cheap. Input/output ports are made out of cheap stuff. Need to tweak a little to get the most out of it. Spacing is tight like a manhattan studio. The unit is lightweight and small so it shifts around when you have big cables. Sometimes it gets lost and doesn't do what it is supposed to do- switch. In which case you just have to restart, but it doesn't happen very often. Check video connection if there is an issue as well, which may prevent from switching.

Putting it together: All that being said, its great at this price doing what it is supposed to do, which is hard to say these days with all the ill manufactured things these days. There is nothing out there that will do what it does- 4 x switch PLUS outputting audio via digital coax. At this price point its great for people who dont really care about maximizing the quality of their output. For those who do, like me, not the best but its the only option at this point. Id be more than glad to pay a bit more for a unit with quality input/output ports with a more substantial case. Seems manufacturers these days think all people want are cheap products. There are enough people out there who would pay a bit more for a more quality product. They should consider a two tier product lineup- and not just for the functions. Since there is room for improvement, it gets 4 stars. Make some changes- Ill buy it, and assuming it works, it gets 5 stars.

UPDATE: down to 3 stars. Right at the 30 day mark, the one feature that differentiated this product from others- coax output, stopped working. I did get it replaced and it works. This is somewhat expected, given the quality of material used and the price paid for something like this. Another 30 days and this gets thrown out with the trash for good. At least Amazon has a great policy to protect against something like this. So its worth a shot if you need these features.

UPDATE 2: 2nd time it malfunctioned within a month. Video stopped outputting. When it works, its fine. They really need to use more quality parts in this to make it last. Raise the price a few bucks if necessary. The parts themselves dont cost much. Too much penny pinching. This is getting ridiculous.

UPDATE 3: really save yourself the hassle, frustration and money. Get a pro hdmi switcher. It costs more BUT the output quality and just as important, build quality, is much better. After switching over to a pro, I havent had a hardware issue in 3 months.

I loved these. They fit in without falling out. They have great sound. I purchased a $40 pair of headphones recently and they were awful compared to these. I will admit I am not a person who makes my living with music or is interested in much more than listening to music and books on my computer, iPod and iPad but these work and deliver quality sound. I love them more than any other headphone/earbuds I have ever had

I'm not an ear bud fan. Neither are my kids, who often find them hard to keep in their ears at all. Sadly, its hard to find over-the-ear style headphones that aren't professional level expensive or Bluetooth these days. Sometimes you just want a standard set of 'phones for using on the plane or when connecting your set to different devices (don't get me started on pairing my bluetooth headphones with 4 different devices... it always just wants to pair with whatever I used last).
This is a fantastic budget friendly over-the-ear style set. They sound good, they are comfortable especially for younger ears, and they fold up to carry in a bag. The cable is also removable, which is nice. It comes with a cable that offers an inline mic with a TRRS plug on the end for use with a phone, but you can just as well swap that out for a standard 3.5mm end-to-end aux cable, making this truly a versatile pair of headphones for whatever you intend to use it with.
Giving it 4 stars because honestly, they aren't the most amazing sounding headphones and they don't have much noise isolation, but they sound decent enough to listen to music and movies and for the price it's hard to beat!

I thought these were Bluetooth, but they came with wires and need to be wired somehow. I thought they would be just Bluetooth and connect to my tv. But you need to wire these and there were no instructions with it.
Best headband speakers replacement, period.

I really just chose this speaker because it's so cute. It's shaped like a mini retro purse. The surprise is the sound quality is actually good. I wouldn't use this for anything but personal use, though. It's ideal if you like to listen to music in your closet or bathroom. It makes a great gift for little girls. I highly recommend it.

Thanks so much for taking the time to read this review. I hope the information that I've provided helps make your decision a little easier.

I selected this mouse as much for the cool factor as for the function. I needed a wireless mouse to use with a laptop and this one looked like a good fit. So far I have no complaints, but I do offer one word of caution with it.

The most obvious thing about this mouse is the strange appearance. It doesn't resemble any other mouse I have used and at first it looks like it might be uncomfortable on the hands. On the contrary, though, it is quite comfortable and I have had no issues with it being too small for my hands even though it is a typical-sized mouse.

I used with with my Windows 10 system and it works just fine. I have not tested it against my Linux system though I have no reason to believe it won't work - every other wireless mouse I have tried has worked without any trouble at all so I expect this one to be no different. If it proves otherwise I will return here and update.

I ran into an immediate issue with this mouse - I could not find the receiver and as such I was unable to get it to connect to the system. It does not have any Bluetooth capability so that is not an option. As it turns out, the receiver was packaged in the box but was in a small plastic baggie separate from the mouse and when the box was opened to remove the mouse the receiver fell out, unnoticed. I thought I had been sent a mouse without the receiver until I finally realized what had happened and located the receiver. So, use some caution when taking this mouse out of the box.

Overall, I am pleased with this mouse. It works as expected and is more comfortable than it looks.

Works well.

Pros:
Paired easily with iPhone 6
Cables are pretty long. Comes with an extender.
Nice USB out for charging 2 amp
Nice magnet mount in case you want to put it in the glove box.
No BT connection issues.

Cons:
No FM connection, you will need an auxiliary input
You have to push the power button every time. There might be a setting to change this but I haven't found it.

I got these to replace another pair of earbuds that lasted awhile but eventually gave out. I didn‚Äôt expect much from the price. These were more expensive than those so I thought it was going to be nice. No, these crapped out after three months of use. The battery life is awful. The sound quality went horrible. Do not buy these if they become available again. All the money I‚Äôm wasting on these cheap earbuds I might as well get Apple ones!

i love my Echo Dot but i am still learning but right out of the box she can do all the basic things you want. the possibilities are endless and there are more things added all the time for the Echo dot. i have it hooked up to my JBL Extreme Bluetooth speaker and it is wonderful. i know the time is coming that almost everyone will have one because it is definitely the future.
These along with the stereo signal splitter made hooking up my Bose revolve speakers a snap.

StarTech USB S-Video and Composite Audio Capture Cable is a nifty little device that allows you to capture video and audio on your computer from other devices, like dvd players. This comes with all the equipment you need, including the software to convert the captured video to mpeg 1, mpeg 2 or mpeg 4 encoding.

For my uses, these are great. They were very well packaged and secure for shipping. The box is very nice and sturdy, lined with foam. I need to hear the environment around me. This has been an issue with previous earbuds. Commercials between videos or songs can get so loud! That is the deal-breaker for me, as it's a safety issue. These do not get too loud, even on the loudest setting, so I am able to remain safe. I don't have an issue hearing the sounds coming from the buds, but I'm not in high-traffic outdoor areas regularly either. My ear canals are unusually small for an adult. I was afraid these may be too-big, but they are snug. Any bigger and it may have been an issue. I used the smaller of the plastic tips. Over the ear designs are the only ones that have ever worked for me. I did look at some other models in the past, but I found them a bit more expensive than I felt justified to spend unknowing how well they may work for me. However, knowing how well these work, I find them to be a really great value and would have purchased them before if I had known how well they worked. It was only by chance they were up for review and I had been seeking a replacement on my old pair that I've been using for the past few years.

The Bluetooth is nice. I have a simple cell phone. It only took asking my phone to connect to work. It was the easiest that I have ever had with connecting anything Bluetooth to my phone. I liked this as I'm not the most savvy at using Bluetooth electronics. If I can do it, anyone can.

I'm not great at using the buttons as they are really sensors on the flat-side of the body on the earbuds. I'm getting used to it but they are touch sensitive and there is a correct spot and amount of pressure that works best. I'm still getting a feel for it and there is a slight delay, so it's very easy to double-tap. The included booklet has been helpful to learn to use these straight out of the package.

Sometimes I get down on the floor at the gym to use the foam rollers and stretches, other times I'm using them in the car to take calls. I've tried them at work as well. Every scenario has worked well for me. I really do wish I've had these before. Sometimes while getting my breaks at work, I would want to listen to things from my phone, but didn't want to risk disturbing my co-workers with some of the news and hobby related videos I enjoy. I asked a few co-workers if they could hear my earbud noise, they could not.

The case is very easy to use as well and fits easily into my pockets. I'm a lady, so my pockets are not always very generously sized. It charges very quickly, and I've not found myself running out of charge. I cannot speak on the long-term durability for this as they are new. If/when I experience any issues with the charge, I will be sure to post an update.

In summary, these would be better for users that need to hear their surroundings for safety. For those that want extreme high volume, they may not be as happy. They stay on my ears securely and the case works very well. I'm pleasantly surprised how well I like these and hope that they are durable since they are working so well for me.

Thanks for reading my review. I hope you found it helpful.

These wireless headphones are great! I was afraid they were going to fall out of my ear but they haven't! I've been on mile long walks and runs and they've never fallen out or lost connection. Just for the sound quality, it's well worth the price. Thr charging case is magnetic and quickly charges the headsets. I would definitely buy these again!

I purchased this unit to use instead of my Sony tv's built in speaker, and it is amazing. Sound is crystal clear. Plus, I can now use it for my ipod, mobile phone, zoom meetings, etc....
The set up is very easy. You can use physical wires, or the bluetooth connection. This soundbar, just after using for a little while of use, has been truly phenomenal. Also great for parties, or just listening to spotify / itunes music or movies. I can also watch movies on my phone and still get a full loud cinema sound. This device is very sleek, attractive and has a streamlined design. The only complaint I have is the sound volume control. It doesnt remember my last setting, so I have to adjust when turned on. Overall, This is an excellent product that I highly recommend to my friends if they needed one.

Wireless headphones are great, but I have a love/hate relationship with using Bluetooth on a PC. When using the mic with headset profile for calls, the audio gets routed totally differently than regular stereo sound (A2DP), which gets confusing if multitasking and playing sound while also using the mic. And then there's the delay/lag etc that usually comes along with Bluetooth from a Windows desktop. But that's why I love the USB dongle here!
Plug the little USB bit in, and it detects the headphones like an alternate sound card, full blown crystal clear stereo audio, even if using the mic! And the mic can be extended or retracted, something I love since I lost the removable mic on my old headphones.
But, if I want to use it with my phone or tablet, I can revert to standard Bluetooth and connect that way on my Android devices. The price is a little bit steep, but the quality is there, this is a well designed and well made product that works as intended so far. I'm impressed.

Husband is very happy with this inexpensive amplifier receiver. He loves the blue tooth so he can hook up his phone or tablet for music. He also has it hooked up with his Yamaha Clavinova electronic piano. It was a nice touch to add the speaker wire for easy hook up. Remote works well and the face has a very well lit up so you can read the stations and things,

This is a great little water proof speaker. It is super easy to use and paired within seconds. It has a suction cup holder to attach to the tiles and also a carabiner that can hook onto anything really. You can control your music that you are connected to easily from it and it is pretty much intuitive to use.

The sound quality is nice and it gets pretty loud all considering, not blasting loud but loud enough for your bathroom. The battery has a nice life too so no complaints there. All in all very happy with this.

Fantastic!!! We bought cheaper noise cancelling headphones before, but I guess you get what you pay for. Those are so much better and the listening quality during our last flight was great. I will buy a second one when they are back on sale.

This case is exactly what I wanted: extremely durable shock-absorbing (read: drop-proof) protection without screen protection. Let me qualify that statement: I did *not* want screen protection. I love the pearl eink display on my graphite Kindle Keyboard, and it now has a big brother. I do not want a screen cover, as this would greatly reduce the screen's otherwise remarkable clarity, adding unwanted elements such as bubbles, surface scratches, and glare to the mix--no thank you. There is a reason I disliked reading on the iPad so much I gave it back (very reflective!). In fact, this OtterBox defender case came with a stick-on screen protector--no way. It would ruin that big, glorious pearl eink display.

A screen cover serves no purpose once you remove the device from your backpack/messenger/tote/briefcase for use. Assuming you transport your Kindle device safely in an appropriate sleeve (you put your other expensive electronic equipment--your laptop/tablet in one; your Kindle deserves the same amount of respect), the screen protector is completely unnecessary--the sleeve protects the screen during travel. THAT is when the screen needs protecting--when you are not using it, from the other goodies in your messenger bag/backpack (keys, pens, earbuds, and anything else rattling around in there). Yes, that's right--I'm talking about a Kindle in an Otterbox Inside a sleeve inside your briefcase. ...Inception-level protection. You got it. Better safe than sorry, right? What if they once again stop producing our beloved Kindle DX and something happens to yours? I do not want to have to replace my DX--especially if it has to be with a Fire device (5% the battery life, reflective, heavy, expensive--no thanks!). When you are holding your Kindle in your hand, reading, a screen cover only detracts from the experience.

What you see in my pictures is exactly what you get: a beefy, black rubber (not silicone--too easily torn; rubber is much stronger) form-fitting sleeve with an equally form-fitting outer plastic shell. Science geeks like me understand how this works, and just in case you are not one, here is the idea: if you drop your device onto the floor, the outer shell absorbs some of the impact energy generated by the device hitting the floor. It then disburses the remaining energy of the impact broadly into the rubber inner lining. The rubber lining then in turn disburses the now greatly-reduced impact energy into the device. In other words, by the time the force of the impact is filtered through two layers of protection, the second of which is very absorbent and resilient (rubber) the device inside absorbs little if anything of the original impact.

I feel very good about having my Kindle DX in an Otterbox Commuter. If I ever had one of those incredibly poorly-designed (read: seriously fragile) apple devices, such as an iPad or iPhone (which I do not, and am not ever likely to), it too would live in an OtterBox Commuter case. OtterBox = the best protection a device can get. I paid $18 including shipping for this. A great price, and worth much more in terms of peace of mind.

This device is a WiFi repeater. That means that it picks up your existing WiFi signal and rebroadcasts it to extend the reach of your network.

I got this (and the [[ASIN:B004WPUHXO Amped Wireless High Power Outdoor 14dBi Directional WiFi Antenna Kit (AD14EX)]]) to extend my wireless network to my workshop, at the back of the yard, about 250 feet from the house. This is far enough away that I don't get even the smallest amount of the WiFi signal from the house. I wanted to watch TV while I work, and I also needed to be able to use a phone there. I could run Cat-5e wiring underground, but that would require digging a trench across the yard, and also running the Ethernet cable from the router inside the house to a demarcation point at the exterior of the house, which would be quite a bit of work. Using this repeater and antenna--two pairs of them, actually, the pair in the house and the other pair in the workshop--I'm able to get a very strong and fast network link in the workshop.

It's incredibly easy to set up. The antenna is designed to be mounted outdoors, and they recommend using 25 feet of [[ASIN:B004WW5WAA Amped Wireless Premium Outdoor 25ft Antenna Extension Cable (APC25EX)]] to connect the antenna to the Smart Repeater. Instead, I connected the Smart Repeater directly to the antenna with the short cable that comes with the antenna, and both are sitting in a closet at the edge of the house. In the workshop, I have the Smart Repeater and antenna sitting on a shelf above my desk. I would probably get an even better signal if I mounted the antennas outside, but it works just fine for me with the antennas inside. In the workshop, I aimed the second antenna in the general direction of the one in the house, and it works great. There are a few trees between the buildings, and the signal still gets through.

You use a Web browser to set up the Smart Repeater, and it's incredibly easy. It automatically scans to find your existing wireless network, and then lets you choose a name for the new wireless network that connects to the first. It took me about 6 minutes to set up, including 3 minutes for the device to reboot after configuration.

Without doing anything to really optimize things, I'm getting 2.5 Mbps downlink, and about half that uplink. This is slower than my router's upstream connection, but it works just fine. For comparison, when I'm in the house connected directly to my WiFi router, I get 19 Mbps downlink, and 1 Mbps uplink. So I'm getting much less speed downlink, but all the available uplink bandwidth. I guess I'll go experiment with mounting and aiming the antennas better. But even with the reduced speed, I'm really enjoying having the network and phone in the workshop.

These seem like nice headphones

They‚Äôre simple and easy to use

I like the design overall. They seem straightforward to pair, just like any other device.

Overall I think they‚Äôre nice

Well I'm surprised, they work. However depending on how good your output is. It had issues going thru 30ft of cat 5e in 1080 but if you can get it at 480p just add amplifier and keep adjusting while slowly increasing resolution to 720p then 1080i. I also tested it with another piece of equipment and the cheapest cables ever. I made 2 cat 5e patch cables 160 ft long, not even copper, the cheapest cable ever and after adding 5 dollar monoprice amplifier tv works great at 1080i

This speaker is much larger than expected. We've been using this in the hot tub. We've had water proof speakers before, but never one that could actually be put in the water and float around. We've put it directly in the hot tub and we've put it in the cup holders. What I really like about this is that there is all around sound. You don't have to position it with the speakers facing a certain direction just to hear it. You can hear it from all directions! The sound is pretty good, too. My daughter has used this in the backyard with friends and it was more than adequate. We have found it easier to control the volume with our phones than the actual device, but you can control it from the speaker, too. The light feature is fun at night. Our hot tub light bulb is out and needs to be replaced and this does the job for us. It was easy to pair with our phones. Overall, we are very happy with this new speaker!
Husband needed for some audio purpose and he says it worked as it should.

I CHOSE this model over another because of the supposed built-in Alexa compatibility. You can indeed connect the soundbar to an Echo device *as a regular bluetooth connection*, but the instructions to enable Auto VA (auto virtual assistant mode) via Bluetooth so the soundbar maintains a BT connection with Echo while using other inputs DOESN'T WORK. The instructions say to first connect the soundbar to Echo via BT (‚úÖ), and then to press the Bluetooth button for 10 seconds to enable Auto VA (‚ùå). HOWEVER; after five seconds, the soundbar enters Bluetooth pairing mode. I've tried dozens of times, connecting and disconnecting the BT connection with Echo and restarting and resetting the soundbar: NO DICE.

It's frustrating because this feature is in the title of the product and is clearly described in the User Manual ‚Äî and yet it doesn't work at all.

I imagine Auto VA via AUX input works okay, but that means I have to move my Echo or get a wicked-long audio cable, neither of which I want to do.

However, otherwise the soundbar sounds fine. Not quite as good as the Bose Companion computer speakers I used previously, but whole worlds better than the built in TV speakers. It's just a shame that I have disconnect and reconnect to Alexa so often.
Headphones have been great
Great sound for a small, inexpensive speakerm

This was intended to function as a charging hub. I have 2 tablets, 2 headphones, a WiMax Router, an ebook reader, a battery pack, and a smart phone - All of which uses USB to charge. This item wasn't meeting the demands. I am sure it will make a good USB data hub, but nothing else. Don't expect it to power much of anything in turn.

I deducted 2 stars because at this price, this 2022 Sony TV really should be 1080p instead of 720p, there really should be HDMI CEC (Sony calls this Bravia Sync), and because the remote control is way too long. There's a lot of empty space. The remote takes up more space on your table than it has to.

The TV is very easy to set up from start to finish. It's a nice-looking TV, and seems of good build quality. If you input a high-quality signal into the HDMI port, you'll be very happy with the picture.

The speaker quality on this TV is perfectly fine.

it took me a while to find these. I did searches and it wasn't until my husband came across this. I do have bluetooth B&O headphones but they only last for 4 hours. So I use my Westones to listen to my meditation music or my Apple playlist alone. I love that Apple allowed a company to make this because I spent a lot of money on westones for best quality listening. AND I love the ability to charge my phone at the same time. so this little thing is worth the money!

Now I know many other companies make a similar thing but I ran into the problem of not compatability and I spend money on 3 different ones. so yes, these Belkins ARE the bomb!

Product description says hot shoe mount but the box says cold shoe mount.  It is a cold shoe mount. Holds my phone securely.  Doesnt fit into my camera hot shoe.  Its 99.99% sturdy plastic.  The clamp is not spring loaded, meaning when you push the button to release the clamp to take the phone out, you have to manually pull the clamp apart.

I got this speaker to replace a mini set that I use in the bathroom. I wanted something waterproof this time. You can clip the speaker to anything you'd like, even a shower curtain. The control buttons are on the top of the speaker. You can adjust the volume, pause, skip, and answer calls. You can pair it with any device via Bluetooth or use the cable that's included. The sound quality is okay for inside. The volume doesn't go up high enough to use it in a more noisy environment. Other than that, it's a decent speaker.

Thanks so much for taking the time to read this review. I hope the information that I've provided makes your decision a little easier.

So I have several large speaker Alexa devices, but due to scalpers, those aren't available currently. So I bought this instead. The sound quality is crackly and awful. It's not very loud either. The sound is very tinny and just sounds bad. Anyway, it was only $20 so I'm not too mad about it.

The two speaker cover arrived, each is constructed of an outer frame and mesh grille; the mesh grille on one of the frames had fallen out due to poor workmanship during the original installation. I had to reinstall the mesh and then melt the plastic anchor to fasten the mesh to the outer frame.
Great little speaker. Price is good and quality is too. Sounds surprisingly good.

Great sound in a compact size party speaker.
I like the digital display on the front of the speaker.
Plus, the added lighting allows this to light up a room with party atmosphere.
The Bluetooth connection is stable with a range of 25 feet from my cell phone.
The speaker has some bass, but keep in mind the speaker size is 6.5 inch.
Great pool side speaker too.

Even at top volume the noise cancellation on this set of headphones isn‚Äôt great. With a name like Microsoft I expected more from the product. Since this is about the best set I‚Äôve found for the money I will be keeping them, but it hasn‚Äôt been my best purchase this year.

The 1st thing I noticed about these headphones when I received them (other than the amazing box they came in) are that they are noticeably heavier than my other headphones. I take that as an indication of higher quality speakers.

They do sound amazing. I listened to an album I have heard dozens of times before in the car & on earbuds & could hear elements I have never picked up on before. I actually thought I was listening to a different version of the song. I expected an exaggerated bass like I get with some earbuds but the sound is straightforward.

The noise cancelling seems about the same as my much cheaper headphone set but both are very good & make a world of difference on a plane or other noisy situations. Pairing is practically automatic on Apple devices but it is also easy for my Android phone. I think we have 3 or 4 devices currently paired to this set.

The headphones turn on as soon as they are unfolded. This is a cool feature but it means they are always on if they are worn around the neck. The battery lasts a long, long time. One charge played movies & noise cancelling for 7 hours of flying, probably another hour of music plus at least 4 more hours of just noise cancelling because someone forgot to close them until they were down to 2%

The volume & play /pause are easily controlled by tapping the right ear cuff. The charge port is the robust Apple lighting cable type which was a surprise to me until my daughter told me that Apple owns the Beats brand.

The carry case is much bigger than the folded headset. At first glance it doesn't look thick enough to provide good protection but pinching the material reveals that it has a thin, soft layer of foam or something inside. The zipper is the waterproof type which is a nice. The case comes with a hang tag & carabiner.

The headphones were too tight for my XL head. My ears were sore after long days on airplanes. I extended the cuffs all the way to reduce the tension which helped a little but made them harder to wear. The ear cuffs are a little smaller than another pair I have & I like the larger cuff because I can move them around a little on the ear for comfort while still getting a good 'seal' on my ear.

I ended up giving these to my daughter & she absolutely loves them. She is very is proud to have the Beats brand which isn't so important to me.

EDIT: Replacement battery went belly-up this June, about 18 months after installation. This was the second one the seller had given me. At least my daughter got a year and a half of use out of it before it stopped charging or turning on. I went to go remove it and oh my goodness, this battery was SWOLLEN. I'm glad I removed it when I did because I know what happens to Li-po batteries if this thing had burst. To be fair, she went away to camp and left it plugged in, so I'm not sure if this would have happened under normal usage. Be careful with your batteries and treat them well.
I don't think I can reach out to the seller now for a replacement 1.5 years later, but I wish I could say it lasted longer than that. Original review was 4 stars, reducing it now to 2 because the swollen part is alarming and I shouldn't have to swap batteries every other year like this.

ORIGINAL REVIEW BELOW:
It seems that the battery I received was not actually the stated capacity, after a few charging cycles is claimed to only have around 79% of it's life remaining. The good news is that the seller is excellent and replaced it ASAP. The new I have is still around 85% capacity, but to be honest for the price I'm happy with it. My old battery was much worse, so this is a major improvement and I can't complain much for the price.
If you want something closer to the original battery, you'll have to easily pay twice as much if not more. This is a decent value for what it is, and customer support really stands behind the product.

Due to the wrong placement, the sound from my speaker is very low and the bluetooth is also intermittent. I tried to solve the problem, and from the product's home page, I found that the side with the buttons on the speaker always faces up, and when facing the buttons, the speaker always hangs on the wall. When the position is adjusted, the sound of the speaker becomes louder, bluetooth has also become very stable. The sound is very clear when playing songs. Love it!

I wanted to be able to incorporate the Harmony Hub Extender with Harmony Elite remote into my existing Z-wave network, to control lighting. It was easy enough to pair it with the Hub and download new firmware to it.

However, there was quite of bit of trial & error to get it paired with my Qolysys Z-wave panel. Many times it would not pair properly. And the Extender & Hub kept going offline, making it hard to do anything.

So I read some advice online and did the following: (1) do a reset to factory defaults for both the Harmony Hub & Extender, (2) swap the power adapter for a fast charger, giving the unit a more robust power supply, (3) made sure Hub was connected on the 2.4 GHz side of my Asus Wi-Fi Lyra mesh system, (4) assigned a static IP address to the Hub, (5) added & removed the Extender several times from the panel and (6) not try to make the Extender a secondary controller of the Z-wave network.

Eventually using the mobile Harmony app, the Extender started recognizing all of my devices. I can now reliably control lighting & the thermostat from the remote. It complements the control I have from the panel & the Alarm.com app.

Was it worth the effort? Probably not. But got the Harmony Elite, Hub & Extender as refurbished units for half the price of new, so that dampens the frustration some.

I bought this stacking kit when I purchased the FiiO E12A Mont Blanc IEM Special Edition Portable Headphone Amp, Titanium so I could connect it to my FiiO X5 High Resolution Music Player (2nd Generation)(Titanium). It is easy to set up, but it sure is ugly once you get it on there. Some of you may like that - I thought it looked kind of cool, like a weird set of custom recording gear or something. But the rubber bands used to hold the headphone amp onto the back of the DAP were strange looking. They also get in the way of the E12A‚Äôs USB port, so I would have to scoot the bands out of the way when I needed to get in there. They got in the way of the X5‚Äôs volume keys too, but you won‚Äôt need to use those if you‚Äôre using a headphone amp.
I eventually broke the plastic frame on one of the cutaways for the rubber bands when I was trying to put my X5 back in. It‚Äôs thin in a few spots, and the plastic cracked. Instead of buying another one, I used some Command Strip Picture Hanging Strips (sort of like velcro, but without the fuzzy strip) to snap them together. It looks neater, and it‚Äôs easier to use.
Very compact product easy install and video quality is good but the microphone seems to be affected and doesn't get out clearly.
Great speaker, works awesome as center speaker in 7.1 surround sound setup.

I received this as a free review sample. The reason why I docked it a star is the active tablet window needs improvement (and that could have been one of the stand-out features if properly designed.) Here is the problem: it's the perfect size for an iPad Air 2, but could not accommodate my Tab 2 10.1 inch tablet. It did hold my Samsung Tab Pro 8.4 (even in an Otterbox Defender case). The vinyl window wrinkles and also reduces sensitivity when you interact with your tablet.

If the active tablet window is unimportant to you, then the rest of this backpack is a winner. Pairing my phone to the bluetooth speakers was as simple as flipping a switch and scanning for it on my phone's settings. And the speakers are loud with better than expected sound quality. I was pleased with that - some thought went into the speakers.

The padding is more than ample for protecting electronics, and there are sufficient pockets for the geekiest geek. What I like, though, is the storage areas are not overly complex. I own a Booq bag that is a storage dream come true, but almost requires a photographic memory to remember were all of the pockets are. This one is designed much simpler, but still efficient and effective.

Construction (except for the active tablet window) is first rate. The tablet window is marred by a difficult zipper, whereas all of the other zippers on this bag are sturdier and smooth. The outer fabric seems tough (I have not had it long enough to make any claims beyond that), and all of the seams are reinforced, straight and tight.

It's very comfortable and can be adjusted to evenly distribute the weight of a fully loaded pack. Considering that the bag itself is somewhat heavy this is a major plus for me.

I do want to note one thing about the backup battery: it is rated at (and stores) the full 4000mAh. However, like all batteries using this one's technology it's only 70% efficient, so expect about 2800mAh of usable capacity. That is not a flaw in this bag, but a reality that I wanted to point out so your expectations are properly set.

Overall, this is a well made bag with some innovative features (battery back-up and bluetooth speakers). If the active tablet window is not an important feature it's definitely worth considering. This one will be replacing my Booq because the storage is there without the complexity.

I am not going to repeat the product description, which is complete with regard to basic specifications and what this package contains. I am going to confine my review to personal observations and actual use of this camera. Note two things: I received this as a review sample, and I have not extensively used this camera. Thus far I have been using it for approximately a week, which is sufficient for basic functions, but not for long term reliability.

This is a complete solution, down to an 8GB SD card and a pair of batteries that are included in the package. The main limitation with this camera is you will get about an hour of use for every three hours of charging. That is not bad for extreme type videos for which this camera was designed, but do understand up front that this is not going to replace a DVR or even your phone's video camera capabilities (depending on your phone) for regular video capture. Again, this is not designed as a general purpose video camera so I do not view that limitation as a detriment.

The 8GB card that ships with this camera holds an hour of video at full 1080P 30FPS resolution. The camera will accommodate up to 32GB SD cards, and if you have an external battery pack like a [[ASIN:B00KX2DUU2 Lumsing¬Æ 4000mAh Ultrathin Portable Power Bank External Battery Pack Backup]] you can, in fact, capture up to four hours of video. Using an external battery pack is probably not a good idea when trying to mount this for extreme sports videos, but will allow you to use this camera for more general purpose uses.

One feature that I particularly like is the fact that this uses a regular micro USB connection for charging and transfer. I have a few cameras that use barrel connectors and they limit your charging options, so this use of standard cables is a plus.

Note that his this camera has no options other than MOV files for video. I had no problems with that format on my Windows XP laptop and it's fairly common with both Microsoft and Apple environments, but not all applications that run on those platforms.

Another feature that I especially like is this camera comes with just about every conceivable attachment that you can think of. If you are directly comparing this to a GoPro the value proposition of this package is apparent. I am not saying that this is better than a GoPro because that camera has become something of a standard, and also I do not have enough direct experience with that camera to make a valid comparison. What I am saying is if this camera will meet all of your needs and/or if you have a set budget this one offers more value. The real decision, though, is yours.

Overall, I am very pleased with this camera and the video quality. It's reasonably easy to operate and is versatile for the uses for which it was designed. While I cannot credibly compare this to the GoPro I can compare it to the [[ASIN:B00NEYHIHM Polaroid POLC3 Cube HD Digital Video Action Camera Camcorder]], which I do own, and between the two this one is hands down the better choice. In the class of value-priced action cameras this one gets a solid five stars from be for both performance and value.

My husband and I bought two sets of these three years ago from Circuit City during their going out of business sale. We both travel quite a bit and were in need of decent headphones for longer flights (let's face it, the ear buds provided by the airlines just don't cut it). My husband accidentally left his set, in their pouch, in the seat back pocket on a flight last year and was in need of a replacement set for our trip to Germany last week. I was amazed by the price when I came onto Amazon to check - $29.99 was a steal compared to the $80 we spent a few years back! This headset is not the top of the line, but it is effective in canceling out the low aircraft drawl while in-flight. (They are also quite nice when you need to drown out the crying child in 23F. ;)) The battery life is remarkable. I have had to change the battery on my set only twice in the three years I've owned it. The only complaint that I have, which results in the four star rating instead of five, is that after wearing the set for a few hours (i.e., Amsterdam to Houston, TX), my ears begin to ache on the outside. It is almost like the headset becomes to tight over longer periods of time. I tend not to wear earrings on airplanes, so I can rule out the possibility of pinching. Other than that slight achy feeling, these are wonderful for the casual traveler and the price simply cannot be beat!

These really work well for us on our twelve acre farm.  With people working on various projects, it‚Äôs great to hand everybody a walkie talkie and keep track of where they are, how it‚Äôs going - and calling them in for meals!  It‚Äôs been nearly impossible to get the attention of my grandson when he‚Äôs on the tractor - but now, no problem!  These would be a great choice for a large group going camping - every child should be taught how to use one and keep one with them whenever they are away from the group.  Great for safety!  Quality walkie-talkies - all are working!

my logitech wireless mouse refused to right click to copy and paste, so I found this one to replace it. plugged in the usb nano receiver and put a battery in it, turned it on and it started working immediately. no drivers to install, no shut downs, nothing. how much easier can that be?

This is an attractive keyboard and functions mostly well. However, it doesn‚Äôt connect as immediately to Bluetooth as others I‚Äôve had. I have to keep hitting a key for it to eventually connect. The worst thing about it, is that the bumpers at the bottom of the keyboard are exactly where I rest my wrists to type and are quite uncomfortable. For that reason alone, I would not buy this item again.

*UPDATED REVIEW*

A seller replaced a different defective FM transmitter unit with this one for me (mine has the Kollea brand name on it, but this is the identical unit, private-labeled). This is a better product than what it replaced, but is not without it's flaws. I have three (*UPDATE: now four, and the fourth one is a deal-breaker--see below) complaints with this unit:

1) It will not automatically reconnect to my phone about 75% of the time. I have to manually shut Bluetooth off and turn it back on on the phone, sometimes a few times before it pairs successfully. This is a hassle--a PITA. Every time I get in the car, I have to go through this process--every time power is cut from the transmitter, actually, so if your passenger knocks it and it pops out of the 12V socket, it will have to be re-paired, which is supposed to happen automatically, but does not, and you then have to go through the process. Frustrating.

2) Charge output is only 1.0A. this is why I returned the first one--phone gives a "slow charging" warning when charging from this unit, regardless of what USB cable I use (I tried four different cables, all of which I know for certain can carry 2.1A).

3) Callers have occasionally complained they cannot hear me well when using this unit, and I occasionally (but not often) encounter FM interference. I believe Bluetooth itself is part of the problem, and anyone who has used a few Bluetooth headsets or units like this knows audio quality is terrible. Period. We just deal with it. Add to that the burden of having to transmit your signal via FM to a car stereo and the user-side audio (what you will hear in your car) is always going to be craptastic.

4) (*UPDATE) When paired, voice recognition on my phone, which is usually quite good, becomes severely impaired. This is also likely the culprit for complaint #3, above. I suspect this is because when paired, it tries to use the built-in microphone for voice recognition instead of the microphones on my phone (of which there are 4). It is disabling the extremely good microphones in my phone (Nokia lumia Icon which is well known for having incredible audio input) and using the unit's crappy microphone instead. This microphone is located in the unit, which is attached to the center console of my car near the shifter, and thus picks up all the vibrations and related road and engine noise transmitted through the structure of the car as I drive. This approach is terrible. I have stopped using the unit for anything requiring voice input, including telephone calls. In other words, this is just a big awkward charger now, and one that charges painfully slowly (see complaint #2). If it were possible to disable the onboard mic, and use the mics in my phone instead for calls and voice recognition, this would be a much more serviceable unit As it is now, it is just a piece of junk.

Cannot recommend this item. There are definitely worse products out there. I have not tried them all, but of those I have used, this is the best one so far. I will likely keep using it until the lack of automatic pairing pushes me over the edge with it one day and I get something else. (*UPDATE: this thing just does not work well, and I am now looking for something else.)

I don't know much about the technicalities about this laptop. I have been using it and love it. I have a great familiarity with Dell computers, so that recognition is helpful. First of all, the size. This is small enough to take to the bedroom with me. I can prop it up without it being cumbersome.

The chrome is beautiful. The feel is light. I find the image quality is very good. And, I love the backlit keyboard. Always helpful when keyboarding in the darken rooms. I work in live AV production, and usually keep a pair of Sony over-the-ear headphones in my gear bag for monitoring sound on location. Quality of the sound is important for concert and other live music gigs. But those big Sonys take up a lot of space, so I've been considering a good set of IEMs for a while now. In the past I haven't had good results from anything that wasn't a large over-the-ear set, and I have small ears that reject a lot of ear-bud style devices so I was excited to get a chance to try these out.

Ok, to be fair, I don't have any other IEMs to compare this to, but I'm BLOWN AWAY at how incredible they sound at such a miniscule size. I put on the smallest tips for my ears and they actually stay in relatively well, and create the passive noise cancellation I was expecting but without being uncomfortable to wear for an extended period of time. But the range of sound reproduced was something I have only experienced in larger studio headphones!
A perk of IEMs versus larger headphones on jobs like mine are that I can pull out one so I can hear the sound around me while monitoring with my other ear (great if working with an audio engineer who needs to communicate with me on the job), and it comes with a pretty nifty case to wrap it up and slide into my bag. The case makes it bigger than it needs to be, but honestly this is so much less space than my old headphones took up, and keeps the cord from getting tangled. I love it!
For personal use, they sound great even on consumer equipment, but they really shine on devices that can drive the additional range such as my old LG V20 with it's Quad DAC built in (one of the reasons I keep that old device around!).
The price tag is a little steep for me personally, but my Sony headphones retail somewhere around this (I had bought them used), and I KNOW there are pricier options out there, so it seems to fit right into the audiophile equipment range.

Pretty good speed and excellent storage. Screen is large and bright, speakers are excellent and it is lightweight. So nice to have access to a laptop again. I‚Äôm ok with it not being touch screen, but I wish it was a little faster

I just wish it would tell you "volume is maximum" or something like that, because I wish they would go louder. I tried raising the volume and all I did was make the L headphone mono and I had to reset to make them stereo again. Otherwise the sound is wonderfully rich and clear. And noise cancelling is pretty good. Again, would be better if I could raise the volume. more.

Wonderful replacement tips for my Shure Aonic 4. The sound is comfortable, and the feeling is soothing. They're not a perfect fit for the Shure, even though they're supposed to be compatible; the tips come off freely if pulled, but surprisingly they stay on when removing the earbuds from the within the ears.
I like these headphones a lot, but they definitely aren‚Äôt noise canceling!

[[VIDEOID:6295ef27257a86cbdd7a82ec5d1b45bc]] Haven‚Äôt tested these while swimming but I love the style overall.

I am a big fan of the bone conducting style headphones. They don‚Äôt sit in your ear but just outside. This is nice so that you can still hear the world around you - when I am walking my dog at night, I like that a lot. It makes sense to hear cars and people on the background.

Overall they‚Äôre nice.

It played music fine and sound quality seemed good. The color changing is the really cool part though.
