I purchased this for two reasons. First I wanted a memory card that I could use in my [[ASIN:B00966PFHW Philips DVT1000/00 2 GB Digital Voice Tracer with 2 Built-In Microphones Voice Recorder]]. Second I also wanted to copy and store many photos from my laptop on this card. I was able to do both without losing the files associated with either system.

Not only did this card work in both my Dell Inspiron 1720 with Windows Vista Service Pack 2 but it also worked fine in my [[ASIN:B00966PFHW Philips DVT1000/00 2 GB Digital Voice Tracer with 2 Built-In Microphones Voice Recorder]] (without the reader).

Using my Dell's USB 2.0 port and the reader that came with the card, I was able to transfer 330 photo files (a total of 485 MB) in under three minutes which to me is extremely impressive. What is also impressive is that this is so, so tiny. I don't stay up on technology much any more, but if this got any smaller I would have to use a magnifying glass and tweezer just to remove the card from the reader and insert it into my recorder. The card has a nice indent in it so you can pull it out with your nail (that's if you have finger nails).

I got this on gold box special for $26.99 instead of the current price of $68.24 and now I'm sorry I didn't buy two. In summary this is fast, small, and portable memory with lots of storage! Perhaps there's something better out there but I'm so satisfied I'm not looking!

The Flip is a pint-sized camcorder with a surprising feature set given its compactness. Though is it not a full-featured camcorder and I would not recommend it for serious recording (special events or production material), it is excellent for on-the-go shots and for spontaneous recording when opportunities present themselves.

The Flip is small - a little smaller than an ice cream sandwich. It may be little, but there's tremendous convenience in being able to drop your camcorder in your shirt pocket or your purse and have it at the ready. This compact size holds everything you need to start recording - batteries, flash RAM and all. Without tapes or DVD media on which to record, there's little reason for this device to be any bigger.

It is a solid little thing and feels durable. That doesn't mean it would do well if dropped or stepped on, but it likely will be ok if jostled a little.

Recording is simple. No, I should be more clear - recording with the Flip is trivial. There is no real science to using it: turn it on, point and press record. Press the record button again to stop recording. Even technological novices, or people afraid of electronics will have no trouble using the Flip to record. Playing back is equally simple - once the recording is finished, press the Play button.

There are + and - buttons, used for Zoom. The Flip doesn't have a particularly capable zoom, so shooting from a distance will not yield especially great results.

I tested this camcorder in my basement on a bright, sunny day, and I wandered about recording and chattering to myself. When I played back what I had recorded, I made a pleasant discovery - it does some light balancing and deals with changes in light levels so that the video is still clear. The sound is also good, better than I expected. When I walked down a dark hallway and into an unlit room, it had tried very hard to accommodate for the lack of light but it was unable to completely overcome the darkness. As there is no light on the camcorder to come on when it is dark, this is understandable, but it did surprisingly well in spite of that.

I attached the Flip to my computer to pull the video to my hard drive. FlipShare installed itself and started up, seeing the video I had made. It allowed me to pull it over and even gave me the option to delete it from the camera. Once finished, I was able to play the video through FlipShare. Instead, I decided to hunt it down and use a different application to play it.

I found the file and tried to open it with Windows Media Player. I got audio, but not video. When I switched to QuickTime, my video came up and filled my screen. This is the point at which I made an unfortunate discovery. Every minute move I had made while recording was now plainly obvious, as there is no anti-jitter built into the device.

The video, on a 1440x900 resolution screen, looked clear. It records at 1280x720, which is not that much smaller, so I was a little surprised. I would have expected a little pixelation, but this actually was not an issue.

There are few settings that can be adjusted on the Flip - language, date, time and recording light.

The Flip is a nice camcorder that provides tremendous convenience and fun. It is very easy to use and very compact. It is important to remember that it has some limitations which make it a less-than-ideal choice for more serious application, but if those limitations are not an issue for you then the Flip is a fun and affordable way to capture things on video.

This is a good brand for speakers in my opinion- my son needed a new one and this one has great sound with a surprising amount of bass.
With the Bluetooth it's simple to set up. And the portable with a long battery life.

To be honest, I got my IPAD about 2 months ago and purchased a bluetooth keyboard case (from Amazon of course). Anyway, I was looking for an alternative case to be able to use as just a case (nothing to do with a keyboard). I saw this offered to me in Vine and figure I could give it an honest review. To top it all off it has the Smart magnetic feature which puts the IPAD to sleep when closed and wakes it up when opened (saves battery life). I highly recommend, this is a great cover for all!!!

I love that this amplifier has an internal 2,000mAh battery so there is no searching for the correct sized batteries when you need it. All I do is keep it charged up and ready to rock.

This is an outstanding product that I definitely recommend.

Sanyo DS25390 is a simple, no- frills television that offers enough features to get by but is lacking in some of the basics that we now take for granted in television sets, making it a questionable choice of sets for many consumers. Starting with the remote control, this television is very limited and quite out of date. Besides the usual keys (the ten numbered buttons, power button, etc.), you get a set- up key, CC key (closed captioning), Enter, and a Previous Channel selector. The various settings for the television can be accessed from the remote using the menu button, and they include the usual options (changing brightness, color, etc.). There isn't much more to it than that and the control itself has an old- fashioned look to it.

Picture quality on Sanyo DS25390 is okay, but nothing exceptional. The sharpness is the greatest weakness of this Sanyo television. Depending on your distance from the screen, the images seem a little fuzzy on the edges. At a good distance, this problem is minimized well enough that most people will not notice but it is definitely not as sharp as the picture on most newer models.

Picture quality is most important, but one other important consideration when choosing any television is its features and friendliness to accessories. Sanyo DS25390 has limited abilities and limited features. Chief among these is the limits on input. There are only a few input and output jacks and, because of this, there is no way to directly hook up a DVD player or video camera. This fact alone would probably discourage most people from considering this television. You could probably connect a DVD player or other device by going through a VCR first, but how many among is still own a VCR? I realize this television set was considered acceptable during its day, but it is difficult to overlook things like this.

One other problem I have with this television is the sound quality. There is only one small speaker, so the sound delivered is in mono. This certainly reduces the sound quality when watching certain movies or music video. The sound is acceptable for most television shows because the need for stereo quality isn't important. But it isn't very good for certain films and other programs that are greatly enhanced with stereo sound.

Overall, Sanyo Model DS25390 is a difficult television set to evaluate. It seems adequate in some ways and it was probably considered a good television set when it was first introduced. But compared to modern televisions, I cannot imagine anyone buying this set. The fact that a DVD player cannot be directly hooked up to this television is reason enough to reject it. Add to that the picture quality and its lack of sharpness and you have a television set that is too flawed to recommend. It's inexpensive, yes. But you most certainly get what you pay for.

I was really amazed at the sound! A tiny speaker the size of a soda can that creates a wonderful sound environment. I have it hooked to my Echo dot and the sound clarity is really good! And the bass coming out of the top is pretty precise. It's not the thundering bass but the correct one (to my ears). Takes up really a very small space.

Set up was very easy. Pressed a button to pair it with Echo using Bluetooth. My phone and Echo both picked it up really quick. Can't really tell if it's going to work in long distance but I have no reason to doubt what the manufacturer is claiming.

The only issue I had was figuring out how to use the volume buttons. I assume it's a quick press to lower or increase the volume but it's actually a long press. And then I am not sure how long to hold down the button to increase and decrease since there's no visual cue. But once I found the right volume it's OK. I can control the actual volume from the source as well.

I got the black one so it sits very nicely behind a few Knick Knacks and not really visible. The sound is "surround" so it's not directional. I have not paired it up with a twin to test out the stereo effect. But that's not how I intend to use this speaker anyways.

Very happy with this purchase. Kudos to the engineers for putting together such a nice speaker!

After a bad experience with another flat amp antenna I purchased the leaf for just over $50 .
It picks up 19 stations in the "low country" around a lot of tall pine trees.(20 is the max number of stations in a 60 mile radius here with any antenna according to the TV manufacturer).

You can paint the ant/ cables to match the walls. Comes with push pins for walls and Velcro for wall or window if you want them.Also has a plug into TV for the amp or you can plug into the wall like I did so it isn't hampered by the surge protector.

I get ABC, CBS,NBC,FOX,THIS,3 PBS stations, 3 Christian channels,a Spanish channel, WE,GET,MY,BOUNCE,YOU TOO, one music video channel and one other. The reception on all (but 2) is exceptionally strong with no blips in power even if you cannot put it in a window. I have mine hanging behind my curtain and most channels get 90-100% station strength almost constantly when 35%, even 30% will give you the station clear enough to watch a program with very few "blips" in reception.

I am enjoying not adjusting the Rabbit ear antenna (when I watched certain channels) even though it worked *good* enough for the money.

If you had another antenna before that only picked up 5-13 channels (for exp.) and you switch to a more powerful one like this, remember to unplug your TV a good minute before re- auto programming ( I forgot at first myself) as some TVs seem to "remember" how many it gets and stops at that number.

No need for an ugly outside antenna with this one.

When I use my hair dryer or turn on another "power draw", it doesnt get the interference the previous amplified antenna had, so probably uses less electricity, yet pulls in more stations.
I'm very happy with it. I get more channels than my basic cable had that I enjoy watching also.

I received this as a free review sample. First, this is for low draw devices like mice, keyboards, thumb drives and the such. It will NOT support an external drive that gets its power from your machine's USB port.

For me this is perfect because it's USB 2.0 only (although it will also kick down to USB 1.1). I am using it on an old ThinkPad T61, which immediately recognized it as soon as I plugged it in. I did not test the Ethernet connection (which needs a separate driver on my XP machine), but the USB ports are problem free.

As a test I tried this hub on my Note 4 phone using a [[ASIN:B00LM4PDUU LinkS Micro-USB 3.0 OTG Adapter]] and the USB ports worked like they did on my T61. Again, I did not test the Ethernet port, but did populate two USB ports with a keyboard and mouse, and both were immediately recognized by the phone.

Bottom line: this is a nice way to expand USB ports for low power draw devices. The Ethernet port is a bonus and especially if you need to direct connect to a router, but you may need to download a driver to get it working.

Great for taking pictures when your house / office is dark. I bought 2 desk spot lamps and it works even at night. Taking off 1 star for no instructions and no way to fold it back up to put into bag. I got creative with chip clips.  I did have to iron the inserts as they are folded instead of rolled like others said.  It does take great pictures if you put a light on the very top.

and he started eating the ear pads on two different pairs of my husband's headphones. I keep telling him to put them up so he can't reach them. He did last night so the little stinker got a tube of lipstick and a bottle of hair spray and brought them in the room. I caught him before he could do more than just crush the lipstick so that it is unusable. The ear pads work great though and super easy to replace.

I bought this so I could switch my audio between my computer that is hooked up to my tv and just play audio from the tv when I‚Äôm not using the computer. The transmitter has a small footprint which is nice and several different types of ports you can plug into. The thing I didn‚Äôt like was that it could not automatically switch between which audio device was transmitting. If I switched from my computer to something on my tv then I would have to manually change it. When I tried to make it so that my computer would automatically connect via Bluetooth the transmitter would continually say ‚Äúconnecting ‚Äú over and over again it was super annoying. I didn‚Äôt care for this one but I got avantree audikast and I love it, it does exactly what I want it to do. So this device is not bad, the audio commands from the device is pretty annoying but it is an okay device

I received this as a free review sample. As advertised the protection is excellent. The construction is as well, and you actually can turn it inside out to change the color scheme.

Here is the 'but': this case literally fits the Sound Blaster Roar 2 like a glove (and it is only for the Roar 2 model.) The stretching and pulling required is a bit onerous. I thought it would be a learning curve issue, but each time I use this bag it is as difficult as the last time. Difficult, but not impossible. On the other hand, had this been designed for an easier fit I am not sure the same level of protection would be there.

Also note that this is strictly for transporting the Roar 2. Once it is inserted in this case you cannot access controls. I kind of like that because I do carry my Roar 2 around and appreciate the fact that this will keep it from getting dinged.

One final thing: the top cover does not completely close. There is a gap and there is no zipper. That is why you can turn this inside out.

Bottom line: this provides excellent protection and is well made. On the other hand, there are challenges as I noted above and you will need to weight those into a purchase decision. I do use mine a lot and have a love/hate relationship with it.

The good and the bad.

The good is that these work. I plugged them in and walla!, sound.

The bad is the pause button is pretty sporadic. I use these kind of headphones with my ipod to listen to audio books. The pause button is absolutely essential (honestly, having a pause button saves the battery on your ipod, so I guess it's important that way too). But it just didn't work every time, sometimes, even with lifting it up and very deliberately pressing the button one time, it would stick and whatever you are listening to would advance. This isn't super bad if you are listening to music, you just might cut short you favorite jam. But if you are listening to an audio book it will advance to the next chapter of a book, before you have finished listening to it.

This has caused me supreme annoyance, trying to go back and find my spot in an audiobook means you will end up having to listen to something twice because it it is pretty impossible to find where you left off.

So, these were super duper cheap, I use them on my computer now because I don't have to worry about the pause button, I have a mouse and keyboard for that.

Guess you get what you pay for.

On my last trip, while juggling a heavy bag on one shoulder as I pulled my new Amazon wheeled carry-on, I noticed that other travelers had their computers in bags that slipped over the trolley handle. There and then I decided I needed a new bag for my electronics. This one fills the bill. My Dell laptop fits perfectly (and it isn't a skinny one). There's also a pocket in the front for my Fire tablet in its keyboard case, with room for my cables. There's a strap in the back that slips over my wheeled carry-on's handle, just like the ones I saw other people using. No more sore shoulders or cramped up fingers for me. Thanks, AmazonBasics!

I had an issue in the past with cables not clicking and locking in properly. So my mother in law would come over vacuum knock out the cable because it wouldn't take much to knock it out then I had the wife yelling at me because the audio didn't work. Save yourself the headache snag this cable and let it lock in and not worry about being yelled at.

The Mcoplus VM-M03 Metal Shotgun Video Microphone is the next step in my attempt to address sound quality issues in my videos. While a lavalier is good for a vlogging situation, it's not great for getting on location sounds.

I'm not a professional videographer or anything so I've included pictures of the frequency response charts from the microphone's instruction manual. In my specific case, the quality of this microphone vs the built-in mic of my phone or mirrorless camera is that it seems to pick up a little less of the unwanted ambient noise, but the biggest difference for me is of course, the wind noise reduction afforded by the fur cover.

This microphone is an affordable upgrade to the built-in mics of my equipment and fits my needs well. I can't say that my recommendation should be taken by anyone who actually does videography professionally.

Update: Customer service sent another one to replace the one that did not work and within days it stopped working as well.

This POS has barely worked since I received it (I.e. screens connected to it don't work until directly plugged into computer or microphones going on and out) but in under a year it stopped working entirely. I'm so pissed that I spent the better half of my morning trying to figure out how something that is on just isn't working.

I have been shooting a Canon 50D DSLR for several years, mostly outside or with stage lighting. Occasionally, I also have been using a small camera-mounted flash, but it is weak and very limited. To improve my flash photography, I decided to try the Mago Speedlight by Pixel. This is an excellent, mid-priced flash with loads of features.

The Mago Speedlight comes with a nice soft case and a fold-out manual which guides you through the setup of the flash and includes screenshots of the back LCD. It also includes a small stand which is great for use in slave mode, and a clip-on flash defuser. The flash uses 4 AA batteries or an external power supply (not provided). It is even upgradable via a USB port hidden in the battery compartment (not tested).

The controls are easy to use after some experimenting. The manual really helps as there are so many features. The buttons are solid and the display is easy to read, with an optional green backlight.

The flash head can be tilted up and down, or rotated left or right. It also includes a built-in defuser and a white card reflector. These are very useful if you are not bouncing the flash off of a ceiling or reflector.

One interesting feature is an LED model light that can be turned on/off easily via a dedicated button. This light is quite bright and very useful for setting up your shots.

I tested the flash on a Canon 50D with 20mm and 50mm lenses and somewhat cooperative subjects (my kids). After learning the controls, I took several excellent pictures.

The flash supports E-TTL mode, manual mode, and multi-flash mode. I tested all three.

To test the multi-flash mode, I set the flash to 5 bursts at 500 HZ and took a picture of fan blades, resulting in a very interesting effect.

As a final test, I put the flash in slave move (S1) and put my old flash on the camera. This flash worked great as a slave flash and I took some interesting pictures using both flashes. I also used S1 mode to slave the this flash to the camera's on-board flash. Note, I did not test the wireless flash mode (a smart slave mode) as I do not have another flash that supports that feature.

Disclaimer: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at no cost, I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.

We recently moved into a new home and I took the time to install all of my electronics so each connection not only works correctly but looks professionally installed.

Having the correct plates makes all of the difference in having an install look clean and professional and this plate is exactly that.

I installed this plate directly behind my flat screen TV mounts and snaked the power cable through one port and all of the HDMI and audio cables through the other.

I used a matching plate behind our entertainment cabinet that houses our surge protector, Fire Cube, Apple TV and stereo.

This is an awesome wall plate if you are interested in an amazingly clean, great looking, professional installation.

I use this to play music while I'm riding my bike to work everyday so I have it turned up full blast the whole way. It takes full volume without distortion but I wish it could pump out a bit more bass (has a slight rattle when the speakers bottom out).

Still, for the price and against competing portable speakers it gets LOUD and pairs seamlessly with my phone. I get a week's worth of riding out of a charge, so that's roughly 12 hours of full volume playing without dying on me. Pretty good. I like this speaker, it sounds good, it plays loud and since I use it 12 hours a week I generally get a year or two out of it before it breaks. For the amount of use I put it through that's pretty good for the price, I'm sure it will last you far longer since I used mine so often.
Bluetooth doesn‚Äôt want to connect every time I‚Äôm trying. So what‚Äôs the point of me spending 30$ for something that doesn‚Äôt work well!!

Two members of the family just told me that they had broken their headphones with this product came up to get. I decided it was worth a try, despite some previous experiences not being too great with cheaper headphones. Let's see what happened.

WHAT ARE THESE LIKE?
These headphones make some claims. They come in a great box who for Carlos fans will be a thrill. It is well decorated and presentation is fabulous. That means they would be a nice gift in that respect.

LEATHER?
The case says that these are leather padded ear cups and underneath headband. I am still not sure about this. Perhaps it is that bonded leather that is made from leather residue chopped up and blended with binders to remake it into sheets which are printed with leather look imprinting. Technically that can be called leather, but it really is not as much leather as I would like.

EAR CUPS AND HEADBAND
Having said that, these white headphones are comfortable. I can wear them longer than some others that I have had which are a bit rough after only an hour. These can be worn for several hours without a problem.

CORD
This comes with a cord which is only 38 inches long. That is a bit short for me. I find it is annoying and not quite as long as I would prefer.

SOUND
The sound of these is surprisingly great. The bass is really good, and the mids and highs are definitely clear and not muddy.

CONTROLS
The controls on the white pair are awful in that they are nearly impossible to read. The buttons are white and the markings are just very thin raised white on the buttons. It should really be colored with marker- which I took care of. Using a very fine permanent marker I colored just the raised areas. The up/down and play pause buttons are separated by the noise cancellation button which is good.

ADJUSTABILITY
These are very adjustable. They go longer, tilt in and out and rotate from side to side.

COMPACT?
These do fold flat and compact if you need to travel with them or store them in a smaller place.

SOUND CANCELLATION
THAT is where we part ways with these headphones. The noise cancellation is awful. It barely works. When it is turned on, the sound gets really compromised too. It becomes almost muffled in a way.

OTHER FEATURES
The ability to know how much power is left on the headphones while using the phone is nice, but it does not help if you are not using it with a phone and some other bluetooth device. Calling, people hear just fine and we can hear them too (several of us tried this feature with our phones)

THE BOTTOM LINE
For the price, these headphones are a step up from what I usually get when I try them. The sound is very good and well balanced, the folding up for storage is great, and the comfort is also on the upper level. The only disappointments are noise cancellation, short cord for corded listening, and the hard to read buttons.

MY RATING
FOUR STARS. If the noise cancellation worked better, these would be over the top amazing. As they are, they are still pretty great. I love the white color- it stands out from the rest, despite getting dirty faster. They are a great gift to yourself or someone else and are some of the nicer headphones I have used.

I used this daily, and it lasted for about 9 months worked great.  It is now sometimes not making the sound come out both speakers "in stereo".  If I wiggle the cord it will play in stereo for a little while.  I really like the coiled feature which keeps the cord out of the way.  It is fairly inexpensive so I decided to buy a new one.

I ordered these without seeing any dimensions (via Amazon mobile). I thought they were 8" tall given that they are refered to as "bookshelf" speakers. I don't know what bookshelves Sony is putting these things on but they are 20" tall. Not really what I was shopping for to use with a desktop computer.

After using surge protection for audio, video and computer equipment for more than 30 years I can definitely say not all of these products are created equally.

While surge protectors will often boast of great protection, more often than not they are more multi outlet plugs rather than actual protection.

I have thoroughly tested this wall surge protector and it has passed all of my testing. This will definitely protect your important investments.

The only thing I wish was different was the outlets should be spaced a bit further apart to allow for larger power blocks, or better yet that the outlets rotated as so often plugs are of a size where they extend over another outlet. The 3 USB-A ports are definitely a nice addition as this helps avoid having to use plugs for USB powered devices. I like having the indicator lights readily letting me know that the device is working properly.

This is an outstanding surge protector that has proven itself through extensive use and testing.

This is definitely a surge protector I recommend.
Excellent case for the speakers.  Nicely made.  A gift for a teenage boy - holding up quite well after months of use.  Goes to the beach, parks, pool.
Apple earbuds just as expected, good quality, and will probably buy them again when I destroy these.

The sound quality and power of this speaker bar is amazing.  Setup is pretty easy although it took several attempts to program my tv remote into the speaker.  Bluetooth worked flawlessly so it looks like the former issues of bluetooth connectivity have been resolved.  The subwoofer is very powerful.  I like the simplicity of having 3 sound modes, with the dialog mode turning down the bass for late night viewing when others might be disturbed.  The only issue is the speaker bar is a bit chunkier than some others, however those others that I have seen can't match the quality of sound.

We didn‚Äôt buy the entertainment package with my minivan - we decided to get a few portable DVD players instead, and I am glad we did !

They‚Äôre so easy to use and it‚Äôs really nice that each kid can pick whatever movie they want to watch, without fighting over the TV. They can have headphones and we‚Äôve got a quiet trip to wherever we are going.

These DVD player is a great size, light weight and easy to use. Screen seems very nice.

Bottom Line - The speaker itself is excellent but Bluetooth can be an irritating technology.

The speaker is lightweight and even has an attached carrying strap. Unlike a lot of lightweight products though, it doesn't feel flimsy or fragile at all. Instead it has a nice, solid, durable feel to it. While I am not an audiophile, the speaker has a deep, rich sound that I really like. It does well with audiobooks, music, and videos.

The problems seem to be with Bluetooth. One major issue is that the sound stutters while using Bluetooth. It's very noticeable when playing music and very irritating when listening to audiobooks. That's happened with every Bluetooth speaker I've ever tried. A google search indicates that it's a common problem related to the amount of information the computer is trying to pump out to the speaker. There's a checklist of possible issues to go through to try to fix the problem but the stuttering seems all too common with this technology.

Another issue involves changing modes on a Bluetooth speaker. To sidestep the stuttering I plugged this speaker into my computer with a standard jack. It worked fine and the sound was good. When I unplugged it to bring the speaker into another room with me, I had to redo my audio settings. When I plugged it back in with the jack, an audiobook played just fine but there was no sound while playing videos. Again, I had to go into the audio settings and fiddle with them to be able to watch a movie. I've had similar issues with other Bluetooth speakers.

If you are a techie you may be able to resolve such things quickly and easily. The less tech adept you are, the more hassle they will be though. Myself, I'm just going to leave the speaker connected to my pc via a good old fashioned jack because I like its sound. Bluetooth? Bah, I haven't got time to bother with it.

Akaso Brave 4 (Updated) Review

Note: WiFi apps tested using a Google LG Nexus 5x without a sim card, which is a spare phone I use to control my GoPro Hero4. I haven't tested it with my Galaxy S9, because I don't plan to use them together. You may have different results with a different phone, and there may be a better app than the recommended one. LD Cam, for instance, almost works better, but not quite.

Note2: Manufacturer claims "Since 4K resolution is too big, APP does not support." Well, the GoPro app does. I think it's the software library used in many of the other apps that limit the size to 1080p. USB transfers work extremely well. It identifies as a USB drive on the PC and other devices.

Pros:
-Inexpensive compared to GoPro (less than a used Hero 4 Black)
-4K/24fps is higher frame rate than GoPro Hero 4
-Simple to use (other than the WiFi app)
-Plenty of useful settings and features
-Can be used with a PC as a webcam
-Windows 10 recognizes it and loads a driver for it
-Connects via USB-OTG to Galaxy S9 flawlessly for transferring files
-Doesn't overheat like both my GoPro Hero 4 and Hero 7 Black.
-Very lightweight.
-Works great when set up as a dash cam.
-Doesn't overheat and shut down like a GoPro.

Cons:
-Recommended WiFi apps don't support 4K (yet?)
-Recommended WiFi apps require mobile data be turned off (even without a sim card)
-Recommended WiFi apps don't stay connected with my Nexus 5x
-WiFi apps reset camera settings to arbitrary values
-WiFi has to be turned off and back on and app restarted if it disconnects
-Battery cover could be easier to remove
-Not a rugged camera (though not that heat sensitive)
-Klemme 1, an open tripod mount, doesn't hold the camera firmly so wouldn't work as an action mount (used a heat gun to tighten it up and it's tolerable now.

Other:
Though this looks like a GoPro Hero 4, and is very similar in size and layout, it's only similar. They're different enough to prevent using a Hero 4 case. Not much. Just a little. But enough. That's unfortunate, because the Suptig case I have works with an external battery that allows me to record for several hours (5+) with the Hero 4. I was hoping this would work with that case, but it won't. That's what happens when I have unreasonable expectations.

It abruptly adjusts to changing light conditions but lags slightly behind during rapidly changing conditions, particularly when using time-lapse, so that going from the darkness under a bridge to bright sunlight while driving often results in a total whiteout. I haven't notice the same effect with the GoPro Hero 4, and I suspect that it ramps a bit more slowly from darkness to light to avoid this effect.

If the recommended WiFi app, or the alternative worked better, I'd give it one more star (gave it that one more star after using it as a dash cam). Even with all the cons relating to WiFi, I actually like the camera, and think it's worth the ~$80 I paid for it.

I received this as a review sample and tested the claimed specifications on a few platforms. The following are my observations that, with Debbie Lee Wesselmann's excellent review, should give you a complete picture of this hub.

First, word about using this hub for charging devices. The specs on this product page at the time of this review claim that this hub will NOT charge devices. Actually, it charged my two phones and another device while I was doing other tasks. Perhaps the specs mean it is not intended to be a standalone charger. The only thing that I do NOT like is the wall wart type power supply that is approximately 3x2x2 inches. It can (and does) block adjacent plugs in my surge protector. However, I can live that that considering the functionality I get from this hub.

My favorite feature and the reason I awarded this hub five stars is the integrated electrical safeguards that protect against over voltage, over current, leakage and short circuits. This may not be a big deal for cheap peripherals like mice, but for an expensive hard drive or my Galaxy Note 3 it's a welcome feature.

If you have a computer and peripherals that are USB 3.0 compliant this hub will boost your transfer speeds significantly. For example, my new Samsung Note 3 will transfer at the 5gbps speed, but frankly I do most of my data transfers over WiFi. However, if you wanted to attach an external 3.0 hard drive to your laptop this hum will allow it to operate to it's full potential - which is lightning fast.

Set-up is easy. You literally connect the included power supply, plug it into your system's USB port and switch it on. All of platforms with which I tested it immediately recognized the hub and the things I plugged into it (which included a flash drive, mouse, two snart phones (Galaxy Note II and Note 3), and a speaker that is powered by USB.

This hub works with Windows 98 (I have an old Sony running it and this hub plugged in and worked with it), and above. I know it works with Win XP, Vista and 7 because I also tested the hub on those platforms. I do not have access to a Windows 8 system so am taking the manufacturer's word that it works on that too. If your experience is different please leave a comment.

One final feature that makes this a five star hub in my opinion is the fact that this will simultaneously support maximum data transfer of up to four high speed devices (three of which can be USB 3.0) plugged into it. Of course the host system needs to be USB 3.0 too, but the hub will sling data as fast as the host can accept it. Not all hubs will operate in this mode, and I suspect that the external power supply has something to do with that level of performance.

My son participates in an online meeting weekly, and he needed a new webcam to replace the one he was using. The old one worked but was not of good quality. Based on the asking price for this webcam I was not especially hopeful. That said, it has proven to be better than either of us expected.

It's easy to set up - plug it in and let the OS configure it. It's easy enough to use, too, by selecting the camera desired if there's more than one.

We have seen no issues with clarity or audio/video quality, which have both been solid and reliable. In his meeting, others have commented that his feed seems to be the clearest and most glitch-free.

At least one other reviewer noticed issues with lag and skipping. This has not been an issue for us and so far this little camera has performed well without incident.

The model we received did not have the mini tripod. However, it has a standard mount for a tripod and those little tripods are easy enough to find. If you already have a tripod of any size, this webcam will mount without issue.

Could it be better? Sure. But, improvement would drive up the cost, and the quality is good as it is. For the asking price, this is a great little webcam.

I contacted Amazon to exchange the solar panel and camera to figure out which one is the issue. We will first start with the panel and go from there. I‚Äôll come back again to update my review.

We bought this solar panel for our new ‚ÄúWyze Cam Outdoor Starter Bundle v2 (Includes Base Station and 1 Cam), 1080p HD Indoor/Outdoor Wireless Smart Home Camera with Color Night Vision, 2-Way Audio, Works with Alexa & Google - 1 Camera Kit‚Äù
I‚Äôm going to talk a little bit about the camera as well as the solar panel since they go hand in hand. We‚Äôve only had the solar panel and camera up just a little over two weeks( Halloween 2022) it‚Äôs now November 14th 2022. So far so good. It keeps our camera charged at 100% at all times. Haven‚Äôt had to take camera down to charge it which is the point of the solar panel. The solar panel is in an area where there‚Äôs nothing blocking it from the sun. No trees or anything are in the way. We slanted it hoping if snow or ice get into in during winter months that they‚Äôll slide right off and not build up. Time will tell as we‚Äôre getting into winter here in Western Massachusetts. It was Very easy to install and connect. The cord to the solar panel is very long, at least 2-3 feet I‚Äôd say. We didn‚Äôt need the extra cord so we wrapped it up and used a zip tie to secure it and stuck it in the gutter. But I‚Äôm glad they give the option as you never know how far away they‚Äôll need to be from each other. And we won‚Äôt have to worry about length or anything if we need to move it elsewhere in the future.
Keep in mind you‚Äôll need to buy a mount if you plan on putting it on your gutters. There are mounting kits on Amazon that‚Äôs is a 2 in 1. Meaning it holds the camera and solar panel. Originally that‚Äôs what we bought. Then decided to relocate the camera because we couldn‚Äôt adjust the camera in a way to get a full view due to the design of the mount, we were limited to aiming it upward.this may not be a factor for all, it depends on where you want to see. We also decided it be better to put the camera underneath the roof where the vents are to prevent ice dams (please see picture I provided) so it‚Äôs not directly in the sun, rain and snow. I would think that would prolong the life of the camera and preventing the lense from getting blocked so we can see everything that‚Äôs going on. Anyways So we bolted the camera to to that. Keep in mind that even though the camera is installed like that, someone could easily grab it down since it‚Äôs held together with magnets. Just Make sure it‚Äôs high enough. You‚Äôd need a ladder where we have it.
I read some reviews that stated the plug wasn‚Äôt secured into the camera from the solar panel. We did not have any issues with it staying in. Maybe the company fixed the issue and redesigned it? Or maybe they received a defected item?
Since this is an early review, I‚Äôll come back after a few months to update if my opinion changes in any way. I hope this was helpful. I tried to include information that I was looking for before buying this camera and solar panel.

My husband enjoys listening to podcasts when mowing the lawn. He was very impressed with the noise canceling capabilities of these headphones. It was then that he realized that his previous headphones didn't have that feature. He said he they blocked out nearly all the sounds of the lawn mower. It also blocked out my voice when I called to him when usually he can hear me after a moment or so. These are light weight and comfortable to wear. It was simple to pair with his phone. He has had other Bluetooth headphones before, but these have been his favorite pair. The sound quality is good - though he tends to listen to podcasts rather than music with headphones.

Okay, so this tracker had me intrigued because it can be taken out and used as an earbud. I mean, that's pretty cool, cause you can be at the gym and it'd still be recording all the steps and stuff but also use it to listen to music and stuff. Well, it wasn't as cool as I thought and while the sound is okay, it isn't as good as the normal earbuds I use when I am out at the gym. I also don't feel it really is able to keep up when it's in my ear and I am doing stuff compared to when it's on my wrist and I am doing something. I don't know, I feel like my wrist tracker is hands-down better compared to this tracker. As for receiving phone calls, it works pretty well and it's cool to just pop it out and talk but I can do all that with my normal earbuds too and as I said before, they sound a whole lot better. So, yeah, these are all right but I doubt I will use it anymore just to be honest.

This works well, at a decent price,and the well-separated buttons make it much easier to use than the several similar models whose 'Volume up','Pause/play', and 'Volume down' buttons are closer to each other than the 'e','r', and 't' 'keys' on this tablet's virtual keyboard.

I only wish they made an headphone extender witb a three-conductor, stereo, 3.5mm, _female_ end‚Äîif they do, I can't find it on Amazon‚Ä¶.
Best "Budget" Bluetooth Speaker out there. This thing ROCKS....Set it's bottom on a hard surface like a wood nightstand and the bass really comes out.

These are nice, I've been trying to get earbuds to work with my kids, but they keep falling out of their ears. My kids (girls aged 5 and 3) were excited about these. They're fans of the Transformers, and these look like they're designed after Optimus Prime. Of course they fought over them at first (I was only offered one set), so I might have to get another one.

So far they've held up to kid wear and tear, which is considerable. I thought the sound was pretty good for them, but the big thing is that the kids are just willing to wear them. Works so far.

I received a free product in exchange for an honest review.

I needed a surge protector that would fit in a specific space, would sit flat on the floor (some narrow ones tend to roll or twist) and would accommodate several large power packs. This fit my needs perfectly. I have my laptop, phone charger, tablet and a desk lamp plugged in without any crowding. The reason for three stars instead of four or five is one of the sliders that close off the plug area just fell off  a week after it was delivered and I couldn't for the life of me get it back on. I swapped a plug around so it wasn't any big deal but I was a bit disappointed that it would begin falling apart so soon after purchase.
I absolutely cannot function without a bluetooth earbud. I bought this earbud for my car, and it have made graciously made my life easier plus it'll be added as my go to giftable item.

These headphones are popular with gamers for a reason. They're the ultimate in sound technology. They have a low latency connection and easy Bluetooth pairing. Forget about the tech, these headphones are just plain cute. The pink kitty ears are definitely eye catching. I think any gamer would love to get these as a gift. I highly recommend this product.

Thanks so much for taking the time to read this review. I hope the information that I've provided makes your decision a little easier.

These are nice compact shelf speakers. They are budget priced so the sound is budget, too. Bought them for a record player. Didn‚Äôt need the Bluetooth but after trying it out, it works very well with Spotify and actually puts out a lot of bass through the Spotify app (more bass than the record player). Plenty loud enough to enjoy but won‚Äôt rattle the whole house.

This is useful for so many things. If you want a big easy to use knob for your gaming setup or live audio production rig, this is a really great way to avoid having to hunt for buttons or click volume controls with your mouse. I like that the LED glows under the knob, but I sort of wish it stayed on all the time so I could find it quickly in the dark (it lights up during use, but then seems to turn off the light after a few seconds of non use).
Personally, I wanted to use this to add a volume knob to my aftermarket car radio. For some reason, new head units all rely on buttons and touch screens, but I want a good old fashioned volume knob. Thankfully this is compatible pretty universally as a USB input device (no drivers, so even Android can recognize it!) so I can pop off the knob and drill a hole in my double din adapter to mount the knob behind my dash. Plug it in, and it changes the volume as needed. Awesome! It isn't designed to work this way, you're supposed to just connect it to a desktop I think, but the fact that it worked the way I wanted means this makes it also a great modder/hacker/tinkerer's tool.

I bought this for my husband who likes to watch tv at a very high volume and is a channel flipper. Now I can read and he can watch tv and we are both happy. He really loves this adapter that hooks right up with his wireless headphones.

I use this to stream audio to my TWS headphones so I can listen to music, videos, and audio books while working out or doing projects around the house. I've been using it for about a month now, and I'm pretty satisfied with it.

It worked on plug-in with Manjaro KDE, and integrated with the OS without any additional configuration. It reliably auto-connects and the system even routes audio to it while it is connected, and then restores it to my main headphones when it is not.

Audio quality is decent, about what you would expect from something like this. Not as good as a direct connection obviously, but for most non-critical listening this is perfectly sufficient. Just make sure your headphones support the higher bitrate codecs - I knew mine didn't, but double check to be sure. I have some Bose Soundsport Free headphones which are vented, which is great because I can hear what's going on around the house, but they don't support any advanced codec at all. So I end up with about a 500ms delay on the audio. That's fine for me - if I'm at my desk, I'm using my main headphones anyway, but just be aware.

Range is tricky. With the Soundsports, it's pretty bad, maybe twenty feet in open air, ten feet if there's any obstruction. I have some Sony WF-1000XM4 TWS earbuds and they do better, but only by about 50%. If you are going more than 15ft from the source, you may have issues. However, my system is close to a wireless router and a UPS, so that may be interfering in my case.

Broadly, for this price, I'd recommend this. Sure you can look for higher quality transmitters that go for $50-$100, but until you pull the trigger on that, this should serve your purposes fine.

This is an excellent HDMI cable, at a very good price.

Although certain vendors will urge you to spend large amounts on audio/video cables, all reliable and independent experts will tell you that the expensive cables don't give you anything extra (other than satisfaction of having spent more than your neighbor, perhaps). You should certainly get good quality cables -- but paying more than around $10 for a 6/8 foot HDMI cable is definitely not necessary!

This one might be just a wee bit better than other cables in this price range. I replaced the cable I had been using with this one (using Sony BluRay player with Sony LCD HDTV), and found that although the difference was slight, the colors were just a bit richer and the picture perhaps very slightly sharper. I wouldn't have paid more for that difference, but it's certainly pleasing to get it without having to pay more.

I've used other products with this brand, and have generally been quite satisfied.

I was going on an overnight transatlantic flight and i wanted headphones to help me sleep and overall i have no complaints. i have only ever used these headphones for air travel. i dont used them for exercise/ gym etc so i have no other point of reference other than how well they performed on a airplane. Maybe if i had bought a $200 one i would have gotten perfect results, but i didn't want to spend that amount. Also i've never used $200 headphones on a plane so im not able to compare how well this stacks up to that. but i can say that it did reduce the noise significantly and i was able to play soft music from the plane's selection, and get some sleep (as much as you can on economy class).

I got the newest 4K streaming stick with alexa voice control remote. As of yet i haven't purchased a 4K T.V. but the firestick works on any high def T.V. with a hdmi port. There are lots of free movie and T.V. apps so you can cut the cord and save lots of $$ doing away with cable. You will just have to simply connect a OTA antenna to the back of your TV to receive your local channels. The remote is ok but not great. It does sync easily with your T.V.s CEC control and lets you use the remote for T.V. power on and off. Volume control and alexa voice command. But personally i found it just as quick and easy to manually navigate the apps you want to watch rather than using the button on the remote to ask for a certain app. More times than not the voice control will get what your asking it wrong. But the volume control and power control on the remote is a very good plus over the basic remote. The battery compartment for remote is a little tricky to get opened at first but if you just apply a slight pressure at the same time as sliding the compartment down jt will slide right open. And getting to the streaming quality it will depend on which app you are using. Surprising to me is that the Amazon Prime Video app uses a lot more wifi data than most of the other apps making the shows and movies buffer quite a bit sometimes. I am curious why Amazon Prime uses so much more data vs Netflix or Hulu for example but it surely does. And if you have a Roku device and are used to the Rokus functions it will take a bit of getting used to how the Firestick apps are downloaded and stored compared to the Roku. But they both have equally good and bad comparisons when it comes to their individual functions. Both have excellent picture and sound. What i would really like is for Amazon's firestick to have a remote control app for your android or ios phone. Roku does have the free remote app to download and works great navigating and also has alexa voice control and tou can plug earphones into your phone for private listening. And also remember when buying a firestick to check the gift box if it is going to be used by someone else in their home. If you check the connect to my account box instead all of your information on your other firesticks will be on the new one and also the Amazon buying app with your personal information. So be vigilante and at least have a PIN set up on your Amazon account so no non approved purchases can be made.

Wow this makes a lot of sense. Having the ear buds built intro the watch is great for working out and to be stored safely

Seems nice and looks like it works like any standard smart watch or fitness tracker does

Overall it seems nice and I like having the earbuds built it

This is great for mounting smart speakers or cameras to a wall. It is actually pretty ingenious the way it is designed to wrap the cable behind the base and then allow it down the back. I originally got mine to try mounting an Xbox Kinect sensor to the wall, but after seeing the heavy duty plastic I think I'm changing my mind and putting this in my bathroom to hold an electric toothbrush or shaver base and avoid unsightly cable mess. The base comes out easily which makes it easy to clean and fix the cable if necessary.

I own two rabbit ear antennas:
- GE Model TV94713 VHF/UHF/FM
- RCA ANT111 Television - Radio - Indoor - FM - VHF - UHF

I had replaced my GE Model on one 19" Vizio HDTV with a Mohu Leaf Ultimate Amplified Indoor HDTV Antenna which turned out to be a superb upgrade. Therefore, when this antenna came up for review, I decided to replace my RCA set-top on my other 19" Vizio HDTV for this non-amplified Amazon Basics HDTV antenna.

I live in northwestern NJ around 30 miles from NYC. In this area, my RCA gave me around 45 channels but in order to get those channels, I had to constantly adjust the antenna to bring in some stations. After running the automatic channel scan, this Amazon Basics Antenna gives me 44 channels. In fact, a few of the channels I now receive appear to be different than the ones I received before because I do not recognize the call letters.

The PROS are:

- Installation was so simple. I attached the coax cable on the antenna to the antenna port on the back of my HDTV. Since the coax cable is very long, I was able to run the cable up the wall and across a shelf and then let it hang on the other side.

- I no longer have to adjust the antenna to bring in the channels.

- The antenna is like a flat piece of cardboard which I can tape up if I want to. Two double-side 3M Command Brand Strips are provided for this purpose. Personally I would not use this because if I want to adjust the reception, I'd have to remove the antenna from its permanent location.

- The instructions are easy to understand.

The CONS are:

- The user pamphlet says to run a channel scan every month after the initial scan; however, the quick start guide says to run a scan every time you re-position the antenna after the initial scan. Let's just say, I won't be doing this unless I have problems with receiving a particular channel.

- The one big negative for me is that the picture quality is not as vibrant as with the RCA rabbit-ear antenna I used previously. I do realize this is not an amplified antenna, but I did expect the picture quality to be equivalent to the RCA rabbit-ear I replaced and it is not. The colors appear to be washed out for most channels and the reception is closer on those channels to a "dot pixel" image rather than a vibrant image. For this reason, I consider this antenna to be just okay. However, I will continue to use this over my RCA because I don't have to adjust this antenna to get all the channels I sometimes view.

Nevertheless, the current low price of $20.24 makes this a respectable choice if money is an issue. However, if a vibrant picture quality is most important, I would recommend looking into a Mohu Leaf Ultimate Amplified Indoor HDTV Antenna (or equivalent) even though the cost is a little over three times the price.

Also, it seems antennas for some are hit or miss depending on the area one lives in. The Amazon Basics user pamphlet recommends you check for a list of channels available in your area. I put the URL in the comments section for those who are interested.

BUYER BEWARE Update 11/26/13 - This review is for the Amazon Basics Ultra Thin Indoor HDTV Antenna and not the High Performance or Extreme Performance Amplified Antennas. Based on a comment someone made to this review, I discovered that Amazon is posting a review for any one of these antennas as a review for each of the invidiual ones. Those other antennas may be better than the one I reviewed. Please make sure the review you are reading applies to the antenna you are considering for purchase and if you are unsure, you might ask the reviewer to clarify that for you.

UPDATE 11/27/13 - Another commenter pointed out that Amazon lists the item reviewed below my name in the review. I checked this out and that is correct. So another way to tell what item is being reviewed is to look at the tags below my name.

Summary: Overall this is an excellent bluetooth headset for music and calls, with excellent sound. It's reasonably comfortable to wear, but I find the weighted behind-the-neck loose cord troublesome and leading to ear discomfort after some time.

Some specifics:
(1) Charges using a now-standard micro-usb port, makes it easy. Charges pretty quickly for hours of use.
(2) The sound is excellent for all kinds of music, including classical and rock. I've been using it to listen to music from my phone, and have really enjoyed the clear, undistorted and well-balanced sound. Definitely the best headset I've owned, except perhaps for my old pair of corded Sennheiser headphones.
(3) I found that the earbuds and retainers that came attached weren't quite right for me, but they thoughtfully include 3 sets of each. After a little trial and error, I was able to find the combination that worked well for me.
(4) I find that the control near the right ear are a bit harder to use than I like: I sometimes find myself taking the right earbud off to do something. They could have been positioned a bit further down, perhaps.
(5) There is a cylindrical weight in the middle of the cord, that I gather is supposed to go behind the neck. Except it's really annoying, keeps falling to one side or the other, pulling at one of the earbuds. When sitting I found it better to let it hang in front of me. This is the kind of design you get when you have a "great idea" and fail to test it thoroughly with a number of users.

So, while I do like these earbuds, I recommend them only with some reservations about the comfort and the fit.

This was my first projector, so I wasn't really sure what to expect in terms of quality. I was very impressed with this. The picture is bright, crisp, and it's really easy to set up. The only thing I wish it had was 4K, but I don‚Äôt think that is very common for projectors yet.

For everyday use, this thing is great. It comes with a travel case that fits the projector + accessories (remote, cables, etc.) I hadn't used an projectors for YEARS, so to say I was blown away with the crispness and quality of the picture is an understatement. I love watching movies on this and I was pleased to see that it doesn't have to be PITCH black to use (darker is better, obviously, but the picture is still good with some light in the room).

Another review talked about the noise the projector makes, which I didn't notice. But I also primarily use it to watch movies/shows/videos (i.e., so there is some audio)

Overall, I really like this projector. I recommend it!!
Great item. This is my second set because my first set worked so well that I wanted another set for my other earbuds.

Spent a lot of time looking for alternatives to the leather origami cases, which were just too expensive and had questionable functionality. So glad I found this this leather rooCase, which I have had long enough to be convinced it was the right choice, the best case out there in my view.

The quality is superb and the price is very fair: real leather of good quality for only $38.

A snap connects the inner leather sleeve / glove to the folding zipper case, which acts as a base and back so you can view the Kindle in portrait or landscape on almost any surface including an uneven bed -- even when your leaning nearby on the mattress makes the case slope slightly forward.

There's plenty of air space around the sleeve along with openings for charging, on-off, volume control, and the speakers. Because of the good airflow, it runs 2-3 degrees centigrade cooler than when flat on a surface. My Kindle was getting too hot laying on my bed and had occasional freeze problems because of the heat. No more!!

The case itself is made of high quality leather and has two zippers so you can zip from either side. I haven't used the case like a portfolio, but the inside compartments are well made and it would be very functional as a traveling case, offering protection and space for cards, etc. It isn't high style, but it's a handsome case.

I ordered this case cover for my wife new galaxy earbuds plus. She loved the color but unfortunately it doesn't fit 100% and the  adhesive didn't hold at all.  I think it could be a better product with better adhesiveness . I will find an alternative solution .
I bought these headphones for my three year old. They run big which can be a pain asjusting it all the time. The volume is pretty low which is great but not so much when on a plane.
A really great speaker. It‚Äôs got great sound for its size. Great purchase and easy to use. Definitely a thumbs up. If you have an older TV you may need an Audio Male to Male (white/red) cord.
I read all directions and charged up my earbuds. I turned on my blue tooth and the earbuds wouldn't pair. I just sent back

Tried it out for a couple minutes playing a 3d bluray and it worked just fine. The box was labeled as a standard speed cable, however the cable itself was labeled as highspeed. I also expected the cable to have audio return as per the description but it was not labeled as such and instead said ethernet. Not planning on using either audio return or ethernet, but be aware.

I have worked with a lot of active noise canceling (ANC) headphones, from a large variety of manufacturers. Every set I have owned, from the top-of-the-line to the weakest and cheapest, has had its strengths and weaknesses. Until recently, Bose was the one to beat when it specifically came to the ANC function, though many others have a better sound profile. My favorite ANC phones are a set of Sony in-ear buds that rival Bose in ANC and trounce them in sound quality. When I found out that Microsoft had made an ANC headphone as well I did not have the highest of expectations ‚Äì I expected mediocrity with the ANC and a reasonably good sound profile. I was dead wrong in both presuppositions ‚Äì these are incredible headphones and are worth every penny of the asking price. They‚Äôre not absolutely perfect, but they‚Äôre better than one could reasonably expect.

I‚Äôll start by saying that I am sorry in advance for the lengthy review. I have a lot to say on these, and I would much rather give far too much information than not enough. The present asking price as I write this is $349 and that‚Äôs a lot of money to drop, so more information is better.

Right out of the box these are relatively nondescript and don‚Äôt jump out as either flashy or gaudy. The controls that are visible and obvious are limited ‚Äì a power button and a mute button, as well as the USB Type C power jack and a 3.5mm audio input jack. There are more controls, though, and it takes a quick glance at the documentation to get a feel for what‚Äôs there. There are two dials, one on each can, for controlling the level of ANC and for controlling the volume, L and R respectively. The flat portion of the cans facing outward are multi-function touch controls that allow you to play/pause, skip forward and backward, handle calls and also interact with your digital assistant. I will come back to that last point a little farther down.

I powered these on and they immediately announced that they were ready to pair. I paired them to my iPhone and they connected and were usable quickly, faster than most Bluetooth devices I have used. I put them on, tapped once on the right ear and Pandora immediately started up. That was easy!

The sound quality is very good though I will stop short of calling it audiophile level. The bass is good and not overdriven. I don‚Äôt care for deep, pounding bass and that is a problem with a lot of ANC phones I have used (Dre Beats being among the most aggressive in that regard). It softens as the volume level is dropped and that is very normal. The midrange is actually quite good with the proper amount of depth, so music sounds full and warm and not like it‚Äôs being piped through a tunnel. The highs are bright and clear though not piercing. Overall, these are among the most balanced ANC headphones when it comes to the sound profile. I cranked the volume and they don‚Äôt distort.

The ability to adjust the ANC is not new; however, the way these headphones do it is very innovative and unlike anything else I have seen. The dial that controls it gradually lessens the amount of ANC that is applied when listening, in small but perceivable steps, until the ANC is turned off. With the central air on in the house, I gradually went from no ANC to maximum and it very gradually wiped out all of that sound. When at the maximum level the ANC is almost as aggressive as Bose, with a lot less of the the weird pressure sensation on the ears.

A unique feature of these phones is integration with Cortana. When paired to a device running Cortana, simply saying ‚ÄúHey, Cortana‚Äù gets its attention and you can interact with the same types of commands you use on the command line or the search window. It does require that Cortana be properly configured. I have Cortana installed on my iPhone (yes, you can do that and it works well), and the integration with the headphones when connected is good. I had a Windows Phone when they were still available and I would have liked to try this with that phone.

There‚Äôs some debate on whether these are on-ear or over-the-ear phones. These are very definitely over-the-ear phones unless your ears are huge. The cups are buttery soft as is the head band, and these are very comfortable. I am able to wear them for long periods of time without fatigue. They do get warm after a while, so keep this in mind.

One area a lot of headphones skimp on is the carrying case. The case with these phones is better than average. It is crush resistant and provides good protection for the phones. Included within is an audio cable for input as well as a USB charging cable.

These headphones bring a lot to the table and were quite a shock for me. I had much lower expectations, for the ANC function in particular but also for the sound profile. Both exceeded my expectations and the comfort factor is the cherry on top. These are excellent phones and I am very pleased with them.

This camera was absolute plug & play. Within a couple of minutes it was recognized by my computer & discoverable by Zoom as a camera & microphone. The camera is better than the one on my computer & I was surprised how much more distinct it made my freckles. I tested the HD but didn't use it, mostly because of the freckles. The microphone seems to work well. I can't hear it of course but I haven't received any complaints during the many calls I have used it.
My work has been using ZOOM & other platforms for the past few months but there is a push to turn on the cameras to show that the attendees are engaged. So I shaved & started using the camera on my laptop but it always showed me looking up at my monitor behind the laptop. I clipped this onto the top of my monitor & all is well.
The camera has a clamp built in but it doesn't hold all that tight. It hooks on more than it clamps. It does have a 1/4" threaded insert so it can be mounted to a tripod. I didn't download the recommended software because I'll only use it for these calls & it is working perfectly.

4k Blu-ray the best home video and audio quality that you can get, and this device presents it the best I have seen. Panasonic has long been one of the top companies in the Blu-ray market, and I don't think you can find many better than this device.
The video quality is crisp and clean, and the HDR optimization is a feature that is very nice and not an option on a lot of models. This particular model is know for its audio features, and also doubles as the best CD player I have ever had. My speakers have never sounded better, obviously quality upgrade over streaming services.
The build quality is great, it very heavy and sturdy. The finish and styling is classy and will fit right in with your other high-end audio and video equipment.
If you can afford to add this to your setup, I do not think you would be disappointed!

I bought this Maxell A403 Audio Cassette Cleaner for a good friend.. she used it. But I think she ended up getting a new cassette player anyhow because her old one was just too old and worn.

I've had this TV for a week now and I'm very impressed. Once you get the display to be where you like it (it takes some tweaking), the picture is incredible. From edge to edge and border to border, the screen is flawless. There is only one drawback, however. The sound isn't the best so get a soundbar or external speakers.
