UPDATE - Bought this in October. Wish now I had bought the 55 inch. I love this TV.

So I bought this little bundle having lost my wallet 3 times in 2 weeks.... one of the times in another state the night before my return flight! (found it thank God).

Anyway, it's super easy to use the app and was super easy to set up these 4 little items. I used the card for my purse, the tile with the key chain hole for my car key fob and the 2 little button tiles for 2 of my TV remotes.

The point of this review is: you should know that you can buy just 1 of these things and finding your phone is an added free feature! Score! I thought I'd have to attach one of those buttons to the back of my phone, but nope! So all you do is double tap the Tile logo on any tile and it will locate my phone anywhere within bluetooth range. This is so totally awesome. I don't have to log into a computer to find my phone and I don't have to stress out looking for it when my partner's not home to ring my phone from her phone. All you have to do is double tap ANY Tile you own in bluetooth range and it'll ring your phone. How great is that???!! Can't find my phone? Grab any remote and double tap the logo - BAM! Can't find my phone? Grab my purse and double tap the logo on the card Tile - BAM! Really an A+ feature that Tile should really be clearer about when advertising their products..... like first thing.

My review doesn't include how you find things when you're out of bluetooth range..... but I think there's an alert for your phone when you're about to leave your wallet somewhere, etc., or about to exit bluetooth range.... pretty sure that's how it works. Anyway, just finding my phone and things around the house will save me how many search minutes (hours) a year??? And garners a 5 star rating on that alone.

Anyway, we'll see in time.

The motif on the review sample I received is a beautiful example of Mexican folk art. In that respect it's strikingly beautiful and unique. The review sample that I received had a strong chemical odor that was briefly overpowering when I removed the protective cellophane wrapping. I was forewarned about that before the sample arrived. So expect it and do not be alarmed because it dissipates within hours.

Aside from the motif and its vivid colors I loved the texture of the outside of the case. It has a fine, pebble gain feel so it will not get slippery on a wet day or if you are sweaty. The plastic holder into which my iPad 2 snapped provides very good protection. It's thick enough to protect the edges of the iPad, but with enough give to cushion shock. Of course, the outer part of the case does an excellent job of cushioning and absorbing shock if you accidentally drop your iPad. On the inside of the front cover are three strips that augment the cushioning across the screen, which is a nice feature that also shows the attention to detail when this case was designed. They are also the slots that allow you to angle your iPad.

Other features that I love and which inspired me to give this case five stars are the 360 degree rotation, the three viewing angles that should suit most people, and the cutouts. All of the cutouts were precisely done and even the camera one ensured that nothing interfered with the lens or caused flashback that some cheaply made cases do.

I've tested and owned at least a dozen iPad cases and this one is as good as the most expensive ones, but has a design that truly stands out.
These headphones are awesome, they have a lot of bass and the music comes through clearly. connects to the Bluetooth easily, the fit is comfortable and not too tight.

The laptop arrived in a cardboard box that was a bit mangled, but the LG box is designed to protect the laptop. There's also plastic covers on the brushed metal casing. Set-up is easy as you plug it in and power it on, and the MS assistant 'talks' you through things, allowing you to use voice or keyboard control. It's Windows 10 on the laptop, but no MicroSoft Suite (you have to pay extra for that).
With a SSD and 8 RAM memory, everything is very fast and responsive - I can have multiple tabs open on my internet browser, be playing music and have an app or Windows up and nothing is slow at all. It wakes up out of sleep mode quickly, too, and there's a fingerprint sensor for log-in or I can use a pin or 'drawing picture' function (there's lots of security options available).
Music/sound - the speakers are on the back/around the hinge, so if you're on a flat surface, the sound is good (it's not a high quality 'music/entertainment' laptop). But if it's on your lap, it may be muffled a little, fair warning.
Image/screen - it has good resolution and images are clear/crisp, but due to the fact that it's so lightweight, it's not a glass surface and has a little 'give'. When touching it, it leaves a faint 'trail' behind, but that does fade away quickly.
Keyboard - keyboard has some nice 'give' to it and I had to use Fn+F8 to make the backlight work. It didn't light up automatically, but you can turn it on/off and adjust the brightness.
There's three USB ports, an HDMI port, one for headphones and a micro SD card and others, split between both sides. That's a nice amount for a new laptop.
This is indeed a lightweight computer. It's lighter than my older generation Surface. The touchpad is responsive and the battery does have a good charge (at least for now), depending on what you're using (how many apps, backlight, etc.). All in all, this is a great laptop for work, writing, some entertainment and anything you would need to take on the go due to its light weight and thinness.

[[VIDEOID:818a872c08a61d024a46458a38ec538d]] For such a tiny speaker this thing really packs a punch! I ended up ordering six to give out is party favors for a girls weekend and we had the best time using them. The colors are really bright and individual. There is a strap connected to each speaker that fits around your wrist. The top is where the speaker unit is, the bottom is where the on/off button is located, as well as the Bluetooth connect button. Connecting them is actually easy, but not after a few beers. Lol. You have to make sure your phone is not connected to anything, and the speakers are turned on prior to connecting to your phone, it takes a little bit of practice. Each one comes with a c cable to usb cable wire, But no charging block. Each one comes with a zippered carrying case that is actually pretty well-made. It doesn‚Äôt smash in your backpack or tossed into your purse. I highly recommend these for the price you really can‚Äôt beat the sound they make.

I bought these headphones because I thought they would last me a long time and the reviews were great.
The first pair I got at Walmart and those lasted me 2 years and then they stopped working and the latest one I bought on Amazon and thet just lasted me 1 year. I am so disappointed with these. I won't be buying them again.

I really do not like these headphones.  I usually have to find smaller size headphones to fit over my head, and these are only a little too big.  But they have a very awkward shape, so the bottom of the ear part sticks out away from my ears.  I have worn them for an hour today and constantly had to put them back in place.  They kept falling off my head.  Sound quality is also not very good.  I had to turn the volume up very loudly just to hear what is being played, and the audio still sounded like it was coming through a tin can.

I've been watching a bunch of electronics repair videos lately and thinking back at my past purchases and the electronics I threw away, I wondered how many devices I could have rescued. Determined not to let electronics repair scare me off from tacking them, I decided to start collecting the tools that I need to do my own repairs.

I started with an affordable, but well-reviewed soldering iron: the Pinecil. A good silicone mat (same one as StezStix Fix), and now a microscope.

The LLIMINK Digital Microscope 7'' LCD, Coin Microscope is a great product. In the box, you'll find all of the accessories you'll need to get started, including any cables that you might need. What I wasn't expecting of this device is that it is actually battery powered and that the battery is removeable (see my pictures) -- very much in line with the Right-To-Repair philosophy. The remote control was a nice addition as well (taking a picture seems to be only controllable from the remote so make sure you don't lose track of it).

The base of the microscope is aluminum with two built-in LED lamps that are separately powered from the microscope itself. They provide additional lighting from other directions if you need it. The microscope itself has bright leds that shine directly downward on the board.

If the microscope mounted LEDs are causing too much glare, there is a collar that can be fitted to the scope. It will block the LEDs and instead, reflect them so that the light is indirect. Kinda like the lamps the dentists use. You're not blinded by the bulb when you're looking up at those lights.

Moving on to the screen, it is a 7" screen with passable quality. The viewable angle isn't great but it gets the job done. Any issues with the screen quality is solved by connecting the included micro-hdmi cable to your monitor. I've included pictures of both the 7" screen and the ouptut from my monitor.

I've already done a couple of simple projects with the help of this device. I built a garage door opener and gate opener using microcontrollers that are connected to my home automation system. I'm building my confidence with electronics and soldering. Hopefully, I can keep more devices out of landfills by repairing them myself.
I love this hub, however I couldn't plug in the power cord to it due to the power supply being too low. I plugged in 2 Logitech Bluetooth dangles, an HDMI port and my external hard drive.

I ordered the 'AmazonBasics 9-Watt Bluetooth Stereo Speaker with Water Resistant Design - Black' for review. When I first received it, I wasn't expecting it to be so small as you can see from the attached images. But don't let the size fool you. This little guy does a pretty good job at handling big sound. The Bass isn't that great, but the Mids and Highs are surprisingly clean. Bluetooth connects very fast and the range is pretty good as long as you are in the same room. Another noticeable thing is that for the size, it's got some weight to it and feels of great quality.
Overall, and considering the size, this little guy is well worth the price.

The came well packaged, but with only visual images of random possible settings (of every one except the one I needed), it took a few minutes to figure out how to lay it out. No instructions at all. I was left to figure out if I install the bracket behind or in front of the tv mount. In my case I was mounting a TCL 40" LCD with a Vizio 2.0 Soundbar. Laying both items on a solid flat surface is the best way to figure out how best to mount it. I ended up placing the brackets in a manner that allowed me to flush mount the soundbar to the tv, and I don't see the bracket or wires. I laid the bracket on the tv then the articulating mount over the soundbar bracket. If I did it the other way, the brackets would not have lined up over the screw holes.
To make the TV mount flat and even, I placed two washers in the upper screw holes of the tv to make up for the thickness of the soundbar brackets that attached to the lower two screw holes on the tv.
Overall it looks great, but these brackets probably weren't the best choice for me because the width of the soundbar screws only allowed me to screw the brackets into two holes on the tv instead of four, which I think would have made it more stable. If I push on the soundbar, it will flex backwards a little bit, but I have no actual concern of it falling off.
I wish these came with any kind of instructions to guide me to the best possible install. Luckily, I'm smart and made it work.
These brackets would have to be about 4 inches longer to make an ideal fit for my situation of widely placed screws on the soundbar, and a narrow VESA pattern of 100*150

This dual wireless charger works great and charges faster than any of the other wireless chargers I'm using, even faster than the Samsung genuine wireless charger. I use it to charge my Galaxy Note 4 and my wifes Galaxy  S5 both of which have TPU cases wrapped over the charging receiver .  The only negative thing I can say about this item is the 110v converter that plugs into the wall sticks straight out of the walloutlet several inches and can be inadvertently kicked or walked into if it's in a high traffic area.
I have used several infrared receivers over the years but this one has a low mushy sound and using it to aid my tv hearing is not acceptable.

The current trend with ear buds is to boost the bass to the point of overpowering the rest of the sound profile. I don‚Äôt particularly like bass that is too heavy because it can give me awful headaches. These buds have the bass boosted but it is not over the top.

These ear buds are very lightweight and low profile. Smaller than many ear buds I have used they fit in my ears very comfortably. The silicone inserts are soft and do not cause any discomfort, but just as important they create a good seal in the ear canal and as a result they have good passive noise canceling (sound isolation). This is a good sign right out of the package - many ear buds I have tried do not seal properly.

The sound profile is the most important aspect of any earphones or ear buds. There are really three areas in the sound profile that merit mention - the highs, the mids and the bass. This set of buds is marketed as heavy bass and that is not completely true. Yes, they do have good bass, but it is not heavily overdriven like most. The bass is a little more front-and-center, not in-your-face, if that makes some sense. The mids are good and the music sounds full as a result, not hollow and depthless. The highs are very bright and clear which is a slight surprise - most ear buds that enhance the bass do so at the expense of the highs, so having a set that had strong bass and highs together is a very nice change of pace.

These buds come with a very small carrying case. It is a pinch case and has enough room for just the buds and the replacement silicone inserts. It is a soft plastic case and provides protection only from dirt and moisture (though by no means waterproof) so this is not a case that will help when the buds are crammed in a pocket or backpack.

This is a very nice set of ear buds at a very nice asking price. They have a very good sound profile and they are comfortable to wear. Keep these in mind when looking for inexpensive buds and good sound.

Disclaimer: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at no cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.

Works great! I got this for my son,because he has the plug in his truck that his cell can play his music through his truck speakers! He is extremely happy with this cord! It is very strong and durable! It works great and we are extremely happy with this product! I would definetly recommend and I would definetly buy again!

UPDATE 7/3/2012: When I wrote my initial review these headphones were selling for about $60. As of July 2012 they're now selling for $195. That's absurdly high for these headphones - they're not worth that much. I have no clue what has driven the change in price but unless the price resets to something a lot more reasonable then I suggest looking at other options. These are still good headphones; they're just not $195 headphone quality.

My original review follows.

---

In the lab where I work there are literally hundreds of computers running constantly so there is need for ANC headphones, especially if one wants to listen to music. The gear of choice in said lab is Bose but not everyone is willing to spend $300 for a set of good headphones. Philips offers these headphones which cost a fraction of most other ANC phones and work well enough to make them worthwhile.

Because Bose is considered the standard when it comes to ANC phones, I will use them as a reference point.

These headphones are a bit smaller than the Bose QC15's, and the way they lay on the ear can be mildly uncomfortable over time when one is used to larger headphones that completely cover the ear. Not everyone will have this problem, though. Some people find these phones to be perfectly acceptable and are content with the soft pads.

Sound quality is fine. I have a pair of Sennheisers that have better sound, but Sennheiser is known for their sound quality and are hard to beat. Then again, they tend to be expensive too. When considering the price differential, the quality of sound coming out of the Philips is very satisfying. Unlike Bose, the Philips phones do not overdrive the bass and they provide a more realistic sound.

These are noise canceling phones, and with a battery in them they do indeed actively cancel noise. It is not in the same league as Bose, but that is relative - the Bose cost nearly 10 times as much but the ANC is not 10 times better. Overall, Philips does an adequate job of canceling low-frequency noise, to the point that one can listen to music at lower volumes in a noisy environment like a plane. They don't completely knock out all the sound but they kill enough noise to make an appreciable difference.

I have only one complaint with these headphones - the cord is not detachable. It would be nice to use them strictly as ANC phones in the lab like the Bose, but unfortunately this is not an option.

For those on a more conservative budget or those that refuse to spend a premium for ANC headphones, Philips offers this set for a reasonable price that perform very well for their class. This is one of those weird cases when you actually get more than you pay for.

This Webcam works great for me. I draw and I also knit and crochet. I am hoping to be able to use this webcam to eventually do a podcast. I had so much fun working with it I almost forgot to give a review. Plug and play, easy to use!

The box comes with a camera with an attached USB cord and a small tripod. It also has a cleaning cloth and instructions. The camera has an attached camera cover. Also, there is a clamp attached to the camera and a light ring with two settings.

I have already recommended this Webcam to family and friends.

Great fit, sound quality, and app support. These earbuds are a little worse off in the ANC department, as I've tried the Elite Active 4's, and I feel like the bass is also a bit lacking. Still, they're great for working out, and they stay in your ears even while running, which is a plus! Would definitely recommend.
I keep coming back to these as the best for keeping my earbuds tangle free. People fall in love with mine, so I gift them and then buy more.

The sound quality is average at least and can be cranked up very loud. It is a fairly big/heavy unit unlike most of the portable speakers on the market. It is a party maker and also has the ability to charge other electronic devices with its oversized battery. I like it and would buy it again.

These headphones have amazing sound quality for the cost of the unit. I have many cheap headsets and these easily sound the best.

The headset is easy to use with a standard 3.5mm plug, in my case xbox controller but also usable across pc and other platforms.

There is a volume control that also has a mute button for the mic. The microphone also moves to multiple positions and will completely swing up out of the way.

I have recommended these to other people. All in all a great product

I bought to connect my audio speaker to my new vinyl record player. It does its job. 2 cables in the package, for two different speakers. If you are very picky about the audio quality it may not be your product, but that's not who I am. I don't have either a big audio system so I was not able to test its full quality. I'd buy it again for another compact system. the cables are only 6' long

Using meters, then a scope, the most I can get is 4milliamps, not 400, FOUR! Not sure what's up, but the output on this is nothing near what's claimed. Might return for replacement, see if there's maybe a QC issue or just a fluke, either way, it's not working for me as-is.

I had the opportunity to directly compare my review sample to the [[ASIN:B001EZYMF4 Sennheiser CX 300 II Precision Enhanced Bass Earbuds]], which is a highly regarded IEM (in ear monitor) in the same price range. This one actually sounded better to my ears although both were nearly identical in specifications.

This is my third Brainwavz phone model, and I have quickly come to regard this brand as a real contender in the market. I will not lie - I much prefer the [[ASIN:B00ENZRS76 Brainwavz HM9 Hi-Fi Noise Isolating Headphones]] model because I love over-the-hear style phones. However, this set of phones, at about a third of the cost, is also close in sound quality as the HM9. In fact, the bass in this one is much better than the HM9 (or the Sennheiser CX 300 II to which I am directly comparing these.)

For me comfort is everything because I listen to music much of my time. These are perfect for both pleasure listening where I sit back and enjoy the music for its own sake. These are also good enough for me to hear every nuance when I am transcribing or studying a track to learn. In that respect these phones are good enough for professional musicians, but I will admit that they would not be my first choice for plugging into a high-end sound system.

Since I spend more time listening to MP3 tracks than off vinyl these do the job since MP3 files lose some fidelity by their very nature. I will say, though, that these phones passed my basic test suite, which includes Miles Davis' [[ASIN:B00136JQMI Kind Of Blue]]. That is my reference model for sound because it contains high, mid and low frequency instruments that exercise any sound system. I listened to that album both from CD and from an MP3 file. Reproduction was superb.

Not only do these phones have respectable sound and comfort, the package is complete. They come with a zippered hard shell case, which protects the phones. However, they come with more extras that add to the value and provide versatility: a 1/4 adapter for plugging directly into standard headphone jacks, and an airplane adapter.

If you are in the market for mid-range IEMs give these serious consideration. In my opinion they are easily the equal of better known brands like the Sennheiser I mentioned and can be a better value if you need the extras that this set includes.

I like to listen to audio books as I go on bike rides, so I've been looking for a product like this. When I run I use over the ear headphones, but I can't fit those on over or under my cycling helmet. These sunglasses are a great solution. There are speakers underneath the arms that broadcast music almost directly into your ears. The effect is an open ear speaker system that allows you to hear your music, but also lets you stay mindful of ambient noises.

The sunglasses have enough of a tint to be comfortable, but not so much that they are impractical in low light. The arms rest easily on your ears and the nose piece is a solid bit of plastic that does not pinch the bridge of your nose. The glasses are very light even with the battery and speaker system.

The sunglasses connect to your cell phone via Bluetooth without any issues. There is a large power button on the right arm that is easy to locate by touch. I preferred these for comfort and for sound quality to ear buds. The sound quality is about what you'd expect for tiny speakers mounted to the arms of sunglasses. It's not concert hall quality, but it gets the job done, and it's better than a lot of other speakers on the market.

These sunglasses are great for athletes who like to listen to music while they're out exercising. Also included is a case, a bag, a lens cloth, and a charging cable.

I had high hopes for this product.  Originally, I purchased 2 to use with a Bluetooth transmitter for my TV.  However, poor latency of the transmitter squashed that plan and I decided to return 1 of the speakers along with the transmitter.  But, when I linked it to my phone and listened to a number of tunes that sound and play well with headphones, the sound was terrible.  Virtually everything I played sounded "muddy".  I tried adjusting the sound with the equalizer in my audio player (MediaMonkey) and it didn't help much.  I even downloaded the speaker's app and that didn't help either.  I made sure the bass boost was off when doing all of this, so that wasn't the cause.  To make matters worse, while playing many of the songs I head only one channel - the other was extremely faint.  And on one instance, a song that wasn't very bass heavy actually made the speaker "rattle".  I'll probably return this speaker also.  It's too bad.  I was considering buying a few for Xmas gifts this year.

I really like this headphone headset because I forget that I'm wearing it. It fits snug, but with light soft rubber that wraps around your ears and the back of your head. I love it for running because all the 'in ear' devises get too sweaty for in the ears. This rest outside of you front earlobe by your face. You also can actually use this for lap swimming too. It stays in place and there is nothing to fall out of your ears and no wires.

To Use: Easy download of your playlist.

Trust you found this review honest and helpful:-)

This product came on time and was packaged with other items.

Pros: Setup was easy! Extended range on my Bluetooth headphones.

Cons: Only gained 20 feet. Was hoping to be able to extend to a toss my house (50 ft.)

Overall this is a functional Bluetooth extender, but doesn‚Äôt extend to the range that was advertised. Go for a higher quality item and skip this one.

Of the three main GPS receiver manufacturers - Garmin, TomTom and Magellan - I have had the most success with TomTom devices. My first GPS was a TomTom and it served me well for years until the map outgrew the memory. I was excited to have the opportunity to try this one; so far, it has been a good unit, though I do not care for the menu system.

This is a larger unit than the original one I had, upgrading from a 4.3" to a 6". I like the screen real estate. For all that screen space, TomTom has made good use of it, maximizing the visible map and keeping the interface clean and uncluttered. One area where I am slightly disappointed, though, is in the speed display which is a little small - it's good to keep it out of the way but it's a little smaller than I like and it a bit harder to read. If you use your GPS for watching your speed, this could be a problem.

Navigation is easy. I like the way this unit routes me to my destination yet does not nag me when I go off the chosen route. Others I have used (including my old TomTom) would badger me to make a U-turn for a while before deciding that there was another way to get where I was going. This unit does make that point sometimes, but it also is smart enough to reroute when I have multiple similar routes.

The biggest plus for this unit (and it seems to be a TomTom thing) is that the voice very clearly enunciates without distortion or the unit buzzing. I have had this issue with every other unit of every other brand, but my old TomTom was clear and understandible even at higher volumes. Since this one is the same, I believe TomTom has a better understanding of how to build a unit that sounds right.

Navigating from work to home is usually a straight shot down the interstate for 40+ miles and a little bit of backroads. To test, I instead took a long, out-of-the-way route that I use when there is heavy traffic volume. Knowing it would try to put me on the interstate, I set the farthest point as a first leg, then set it to take me home from there. The route it chose was actually only slightly different than the one I had chosen already, and the difference was that I accounted for rush hour traffic.

Speaking of traffic... This unit gathers traffic data without relying on mobile data. I greatly prefer this to having to run an app on my phone and letting it gather traffic info from online. So far I have not had it report a reroute due to traffic; I will come back here and update when it does.

The main complaint I have about this GPS is the menu system. WIth TomTom's older units, the menu system was fairly traditional and was smiliar to that of a PC application menu system (sorta). The new interface has a scrolling row of icons that lead to more icons. I am not a fan of this type of interface and is the one thing I would change about this unit if I could.

When this unit is first powered on and set up it downloads a hefty amount of data to update the map. This is unavoidable, unfortunately. Do not be discouraged by this - it will be up to date and ready to go when it finishes.

I have not had any real issues with this unit so far. It works well and I like how it navigates. I don't like the menu system and find it very awkward, but it gets me where I want to go with little fuss.

This is the 3rd pair I have owned , as good as ant 200 headphones, eventually the battery life get to short to use ....but I use every day and they last 6-8 months ..so for 40 bucks they are more than worth it
Perfect! Exactly what I needed. Great price. Super fast delivery.  Using this to connect my Bose mini link speaker and laptop.

These headphones were good for a while- they held their charge like they were supposed to in the beginning and they worked really well. Great sound and mic quality- especially for being on the cheaper end of Bluetooth headphones. Though, after a couple of weeks of use, the left headphone specifically would altogether stop charging. I would be able to have it on for maybe 2-8 minutes, then it would notify me that it was at low battery. I'm not exactly sure what happened here, but the left headphone because practically useless. I was able to return them though and got a full refund. I'm sad they didn't work out- they were really cute headphones!

these stands do not fit with a 5.1 vizio system as advertised.  do not buy these for this system.  Someone should make this right and provide a partial refund since they do not attach to the back and match up for my speakers. Please fix your listings for the correct products.  thank you.

I've pretty much hated these headphones since I got them. They pinch my ears and the battery doesn't last but maybe 4 hours or so. I used them because I had them...but just now (only 4 months after purchase) They've started turning the volume all the way down on their own randomly. It's very annoying. If a button is catching, I can't figure out where. I just gave up and bought a new, different pair to use.

the screen protector worked poorly. Too many bubbles that couldn't be removed. I finally gave up and took it off. I like the padded case though,it really comes in handy for storing the items. the wall charger works great. Don't know exactly how long it takes to fully charge, but doesn't seem to take more than an hour or two.the  hdmi to hdmi cable for the tv to kindle didn't work and I tried to get it replaced but Digital was of no help at all. I like the cover viewing stand but wish it had an opening for the charging cable when closed, might cut one in it myself. the styless works great and is very comfortable to use.The small bag isn't worth much and the fish bone is completely useless. The earbuds worked alright though. Except for Digitals' bad customer service , which Amazon corrected I probably still would buy though.

Update: After less than 60 days of owning the TV, the ENTIRE audio panel died. None of the external audio ports work anymore for no reason whatsoever. Worked fine, then boom just stopped working. Thought it was my soundbar, so I bought a new soundbar, but nope, soundbar works just fine when connected to the cable box. Amazon Prime was awesome in helping me return it, and I'll be picking up a more reliable brand. When it came time to purchase a new TV we approached it the same way we approached buying a house. We made a list of the features we wanted (a SmartTV with Wifi, streaming channels, Amazon Prime, 40‚Äù and affordable at around the $250 mark). After looking at our options in terms of price and convenience, we decided that it made the most sense to purchase it through Amazon Prime.

After much research, we decided that the TCL TV‚Äôs offered the best value, met our budget requirements, and our decision to purchase the TV through Amazon enabled us to purchase the TV with interest free financing over 6 months.
Appearance.
The TV came in a large box with the stand hardware: remote, power cable and batteries plus simple instructions that were in separate bags. You do not get a HDMI or any other cables. The TV has a simple non-fussy design with approximately half inch bezel all around. The stand that comes with it is simple and screws on with two screws at each side. The stand footprint requires about 8.5 inches of depth to stand on. I like that the stand is low profile raising the screen about 2‚Äù above the surface it is standing on.

Setup

The old analog phono inputs are on the back and quite hard to reach once the TV is up on the mantle and they protrude straight out the back which would require more space between the wall and the TV if you use them. The power cable plugs into a recessed area low down on the left side and doesn‚Äôt interfere with the location of the tv. All the modern input and output sockets are behind the screen on the right side about 8 inches back. We don‚Äôt use any subscription TV service; just a double bowtie antenna mounted on one of the gutter pipes at the back of the house. The coaxial input for the antenna along with three HDMI ports, an optical input, 3.5mm jack and USB socket are all here. We use two of the HDMI sockets one for the 1TB Media hub and the other for our notebook.

Once everything is plugged in and turned on. The TV introduces you to the basic setup process. It takes less than five minutes to find your way around. The remote is minimalist with the most basic controls on the front (Volume Up/Down toggle and mute buttons on the side). It‚Äôs small, unfussy and easy to use. The UI for the TV is not flashy but functional and easy to navigate. Setting up WIFI, registering your TV and introducing you to streaming channels and how to add them to your desktop are covered quickly and then you are left to your own devices.

Since we are just using an antenna we were initially a little apprehensive. Wondering how well that would work, or even if the TV had a tuner since everyone seems to use dish or cable these days. It has a tuner that works flawlessly. We managed to pick up almost 3 dozen channels many of them HD. A quick look online showed us a map of where the broadcast towers are and helped us aim our antenna for best reception.

In use.

The TV has a really nice clean picture and since it is an LED TV where a grid array of LED's light the screen uniformly rather than a couple of fluorescent lamps there is practically no limit to the viewing angle. The screen is not high gloss and prevents reflection and most glare from bright light sources. When turned on a non invasive 3‚Äù horizontal strip of illuminated plastic at the bottom shows you the TV is powered on. It flashes during startup and goes out when the screen is illuminated.

Image

Image quality is excellent BUT on initial setup it is on a bright echo setting. Which is very high contrast and overly saturated. I guess it is a power saving mode (claimed 16 watts) but it is a bit stark and overwhelming and shows some dithering on smooth color transitions as though it is running at a lower bitrate with fewer colors. When turned to theater mode the quality of the picture is MUCH better with very smooth transitions on subtle colour gradients.

Sound

Sound is similar. Like most LCD style TV‚Äôs this one comes with tiny speakers. Again the default sound setting seems to be very flat. Probably to conserve energy. There are about four presets and again we went with theater which gives the broadest range and warm midtones without overdoing the bass. It doesn‚Äôt sound too bad and is not thin and reedy like the default setting.

Smart TV functionality.

We originally wanted WIFI because as Amazon Prime members we get a lot of free on demand media. This is similar to Netflix where you can watch a huge catalog of TV and movies for free, buy or rent them for a small fee. The same goes with music. This worked perfectly.

What we weren‚Äôt expecting was the sheer volume of streaming media available for free via WIFI. There are hundreds of channels, many of them free to choose from, many mainstream ones that let you view their current episodes of popular shows on demand when you want to watch them. You can also sign up for pay for view services like HBO and showtime individually.

One nice thing is that the TV has a global search option. You can search for anything by title, director, actors name, character, keywords and the TV will find everything relating to your search and list what is available by channel. So you can easily pick out what you want to see.

Mobile devices and streaming from those devices

There are apps for Android and iOS as well as Windows. I was able to control the TV from all our devices. In many ways it is more responsive, especially if you need to type in text. If you have media on your PC there are Apps for the TV that will let you stream from your phone, notebook, desktop computer etc.

Streaming from those devices tends to work ok. I did find that the TV‚Äôs built-in media player was a little limited in supported data formats. Setting up our digital media hub with its own channel was very easy and luckily our Western Digital media hub has far more extensive support for many of the more exotic file formats like FLAC lossless digital audio. And other formats are more often limited to computers. The TV does support the more mainstream formats like mp3, mpg, jpg etc.

Conclusion

For us, this TV proved to be a very good and affordable purchase. Especially when you factor in the 6 months interest fee financing Amazon offers prime members. We did sign up for a free month of Netflix too. The remote has a dedicated Netflix and Amazon streaming button. But we were not that impressed with Netflix when our Amazon Prime membership offered all the same features and more thanks to the addition of Amazon Prime music.

When you combine all this TV‚Äôs features with our media hub and Amazon Prime we are a bit overwhelmed with the sheer amount of stuff out there to watch. Even if we had no antenna and just a WIFI internet connection. The vast number of free streaming HD channels is extensive making the need for TV subscription plans pretty much obsolete unless you have a very specific need.

We really like this TV and highly recommend it.

This Bluetooth speaker came well packaged and on time.

Pros: Great sound from a small speaker. Easy to setup. And connect to all my Bluetooth devices.

Cons: It has a very musk-y smell. Like it was manufactured in a barn or farm yard. (I know what this smells like considering where I live.) (-2 stars) Very overpowering.

Overall I had to Fabreze It, before using it do to the barnyard smell. Once you get past the smell, it does have a pretty good sound from a small speaker. It has a 5 hour battery life. It also warns you to not use it in a humid area, or to get it wet so be advised. If you are looking for one that is water proof i would recommend a JBL one. With the smell, I can‚Äôt recommend this.

This is a great way to use HDMI devices on TVs that have no spare HDMI ports or are not equipped with one. I tested the review sample that I received on a 2008 Sanyo TV that came equipped with two HDMI ports that I quickly occupied with a Roku and a Chromecast, and with a 2011 model Samsung. Both displayed the transformed signal from this box beautifully.

It has come excellent features like the array of color encoding schemes and outputting either the most common PAL and NTSC ones with the flip of a switch. I also love that this is powered via USB, which one of my TVs as, so it's one less wall wart.

Do be aware that this only converts in one direction: HDMI in (from Blu-Ray players, etc) to composite out via RCA jacks on a TV or monitor. I tested this going the other direction - RCA to HDMI - and it did not work. Of course it was not advertised as such, but I felt compelled to try anyway. I would love it if I could flip a switch and change directions of the signal transformation because I could then connect my old VHS player to an HDMI port on my TV.

Regardless of my personal wishes, this does exactly what it claims with no problems or issues, and that merits five stars according to how I rate.

As described in description. Easy to use and comfy sleep headphones. Battery life is excellent was able to listen to my meditation music for 8 hrs. Woke up and the headphones still had a charge. I would recommend these sleep headphones.
Premium speaker wire. I really like it.

First off, I am not an audiophile. This is a review from a simple person who wanted music at work.

I am a Rural Carrier for the United Stated Postal Service. I deliver mail in an LLV truck and these vehicles are basically mobile tin cans. Every panel rattles, making for quite an unpleasant environment, audio wise. I tried playing music directly off my phone, but alas my speakerphone is only so loud and is constantly drowned out by the LLV.

So, I researched Bluetooth speakers and, based on the reviews and popularity, recently purchased two:
-[[ASIN:B016XTADG2 Anker SoundCore Bluetooth Speaker with 24-Hour Playtime, 66-Foot Bluetooth Range & Built-in Mic, Dual-Driver Portable Wireless Speaker with Low Harmonic Distortion and Superior Sound - Black]]
-[[ASIN:B01LZV6TYQ OontZ Angle 3 PLUS Splashproof Bluetooth Speaker - Designed & Engineered by Cambridge SoundWorks for Richer Bass, HD Sound, and 30-Hour Playtime, 10W+ Power, Water Resistant, Portable Wireless Speaker]]

The Anker SoundCore is being returned while I am keeping the OontZ Angle 3 Plus and here is why.

I tested both speakers in my home at first. My very first impression, out of the box:
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - was nice to touch and just felt solid and very well built.
Anker SoundCore - just felt like a simple lightweight brick. It really didn't give the impression of longevity or durability.

The set-up guides were quite different from each other.
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - Extremely easy to read, follow and understand (remember, I am not a music nut lol. This was my first time ever using a Bluetooth speaker and was in completely uncharted territory.) It was all in English, and only English and the diagrams were detailed and made the entire set-up process seamless and carefree.
Anker SoundCore - This guide was very hard to follow. It is printed in darn near every language, in tiny print and the diagrams were quite small as well. I ultimately did get the speaker paired with my phone and figured out what buttons did what, but it took nearly 15 minutes to do so.

Bluetooth Pairing
With both speakers and my phone lined up on a table (well within the proximity specified in each set-up guide), both speakers paired, however:
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - MUCH faster in pairing (mere seconds!).
Anker SoundCore - took nearly two minutes to complete the pairing process.

Pause/Play Button
Since I dismount to deliver packages to a customer's door routinely on my route, I really need to have a simply way to pause my music. I really like how both speakers offer this function on directly on the units, saving me from having to handle my phone.
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - I barely press the Play/Pause button and the speaker immediately reacts. There is NO hesitation.
Anker SoundCore - I press the Play/Pause button and there is a delay of about 5 seconds.. just long enough to make me think I didn't press hard enough and reach to do it again only for the speaker to finally react.

Volume/Overall Playback Quality
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - Wow. Just wow. It is truly unbelievable to hear such full sound, and bass(!), coming from such a small unit. I found myself perfectly pleased with the output without ever reaching max volume on the speaker itself. So I am looking forward to how well it will work in my LLV during my first road test. As for now, I am thoroughly impressed!
Anker SoundCore - I maxed out the volume on my phone and the speaker and was just not impressed. If I could guess, I'd say the max output this speaker achieved was only about 25% more than my speakerphone alone (while the OontZ Angle 3 Plus blew it out of the water with close to double, if not more, output than my speakerphone alone).
I also noted some kind of distortion or interference type background sound with the Anker SoundCore at mid volume and above.

Speakerphone/Mic
I was able to answer an incoming phone call on both units as described in each set-up guide. The quality of in-call sound on each speaker differed:
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - My husband's (the caller) voice was crisp and clear, as if he was sitting talking right next to me. There was no distortion or feedback out of the speaker. Husband reported nothing but a clear voice on his phone.
Anker SoundCore - Husband's voice was clear, but echoed horribly. No matter what volume level I used. There was no distortion (I was expecting this given the distortion with the music playback) bu the continuous echoing is a major issue for me. Husband reported a slight "faded" type of echo on his phone.

Road Test (in my LLV)
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - The sound is amazing in the truck! Thinking I would need it, I maxed the volume on both the speaker and my phone then pressed play on my music. Well, I certainly don't need max volume. I reduced the volume on both the speaker and my phone and found a very happy medium output. This speaker performs perfectly in the loud, rattling setting of a USPS LLV.. even while bouncing down rural dirt two tracks and washboard gravel roads. I am extremely pleased with this tiny speaker.
Anker Soundcore - Even with maxed volume settings, I could not get this speaker to perform anywhere near as well as the OontZ Angle 3 Plus. It had volume and was loud enough to hear over the vehicle's own noise, however the distortion/interference mentioned earlier was still present and in the truck during the road test it had what I would describe as an echoing effect on the music, specifically the singers' voices. It just wasn't clear. (I hope that makes sense.)

Battery Life/Listen While Charging
OontZ Angle 3 Plus - So far, the battery life is impressive. After receiving it, I charged it overnight (as recommended). I then had it connected to my phone for about an hour of home testing. Turned it off and I next used it at work on a Saturday.. had it powered on and connected to my phone and actively playing music for about 5.5 hours. I then used it again on Monday (much longer and busier days in the USPS, FYI).. had it on, connected and active continuously for nearly 9 hours. I have yet to see the low battery light come on. I plan to see just how many days of work I can get out of a single charge.
Anker Soundcore - I have no information for this section on this speaker since I am returning it.

Exterior/Cleaning
At first, I had the OontZ Angle 3 Plus setting on the dashboard of the LLV. This didn't last more than two stops. Despite having the four rubber "feet", the speaker still slid around causing more of a distraction than I would like. I ended up setting it on top of my personal bag, in a bin by my feet with the speaker facing up. This move really helped my piece of mind, knowing it will not go anywhere. This speaker has a soft rubber exterior. It is quite nice and feels luxurious, however... this exterior attracts all dust particles within 50 feet! USPS LLVs are *not* known for being the cleanest and even though I moved the speaker from the dust-ridden dashboard to a bin, it was still slathered with dust and dirt by the end of my route. I figured it was a fair trade, sacrificing the appearance for the gain of having decent music. But.. I got home and went to clean it. I will tell you, my expectations of this working were very low. I didn't think the dust would come off that supple rubber. But with a wet paper towel and a few slow wipes, it did. So, it can be cleaned up!

Case
I did purchase the case for this speaker ([[ASIN:B01NBDY6VP [Official] OontZ Angle 3 Plus Bluetooth Portable Speaker Carry Case, Neoprene with Aluminum Carabiner, reinforced zipper, by Cambridge SoundWorks [NOT FOR OontZ Angle 3]]]). I was mainly wanting a safe way to transport and store the speaker, but after reading the other reviews I was hoping I would be able to keep it clean in the case and still enjoy my music on my route. I received the case and used it yesterday. The case is extremely nice and I appreciate the interior mesh pocket. I have no need for it now, but I'm sure it will come in handy if I ever take this speaker on vacation and need to take the charging cables along. As for playback while in the case? Yeah, it was terribly muffled. It didn't work for me as it apparently has for others. Yet, the case itself is exactly what I was wanting for taking it to and from work. It is not as thickly padded as I would have expected, however it does protect the speaker.

Overall, for my specific purpose and intended use for a Bluetooth speaker, the Anker SoundCore simply won't cut it. However, it is still a nice speaker and will perhaps fit your needs perfectly. After all, most people don't drive LLVs and have the same high demands that go along with that. For me, the OontZ Angle 3 Plus is what I'll be bopping down the road to, mailbox to mailbox.

Happy hunting! Hope this review helps you out!

I selected this mouse with the thought that it would be a good travel mouse. I like the feature set, specifically the ability to recharge the mouse instead of replacing the batteries. So far, I have had no issues with this mouse. In the price range, it‚Äôs a good one.

Wow, these inexpensive fitness tracker watches have really come a long way! I've used WearOS, Fitbit, Galaxy and Amazfit brand watches, and usually find the cheap ones are cute for my kids but not very accurate or full of mostly gimmicky features.
This one actually looks and acts a lot like a cheaper version of my current Amazfit GTS3 watch. The way the menu works, the way the app works... it's all very familiar. Granted, this watch does not have the high resolution OLED display that my Amazfit does, but the display is capable of vivid colors and looks great!

The accuracy is surprisingly spot on, I even tested my heart rate with this and other smartwatches I own since usually there's a lot of discrepancy, and it often lined up exactly. Steps were interesting- most smartwatches don't count steps unless you move for more than a few steps at a time (disregarding a step here or there as an error). This one goes a step further and actually refused to count steps I made unless I was WEARING THE WATCH! I'm not sure if this is a attempt to prevent cheaters from shaking their watch or something, but I noticed it would not count any of my steps when I held it in my fingers, but when I put it on my wrist, it counted! Perhaps there is a proximity sensor on the back of the watch, I'm not sure. This might be a problem for those who occasionally put the watch in a pocket or something to get steps if, for example, pushing a shopping cart (since your wrist doesn't move, pushing strollers and carts tend to not count anyway- one workaround is to put the watch in a pocket but that might not work now).

Another thing I wish it had is a better notification system. Certain apps which aren't in their list of known notifications won't work correctly (Google Voice, for example). But that's true of all cheap tracker watches. It also can't install apps or extend functionality like the more expensive ones. There is definitely a reason my regular watch costs 5-6x as much as this one, but for what it is on a budget, honestly, it's pretty amazing!

THE GOOD:
--------------
* Wide ranging output from 15v to 20v. Take a look at your power adapter to see what the voltage is. If it falls in this range, you should be good. We're using this for my son's HP laptop. The original brick is still good, we just don't want to unplug it every time he wants to take the laptop to a friends house.
* A plethora of connecting tips. They are universal. So if your notebook uses 19v, then the 19v tip here will be compatible.
* On each tip, if you examine closely, the voltage is stamped on it. I took a close up picture to show this.

THE BAD:
------------
* Nothing at all. Gets the job done! 5-Stars.

Prior to this I was using a traditional lap desk with a padded base which worked but each time I moved it shifted everything on the desk‚Äôs surface. This product fit what I needed perfectly.

The table is completely adjustable in height and tilt, allowing for it to be used whether seated or while laying down. Having the ability to easily raise and lower the legs makes it where you can always have the surface where you need it and allow for adequate clearance beneath.

The surface provides plenty of space for both my laptop and mouse without feeling cramped.

Having the built in fan is a great addition as it helps keep my laptop cool without my needing to move my laptop fan base from my normal workstation.

This has been the perfect laptop desk for working away from my workstation whether I‚Äôm sat on the couch or laying in bed. During these COVID days, like many, I‚Äôm working all over the place so it‚Äôs nice having tools that make that a bit easier.
